Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-23 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html)\nState / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 22 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 31 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 7 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 6 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 43 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 5 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 3 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 215 / 9 - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 39 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 41 / 0\nTotal 555 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ribavirin inhibits Zika virus.\nDate: 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Antiviral Research journal (edited)\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166354217301973) \nref: Kamiyama N, Soma R, Hidano S, et al. Ribavirin inhibits Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) replication in vitro and suppresses viremia in\nZIKV-infected STAT1-deficient mice. Antiviral Res. 2017; 146: 1-11.\ndoi: 10.1016/j.antiviral.2017.08.007\n-\nHighlights\n- Ribavirin inhibits ZIKV replication in mammalian cells.\n- Ribavirin prevents ZIKV-induced apoptosis and cell death.\n- Ribavirin administration abrogates viremia in ZIKV-infected\nSTAT1-deficient mice.\n- Leading to a prolonged survival.\nAbstract\nZika fever, a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Zika virus\n(ZIKV), is an epidemic disease for which no effective therapy has been\nestablished. The recent outbreaks of ZIKV in Brazil and French\nPolynesia have been linked to a considerable increase in the incidence\nof fetal microcephaly and other diseases such as Guillain-Barre\nsyndrome. Because there is currently no specific therapy or vaccine,\nthe early exploitation of a method to prevent expansion of ZIKV is a\nhigh priority. To validate commonly used antiviral drugs, we evaluated\nthe effect of ribavirin, a drug used to treat hepatitis C with\ninterferon-beta (IFN-beta), on ZIKV replication. In mammalian cells,\nwe observed an inhibitory effect of ribavirin on ZIKV replication and\nZIKV-induced cell death without cytotoxic effect. Furthermore, we\nfound that STAT1-deficient mice, which lack type I IFN signaling, were\nhighly sensitive to ZIKV infection and exhibited lethal outcome.\nRibavirin abrogated viremia in ZIKV-infected STAT-1-deficient mice.\nThese data suggest that the inhibition of viral RNA-dependent RNA\npolymerases may be effective for treatment of ZIKV infection. Our data\nprovide a new insight into the mechanisms for inhibition of ZIKV\nreplication and prevention of Zika fever. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It will be interesting to see if these encouraging results showing\ninhibition of Zika virus replication can be replicated in non-human\nprimates. The challenge for use of drugs to inhibit Zika virus\ninfection in humans is that most (around 80 percent) Zika virus\ninfections are asymptomatic or have very mild symptoms. These\nindividuals will probably not seek medical treatment, even though\ntheir fetuses are at risk of infection with teratogenic effects. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Zika virus skewed immunosuppression.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Microbiology journal (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/articles/s41564-017-0016-3) \nref: Foo SS, Chen W, Chan Y, et al. Asian Zika virus strains target\nCD14+ blood monocytes and induce M2-skewed immunosuppression during\npregnancy. Nat Microbiol. 2017. doi: 10.1038/s41564-017-0016-3\n-\nAbstract\nBlood CD14+ monocytes are frontline immunomodulators categorized into\nclassical, intermediate or non-classical subsets, and subsequently\ndifferentiated into M1 pro- or M2 anti-inflammatory macrophages on\nstimulation. Although the Zika virus (ZIKV) rapidly establishes\nviraemia, the target cells and immune responses, particularly during\npregnancy, remain elusive. Furthermore, it is unknown whether African-\nand Asian-lineage ZIKV have different phenotypic impacts on host\nimmune responses. Using human blood infection, we identified CD14+\nmonocytes as the primary target for African- or Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection. When immunoprofiles of human blood infected with ZIKV were\ncompared, a classical/intermediate monocyte-mediated M1-skewed\ninflammation by the African-lineage ZIKV infection was observed, in\ncontrast to a non-classical monocyte-mediated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression by the Asian-lineage ZIKV infection. Importantly,\ninfection of the blood of pregnant women revealed an enhanced\nsusceptibility to ZIKV infection. Specifically, Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection of pregnant women's blood led to an exacerbated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression of non-classical monocytes in conjunction with a\nglobal suppression of type I interferon-signaling pathway and an\naberrant expression of host genes associated with pregnancy\ncomplications. Also, 30 ZIKV+ sera from symptomatic pregnant patients\nshowed elevated levels of M2-skewed immunosuppressive cytokines and\npregnancy-complication-associated fibronectin-1. This study\ndemonstrates the differential immunomodulatory responses of blood\nmonocytes, particularly during pregnancy, on infection with different\nlineages of ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Virus alters mosquito genes.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: bioRxiv journal (edited)\n(http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/08/22/179416) \nref: Etebari K, Hegde S, Saldana MA, et al. Global transcriptome\nanalysis of _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to Zika virus\ninfection. bioRxiv 179416; doi:10.1101/179416\n-\nZika virus (ZIKV) of the Flaviviridae family is a recently emerged\nmosquito-borne virus that has been implicated in the surge of the\nnumber of microcephaly instances in South America. The recent rapid\nspread of the virus led to its declaration as a global health\nemergency by the World Health Organization. The virus is transmitted\nmainly by the mosquito _Aedes aegypti_ that also vectors dengue virus,\nhowever little is known about the interactions of the virus with the\nmosquito vector. In this study, we investigated the transcriptome\nprofiles of whole _Ae. aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to ZIKV\ninfection at 2, 7, and 14 days post-infection using RNA-Seq. Results\nshowed changes in the abundance of a large number of transcripts at\neach time point following infection, with 18 transcripts commonly\nchanged among the 3 time points. Gene ontology analysis revealed that\nmost of the altered genes are involved in metabolic process, cellular\nprocess and proteolysis. In addition, 486 long intergenic non-coding\nRNAs were identified altered upon ZIKV infection. Further, we found\ncorrelational changes of a number of potential mRNA target genes with\nthat of altered host microRNAs. The outcomes provide a basic\nunderstanding of _Ae. aegypti_ responses to ZIKV and helps to\ndetermine host factors involved in replication or mosquito host\nanti-viral response against the virus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Mosquito vector competence depends on the relationship of virus and\nthe mosquito, and the defenses that the mosquito can mobilize against\nthe virus infection. Studies, such as the one above, can document the\nchanges that occur when the virus infects the mosquito, and if\ndifferences in relative vector efficiency of different geographic\nstrains of this mosquito might be related to alternations in mosquito\ngenes when infected. It would be interesting to know if these gene\nchanges affect fitness, and especially longevity of infected\nmosquitoes. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Virus effects on sperm, body fluids.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Lancet Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30444-9/abstract) \nref: Joguet G, Mansuy JM, Matusali G, et al. Effect of acute Zika\nvirus infection on sperm and virus clearance in body fluids: a\nprospective observational study. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii:\nS1473-3099(17)30444-9. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30444-9\n-\nSummary\nBackground\nEvidence of human sexual transmission during Zika virus emergence is a\nmatter of concern, particularly in procreation, but to date, kinetics\nof seminal shedding and the effects of infection on human reproductive\nfunction have not been described. To investigate the effects of Zika\nvirus infection on semen and clearance of Zika virus from semen and\nbody fluids, we aimed to study a cohort of Zika virus-infected men. Methods\nThis prospective observational study recruited men presenting with\nacute Zika virus infection at Pointe-Ã -Pitre University Hospital in\nGuadeloupe, French Caribbean, where a Zika virus outbreak occurred\nbetween April and November, 2016. Blood, urine, and semen were\ncollected at days 7, 11, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 after symptom onset,\nand semen characteristics, such as total sperm count, sperm motility,\nvitality, and morphology, and reproductive hormone concentrations,\nsuch as testosterone, inhibin, follicle-stimulating hormone, and\nluteinising hormone, were assessed. At days 7, 11, and 20, semen was\nprocessed to isolate motile spermatozoa. Zika virus RNA was detected\nby RT-PCR using whole blood, serum, urine, seminal plasma, semen\ncells, and motile spermatozoa fractions. Zika virus was isolated from\ndifferent sperm fractions on Vero E6 cultures. Findings\n15 male volunteers (mean age 35 years SD 5; range 25-44) with acute\nZika virus infection and positive Zika virus RNA detection in blood or\nurine were enrolled. Total sperm count was decreased from median\n119âÃâ10^6 spermatozoa (IQR interquartile range 22-234)\nat day 7, to 45.2âÃâ10^6 (16.5-89.6) at day 30, and 70\nÃ 10^6 (28.5-81.4) at day 60, respectively, after Zika virus\ninfection. Inhibin values increased from 93.5 pg/mL (IQR 55-162) at\nday 7 to 150 pg/mL (78-209) at day 120 when total sperm count\nrecovered. In motile spermatozoa obtained after density gradient\nseparation, Zika virus RNA was found in 3 of 14 patients at day 7, 4\nof 15 at day 11, and 4 of 15 at day 20, and replication-competent\nvirus was found in the tested patient. Seminal shedding kinetics\nseemed heterogeneous among patients. Whole blood was the fluid most\nfrequently positive for Zika virus RNA (62 of 92 samples) and 3\npatients remained positive at day 120. Interpretation\nSemen alterations early after acute Zika virus infection might affect\nfertility and could be explained by virus effects on the testis and\nepididymis. Frequency of shedding and high viral load in semen,\ntogether with the presence of replicative virus in a motile\nspermatozoa fraction, can lead to Zika virus transmission during\nsexual contact and assisted reproduction procedures. Whole blood seems\nto be the best specimen for Zika virus RNA detection, diagnosis, and\nfollow-up. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall In a new study that included 12 men in French Guiana who had Zika\nvirus, 4 never had any detectable Zika in their semen, 1 excreted Zika\nvirus in his semen for at least 3 days, and 7 had Zika virus in semen\nfor at least 1 month. The maximum duration of detectable Zika in semen\nin the study was 45 days ((http://tinyurl.com/y9nhtgtk)). This report\nwas provided by Roland HÃ¼bner. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Vaccine update.\nDate: 22/29 Aug 2017.\nSource: Journal of the American Medical Association, JAMA (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2649168) \nref: Lyon J. Vaccines protect fetus from Zika. JAMA. 2017; 318(8):\n689. doi:10.1001/jama.2017.11200\n-\nResearchers funded in part by the National Institutes of Health have\nrecently demonstrated that 2 experimental vaccines can restrict\ntransmission of Zika virus from pregnant mice to their fetuses,\nthereby shielding offspring from congenital damage or death. Multiple candidate Zika vaccines have been shown protective against\ninfection with the virus in animal studies, with several now in human\ntrials, but none were tested in the context of pregnancy, according to\nthe authors of the study published in Cell\n(http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(17)30759-6). The 2\nvaccine candidates investigated in the new study are the 1st to\ndemonstrate efficacy in preventing vertical transmission of the virus\nand related fetal death in an animal model. Although the vaccines were\nadministered to female mice prior to pregnancy, the result is\nconsidered an important step toward developing a vaccine that could be\nsafely given to pregnant women. One of the 2 candidates is a modified messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine\nencoding Zika genes, developed by the biotechnology company Moderna.\nIt is already in safety trials in women who are not pregnant. The\nother is a live-attenuated Zika strain developed by researchers at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB). The testing was carried out by scientists from the National Institute\nof Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Washington University School of\nMedicine, and UTMB. The researchers 1st vaccinated the mice with 1 of\nthe vaccines or a placebo. After mating, the animals were challenged\nwith the virus 6 days into pregnancy. A week later, more than 50\npercent of placentas and fetuses from mice administered the mRNA\nvaccine had virtually no Zika RNA. The remainder had \"substantially\nlower\" levels relative to placebo.\nThe live vaccine provided broader protection: 78 percent of placentas\nand 83 percent of fetuses had Zika RNA at or below the level of\ndetection, while the placebo group exhibited significantly higher\nlevels of placental and fetal Zika RNA. Mice vaccinated with either\nvaccine had significantly higher rates of fetal viability; whereas 100\npercent of fetuses from mice vaccinated with the mRNA vaccine were\nborn, none survived to term in the placebo group. A working group funded by the Wellcome Trust recently approved ethical\nguidelines for testing such vaccines in pregnant women, normally\nexcluded from drug trials. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It is reassuring to learn that at least 2 vaccines are now entering\nclinical trials in women. Although anti-Zika virus drugs are under\ndevelopment, preventing infection through vaccination seems to be the\nmost effective measure to prevent fetal infection and adverse effects\nof the virus infection in adults. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"297":{"title":"Dengue/DHF update (11): Americas","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Dengue/DHF update (11): Americas","summary":"\nDENGUE/DHF UPDATE (11): AMERICAS\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nCases in various countries:\nAmericas regional\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. (conf.) 368 cases; Provinces most\naffected: Tumbes (84 cases), La Cruz y Zarumilla.\n(http://larepublica.pe/sociedad/892895-tumbes-certifican-368-casos-de-dengue-93-casos-de-chikungunya-y-106-de-leptospirosis)\n. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Bosnia and Herzegovina":{},"Botswana":{},"Brazil":{"36":{"title":"Glanders, equine - USA: (FL) ex Europe sporting events\r\n\t","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Glanders, equine - USA: (FL) ex Europe sporting events\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 17 Aug 2017. Source: The Horse (edited) (http://www.thehorse.com/articles/39562/dressage-horse-detained-after-positive-glanders-test)   An American dressage horse returning to the United States after a competition tour in Europe has tested positive for Glanders. Shipped from Amsterdam to Miami after participating in Sweden and UK  An American dressage horse returning to the United States after a competition tour in Europe could be euthanized or shipped back out of the country after testing positive for glanders during routine USDA equine import quarantine.  Glanders is a highly contagious upper respiratory disease that can be passed from horse-to-horse as well as to human handlers. Acute clinical signs include fever; cough; difficulty breathing; nasal discharge; swollen and painful submaxillary lymph nodes (the \"glands\" in \"glanders\"); rapidly spreading ulcers on the nasal mucosa, nodules, and chronic abscesses; and small abscesses in the lung and/or abscesses in the liver or spleen, among others. Clinical signs of chronic glanders include coughing; malaise; weight loss; intermittent fever; possible thick nasal discharge, usually out of one nostril; ulcers and nodules on the nasal mucosa; enlarged submaxillary lymph nodes; chronic enlargement and induration (hardening) of lymphatics and lymph nodes; joint swelling and painful leg edema (fluid swelling); and nodules, particularly on the legs, that rupture, release pus, and ulcerate. Glanders has been eradicated from North American and was last reported in the United States in the 1940s. It's recently been reported in several areas around the world, however, including South America, Eastern Africa, Asia, the Middle East, and a rare case in Germany in 2014.  Earlier this month August 2017, the 18-year-old Dutch Warmblood gelding Sagacious HF was shipped from Amsterdam to the Miami International Airport after participating in competitions in Sweden and England with Chase Hickok. Under USDA rules, all horses entering the United States, except those coming from Canada, must be quarantined and tested for 4 diseases  dourine, glanders, equine piroplasmosis, and equine infectious anemia  upon arrival.  Jeanine Neskey, interim public affairs specialist for the USDA Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), said an animal that produces a positive test result is denied entry to the United States.  \"Denied entry means that it must be either removed from the U.S. or be euthanized,\" she said. \"If the horse is denied entry into the U.S. (and not euthanized), the owner is free to take the horse to any other country that will accept it.\"  Scott Leibsle, DVM, Idaho's deputy state veterinarian, said Sagacious could have contracted the disease through contaminated feed or through water buckets also used by other horses participating in competitions. The gelding might also have been an asymptomatic carrier of the disease, possibly developing signs after experiencing stress  \"Transport is the most stressful thing you can do to a horse,\" he said. \"At the same time, you're putting it with new animals in a new area, and putting it under the stress of competition.\"  Currently APHIS uses a complement fixation test (CFT) to detect glanders. However, the agency is evaluating other testing methods, including the Western Blot procedure.  \"Advancing research and improved technology continue to develop new or improved testing methods for animal diseases,\" Neskey said. \"USDA routinely evaluates all testing methods available and incorporates the methods most appropriate to the needs of import quarantine testing.\"  After Sagacious produced a 2nd positive CFT glanders test, he produced a negative Western Blot glanders test. Arrangements were made to place him on extended quarantine pending the results of additional testing with both tests, slated for Wed 23 Aug 2017.  Byline: Pat Raia   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Glanders, also known as farcy, is a contagious infectious disease of equines, acute or chronic, usually fatal, caused by the bacterium _Burkholderia mallei_, and characterized by the development of ulcerated nodules that are most commonly found in the upper airway, lungs ,and skin. Felines and other animals are susceptible to infection, which is usually fatal. Humans can be infected and the microorganism (_B. mallei_) is considered a potential bioterrorism agent.  The disease, one among the oldest known and that used to be prevalent worldwide, is currently eradicated or effectively controlled in many countries. Recently the disease has been reported in some countries, including Iraq, Turkey, Pakistan, India, Mongolia, China, Brazil, United Arab Emirates, and countries in Africa. Glanders is one of the diseases contained in the list of diseases for mandatory reporting to the World Animal Health Organization (OIE).  The bacterium _Burkholderia mallei_ a clonal pathogen, can be found in nasal secretions and skin ulcers of infected animals. The transmission of glanders occurs commonly from intake of water or food contaminated with nasal secretions and exudates eliminated from infected animals, contact with contaminated equipment (saddles, harness) and by eating contaminated equine meat.  In the nasal form, nodules arise in septum and turbinates. Nodules progress to irregular edged ulcers; star-shaped scars are characteristic after the resolution of the ulcers. In the early stage, submandibular lymph nodes are enlarged and edematous, adhering to the skin and deep tissues in advanced stages of the disease. In the pulmonary form, inflammatory nodules with caseous or calcified centers are found in the lungs. With the progression of the disease areas of consolidation and pneumonia may be present. The nodules may break and eliminate the inflammatory content into the bronchial tree, spreading the infection to the upper respiratory tract. In the cutaneous form, nodules arise along the lymphatic vessels, especially on the extremities. The nodules may degenerate to form ulcers with drainage of highly infectious purulent material. The liver and spleen may have typical nodular lesions. Histologically, vasculitis, thrombosis, inflammatory cell infiltration and degeneration can be seen.  A test based on complement fixation can also be used for screening, but the ELISA test, although more sensitive, is not being routinely used. PCR can be used for specific identification ((https://www.merckvetmanual.com/generalized-conditions/glanders/overview-of-glanders)).  There are no vaccines. Prevention and control depend on early detection and eliminating infected animals in addition to quarantine and complete disinfection. Treatment, administered only in endemic areas, which does not lead to microbiological cure, is the use of doxycycline, ceftazidime, gentamycin, or streptomycin. Sulfa drugs (including in combination with trimethoprim) seem to be effective in prevention and glanders treatment ((http://www.merckmanuals.com/vet/generalized_conditions/glanders/overview_of_glanders.html?qt=glanders&alt=sh#Diagnosis)).  For glanders-free countries, there are OIE recommendations on importing equines. An international veterinary certificate is required attesting that the animals showed no clinical signs of glanders and were kept in an exporting country free of the disease for at least 6 months prior to shipment ((http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/GLA-EN.pdf)). It appears foreign horse owners will not be able to comply, therefore will be unable to repatriate their show horses? Further information would be welcome.  OIE WAHID's latest information shows continuing glanders in Sao Paulo and Minas Gerais states in 2014 (red circles on map; zoom in), but there have been no immediate or continuing event reports for Brazil in 2015. The OIE report and map are available at (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=11974).  As a horse owner, this would be devastating. We certainly hope Sagacious test later this month August 2017 clears him of this disease. - Mod.TG  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/212). A 12 Aug 2017 report quotes USA health\nofficials indicating that the Zika outbreaks in the Caribbean and\nSouth America are waning and that has helped slow the spread of the\nmosquito-borne virus to Florida and other localities in the USA this\nyear (2017).\n(http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/experts-herd-immunity-us-slows-zika-florida-49179180) Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in\nthe Americas mentioned above and below can be accessed at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574);\nNorth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106);\nCentral America (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455);\nCaribbean (http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/); and\nSouth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186). - Mod.TY Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. Americas. 16 Aug 2017. (reported) case numbers have fallen\ndramatically from their peak in January-March 2016 and not recovered\nthis year (2017). Increased herd immunity from previous Zika virus\ninfections has been suggested as one reason for the decline.\n(http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/08/zika-has-all-disappeared-americas-why) North America\n\nUSA\n- Hidalgo county, Texas. 3 Aug 2017. South America\n\nArgentina (Salta province). 13 Aug 2017. November 2016-May 2017, 1st\nlocally acquired outbreak (conf.) 203 cases of which 7 pregnant.\nDepartment most affected: San Martín (Tartagal, General Mosconi,\nAguaray, and Embarcación), and Morillo.\n(http://www.eltribuno.info/salta/nota/2017-8-13-0-0-0-hubo-203-casos-de-zika-en-el-primer-brote-autoctono)\n Brazil\n- Origin and spread. 15 Jun 2017. (reported) Analyses of viral genomes\nwith ecological and epidemiological data yield an estimate that ZIKV\nwas present in northeast Brazil by February 2014 and is likely to have\ndisseminated from there, nationally and internationally, before the\n1st detection of ZIKV in the Americas. Estimated dates for the\ninternational spread of ZIKV from Brazil indicate the duration of\npre-detection cryptic transmission in recipient regions. The role of\nnortheast Brazil in the establishment of ZIKV in the Americas is\nfurther supported by geographic analysis of ZIKV transmission.\n(http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v546/n7658/full/nature22402.html) - Eye lesions. 17 Jul 2017 (reported) of 112 infants born to Zika\nvirus infected mothers in Brazil, 24 (21 percent) had eye\nabnormalities; 10 infants (42 percent) with abnormal eye examination\nfindings did not have microcephaly, 8 (33 percent) did not have any\ncentral nervous system findings, and 2 (8 percent) had eye\nabnormalities despite maternal 3rd trimester infection. Eye\nabnormalities may be the only initial finding in congenital Zika virus\ninfection, and all infants with potential Zika virus exposure should\nundergo screening eye examinations.\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/article-abstract/2636587) Peru\n- National. 22 Jul 2017. 2016-22 Jul 2017 (susp.) 6432 cases, (conf.)\n1438 cases with 264 pregnant with 17 cases of suspected Zika\nvirus-related microcephaly. For 2017 up to 23 Jul 2017 (susp.) 5552\ncases, (conf.) 649 cases with 172 pregnant, 5 cases of suspected Zika\nvirus-related microcephaly. Epidemic peak on week 15 week ending 14\nApr 2017, then sharp decline.\n(http://www.dge.gob.pe/portal/docs/vigilancia/boletines/2017/29.pdf)\n - Piura region. 29 Jul 2017. (susp.) 94 cases, (conf.) 13 cases of\nwhom 5 pregnant.\n(http://diariocorreo.pe/edicion/piura/casos-de-dengue-y-zika-aumentan-ligeramente-semana-a-semana-764780/)\n Asia\n\nThailand (Phichit province). 4 Jul 2017. (reported) 1st case reported in state\nin a 27-year-old man in the Krishnagiri district.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/tamil-nadu-reports-first-case-of-zika-virus/article19254690.ece) Imported cases with little or no possibility of ongoing mosquito\ntransmission\n\nCanada. 26 Jul 2017. Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-16 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html) State / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 20 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 29 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 6 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 4 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 40 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 4 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 2 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 203 / 9 - Texas. 11 Aug 2017. 1 Jan 2016-31 July 2017, 219 pregnant women with\nlaboratory evidence of possible recent Zika virus infection were\nidentified in Texas, including 49 (22 percent) with\nlaboratory-confirmed Zika virus). One woman was infected in Texas; all\nothers were exposed outside the United States and its territories.\nZika virus testing was completed for 80 (43 percent) of the 185\ninfants or fetuses, and Zika virus-associated birth defects were\ndocumented in 15 (8 percent) pregnancies (14 live-born infants and one\nfetal loss), including 6 (17 percent) of the 36 infants or fetal\nlosses delivered by women with laboratory-confirmed Zika virus\ninfection. Of these, 10 infants or fetuses had microcephaly; 5 of\nthose with microcephaly had additional birth defects, including\nholoprosencephaly the brain doesn't properly divide into the right\nand left hemispheres, hydranencephaly brain's cerebral hemispheres\nreplaced by sacs filled with cerebrospinal fluid, craniosynostosis\npremature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, often resulting in\nan abnormal head shape, and clubfeet feet turned inward. Zika\nvirus-associated birth defects identified in the remaining 3 infants\nincluded holoprosencephaly, cataracts, and ventral pons hypoplasia.\n(https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6631a5.htm?s_cid=mm6631a5_e) Neurological effects not only occur in fetuses and neonates, there\nare occasional cases in adults as well. A report describes a case of\nZIKV meningoencephalitis and probable myelitis and its associated\nmagnetic resonance imaging findings that rapidly resolved during\nrecovery in a previously healthy adult.\n((http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0921)). -\nMod. TY - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 40 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 39 / 0\nTotal 554 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Evaluation of diagnostic tests.\nDate: September 2017 (ahead of print).\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/9/16-2043_article) \nref: Safronetz D, Sloan A, Stein DR, et al. Evaluation of 5\ncommercially available Zika virus immunoassays. Emerg Infect Dis.\n2017; 23(9): 1577-80. doi: 10.3201/eid2309.162043. Epub 2017 Sep 17\n-\nAbstract\n\nBecause of global spread of Zika virus, accurate and high-throughput\ndiagnostic immunoassays are needed. We compared the sensitivity and\nspecificity of 5 commercially available Zika virus serologic assays to\nthe recommended protocol of Zika virus IgM-capture ELISA and\nplaque-reduction neutralization tests. Most commercial immunoassays\nshowed low sensitivity, which can be increased. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The low sensitivity is a significant concern. Readers interested in\nthe evaluation of the specific tests may wish to see the full report\navailable at the source URL above. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Saliva transmission unlikely.\nDate: Tue 1 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Communications (edited)\n(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5539107/? \nref: Newman CM, Dudley DM, Aliota MT, et al. Oropharyngeal mucosal\ntransmission of Zika virus in rhesus macaques. Nat Commun. 2017; 8(1):\n169. doi: 10.1038/s41467-017-00246-8\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus is present in urine, saliva, tears, and breast milk, but\nthe transmission risk associated with these body fluids is currently\nunknown. Here we evaluate the risk of Zika virus transmission through\nmucosal contact in rhesus macaques. Application of high-dose Zika\nvirus directly to the tonsils of 3 rhesus macaques results in\ndetectable plasma viremia in all animals by 2 days post-exposure;\nvirus replication kinetics are similar to those observed in animals\ninfected subcutaneously. 3 additional macaques inoculated\nsubcutaneously with Zika virus served as saliva donors to assess the\ntransmission risk from contact with oral secretions from an infected\nindividual. 7 naive animals repeatedly exposed to donor saliva via the\nconjunctivae, tonsils, or nostrils did not become infected. Our\nresults suggest that there is a risk of Zika virus transmission via\nthe mucosal route, but that the risk posed by oral secretions from\nindividuals with a typical course of Zika virus infection is low. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall It is good to learn that Zika virus transmission via mucosa is\nunlikely. It will be interesting to know if virus shedding in saliva\nis a common occurrence in infected humans. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> CDC guidance for pregnancy.\nDate: Mon 24 Jul 2017.\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2017; 66(29): 781-93(edited)\n(https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6629e1.htm) \nref: Oduyebo T, Polen KD, Walke HT, et al. Update: Interim guidance\nfor health care providers caring for pregnant women with possible Zika\nvirus exposure  United States (including US Territories), July 2017.\nMMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2017; 66(29): 781-93. doi:\n10.15585/mmwr.mm6629e1\n-\nCDC has updated the interim guidance for US health care providers\ncaring for pregnant women with possible Zika virus exposure in\nresponse to 1) declining prevalence of Zika virus disease in the World\nHealth Organization's Region of the Americas (Americas) and 2)\nemerging evidence indicating prolonged detection of Zika virus\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies. Zika virus cases were 1st reported\nin the Americas during 2015-2016; however, the incidence of Zika virus\ndisease has since declined. As the prevalence of Zika virus disease\ndeclines, the likelihood of false-positive test results increases. In\naddition, emerging epidemiologic and laboratory data indicate that, as\nis the case with other flaviviruses, Zika virus IgM antibodies can\npersist beyond 12 weeks after infection. Therefore, IgM test results\ncannot always reliably distinguish between an infection that occurred\nduring the current pregnancy and one that occurred before the current\npregnancy, particularly for women with possible Zika virus exposure\nbefore the current pregnancy. These limitations should be considered\nwhen counseling pregnant women about the risks and benefits of testing\nfor Zika virus infection during pregnancy. This updated guidance\nemphasizes a shared decision-making model for testing and screening\npregnant women, one in which patients and providers work together to\nmake decisions about testing and care plans based on patient\npreferences and values, clinical judgment, and a balanced assessment\nof risks and expected outcomes. For these recommendations, the definition of possible Zika virus\nexposure has not changed and includes travel to, or residence in an\narea with risk for mosquito-borne Zika virus transmission or sex with\na partner who has traveled to or resides in an area with risk for\nmosquito-borne Zika virus transmission. These areas can be found on\nthe CDC \"Zika Travel Information\" webpage. Key recommendations include the following:\n1- All pregnant women in the United States and US territories should\nbe asked about possible Zika virus exposure before and during the\ncurrent pregnancy, at every prenatal care visit. CDC recommends that\npregnant women not travel to any area with risk for Zika virus\ntransmission. It is also recommended that pregnant women with a sex\npartner who has traveled to or lives in an area with risk for Zika\nvirus transmission use condoms or abstain from sex for the duration of\nthe pregnancy.\n2- Pregnant women with recent possible Zika virus exposure and\nsymptoms of Zika virus disease should be tested to diagnose the cause\nof their symptoms. The updated recommendations include concurrent Zika\nvirus nucleic acid test (NAT) and serologic testing as soon as\npossible through 12 weeks after symptom onset.\n3- Asymptomatic pregnant women with ongoing possible Zika virus\nexposure should be offered Zika virus NAT testing 3 times during\npregnancy. IgM testing is no longer routinely recommended because IgM\ncan persist for months after infection; therefore, IgM results cannot\nreliably determine whether an infection occurred during the current\npregnancy. The optimal timing and frequency of testing of asymptomatic\npregnant women with NAT alone is unknown. For pregnant women who have\nreceived a diagnosis of laboratory-confirmed Zika virus infection (by\neither NAT or serology positive/equivocal Zika virus or dengue virus\nIgM and Zika virus plaque reduction neutralization test (PRNT) 10 and\nhigher and dengue virus PRNT less than 10 results) any time before or\nduring the current pregnancy, additional Zika virus testing is not\nrecommended. For pregnant women without a prior laboratory-confirmed\ndiagnosis of Zika virus, NAT testing should be offered at the\ninitiation of prenatal care, and if Zika virus RNA is not detected on\nclinical specimens, 2 additional tests should be offered during the\ncourse of the pregnancy coinciding with prenatal visits.\n4- Asymptomatic pregnant women who have recent possible Zika virus\nexposure (that is, through travel or sexual exposure) but without\nongoing possible exposure are not routinely recommended to have Zika\nvirus testing. Testing should be considered using a shared\npatient-provider decision-making model, one in which patients and\nproviders work together to make decisions about testing and care plans\nbased on patient preferences and values, clinical judgment, a balanced\nassessment of risks and expected outcomes, and the jurisdiction's\nrecommendations. Based on the epidemiology of Zika virus transmission\nand other epidemiologic considerations (such as, seasonality),\njurisdictions might recommend testing of asymptomatic pregnant women,\neither for clinical care or as part of Zika virus surveillance. With\nthe decline in the prevalence of Zika virus disease, the updated\nrecommendations for the evaluation and testing of pregnant women with\nrecent possible Zika virus exposure but without ongoing possible\nexposure are now the same for all areas with any risk for Zika virus\ntransmission.\n5- Pregnant women who have recent possible Zika virus exposure and who\nhave a fetus with prenatal ultrasound findings consistent with\ncongenital Zika virus syndrome should receive Zika virus testing to\nassist in establishing the etiology of the birth defects. Testing\nshould include both NAT and IgM tests.\n6- The comprehensive approach to testing placental and fetal tissues\nhas been updated. Testing placental and fetal tissue specimens can be\nperformed for diagnostic purposes in certain scenarios (e.g., women\nwithout a diagnosis of laboratory-confirmed Zika virus infection and\nwho have a fetus or infant with possible Zika virus-associated birth\ndefects). However, testing of placental tissues for Zika virus\ninfection is not routinely recommended for asymptomatic pregnant women\nwho have recent possible Zika virus exposure but without ongoing\npossible exposure and who have a live born infant without evidence of\npossible Zika virus-associated birth defects.\n7- Zika virus IgM testing as part of preconception counseling to\nestablish baseline IgM results for non pregnant women with ongoing\npossible Zika virus exposure is not warranted because Zika virus IgM\ntesting is no longer routinely recommended for asymptomatic pregnant\nwomen with ongoing possible Zika virus exposure. also at the source URL above:\nAdditional interim guidance:\n- Laboratory testing of pregnant women with exposure to areas with\nrisk for Zika virus transmission\n- Prenatal management of pregnant women with laboratory evidence of\npossible Zika virus infection\n- Evaluation of placental and fetal tissue specimens for Zika virus\ninfection \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be)(promed@promedmail.org) Readers interested in accessing the full report can find it at the\nsource URL above. Interestingly, a malaria drug has been shown to\ninhibit autophagy which limits vertical transmission of Zika virus in\npregnant mice. (http://dx.doi.org/10.1084/jem.20170957). Roland\nHübner is thanked for sending in this report. - Mod. TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Neurologic complications in adults.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: JAMA Neurology (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamaneurology/fullarticle/2647256) \nref: da Silva IRF, Frontera JA, Bispo de Filippis AM, et al.\nNeurologic complications associated with the Zika virus in Brazilian\nadults. JAMA Neurol. 2017. doi: 10.1001/jamaneurol.2017.1703. Epub\nahead of print\n-\nKey points\n-\nQuestion. What is the spectrum of neurologic manifestations in adults\nwith Zika virus infection?\nFindings. This cohort study evaluated adult patients with new-onset\nparainfectious or neuroinflammatory disease for the presence of acute\nZika virus infection in both serum and cerebrospinal fluid samples\nusing molecular and serological testing. An increase in the incidence\nof Guillain-Barré syndrome and encephalitis was observed compared\nwith the period before the outbreak of the Zika virus.\nMeaning The Zika virus may be associated with a rapid increase in the\nincidence of life-threatening neurologic syndromes; serologic and\nmolecular testing using blood and cerebrospinal fluid samples can\nserve as an alternative diagnostic strategy. Abstract\n\nImportance. There are no prospective cohort studies assessing the\nincidence and spectrum of neurologic manifestations secondary to Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) infection in adults.\nObjective. To evaluate the rates of acute ZIKV infection among\npatients hospitalized with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS),\nmeningoencephalitis, or transverse myelitis.\nDesign, setting, and participants. A prospective, observational cohort\nstudy was conducted at a tertiary referral center for neurological\ndiseases in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, between 5 Dec 2015-10 May 2016,\namong consecutive hospitalized adults (older than 18 years of age)\nwith new-onset acute parainfectious or neuroinflammatory disease. All\nparticipants were tested for a series of arbovirosis. 3-month\nfunctional outcome was assessed.\nInterventions. Samples of serum and cerebrospinal fluid were tested\nfor ZIKV using real-time reverse-transcriptase-polymerase chain\nreaction and an IgM antibody-capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent\nassay. Clinical, radiographic (magnetic resonance imaging),\nelectrophysiological, and 3-month functional outcome data were\ncollected.\nMain outcomes and measures. The detection of neurologic complications\nsecondary to ZIKV infection.\nResults. 40 patients (15 women and 25 men; median age, 44 years\nrange, 22-72 years) were enrolled, including 29 patients (73\npercent) with GBS (90 percent Brighton level 1 certainty), 7 (18\npercent) with encephalitis, 3 (8 percent) with transverse myelitis,\nand 1 (3 percent) with newly diagnosed chronic inflammatory\ndemyelinating polyneuropathy. Of these, 35 patients (88 percent) had\nmolecular and/or serologic evidence of recent ZIKV infection in the\nserum and/or cerebrospinal fluid. Of the patients positive for ZIKV\ninfection, 27 had GBS (18 demyelinating, 8 axonal, and 1 Miller Fisher\nsyndrome), 5 had encephalitis (3 with concomitant acute neuromuscular\ndisease), 2 had transverse myelitis, and 1 had chronic inflammatory\ndemyelinating polyneuropathy. Admission to the intensive care unit was\nrequired for 9 patients positive for ZIKV infection (26 percent), and\n5 (14 percent) required mechanical ventilation. Compared with\nadmission during the period from 5 Dec 2013 - 10 May 2014 (before the\nBrazilian outbreak of ZIKV), admissions for GBS increased from a mean\nof 1.0 per month to 5.6 per month, admissions for encephalitis\nincreased from 0.4 per month to 1.4 per month, and admissions for\ntransverse myelitis remained constant at 0.6 per month. At 3 months, 2\npatients positive for ZIKV infection (6 percent) died (1 with GBS and\n1 with encephalitis), 18 (51 percent) had chronic pain, and the median\nmodified Rankin score among survivors was 2 (range, 0-5).\nConclusions and relevance. In this single-center Brazilian cohort,\nZIKV infection was associated with an increase in the incidence of a\ndiverse spectrum of serious neurologic syndromes. The data also\nsuggest that serologic and molecular testing using blood and\ncerebrospinal fluid samples can serve as a less expensive, alternative\ndiagnostic strategy in developing countries, where plaque reduction\nneutralization testing is impractical. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) This study illustrates the need to consider post-Zika virus infection\nas a cause of a variety of neurological diseases. Further neurological\nfollow up of adults convalescent from acute Zika virus infection would\nbe of interest. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Persistence in brain cells.\nDate: Tue 11 Jul 2017.\nSource: mBio (edited)\n(http://mbio.asm.org/content/8/4/e00952-17.long) \nMladinich MC, Schwedes J, Mackow ER. Zika virus persistently infects\nand is basolaterally released from primary human brain microvascular\nendothelial cells. MBio. 2017; 8(4). pii: e00952-17. doi:\n10.1128/mBio.00952-17\n-\nZIKV persists in patients, crossing placental and neuronal barriers,\ndamaging neurons, and causing fetal microencephaly. We found that ZIKV\npersistently infects brain endothelial cells that normally protect\nneurons from viral exposure. hBMECs are not damaged by ZIKV infection\nand, analogous to persistent HCV infection, ZIKV constitutively\ninduces and evades antiviral ISG IFN-stimulated genes and IFN\ninterferon responses to continuously replicate in hBMECs. As a\nresult, hBMECs provide a protective niche for systemic ZIKV spread and\na viral reservoir localized in the normally protective blood-brain\nbarrier. Consistent with the spread of ZIKV into neuronal\ncompartments, ZIKV was released basolaterally from hBMECs. Our\nfindings define hBMEC responses that contribute to persistent ZIKV\ninfection and potential targets for clearing ZIKV infections from\nhBMECs. These results further suggest roles for additional\nZIKV-infected ECs to facilitate viral spread and persistence in the\nprotected placental, retinal, and testicular compartments. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Prior flavivirus infection and Zika virus infection.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Pathogens (edited)\n(http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1006487) \nMcCracken MK, Gromowski GD, Friberg HL, et al. Impact of prior\nflavivirus immunity on Zika virus infection in rhesus macaques. PLoS\nPathog. 2017; 13(8): e1006487. doi: 10.1371/journal.ppat.1006487\n-\nAbstract\n\nStudies have demonstrated cross-reactivity of anti-dengue virus (DENV)\nantibodies in human sera against Zika virus (ZIKV), promoting\nincreased ZIKV infection in vitro. However, the correlation between in\nvitro and in vivo findings is not well characterized. Thus, we\nevaluated the impact of heterotypic flavivirus immunity on ZIKV titers\nin biofluids of rhesus macaques. Animals previously infected (420 days\nor longer) with DENV2, DENV4, or yellow fever virus were compared to\nflavivirus-naïve animals following infection with a Brazilian ZIKV\nstrain. Sera from DENV-immune macaques demonstrated cross-reactivity\nwith ZIKV by antibody-binding and neutralization assays prior to ZIKV\ninfection, and promoted increased ZIKV infection in cell culture\nassays. Despite these findings, no significant differences between\nflavivirus-naïve and immune animals were observed in viral titers,\nneutralizing antibody levels, or immune cell kinetics following ZIKV\ninfection. These results indicate that prior infection with\nheterologous flaviviruses neither conferred protection nor increased\nobserved ZIKV titers in this non-human primate ZIKV infection model. Author summary\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne, emerging flavivirus. In\naddition to asymptomatic or mild febrile manifestations, ZIKV\ninfection in humans is associated with comparatively rare congenital\nand neurological abnormalities. Previous in vitro studies have\ndemonstrated cross-reactivity of antibodies derived from dengue virus\ninfections with ZIKV, as well as antibody-mediated enhancement of\ninfection in cell culture. Therefore, there is concern among\nvaccinologists and the public health community that the more severe\ndisease manifestations could result from prior immunity, either from\nnatural infection or vaccination, to antigenically-related\nflaviviruses (such as, dengue, yellow fever, Japanese encephalitis).\nIn this study, we evaluated the impact of prior immunity to dengue or\nyellow fever virus on ZIKV infection in a non-human primate model.\nAfter confirming that our immune cohorts were capable of\nrecapitulating the published in vitro observations of cross-reactivity\nand enhancement, we looked for alteration of viral titers in\nperipheral blood, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, saliva, and vaginal\nsecretions, as well as alterations in gross pathology, clinical\nparameters, and immune response, as compared to our flavivirus-naïve\ncohort. Importantly, no significant differences between\nflavivirus-naïve and primed animals were observed in viral titers or\nbiofluid distribution, neutralizing antibody levels, or immune cell\nkinetics following ZIKV infection. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be)(promed@promedmail.org) Previous dengue infection, whether acquired naturally or antibody\nelicited by vaccines, has been a concern due to the possibility of\nantibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) with more severe disease. This\nconcern also relates to Zika virus antibody from vaccination for\nenhancement of dengue virus infections with resulting more severe\ndisease. The monkey studies reported above indicated that this may not\nbe a problem for Zika virus vaccinated individuals. Another effort to\navoid ADE is development of a vaccine that has epitopes specific for\nZika virus that are not shared by other flaviviruses. A group of\nresearchers developed a recombinant vaccine targeting a viral envelope\nsub-unit specific to the Zika virus\n((http://www.pharmaceutical-journal.com/news-and-analysis/news-in-brief/researchers-find-way-to-overcome-zika-vaccinedengue-virus-conundrum/20203379.article)).\nRoland Hübner is thanked for calling this latter reference to our\nattention. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Virus inhibition.\nDate: 25 Jul 2017.\nSource: Nature Communications (edited)\n(https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms15672) \nref: Yu Y, Deng YQ, Zou P, et al. A peptide-based viral inactivator\ninhibits Zika virus infection in pregnant mice and fetuses. Nat\nCommun. 2017; 8: 15672. doi: 10.1038/ncomms15672\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV), a re-emerging flavivirus associated with\nneurological disorders, has spread rapidly to more than 70 countries\nand territories. However, no specific vaccines or antiviral drugs are\ncurrently available to prevent or treat ZIKV infection. Here we report\nthat a synthetic peptide derived from the stem region of ZIKV envelope\nprotein, designated Z2, potently inhibits infection of ZIKV and other\nflaviviruses in vitro. We show that Z2 interacts with ZIKV surface\nprotein and disrupts the integrity of the viral membrane. Z2 can\npenetrate the placental barrier to enter fetal tissues and is safe for\nuse in pregnant mice. Intraperitoneal administration of Z2 inhibits\nvertical transmission of ZIKV in pregnant C57BL/6 mice and protects\ntype I or type I/II interferon receptor-deficient mice against lethal\nZIKV challenge. Thus, Z2 has potential to be further developed as an\nantiviral treatment against ZIKV infection in high-risk populations,\nparticularly pregnant women. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall It will be interesting to see if the same protective effect occurs\nwhen tested with Zika virus infections of non-human primates. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{9}</strong> Female reproductive tract infection.\nDate: Wed 26 Jul 2017.\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Pathogens (edited)\n(http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1006537) \nCarroll T, Lo M, Lanteri M, et al. Zika virus preferentially\nreplicates in the female reproductive tract after vaginal inoculation\nof rhesus macaques. PLoS Pathog. 2017; 13(7): e1006537. doi:\n10.1371/journal.ppat.1006537\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-transmitted virus that can cause\nsevere defects in an infected fetus. ZIKV is also transmitted by\nsexual contact, although the relative importance of sexual\ntransmission is unclear. To better understand the role of sexual\ntransmission in ZIKV pathogenesis, a nonhuman primate (NHP) model of\nvaginal transmission was developed. ZIKV was readily transmitted to\nmature cycling female rhesus macaque (RM) by vaginal inoculation was\nreadily transmitted to mature cycling female rhesus macaque (RM) by\nvaginal individual RM with 1-5 vaginal inoculations required to\nestablish infection. After treatment with Depoprovera, a widely used\ncontraceptive progestin, 2 RM that initially resisted 8 vaginal ZIKV\ninoculations became infected after one ZIKV inoculation. Thus,\nDepoprovera seemed to enhance susceptibility to vaginal ZIKV\ntransmission. Unexpectedly, the kinetics of virus replication and\ndissemination after intravaginal ZIKV inoculation were markedly\ndifferent from RM infected with ZIKV by subcutaneous (SQ) virus\ninoculation. Several groups have reported that after SQ ZIKV\ninoculation vRNA is rapidly detected in blood plasma with vRNA less\ncommon in urine and saliva and only rarely detected in female\nreproductive tract (FRT) secretions. In contrast, in vaginally\ninoculated RM, plasma vRNA is delayed for several days and ZIKV\nreplication in, and vRNA shedding from, the FRT was found in all 6\nanimals. Further, after intravaginal transmission ZIKV RNA shedding\nfrom FRT secretions was detected before or simultaneously with plasma\nvRNA, and persisted for at least as long. Thus, ZIKV replication in\nthe FRT was independent of, and often preceded virus replication in\nthe tissues contributing to plasma vRNA. These results support the\nconclusion that ZIKV preferentially replicates in the FRT after\nvaginal transmission, but not after SQ transmission, and raise the\npossibility that there is enhanced fetal infection and pathology after\nvaginal ZIKV transmission compared to a mosquito transmitted ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{10}</strong> _Aedes albopictus_ populations as vectors.\nDate: 2 Aug 2017.\nSource: American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (edited)\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0969) \nref: Azar SR, Roundy CM, Rossi SL, et al. Differential vector\ncompetency of _Aedes albopictus_ populations from the Americas for\nZika virus. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2017; 97(2): 330-9;\ndoi.org/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0969\n-\nAbstract\n\nTo evaluate the potential role of _Aedes albopictus_ (Skuse) as a\nvector of Zika virus (ZIKV), colonized mosquitoes of low generation\nnumber (less than or F5) from Brazil, Houston, and the Rio Grande\nValley of Texas engorged on viremic mice infected with ZIKV strains\noriginating from Senegal, Cambodia, Mexico, Brazil, or Puerto Rico.\nVector competence was established by monitoring infection,\ndissemination, and transmission potential after 3, 7, and 14 days of\nextrinsic incubation. Positive saliva samples were assayed for\ninfectious titer. Although all 3 mosquito populations were susceptible\nto all ZIKV strains, rates of infection, dissemination, and\ntransmission differed among mosquito and virus strains. _Aedes\nalbopictus_ from Salvador, Brazil, were the least efficient vectors,\ndemonstrating susceptibility to infection to 2 American strains of\nZIKV but failing to shed virus in saliva. Mosquitoes from the Rio\nGrande Valley were the most efficient vectors and were capable of\nshedding all 3 tested ZIKV strains into saliva after 14 days of\nextrinsic incubation. In particular, ZIKV strain DakAR 41525 (Senegal\n1954) was significantly more efficient at dissemination and saliva\ndeposition than the others tested in Rio Grande mosquitoes. Overall,\nour data indicate that, while _Ae. albopictus_ is capable of\ntransmitting ZIKV, its competence is potentially dependent on\ngeographic origin of both the mosquito population and the viral\nstrain. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) This study illustrates that fact that not all Zika virus strains and\n_Ae. albopictus_ populations are created equal in terms of efficiency\nof transmission of this virus. Although some populations of this\nmosquito are able to efficiently transmits some Zika viruses, the fact\nthat _Ae. albopictus _ are not strictly human biters, further reduces\ntheir role as transmitters of this virus to people. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{11}</strong> _Culex quinquefasciatus_ as vectors.\nDate: Wed 9 Aug 2017.\nSource: Emerging Microbes & Infections (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/emi/journal/v6/n8/full/emi201759a.html?foxtrotcallback=true) \nref: Guedes DR, Paiva MH, Donato MM, et al. Zika virus replication in\nthe mosquito _Culex quinquefasciatus_ in Brazil. Emerg Microbes\nInfect. 2017; 6(8): e69. doi: 10.1038/emi.2017.59\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a flavivirus that has recently been associated\nwith an increased incidence of neonatal microcephaly and other\nneurological disorders. The virus is primarily transmitted by mosquito\nbite, although other routes of infection have been implicated in some\ncases. The _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito is considered to be the main\nvector to humans worldwide; however, there is evidence that other\nmosquito species, including _Culex quinquefasciatus_, transmit the\nvirus. To test the potential of _Cx. quinquefasciatus_ to transmit\nZIKV, we experimentally compared the vector competence of\nlaboratory-reared _Ae. aegypti_ and _Cx. quinquefasciatus_.\nInterestingly, we were able to detect the presence of ZIKV in the\nmidgut, salivary glands and saliva of artificially fed _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_. In addition, we collected ZIKV-infected _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_ from urban areas with high microcephaly incidence in\nRecife, Brazil. Corroborating our experimental data from artificially\nfed mosquitoes, ZIKV was isolated from field-caught _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_, and its genome was partially sequenced.\nCollectively, these findings indicate that there may be a wider range\nof ZIKV vectors than anticipated. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be) Finding a virus in field-collected mosquitoes in areas of active\nvirus transmission is highly suggestive, but not conclusive, of their\nability to transmit that virus. The study above goes the next step\ntoward proving vector capability by infecting _Culex quinquefasciatus_\nfed with Zika virus and subsequently demonstrating the virus in\nsaliva, implicating their ability to transmit it. The role of _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_ in Zika virus transmission is currently confusing.\nThe study above and one done in China indicate that this species is a\ncompetent vector. Several other studies have shown this species to be\ninefficient vectors or refractory to Zika virus infection. One wonders\nif the specific _Cx. quinquefasciatus_ used or the Zika virus isolates\nwith which they were tested could account for these very different\nresults. Resolving these discrepancies is important because this\nmosquito species is very widely distributed around the world and bears\ndirectly on risk of outbreaks in geographic areas where _Aedes\naegypti_ or _Ae. albopictus_ , Zika virus vectors, do not occur. -\nMod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"51":{"title":"Mumps update (24): Australia (QL), New Zealand (OT),\r\n\tBrazil (AM) ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Mumps update (24): Australia (QL), New Zealand (OT),\r\n\tBrazil (AM) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Australia (Cairns, Queensland) <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago) <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)   <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Australia (Cairns, Queensland). Date: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST. Source: The Cairns Post (edited) (https://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5)   Far North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since 24 Jul 2017, compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.  Tropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.  \"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.  He said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.  \"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.  \"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"  Northern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.  \"This year's 2017 increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.  \"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ..  The disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.  This is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.  Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.  Byline: Daniel Bateman   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ    <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago). Date: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST. Source: Stuff (edited) (http://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5)   University of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin Otago, South Island.  Three young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.  Nationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".  Auckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month  most aged 10 to 19  while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year 2017.  The Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month July 2017 it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.  The MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.  Most people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.  Men hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.  The outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.  Pro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"  The outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on Mon 14 Aug 2017.  All students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.  Marlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear  including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.  Personal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre 3 ft away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.  Dr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.  There have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.  Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of New Zealand can be seen at (http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ   <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas). Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017. Source: Em Tempo in Portuguese, trans. & summ., edited (http://www.emtempo.com.br/manaus-tem-surto-de-caxumba-com-230-casos/)   With 230 cases of mumps in Manaus Amazonas state in 19 places, registered since April 2017, mainly in schools, the Municipal Health Department (Semsa) warns parents to keep the updated immunization booklet for children and adolescents.  Up to 2016, there were no official mumps outbreak records in Manaus. In 2017, as of 18 Aug, there have been 230 cases reported from 19 localities, most of them in schools, which suggests low vaccination coverage in children and adolescents. The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ..  Byline: Isac Sharlon   <br><br>Communicated by: Emerson Capistrano Epidemiological Surveillance Boa Vista Health Service Roraima, Brazil (emerson.capistrano@gmail.com)  ProMED-mail thanks Emerson Capistrano for submitting this report. - Mod.LK  Maps of Brazil can be seen at (http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/10254). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"72":{"title":"Chikungunya (27) - Americas, Europe, Asia ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Chikungunya (27) - Americas, Europe, Asia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHIKUNGUNYA (27) - AMERICAS, EUROPE, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n\nAmericas\n\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO report Mexico and Central America\n\nMexico (Jalisco state)\nCosta Rica South America\n\nArgentina (Salto province)\nBrazil:\n- Roraima state\n- Ceara state\nPeru (Piura region) Europe\n\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region in Provence) Asia\n\nTaiwan (Tainan)\nIndia:\n- Delhi\n- Ludhiana, Punjab\n- Chandigarh, Haryana and Punjab states\n- Tamil Nadu state\n- Baramati tehsil, Pune, Maharastra state\n- Pune Maharashtra state ex Assam state\n- Kerala state\nBangladesh (Dhaka)\nNepal (Bhaktapur, province 3) \nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n\nAmericas\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n18 Aug 2017\n(http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8975&Itemid=40931&lang=en) \nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or\nterritory - 2017 to EW 33 week ending 18 Aug 2017. (reported) severe\ncase. A 69 year old from Assam was diagnosed with chikungunya around a\nweek ago. The disease had affected almost all his vital organs \nheart, brain, liver and kidney.
