TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be) The number of reported cases of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection\nin the Americas appears to have declined this year (2017). Given the\noutbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) infections in the region, and the\nclinical similarity of cases of that virus infection and CHIKV\ninfection, one wonders how many cases that were not laboratory\nconfirmed but clinically diagnosed as ZIKV infections were, in\nreality, CHIKV infections. It is also possible that a significant\nproportion of the population have been infected by CHIKV in the\nprevious 3 years and are now immune. It seems likely, however, that\nCHIKV is now endemic in the Americas, and sporadic, small outbreaks\nmay continue to occur as they do in Asia and Africa. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"80":{"title":"Yellow fever - Americas (56): French Guiana ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Yellow fever - Americas (56): French Guiana [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nYELLOW FEVER - AMERICAS (56): FRENCH GUIANA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Tue 22 Aug 2017, 11:43 PM.\nSource: SFR France-Antilles in French, trans. Corr.SB, edited\n(http://www.martinique.franceantilles.fr/actualite/sante/un-cas-de-fievre-jaune-en-guyane-429923.php) \nFor the 1st time since 1998, a case of yellow fever has been confirmed\nin Guiana. It is a woman who stayed in the forest towards Saint-Élie\nand Oiapoque, in the border area with Brazil. The Institute Pasteur of Guiana yesterday Mon 21 Aug 2017 confirmed\nyellow fever virus infection in Guiana, for the 1st time since 1998.\nThe infected person died on 9 Aug 2017. She could have been infected\nin the border area of Oiapoque in Brazil, according to the initial\ninvestigations of the ARS (Agence Regional de Santé; regional health\nagency). She had been in the forest near St Elie and in the Oyapock\nValley. The mosquito control department of the CTG Collectivité Territoriale\nde Guyane  official name of French Guiana began its mosquito\ncontrol operations around the identified places of transit of the\ndeceased patient: the Cayenne hospital centre, the Kourou medical and\nsurgical centre; the surrounding forest of Saint-Élie; degradation of\nPetit Saut; the lower Oyapock. The ARS recommends that unvaccinated people who present with symptoms\nand who have visited the area since 15 Aug 2017 should consult their\ndoctor without delay. Unvaccinated people can be vaccinated at most\ngeneral practitioners and at the following centres: - CPS of the Red Cross, - traveller centre or CDPS of the Centre Hospitalier de Cayenne,\n- PMI centers of the CTG. The ARS reminds all that vaccination is the main prevention measure\nagainst yellow fever. Transmission to humans, symptoms and treatments:\n\nYellow fever is an acute viral disease transmissible from animal\n(monkey) to man and man to man by various mosquitoes (genus _Aedes_,\nbut also other genera circulating in the forest). The yellow fever\nvirus is transmitted by the bite of an infected mosquito. After an incubation period of about one week, the disease is\ncharacterized by fever, chills, muscle pain, headache, nausea,\nvomiting. Severe forms (hemorrhage, liver disorders, kidney problems)\ncan develop in 15 per cent of cases. Vaccination is the main prevention measure against yellow fever. The\nvaccine is safe, and very effective, a single dose is usually enough\nto give lasting immunity and lifetime protection against the disease.\nIn 30 days, it gives an effective immune protection to 99 per cent of\nvaccinated subjects. In case of yellow fever, symptomatic treatment may be proposed\n(rehydration, antipyretic medicines to limit fever, vomiting and pain,\nantibiotics for superinfections). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) It is hard to know if this case is related to this year's (2017)\nyellow fever (YF) outbreak in Brazil. The Brazilian state of Amapá\nborders French Guiana, but there have been no reported YF cases in\nhumans or in non-human primates in the state. However, French Guiana\nis endemic for YF and the area where the woman was infected is\nforested and is likely to have foci of sylvan (forest) YF. Yellow\nfever was detected in 1951 in French Guiana and YF immunization has\nbeen compulsory there since 1967. In the year 2000, a cluster survey\nshowed that immunization coverage in the population was estimated at\n80-90 per cent, depending on the age category\n(http://www.invs.sante.fr/publications/2002/couv_vaccin_guyane/r_couv_vaccin_guyane.pdf). The last case of autochthonous YF notified in Guiana before the one\ncited above occurred in 1998 in a town on the border with Surinam.\nSince then, the compulsory notification system built around all health\ncare structures and a reference laboratory at Cayenne's Pasteur\nInstitute have received no notification of Yellow fever cases until\nnow. Health authorities in French Guiana are wise to emphasize\nvaccination as the best preventive measure against YF. One hopes that\nthis is an isolated case, and not an indication of ongoing YF virus\ntransmission in the country or in neighboring Amapá state in Brazil. A map of French Guiana can be accessed at\n(http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/samerica/gf.htm) and a\nmaps of Brazil at (http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6). - Mod.TY A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/577). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"82":{"title":"Oropouche virus - Brazil (02) ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Oropouche virus - Brazil (02) [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nOROPOUCHE VIRUS - BRAZIL (02)\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: Outbreak News Today (edited)\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/oropouche-virus-emerge-cause-public-health-problem-93070/) \nAfter the Zika epidemic, which began in 2015, and the outbreak of\nyellow fever early in 2017, Brazil runs a serious risk of being\nafflicted by Oropouche, another virus that is widely distributed\nthroughout South and Central America and the Caribbean. Oropouche has\nadapted to urban environments and is moving ever closer to Brazil's\nmajor cities. An arbovirus transmitted by a mosquito (like Zika and\nyellow fever), Oropouche causes acute fever and may lead to meningitis\nand meningoencephalitis (inflammation of the brain and meninges). \"Oropouche is a virus that could potentially emerge at any moment and\ncause a serious public health problem in Brazil,\" said Luiz Tadeu\nMoraes Figueiredo, a professor at the University of São Paulo's\nRibeirão Preto Medical School (FMRP-USP). Figueiredo is a researcher\nfor a Thematic Project supported by the São Paulo Research Foundation\n(FAPESP) focusing on emerging zoonotic viroses. According to him, about 500 000 cases of Oropouche fever have been\nreported in Brazil in recent decades but that the number of cases will\ngrow because the virus, transmitted by the midge _Culicoides\nparaensis_, is no longer found only in Amazonian villages and is\nspreading to the big cities. \"_C. paraensis_ is distributed throughout\nthe Americas, and Oropouche virus therefore has considerable emergence\npotential,\" he said. \"The virus may well spread from the Amazon region\nand central plateau to the most densely populated regions of the\ncountry.\" The incidence of Oropouche fever is also rising in urban areas of Peru\nand Caribbean countries. In Brazil, the virus has been isolated from\nbirds in Rio Grande do Sul state and from a marmoset in Minas Gerais\nstate. The presence of neutralizing antibodies (which bind to the\nvirus, tell the immune system to destroy it, and prevent it from\ninfecting the organism) has been detected in primates in the city of\nGoiânia Goiás state. \"We recently diagnosed a patient from Ilhéus\ncity in the northeastern state of Bahia with Oropouche fever, in\npartnership with Eurico Arruda a professor in FMRP-USP's Department\nof Cellular Biology. This shows the virus is circulating around\nBrazil,\" Figueiredo said. In 2002, researchers at FMRP-USP diagnosed 128 people infected by\nOropouche virus in Manaus, Amazonas state's capital city. They\npresented with typical symptoms of the infection, such as acute fever,\njoint pain, headache, and pain behind the eyes; 3 also developed a\ncentral nervous system infection. \"The virus was found in these\npatients' cerebrospinal fluid,\" Figueiredo said. The researchers were\nintrigued to find that one of these 3 patients had neurocysticercosis,\nan infection of the central nervous system caused by the pork tapeworm\n_Taenia solium_, and another had AIDS. \"This shows that some\nimmunodepressive diseases can facilitate penetration of the central\nnervous system by the virus. Hardly anyone thinks of this when\ntreating an arbovirus infection, but the possibility must be\nconsidered,\" Figueiredo said. The 128 patients with Oropouche in Manaus had been clinically\ndiagnosed with dengue fever. The Oropouche and dengue viruses produce\nsimilar symptoms. For this reason, researchers at FMRP-USP and other\ninstitutions such as Fundação Oswaldo Cruz Fiocruz have begun to\nwarn that many suspected cases of dengue in Brazil may be cases of\ninfection by Oropouche. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Oropouche virus is endemic in Brazil and many other countries in\nSouth and Central America and the Caribbean. The report above\nindicates that it is spreading, as the biting midge vector,\n_Culicoides paraensis_, becomes more urbanized in its distribution.\nThe results of blood samples taken in 20 municipalities in Amazonas\nstate indicate the presence of the virus of Oropouche fever. This has\nbeen confirmed by Fiocruz Amazonia in an investigation carried out\ntogether with state health surveillance. The sampling corresponds to\nthe 2011-2016 period. In total, 306 individuals were investigated, and\n9 positives were found among them (see Oropouche virus - Brazil\nhttp://promedmail.org/post/20170814.5247798). Surveillance will need to be intensified, with corresponding\nlaboratory support, to be able to differentiate Oropouche virus\ninfection from infections caused by dengue, chikungunya, and Zika\nviruses. Oropouche virus is a bunyavirus of the Simbu group. No\nvaccine is available, so avoidance of bites by the vector midge is the\nbest preventive measure. Maps of Brazil can be seen at\n(http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6). - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"86":{"title":"Glanders - Brazil: (TO) equine, human susp, RFI ","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Glanders - Brazil: (TO) equine, human susp, RFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nGLANDERS - BRAZIL: (TOCANTINS) EQUINE, HUMAN SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Wed 23 Aug 2017.\nSource: G1 in Portuguese, machine trans., edited\n(http://g1.globo.com/to/tocantins/noticia/vaqueiro-que-cuidava-de-cavalo-sacrificado-por-mormo-pode-ter-sido-infectado.ghtml) \nThe cowboy working on the farm where a case of glanders was confirmed\nin a horse PRO/PORT Mormo - Brazil (02) (TO), equine, confirmed\nhttp://promedmail.org/post/20170823.5270939, is also suspected to\nhave the disease. The information was passed on by the secretary of\nhealth of Palmeirante Tocantins state, Beatriz Ferreira. She noted\nthat examinations have already been made and that steps are being\ntaken to ensure that the disease does not spread. The cowboy's family\nhas been examined, but no one besides him has symptoms of the disease.\nThe main indicators of glanders are fever, skin lesions, nose bumps,\nand pneumonia. The disease is difficult to treat and can be fatal. The cowboy was referred to the Municipal Hospital of Colinas do\nTocantins for tests, but was not admitted. The G1 tried to contact the\ncity hall to ask what the deadline for the outcome was, but the calls\nwere not answered. The farm where the infected horse was isolated and\nthe animal was sacrificed. The neighboring properties are being\ninspected by Adapec Agência de Defesa Agropecuária; Agency of\nFarming Defense. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n(promed-port@promedmail.org) Glanders is an infection caused by _Burkholderia mallei_ and occurs\nprimarily in horses and related animals. It is rare in humans. It is\nunclear what symptoms occurred in the person and how the diagnosis was\nmade. The following appears to be the most recent review of _B. mallei_\ninfections in humans including the description of disease\nmanifestations:\nVan Zandt KE, Greer MT, Gelhaus HC. Glanders: an overview of infection\nin humans. Orphanet J Rare Dis. 2013 Sep 3;8:131. doi:\n10.1186/1750-1172-8-131 (the full text and citations can be found at\nthe original URL\n(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3766238/)). \"Features of human clinical glanders\n\n\"General symptoms\n\"Many forms of glanders have been described, including chronic,\ndisseminated, pulmonary, and septicemic. The variety of infections is\nlargely explained by various routes of infection. Localized infections\nare generally regionally confined and typically characterized by foci\nof suppuration. The abscesses can ulcerate and drain for long periods\nof time. However, localized infections may disseminate, leading to\npulmonary, septicemic, or multi-tissue infection <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>. The most common\nclinical features of the eight laboratory-acquired infections from\nFort Detrick included (in order of most common occurrence) afternoon\nto evening low-grade fever, malaise, fatigue, headache, myalgias\nincluding backache, lymphadenopathy, and chest pain. Approximately\nhalf of the patients not only felt better but were also clinically\nbetter for a period of time after the first wave of disease symptoms.\nThis period lasted from a few days to 2 months then patients developed\nclinical signs of infection. \"Mucosal involvement\n\"Involvement of the eye and conjunctiva in a _B. mallei_ infection\npresents with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. Nasal involvement\nis characterized by inflammation and swelling of the nose, which is\ncommon following inhalation of _B. mallei_. This may be followed by\ncopious nasal discharge. Additionally, infection may invade the nasal\nseptum and bony tissues, causing fistulae and tissue destruction <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>.\nThe face may swell and regional lymph nodes may become inflamed.\nInfection may also extend lower in the respiratory tract, resulting in\nbronchitis which can be accompanied by cough and mucopurulent sputum\nproduction. Constitutional signs and symptoms such as fever and chills\ntypically occur within the first few days following infection.\nAdditionally, these symptoms may persist through treatment and be\nsevere. Common signs and symptoms can include, but are not limited to,\nfever or low-grade fever in the afternoon to evening; chills with or\nwithout rigors; and severe headache <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>. \"Cutaneous involvement\n\"Cutaneous manifestations include papular lesions that may erupt\nanywhere on the body with a more chronic, indolent course of\ninfection. _B. mallei_ entry through an abrasion is typically followed\nby an inflammatory response, including pain and swelling. In these\ncases, a glanders node may appear as a single blister, gradually\ndeveloping into an ulcer that may become hemorrhagic 18,35. A\nlocalized infection with a discharge typically develops at the entry\nsite. Inflammation may extend along regional lymphatics and cause\nlymphangitis with numerous foci of suppuration along their course. The\nendotoxins present in _B. mallei_ strains affect the smooth muscle of\nthe lymphatics <br><br><strong>{9}</strong> by enhancing the irritation and inflammation seen\nin the lymphatics. \"Pulmonary involvement\n\"A pulmonary infection typically results in pneumonia, pulmonary\nabscess, pleuritis, and plural effusion. Signs and symptoms of\npulmonary infection can include cough, dyspnea, chest pain, and\nmucoplurent sputum. Nonspecific signs and symptoms such as fatigue,\nfever (often exceeding 102 deg F 38.9 deg C), chills, headache,\nmyalgias, lymphangitis, sore throat, pleuritic chest pain, cough,\ntachypnea, dyspnea, discharge, and gastrointestinal signs often\naccompany respiratory infections <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>. Many symptoms may take up to 2\nto 3 weeks to develop. Nonspecific signs, such as dizziness, rigors,\nmyalgia, nausea, night sweats, severe headache, tachycardia, weight\nloss, and mucosal eruptions are also usually present and may indicate\na disseminated infection <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>. \"Dissemination of infection\n\"Dissemination from local cutaneous or mucosal infection result in\nsepticemia and the colonization of internal organs such as the spleen,\nliver, and lungs with the development of abscesses <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>.\nUltrasonography and computed tomography may reveal multiple, small\ndiscrete abscesses in both the liver and the kidney <br><br><strong>{23}</strong>. These\ninfections are typically associated with septic shock and high\nmortality.\" This publication describes what seems to have been the last of the\ncases of human _B. mallei_ in the USA:\nSrinivasan A, Kraus CN, DeShazer D, et al. Glanders in a military\nresearch microbiologist. N Engl J Med. 2001; 345: 256-8; (full text\nand citations can be found at the original URL\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM200107263450404) \"Infection with _Burkholderia mallei_ (formerly _Pseudomonas mallei_)\ncan cause a subcutaneous infection known as farcy or can disseminate\nto cause the condition known as glanders. In humans, acute infection\nwith _B. mallei_ is characterized by necrosis of the tracheobronchial\ntree, pustular skin lesions, and either a febrile pneumonia, if the\norganism was inhaled, or signs of sepsis and multiple abscesses, if\nthe skin was the portal of entry (1). At the turn of the 20th century,\nglanders was an important cause of death among horses, and there were\nsecondary, often fatal, infections in humans (2). Because of the\nlethal and contagious nature of the disease, _B. mallei_ was\nconsidered an ideal agent for biologic warfare and was used for this\npurpose by Germany in World War I (3). \"Aggressive control measures essentially eliminated glanders from the\nWest. However, with the resurgent concern about biologic warfare, _B.\nmallei_ is now being studied in laboratories worldwide. We describe\nhere the first reported case of human glanders in the USA in more than\n50 years and discuss some of the important events in the history of\nthe disease and its initial eradication. \"Case report\n\n\"In March 2000, tender, left axillary adenopathy and fever\n(temperature, 38.6 deg C 101.5 deg F) developed in a 33 year old\nmicrobiologist at the US Army Medical Research Institute for\nInfectious Diseases who had type 1 diabetes mellitus. The patient had\nworked for 2 years investigating the basic microbiology of _B. mallei_\nand did not routinely wear latex gloves. The adenopathy and fever\npersisted despite treatment for 10 days with a first-generation\ncephalosporin. An evaluation after this treatment, which included\nchest radiography as well as cultures of blood and urine, was\nunrevealing. During the next few weeks, the patient had increasing\nfatigue, night sweats, malaise, rigors, and weight loss. \"In early April 2000, his symptoms and adenopathy resolved during a\n10-day course of clarithromycin, but he relapsed 4 days after the\nmedication was stopped. On 2 May 2000, he was admitted to his local\nhospital with diabetic ketoacidosis. A computed tomographic (CT) scan\nshowed multiple hepatic and splenic abscesses. \"On 4 May 2000, respiratory distress requiring mechanical ventilation\ndeveloped, and the patient was transferred to Johns Hopkins Hospital\nin Baltimore. Physical examination revealed a temperature of 40.3 deg\nC 104.5 deg F and a heart rate of 122 beats per minute. The patient\nhad a grade 2/6 systolic murmur, coarse breath sounds, and moderate\nepigastric tenderness. Laboratory studies showed a white-cell count of\n8300 per cubic millimeter, with 83 per cent neutrophils, 9 per cent\nmonocytes, and 8 per cent lymphocytes. The hematocrit was 25.6 per\ncent. The concentrations of aspartate aminotransferase and alanine\naminotransferase were 53 U per liter and 56 U per liter, respectively,\nand the alkaline phosphatase was 197 IU per liter. Cultures of the\npatient's blood and a sample from a fine-needle aspiration biopsy of a\nliver abscess grew a small, bipolar, weakly staining, gram-negative\nrod that was identified by an automated bacterial-identification\nsystem as _Pseudomonas fluorescens_ or _P. putida_. However,\ngas-liquid chromatography of the cellular fatty acids (Microbial ID,\nNewark, Del.) placed the organism in the genus _Burkholderia_.\nSubsequent phenotypic testing and 16S ribosomal RNA gene-sequence\nanalysis identified the organism as _B. mallei_. Initial\nsusceptibility testing showed the isolate to be sensitive to imipenem,\nceftazidime, and tetracycline. \"The patient was treated with imipenem and doxycycline, and there was\nrapid improvement. After two weeks, the imipenem was replaced by\nazithromycin, and the patient completed a six-month course of\ntreatment with azithromycin and doxycycline. Although the organism was\nfound retrospectively to be relatively resistant to azithromycin, a CT\nscan obtained after six months of treatment showed substantial\nimprovement of the liver and spleen abscesses, and one year later the\npatient remained in good health. \"Discussion\n\nThis is the 1st reported human case of glanders in the\nEnglish-language medical literature since 1949 (4) and it occurred in\nthe context of research on agents of biologic warfare. \"Glanders may have been the first biologic weapon of the 20th century.\nDuring World War I, Germany had a program of biologic sabotage against\nseveral countries, including the United States, whereby cultures of\n_B. mallei_ and anthrax were distributed to undercover agents who\nattempted to infect livestock that were to be shipped to Allied\ncountries (3). The intention was both the destruction of livestock and\nthe transmission of the highly contagious, lethal agent from livestock\nto humans. It is currently suspected that attempts are being made to\ndevelop an aerosolized form of antibiotic-resistant _B. mallei_ that\ncould become a biologic weapon as potent as anthrax. \"Glanders, an important human and veterinary disease, was eliminated\nwithout a vaccine or effective treatment. It appears to have been\nabolished by the veterinary use of a skin test to detect exposure to\nB. mallei combined with draconian agricultural measures to control\ninfection (5). \"At the turn of the 20th century, Canada, Britain, and the USA all\nimplemented glanders-control programs. By that time, the symptoms of\nequine glanders, which include fever and inflammation of the nasal\nmucosa with ultimate necrosis and obstruction of the oropharynx, had\nbeen well described (6). Laws were passed that required notification\nof the health department and the immediate slaughter of affected\nanimals, with proper disposal of the carcasses. In addition, all\nhorses on the premises where the infected horses were found had to be\ntested with the mallein skin test for exposure to _B. mallei_; any\nhorses with a reaction also had to be slaughtered. Horses with no\nreaction were quarantined and then retested two to three weeks later.\nFurthermore, the equine contacts of the horses were traced to track\ndown other horses that might have been exposed and then moved to other\nfacilities. \"The case we describe illustrates the major clinical features of\nglanders, which can usually be traced to direct contact with _B.\nmallei_, as in workers exposed to animals with glanders (7) and in\npersonnel who were exposed in laboratories during World War II (8).\nAlthough the patient discussed here could not recall a clear break in\nhis skin or an accident in the laboratory, most reported occupational\ninfections occur without recognized instances of exposure (9). As\nRobins commented in 1906, \"It is perhaps not advisable to be too\ndogmatic as to the invariable necessity of an abrasion being present\nin every case of human glanders . . . as in several such cases of\nour series it is distinctly stated that there was no abrasion.\" (7).\nAs in our patient, _B. mallei_ often enters the body through the hand\nor arm. After an incubation period lasting between a few days and\nseveral weeks, local suppuration and regional lymphadenopathy occur.\nConstitutional symptoms often accompany the infection, with fever,\nrigors, and malaise predominating. If the infection is left untreated,\nabscesses in the lymph nodes will generally form, then break down and\ndrain. \"Dissemination of the infection occurs 1 to 4 weeks after infection of\nthe lymph nodes. Abscesses can be widespread, and _B. mallei_ can\ninfect almost any tissue (7). Abscesses in the liver and the spleen,\nas were seen in our patient, appear to be relatively common, as does\npulmonary involvement, including consolidation, abscesses, and pleural\nnodules. The acute onset and rapid resolution of the respiratory\nfailure in our patient were more consistent with the respiratory\ndistress syndrome associated with gram-negative bacteremia than with\nthat associated with pulmonary glanders. Subcutaneous and\nintramuscular abscesses sometimes develop as well (7). \"There are few data regarding the antibiotic treatment of glanders,\nsince the disease had largely disappeared by the time antibiotics\nbecame available. In vitro, ceftazidime, gentamicin, imipenem,\ndoxycycline, and ciprofloxacin all have reliable activity against _B.\nmallei_ (10), and our patient's infection responded well to a\ncombination of imipenem and doxycycline. Experimentally induced\nglanders also responds to a combination of sulfazine and trimethoprim\n(11). However, treatment of the disease in the setting of bioterrorism\nmay be more difficult if the organism is drug-resistant. \"This case demonstrates the difficulties that microbiology\nlaboratories may have in recognizing potential agents of biologic\nwarfare. These microbes are rarely encountered and may be\nmisidentified by conventional, phenotypic identification systems.\nTechniques such as cellular analysis of fatty acid and 16S ribosomal\nRNA gene sequencing can be used to identify the organisms correctly,\nbut these tests are not widely available. \"Finally, this case may serve as a harbinger of the resurgence of\nnearly forgotten diseases such as glanders, plague, smallpox, and\nanthrax. Research on these diseases is now being conducted in more\nlaboratories, which increases the risk of occupational exposure. There\nis also the looming threat that some group will eventually mount a\nsuccessful campaign of bioterrorism. Resources must be allocated both\nto prevent and to prepare for these frightening possibilities.\" Maps of Brazil can be seen at\n(http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62881). The state of Tocantins is\nlocated in central Brazil. - Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]},"136":{"title":"Zika virus (17): Americas, research, observations ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Zika virus (17): Americas, research, observations [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nZIKA VIRUS (16): AMERICAS, RESEARCH, OBSERVATIONS\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries: Americas\n\nAmericas cumulative case numbers Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-23 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html)\nState / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 22 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 31 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 7 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 6 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 43 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 5 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 3 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 215 / 9 - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 39 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 41 / 0\nTotal 555 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ribavirin inhibits Zika virus.\nDate: 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Antiviral Research journal (edited)\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166354217301973) \nref: Kamiyama N, Soma R, Hidano S, et al. Ribavirin inhibits Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) replication in vitro and suppresses viremia in\nZIKV-infected STAT1-deficient mice. Antiviral Res. 2017; 146: 1-11.\ndoi: 10.1016/j.antiviral.2017.08.007\n-\nHighlights\n- Ribavirin inhibits ZIKV replication in mammalian cells.\n- Ribavirin prevents ZIKV-induced apoptosis and cell death.\n- Ribavirin administration abrogates viremia in ZIKV-infected\nSTAT1-deficient mice.\n- Leading to a prolonged survival.\nAbstract\nZika fever, a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Zika virus\n(ZIKV), is an epidemic disease for which no effective therapy has been\nestablished. The recent outbreaks of ZIKV in Brazil and French\nPolynesia have been linked to a considerable increase in the incidence\nof fetal microcephaly and other diseases such as Guillain-Barre\nsyndrome. Because there is currently no specific therapy or vaccine,\nthe early exploitation of a method to prevent expansion of ZIKV is a\nhigh priority. To validate commonly used antiviral drugs, we evaluated\nthe effect of ribavirin, a drug used to treat hepatitis C with\ninterferon-beta (IFN-beta), on ZIKV replication. In mammalian cells,\nwe observed an inhibitory effect of ribavirin on ZIKV replication and\nZIKV-induced cell death without cytotoxic effect. Furthermore, we\nfound that STAT1-deficient mice, which lack type I IFN signaling, were\nhighly sensitive to ZIKV infection and exhibited lethal outcome.\nRibavirin abrogated viremia in ZIKV-infected STAT-1-deficient mice.\nThese data suggest that the inhibition of viral RNA-dependent RNA\npolymerases may be effective for treatment of ZIKV infection. Our data\nprovide a new insight into the mechanisms for inhibition of ZIKV\nreplication and prevention of Zika fever. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It will be interesting to see if these encouraging results showing\ninhibition of Zika virus replication can be replicated in non-human\nprimates. The challenge for use of drugs to inhibit Zika virus\ninfection in humans is that most (around 80 percent) Zika virus\ninfections are asymptomatic or have very mild symptoms. These\nindividuals will probably not seek medical treatment, even though\ntheir fetuses are at risk of infection with teratogenic effects. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Zika virus skewed immunosuppression.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Microbiology journal (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/articles/s41564-017-0016-3) \nref: Foo SS, Chen W, Chan Y, et al. Asian Zika virus strains target\nCD14+ blood monocytes and induce M2-skewed immunosuppression during\npregnancy. Nat Microbiol. 2017. doi: 10.1038/s41564-017-0016-3\n-\nAbstract\nBlood CD14+ monocytes are frontline immunomodulators categorized into\nclassical, intermediate or non-classical subsets, and subsequently\ndifferentiated into M1 pro- or M2 anti-inflammatory macrophages on\nstimulation. Although the Zika virus (ZIKV) rapidly establishes\nviraemia, the target cells and immune responses, particularly during\npregnancy, remain elusive. Furthermore, it is unknown whether African-\nand Asian-lineage ZIKV have different phenotypic impacts on host\nimmune responses. Using human blood infection, we identified CD14+\nmonocytes as the primary target for African- or Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection. When immunoprofiles of human blood infected with ZIKV were\ncompared, a classical/intermediate monocyte-mediated M1-skewed\ninflammation by the African-lineage ZIKV infection was observed, in\ncontrast to a non-classical monocyte-mediated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression by the Asian-lineage ZIKV infection. Importantly,\ninfection of the blood of pregnant women revealed an enhanced\nsusceptibility to ZIKV infection. Specifically, Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection of pregnant women's blood led to an exacerbated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression of non-classical monocytes in conjunction with a\nglobal suppression of type I interferon-signaling pathway and an\naberrant expression of host genes associated with pregnancy\ncomplications. Also, 30 ZIKV+ sera from symptomatic pregnant patients\nshowed elevated levels of M2-skewed immunosuppressive cytokines and\npregnancy-complication-associated fibronectin-1. This study\ndemonstrates the differential immunomodulatory responses of blood\nmonocytes, particularly during pregnancy, on infection with different\nlineages of ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Virus alters mosquito genes.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: bioRxiv journal (edited)\n(http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/08/22/179416) \nref: Etebari K, Hegde S, Saldana MA, et al. Global transcriptome\nanalysis of _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to Zika virus\ninfection. bioRxiv 179416; doi:10.1101/179416\n-\nZika virus (ZIKV) of the Flaviviridae family is a recently emerged\nmosquito-borne virus that has been implicated in the surge of the\nnumber of microcephaly instances in South America. The recent rapid\nspread of the virus led to its declaration as a global health\nemergency by the World Health Organization. The virus is transmitted\nmainly by the mosquito _Aedes aegypti_ that also vectors dengue virus,\nhowever little is known about the interactions of the virus with the\nmosquito vector. In this study, we investigated the transcriptome\nprofiles of whole _Ae. aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to ZIKV\ninfection at 2, 7, and 14 days post-infection using RNA-Seq. Results\nshowed changes in the abundance of a large number of transcripts at\neach time point following infection, with 18 transcripts commonly\nchanged among the 3 time points. Gene ontology analysis revealed that\nmost of the altered genes are involved in metabolic process, cellular\nprocess and proteolysis. In addition, 486 long intergenic non-coding\nRNAs were identified altered upon ZIKV infection. Further, we found\ncorrelational changes of a number of potential mRNA target genes with\nthat of altered host microRNAs. The outcomes provide a basic\nunderstanding of _Ae. aegypti_ responses to ZIKV and helps to\ndetermine host factors involved in replication or mosquito host\nanti-viral response against the virus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Mosquito vector competence depends on the relationship of virus and\nthe mosquito, and the defenses that the mosquito can mobilize against\nthe virus infection. Studies, such as the one above, can document the\nchanges that occur when the virus infects the mosquito, and if\ndifferences in relative vector efficiency of different geographic\nstrains of this mosquito might be related to alternations in mosquito\ngenes when infected. It would be interesting to know if these gene\nchanges affect fitness, and especially longevity of infected\nmosquitoes. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Virus effects on sperm, body fluids.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Lancet Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30444-9/abstract) \nref: Joguet G, Mansuy JM, Matusali G, et al. Effect of acute Zika\nvirus infection on sperm and virus clearance in body fluids: a\nprospective observational study. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii:\nS1473-3099(17)30444-9. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30444-9\n-\nSummary\nBackground\nEvidence of human sexual transmission during Zika virus emergence is a\nmatter of concern, particularly in procreation, but to date, kinetics\nof seminal shedding and the effects of infection on human reproductive\nfunction have not been described. To investigate the effects of Zika\nvirus infection on semen and clearance of Zika virus from semen and\nbody fluids, we aimed to study a cohort of Zika virus-infected men. Methods\nThis prospective observational study recruited men presenting with\nacute Zika virus infection at Pointe-Ã -Pitre University Hospital in\nGuadeloupe, French Caribbean, where a Zika virus outbreak occurred\nbetween April and November, 2016. Blood, urine, and semen were\ncollected at days 7, 11, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 after symptom onset,\nand semen characteristics, such as total sperm count, sperm motility,\nvitality, and morphology, and reproductive hormone concentrations,\nsuch as testosterone, inhibin, follicle-stimulating hormone, and\nluteinising hormone, were assessed. At days 7, 11, and 20, semen was\nprocessed to isolate motile spermatozoa. Zika virus RNA was detected\nby RT-PCR using whole blood, serum, urine, seminal plasma, semen\ncells, and motile spermatozoa fractions. Zika virus was isolated from\ndifferent sperm fractions on Vero E6 cultures. Findings\n15 male volunteers (mean age 35 years SD 5; range 25-44) with acute\nZika virus infection and positive Zika virus RNA detection in blood or\nurine were enrolled. Total sperm count was decreased from median\n119âÃâ10^6 spermatozoa (IQR interquartile range 22-234)\nat day 7, to 45.2âÃâ10^6 (16.5-89.6) at day 30, and 70\nÃ 10^6 (28.5-81.4) at day 60, respectively, after Zika virus\ninfection. Inhibin values increased from 93.5 pg/mL (IQR 55-162) at\nday 7 to 150 pg/mL (78-209) at day 120 when total sperm count\nrecovered. In motile spermatozoa obtained after density gradient\nseparation, Zika virus RNA was found in 3 of 14 patients at day 7, 4\nof 15 at day 11, and 4 of 15 at day 20, and replication-competent\nvirus was found in the tested patient. Seminal shedding kinetics\nseemed heterogeneous among patients. Whole blood was the fluid most\nfrequently positive for Zika virus RNA (62 of 92 samples) and 3\npatients remained positive at day 120. Interpretation\nSemen alterations early after acute Zika virus infection might affect\nfertility and could be explained by virus effects on the testis and\nepididymis. Frequency of shedding and high viral load in semen,\ntogether with the presence of replicative virus in a motile\nspermatozoa fraction, can lead to Zika virus transmission during\nsexual contact and assisted reproduction procedures. Whole blood seems\nto be the best specimen for Zika virus RNA detection, diagnosis, and\nfollow-up. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall In a new study that included 12 men in French Guiana who had Zika\nvirus, 4 never had any detectable Zika in their semen, 1 excreted Zika\nvirus in his semen for at least 3 days, and 7 had Zika virus in semen\nfor at least 1 month. The maximum duration of detectable Zika in semen\nin the study was 45 days ((http://tinyurl.com/y9nhtgtk)). This report\nwas provided by Roland HÃ¼bner. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Vaccine update.\nDate: 22/29 Aug 2017.\nSource: Journal of the American Medical Association, JAMA (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2649168) \nref: Lyon J. Vaccines protect fetus from Zika. JAMA. 2017; 318(8):\n689. doi:10.1001/jama.2017.11200\n-\nResearchers funded in part by the National Institutes of Health have\nrecently demonstrated that 2 experimental vaccines can restrict\ntransmission of Zika virus from pregnant mice to their fetuses,\nthereby shielding offspring from congenital damage or death. Multiple candidate Zika vaccines have been shown protective against\ninfection with the virus in animal studies, with several now in human\ntrials, but none were tested in the context of pregnancy, according to\nthe authors of the study published in Cell\n(http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(17)30759-6). The 2\nvaccine candidates investigated in the new study are the 1st to\ndemonstrate efficacy in preventing vertical transmission of the virus\nand related fetal death in an animal model. Although the vaccines were\nadministered to female mice prior to pregnancy, the result is\nconsidered an important step toward developing a vaccine that could be\nsafely given to pregnant women. One of the 2 candidates is a modified messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine\nencoding Zika genes, developed by the biotechnology company Moderna.\nIt is already in safety trials in women who are not pregnant. The\nother is a live-attenuated Zika strain developed by researchers at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB). The testing was carried out by scientists from the National Institute\nof Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Washington University School of\nMedicine, and UTMB. The researchers 1st vaccinated the mice with 1 of\nthe vaccines or a placebo. After mating, the animals were challenged\nwith the virus 6 days into pregnancy. A week later, more than 50\npercent of placentas and fetuses from mice administered the mRNA\nvaccine had virtually no Zika RNA. The remainder had \"substantially\nlower\" levels relative to placebo.\nThe live vaccine provided broader protection: 78 percent of placentas\nand 83 percent of fetuses had Zika RNA at or below the level of\ndetection, while the placebo group exhibited significantly higher\nlevels of placental and fetal Zika RNA. Mice vaccinated with either\nvaccine had significantly higher rates of fetal viability; whereas 100\npercent of fetuses from mice vaccinated with the mRNA vaccine were\nborn, none survived to term in the placebo group. A working group funded by the Wellcome Trust recently approved ethical\nguidelines for testing such vaccines in pregnant women, normally\nexcluded from drug trials. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It is reassuring to learn that at least 2 vaccines are now entering\nclinical trials in women. Although anti-Zika virus drugs are under\ndevelopment, preventing infection through vaccination seems to be the\nmost effective measure to prevent fetal infection and adverse effects\nof the virus infection in adults. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"160":{"title":"Inappropriate vaccinia virus use - USA: (CA) stem cell clinic\r\n\t","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Inappropriate vaccinia virus use - USA: (CA) stem cell clinic\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nINAPPROPRIATE VACCINIA VIRUS USE - USA: (CALIFORNIA) STEM CELL CLINIC\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Mon 28 Aug 2017.\nSource: New York Times (edited)\n(https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/28/health/fda-stem-cell.html?_r=1) \nThe FDA US Food and Drug Administration announced a crackdown on\ndangerous stem cell clinics on Mon 28 Aug 2017, while at the same\ntime pledging to ease the path to approval for companies and doctors\nwith legitimate treatments in the growing field. The agency reported\nactions against 2 large stem cell clinics and a biotech company,\nsaying that it was critical to shut down \"unscrupulous actors\" in\nregenerative medicine, a broad umbrella that includes stem cell and\ngene therapies and immunotherapies. \"The FDA will not allow deceitful\nactors to take advantage of vulnerable patients by purporting to have\ntreatments or cures for serious diseases without any proof that they\nactually work,\" said Dr Scott Gottlieb, the FDA commissioner. Stem cells, which can be extracted from bone marrow, blood, or fat,\ncan develop into many different types of cells, and are thought to\nhave the potential to repair or replace tissue damaged by disease,\ninjury, or aging. But so far, the FDA has approved only a few\nstem-cell products. The companies that the FDA cited have been performing liposuction to\nremove belly fat from patients, extracting stem cells and then\ninjecting those cells back into the patients to treat various\nailments. On Fri 25 Aug 2017, the agency said, federal marshals seized 500\ndoses of live vaccinia virus vaccine for smallpox belonging to\nStemImmune Inc., a San Diego firm that develops stem cell-based\nimmunotherapies for cancer. The raid came after the FDA learned that\nthe vaccine was being used to create an unapproved stem cell product,\na combination of excess amounts of vaccine and stem cells derived from\nbody fat, which was then administered to cancer patients with\npotentially compromised immune systems. The FDA said patients at the\nCalifornia Stem Cell Treatment Centers in Rancho Mirage and Beverly\nHills, California, received the treatment made with the smallpox\nvaccine. It also said it had serious concerns about how StemImmune\nobtained the vaccine for use in an unapproved and potentially\ndangerous treatment. StemImmune obtained at least some of the vaccine from the CDC,\naccording to Thomas Skinner, a CDC spokesman. In its request, the\ncompany said it was conducting cancer research involving the vaccinia\nvirus, and needed to vaccinate researchers  a seemingly legitimate\nreason. The company did not tell the CDC that it was going to inject\nthe vaccine into patients, he said. A statement from StemImmune said\nthe company had lawfully obtained the drug. The FDA also issued a warning letter to US Stem Cell, a private clinic\nin Sunrise, Florida. The company was the subject of a March 2017\nreport in The New England Journal of Medicine, describing how one\nwoman went blind and 2 others suffered severe, permanent eye damage\nafter being given shots of stem cells, extracted from fat, into their\neyes. The warning letter accused the company of impairing the FDA's\nability to conduct its inspection by refusing to allow inspectors in,\nand denying them access to employees. It also said that US Stem Cell\nhad failed to establish proper quality control and sanitary\nstandards. The entire article related to FDA issues with stem cell clinics can\nbe found at the source URL above. - Mod.LL Byline: Sheila Kaplan, Denise Grady \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Clearly scientifically inappropriate use of stem cells by\n\"unscrupulous\" clinics is occurring as discussed in the article above.\nThe posting of this on ProMED was precipitated by the report of the\nsmallpox vaccine, referred to as vaccinia, administered with stem\ncells by injecting directly into a tumor. The current vaccine\n\"ACAM2000\" is the same virus as the former \"Dryvax\" except that the\nvirus is grown in tissue culture rather than from inoculation of\ncalves. The only approved indication for the vaccine is to protect\nindividuals who are working with variations of the vaccinia vaccine in\nlaboratories and for military personnel or others who theoretically\ncould be exposed to smallpox as a biowarfare event. I recently immunized several dozen laboratory workers with ACAM2000\nrelated to work they will be doing with a recombinant vaccinia virus\nin an animal model. In order to obtain the vaccine, we had to fill out\na request form with a list of individuals to be immunized. As a\nreminder, the technique for immunization is \"scarification\" where a\nsmall amount of the reconstituted virus is introduced into the skin\nusing a bifurcated needle\n((https://jetinfectors.files.wordpress.com/2017/01/bifurcated-needle-1.jpg?w=401&h=261)).\nThe primary \"take\" is a vesicle/pustule developing about 7 days later\n(shown at\n(http://health.mo.gov/emergencies/ert/pdf/SmallpoxVaccinationReactions.pdf)).\nOne contraindication for use is in immunocompromised hosts (including\nsome patients with cancer) and the virus is never inoculated by other\ntechniques. More information about vaccination can be obtained from\nthe CDC at (https://www.cdc.gov/smallpox/vaccine-basics/index.html). Currently in press in Lancet Infectious Diseases, Clarissa Damaso from\nInstituto de Biofísica Carlos Chagas Filho, Universidade Federal do\nRio de Janeiro, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil has written an excellent review\non the history of smallpox vaccines: Damaso CR: Revisiting Jenner's mysteries, the role of the Beaugency\nlymph in the evolutionary path of ancient smallpox vaccines. Lancet\nInfect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30445-0. doi:\n10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30445-0; full text, references, and figures\navailable at\n(http://www.thelancet.com/pdfs/journals/laninf/PIIS1473-3099(17)30445-0.pdf): \"The origins of Jenner's vaccine have been intensively debated over\nthe years. British researcher Downie studied the close immunological\nrelationship of variola, cowpox, and vaccinia viruses, which led him\nto propose in 1951 that vaccinia virus had emerged from cowpox virus\nin the early years of vaccination (26). In 1965, Downie strongly\nopposed Peter Razzell's proposal that vaccinia virus had derived from\nan attenuated form of variola virus (27-29). Derrick Baxby (1940-2017)\nalso refuted Razzell's belief and proposed in 1981 that modern 20th\ncentury vaccines had derived from horsepox virus (30-32). In fact, we\ncurrently know that vaccinia virus is more closely related to horsepox\nvirus than to cowpox virus. On the basis of full-genome analysis and\nrecent phylogenetic inferences, horsepox virus is considered an\nancestor of the vaccinia lineage (33-36). Because all modern smallpox\nvaccine strains consist of vaccinia virus, one would expect that\nhorsepox virus, or even vaccinia virus, would be better candidates\nthan cowpox virus for the original source of Jenner's vaccine.\nAlthough an attractive hypothesis, the obscure history of cowpox,\nhorsepox, and vaccinia viruses further adds to the mystery. Since the\nmid-20th century, cows have been rarely found sick because of\ninfection by cowpox virus, and only felines, pet rodents, and zoo\nanimals, primarily in Europe, have been affected by the virus in the\npast decades (37-40). As for horsepox, the disease is rare and some\nbelieve it is extinct, at least in Europe (23,24,31,32,41). Only one\nexisting strain of horsepox virus obtained from Mongolian horses in\n1976 is currently known (33). However, vaccinia virus has never been\nfound naturally occurring in animals, except in India, where the\nstrain buffalopox infects buffaloes, and in Brazil, where the strain\nCantagalo (Cantagalo virus) infects dairy cows (2,42-44). In any case,\nall 3 orthopoxviruses cause zoonotic infections, and individuals\nacquire the infection when handling infected animals figures 2 and 3\n(2,22,37,40,45,46)\" \"The history and evolutionary relationships of the different smallpox\nvaccine strains remain obscure, because most strains and clonal\nvariants have not yet been completely sequenced. Historical and\nscientific evidence suggests that the Beaugency lymph lymph passed in\ncows by Chambon and Lanoix and, in October, 1866, they mixed this\nmaterial with lymph obtained from a 2nd natural case of cowpox\ndiscovered in Saint-Mandé, in the suburbs of Paris. The mixture was\nreferred to as the Beaugency lymph and was used subsequently by the\nAnimal Vaccine Institute as a seed to produce the vaccine\n(20,48,72,74) and horsepox virus made a strong contribution to the\ngenetic makeup of the existing vaccine strains, particularly those\nfrom continental Europe, USA, and Brazil. Evidence also suggests that\nthe Beaugency lymph was probably a vaccinia virus strain or a close\nancestor related to horsepox virus, and not a cowpox strain. Thus, it\nis reasonable to believe not only that cowpox virus was not used as a\nsmallpox vaccine in the 19th century, but that it might have never\nbeen used at all. Assumptions about the origins of the Beaugency lymph\nalso indicate that vaccinia virus was once a circulating virus in\nanimals in Europe in the 19th century, but later it disappeared and\nnow has no natural hosts, except in Brazil, India, and perhaps in\nEgypt, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Nepal. Many questions still persist,\nand analysis of full-genome sequences of ancient vaccine strains would\nhelp unravel this fascinating medical mystery.\" - Mod.LL A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"297":{"title":"Dengue/DHF update (11): Americas","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Dengue/DHF update (11): Americas","summary":"\nDENGUE/DHF UPDATE (11): AMERICAS\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nCases in various countries:\nAmericas regional\n\nCases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. Date: Wed 6 Sep 2017. Source: Medical Xpress, The Associated Press (AP) report (edited) (https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-09-brazil-declares-yellow-fever-outbreak.html)   Brazil's Health Ministry has declared an end to a yellow fever outbreak that killed more 250 people over the past 9 months.  The ministry said Wed 6 Sep 2017 that the last case of the mosquito-borne disease was in June. In total, 777 people were infected, of whom 261 died.  The outbreak was highly unusual in a country that typically sees a handful of cases each year. The disease also occurred in areas not previously considered at risk and where vaccination rates were low.  In response, Brazil mounted a massive vaccination campaign, sending out more than 36.7 million doses. Vaccination efforts are continuing since the ministry says the average coverage rate in areas that bore the brunt of the outbreak is around 60 percent, below the target of 95 percent.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org) and ProMED-mail Rapporteur George Robertson  It is good to learn that the yellow fever (YF) outbreak in Brazil has been officially declared over. The good news that emerged during the outbreak is that all the YF cases were reported to have been due to spill-over from the sylvan (forest) cycle of transmission, and not to the urban cycle transmitted by _Aedes aegypti_, which could have resulted in a much bigger outbreak in this under-vaccinated population. The occurrence of the YF case in the neighboring country of French Guiana is a reminder that YF virus is endemic in the general area.  Maps of Brazil can be accessed at (http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6). A map showing Brazil and French Guiana can be accessed at (http://www.worldatlas.com/webimage/countrys/samerica/southamericalarge.jpg). - Mod.TY   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Vaccine coverage gaps. Date: Wed 16 Aug 2017. Source: The Lancet Infectious Diseases (edited) (http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30419-X/fulltext)   ref: Shearer FM, Moyes CL, Pigott DM, et al. Global yellow fever vaccination coverage from 1970 to 2016: an adjusted retrospective analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30419-X. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30419-X. Epub ahead of print - Summary - Background Substantial outbreaks of yellow fever in Angola and Brazil in the past 2 years, combined with global shortages in vaccine stockpiles, highlight a pressing need to assess present control strategies. The aims of this study were to estimate global yellow fever vaccination coverage from 1970 through to 2016 at high spatial resolution and to calculate the number of individuals still requiring vaccination to reach population coverage thresholds for outbreak prevention.  Methods For this adjusted retrospective analysis, we compiled data from a range of sources (such as, WHO reports and health-service-provider registries) reporting on yellow fever vaccination activities between 1 May 1939, and 29 Oct 2016. To account for uncertainty in how vaccine campaigns were targeted, we calculated 3 population coverage values to encompass alternative scenarios. We combined these data with demographic information and tracked vaccination coverage through time to estimate the proportion of the population who had ever received a yellow fever vaccine for each 2nd level administrative division across countries at risk of yellow fever virus transmission from 1970 to 2016.  Findings Overall, substantial increases in vaccine coverage have occurred since 1970, but notable gaps still exist in contemporary coverage within yellow fever risk zones. We estimate that between 393 million and 472 million people still require vaccination in areas at risk of yellow fever virus transmission to achieve the 80 percent population coverage threshold recommended by WHO; this represents between 43 percent and 52 percent of the population within yellow fever risk zones, compared with between 66 percent and 76 percent of the population who would have required vaccination in 1970.  Interpretation Our results highlight important gaps in yellow fever vaccination coverage, can contribute to improved quantification of outbreak risk, and help to guide planning of future vaccination efforts and emergency stockpiling.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Both reports above point out the adverse consequences of inadequate vaccination coverage. Although it is expensive to track the proportion of the population that is vaccinated over time, and mount ongoing population coverage to reach 80 percent or more, dealing with significant outbreaks such as the ones in Angola and Brazil is much more expensive in terms of finances and human lives. Brazil wisely continues vaccination campaigns to reach this level. One hopes that institutional memories are sufficiently strong to continue coverage over the long-term. - Mod.TY  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Brunei":{},"Bulgaria":{"197":{"title":"Brucellosis - Bulgaria (06): (SL, BL) melitensis,\r\n\tlivestock, OIE ","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Bulgaria (06): (SL, BL) melitensis,\r\n\tlivestock, OIE [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 4 Sep 2017. Source: OIE, WAHID (edited) (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24628)   Brucellosis (_Brucella melitensis_), Bulgaria  Information received on and dated 4 Sep 2017 from Dr Damyan Iliev, Chief Veterinary Officer & Deputy Executive Director, Bulgarian Food Safety Agency, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria   \nReport type: Immediate notification Date of start of the event: 8 Aug 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 8 Aug 2017 Reason for notification: Recurrence of a listed disease Date of previous occurrence: 2 Nov 2016 Manifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection Causal agent: _Brucella melitensis_ Nature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic) This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.  New outbreaks (4) Outbreak 1: Rechitsa, Sliven Date of start of the outbreak: 8 Aug 2017 Outbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: Farm Affected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Goats / 105 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0 Sheep / 125 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0  Outbreak 2: Gergevec, Sliven Date of start of the outbreak: 11 Aug 2017 Outbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: Backyard Affected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Sheep/ goats / 257 / 21 / 0 / 21 / 0  Outbreak 3: Kochan, Blagoevgard Date of start of the outbreak: 18 Aug 2017 Outbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: Backyard Affected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Sheep / 205 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0  Outbreak 4: Kochan, Satovcha, Blagoevgard Date of start of the outbreak: 23 Aug 2017 Outbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: Backyard Affected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Sheep/ goats / 368 / 10 / 0 / 10 / 0  Summary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 4 Total animals affected: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered Goats / 105 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0 Sheep / 330 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0 Sheep / goats / 625 / 31 / 0 / 31 / 0 Outbreak statistics: rates apparent, expressed as percentages: Species / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost* Goats / 2.86 / 0 / 0 / 2.86 Sheep / 0.91 / 0 / 0 / 0.91 Sheep / goats / 4.96 / 0 / 0 / 4.96 *Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter  Epidemiology: Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive  Control measures Measures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals  Measures to be applied: no other measures  Future Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  \"Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats (excluding _B. ovis_ infection) is primarily caused by one of the 3 biovars of _B. melitensis_. Sporadic infections caused by _B. abortus_ or _B. suis_ have been observed in sheep and goats, but such cases are extremely rare. Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread worldwide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are northern and central Europe, southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand.  Pathologically and epidemiologically, _B. melitensis_ infection in sheep and goats is very similar to _B. abortus_ infection in cattle. In most circumstances, the primary routes of transmission of Brucella are the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges expelled by infected ewes and goats when they abort or have full-term parturition. Shedding of Brucella is also common in udder secretions and semen, and Brucella may be isolated from various tissues, such as lymph nodes from the head, spleen and organs associated with reproduction (uterus, epididymides and testes), and from arthritic lesions\" (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf).  \"_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 B. melitensis vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin\" (http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_melitensis.pdf). - Mod.CRD  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/81).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Burkina Faso":{"306":{"title":"PRO/EDR> Malaria - Italy (02): fatal case, non-travel related","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Malaria - Italy (02): fatal case, non-travel related","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 6 Sep 2017. From: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project (edited)   ProMED circulated a request for further information through the Epi-Core network, and this is a summary of the various responses we received:  Reconstruction of the history 1. Prior to onset of illness, the family was staying at Bibione, Province of Venice (seaside resort) and on 13 Aug 2017, the girl was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus at the Portogruaro hospital (40 km approx 28 mi north of Venice). 2. The family including the girl returned to Trento where they live on 16 Aug 2017 and she was admitted to the hospital for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. She was discharged on 21 Aug 2017. 3. On 16 Aug 2017, 2 children from Burkina Faso with falciparum malaria were admitted to the same children's ward in Trento hospital. 4. Fever was reported in the girl on 28 Aug 2017, the fever then disappeared but returned on 30 Aug 2017 when she was again hospitalized at Trento hospital. Malaria was diagnosed and treatment was started. On 2 Sep 2017 she was air-lifted to the University Hospital in Brescia with a diagnosis of cerebral malaria.   \n<br><br>Communicated by: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project (promed@promedmail.org)  ProMED-mail would like to thank all of the EpiCore members who responded to the request for more information on this event.   The overlap with the 2 cases from Burkina Faso was 5 days and thus infection would have had to have beeen through direct transmission by blood and not through mosquitoes. If the needle used for blood sugar testing in some manner was shared between the known malaria patients and the young girl who had been hospitalized for diabetes, then nosocomial transmission is a possibility.  An alternative possibility is that the infection occurred from local Italian mosquitoes that had been infected by an asymptomatic gametocyte carrier. This is well known to happen and malaria was endemic in northern Italy in the past especially in the period between both world wars when there was a high prevalence of the disease, but it was _P.vivax_ and not _P. falciparum_. Whether the local mosquitoes (_A. maculipennis_ complex) are capable of transmitting _P. falciparum_ malaria is not known, but the possibility is not excluded.  )From infection to the debut of symptoms, the incubation period is usually 7 - 10 days in non-immune individuals. If the hospitalization for the suspected diabetes mellitus in Portogruaro hospital was in fact when she presented with the 1st symptoms of malaria, then she was most likely infected 7 - 10 days previously, however, fever would have been a key presenting symptom.  Thus the key question is when did the 1st symptoms of malaria actually appear  and the only certain point in the information we presently have is that she was febrile on 28 Aug 2017.  There is a huge variability from the time the symptoms started to the time of death in imported (non-immune) malaria cases. A large study of 22 fatal outcomes of patient with _P. falciparum_ malaria returning to Switzerland (Christen et al. Am J Trop Med Hyg 2006;75:1188-94) reported an average of 8 days with a low of 3 days. Thus if the 1st symptoms of malaria were on 28 Aug 2017, the date of actual infection must have taken place within the 10 prior days.  Does the climate allow development of the malaria parasite in the mosquito? The average temperature for Trento in August 2017 is found here: (https://www.accuweather.com/en/it/trento/216357/august-weather/216357). The average night temperature is only reaching 20 C (approx. 68 F) on 18 Aug 2017, otherwise it was well below 20 C (approx. 68 F) with a low of 13 C (approx. 55 F). In order to allow _P.falciparum_ to develop in mosquitoes, the average night temperature must be 20 C (approx. 68 F) or more for 8 - 10 days. Thus the temperature in Trento in August 2017 excludes the possibility the 2 patients from Burkina Faso infected local mosquitoes, which then infected the patient.  The average temperature for Bibione in August 2017 is found here: (https://www.accuweather.com/en/it/bibione/2550920/august-weather/2550920). )From 1 Aug 2017 to 20 Aug 2017 the average night temperature was above 20 C approx. 68 F except for 2 days (12 and 13 Aug 2017) and thus the _P. falciparum_ parasite had the climatic conditions to develop in the mosquito if local mosquitoes are able to transmit _p. falciparum_ and were infected by a gametocyte carrier.  The risk of reintroducing malaria in Italy was discussed in Romi et al. in 2012 (Romi R et al. Probable autochthonous introduced malaria cases in Italy in 2009-2011 and the risk of local vector-borne transmission. Euro Surveill. 2012 Nov 29;17(48). pii: 20325). In Trento (Province of Trentino) the _Anopheles_ species in _A. maculipennis_ complex is present which is regarded as zoophilic (not preferring humans).  In conclusion, it is a possibility that the girl was infected by mosquitoes during her stay in Bibione, but nosocomial infection in Trento is an alternative explanation. - Mod.EP  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/75).
