2\nChile / 0 / 0 / 34 / 0 / 0\nParaguay / 662 / 16 / 0 / 0 / 2\nUruguay / 0 / 0 / 1 / 0 / 0 Totals, Americas / 566 176 / 217 666 / 6095 / 20 / 3521 Caribbean and South America. A 12 Aug 2017 report quotes USA health\nofficials indicating that the Zika outbreaks in the Caribbean and\nSouth America are waning and that has helped slow the spread of the\nmosquito-borne virus to Florida and other localities in the USA this\nyear (2017).\n(http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/experts-herd-immunity-us-slows-zika-florida-49179180) Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in\nthe Americas mentioned above and below can be accessed at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574);\nNorth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106);\nCentral America (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455);\nCaribbean (http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/); and\nSouth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186). - Mod.TY Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. Americas. 16 Aug 2017. (reported) case numbers have fallen\ndramatically from their peak in January-March 2016 and not recovered\nthis year (2017). Increased herd immunity from previous Zika virus\ninfections has been suggested as one reason for the decline.\n(http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/08/zika-has-all-disappeared-americas-why) North America\n\nUSA\n- Hidalgo county, Texas. 3 Aug 2017. (conf.) health officials report 1\nlocally acquired case.\n(https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/68106) - Florida. 4 Aug 2017. (conf.) 1st sexually-transmitted case this year\n2017.\n(http://www.mypalmbeachpost.com/news/cerabino-zika-virus-brings-new-form-florida-dating/ohzkiz1tsboOFQWZVwSaOM/) Mexico and Central America\n\nMexico\n- National. 25 Jul 2017. (reported) 450 cases of whom 185 are\npregnant. State most affected: Nayarit and municipalities most\naffected there: Santiago Ixcuintla (86 cases), Tepic, San Blas (11),\nTuxpan (9), and Rosamorada (7).\n(https://www.vallartadaily.com/living/health/nayarit-reports-cases-zika-state/) - Puebla state. 30 Jun 2017. (registered) 14 cases 4 of whom\npregnant.\n(http://www.unionpuebla.mx/articulo/2017/06/30/salud/puebla-con-baja-incidencia-en-casos-de-dengue-zika-y-chikungunya)\n\nA report dated 17 Aug 2017 mentions 65 cases so far this year (2017)\nin Puebla, the 5th most affected state in Mexico with 9 percent of the\nnational total cases\n((https://www.centronline.mx/contenido/2017/08/17/112535/Aviso.aspx)\n). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ - Reynosa, Tamaulipas state. 14 Aug 2017. (probable) 35 cases, (conf.)\n2 cases.\n(https://www.elmanana.com/sedisparancasosprobablesdezika-3990344.html)\n - Cuenca del Papaloapan, Oaxaca state. 15 Jul 2017. (reported) 1\ncase.\n(http://www.nvinoticias.com/nota/64413/registran-casos-de-dengue-y-zika-en-region-de-la-cuenca) Belize. 20 Jul 2017. Since November 2016, (conf.) about 800 cases,\nincreasing.\n(https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/66171) Costa Rica. 5 Aug 2017. (susp.) 1424 cases, (conf.) 238 cases.\n(http://www.prensa-latina.cu/index.php?o=rn&id=105898&SEO=comportamiento-del-zika-chikungunya-dengue-y-malaria-en-costa-rica)\n Panama. 6 Aug 2017. (conf.) 252 cases. Current suspected outbreak on\nTaboga Island.\n(http://www.panamaamerica.com.pa/nacion/investigan-brote-de-zika-en-taboga-1079351)\n Caribbean\n\nUSA Virgin Islands. 28 Jul 2017. (conf.) 1st case of Zika-related\nmicrocephaly.\n(http://viconsortium.com/health/17-additional-pregnant-woman-infected-with-zika-d-o-h-s-latest-report-shows-bringing-total-to-271/) An 11 Aug 2017 report indicates that from 1 Jan-25 Apr 2017, 2550\ncases of women with possible Zika virus infection completed\npregnancies; In 2017, 282 pregnant women are confirmed positive for\nZika virus infection; Islands affected this year: St Thomas 683\nconfirmed cases, St Croix 252 confirmed cases\n((http://viconsortium.com/health/11-cases-of-pregnant-women-with-zika-added-to-d-o-h-report-total-now-282/)). South America\n\nArgentina (Salta province). 13 Aug 2017. November 2016-May 2017, 1st\nlocally acquired outbreak (conf.) 203 cases of which 7 pregnant.\nDepartment most affected: San Martín (Tartagal, General Mosconi,\nAguaray, and Embarcación), and Morillo.\n(http://www.eltribuno.info/salta/nota/2017-8-13-0-0-0-hubo-203-casos-de-zika-en-el-primer-brote-autoctono)\n Brazil\n- Origin and spread. 15 Jun 2017. (reported) Analyses of viral genomes\nwith ecological and epidemiological data yield an estimate that ZIKV\nwas present in northeast Brazil by February 2014 and is likely to have\ndisseminated from there, nationally and internationally, before the\n1st detection of ZIKV in the Americas. Estimated dates for the\ninternational spread of ZIKV from Brazil indicate the duration of\npre-detection cryptic transmission in recipient regions. The role of\nnortheast Brazil in the establishment of ZIKV in the Americas is\nfurther supported by geographic analysis of ZIKV transmission.\n(http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v546/n7658/full/nature22402.html) - Eye lesions. 17 Jul 2017 (reported) of 112 infants born to Zika\nvirus infected mothers in Brazil, 24 (21 percent) had eye\nabnormalities; 10 infants (42 percent) with abnormal eye examination\nfindings did not have microcephaly, 8 (33 percent) did not have any\ncentral nervous system findings, and 2 (8 percent) had eye\nabnormalities despite maternal 3rd trimester infection. Eye\nabnormalities may be the only initial finding in congenital Zika virus\ninfection, and all infants with potential Zika virus exposure should\nundergo screening eye examinations.\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/article-abstract/2636587) Peru\n- National. 22 Jul 2017. 2016-22 Jul 2017 (susp.) 6432 cases, (conf.)\n1438 cases with 264 pregnant with 17 cases of suspected Zika\nvirus-related microcephaly. For 2017 up to 23 Jul 2017 (susp.) 5552\ncases, (conf.) 649 cases with 172 pregnant, 5 cases of suspected Zika\nvirus-related microcephaly. Epidemic peak on week 15 week ending 14\nApr 2017, then sharp decline.\n(http://www.dge.gob.pe/portal/docs/vigilancia/boletines/2017/29.pdf)\n - Piura region. 29 Jul 2017. (susp.) 94 cases, (conf.) 13 cases of\nwhom 5 pregnant.\n(http://diariocorreo.pe/edicion/piura/casos-de-dengue-y-zika-aumentan-ligeramente-semana-a-semana-764780/)\n Asia\n\nThailand (Phichit province). 4 Jul 2017. (susp.) 27 cases, (conf.) 11\ncases.\n(http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1280835/11-zika-cases-confirmed-in-phichit-27-under-watch) Maps of Thailand can be accessed at\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_Thailand) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1371). - Mod.TY Taiwan. 31 Jul 2017. (conf.) 1 imported case ex Viet Nam.\n(http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2017/07/31/2003675659) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Taiwan can be accessed at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/193). - Mod.TY  Viet Nam (Dak Lak province). August 2017. (reported) in June, 2016, a\ngirl was born with microcephaly in Dak Lak Province, in the Central\nHighlands region of Viet Nam, at 37 weeks of gestation. The infant's\nmother (aged 23 years) had experienced symptoms of fever and rash\nassociated with Zika virus infection during her 2nd trimester. The\nsymptoms resolved uneventfully.\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30412-7/fulltext) Maps of Viet Nam can be seen at\n(http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png) and\n(ttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/62774). - Mod.TY Singapore (Serangoon). 14 Aug 2014. (conf.) 2 new cases of locally\ntransmitted Zika virus infection in Serangoon, the 3rd cluster in the\narea in less than 1 month.\n(http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/2-new-cases-of-locally-transmitted-zika-virus-in-serangoon-nea) A 26 Jul 2017 previous report confirmed a cluster of 3 locally\nacquired cases at Serangoon North Avenue 1.\n(http://www.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/news-releases/three-case-zika-cluster-reported-at-serangoon-north-avenue-1) Maps of Singapore can be accessed at\n(http://www.studies-overseas.com/WebForms/Singapore%20Map%20Places.png)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/33319). - Mod.TY India\n- National. 25 Jul 2017. (susp.) 1 case, (conf.) 3 cases, one of whom\nis pregnant.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/health/four-zika-cases-reported-in-india-so-far-govt/article19358623.ece) Maps of India can be accessed at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Mod.TY - Tamil Nadu state. 11 Jul 2017. (reported) 1st case reported in state\nin a 27-year-old man in the Krishnagiri district.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/tamil-nadu-reports-first-case-of-zika-virus/article19254690.ece) Imported cases with little or no possibility of ongoing mosquito\ntransmission\n\nCanada. 26 Jul 2017. As of 4 May 2017 (reported) 499 cases with 2\naffected newborn babies. 103 cases in Quebec as of 12 May 2017.\n(https://sherbrooktimes.com/nine-cases-of-zika-in-the-region-of-the-capitale-nationale/20262) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Canada can be accessed at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12). - Mod.TY USA\n- Case numbers mainland. Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-16 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html) State / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 20 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 29 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 6 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 4 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 40 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 4 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 2 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 203 / 9 - Texas. 11 Aug 2017. 1 Jan 2016-31 July 2017, 219 pregnant women with\nlaboratory evidence of possible recent Zika virus infection were\nidentified in Texas, including 49 (22 percent) with\nlaboratory-confirmed Zika virus). One woman was infected in Texas; all\nothers were exposed outside the United States and its territories.\nZika virus testing was completed for 80 (43 percent) of the 185\ninfants or fetuses, and Zika virus-associated birth defects were\ndocumented in 15 (8 percent) pregnancies (14 live-born infants and one\nfetal loss), including 6 (17 percent) of the 36 infants or fetal\nlosses delivered by women with laboratory-confirmed Zika virus\ninfection. Of these, 10 infants or fetuses had microcephaly; 5 of\nthose with microcephaly had additional birth defects, including\nholoprosencephaly the brain doesn't properly divide into the right\nand left hemispheres, hydranencephaly brain's cerebral hemispheres\nreplaced by sacs filled with cerebrospinal fluid, craniosynostosis\npremature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, often resulting in\nan abnormal head shape, and clubfeet feet turned inward. Zika\nvirus-associated birth defects identified in the remaining 3 infants\nincluded holoprosencephaly, cataracts, and ventral pons hypoplasia.\n(https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6631a5.htm?s_cid=mm6631a5_e) Neurological effects not only occur in fetuses and neonates, there\nare occasional cases in adults as well. A report describes a case of\nZIKV meningoencephalitis and probable myelitis and its associated\nmagnetic resonance imaging findings that rapidly resolved during\nrecovery in a previously healthy adult.\n((http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0921)). -\nMod. TY - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 40 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 39 / 0\nTotal 554 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Evaluation of diagnostic tests.\nDate: September 2017 (ahead of print).\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/9/16-2043_article) \nref: Safronetz D, Sloan A, Stein DR, et al. Evaluation of 5\ncommercially available Zika virus immunoassays. Emerg Infect Dis.\n2017; 23(9): 1577-80. doi: 10.3201/eid2309.162043. Epub 2017 Sep 17\n-\nAbstract\n\nBecause of global spread of Zika virus, accurate and high-throughput\ndiagnostic immunoassays are needed. We compared the sensitivity and\nspecificity of 5 commercially available Zika virus serologic assays to\nthe recommended protocol of Zika virus IgM-capture ELISA and\nplaque-reduction neutralization tests. Most commercial immunoassays\nshowed low sensitivity, which can be increased. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The low sensitivity is a significant concern. Readers interested in\nthe evaluation of the specific tests may wish to see the full report\navailable at the source URL above. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Saliva transmission unlikely.\nDate: Tue 1 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Communications (edited)\n(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5539107/? \nref: Newman CM, Dudley DM, Aliota MT, et al. Oropharyngeal mucosal\ntransmission of Zika virus in rhesus macaques. Nat Commun. 2017; 8(1):\n169. doi: 10.1038/s41467-017-00246-8\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus is present in urine, saliva, tears, and breast milk, but\nthe transmission risk associated with these body fluids is currently\nunknown. Here we evaluate the risk of Zika virus transmission through\nmucosal contact in rhesus macaques. Application of high-dose Zika\nvirus directly to the tonsils of 3 rhesus macaques results in\ndetectable plasma viremia in all animals by 2 days post-exposure;\nvirus replication kinetics are similar to those observed in animals\ninfected subcutaneously. 3 additional macaques inoculated\nsubcutaneously with Zika virus served as saliva donors to assess the\ntransmission risk from contact with oral secretions from an infected\nindividual. 7 naive animals repeatedly exposed to donor saliva via the\nconjunctivae, tonsils, or nostrils did not become infected. Our\nresults suggest that there is a risk of Zika virus transmission via\nthe mucosal route, but that the risk posed by oral secretions from\nindividuals with a typical course of Zika virus infection is low. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall It is good to learn that Zika virus transmission via mucosa is\nunlikely. It will be interesting to know if virus shedding in saliva\nis a common occurrence in infected humans. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> CDC guidance for pregnancy.\nDate: Mon 24 Jul 2017.\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2017; 66(29): 781-93(edited)\n(https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6629e1.htm) \nref: Oduyebo T, Polen KD, Walke HT, et al. Update: Interim guidance\nfor health care providers caring for pregnant women with possible Zika\nvirus exposure  United States (including US Territories), July 2017.\nMMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2017; 66(29): 781-93. doi:\n10.15585/mmwr.mm6629e1\n-\nCDC has updated the interim guidance for US health care providers\ncaring for pregnant women with possible Zika virus exposure in\nresponse to 1) declining prevalence of Zika virus disease in the World\nHealth Organization's Region of the Americas (Americas) and 2)\nemerging evidence indicating prolonged detection of Zika virus\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies. Zika virus cases were 1st reported\nin the Americas during 2015-2016; however, the incidence of Zika virus\ndisease has since declined. As the prevalence of Zika virus disease\ndeclines, the likelihood of false-positive test results increases. In\naddition, emerging epidemiologic and laboratory data indicate that, as\nis the case with other flaviviruses, Zika virus IgM antibodies can\npersist beyond 12 weeks after infection. Therefore, IgM test results\ncannot always reliably distinguish between an infection that occurred\nduring the current pregnancy and one that occurred before the current\npregnancy, particularly for women with possible Zika virus exposure\nbefore the current pregnancy. These limitations should be considered\nwhen counseling pregnant women about the risks and benefits of testing\nfor Zika virus infection during pregnancy. This updated guidance\nemphasizes a shared decision-making model for testing and screening\npregnant women, one in which patients and providers work together to\nmake decisions about testing and care plans based on patient\npreferences and values, clinical judgment, and a balanced assessment\nof risks and expected outcomes. For these recommendations, the definition of possible Zika virus\nexposure has not changed and includes travel to, or residence in an\narea with risk for mosquito-borne Zika virus transmission or sex with\na partner who has traveled to or resides in an area with risk for\nmosquito-borne Zika virus transmission. These areas can be found on\nthe CDC \"Zika Travel Information\" webpage. Key recommendations include the following:\n1- All pregnant women in the United States and US territories should\nbe asked about possible Zika virus exposure before and during the\ncurrent pregnancy, at every prenatal care visit. CDC recommends that\npregnant women not travel to any area with risk for Zika virus\ntransmission. It is also recommended that pregnant women with a sex\npartner who has traveled to or lives in an area with risk for Zika\nvirus transmission use condoms or abstain from sex for the duration of\nthe pregnancy.\n2- Pregnant women with recent possible Zika virus exposure and\nsymptoms of Zika virus disease should be tested to diagnose the cause\nof their symptoms. The updated recommendations include concurrent Zika\nvirus nucleic acid test (NAT) and serologic testing as soon as\npossible through 12 weeks after symptom onset.\n3- Asymptomatic pregnant women with ongoing possible Zika virus\nexposure should be offered Zika virus NAT testing 3 times during\npregnancy. IgM testing is no longer routinely recommended because IgM\ncan persist for months after infection; therefore, IgM results cannot\nreliably determine whether an infection occurred during the current\npregnancy. The optimal timing and frequency of testing of asymptomatic\npregnant women with NAT alone is unknown. For pregnant women who have\nreceived a diagnosis of laboratory-confirmed Zika virus infection (by\neither NAT or serology positive/equivocal Zika virus or dengue virus\nIgM and Zika virus plaque reduction neutralization test (PRNT) 10 and\nhigher and dengue virus PRNT less than 10 results) any time before or\nduring the current pregnancy, additional Zika virus testing is not\nrecommended. For pregnant women without a prior laboratory-confirmed\ndiagnosis of Zika virus, NAT testing should be offered at the\ninitiation of prenatal care, and if Zika virus RNA is not detected on\nclinical specimens, 2 additional tests should be offered during the\ncourse of the pregnancy coinciding with prenatal visits.\n4- Asymptomatic pregnant women who have recent possible Zika virus\nexposure (that is, through travel or sexual exposure) but without\nongoing possible exposure are not routinely recommended to have Zika\nvirus testing. Testing should be considered using a shared\npatient-provider decision-making model, one in which patients and\nproviders work together to make decisions about testing and care plans\nbased on patient preferences and values, clinical judgment, a balanced\nassessment of risks and expected outcomes, and the jurisdiction's\nrecommendations. Based on the epidemiology of Zika virus transmission\nand other epidemiologic considerations (such as, seasonality),\njurisdictions might recommend testing of asymptomatic pregnant women,\neither for clinical care or as part of Zika virus surveillance. With\nthe decline in the prevalence of Zika virus disease, the updated\nrecommendations for the evaluation and testing of pregnant women with\nrecent possible Zika virus exposure but without ongoing possible\nexposure are now the same for all areas with any risk for Zika virus\ntransmission.\n5- Pregnant women who have recent possible Zika virus exposure and who\nhave a fetus with prenatal ultrasound findings consistent with\ncongenital Zika virus syndrome should receive Zika virus testing to\nassist in establishing the etiology of the birth defects. Testing\nshould include both NAT and IgM tests.\n6- The comprehensive approach to testing placental and fetal tissues\nhas been updated. Testing placental and fetal tissue specimens can be\nperformed for diagnostic purposes in certain scenarios (e.g., women\nwithout a diagnosis of laboratory-confirmed Zika virus infection and\nwho have a fetus or infant with possible Zika virus-associated birth\ndefects). However, testing of placental tissues for Zika virus\ninfection is not routinely recommended for asymptomatic pregnant women\nwho have recent possible Zika virus exposure but without ongoing\npossible exposure and who have a live born infant without evidence of\npossible Zika virus-associated birth defects.\n7- Zika virus IgM testing as part of preconception counseling to\nestablish baseline IgM results for non pregnant women with ongoing\npossible Zika virus exposure is not warranted because Zika virus IgM\ntesting is no longer routinely recommended for asymptomatic pregnant\nwomen with ongoing possible Zika virus exposure. also at the source URL above:\nAdditional interim guidance:\n- Laboratory testing of pregnant women with exposure to areas with\nrisk for Zika virus transmission\n- Prenatal management of pregnant women with laboratory evidence of\npossible Zika virus infection\n- Evaluation of placental and fetal tissue specimens for Zika virus\ninfection \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be)(promed@promedmail.org) Readers interested in accessing the full report can find it at the\nsource URL above. Interestingly, a malaria drug has been shown to\ninhibit autophagy which limits vertical transmission of Zika virus in\npregnant mice. (http://dx.doi.org/10.1084/jem.20170957). Roland\nHübner is thanked for sending in this report. - Mod. TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Neurologic complications in adults.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: JAMA Neurology (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamaneurology/fullarticle/2647256) \nref: da Silva IRF, Frontera JA, Bispo de Filippis AM, et al.\nNeurologic complications associated with the Zika virus in Brazilian\nadults. JAMA Neurol. 2017. doi: 10.1001/jamaneurol.2017.1703. Epub\nahead of print\n-\nKey points\n-\nQuestion. What is the spectrum of neurologic manifestations in adults\nwith Zika virus infection?\nFindings. This cohort study evaluated adult patients with new-onset\nparainfectious or neuroinflammatory disease for the presence of acute\nZika virus infection in both serum and cerebrospinal fluid samples\nusing molecular and serological testing. An increase in the incidence\nof Guillain-Barré syndrome and encephalitis was observed compared\nwith the period before the outbreak of the Zika virus.\nMeaning The Zika virus may be associated with a rapid increase in the\nincidence of life-threatening neurologic syndromes; serologic and\nmolecular testing using blood and cerebrospinal fluid samples can\nserve as an alternative diagnostic strategy. Abstract\n\nImportance. There are no prospective cohort studies assessing the\nincidence and spectrum of neurologic manifestations secondary to Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) infection in adults.\nObjective. To evaluate the rates of acute ZIKV infection among\npatients hospitalized with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS),\nmeningoencephalitis, or transverse myelitis.\nDesign, setting, and participants. A prospective, observational cohort\nstudy was conducted at a tertiary referral center for neurological\ndiseases in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, between 5 Dec 2015-10 May 2016,\namong consecutive hospitalized adults (older than 18 years of age)\nwith new-onset acute parainfectious or neuroinflammatory disease. All\nparticipants were tested for a series of arbovirosis. 3-month\nfunctional outcome was assessed.\nInterventions. Samples of serum and cerebrospinal fluid were tested\nfor ZIKV using real-time reverse-transcriptase-polymerase chain\nreaction and an IgM antibody-capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent\nassay. Clinical, radiographic (magnetic resonance imaging),\nelectrophysiological, and 3-month functional outcome data were\ncollected.\nMain outcomes and measures. The detection of neurologic complications\nsecondary to ZIKV infection.\nResults. 40 patients (15 women and 25 men; median age, 44 years\nrange, 22-72 years) were enrolled, including 29 patients (73\npercent) with GBS (90 percent Brighton level 1 certainty), 7 (18\npercent) with encephalitis, 3 (8 percent) with transverse myelitis,\nand 1 (3 percent) with newly diagnosed chronic inflammatory\ndemyelinating polyneuropathy. Of these, 35 patients (88 percent) had\nmolecular and/or serologic evidence of recent ZIKV infection in the\nserum and/or cerebrospinal fluid. Of the patients positive for ZIKV\ninfection, 27 had GBS (18 demyelinating, 8 axonal, and 1 Miller Fisher\nsyndrome), 5 had encephalitis (3 with concomitant acute neuromuscular\ndisease), 2 had transverse myelitis, and 1 had chronic inflammatory\ndemyelinating polyneuropathy. Admission to the intensive care unit was\nrequired for 9 patients positive for ZIKV infection (26 percent), and\n5 (14 percent) required mechanical ventilation. Compared with\nadmission during the period from 5 Dec 2013 - 10 May 2014 (before the\nBrazilian outbreak of ZIKV), admissions for GBS increased from a mean\nof 1.0 per month to 5.6 per month, admissions for encephalitis\nincreased from 0.4 per month to 1.4 per month, and admissions for\ntransverse myelitis remained constant at 0.6 per month. At 3 months, 2\npatients positive for ZIKV infection (6 percent) died (1 with GBS and\n1 with encephalitis), 18 (51 percent) had chronic pain, and the median\nmodified Rankin score among survivors was 2 (range, 0-5).\nConclusions and relevance. In this single-center Brazilian cohort,\nZIKV infection was associated with an increase in the incidence of a\ndiverse spectrum of serious neurologic syndromes. The data also\nsuggest that serologic and molecular testing using blood and\ncerebrospinal fluid samples can serve as a less expensive, alternative\ndiagnostic strategy in developing countries, where plaque reduction\nneutralization testing is impractical. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) This study illustrates the need to consider post-Zika virus infection\nas a cause of a variety of neurological diseases. Further neurological\nfollow up of adults convalescent from acute Zika virus infection would\nbe of interest. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Persistence in brain cells.\nDate: Tue 11 Jul 2017.\nSource: mBio (edited)\n(http://mbio.asm.org/content/8/4/e00952-17.long) \nMladinich MC, Schwedes J, Mackow ER. Zika virus persistently infects\nand is basolaterally released from primary human brain microvascular\nendothelial cells. MBio. 2017; 8(4). pii: e00952-17. doi:\n10.1128/mBio.00952-17\n-\nZIKV persists in patients, crossing placental and neuronal barriers,\ndamaging neurons, and causing fetal microencephaly. We found that ZIKV\npersistently infects brain endothelial cells that normally protect\nneurons from viral exposure. hBMECs are not damaged by ZIKV infection\nand, analogous to persistent HCV infection, ZIKV constitutively\ninduces and evades antiviral ISG IFN-stimulated genes and IFN\ninterferon responses to continuously replicate in hBMECs. As a\nresult, hBMECs provide a protective niche for systemic ZIKV spread and\na viral reservoir localized in the normally protective blood-brain\nbarrier. Consistent with the spread of ZIKV into neuronal\ncompartments, ZIKV was released basolaterally from hBMECs. Our\nfindings define hBMEC responses that contribute to persistent ZIKV\ninfection and potential targets for clearing ZIKV infections from\nhBMECs. These results further suggest roles for additional\nZIKV-infected ECs to facilitate viral spread and persistence in the\nprotected placental, retinal, and testicular compartments. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Prior flavivirus infection and Zika virus infection.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Pathogens (edited)\n(http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1006487) \nMcCracken MK, Gromowski GD, Friberg HL, et al. Impact of prior\nflavivirus immunity on Zika virus infection in rhesus macaques. PLoS\nPathog. 2017; 13(8): e1006487. doi: 10.1371/journal.ppat.1006487\n-\nAbstract\n\nStudies have demonstrated cross-reactivity of anti-dengue virus (DENV)\nantibodies in human sera against Zika virus (ZIKV), promoting\nincreased ZIKV infection in vitro. However, the correlation between in\nvitro and in vivo findings is not well characterized. Thus, we\nevaluated the impact of heterotypic flavivirus immunity on ZIKV titers\nin biofluids of rhesus macaques. Animals previously infected (420 days\nor longer) with DENV2, DENV4, or yellow fever virus were compared to\nflavivirus-naïve animals following infection with a Brazilian ZIKV\nstrain. Sera from DENV-immune macaques demonstrated cross-reactivity\nwith ZIKV by antibody-binding and neutralization assays prior to ZIKV\ninfection, and promoted increased ZIKV infection in cell culture\nassays. Despite these findings, no significant differences between\nflavivirus-naïve and immune animals were observed in viral titers,\nneutralizing antibody levels, or immune cell kinetics following ZIKV\ninfection. These results indicate that prior infection with\nheterologous flaviviruses neither conferred protection nor increased\nobserved ZIKV titers in this non-human primate ZIKV infection model. Author summary\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne, emerging flavivirus. In\naddition to asymptomatic or mild febrile manifestations, ZIKV\ninfection in humans is associated with comparatively rare congenital\nand neurological abnormalities. Previous in vitro studies have\ndemonstrated cross-reactivity of antibodies derived from dengue virus\ninfections with ZIKV, as well as antibody-mediated enhancement of\ninfection in cell culture. Therefore, there is concern among\nvaccinologists and the public health community that the more severe\ndisease manifestations could result from prior immunity, either from\nnatural infection or vaccination, to antigenically-related\nflaviviruses (such as, dengue, yellow fever, Japanese encephalitis).\nIn this study, we evaluated the impact of prior immunity to dengue or\nyellow fever virus on ZIKV infection in a non-human primate model.\nAfter confirming that our immune cohorts were capable of\nrecapitulating the published in vitro observations of cross-reactivity\nand enhancement, we looked for alteration of viral titers in\nperipheral blood, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, saliva, and vaginal\nsecretions, as well as alterations in gross pathology, clinical\nparameters, and immune response, as compared to our flavivirus-naïve\ncohort. Importantly, no significant differences between\nflavivirus-naïve and primed animals were observed in viral titers or\nbiofluid distribution, neutralizing antibody levels, or immune cell\nkinetics following ZIKV infection. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be)(promed@promedmail.org) Previous dengue infection, whether acquired naturally or antibody\nelicited by vaccines, has been a concern due to the possibility of\nantibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) with more severe disease. This\nconcern also relates to Zika virus antibody from vaccination for\nenhancement of dengue virus infections with resulting more severe\ndisease. The monkey studies reported above indicated that this may not\nbe a problem for Zika virus vaccinated individuals. Another effort to\navoid ADE is development of a vaccine that has epitopes specific for\nZika virus that are not shared by other flaviviruses. A group of\nresearchers developed a recombinant vaccine targeting a viral envelope\nsub-unit specific to the Zika virus\n((http://www.pharmaceutical-journal.com/news-and-analysis/news-in-brief/researchers-find-way-to-overcome-zika-vaccinedengue-virus-conundrum/20203379.article)).\nRoland Hübner is thanked for calling this latter reference to our\nattention. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Virus inhibition.\nDate: 25 Jul 2017.\nSource: Nature Communications (edited)\n(https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms15672) \nref: Yu Y, Deng YQ, Zou P, et al. A peptide-based viral inactivator\ninhibits Zika virus infection in pregnant mice and fetuses. Nat\nCommun. 2017; 8: 15672. doi: 10.1038/ncomms15672\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV), a re-emerging flavivirus associated with\nneurological disorders, has spread rapidly to more than 70 countries\nand territories. However, no specific vaccines or antiviral drugs are\ncurrently available to prevent or treat ZIKV infection. Here we report\nthat a synthetic peptide derived from the stem region of ZIKV envelope\nprotein, designated Z2, potently inhibits infection of ZIKV and other\nflaviviruses in vitro. We show that Z2 interacts with ZIKV surface\nprotein and disrupts the integrity of the viral membrane. Z2 can\npenetrate the placental barrier to enter fetal tissues and is safe for\nuse in pregnant mice. Intraperitoneal administration of Z2 inhibits\nvertical transmission of ZIKV in pregnant C57BL/6 mice and protects\ntype I or type I/II interferon receptor-deficient mice against lethal\nZIKV challenge. Thus, Z2 has potential to be further developed as an\nantiviral treatment against ZIKV infection in high-risk populations,\nparticularly pregnant women. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall It will be interesting to see if the same protective effect occurs\nwhen tested with Zika virus infections of non-human primates. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{9}</strong> Female reproductive tract infection.\nDate: Wed 26 Jul 2017.\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Pathogens (edited)\n(http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1006537) \nCarroll T, Lo M, Lanteri M, et al. Zika virus preferentially\nreplicates in the female reproductive tract after vaginal inoculation\nof rhesus macaques. PLoS Pathog. 2017; 13(7): e1006537. doi:\n10.1371/journal.ppat.1006537\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-transmitted virus that can cause\nsevere defects in an infected fetus. ZIKV is also transmitted by\nsexual contact, although the relative importance of sexual\ntransmission is unclear. To better understand the role of sexual\ntransmission in ZIKV pathogenesis, a nonhuman primate (NHP) model of\nvaginal transmission was developed. ZIKV was readily transmitted to\nmature cycling female rhesus macaque (RM) by vaginal inoculation was\nreadily transmitted to mature cycling female rhesus macaque (RM) by\nvaginal individual RM with 1-5 vaginal inoculations required to\nestablish infection. After treatment with Depoprovera, a widely used\ncontraceptive progestin, 2 RM that initially resisted 8 vaginal ZIKV\ninoculations became infected after one ZIKV inoculation. Thus,\nDepoprovera seemed to enhance susceptibility to vaginal ZIKV\ntransmission. Unexpectedly, the kinetics of virus replication and\ndissemination after intravaginal ZIKV inoculation were markedly\ndifferent from RM infected with ZIKV by subcutaneous (SQ) virus\ninoculation. Several groups have reported that after SQ ZIKV\ninoculation vRNA is rapidly detected in blood plasma with vRNA less\ncommon in urine and saliva and only rarely detected in female\nreproductive tract (FRT) secretions. In contrast, in vaginally\ninoculated RM, plasma vRNA is delayed for several days and ZIKV\nreplication in, and vRNA shedding from, the FRT was found in all 6\nanimals. Further, after intravaginal transmission ZIKV RNA shedding\nfrom FRT secretions was detected before or simultaneously with plasma\nvRNA, and persisted for at least as long. Thus, ZIKV replication in\nthe FRT was independent of, and often preceded virus replication in\nthe tissues contributing to plasma vRNA. These results support the\nconclusion that ZIKV preferentially replicates in the FRT after\nvaginal transmission, but not after SQ transmission, and raise the\npossibility that there is enhanced fetal infection and pathology after\nvaginal ZIKV transmission compared to a mosquito transmitted ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{10}</strong> _Aedes albopictus_ populations as vectors.\nDate: 2 Aug 2017.\nSource: American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (edited)\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0969) \nref: Azar SR, Roundy CM, Rossi SL, et al. Differential vector\ncompetency of _Aedes albopictus_ populations from the Americas for\nZika virus. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2017; 97(2): 330-9;\ndoi.org/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0969\n-\nAbstract\n\nTo evaluate the potential role of _Aedes albopictus_ (Skuse) as a\nvector of Zika virus (ZIKV), colonized mosquitoes of low generation\nnumber (less than or F5) from Brazil, Houston, and the Rio Grande\nValley of Texas engorged on viremic mice infected with ZIKV strains\noriginating from Senegal, Cambodia, Mexico, Brazil, or Puerto Rico.\nVector competence was established by monitoring infection,\ndissemination, and transmission potential after 3, 7, and 14 days of\nextrinsic incubation. Positive saliva samples were assayed for\ninfectious titer. Although all 3 mosquito populations were susceptible\nto all ZIKV strains, rates of infection, dissemination, and\ntransmission differed among mosquito and virus strains. _Aedes\nalbopictus_ from Salvador, Brazil, were the least efficient vectors,\ndemonstrating susceptibility to infection to 2 American strains of\nZIKV but failing to shed virus in saliva. Mosquitoes from the Rio\nGrande Valley were the most efficient vectors and were capable of\nshedding all 3 tested ZIKV strains into saliva after 14 days of\nextrinsic incubation. In particular, ZIKV strain DakAR 41525 (Senegal\n1954) was significantly more efficient at dissemination and saliva\ndeposition than the others tested in Rio Grande mosquitoes. Overall,\nour data indicate that, while _Ae. albopictus_ is capable of\ntransmitting ZIKV, its competence is potentially dependent on\ngeographic origin of both the mosquito population and the viral\nstrain. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) This study illustrates that fact that not all Zika virus strains and\n_Ae. albopictus_ populations are created equal in terms of efficiency\nof transmission of this virus. Although some populations of this\nmosquito are able to efficiently transmits some Zika viruses, the fact\nthat _Ae. albopictus _ are not strictly human biters, further reduces\ntheir role as transmitters of this virus to people. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{11}</strong> _Culex quinquefasciatus_ as vectors.\nDate: Wed 9 Aug 2017.\nSource: Emerging Microbes & Infections (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/emi/journal/v6/n8/full/emi201759a.html?foxtrotcallback=true) \nref: Guedes DR, Paiva MH, Donato MM, et al. Zika virus replication in\nthe mosquito _Culex quinquefasciatus_ in Brazil. Emerg Microbes\nInfect. 2017; 6(8): e69. doi: 10.1038/emi.2017.59\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a flavivirus that has recently been associated\nwith an increased incidence of neonatal microcephaly and other\nneurological disorders. The virus is primarily transmitted by mosquito\nbite, although other routes of infection have been implicated in some\ncases. The _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito is considered to be the main\nvector to humans worldwide; however, there is evidence that other\nmosquito species, including _Culex quinquefasciatus_, transmit the\nvirus. To test the potential of _Cx. quinquefasciatus_ to transmit\nZIKV, we experimentally compared the vector competence of\nlaboratory-reared _Ae. aegypti_ and _Cx. quinquefasciatus_.\nInterestingly, we were able to detect the presence of ZIKV in the\nmidgut, salivary glands and saliva of artificially fed _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_. In addition, we collected ZIKV-infected _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_ from urban areas with high microcephaly incidence in\nRecife, Brazil. Corroborating our experimental data from artificially\nfed mosquitoes, ZIKV was isolated from field-caught _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_, and its genome was partially sequenced.\nCollectively, these findings indicate that there may be a wider range\nof ZIKV vectors than anticipated. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be) Finding a virus in field-collected mosquitoes in areas of active\nvirus transmission is highly suggestive, but not conclusive, of their\nability to transmit that virus. The study above goes the next step\ntoward proving vector capability by infecting _Culex quinquefasciatus_\nfed with Zika virus and subsequently demonstrating the virus in\nsaliva, implicating their ability to transmit it. The role of _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_ in Zika virus transmission is currently confusing.\nThe study above and one done in China indicate that this species is a\ncompetent vector. Several other studies have shown this species to be\ninefficient vectors or refractory to Zika virus infection. One wonders\nif the specific _Cx. quinquefasciatus_ used or the Zika virus isolates\nwith which they were tested could account for these very different\nresults. Resolving these discrepancies is important because this\nmosquito species is very widely distributed around the world and bears\ndirectly on risk of outbreaks in geographic areas where _Aedes\naegypti_ or _Ae. albopictus_ , Zika virus vectors, do not occur. -\nMod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Equatorial Guinea":{},"Eritrea":{},"Estonia":{},"Ethiopia":{"114":{"title":"Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t","date":["26","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy  Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15 <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania  Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics   Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert. Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Mainichi (edited) (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170821/p2g/00m/0dm/077000c)   Japan's health ministry has issued a warning for people traveling to Europe on the back of an outbreak of measles in countries such as Italy and Romania. The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is advising tourists to go to hospital if they develop a high fever or generalized rash after returning to Japan.  Although the World Health Organization verified that Japan has eliminated infections of endemic measles strains in 2015, group infections originating from people who contracted the disease abroad are spreading in the country. As of 6 Aug 2017, the number of patients reached 169 this year in Japan, already eclipsing the figure in the previous year.  About 4100 patients in Italy and around 6500 patients in Romania have already been confirmed as of August 2017 compared with about 860 and 2000, respectively, throughout 2016, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.  Symptoms of the highly contagious disease include runny nose, red and watery eyes, high fever, and rash. The virus is spread through coughing and sneezing and can cause complications such as pneumonia and can even result in death in one in 1000 patients, according to the ministry. The ministry recommends people traveling overseas to check their vaccination records and take an additional shot if they have only been vaccinated once.  The disease was prevalent about a decade ago in Japan with the number of patients soaring to over 10 000 in 2008 but the country was later considered as free from infections of the virus.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy. Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017 5:36 PM AEST. Source: News.com.au, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report (edited) (http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/fourth-case-of-measles-at-perth-school/news-story/ece041f55111645e10f70046d92479dd)   A 4th child has been diagnosed with measles at Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, more than a week after the health department gave an on-site vaccine to students. A Health Department spokeswoman confirmed the latest case, which came 3 weeks after the highly contagious disease was first detected in an unvaccinated year 10 student who had returned from Italy.  Revelations that about half the school's 400 students were unvaccinated against the disease led the Health Department to offer a voluntary, free on-site vaccine to students, but it is unknown how many took up the offer.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK   Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15. Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2017; 22(34) (edited) (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22861)   ref: Werber D, Hoffmann A, Santibanez S, et al. Large measles outbreak introduced by asylum seekers and spread among the insufficiently vaccinated resident population, Berlin, October 2014 to August 2015. Euro Surveill. 2017; 22(34): pii=30599 - Abstract  The largest measles outbreak in Berlin since 2001 occurred from October 2014 to August 2015. Overall, 1344 cases were ascertained, 86 per cent (with available information) unvaccinated, including 146 (12 per cent) asylum seekers. Median age was 17 years (interquartile range: 4-29 years), 26 per cent were hospitalised and a 1 year old child died. Measles virus genotyping uniformly revealed the variant 'D8-Rostov-Don' and descendants. The virus was likely introduced by and initially spread among asylum seekers before affecting Berlin's resident population. Among Berlin residents, the highest incidence was in children younger than 2 years, yet most cases (52 per cent) were adults. Post-exposure vaccinations in homes for asylum seekers, not always conducted, occurred later (median: 7.5 days) than the recommended 72 hours after onset of the 1st case and reached only half of potential contacts. Asylum seekers should not only have non-discriminatory, equitable access to vaccination, they also need to be offered measles vaccination in a timely fashion, that is, immediately upon arrival in the receiving country. Supplementary immunisation activities targeting the resident population, particularly adults, are urgently needed in Berlin.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5857). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania. Date: Fri 25 August 2017. Source: Romania Insider (edited) (https://www.romania-insider.com/measles-kills-iraqi-refugee/)   The ongoing measles outbreak keeps making victims in Romania. A 10 month old girl, who was a refugee from Iraq, became the 33rd person to die of the infection, reports local Digi24. The girl arrived in Romania on 7 Jul 2017 with her family, and the doctors diagnosed her with measles in August. They also discovered that the child was suffering from malnutrition and severe psychomotor retardation.  The measles outbreak is still a major problem in Romania, with more than 8900 cases reported across the country until 25 Aug 2017, including 33 deaths, according to data from the National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT). Most deaths were registered in Timis (9), Dolj (7), and Arad (6) counties.  Measles is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by a virus. It causes a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and runny nose. According to information posted on WHO's website, the virus is highly contagious, spreading by coughing and sneezing, close personal contact, and direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions. Unvaccinated young children pose the highest risk of measles and its complications, including death.  The Romanian Government adopted earlier this month August 2017 a draft bill on the organization and financing of population vaccination (https://www.romania-insider.com/romania-draft-bill-vaccination/). The project was sent to the Parliament for approval and could come into force in January 2018.  byline: Irina Marica   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Measles tends to be more severe in children who are malnourished, especially children who are also vitamin A deficient. And complications are commoner and more serious in malnourished children. Because of complications such as diarrhoea, measles may lead to failure to thrive. Infection with measles virus may lead to kwashiorkor or marasmus in children who are underweight at the time that they get infected. Therefore, measles may result in, or aggravate, malnutrition.  Maps of Romania can be found at (http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK   Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics. Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017. Source: News-Medical/Life Sciences (edited) (https://www.news-medical.net/news/20170826/New-study-highlights-role-played-by-demographics-in-the-spread-of-measles.aspx)   Even if the incidence of measles infection has decreased by at least 90 per cent worldwide since the introduction of the vaccine, measles is still one of the major causes of death in children among vaccine-preventable diseases. Regular measles epidemics are reported in developing countries and recurrent episodic outbreaks occur in the developed world.  A new study by Bocconi University and Bruno Kessler Foundation analyzing 9 countries (Australia, Ethiopia, Kenya, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases see reference below, highlights the role played by demographics in the spread of measles and concludes that future vaccination strategies in high-fertility countries should focus on increasing childhood immunization rates, while immunization campaigns targeting adolescents and young adults are required in low fertility countries.  Using a transmission model calibrated on historical serological data the authors estimate that the susceptible proportion of the population (that is, unprotected against the infection) varies from about 3 per cent in the UK to more than 12.5 per cent in Ethiopia, with astonishing differences in its age composition, due to different vaccination strategies and divergent demographic trends. While the percentage of over-15 among susceptible individuals in Ethiopia and Kenya is, respectively, 28 per cent and 43 per cent, adolescents and young adults represent 74 per cent of unprotected individuals in South Korea, 66 per cent in Italy and 53 per cent in the US, with considerable immunity gaps in individuals aged 30-40 years.  \"Every effort to increase the vaccination coverage rate among children is praiseworthy\", says Alessia Melegaro, a Bocconi professor and principal investigator of DECIDE, the ERC European Research Council-funded project which produced the article, \"but in some developed countries it's the lack of coverage among adolescents and adults that poses a serious threat to the goal of eliminating measles.\"  \"Measles incidence could increase, in the next decades, in Italy, Australia, and Singapore and Ethiopia is at high risk of future large epidemics\", says Stefano Merler from Bruno Kessler Foundation, \"and this is particularly worrying considering that individuals get infected later in life when the disease is more severe. The median age at infection for 2015 was estimated to be 5-10 years in the UK, Ireland, and Ethiopia; 10-15 years in the USA, Australia, Singapore, and Kenya; and older than 20 years in Italy and South Korea\".  The proposed model shows that the introduction of the measles vaccine, which occurred at different times in the 9 countries, has considerably reduced the disease burden in terms of disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs), a measure expressed as the number of years lost because of illness, disability, or early death. Every vaccine dose averts 2 or 3 weeks of DALYs in the developed world and around 20 weeks in Kenya and Ethiopia. Which translates into 2-mln years 2 million DALYs since the vaccine introduction in the UK, 13-mln 13 million DALYs in the US, and 36-mln 36 million DALYs in Ethiopia.  \"Vaccination has undoubtedly achieved incredible results in terms of public health. In particular,\" continues Prof Melegaro \"our analysis showed that routine 1st dose vaccine administration has been responsible for more than 90 per cent of the overall number of vaccine-immunized individuals in most countries. In Ethiopia and Kenya, catch-up and follow-up campaigns substantially mitigated the effect of suboptimum routine vaccine coverage, generating 25-45 per cent of the immunized fraction of the population. Tailoring immunization campaigns to achieve measles eradication goals is essential and currently, for some countries, this means considering also the role of unprotected adolescents and young adults.\"   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Reference - Trentini F, Poletti P, Merler S, Melegaro A. Measles immunity gaps and the progress towards elimination: a multi-country modelling analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30421-8. Epub ahead of print; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28807627).   While it is recommended that children get 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12 through 15 months of age, and the 2nd dose at 4 through 6 years of age, this study emphasizes that it is important that adolescents and young adults also are up to date on their MMR vaccination. - All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. As per a weekly report issued by Prevention and Control\nProgram for Dengue in Sindh, as many as 27 new dengue fever cases\nsurfaced in the city from 1 to 7 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/08/363624/a27-more-dengue-cases-surface-in-karachi/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 8 Aug 2017. 3rd death due to dengue\nhemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. Most of the affected patients were\nbrought from the Tehkal Payan area from where water samples have been\ncollected to determine the situation.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1476245/third-dengue-death-\nreported-k-p/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 16 Aug 2017. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. Dengue continues in\nPeshawar, claiming 7 lives with 69 new cases reported from different\nareas of the city during the last 24 hours, raising the number of\ntotal cases to 1703. So far, he said, 7 deaths including 6 from Khyber\nTeaching Hospital and one in Hayatabad Medical Complex were reported\nfrom dengue epidemics in Peshawar. Out of 69 new cases, 41 were\nreported in Khyber Teaching Hospital (KTH), 13 in Hayatabad Medical\nComplex (HMC), 12 in Lady Reading Hospital (LRH), and 3 in Naseerullah\nKhan Babar Teaching Hospital (NBTH), Peshawar, he said. A rapid\nresponse team has also been set up with mandate to swiftly reach to\nthe affected areas from where new cases were surfaced besides helping\nthe field staff in conduct of fumigation spray, removal of larvae, and\nprovision of other necessary medicines.\n(https://dnd.com.pk/dengue-rampage-in-peshawar-kills-seven-69-new-cases-surface/133250) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://pakistanmap.facts.co/pakistanmapof/PakistanAdministrativeMap.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ China\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp). 16 Aug 2017.\nGuangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in south China has reported its 1st\nimported dengue case this year 2017, local inspection and quarantine\nbureau said. Over the past 2\nmonths, around 90 patients were taken to HCM Paediatrics Hospital No 1\nper week on average.\n(http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/182701/rising-dengue-fever-cases-leave-17-dead.html) - National. 19 Aug 2017. The number of dengue fever cases in Viet Nam\nspiked by some 10 000 cases in the past week. This is up by about 10 000 since the last total case\ncount was released on 3 Aug 207. The outbreak is stretching the\ncountry's medical system as more than 78 000 of the cases required\nhospitalization. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed strain homology with the Burkina Faso 2016 strain. On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. Sir Gangaram Hospital reported the rare case,\nwhere the woman, who went to the eye OPD outpatient department,\ncomplained of \"sudden blurring of vision in the left eye,\" as reported\nby IE Indian Express. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017. The total number of reported dengue cases including\ndengue haemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome was lower than the\n3 year-threshold of the same period from 2014-2016. China\nAs of 31 Jul 2017, there were 503 cases of dengue reported in China in\n2017. This number is higher than that reported during the same period\nsince 2012 but follows historical trend. Lao PDR People's Democratic Republic\nAs of 4 Aug 2017, there were 5740 cases of dengue with 7 deaths\nreported in Lao PDR in 2017, with 406 cases reported in epi week 31\n(week ending 5 Aug 2017). Dengue activity is high with the number of\ndengue cases reported this year 2017 being higher than the cases\nreported for same period since 2014. During week 31, there were 61 cases\nreported and the number of reported cases in 2017 remains lower than\nthose reported for the same time period in 2016 . Viet Nam\nAs of 3 Aug 2017, there were 80 555 cases of dengue reported in Viet\nNam including 22 deaths. Compared with the same period in 2016, the\ncumulative number of cases increased by 33.5 per cent, and the number\nof deaths rose by 5. Most cases were reported from the South (59 per\ncent). A sharp increase in the number of reported cases has been\nobserved in the North (almost 25 times higher than the same period\nlast year 2016), especially from Ha Noi, with about 13 440 cases.
