The number of cases reported is lower\nthan that reported during the same time period in the previous years\n(2012-2016). Pacific Islands countries and areas\n\nFrench Polynesia\nIn French Polynesia, 12 cases (including 1 death) in week 29 and 12\ncases in week 30 (week ending 29 Jul 2017). Among these, 15 cases were\nconfirmed as DENV-1 infection. New Caledonia (no update)\nAs of 1 Aug 2017, 4,452 dengue cases were reported in 2017. There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Finland":{"13":{"title":"Measles update (41): Europe (Finland, Italy) ","date":["17","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (41): Europe (Finland, Italy) [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nMEASLES UPDATE (41): EUROPE (FINLAND, ITALY)\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nEurope\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Finland\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Italy\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Italy \nEurope\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Finland.\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017.\nSource: Eurosurveillance 2017;22(33) (edited)\n(http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22857) \nA cluster of measles linked to an imported case, Finland, 2017\n\nSeppälä E, Zöldi V, Vuorinen S, Murtopuro S, et al. A young Italian adult was diagnosed with measles in Finland in June\n2017. During the stay in Finland and subsequent travel to Estonia, the\ncase exposed altogether several hundred persons to measles. As of Fri\n11 Aug 2017, 5 secondary cases of measles have been detected. As the\ninvestigation is still ongoing, we present here the preliminary\nfindings and implemented control measures regarding this cluster of\nmeasles. Description of the cluster\n\nIndex Case 1 was a young Italian adult who arrived in Finland on Sun\n11 Jun 2017 and attended an international camp in Finland from 12 to\n25 Jun 2017 (Figure 1 for Figures/Tables, see original URL -\nMod.LL). After developing fever and respiratory symptoms on Fri 16 Jun 2017\nand rash on Wed 21 Jun 2017, Case 1 was admitted to the hospital of\nCity A and was isolated and monitored because enterovirus infection or\nmeasles was suspected. Serum and throat specimens were taken on Thu\n22 Jun 2017. While the confirmatory laboratory results were still\npending, the case was discharged and returned to the camp premises on\nSat 24 Jun 2017. On Sun 25 Jun 2017, Case 1 traveled to Helsinki\nby train (without a designated seat, 3.5 hours) and to Tallinn by\nferry (no cabin booked, 2.5 hours), staying one night before flying\nback to Italy. On Tue 27 Jun 2017, Case 1 was laboratory-confirmed\nfor measles infection. The case self-reported to be vaccinated with 2\ndoses of measles-containing vaccine; however, the laboratory results\ncontradicted this as the case tested negative for measles-specific IgG\nantibodies (Table). Subsequently, 5 secondary cases of measles were identified (Figures 1\nand 2). 4 of them were laboratory-confirmed (Cases 2, 4, 5 and 6).\nCase 3 was classified as a probable case (no laboratory testing\nbecause of parental objection). Cases 2 and 3 were adolescent siblings\nliving in City A. Both attended a summer camp organized at the same\npremises as the international camp. Both were placed in home\nisolation. Case 4 was a person working in a cafeteria in City B who\nhad visited the camp premises on Mon 19 Jun 2017. Cases 2, 3 and 4\nhad lunch in the same canteen used by other camp attendees including\nCase 1. Epidemiological investigations for Case 5 are still ongoing\nbut so far no link between other cases has been established. It is\npossible that there is an unknown case in the transmission chain. Case\n6 was a close contact of Case 5, identified during contact tracing.\nThe case had been vaccinated with 2 doses of the measles-mumps-rubella\n(MMR) vaccine in childhood; all other secondary cases were\nunvaccinated (Table). Laboratory findings\n-\nHealthcare providers were asked to send all clinical samples from\nsuspected measles cases to the measles reference laboratory of the\nFinnish National Institute for Health and Welfare (THL). Measles\nsequences available for 5 cases were identical and genotyped as D8\n(Table). Based on the Measles Nucleotide Surveillance database, this\nstrain was identical to strains isolated in Italy during 2017 and to a\nstrain identified in a British traveler, and it shared very high\nnucleotide similarity () 99.78 percent) with more than 600 sequences\ndetected on 5 continents between 2015 and 2017, indicating recent\nglobal spread of nearly identical measles viruses 1,2. 6 suspected\ncases were discarded after laboratory analysis. In addition, 3\npotentially exposed, asymptomatic people tested negative for measles. Conclusion\n\nIn Finland, a country with nationally high MMR vaccination coverage,\nextensive outbreaks of measles are unlikely to occur. However,\ntransmission chains among unimmunized individuals linked to an\nimported case are possible. A prompt response and the cooperation of\nhealth authorities, the media and possible other stakeholders are\ncrucial to interrupt transmission chains as soon as possible. Ensuring\nuniversally high vaccination coverage is essential to prevent clusters\nand outbreaks in the future. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The full report can be found at the source URL. - Mod.ML \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Italy.\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017.\nSource: Eurosurveillance 2017;22(33) (edited)\n(http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22858) \nOngoing large measles outbreak with nosocomial transmission in Milan,\nnorthern Italy, March-August 2017\n\nAmendola A, Bianchi S, Frati ER, Ciceri G, et al. A large measles outbreak has been ongoing in Milan and surrounding\nareas, a densely populated area with nearly 4 million inhabitants.\nRapid and active surveillance was set up by the Subnational Reference\nLaboratories (SRL) Milan, established as part of the measles and\nrubella surveillance network MoRoNet <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> in March 2017, with 303\ninvestigated cases at the time of submission of this report. We\npresent a detailed analysis of the period 1 Mar 2017 to 30 Jun 2017,\nwith the aim to conduct a complete and rapid characterization of\nwild-type measles virus (MV) strains circulating. Confirmation and investigation of cases and clusters in Milan\n\nFrom 1 Mar to 30 Jun 2017, 233 suspected cases of measles were\ninvestigated: there were 203 (87 percent) laboratory-confirmed cases\n(median age: 30 years; range: 2 months-77 years) and 30 (13 percent)\nwere discarded. Overall 60 percent (n = 121) of the confirmed\ncases were individuals aged 15-39 years and 6 percent (n = 12)\nwere ≤ 1 year of age; 88 percent (n = 179) were not\nvaccinated and 12 percent (n = 24) were vaccinated (6 with 2 doses\nof measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine, 10 with one dose, and 8 did\nnot know the number of doses). According to the epidemiological\nregional database, 108 of 203 were sporadic cases and 95 were related\nto 47 clusters. Cases were classified as sporadic when an\nepidemiological link to other cases could not be established. Molecular surveillance for cases and clusters\n\nThe genotype of MV strains was successfully identified in 187 of 203\n(92 percent) of the confirmed cases by sequencing the highly variable\nregion of nucleoprotein (N) gene (N-450) <br><br><strong>{2}</strong>. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed that the MV strains belonged to genotypes D8 and B3. The most\ncommon genotype detected was genotype D8 (86 percent; 160/187 cases)\nwhich was related to 77 cases in 42 clusters and 83 sporadic cases.\nAll of the D8 cases and clusters were autochthonous or from unknown\nsource. In March 2017, the B3 genotype was detected in 5 imported cases: 2\nsporadic cases and 3 cases which subsequently caused 3 import-related\nclusters. From Apr 2017 to end of Jun 2017, a further 14 autochthonous\nsporadic cases and one cluster were reported. The geographical and\ntemporal distribution, respectively, of sporadic cases and clusters\nrelated to D8 and B3 genotypes are shown in Figure 1 and Figure 2 for\nFigures, see original URL - Mod.LL. Measles virus genotype D8\n\nPhylogenetic analysis showed that all the D8 sequences (n = 160)\nfell into the Osaka lineage (MVi/Osaka.JPN/29.15; similarity range:\n99-100 percent). From March to May, D8 MV strains mainly caused\nclusters in work and family settings, which occurred principally in\nthe north-eastern area of Milan. During the week starting on Mon 27\nMar 2017, a serious family cluster affected 3 cases causing the death\nof one of them. The D8 MV strain was isolated from the biological\nsamples of one of these cases. In Jun 2017, the D8 Osaka variant spread through the city of Milan and\ncaused a nosocomial cluster in a hospital. Based on epidemiological\ndata, a link was established between 12 cases: 8 healthcare workers\n(HCWs), 3 patients and one visitor. Phylogenetic analysis showed that\nthe 9 sequences obtained were 100 percent identical. The match of\nepidemiological data and phylogenetic analysis highlighted a single\ntransmission chain for all cases (Figure 3). Measles virus genotype B3\n\nPhylogenetic analysis showed that all B3 sequences (n = 27) were\nidentical to the variant Dublin (MVs/Dublin.IRL/8.16; similarity: 100\npercent) which is circulating in European countries and responsible\nfor an ongoing epidemic in Romania <br><br><strong>{3}</strong>. The B3 Dublin variant was 1st\nintroduced in the east of Milan at the beginning of March 2017, and\nthere was an epidemiological link to the Roma community in France. By\nthe end of March 2017, this variant was detected in a sporadic case\nreturning from Piedmont (northern Italy). Subsequently, the same\nvariant was isolated in a cluster caused by an index case returning\nfrom the Apulia Region (southern Italy) and in a cluster that was\nimported from Romania. In April 2017, genotype B3 was identified in a\nsporadic case returning from the Lazio Region (central Italy). During May 2017 and June 2017, 12 autochthonous cases were notified in\nthe eastern and south-eastern suburbs of Milan. In June 2017, 3\nnosocomial clusters were identified in an emergency department.\nAlthough initially reported as unrelated clusters, the phylogenetic\nanalysis showed a single source of transmission (n = 7, 2 HCWs, 4\npatients, and one visitor) (Figure 3). Conclusions\n\nEliminating measles and rubella is a core goal of World Health\nOrganization European Region Member States. Effective surveillance is\nessential for eliminating measles and rubella and its verification\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong>. Since the beginning of 2017 and up to Sun 6 Aug 2017, the\nItalian Ministry of Health has reported 4087 cases of measles and 3\ndeaths. Most cases occurred in Piedmont and Lombardy (northern Italy),\nTuscany, Lazio and Abruzzo (central Italy) and Sicily (southern\nItaly). Most were older than 15 years (median age: 27 years) and 89\npercent of the cases were not vaccinated. Overall, 42 percent of the\ncases were hospitalized and 277 cases were reported among HCWs <br><br><strong>{5}</strong>. Timely measles surveillance is critical to disease control.\nIdentifying and confirming suspected measles cases through\nsurveillance allows early detection of outbreaks and analysis of\nongoing transmission in order to mount more effective vaccination\nmeasures. MV genotyping can play an important role in tracking\ntransmission pathways during outbreak investigations <br><br><strong>{6}</strong>. From March to June 2017, the genotypes D8 and B3 co-circulated in\nMilan and surrounding areas. The most common genotype detected was\ngenotype D8, related to 83 sporadic cases and 42 clusters. The high\nsimilarity between the D8 MV strains, all belonging to the Osaka\nlineage, suggests a unique initiating transmission event. This is the\n1st evidence of the Osaka D8 variant in northern Italy, which seems to\nbe replacing the D8 variants that had been circulating in this area\nsince 2013 7,8. Moreover, our data show multiple imported cases of\nB3 MV strains which subsequently spread across Italy and caused\nseveral autochthonous cases and clusters. The B3 Dublin variant has\nreplaced the B3 variant Como that had been present in this Italian\narea from August 2015 to November 2016 <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>. By the end of June 2017, D8 MV strains and B3 MV strains had caused\nclusters in 2 major Milanese hospitals. In August (current month)\n2017, the epidemic is still ongoing and the number of notified cases\nduring the month of July was almost twice the number of cases notified\nin June 2017. Other authors have already reported that where there\nis evidence of both nosocomial and community transmission of measles,\nnosocomial transmission appeared to precede community transmission\nwith a peak of hospital-acquired cases occurring almost 2 weeks before\nthe peak of the community outbreak <br><br><strong>{10}</strong>. In conclusion, the suboptimal immunization level (92.5 percent\nvaccination coverage rate in Lombardy Region; <br><br><strong>{11}</strong>) and the consequent\naccumulation of susceptible population have led to an increase in the\ntransmission of measles in northern Italy with detrimental effects on\nboth public health and ongoing measles elimination efforts.\nFurthermore, the nosocomial outbreaks highlight the importance of\nimproving measles vaccination coverage of healthcare workers. The full report can be found at the source URL. - Mod.ML \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Italy.\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017.\nSource: Eurosurveillance 2017;22(33) (edited)\n(http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22859) \nA nosocomial measles outbreak in Italy, February-April 2017\n\nPorretta A, Quattrone F, Aquino F, Pieve G, et al. Measles vaccination coverage is suboptimal in Italy (ranging between\n85.4 percent and 90.6 percent for one dose during the period\n2007-2016) <br><br><strong>{1}</strong>, which has led to large pockets of susceptible adults.\nWe describe an outbreak in an Italian hospital between February and\nApril 2017 among healthcare workers (HCW), hospital support personnel\n(hospital workers in activities not involving direct contact with\npatients), hospital visitors and community contacts. This outbreak was\npart of a wider epidemic in Italy that started in January 2017 and\nhas, as at Sun 30 Jul 2017, led to 4001 cases nationwide (275 in\nHCW) <br><br><strong>{2}</strong>. Outbreak description\n\nA HCW was referred to the emergency department (ED) of an Italian\nhospital for a rash developed after taking antibacterials for a mild\ncough and coryza. The rash was considered an allergic reaction to the\nantibacterial and the HCW was admitted to the hospital inpatient\nclinic. Three days later, the HCW's child was admitted to hospital for\na rash diagnosed as due to a non-communicable systemic disease. Subsequent serology showed that both the HCW and the child had\nmeasles. The origin of the infection for the index case is still\nunknown. It should be noted, however, that at least 10 community cases\nof measles occurred in the same period in the area of residence of the\nHCW. Using the standard case definition of the European Commission <br><br><strong>{3}</strong>, a\ntotal of 34 measles cases during the following weeks were identified\nby tracing the contacts of the index case. Among them, 15 were HCWs, 5\nwere support personnel, 4 were hospital visitors and 11 were community\ncontacts of the above cases. The secondary cases to the index (n = 8) occurred in 2 of the\nHCW's relatives, in 4 other HCWs, and in 2 support workers who were\nnot immediately recognized as belonging to the hospital outbreak. One\nof the secondary cases, a HCW, was in service until the onset of\nsymptoms, accessing all rooms on 2 inpatient wards. Tertiary cases\n(n = 6) involved the family of this HCW, 3 HCWs and a member of\nsupport personnel. A total of 2 weeks after the admission of the index case, 2 of the\nHCWs belonging to tertiary cases presented during the night to the ED\nwhere they stayed for nearly 10 hours. An additional 15 cases could be\ntraced following this single exposure window, namely 7 HCWs, 2 support\nworkers, 3 relatives of theirs and 3 visitors to the ED during the\ntime the 2 HCWs were present. One more community case was related to\ncontact outside hospital with one of the tertiary HCW cases.\nAdditional cases were related to a visitor at one of the involved\ninpatient wards, who probably got in contact with one of the tertiary\ncases who were HCW during the incubation period and generated 3 cases\nin the community, among them a family pediatrician. Figure 1 and Figure 2 show the epidemic curve and the outbreak tree\nfor figures, see original URL - Mod.LL. Characteristics of cases\n-\nUp to 6 cases occurred in children up to 9 years of age, while 2\noccurred in adolescents between 10 and 17 years and the majority of\ncases (n = 27) in adults 18 years and older. Figure 3 describes\nthe age distribution among different categories of cases. Vaccination status was known for 24 cases. Sixteen were unvaccinated\n(2 children, 14 adults), 2 had received one dose, one a full course of\n2 doses, and 5 cases occurred in contacts who received one dose of\npost-exposure vaccination. Of the 5 contacts who received post\nexposure vaccine, one was an infant younger than one year for whom\ninformation about the date of vaccination is not available; for the\nother 4, the delay between presumed contact date and immunization was\n3 days in 2 cases, 6 and 12 days for the remaining 2 cases. Among the\nHCWs, 2 were vaccinated, 11 were unvaccinated and for 2 of them the\ndata was unavailable. Among the 5 cases belonging to support personnel\n2 were unvaccinated and the status was unknown for the remaining 3. Genotyping was available for 3 cases: genotype B3, subtype 3.1 was\nfound in all of them. Conclusion and recommendations\n\nMeasles elimination in Europe, despite the immunization efforts, is\nstill jeopardized by recurrent outbreaks in susceptible populations\n4-7. Nosocomial transmission of measles is an important and emerging\nway of spreading the infection 8-11. Anyone staying in the hospital\nenvironment, regardless of role, can be affected because measles is\nhighly contagious and persists in the environment for up to 2 hours,\nthus requiring appropriate and timely infection control measures\n12,13.\nConsidering that transmission may occur 3 days before the onset of\nrash, early diagnosis when only non-specific preliminary symptoms\n(cough, coryza and conjunctivitis) are present is crucial for\ncontaining the outbreak <br><br><strong>{14}</strong>.\nA single exposure window, that occurred 2 weeks after the admission of\nthe index case, when 2 cases were present in the ED, resulted in\nfurther 15 cases. \nAppropriate procedures are needed for patients with suspect\ntransmissible infection in the ED, an issue not limited to measles but\nshared with several other highly infective conditions <br><br><strong>{13}</strong>.\nA 2-dose vaccination is the most effective measure to prevent measles\n<br><br><strong>{15}</strong>. This is of crucial importance for HCWs, with a view to their\nhigher risk of exposure and of transmission to vulnerable patients. However, it should be noted that in at least 5 cases in this outbreak,\nmeasles occurred in personnel working in the hospital environment in\nsupport functions, highlighting the need to take into consideration\nthe role of such personnel in the spread of the infection. Given that\nmost of the support personnel belong to outsourced services,\ncoordination is needed between occupational health unit and\noccupational health responsible of outsourced services. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The full report can be found at the source URL. - Mod.ML There is no doubt that inadequate immunization levels are the major\ncontributor to outbreaks of measles. Most of this is due to not\nreceiving the 2 doses of vaccine due to personal or parenteral choice.\nAggressive programs to reverse this unfortunate trend are needed to\nprevent outbreaks of this potentially lethal disease. The nosocomial\nsetting as reflected in the 3rd post represents a special case\nsituation. It is not clear why health care workers are not required to\nbe immunized for measles. Additionally, when a case of measles is\nintroduced into a health care facility, it has been my experience that\nthe infection is not recognized promptly to minimize nosocomial\nspread. - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/75). ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"France":{"6":{"title":"Hepatitis A - USA (20): (CA) fatal ","date":["16","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Hepatitis A - USA (20): (CA) fatal [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nHEPATITIS A - USA (20): (CALIFORNIA) FATAL\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Wed 16 Aug 2017.\nSource: California Health Alert Network (edited)\n(http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/dam/sdc/hhsa/programs/phs/cahan/communications_documents/08-16-2017-Hep%20A.pdf) \nUpdate no. 5: hepatitis A virus outbreak in San Diego county\n\nThis health advisory updates local healthcare providers about recent\nhepatitis A virus (HAV) infections disproportionately affecting\nhomeless and illicit drug-using individuals in San Diego County.\nUpdated recommendations and resources on HAV are provided. Situation\n\nAs of 14 Aug 2017, 333 confirmed or probable HAV cases have been\nreported in an ongoing local outbreak in San Diego County. The cases\nhad symptom onsets between 22 Nov 2016 and 8 Aug 2017. 232 (70\npercent) of the cases have been hospitalized, and 11 patients (3\npercent) have died. The cases range in age from 19 to 87 years (median\n= 44 years), and 227 (68 percent) are male, with 2 (1 percent)\nself-identifying as men who have sex with men (MSM). 131 (39 percent) of the HAV cases are homeless and reported injection\nor non-injection illicit drug use, 53 (16 percent) were homeless only,\n36 (11 percent) were illicit drug users only, 76 (23 percent) were\nneither homeless nor drug users, and 37 (11 percent) had an unknown\nstatus for homelessness and drug use. Of the cases with test results\navailable for review, 58 of 262 (22 percent) have chronic hepatitis C\ninfection, and 15 of 261 (6 percent) have chronic hepatitis B\ninfection. Despite the fact that the majority of the cases in this outbreak had a\nknown indication for HAV immunization, only one case had been\nvaccinated prior to becoming infected: a 20-year-old who had routine\nHAV immunizations as a child. Most of the outbreak cases have been from the El Cajon/La Mesa area\nand downtown San Diego. Some cases have been confirmed in individuals\nwho were only in the southern or northern parts of the county during\ntheir exposure periods. There are several clusters of\nepidemiologically associated cases, although no specific common food,\nbeverage, or drug sources have been identified. Case clusters have\nbeen reported in individuals who have used the same homeless services\nproviders and in the following types of facilities with shared\nrestrooms: jails, single room occupancy hotels, residential drug\ntreatment facilities, and assisted living facilities. 3 healthcare\nworkers contracted HAV infection in this outbreak, as have four food\nhandlers, although no secondary cases have resulted from the\nindividuals working in these sensitive occupations. The CDC has confirmed HAV RNA in serum samples of 199 outbreak cases.\nViral sequencing indicates that 8 unique, closely related strains of\nHAV genotype 1B are involved. These strains are different than those\nassociated with an ongoing HAV outbreak in southeastern Michigan and\nthe outbreaks linked to frozen strawberries in 2016 and pomegranate\narils (seed pods) in 2013. The main outbreak strain in San Diego is\nidentical to one of the strains causing an ongoing HAV outbreak in\nSanta Cruz County. Investigations of the confirmed and probable cases, as well as 37\nsuspect cases, are ongoing. 19 HAV cases have been reported in 2017\nthat are travel-related and are not part of the local outbreak totals.\nOf note, 1 case was diagnosed with symptomatic HAV infection 4 weeks\nafter a trip to Paris, and viral sequence analysis indicated that the\nHAV strain causing his infection is identical to the one causing an\noutbreak among MSM in France. Background\n-\nPerson-to-person transmission through the fecal-oral route is the\nprimary means of HAV transmission in the USA. Most infections result\nfrom close personal contact with an infected household member or\nsexual partner, or their fecally contaminated environment. Hands may\nplay a significant role in the direct and indirect spread of HAV.\nCommonsource outbreaks and sporadic cases can also occur from exposure\nto fecally contaminated food or water. Individuals with increased risk for HAV infection include: travelers\nto countries with high or intermediate endemicity of HAV, MSM, users\nof injection and non-injection illicit drugs, persons with clotting\nfactor disorders, and persons working with nonhuman primates. HAV\noutbreaks have been reported among the homeless, who have a higher\nmorbidity and mortality when compared with the general population and\nan increased risk of infection due to living conditions. Individuals\nwith chronic liver conditions, such as hepatitis B or C, are also\nrecommended to get HAV vaccination because of their increased\nmorbidity and mortality risks should they contract HAV. Recommendations for providers\n\n1. Consider HAV infection in individuals, especially the homeless and\nthose who use illicit drugs, with discrete symptom onset and jaundice\nor elevated liver function tests.\n- Symptoms of concern include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia,\nfever, malaise, dark urine, light-colored stool, and abdominal pain.\n- A complete serology panel with testing for hepatitis A, B, and C is\nrecommended in symptomatic patients. HIV testing is also recommended\nfor those with an undocumented HIV-status.\n- Serologic testing for HAV infection is not recommended in\nasymptomatic individuals or as screening before vaccination. 2. Promptly report all confirmed and suspect HAV cases to the\nEpidemiology Program.\n- Please fax Confidential Morbidity Report (CMRa)\n(http://www.sandiegocounty.gov/content/dam/sdc/hhsa/programs/phs/documents/CMRa.pdf),\nor call 619-692-8499 (Monday-Friday, 8 AM-5 PM), or 858565-5255 (after\nhours, during weekends, and on county-observed holidays).\n- Since this outbreak involves homeless individuals, providers are\nurged to contact the Epidemiology Program while suspected cases are\nstill at the healthcare facility. This action will ensure that a\npublic health investigator can interview the patient by phone for a\nrisk history and will facilitate serum specimen submission to the San\nDiego County Public Health Laboratory for possible genotyping. 3. Provide post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for close contacts of\nconfirmed HAV cases.\n- Susceptible people exposed to HAV should receive a dose of\nsingle-antigen HAV vaccine intramuscular (IM) immune globulin (IG)\n(0.1 mL/kg), or both, as soon as possible within 2 weeks of last\nexposure. The PEP dosage of IG was recently increased and is higher\nthan that noted in the package insert.\n- The efficacy of combined HAV/Hepatitis B virus (HBV) vaccine\n(Twinrix®) for PEP has not been evaluated, so it is not recommended\nfor PEP.\n- Detailed information on PEP may be found on the CDPH California\nDepartment of Public Health Hepatitis A PEP Guidance Quicksheet\n(updated July 2017)\n(https://archive.cdph.ca.gov/programs/immunize/Documents/CDPH_HAV%20PEP%20Clinical%20Guidance.pdf)\nand the CDPH Hepatitis A PEP IG Administration Quicksheet (updated\nAugust 2017)\n(https://www.cdph.ca.gov/Programs/CID/DCDC/CDPH%20Document%20Library/Immunization/HepatitisA-IGPEPGuidance.pdf). 4. Provide HAV vaccine to homeless individuals, illicit drug users,\npatients with chronic liver diseases, MSM, and other at-risk people\nwho are not already immunized, and to any individual who desires\nimmunity to HAV.\n- The 1st dose of single-antigen HAV vaccine (Havrix®, Vaqta®)\nappears to protect more persons than the 1st dose of the combined\nHAV/HBV (Twinrix®) vaccine, but efficacy is comparable after\ncompletion of the respective series. Providers should consider\nshort-term risks of exposure to HAV, the likelihood of follow-up to\ncomplete immunization, and the need for protection from HBV when\nselecting vaccines for those at risk. Immunization against HAV with\nexisting supplies should not be delayed to obtain a different\nformulation of vaccine.\n- Providers who do not have available vaccine may direct patients to\nan immunization clinic at the nearest County Public Health Center.\n-Providers who care for homeless individuals may contact the\nImmunization Program at 619-692-5607 (Monday-Friday, 8 AM-5 PM) to\nlearn how to obtain 317-funded HAV vaccine for use during this\noutbreak.\n- Homeless individuals and illicit drug users are also at higher risk\nfor other vaccine preventable diseases and should be brought\nup-to-date with recommended vaccines per the relevant CDC immunization\nschedule.\n- Providers should check the San Diego Immunization Registry to see if\npatients are already vaccinated and note any vaccinations given.\n- Some individuals who are at risk for HAV may be uncomfortable\ndisclosing the reasons that they are at risk to a provider, so the\nAdvisory Committee on Immunization Practices routinely recommends HAV\nvaccination \"for any person wishing to obtain immunity.\"\n- Adult HAV vaccination is covered by Medi-Cal without prior\nauthorization. 5. Provide HAV vaccination to individuals who have frequent, ongoing\nclose contact with homeless individuals and illicit drug users, and to\nall food handlers in San Diego County.\n- The County Public Health Officer recommends HAV vaccination for\nindividuals with ongoing, close contact with homeless and illicit drug\nusing individuals in San Diego County. This local recommendation is\nbeing made due to the current outbreak and includes persons working in\nhealth care, public safety, sanitation, homeless shelters, and\nhomeless and behavioral service provider agencies.\n- The County Public Health Officer recommends HAV vaccination for all\nfood handlers in San Diego County. This local recommendation is being\nmade to reduce the potential risk of an ill food handler transmitting\nHAV to others. 6. Encourage those who are planning an international trip to check the\nCDC Travelers' Health website and to obtain recommended vaccinations\nbefore travel.\n- High-risk areas for HAV include parts of Africa and Asia, and\nmoderate-risk areas include Central and South America, Eastern Europe,\nand parts of Asia.\n- There are currently HAV outbreaks associated with MSM occurring in\nNew York City and in Western Europe, notably France, Portugal, and\nSpain. MSM should be vaccinated against HAV, especially prior to\ntravel, and be instructed on prevention measures for HAV and other\nsexually transmitted illnesses. 7. Ensure that all healthcare workers use standard precautions in\npatient care to protect themselves against HAV. HAV, like norovirus,\nis a non-enveloped virus, and it may be similarly difficult to\ninactivate in the environment. Alcohol-based hand rubs and\ntypically-used surface disinfectants may not be effective. Therefore,\nadditional precautions to take include:\n- Wash hands with soap and running water for at least 20 seconds after\nproviding care for an HAV patient.\n- Use contact precautions, in addition to standard precautions, in the\ncare of diapered or incontinent HAV patients.\n- Wash hands with soap and running water for at least 20 seconds\nbefore eating and after using a restroom.\n- Use employee-designated restrooms when available, and do not touch\nthe door handle directly when exiting a restroom.\n- Do not eat in patient care areas and never share food, drink or\ncigarettes with patients.\n- Do not handle a cell phone just before (or while) eating. Studies\nhave shown that cell phones have high rates of surface contamination\nwith enteric organisms (and for hospital employees, organisms\nassociated with hospital acquired infections).\n- Perform environmental cleaning in areas housing HAV patients with\nbleach products or other products effective against norovirus.\n- HAV vaccine is recommended for unvaccinated healthcare workers\ncaring for HAV patients or individuals at risk for HAV. The vaccine\nshould be available and encouraged for other unvaccinated healthcare\npersonnel concerned about increased exposure to HAV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nEric McDonald\nCounty of San Diego Health and Human Services Agency\nCalifornia\nUSA\n(eric.mcdonald@sdcounty.ca.gov) ProMED thanks Eric McDonald for this posting. An outbreak epicurve showing number of cases plotted against week of\nonset of symptoms is included in the report and can be found at the\nsource URL above. Since mid-April 2017, about 15-20 cases per week\nhave been reported and seems to be continuing at this rate. A more\ndetailed description of the case cohort is included in this report and\n66 percent had either homelessness and/or non-injection illicit drug\nuse as risk factors. At this point, there have been 11 deaths in the\ncohort but it is not clear if co-infection with either HBV or HCV is a\nrisk factor for death. Clearly, MSM is not a significant risk factor\nin this ongoing outbreak. - Mod.LL The state of California can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/787). San Diego\ncounty can be seen on the map at\n(http://geology.com/county-map/california-county-map.gif). -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ ","keywordsMatched":[]},"54":{"title":"Measles update (42): Europe, Middle East, Africa, Pacific\r\n\t","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (42): Europe, Middle East, Africa, Pacific\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nMEASLES UPDATE (42): EUROPE, MIDDLE EAST, AFRICA, PACIFIC\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nEurope\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Romania\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> France (Ardèche) Middle East\n\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Israel ex Ukraine Africa\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Uganda (Kampala, Wakiso) Pacific\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia) \n\nEurope\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Romania.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Romanian Business News-ACT Media (edited)\n(http://actmedia.eu/daily/healthmin-bodog-measles-epidemic-consequence-of-major-malfunctions-in-vaccination-public-policy/70944) \nA total of 8493 confirmed measles cases had been reported by Fri 11\nAug 2017, since the outbreak of the disease in 2016, informs a\nrelease on the website of the National Center for the Surveillance and\nControl of Communicable Diseases of the National Public Health\nInstitute. Among these cases there were 32 deaths, as follows: 8 in\nTimis County, 6 in Arad, 7 in Dolj, 3 in Caras-Severin, and one in\neach Bihor, Cluj, Calarasi, Satu Mare, Vaslui, Galati, Mures, and\nBucharest. Measles outbreaks have been registered in all 41 counties,\nthe most affected  with over 1000 cases each  being Timis (1215\ncases), Caras-Severin (1110), and Arad (1002). The measles outbreak in Romania in 2016 is not circumstantial, but a\ndirect consequence of the \"major\" malfunctions in public policy\nregarding vaccination, minister of health Florian Bodog stated on Fri\n11 Aug in a press release. \"For years now Romania has been below the\nsafety threshold of vaccination coverage. That is, the risk of a\nmeasles outbreak was imminent. Which is what actually happened. The\noutbreak of the measles epidemic in 2016 is not conjectural, it is a\ndirect consequence of major malfunctions in the public policy on\nvaccination,\" the minister of health stated. According to him, the Vaccination Law corrects the irregularities that\nled to the epidemic, providing the best conditions for protecting\nchildren's health. \"For Romania, the stake of the vaccination bill is\nhuge. Ensuring a healthy future for 4 million children lies in our\nhands. The Romanian parliament, the highest institution of democracy,\nwill decide on the final content of this law. However, beyond the\ndebates in parliament, it is important that all the public opinion be\ninformed and understand the true meaning of the law and the profound\nchanges it brings. (..) We have a moral duty towards our children, to\nprevent harm before it happens. As we also have a moral duty to the\ncommunity in which we live to prevent harm before it happens to other\nchildren or parents,\" Bodog said, quoted in the press release. He added that any bill is amendable and that is why it is open to any\npublic debates as long as they are carried out with honesty, good\nsense and decency. \"But this project is the day-to-day work of\nspecialists in the field of vaccination and who have faced all the\nflaws of the current framework. That is why the law has been carefully\nand correctly thought through by those who best understand how to\nregulate the vaccination policy,\" the minister of health also said. The bill on the organisation and funding of public vaccination in\nRomania was adopted by the government on Wed 9 Aug 2017. The bill\nwas submitted to parliament for debate and adoption. The normative act\nwould come into force on 1 Jan 2018. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) A similar report can be found in El Pais (12 Aug 2017) which states\nin addition that, of the 95 per cent vaccine coverage recommended by\nthe World Health Organization (WHO), 86 per cent have been\nvaccinated since 2007, according to its national epidemiological\ncentre. \"Highly worrying\" figures, acknowledged the prime minister,\nMihai Tudose, this week. \"More than 180 000 children in our country,\nfrom 9 months to 9 years, are not immunized against measles. In some\nregions, the rate of immunization of the 2nd dose does not reach 50\nper cent; and this is very serious.\" Timis and Caras-Severin, Arad\n(all to the west of the country, near the border with Serbia or\nHungary), are the most affected, with more than 1000 measles cases\neach, reported in the last 10 months when the outbreak was declared. According to official estimates, nearly 50 000 children without\nimmunization are not even registered with a family doctor. Most is due\nto serious problems of social exclusion. Submitted by Kathryn Soderholm (kathryn.soderholm@gmail.com) from\nProMED-ESP archive no http://promedmail.org/post/20170814.5248771 and\ntranslated by Mod.LK Maps of Romania can be found at\n(http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> France (Ardèche).\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 11:39 CEST.\nSource: Silver Times (edited)\n(https://sivertimes.com/ardeche-four-hospitalizations-related-to-a-measles-outbreak/64380) \nA measles outbreak was declared in Ardoix, in the northern Ardèche,\nreports France Blue. 6 people  2 adults and 4 children, including\nsome infants  were infected by the virus between early July and 9\nAug 2017. 4 patients had to be hospitalized. The 6 people are now\nout of danger, and the 4 hospitalised patients were able to return\nhome, says the regional Agency of health (ARS), Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes,\ncited by France Bleu. These are all people who live or work in this\nsmall town of 1100 habitats. The ARS called for vigilance and prompted the inhabitants of the\nnorthern Ardèche, to consult a doctor in case of fever and appearance\nof buttons rash. It alerted on the very high contagiousness of the\nvirus that can infect up to 20 people around a sick person, and they\ncan produce severe, even life-threatening disease  in fact, there is\nno curative treatment for measles. In addition, the ARS has been reported to France Bleu that the recent\nconfirmed cases of measles in Ardoix were unvaccinated. According to\nthe figures of the LRA, 71 per cent of the inhabitants of the Ardèche\nregion are vaccinated against measles, which is 10 per cent less than\nthe national average. The government has confirmed its willingness to make mandatory 8\nvaccines, including measles. On this disease, \"Vaccination coverage\namong children at 2 years of age reaches only 78 per cent. As long as\nit does not reach the 95 per cent the risk of epidemic wave periodic\nwill persist\", has declared Agnès Buzyn. Measles has made its 1st victim in France at the end of July 2017. A\nyoung girl, a 16 year old native of Nice, has succumbed to this\ninfectious disease in the hospital North of Marseille, after having\nbeen hospitalized in intensive care for 3 weeks. The girl had never\nbeen vaccinated against measles. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of France can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France#Administrative_divisions) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62734). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \nMiddle East\n\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Israel ex Ukraine.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017 18:11 IDT.\nSource: The Jerusalem Post (edited)\n(http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Politics-And-Diplomacy/Nine-soldiers-recover-after-being-infected-with-measles-502391) \nThe IDF Israeli Defense Forces said on Mon 14 Aug 2017 that 9\nsoldiers diagnosed last week week of 7 Aug 2017 with the highly\ninfectious measles are all recovering and have returned to duty.\nAccording to the IDF, the soldiers all had mild cases of the disease\nand did not serve in the same unit. The index case had just returned from visiting family in the Ukraine\nwhere he likely contracted the disease. When he returned to Israel he\nvisited a clinic where he infected 8 other soldiers who were waiting\nin line to see a physician. \"The IDF, together with the Health\nMinistry, carried out an investigation to locate the cases and\nidentify the source of the infection,\" the army said in a statement,\nadding that all those who had contact with the soldiers had been\ngiven preventative treatment. An IDF spokesman told The Jerusalem Post\nthat the soldier who contracted the disease had 2 stopovers in Europe\non his way back to Israel from the Ukraine but was not able to specify\nwhich countries. WHO in March 2017 warned of a measles outbreak sweeping across\nEurope in places where immunization rates have plummeted. The figures\ncover the agency's entire European region  53 countries including\nIsrael, Kazakhstan, and Russia. According to WHO 559 measles cases\nwere reported in Europe between January and March 2017. While the\nlargest current measles outbreaks in Europe were reported in Romania\nand Italy, other countries reporting cases were France, Germany,\nPoland, Switzerland, and the Ukraine. \"With steady progress toward\nelimination over the past 2 years, it is of particular concern that\nmeasles cases are climbing in Europe,\" said Dr Zsuzsanna Jakab, WHO\nregional director for Europe. \"Today's travel patterns put no person\nor country beyond the reach of the measles virus. Outbreaks will\ncontinue in Europe, as elsewhere, until every country reaches the\nlevel of immunization needed to fully protect their populations.\" Israeli children are routinely immunized with the MMR measles, mumps,\nrubella vaccine which are given in 2 doses, at 1 year and a booster\nin the 1st grade. The Health Ministry has stated that the level of\nvaccine coverage in Israel is among the highest in the West, with 97\nper cent coverage for 1st and 2nd doses MMR and chickenpox vaccine. While no vaccine is 100 per cent effective, an infectious disease\nspecialist told the Post that measles is \"a nasty illness\" that is\npreventable by proper immunization. But while it is highly recommended\nby medical professionals and the Health Ministry, the vaccine is not\nmandatory and according to the IDF the measles vaccine is not part of\nthe vaccines given to new recruits. \"We cannot afford to have soldiers\nwho are severely ill with a highly contagious disease. It would be\nappropriate for the IDF to verify and update immunizations of all\npersonnel and new recruits,\" the infectious disease specialist told\nthe Post. Measles is spread by coughing and sneezing and close contact with\ninfected individuals. While most infected people usually experience\nonly mild symptoms it is one of the leading causes of death among\nyoung children globally. Measles takes about 8-12 days following\ncontact before the individual will show symptoms which include a\nfever, bad cough, red eyes, and a runny nose. A few days after the\nrespiratory symptoms, the infected individual will get a bad rash.\nOther complications of measles include gastroenteritis (diarrhea and\nvomiting), pneumonia, severe bleeding problems, and in some rare cases\nencephalitis (brain infections). In June 2017, 5 cases of measles were reported to the Health\nMinistry  all of them women between the ages of 20-40 who lived in\nJerusalem. byline: Anna Ahronheim \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Even with 97 per cent vaccine coverage, measles virus can cause small\noutbreaks. But these outbreaks won't be able to expand to cause\nsignificant disease in the protected population. HealthMap/ProMED-mail maps\nIsrael: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90)\nUkraine: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/123)\n- Mod.LK \nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Uganda (Kampala, Wakiso).\nDate: Tue 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, The EastAfrican report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/uganda/uganda-plans-mass-measles-vaccination) \nUganda's Health Ministry has said it is rolling out a mass\nimmunisation campaign against measles for children under the age of\nfive, as a measure to control an outbreak of the disease in the\ncapital Kampala and the neighbouring district of Wakiso, where 67\ncases were reported in July 2017. \"The Ministry of Health is\nundertaking a number of measures to control the spread of the disease,\nincluding investigating the extent of its spread in Kampala and\nWakiso,\" said director of health services, Prof Anthony Mbonye. Measles is an airborne disease that affects mostly children between\nthe ages of 6 months and 10 years, although it can also affect\nadults. Although Prof Mbonye said there was no cause for alarm, he urged the\npublic to be vigilant and report any suspected cases to the nearest\nhealth facilities. The public has also been urged to look out for\ncommon early symptoms associated with the disease, which include high\nfever, cough, red swelling eyelids and muscle and body irritability. According to the Ministry of Health, an estimated 20 per cent of\npeople who get infected with measles often develop complications,\nwhich if not managed early enough can lead to death. Despite previous\nmass vaccination campaigns, Uganda has had several outbreaks of the\ndisease. Prof Mbonye blamed it on parents who do not take their\nchildren for immunisation at the right time. Current national\nimmunisation coverage stands at 85 per cent. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) According to WHO, in 2016 global vaccination coverage (all vaccines)\nwas stalled at 86 per cent, with no significant changes during the\npast year. For measles alone, by the end of 2016, 85 per cent of\nchildren had received 1 dose of vaccine by their 2nd birthday, and 164\ncountries had included a 2nd dose as part of routine immunization; 64\nper cent of children received 2 doses of measles vaccine according to\nnational immunization schedules. It is generally thought that because\nmeasles is such a highly transmissible disease, that 90-95 per cent of\npeople must be vaccinated in order to protect the entire population,\nor achieve herd immunity. Maps of Uganda can be seen at\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97) - Mod.LK \nPacific\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia).\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017 9:58 AM AWST.\nSource: The West Australian (edited)\n(https://thewest.com.au/news/wa/third-case-of-measles-among-students-at-steiner-school-ng-b88572888z) \nHealth authorities have confirmed a 3rd case of measles in a student\nfrom the Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, WA and warned there\ncould be more. This is the 2nd student to be infected from an\nunvaccinated high school student at the Bibra Lake school who\ncontracted measles while on holiday in Italy. Before being diagnosed,\nand while still infectious, the student was at the school and other\nlocations in Perth. The WA Health Department's Virus Watch bulletin said the 2 confirmed\nsecondary measles cases were in unvaccinated students. \"All 3 attend a\nsouthern suburbs school with a low rate of vaccination, and further\ncases remain possible,\" it said. byline: Cathy O'Leary \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Australia can be seen at\n(http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK ","keywordsMatched":[]},"72":{"title":"Chikungunya (27) - Americas, Europe, Asia ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Chikungunya (27) - Americas, Europe, Asia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHIKUNGUNYA (27) - AMERICAS, EUROPE, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n\nAmericas\n\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO report Mexico and Central America\n\nMexico (Jalisco state)\nCosta Rica South America\n\nArgentina (Salto province)\nBrazil:\n- Roraima state\n- Ceara state\nPeru (Piura region) Europe\n\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region in Provence) Asia\n\nTaiwan (Tainan)\nIndia:\n- Delhi\n- Ludhiana, Punjab\n- Chandigarh, Haryana and Punjab states\n- Tamil Nadu state\n- Baramati tehsil, Pune, Maharastra state\n- Pune Maharashtra state ex Assam state\n- Kerala state\nBangladesh (Dhaka)\nNepal (Bhaktapur, province 3) \nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n\nAmericas\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n18 Aug 2017\n(http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8975&Itemid=40931&lang=en) \nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or\nterritory - 2017 to EW 33 week ending 18 Aug 2017. (reported) severe\ncase. A 69 year old from Assam was diagnosed with chikungunya around a\nweek ago. The disease had affected almost all his vital organs \nheart, brain, liver and kidney. TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be) The number of reported cases of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection\nin the Americas appears to have declined this year (2017). Given the\noutbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) infections in the region, and the\nclinical similarity of cases of that virus infection and CHIKV\ninfection, one wonders how many cases that were not laboratory\nconfirmed but clinically diagnosed as ZIKV infections were, in\nreality, CHIKV infections. It is also possible that a significant\nproportion of the population have been infected by CHIKV in the\nprevious 3 years and are now immune. It seems likely, however, that\nCHIKV is now endemic in the Americas, and sporadic, small outbreaks\nmay continue to occur as they do in Asia and Africa. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"95":{"title":"Invasive mosquito - UK: (England) ","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Invasive mosquito - UK: (England) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 23 Aug 2017, 1:38 PM. Source: Express (edited) (http://www.express.co.uk/news/nature/844891/Asian-mosquitos-Britain-Eurotunnel-dengue-fever-chikungunya-virus-UK)   Health specialists have blitzed a clutch of notorious Asian tiger mosquitoes suspected to have smuggled their way into Britain through the Eurotunnel. The invasive Asiatic mosquitoes can carry dengue fever and the chikungunya virus, and attack in daylight.  Experts from Public Health England destroyed the batch of mosquito eggs and larvae at the busy Ashford International truck stop earlier this month August 2017. This is the 2nd time that one of the planet's most dangerous insects  so-named because of its striped body and legs  has been discovered entering into the UK during the last year.  Asian tiger mosquitoes  scientific name, _Aedes albopictus_  have been spreading across Europe and are blamed for up to a million global cases of chikungunya globally every year. The disease has no cure and leaves victims in a fever and with excruciating joint pains as well as headaches, nausea and rashes. There is a death risk of one in a thousand cases. France confirmed 4 cases in 2014 and there was an epidemic in Italy a decade ago.  Asian tiger mosquitoes are spreading the disease through the way their eggs and larvae have been exported from native forest haunts in south east Asia in tyre imports. The grubs eggs can survive for months and larvae and pupae develop in small pockets of water retained by tyres.  To counter the threat, the authorities are maintaining a \"mosquito surveillance programme\" at 30 UK ports and airports as well as checks at motorway services on routes from south coast ports and Eurotunnel. Dr Jenny Harries, deputy medical director at Public Health England, said: \"Through these activities we identified a small number of eggs and larvae from the _Aedes albopictus_ mosquito in traps at Ashford International truck stop.  byline: Stuart Winter   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  This report of the discovery of _Aedes albopictus_ at a truck stop in Kent appears to be valid this time and illustrates how this species can be moved internationally. A 2014 report of _Aedes aegypti_ in southern England was rejected. A statement by Jolyon Medlock, head of Medical Entomology & Zoonoses Ecology, Public Health England, Microbiological Research Authority (MRA), Emergency Response Department, Health Protection and Medical Directorate, Porton Down, Salisbury stated, \"This is misleading information as no invasive aedes mosquitoes have been found in the UK. There have been a number of news articles in British newspapers recently 2014 about invasive mosquitoes, reporting mainly on efforts to increase surveillance for _Aedes albopictus_, however no confirmed reports of any invasive aedes mosquito have been found during this surveillance, nor have any reports been submitted to the Medical Entomology group at Public Health England.\" (see Invasive mosquito - UK (02): (England) comment http://promedmail.org/post/20140923.2795988).  Intensive surveillance will be carried out this time as well. One hopes that successful aggressive efforts to eliminate the mosquitoes before they can become established, as they have become established in Italy and southern France. - Mod.TY  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6406).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"151":{"title":"Chemical haze-related illness - UK: (England) beach\r\n\t","date":["30","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Chemical haze-related illness - UK: (England) beach\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" Visit ProMED-mail's web site at (http://www.promedmail.org). Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Fiji\n- French Polynesia (Tahiti) Africa\n\n- Côte d'Ivoire\n- Côte d'Ivoire <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence\n- Air travel related spread of dengue\n- Visual impact <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> World Health Organization update \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries\nAsia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National. 26 Jul 2017. Sri Lanka has now notified 107 015 cases,\nwhich WHO estimates is 4.3 times more than the average number of cases\nusually reported (http://tinyurl.com/ycvszzs8). - National. 19 Aug 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. This compares with about 39 000 cases reported from January\nto August 2016, and 55 150 cases during the entire year 2016.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - National. 25 Aug 2017. Through Fri 25 Aug 2017, Sri Lanka has\nofficially reported 144 052 cases and, as of 3 Aug 2017, 3327 people\nhave died.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-epidemic-waning-sri-lanka-university-jaffna-science-faculty-closed-september-83024/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sri Lanka can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/144). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ India\n- National. 31 Jul 2017. 11 832 more cases than in 2016 and 46 deaths,\n11 more than in 2016. The total has risen to 28 702, with 2536 cases\nand 10 deaths last week week of 24 Jul 2017. A total of 59 cases in July 2017.\nThe actual number of cases is said to be 'far more'; it takes at least\n15 days to confirm cases.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/59-dengue-cases-in-july-amc/articleshow/59853414.cms) - Jharkhand (Jamshedpur). 30 Jul 2017. 75 positive cases in Kolhan and\nadjoining area of Jamshedpur.\n(http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/dengue-cases-rise-positive-cases-shoot-75-kolhan/111026/) - Telangana (Hyderabad). 25 Jul 2017. All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed strain homology with the Burkina Faso 2016 strain. From the registered record, the Samoan Observer reported\nthat in August alone, the lab tests reported 54 requests with 25\nconfirmed positive and 2 deaths. The 2 deaths were suspected to be\nfrom the dengue fever. Following the outbreak, the Ministry of Health\nhas issued a dengue fever alert to keep the general public informed on\nthe outbreak.\n(http://www.emtv.com.pg/featured/2017/08/samoa-issues-dengue-fever-alert/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Samoa can be seen at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ - Fiji. 13 Aug 2017. 6 people died from dengue fever in the 1st 6\nmonths of this year 2017. There were also 2217 laboratory confirmed\ncases.\n(http://fijivillage.com/news/6-people-died-from-dengue-fever-in-first-6-months-of-this-year-srk952/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ - French Polynesia. 9 Aug 2017. Tahiti: 1st death of 2017, a 7 year\nold boy. In the 2nd half of July 2017, 25 cases were recorded across 5\nof French Polynesia's main islands. Half of those infected were\nchildren under the age of 15.\n(http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/336820/seven-year-old-boy-dies-of-dengue-in-tahiti) Maps of French Polynesia can be seen at\n(http://www.spc.int/aquaculture/images/countries/large/french_polynesia_b1.gif)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31048). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Africa\n\n- Côte d'Ivoire. 4 Aug 2017. On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. Sir Gangaram Hospital reported the rare case,\nwhere the woman, who went to the eye OPD outpatient department,\ncomplained of \"sudden blurring of vision in the left eye,\" as reported\nby IE Indian Express. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017. China\nAs of 31 Jul 2017, there were 503 cases of dengue reported in China in\n2017. This number is higher than that reported during the same period\nsince 2012 but follows historical trend. Dengue activity is high with the number of\ndengue cases reported this year 2017 being higher than the cases\nreported for same period since 2014. Compared with the same period in 2016, the\ncumulative number of cases increased by 33.5 per cent, and the number\nof deaths rose by 5. Most cases were reported from the South (59 per\ncent). There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Gabon":{},"Gambia":{},"Georgia":{"64":{"title":"Undiagnosed cough, canine - USA: (MT) ","date":["14","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Undiagnosed cough, canine - USA: (MT) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" Visit ProMED-mail's web site at (http://www.promedmail.org). For assistance from  a  human  being, send mail to: (postmaster@promedmail.org). ############################################################ ############################################################  List-Unsubscribe: http://ww4.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.php ","keywordsMatched":[]},"110":{"title":"Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (07): (GA,WI) equine\r\n\t","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (07): (GA,WI) equine\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this posting: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Georgia (Lowndes county) <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Wisconsin (Jackson county) <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Wisconsin (Chippewa county)   <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Georgia (Lowndes county). Date: Tue 22 Aug 2017. Source: The Valdosta Daily Times summ., edited (http://www.valdostadailytimes.com/news/local_news/horse-with-eee-found-in-lowndes/article_aea7a098-aa2b-5d97-a11f-428bc9eb52d1.html)   A horse in Lowndes county has tested positive for eastern equine encephalitis EEE, according to health officials. EEE is a rare disease caused by a virus spread by infected mosquitoes, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It can cause inflammation of the brain, but on average, only 8 cases of EEE in humans are reported each year, CDC said.  \"The more time someone is outdoors, the more time the person is at risk of being bitten by an infected mosquito; that is why we encourage everyone to take all precautions against mosquito bites,\" said Dr William Grow, South Health District director.  Severe cases of EEE infection in humans begin with the sudden onset of headache, high fever, chills, and vomiting, according to CDC; the illness may then progress into disorientation, seizures, and coma. About a third of patients who develop EEE die, and many of those who survive have mild to severe brain damage, said CDC. There is no specific treatment for EEE. Most cases have been found in Atlantic and Gulf Coast states.  In July 2017, a horse with EEE was found in Brooks county. For more information, call the local health department or visit (http://www.cdc.gov/).  byline: Terry Richards   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  The state of Georgia can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/13267). Lowndes and Brooks counties in south Georgia can be seen on the map at (http://geology.com/county-map/georgia-county-map.gif). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Wisconsin (Jackson county). Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017 9:50 PM CDT. Source: WEAU 13 News summ., edited (http://www.weau.com/content/news/Jackson-County-Horse-Tests-Positive-for-Eastern-Equine-Encephalitis-441350273.html)   The Jackson County Health Department reports a horse has tested positive for eastern equine encephalitis (EEE), which is caused by the EEE virus. The EEE virus is transmitted by mosquitoes. No EEE cases in humans have been reported in Wisconsin since 2011. EEE virus is transmitted to humans, horses, birds, and other animals during bites from infected mosquitoes.  Mosquitoes acquire EEE virus by feeding on infected birds. The virus is not transmitted person to person or directly between animals or between animals and humans. Presence of a EEE positive horse confirms that there are mosquitoes in the area infected with the EEE virus that can transmit the virus to people and other animals.  Clinical signs of EEE infection in horses include depression, loss of appetite, drooping eyelids and lower lip, blindness, paralysis, and death. Horse owners can vaccinate their horses against EEE virus to protect them from becoming ill.  Because EEE virus is known to be currently circulating, Wisconsin residents and visitors to the state should be vigilant in taking measures to prevent mosquito bites. It is important that people contact their healthcare provider if they suspect they have EEE illness. The best way to avoid mosquitoborne diseases is to reduce exposure to mosquitoes and eliminate mosquito breeding sites. When cold weather arrives, the mosquitoes will be eliminated, but until then people are urged to take measures to protect themselves.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)   <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Wisconsin (Chippewa county). Date: Wed 23 Aug 2017 10:54 AM CDT. Source: WEAU 13 News summ., edited (http://www.weau.com/content/news/Chippewa-Co-horse-test-positive-for-EEE-virus-441525563.html)   The Chippewa County Health Department reports that a horse in Chippewa County has tested positive for eastern equine encephalitis (EEE). The EEE virus is transmitted by mosquitoes. The Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection reported the positive test result to the Wisconsin Division of Public Health. No EEE cases in humans have been reported in Wisconsin this year or any year since 2011. The human EEE case in 2011 was only the 2nd case known to have occurred in Wisconsin since 1984.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The state of Wisconsin can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/250). Jackson and Chippewa counties can be seen on the map at (http://geology.com/county-map/wisconsin-county-map.gif).  The 3 articles above include the following measures to prevent mosquito bites: - apply insect repellent containing DEET, picaridin, IR3535, or PMD to clothing as well as exposed skin since mosquitoes may bite through clothing.
