Be sure to follow the instructions on the label; - wear long-sleeved shirts, long pants, and socks when outdoors, especially at dawn and dusk to reduce the amount of exposed skin, as weather permits; - avoid being outdoors from dusk to dawn, peak mosquito biting times, if possible; - set up outdoor fans to keep mosquitoes from flying near you; - make sure window and door screens are in good repair to prevent mosquito entry; - any containers that can collect water, such as tin cans, plastic containers, ceramic pots, or discarded tires, should be discarded or dumped daily; turn over wheelbarrows, wading pools, boats, and canoes when not in use; - clean roof gutters and downspouts for proper drainage; - change the water in birdbaths and pet dishes at least every 3 days; - clean and chlorinate swimming pools, outdoor saunas, and hot tubs; drain water from pool covers; - trim tall grass, weeds, and vines since mosquitoes use these areas to rest during hot daylight hours; - landscape to prevent water from pooling in low-lying areas. Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ  Judging from the number of cases on this posting alone, it is clearly arbovirus season. Prevent breeding places for mosquitoes, use fly and mosquito repellent especially for horses and above all, vaccinate! Vaccination is usually a combination of EEE, western equine encephalitis, West Nile virus, and tetanus. A lot of protection for a couple of injections. - Mod.TG  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"180":{"title":"Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (08): (GA, OH) equine\r\n\t","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (08): (GA, OH) equine\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Georgia <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ohio   <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Georgia. Date: 29 Aug 2017. Source: WSAV (edited) (http://wsav.com/2017/08/29/health-dept-horse-in-bryan-county-tests-positive-for-eee/)   According to the Bryan County Health Department, a horse in Bryan County has tested positive for eastern equine encephalitis (EEE).  EEE virus is a mosquito-borne virus that causes swelling of the brain and is fatal in horses 70 to 90 percent of the time. EEE has also been detected in the mosquito population in western Chatham County, and a horse in Effingham County tested positive for EEE earlier this month August 2017.  The health department encourages horse and large animal owners to vaccinate their animals against the virus and to clean out watering sources, such as buckets and troughs every 3 to 4 days to prevent mosquitoes from breeding in those areas.  For more information on EEE, see: (http://www.cdc.gov/EasternEquineEncephalitis/).   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ohio. Date: 31 Aug 2017. Source: North West Signal (edited) (http://www.northwestsignal.net/news/ag_business/article_455ad7f1-41e9-555a-9d2b-70451f258b60.html)   A horse from Ashtabula County was recently confirmed to have eastern equine encephalitis (EEE) by the Ohio Department of Agriculture's (ODA) Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory.  The animal was euthanized in late July 2017 after showing neurological signs. The animal was not vaccinated against the disease and lived near a low-lying area typically prone to harboring mosquitoes. EEE is often transmitted by mosquitoes and can be transmitted to humans; however, only a few cases are reported each year, and most infected persons report no apparent illness.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The arbovirus season is upon us. The watch word is \"vaccinate!\"  The EEE vaccination is usually combined with western EE, West Nile virus and tetanus. This is cheap insurance to protect your animal from these diseases. If you have not already vaccinated, please do so now. If you vaccinated longer than 6 months ago, please revaccinate, as EEE immunity wanes the fastest. - Mod.TG  ProMED HealthMaps: Georgia, United States: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/213) Ohio, United States: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237)  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Germany":{"86":{"title":"Glanders - Brazil: (TO) equine, human susp, RFI ","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Glanders - Brazil: (TO) equine, human susp, RFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nGLANDERS - BRAZIL: (TOCANTINS) EQUINE, HUMAN SUSPECTED, REQUEST FOR\nINFORMATION\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Wed 23 Aug 2017.\nSource: G1 in Portuguese, machine trans., edited\n(http://g1.globo.com/to/tocantins/noticia/vaqueiro-que-cuidava-de-cavalo-sacrificado-por-mormo-pode-ter-sido-infectado.ghtml) \nThe cowboy working on the farm where a case of glanders was confirmed\nin a horse PRO/PORT Mormo - Brazil (02) (TO), equine, confirmed\nhttp://promedmail.org/post/20170823.5270939, is also suspected to\nhave the disease. The information was passed on by the secretary of\nhealth of Palmeirante Tocantins state, Beatriz Ferreira. She noted\nthat examinations have already been made and that steps are being\ntaken to ensure that the disease does not spread. The cowboy's family\nhas been examined, but no one besides him has symptoms of the disease.\nThe main indicators of glanders are fever, skin lesions, nose bumps,\nand pneumonia. The disease is difficult to treat and can be fatal. The cowboy was referred to the Municipal Hospital of Colinas do\nTocantins for tests, but was not admitted. The G1 tried to contact the\ncity hall to ask what the deadline for the outcome was, but the calls\nwere not answered. The farm where the infected horse was isolated and\nthe animal was sacrificed. The neighboring properties are being\ninspected by Adapec Agência de Defesa Agropecuária; Agency of\nFarming Defense. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-PORT\n(promed-port@promedmail.org) Glanders is an infection caused by _Burkholderia mallei_ and occurs\nprimarily in horses and related animals. It is rare in humans. It is\nunclear what symptoms occurred in the person and how the diagnosis was\nmade. The following appears to be the most recent review of _B. mallei_\ninfections in humans including the description of disease\nmanifestations:\nVan Zandt KE, Greer MT, Gelhaus HC. Glanders: an overview of infection\nin humans. Orphanet J Rare Dis. 2013 Sep 3;8:131. doi:\n10.1186/1750-1172-8-131 (the full text and citations can be found at\nthe original URL\n(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3766238/)). \"Features of human clinical glanders\n\n\"General symptoms\n\"Many forms of glanders have been described, including chronic,\ndisseminated, pulmonary, and septicemic. The variety of infections is\nlargely explained by various routes of infection. Localized infections\nare generally regionally confined and typically characterized by foci\nof suppuration. The abscesses can ulcerate and drain for long periods\nof time. However, localized infections may disseminate, leading to\npulmonary, septicemic, or multi-tissue infection <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>. The most common\nclinical features of the eight laboratory-acquired infections from\nFort Detrick included (in order of most common occurrence) afternoon\nto evening low-grade fever, malaise, fatigue, headache, myalgias\nincluding backache, lymphadenopathy, and chest pain. Approximately\nhalf of the patients not only felt better but were also clinically\nbetter for a period of time after the first wave of disease symptoms.\nThis period lasted from a few days to 2 months then patients developed\nclinical signs of infection. \"Mucosal involvement\n\"Involvement of the eye and conjunctiva in a _B. mallei_ infection\npresents with excessive lacrimation and photophobia. Nasal involvement\nis characterized by inflammation and swelling of the nose, which is\ncommon following inhalation of _B. mallei_. This may be followed by\ncopious nasal discharge. Additionally, infection may invade the nasal\nseptum and bony tissues, causing fistulae and tissue destruction <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>.\nThe face may swell and regional lymph nodes may become inflamed.\nInfection may also extend lower in the respiratory tract, resulting in\nbronchitis which can be accompanied by cough and mucopurulent sputum\nproduction. Constitutional signs and symptoms such as fever and chills\ntypically occur within the first few days following infection.\nAdditionally, these symptoms may persist through treatment and be\nsevere. Common signs and symptoms can include, but are not limited to,\nfever or low-grade fever in the afternoon to evening; chills with or\nwithout rigors; and severe headache <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>. \"Cutaneous involvement\n\"Cutaneous manifestations include papular lesions that may erupt\nanywhere on the body with a more chronic, indolent course of\ninfection. _B. mallei_ entry through an abrasion is typically followed\nby an inflammatory response, including pain and swelling. In these\ncases, a glanders node may appear as a single blister, gradually\ndeveloping into an ulcer that may become hemorrhagic 18,35. A\nlocalized infection with a discharge typically develops at the entry\nsite. Inflammation may extend along regional lymphatics and cause\nlymphangitis with numerous foci of suppuration along their course. The\nendotoxins present in _B. mallei_ strains affect the smooth muscle of\nthe lymphatics <br><br><strong>{9}</strong> by enhancing the irritation and inflammation seen\nin the lymphatics. \"Pulmonary involvement\n\"A pulmonary infection typically results in pneumonia, pulmonary\nabscess, pleuritis, and plural effusion. Signs and symptoms of\npulmonary infection can include cough, dyspnea, chest pain, and\nmucoplurent sputum. Nonspecific signs and symptoms such as fatigue,\nfever (often exceeding 102 deg F 38.9 deg C), chills, headache,\nmyalgias, lymphangitis, sore throat, pleuritic chest pain, cough,\ntachypnea, dyspnea, discharge, and gastrointestinal signs often\naccompany respiratory infections <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>. Many symptoms may take up to 2\nto 3 weeks to develop. Nonspecific signs, such as dizziness, rigors,\nmyalgia, nausea, night sweats, severe headache, tachycardia, weight\nloss, and mucosal eruptions are also usually present and may indicate\na disseminated infection <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>. \"Dissemination of infection\n\"Dissemination from local cutaneous or mucosal infection result in\nsepticemia and the colonization of internal organs such as the spleen,\nliver, and lungs with the development of abscesses <br><br><strong>{9}</strong>.\nUltrasonography and computed tomography may reveal multiple, small\ndiscrete abscesses in both the liver and the kidney <br><br><strong>{23}</strong>. These\ninfections are typically associated with septic shock and high\nmortality.\" This publication describes what seems to have been the last of the\ncases of human _B. mallei_ in the USA:\nSrinivasan A, Kraus CN, DeShazer D, et al. Glanders in a military\nresearch microbiologist. N Engl J Med. 2001; 345: 256-8; (full text\nand citations can be found at the original URL\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM200107263450404) \"Infection with _Burkholderia mallei_ (formerly _Pseudomonas mallei_)\ncan cause a subcutaneous infection known as farcy or can disseminate\nto cause the condition known as glanders. In humans, acute infection\nwith _B. mallei_ is characterized by necrosis of the tracheobronchial\ntree, pustular skin lesions, and either a febrile pneumonia, if the\norganism was inhaled, or signs of sepsis and multiple abscesses, if\nthe skin was the portal of entry (1). At the turn of the 20th century,\nglanders was an important cause of death among horses, and there were\nsecondary, often fatal, infections in humans (2). Because of the\nlethal and contagious nature of the disease, _B. mallei_ was\nconsidered an ideal agent for biologic warfare and was used for this\npurpose by Germany in World War I (3). \"Aggressive control measures essentially eliminated glanders from the\nWest. However, with the resurgent concern about biologic warfare, _B.\nmallei_ is now being studied in laboratories worldwide. We describe\nhere the first reported case of human glanders in the USA in more than\n50 years and discuss some of the important events in the history of\nthe disease and its initial eradication. \"Case report\n\n\"In March 2000, tender, left axillary adenopathy and fever\n(temperature, 38.6 deg C 101.5 deg F) developed in a 33 year old\nmicrobiologist at the US Army Medical Research Institute for\nInfectious Diseases who had type 1 diabetes mellitus. The patient had\nworked for 2 years investigating the basic microbiology of _B. mallei_\nand did not routinely wear latex gloves. The adenopathy and fever\npersisted despite treatment for 10 days with a first-generation\ncephalosporin. An evaluation after this treatment, which included\nchest radiography as well as cultures of blood and urine, was\nunrevealing. During the next few weeks, the patient had increasing\nfatigue, night sweats, malaise, rigors, and weight loss. \"In early April 2000, his symptoms and adenopathy resolved during a\n10-day course of clarithromycin, but he relapsed 4 days after the\nmedication was stopped. On 2 May 2000, he was admitted to his local\nhospital with diabetic ketoacidosis. A computed tomographic (CT) scan\nshowed multiple hepatic and splenic abscesses. \"On 4 May 2000, respiratory distress requiring mechanical ventilation\ndeveloped, and the patient was transferred to Johns Hopkins Hospital\nin Baltimore. Physical examination revealed a temperature of 40.3 deg\nC 104.5 deg F and a heart rate of 122 beats per minute. The patient\nhad a grade 2/6 systolic murmur, coarse breath sounds, and moderate\nepigastric tenderness. Laboratory studies showed a white-cell count of\n8300 per cubic millimeter, with 83 per cent neutrophils, 9 per cent\nmonocytes, and 8 per cent lymphocytes. The hematocrit was 25.6 per\ncent. The concentrations of aspartate aminotransferase and alanine\naminotransferase were 53 U per liter and 56 U per liter, respectively,\nand the alkaline phosphatase was 197 IU per liter. Cultures of the\npatient's blood and a sample from a fine-needle aspiration biopsy of a\nliver abscess grew a small, bipolar, weakly staining, gram-negative\nrod that was identified by an automated bacterial-identification\nsystem as _Pseudomonas fluorescens_ or _P. putida_. However,\ngas-liquid chromatography of the cellular fatty acids (Microbial ID,\nNewark, Del.) placed the organism in the genus _Burkholderia_.\nSubsequent phenotypic testing and 16S ribosomal RNA gene-sequence\nanalysis identified the organism as _B. mallei_. Initial\nsusceptibility testing showed the isolate to be sensitive to imipenem,\nceftazidime, and tetracycline. \"The patient was treated with imipenem and doxycycline, and there was\nrapid improvement. After two weeks, the imipenem was replaced by\nazithromycin, and the patient completed a six-month course of\ntreatment with azithromycin and doxycycline. Although the organism was\nfound retrospectively to be relatively resistant to azithromycin, a CT\nscan obtained after six months of treatment showed substantial\nimprovement of the liver and spleen abscesses, and one year later the\npatient remained in good health. \"Discussion\n\nThis is the 1st reported human case of glanders in the\nEnglish-language medical literature since 1949 (4) and it occurred in\nthe context of research on agents of biologic warfare. \"Glanders may have been the first biologic weapon of the 20th century.\nDuring World War I, Germany had a program of biologic sabotage against\nseveral countries, including the United States, whereby cultures of\n_B. mallei_ and anthrax were distributed to undercover agents who\nattempted to infect livestock that were to be shipped to Allied\ncountries (3). The intention was both the destruction of livestock and\nthe transmission of the highly contagious, lethal agent from livestock\nto humans. It is currently suspected that attempts are being made to\ndevelop an aerosolized form of antibiotic-resistant _B. mallei_ that\ncould become a biologic weapon as potent as anthrax. \"Glanders, an important human and veterinary disease, was eliminated\nwithout a vaccine or effective treatment. It appears to have been\nabolished by the veterinary use of a skin test to detect exposure to\nB. mallei combined with draconian agricultural measures to control\ninfection (5). \"At the turn of the 20th century, Canada, Britain, and the USA all\nimplemented glanders-control programs. By that time, the symptoms of\nequine glanders, which include fever and inflammation of the nasal\nmucosa with ultimate necrosis and obstruction of the oropharynx, had\nbeen well described (6). Laws were passed that required notification\nof the health department and the immediate slaughter of affected\nanimals, with proper disposal of the carcasses. In addition, all\nhorses on the premises where the infected horses were found had to be\ntested with the mallein skin test for exposure to _B. mallei_; any\nhorses with a reaction also had to be slaughtered. Horses with no\nreaction were quarantined and then retested two to three weeks later.\nFurthermore, the equine contacts of the horses were traced to track\ndown other horses that might have been exposed and then moved to other\nfacilities. \"The case we describe illustrates the major clinical features of\nglanders, which can usually be traced to direct contact with _B.\nmallei_, as in workers exposed to animals with glanders (7) and in\npersonnel who were exposed in laboratories during World War II (8).\nAlthough the patient discussed here could not recall a clear break in\nhis skin or an accident in the laboratory, most reported occupational\ninfections occur without recognized instances of exposure (9). As\nRobins commented in 1906, \"It is perhaps not advisable to be too\ndogmatic as to the invariable necessity of an abrasion being present\nin every case of human glanders . . . as in several such cases of\nour series it is distinctly stated that there was no abrasion.\" (7).\nAs in our patient, _B. mallei_ often enters the body through the hand\nor arm. After an incubation period lasting between a few days and\nseveral weeks, local suppuration and regional lymphadenopathy occur.\nConstitutional symptoms often accompany the infection, with fever,\nrigors, and malaise predominating. If the infection is left untreated,\nabscesses in the lymph nodes will generally form, then break down and\ndrain. \"Dissemination of the infection occurs 1 to 4 weeks after infection of\nthe lymph nodes. Abscesses can be widespread, and _B. mallei_ can\ninfect almost any tissue (7). Abscesses in the liver and the spleen,\nas were seen in our patient, appear to be relatively common, as does\npulmonary involvement, including consolidation, abscesses, and pleural\nnodules. The acute onset and rapid resolution of the respiratory\nfailure in our patient were more consistent with the respiratory\ndistress syndrome associated with gram-negative bacteremia than with\nthat associated with pulmonary glanders. Subcutaneous and\nintramuscular abscesses sometimes develop as well (7). \"There are few data regarding the antibiotic treatment of glanders,\nsince the disease had largely disappeared by the time antibiotics\nbecame available. In vitro, ceftazidime, gentamicin, imipenem,\ndoxycycline, and ciprofloxacin all have reliable activity against _B.\nmallei_ (10), and our patient's infection responded well to a\ncombination of imipenem and doxycycline. Experimentally induced\nglanders also responds to a combination of sulfazine and trimethoprim\n(11). However, treatment of the disease in the setting of bioterrorism\nmay be more difficult if the organism is drug-resistant. \"This case demonstrates the difficulties that microbiology\nlaboratories may have in recognizing potential agents of biologic\nwarfare. These microbes are rarely encountered and may be\nmisidentified by conventional, phenotypic identification systems.\nTechniques such as cellular analysis of fatty acid and 16S ribosomal\nRNA gene sequencing can be used to identify the organisms correctly,\nbut these tests are not widely available. \"Finally, this case may serve as a harbinger of the resurgence of\nnearly forgotten diseases such as glanders, plague, smallpox, and\nanthrax. Research on these diseases is now being conducted in more\nlaboratories, which increases the risk of occupational exposure. There\nis also the looming threat that some group will eventually mount a\nsuccessful campaign of bioterrorism. Resources must be allocated both\nto prevent and to prepare for these frightening possibilities.\" Maps of Brazil can be seen at\n(http://s13.postimg.org/jumnalk87/map_of_Brazil.gif) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62881). The state of Tocantins is\nlocated in central Brazil. - Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]},"114":{"title":"Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t","date":["26","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy  Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15 <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania  Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics   Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert. Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Mainichi (edited) (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170821/p2g/00m/0dm/077000c)   Japan's health ministry has issued a warning for people traveling to Europe on the back of an outbreak of measles in countries such as Italy and Romania. The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is advising tourists to go to hospital if they develop a high fever or generalized rash after returning to Japan.  Although the World Health Organization verified that Japan has eliminated infections of endemic measles strains in 2015, group infections originating from people who contracted the disease abroad are spreading in the country. As of 6 Aug 2017, the number of patients reached 169 this year in Japan, already eclipsing the figure in the previous year.  About 4100 patients in Italy and around 6500 patients in Romania have already been confirmed as of August 2017 compared with about 860 and 2000, respectively, throughout 2016, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.  Symptoms of the highly contagious disease include runny nose, red and watery eyes, high fever, and rash. The virus is spread through coughing and sneezing and can cause complications such as pneumonia and can even result in death in one in 1000 patients, according to the ministry. The ministry recommends people traveling overseas to check their vaccination records and take an additional shot if they have only been vaccinated once.  The disease was prevalent about a decade ago in Japan with the number of patients soaring to over 10 000 in 2008 but the country was later considered as free from infections of the virus.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy. Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017 5:36 PM AEST. Source: News.com.au, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report (edited) (http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/fourth-case-of-measles-at-perth-school/news-story/ece041f55111645e10f70046d92479dd)   A 4th child has been diagnosed with measles at Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, more than a week after the health department gave an on-site vaccine to students. A Health Department spokeswoman confirmed the latest case, which came 3 weeks after the highly contagious disease was first detected in an unvaccinated year 10 student who had returned from Italy.  Revelations that about half the school's 400 students were unvaccinated against the disease led the Health Department to offer a voluntary, free on-site vaccine to students, but it is unknown how many took up the offer.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK   Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15. Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2017; 22(34) (edited) (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22861)   ref: Werber D, Hoffmann A, Santibanez S, et al. Large measles outbreak introduced by asylum seekers and spread among the insufficiently vaccinated resident population, Berlin, October 2014 to August 2015. Euro Surveill. 2017; 22(34): pii=30599 - Abstract  The largest measles outbreak in Berlin since 2001 occurred from October 2014 to August 2015. Overall, 1344 cases were ascertained, 86 per cent (with available information) unvaccinated, including 146 (12 per cent) asylum seekers. Median age was 17 years (interquartile range: 4-29 years), 26 per cent were hospitalised and a 1 year old child died. Measles virus genotyping uniformly revealed the variant 'D8-Rostov-Don' and descendants. The virus was likely introduced by and initially spread among asylum seekers before affecting Berlin's resident population. Among Berlin residents, the highest incidence was in children younger than 2 years, yet most cases (52 per cent) were adults. Post-exposure vaccinations in homes for asylum seekers, not always conducted, occurred later (median: 7.5 days) than the recommended 72 hours after onset of the 1st case and reached only half of potential contacts. Asylum seekers should not only have non-discriminatory, equitable access to vaccination, they also need to be offered measles vaccination in a timely fashion, that is, immediately upon arrival in the receiving country. Supplementary immunisation activities targeting the resident population, particularly adults, are urgently needed in Berlin.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5857). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania. Date: Fri 25 August 2017. Source: Romania Insider (edited) (https://www.romania-insider.com/measles-kills-iraqi-refugee/)   The ongoing measles outbreak keeps making victims in Romania. A 10 month old girl, who was a refugee from Iraq, became the 33rd person to die of the infection, reports local Digi24. The girl arrived in Romania on 7 Jul 2017 with her family, and the doctors diagnosed her with measles in August. They also discovered that the child was suffering from malnutrition and severe psychomotor retardation.  The measles outbreak is still a major problem in Romania, with more than 8900 cases reported across the country until 25 Aug 2017, including 33 deaths, according to data from the National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT). Most deaths were registered in Timis (9), Dolj (7), and Arad (6) counties.  Measles is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by a virus. It causes a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and runny nose. According to information posted on WHO's website, the virus is highly contagious, spreading by coughing and sneezing, close personal contact, and direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions. Unvaccinated young children pose the highest risk of measles and its complications, including death.  The Romanian Government adopted earlier this month August 2017 a draft bill on the organization and financing of population vaccination (https://www.romania-insider.com/romania-draft-bill-vaccination/). The project was sent to the Parliament for approval and could come into force in January 2018.  byline: Irina Marica   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Measles tends to be more severe in children who are malnourished, especially children who are also vitamin A deficient. And complications are commoner and more serious in malnourished children. Because of complications such as diarrhoea, measles may lead to failure to thrive. Infection with measles virus may lead to kwashiorkor or marasmus in children who are underweight at the time that they get infected. Therefore, measles may result in, or aggravate, malnutrition.  Maps of Romania can be found at (http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK   Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics. Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017. Source: News-Medical/Life Sciences (edited) (https://www.news-medical.net/news/20170826/New-study-highlights-role-played-by-demographics-in-the-spread-of-measles.aspx)   Even if the incidence of measles infection has decreased by at least 90 per cent worldwide since the introduction of the vaccine, measles is still one of the major causes of death in children among vaccine-preventable diseases. Regular measles epidemics are reported in developing countries and recurrent episodic outbreaks occur in the developed world.  A new study by Bocconi University and Bruno Kessler Foundation analyzing 9 countries (Australia, Ethiopia, Kenya, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases see reference below, highlights the role played by demographics in the spread of measles and concludes that future vaccination strategies in high-fertility countries should focus on increasing childhood immunization rates, while immunization campaigns targeting adolescents and young adults are required in low fertility countries.  Using a transmission model calibrated on historical serological data the authors estimate that the susceptible proportion of the population (that is, unprotected against the infection) varies from about 3 per cent in the UK to more than 12.5 per cent in Ethiopia, with astonishing differences in its age composition, due to different vaccination strategies and divergent demographic trends. While the percentage of over-15 among susceptible individuals in Ethiopia and Kenya is, respectively, 28 per cent and 43 per cent, adolescents and young adults represent 74 per cent of unprotected individuals in South Korea, 66 per cent in Italy and 53 per cent in the US, with considerable immunity gaps in individuals aged 30-40 years.  \"Every effort to increase the vaccination coverage rate among children is praiseworthy\", says Alessia Melegaro, a Bocconi professor and principal investigator of DECIDE, the ERC European Research Council-funded project which produced the article, \"but in some developed countries it's the lack of coverage among adolescents and adults that poses a serious threat to the goal of eliminating measles.\"  \"Measles incidence could increase, in the next decades, in Italy, Australia, and Singapore and Ethiopia is at high risk of future large epidemics\", says Stefano Merler from Bruno Kessler Foundation, \"and this is particularly worrying considering that individuals get infected later in life when the disease is more severe. The median age at infection for 2015 was estimated to be 5-10 years in the UK, Ireland, and Ethiopia; 10-15 years in the USA, Australia, Singapore, and Kenya; and older than 20 years in Italy and South Korea\".  The proposed model shows that the introduction of the measles vaccine, which occurred at different times in the 9 countries, has considerably reduced the disease burden in terms of disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs), a measure expressed as the number of years lost because of illness, disability, or early death. Every vaccine dose averts 2 or 3 weeks of DALYs in the developed world and around 20 weeks in Kenya and Ethiopia. Which translates into 2-mln years 2 million DALYs since the vaccine introduction in the UK, 13-mln 13 million DALYs in the US, and 36-mln 36 million DALYs in Ethiopia.  \"Vaccination has undoubtedly achieved incredible results in terms of public health. In particular,\" continues Prof Melegaro \"our analysis showed that routine 1st dose vaccine administration has been responsible for more than 90 per cent of the overall number of vaccine-immunized individuals in most countries. In Ethiopia and Kenya, catch-up and follow-up campaigns substantially mitigated the effect of suboptimum routine vaccine coverage, generating 25-45 per cent of the immunized fraction of the population. Tailoring immunization campaigns to achieve measles eradication goals is essential and currently, for some countries, this means considering also the role of unprotected adolescents and young adults.\"   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Reference - Trentini F, Poletti P, Merler S, Melegaro A. Measles immunity gaps and the progress towards elimination: a multi-country modelling analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30421-8. Epub ahead of print; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28807627).   While it is recommended that children get 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12 through 15 months of age, and the 2nd dose at 4 through 6 years of age, this study emphasizes that it is important that adolescents and young adults also are up to date on their MMR vaccination. - Mod.LK  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"133":{"title":"Avian influenza (133): Germany (ST) wild bird, HPAI H5N8,\r\n\tOIE ","date":["29","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza (133): Germany (ST) wild bird, HPAI H5N8,\r\n\tOIE [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nAVIAN INFLUENZA (133): GERMANY (SACHSEN-ANHALT) WILD BIRD, HPAI H5N8,\nOIE\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Tue 29 Aug 2017.\nSource: OIE, WAHID (edited)\n(http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24679) \nHighly pathogenic influenza A viruses (infection with) (non-poultry\nincluding wild birds), Germany\n\nInformation received on and dated 29 Aug 2017 from Dr. Karin\nSchwabenbauer, Ministerial Dirigentin and Chief Veterinary Officer,\nDirectorate of Animal Health, Animal Welfare, Bundesministerium für\nErnährung und Landwirtschaft (BMEL), Bonn, Germany Summary\nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 22 Aug 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 25 Aug 2017\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: highly pathogenic influenza A virus\nSerotype: H5N8\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic, advanced)\nThis event pertains to the whole country. New outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (17-015-00798): Seegebiet Mansfelder Land,\nMansfeld-Sudharz, Sachsen-Anhalt\nDate of start of the outbreak: 22 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: not applicable\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of /\nSlaughtered\n_Anatidae_ (unidentified): _Anatidae_ (incognita) (_Anatidae_) / - / 3\n/ 2 / 1 / 0\nAffected population: 3 swans Epidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or\ninconclusive. Control measures\nMeasures applied: surveillance within containment and/or protection\nzone, control of wildlife reservoirs, vaccination prohibited, no\ntreatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures Diagnostic test results:\nFriedrich-Loeffler Institute (FLI) (National laboratory)\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\n_Anatidae_ (unidentified) / real-time PCR / 25 Aug 2017 / Positive Future reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted. The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map\nincluded in the OIE report at the source URL above. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \"Between 8 Nov 2016 and 15 May 2017, more than 1150 cases of HPAI\nH5N8 in wild birds and 107 outbreaks in birds kept in captivity (92\npoultry holdings and 15 zoos/animal parks) were reported in Germany.\nIn April 6 Apr 2017 as well as in May 9 May 2017, one outbreak was\ndetected each in birds kept in captivity. Thus, the HPAI epidemic\nseems to be waning in Germany. However, outbreaks or infections in\nwild birds are sporadically reported. The current avian flu epidemic is the most severe and longest-lasting\nepidemic that has occurred in Europe so far. In total, 29 European\nstates have been or still are concerned. In addition to H5N8, 2 other HPAI subtypes have been detected in\nEurope, i.e. HPAI H5N5 (in 7 states) and H5N6 (in Greece). Outside\nEurope, avian influenza outbreaks of the subtype HPAI H5N8 have been\nreported from Russia, Israel, Egypt, Tunisia, Nigeria, Uganda,\nCameroon, Iran, Nepal, and India. HPAI H5N1 is endemic in Asia and\nsome African countries. Moreover, further HPAIV H5N1 related\nH5-strains are circulating in Asia. Although the current epidemic seems to be waning, isolated outbreaks\nmay still occur. The recent reports of HPAIV cases in birds kept in\ncaptivity, which occurred in May 2017, indicate that, at least in some\ncountries, infectious virus is still circulating in the environment.\nTherefore, biosecurity measures should be maintained. These include,\ninter alia, wearing of stable specific protective clothing and\nfootwear, cleaning and disinfection of equipment that has been in\ncontact with birds, and the best possible prevention of contacts\nbetween poultry and wild birds. So far and worldwide, none of the HPAIV subtypes circulating in Europe\n(H5N8, H5N5, and H5N6) have caused infections in humans;\"\n(https://www.fli.de/en/news/animal-disease-situation/avian-influenza-ai-fowl-plague/).\n- Mod.CRD A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/101). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"175":{"title":"African swine fever - Europe (21): Czech Rep, Romania,\r\n\tPoland, wild boar, spread ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> African swine fever - Europe (21): Czech Rep, Romania,\r\n\tPoland, wild boar, spread [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nAFRICAN SWINE FEVER - EUROPE (21): CZECH REPUBLIC, ROMANIA, POLAND,\nWILD BOAR, SPREAD\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this posting:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Czech Rep, Romania\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Poland, fence considered \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Czech Rep, Romania.\nDate: Wed 30 Aug 2017.\nSource: Pig Progress net (edited)\n(http://www.pigprogress.net/Health/Articles/2017/8/ASF-update-Czech-Republic-approaches-100-reports-177268E/) \nAlthough the outbreaks seem to be contained to one region of the Czech\nRepublic, African Swine Fever ASF continues to make victims among\nthe country's wild boar population. The total amount of dead wild boars discovered in the woods around\nZlín, in the far east of the Czech Republic, stood at 94 at the end\nof August 2017. In this month, 23 new infected carcasses were found,\nwhich is a downward trend from July 2017, when 68 reports were sent\nto the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE). The 1st report of\nASF in Czech wild boars was on Wed 21 Jun 2017. Many neighbouring countries have alerted their local pig producers to\nbe very careful what to feed their pigs - and their inhabitants what\nto purchase and how to dispose of it. So did Slovakia, according to\nthe Slovak Spectator. Zlín is only a few km away from the western\nSlovak border, to its north is Poland where ASF has been around since\n2014 and on its eastern border is Ukraine, where ASF has been\nconfirmed since 2011. In a presentation, given in mid-July 2017 to the European\nCommission's Standing Committee On Animals, Plants, Food and Feed\n(SCoPAFF), Dr Petr Šatrán of the Czech State Veterinary\nAdministration indicated that human activities are most likely the\ncause of the spread of the virus, seeing that the nearest reported\ncases of ASF were roughly 500 km 310.68 mi away and that the\npositive dead wild boars were found in inhabited areas. In the other country where ASF was found for the 1st time in 2017,\nRomania, things appear relatively quiet. News broke early this month\nAugust 2017 that ASF was also found on 2 backyard farms in the north\nof the country. Ever since, the Romanian authorities did not report\nany further outbreaks of ASF to the OIE. Of all other countries in the European Union, especially Poland has\ncontinued to report outbreaks of African Swine Fever in smaller and\nmiddle-sized operations. In August alone, on 23 farm sites of various\nsizes, ASF was found to have infected at least one animal, after which\nthe entire herd would have to be culled. The biggest operation in this respect was a farm near Monki, Podlaskie\nprovince, where all remaining 431 pigs had to be culled after 11 had\ndied as a result of ASF, on Sat 19 Aug 2017. Noteworthy as well was\nthe ASF-related closure of 2 farms in Lack, Lubelskie province, in\nearly August. These farms had 136 and 141 pigs respectively see also\nitem 2. Byline: Vincent ter Beek \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n(http://www.cvlonghorns.de)\n(cvlonghorns@aol.com) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Poland, fence considered.\nDate: Sat 2 Sep 2017.\nSource: Current News summ., edited\n(http://currentlynews.us/articles/poland-will-18857) \nPoland wants to build along the border with Belarus and Ukraine a\nfence preventing migration of wild boars  carriers of the African\nSwine fever ASF. This was said by Poland's Minister of Agriculture,\nKrzysztof Yurgel, Niezalezna reports. As reported, the length of the fence will be 729 km 452.98 mi,\ncosting Poland 130 million zloties (more than 36.2 million USD). The\nfinal decision on a fence will be made within the next 3 weeks. According to experts, ASF has developed in the territory of Poland\n\"thanks to\" the wild boars who entered from Belarus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The accumulated ASF OIE data from Poland as of Thu 31 Aug 2017, are\nas follows (start of event 22 May 2014):\nNumber of follow-up reports: 189\nTotal outbreaks: 550 (Submitted)\nSpecies/ Susceptible/ Cases/ Deaths/ Killed and disposed of/\nSlaughtered\nWild boar/ - / 620 / 620 / 0 / 0\nDomestic Swine/ 6303/ 402/ 188/ 6097/ 0 A map showing ASF cases reported globally to the OIE since 1 Jan 2017,\nas of Thu 31 Aug 2017, is available at (http://tinyurl.com/ybexasqm).\nClick on the European cluster, zoom in to each of the countries of\ninterest. EU disease control measures require designation of risk areas as Part\nI (wild boar at risk, but no cases found), Part II (wild boar testing\npositive but no spill over into domestic pigs), Part III (cases in\nwild boar and occasional spill over into domestic pigs) and Part IV\nwhich concerns the island of Sardinia only. Consignments of live pigs,\nlive wild boars, meat of either source and animal by-products of\neither source are only allowed under certain derogations. For a full\nexplanation, see European Commission Implementing Decision\n2014/708/EU. ASF, a viral disease against which no vaccine has become available so\nfar, is currently threatening central and western Europe, where dense\npopulations of wild boar are present. According to a recent update of DEFRA (UK) ASF situation assessment,\nthe continuing cases in the Czech Republic, the spread in Poland which\nappears to be due to several breakdowns in biosecurity and the new\noutbreaks in Romania are \"concerning\". This signifies a spread in\ngeographic distribution, a possible drop in biosecurity awareness and\ntherefore an increase in the weight of infection in East Europe. Despite the relatively low level of trade in live pigs, there could be\na substantial movement of people, vehicles and personal imports of\npork products, therefore the risk of ASF introduction to the UK has\nbeen raised from \"very low\" (that is, \"rare but could occur\") to\n\"low\". The Russian veterinary watchdog Rosselkhoznadzor believes ASF will\nkeep moving west via 2 main pathways. The southerly route, has already\nseen the virus spread from Ukraine to Moldova. Russian vets believe it\ncould penetrate central Romania, then move to the Balkans, including\nBulgaria and Serbia. On the northern route, now that ASF has been found in the Czech\nRepublic, Rosselkhoznadzor believes, if it gains a foothold, it is\nlikely to head further west, with Germany next in the firing line. The\nsaid is included in a recent update by the Russian journalist\nVladislav Vorotnikov, available at\n(http://www.pig-world.co.uk/comment/where-next-for-african-swine-fever.html).\n- Mod.AS ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Ghana":{},"Greece":{"116":{"title":"West Nile virus - Europe (05): Greece ","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> West Nile virus - Europe (05): Greece [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017 22:30:30. Source: Xinhua News Agency (edited) (http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/25/c_136555728.htm)   Greek authorities said on Fri 25 Aug 2017 that 3 people in Greece infected with the West Nile virus WNV died of complications related to the illness this summer 2017. All cases were reported in August and all victims were over 70 years old, the national Center for Disease Control and Prevention (KEELPNO) noted.  A total of 37 cases have been detected this year 2017, including a patient who is still in hospital in intensive care experts said. In most cases, patients suffered from mild symptoms. It was mainly elderly patients with other chronic illnesses who faced severe complications, according to KEELPNO.  The West Nile virus was first detected in Greece in 2010, when 262 confirmed cases of the disease were recorded, among them, 35 fatal. No cases were recorded in 2015 and 2016. KEELPNO advised the public to take measures to protect themselves against mosquitoes which can transmit the dangerous virus.  Editor: Zhou Xin   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Infection from WNV has been an important public health issue for many European countries, including Greece, since 2010. WNV circulation has been recorded in several countries across the European continent, both in Central Europe and in the Mediterranean basin. In addition to management of individual cases, strategies for vector control, community involvement, and effective risk communication are required for effective control of West Nile virus disease as for other vector borne illnesses. - Mod.UBA  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/83).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Greenland":{},"Grenada":{},"Guam":{},"Guatemala":{"5":{"title":"Cyclosporiasis - USA (04): background ","date":["15","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cyclosporiasis - USA (04): background [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 15 Aug 2017. Source: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease Epidemiology Network) (edited)   The following background information on cyclosporiasis in the United States is abstracted from Gideon and the Gideon e-book series <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> (primary references are available on request).  Cyclosporiasis is the least-common reportable protozoan infection in the United States. In 2008, the reported disease rate among 10 states was 2.25 per 100 000 population.  The true incidence of foodborne cyclosporiasis in the United States has been estimated at 11 407 to 19 808 cases per year (15 hospitalizations), accounting for 0.1 percent of all foodborne illness. Approximately 42 percent of cases are imported.  1110 individual cases of cyclosporiasis were reported during 1997 to 2008. 849 (76.5 percent) of the cases occurred in 7 states, including 498 (44.9 percent of total) in Florida. 51.7 percent of cases with known travel history were autochthonous.  No fatal cases were reported during 1998 to 2006.  During 1998 to 2002, 9 foodborne outbreaks (325 cases) of cyclosporiasis were reported; 0 in 2007; 3 (66 total cases) in 2008; 1 (8 cases) in 2009; 0 in 2010. 11 outbreaks (3533 cases) related to imported food were reported during 1996 to 2014.  Reported disease rates have increased somewhat since 2012. See graph at (https://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/cyclosporiasis.png)  Chronology of reported outbreaks: - 1990. Outbreak (20 cases) among health-care workers at a hospital in Chicago, Illinois. Related to contaminated water - 1995. Outbreak at a country club in New York State - 1995. Outbreak in Florida associated with consumption of contaminated fresh raspberries. - 1996. Multiple outbreaks (1465 cases, 978 confirmed) in at least 15 states including New York (307), Florida (220), Massachusetts (170), New Jersey (103), South Carolina (38). Vehicles included raspberries and other fruit. The raspberries were imported from Guatemala and were thought to have been contaminated by water used in pesticide sprays. - 1997. Outbreak (56 cases) at a hotel in Texas. - 1997. Outbreaks (25 event-associated case clusters encompassing 370 cases) reported from 8 states (California, Florida, Maryland, Nebraska, Nevada, Rhode Island, New York, and Texas) and Canada (Ontario). - 1997. Outbreaks (26 clusters encompassing 228 cases) reported from Virginia, Washington DC, and Baltimore. Fresh basil and basil-pesto sauce implicated as the source. An additional 20 possible clusters (75 cases) were under investigation at the time. - 1997. Outbreaks (over 1700 cases during a 5-month period) associated with raspberries, mesclun lettuce, and basil. Fresh raspberries, imported from Guatemala, were implicated in 19 of 21 outbreaks/70 sporadic cases confirmed in the United States and Canada during this period. - 1998. Outbreak (57 cases) at a wedding in Massachusetts was associated with contaminated berries. - 1999. Outbreaks (62 cases in 2 outbreaks) in Missouri were associated with fresh basil, grown in either the United States of Mexico. - 2000. Outbreak (54 cases) at a wedding in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania was ascribed to imported (Guatemalan) raspberries in a wedding cake. This was the 5th year that outbreaks associated with Guatemalan raspberries had occurred in North America during the spring months. - 2004. Outbreak (96 cases) at a residential facility in Pennsylvania was associated with contaminated raw snow peas imported from Guatemala - 2004. Outbreak (90 cases) in Illinois and Texas was caused by contaminated basil and spring mix salad. - 2005. Outbreak (70 cases) in Florida - 2011. Outbreak (100 cases) in Georgia among persons who had visited an aquarium - 2013. Outbreak (643 cases) involving multiple locations was related to contaminated bagged salad imported from Mexico. - 2014. Outbreak (202 cases, including 49 in Texas) involved multiple locations. - 2015. Outbreak (72 cases) in Texas - 2015. Outbreak (495 cases) in 30 states was related to ingestion of contaminated cilantro imported from Mexico. - 2016. Outbreak (72 cases) in Texas.  Reference  1. Berger SA. Cyclosporiasis: Global Status, 2017. 35 pages, 8 graphs, 435 references. Gideon e-books, (https://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/cyclosporiasis-global-status/)   <br><br>Communicated by: Stephen Berger Geographic Medicine Tel Aviv Medical Center Tel Aviv, Israel (steve@gideononline.com)  ProMED thanks Professor Steve Berger for providing this background information extracted from the GIDEON database. The numbers most probably represent an underestimation as mild, self limiting cases probably would never be investigated by a feces microscopy for protozoan parasites. - Mod.EP  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Guinea":{"31":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (86): Africa,\r\n\tAsia ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (86): Africa,\r\n\tAsia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (86): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR, West Africa\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Tanzania\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab Province) \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR, West Africa.\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: CAJ News Africa (edited)\n(http://cajnewsafrica.com/2017/08/18/hundreds-dead-in-raging-cholera-outbreak/) \nAt least 462 people have died in the conflict-torn Democratic Republic\nof Congo following a cholera outbreak sweeping through Central and\nWest Africa. The deaths from more than 16 539 cases reported so far in\n2017 represent 94 percent of the overall incidence in the regions of\nAfrica. This follows a major epidemic reported mainly in the North\nKivu province, which is the epicentre of the conflict between rebel\ngroups and the government. In the region, health delivery services have come to a standstill\nowing to the conflict. Civilians have been forced to flee their homes,\nadding to the tens of thousands already living in camps for internally\ndisplaced people. Meanwhile, In West Africa, similarly to 2016, several countries report\nsporadic cases. Terror-ridden Nigeria is also battling a severe\noutbreak of the water borne disease with 20 deaths recorded from 809\ncases in 2017. Liberia, a hotspot for diseases, is also affected with\n6 deaths from 129 cases. There have also been outbreaks in Cameroon,\nGhana and Ivory Cast but no casualties have been reported. Overall,\n488 deaths have been reported from 17 548 cases in the affected\nregions. The United Nations Children's Fund stressed the need for increasing\nvigilance and implementing preventative measures in the current\nat-risk seasonal period. \"This highlights the importance of regular\ninformation exchange within countries sharing the same epidemiological\nbasin.\" Byline: Jean Kassongo \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Tanzania.\nDate: Wed 16 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/united-republic-tanzania/taking-stock-lessons-learnt-cholera-outbreak-response-tanzania) \nTaking stock of lessons learnt from the Cholera outbreak response in\nTanzania\n\nThe United Republic of Tanzania is battling an outbreak of Cholera\nthat has since August 2015 affected 26 046 people and claimed 410\nlives. Ending the outbreak and preventing its spread beyond Tanzania's\nborders is a high priority for WHO. To that end, WHO and partners\nsupport a well-coordinated multisectoral response through the National\nCholera Task Force which plans, coordinates and support subnational\nauthorities. Indeed, learning requires a continuous assessment of performance, a\nreview of successes and failures and a robust support for improvement.\nAn After Action Review (AAR) is a simple methodology for facilitating\nthis assessment. It provides for a qualitative review of actions taken\nto respond to an emergency as a means of identifying best practices,\ngaps and lessons learned. As a component of the IHR Monitoring and\nEvaluation Framework (IHR MEF) and part of the preparedness and\nresponse cycle, an AAR seeks to identify what worked well or not and\nhow these practices can be maintained, improved, institutionalized and\nshared with relevant stakeholders. It is within this context that WHO\nsupported the Ministry of Health to convene a meeting of experts to\nconduct an After Action Review following the national response to the\ncholera outbreak. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/cholera-new-deaths-and-infections-across-sudan) \nSinga Hospital in Sudan's Sennar received 16 new cases of cholera\nduring the 1st half of this week week of Sun 13 Aug 2017. A woman\nhas died before she could be transferred to hospital, and 9 others\nwere infected with cholera at El Matateib in North Delta locality in\nSudan's Kassala state. Sennar State\nA medical source told Radio Dabanga that most of the cases in Sennar\ncame from Um Benin village southeast of the city except for 2 cases\nfrom El Dindir and El Souki. From Saturday to Monday 12-14 Aug 2017,\n26 cases of cholera arrived from Um Benin village. This led the local\nhealth authorities to open a new cholera isolation centre at the\nvillage. El Gedaref State\nEl Gedaref Hospital in East Sudan recorded 15 cases of cholera on\nTuesday and Wednesday 15-16 Aug 2017. A medical source told Radio\nDabanga that the hospital received 9 cases on Tue 15 Aug 2017, while\n6 cases were recorded on Wed 16Aug 2017. The medic said that all\ncases of cholera came from Uktuber, El Tadamon, El Geneina, and\nKadugli districts in El Gedaref. Kassala State\nA woman has died before she could be transferred to hospital, and 9\nothers were infected with cholera at El Matateib in North Delta\nlocality in Sudan's Kassala state. Youth activist Mohamed Seyidna told\nRadio Dabanga that \"the woman died in the village before she could be\ntransferred to the hospital\". He said that the hospitalised cases at\nWagar Hospital have risen to 9. He attributed the spread of cholera in the area to water pollution and\ncalled on the health authorities to make efforts to sterilize drinking\nwater and raise awareness of the residents. National epidemic\nThe National Epidemiological Corporation reported in early July 2017\nthat nearly 24 000 Sudanese have been infected and 940 cholera\npatients have died since the outbreak of the infectious disease in\nBlue Nile state in August 2016. The Sudanese authorities however,\nrefuse to call the disease by its name, and instead refer to it as\n\"Acute Watery Diarrhea\". The National Intelligence and Security\nService has repeatedly warned medics and the press in the country not\nto make mention of cholera. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab Province).\nDate: Wed 16 Aug 2017.\nSource: The News (edited)\n(https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/223756-Number-of-cholera-cases-continues-to-swell) \nThe number of cases of cholera, a highly contagious and fatal disease\nis continuously on the rise and there is a threat that spread of the\ninfection may take shape of an epidemic if proper preventive and\ncontrol measures are not taken well in time. The 1st 2 cases of\ncholera were tested positive by National Institute of Health Islamabad\non Mon 31 Jul 2017 and another 2 confirmed positive for the\ninfection on Fri 4 Aug 2017. All the 4 patients were undergoing\ntreatment at Benazir Bhutto Hospital BH where as many as 4 more\nsuspects of the infection have been admitted for treatment. Data collected by 'The News' on Mon 14 Aug 2017 reveals that the\nallied hospitals have sent stool samples of over 10 child patients to\nNIH for confirmation of cholera in last week week of Sun 6 Aug\n2017. On Sat 12 Aug 2017, as many as 20 child patients with severe\ndiarrhoea were admitted at the BBH of which 4 were suspected as\npatients of cholera and their stool samples were sent to NIH for\nconfirmation, said Associate Professor of Paediatrics at Rawalpindi\nMedical University Dr Tariq Saeed when contacted by 'The News' on Mon\n14 Aug 2017. He added the hospital has not received confirmation reports from the\nNIH because of holidays there from Saturday to Monday. However, we\nhave been keeping the suspects in isolation under strict monitoring,\nhe said. He added that repeated rainfalls in the region and water inundation\ninside and outside homes in a number of localities particularly in\nthickly populated areas of the city are causing contamination of water\nand foodstuff that increases chances of spread of a number of\ninfections among population while children are at greater risk of\ncontracting life-threatening infections including cholera. It is important that the transmission of cholera occurs primarily by\ndrinking water or eating food that has been contaminated by the feces\n(waste product) of an infected person, including one with no apparent\nsymptoms. It is observed that heavy rainfall causes collection of heavily\ncontaminated water in streets and houses and the waste water flooding\nout of various nullahs watercourses including Nullah Leh in town\ncauses infections including cholera, typhoid, dysentery,\ngastroenteritis, hepatitis A and E, shigellosis and giardiasis. Professor Tariq said the consumption of contaminated water and\nfoodstuff causes cholera, an infection in the small intestine caused\nby bacterium _Vibrio cholerae_. Its main symptoms are watery diarrhea\nand vomiting that can lead to rapid dehydration and electrolyte\nimbalance, and death in cases which are not treated in time, he said. Health experts say that to avoid cholera and other infections, one\nmust use boiled water for drinking and should use vegetables after\nwashing with clean water and it must be kept in mind that raw\nvegetables should not be eaten in the existing weather conditions\ninstead these should be used after cooking. To a query, Professor Tariq said the heavy rainfall and water\naccumulation may contaminate water at sources and there may be chances\nof contamination of water at tube wells so individuals must boil water\nbefore drinking to avoid cholera and other infections. He added the appearance of cholera is alarming and it is time for\npeople to take extra ordinary preventive measures to safeguard their\nchildren and themselves from the disease. In case water is accumulated inside home due to heavy rainfall and\nflooded out of sewage lines, it must be wiped out immediately and the\nspace should be washed with clean water as soon as possible to avoid\ninfections. Avoiding inundation of contaminated water inside homes is\na must to avoid cholera and other infections, said Professor Tariq. Byline: Muhammad Qasim \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-SoAs\n(promed-SoAs@promedmail.org) Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 percent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are: - Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 percent (95 percent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam; - Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n-\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. WHO prequalified vaccines.\n(https://extranet.who.int/gavi/PQ_Web/).\n61. Balk YO, Choi SK, Olveda RM, et al. A randomized, non-inferiority\ntrial comparing two bivalent killed, whole cell, oral cholera vaccines\n(Euvichol vs Shanchol) in the Philippines. Vaccine 2015; 33(46):\n6350-65; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26348402).\n62. Freedman DO. Re-born in the USA: another cholera vaccine for\ntravellers. Travel Med Infect Dis. 2016; 14(4): 295-6; abstract\navailable at\n(http://www.travelmedicinejournal.com/article/S1477-8939(16)30087-4/abstract).\n63. Qadri F, Wierzba TF, Ali M, et al. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5626). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"75":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (88): Africa,\r\n\tAsia ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (88): Africa,\r\n\tAsia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (88): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Malawi (Southern region)\n2,3 Cholera - Sudan\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR (Kwilu, South Kivu)\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - India (Punjab)\n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Diarrhea - Nepal (Kapilvastu district) \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Malawi (Southern region).\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Capital Radio Malawi summ., edited\n(https://www.capitalradiomalawi.com/index.php/blog/local-news/local-news/item/8352-chikwawa-hit-by-cholera-outbreak) \nA total of 9 people are admitted to Chikwawa district Southern\nregion hospital following a cholera outbreak. This comes barely 4\nmonths after another outbreak hit the district's 2 villages in the\narea of Paramount Chief Lundu, affecting 38 people. The Environmental\nHealth Office for Chikwawa district has confirmed the development,\nciting poor access to safe water and poor quality of sanitary\nfacilities in villages. There are fears that the cholera outbreak may\nspread to other areas where communities do not have access to portable\nwater supply as well as toilets. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Malawi can be seen at\n(http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/malawi.pdf) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8665). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(http://allafrica.com/stories/201708220596.html) \nSouth Darfur\n\nIn 2 months, 42 people have died of cholera in Kalma camp for\ndisplaced people in South Darfur. 539 others have been infected. The\ndeaths occurred between 26 Jun and 20 Aug 2017, the coordinator of\nthe camp in Nyala, Yagoub Abdallah Furi, informed Radio Dabanga\nyesterday 21 Aug 2017. \"There are 3 medical isolation centres\nbelonging to 2 organizations from the USA that have been established\nin the camp since the cholera broke out in Nyala in June 2017.\" Currently there are 37 hospitalized cases at the camp's isolation\nwards. \"There is a large shortage of intravenous solutions. We hope\norganisations working in the medical field and the Ministry of Health\nto provide us with medicines.\" The epidemic reached Manawashi, north\nof Nyala city, at the beginning of August 2017. Central Darfur\n\nAt least 36 people have been infected with cholera in Central Darfur's\nNierteti in the past 11 days. 4 of them died, sources reported to\nRadio Dabanga. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian\nAffairs (OCHA) reported in its latest biweekly bulletin that\n\"humanitarian access and insecurity remain major challenges for the\nimplementation of key health and protection interventions\" in Central\nDarfur. \"Nierteti's hospital faces gaps in medicines, including oral and\nintravenous re-hydration solutions .,\" OCHA stated. \"In Zalingei\nhospital, there are several sanitation issues, including lack of\nlatrines and evidence of improper solid waste management..\" National epidemic\n\nThe National Epidemiological Corporation reported in early July 2017\nthat nearly 24 000 Sudanese have been infected and 940 cholera\npatients have died since the outbreak of the infectious disease in\nBlue Nile state in August 2016. The Sudanese authorities refuse to\ncall the disease by its name, however, and instead refer to it as\n\"acute watery diarrhea\". The National Intelligence and Security\nService has repeatedly warned medics and the press in the country not\nto make mention of cholera. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) *\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/fifteen-cholera-dead-in-west-darfur-camp) \nWest Darfur\n\n15 people have died of cholera while 18 others have been infected in\nMurnei, West Darfur, in the past 3 days. A sheikh in Murnei camp for\ndisplaced people told this station, \"18 people are now in the\nisolation ward in the camp.\" The 18 infected people came from Um Tajok\nvillage near Murnei on 9 Aug 2017. 6 people died of cholera at the\nvillage that day, a sheikh reported from the camp last week week of 7\nAug 2017. Blue Nile\n\nIn Blue Nile state, 3 brothers died in the hospital of Ed Damazin on\nTue 15 Aug 2017. A relative of the deceased told Radio Dabanga that\nthe 3 family members died of the same disease in the hospital, in El\nHijra district. Sennar\n\nMeanwhile in Sennar, 18 people contracted cholera in El Dindir\nlocality this week week of 14 Aug 2017. A medical source told this\nstation that on Thu 17 Aug 2017, El Dindir's hospital received 13\nnews cases of cholera, 8 of which were received earlier this week. 5\nothers arrived on Thu 17 Aug 2017. The medical isolation centre at\nBardana village, south of the city, also recorded 5 new cases of\ncholera. The hospital in Singa received 3 new cases of cholera on Thu 17 Aug\n2017. A medical source informed Radio Dabanga that the 3 patients had\ncome from Um Benin village, south east of Singa. \"16 people suffering\nfrom cholera are still in the isolation ward.\" Northern state\n\nThe 1st cases of cholera have been reported in the southern part of El\nMahas in Northern state, at Arduan health centre. The patients arrived\nfrom Maljab area on Thu 17 Aug 2017, while El Tura health centre of\nEl Mahas received another case. Nubian activist Adham Nasr told Radio Dabanga that the woman has been\nisolated in a room at Arduan health centre to receive treatment. There\nare concerns that the disease might break out in the area during the\nrainy season, which makes it difficult to move from and to Arduan. Red Sea\n-\nA health centre in Arayab area in Ganab, Red Sea state, received 5\nchildren suffering from cholera on Wed 16 Aug 2017. Journalist Osman\nHashim told Radio Dabanga that the one of them has been transferred to\nPort Sudan Hospital. The doctors were unable to give information about\nthe cases. The hospital's administration has not allocated a ward to\nisolate the cholera patients. Earlier in August 2017 a volunteer of one of the cholera awareness\nraising campaigns in Sudan told Radio Dabanga that the reality in the\nhospitals is very poor. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of the Republic of the Sudan can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR (Kwilu, South Kivu).\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Voice of America (VOA) News, Afrique, Agence France-Presse\n(AFP) report in French, machine trans., edited\n(https://www.voaafrique.com/a/seize-morts-du-cholera-en-une-semaine-dans-le-sud-ouest-de-la-rdc/3991609.html) \nA total of 16 people died of cholera in one week in a region in the\nsouth west of the Democratic Republic of the Congo DRC, where about\n100 cases have been recorded, it was learned Fri 18 Aug 2017 from\nthe provincial authorities. \"We have recorded 16 cases of deaths and about 100 people are infected\nwith cholera\" in 3 zones of the province of Kwilu, governor Nicholas\nBulukungu told reporters. \"The province does not have a center\nspecializing in the treatment of cholera. The isolation of the\npatients is a serious problem,\" he said. The town of Bandundu and the\n2 affected localities are inhabited by nearly a million people,\ninvited to \"strict observance of the basic rules of hygiene.\" Another Congolese province (South Kivu in the east) is facing an\noutbreak of cholera with 2 deaths and several tens of cases reported\nfor nearly 3 weeks. According to the UN, cholera has become a major public health problem\nin the DRC with thousands of cases recorded every year in many\nprovinces in this vast country without infrastructure and where most\nof the population lives in poverty. More than 700 deaths of cholera were recorded in 2016 in the DRC. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n(promed-fra@promedmail.org) Maps of the Democratic Republic of the Congo can be seen at\n(http://goo.gl/DM2AT8) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42129). -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - India (Punjab).\nDate: Sat 19 Aug 2017 03:09 PM IST.\nSource: Times of India (edited)\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ludhiana/cholera-outbreak-18-fresh-cases-reported-on-day-5/articleshow/60126504.cms) \n18 fresh cholera cases were reported at Guru Har Rai Nagar Ludhiana,\nPunjab on on day 5 of the outbreak. District epidemiologist Ramesh\nKumar said more than 500 people contracted the disease over the past\nfew days. Health officials are taking all possible measures to stem\nthe outbreak, including organizing medical camps to engender public\nawareness about the disease. Meanwhile, sources said the health department is still trying to hide\nthe exact number of cases reported in the camp. \"No water samples have\nbeen collected on the 5th day of the outbreak. All the 18 patients\nhave been admitted to private hospitals. Health officials are not\npaying attention to affected areas as a number of cases are being\nstill being reported.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1789). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Diarrhea - Nepal (Kapilvastu district).\nDate: Sun 20 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Himalayan Times (edited)\n(https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/child-loses-life-in-outbreak-of-diarrhoea-in-flood-hit-kapilvastu/) \nA child has reportedly succumbed to diarrhea in Sattbhara, of\nMaharajgunj Municipality-7 in Kapilvastu district Province Five on\nSun 20 Aug 2017. According to Jayasawal, more than 50 persons have\nbeen affected in the outbreak of diarrhoea in the municipality since\nThu 17 Aug 2017. He said the consumption of water and fish obtained\nfrom contaminated water sources could be the cause of the outbreak. The health workers deputed from the District Health Office (DHO) have\nbeen treating locals with preventive medicines while the critical ones\nhave been undergoing treatment in the Bahadurgunj Hospital in the\ndistrict. Meanwhile, the DHO has urged the general public to take\nprecautions and preventive measures as there is high risk of diarrhoea\nspreading in the flood-hit areas. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-SoAs\n(promed-SoAs@promedmail.org) Maps of Nepal can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/ydf8ojtj) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38712). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam.
