Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Honduras":{},"Hong Kong":{"24":{"title":"Ranavirus, salamander - China: (Hong Kong) 1st rep, OIE\r\n\t","date":["17","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Ranavirus, salamander - China: (Hong Kong) 1st rep, OIE\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 16 Jan 2014. Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30 (33) (edited) (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=23838)   Infection with ranavirus, Hong Kong (SAR-PCR)  Information received on and dated 17 Aug 2017 from Dr Thomas Sit, Chief Veterinary Officer/Assistant Director (Inspection & Quarantine), Agriculture, Fisheries and Conservation Department, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government, Hong Kong, Hong Kong (SAR-PRC)  Summary Report type: immediate notification (final report) Date of start of the event: 20 Mar 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 11 Aug 2017 Report date: 16 Jan 2014 Date submitted to OIE: 16 Jan 2014 Date event resolved: 1 Apr 2017 Reason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease Manifestation of disease: clinical disease Causal agent: _Ranavirus_(Chinese giant salamander ranavirus) Nature of diagnosis: laboratory (advanced) This event pertains to a defined zone within the country  New outbreaks (1) Summary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1 Outbreak 1: Ocean Park, Southern, Hong Kong Date of start of the outbreak: 20 Mar 2017 Outbreak status: resolved (1 Apr 2017) Epidemiological unit: not applicable Water type: fresh water Population type: wild Population system: closed Total animals affected: Species / Apparent morbidity rate percentage / Apparent mortality rate percentage / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Chinese giant salamander (_Andrias davidianus_) / 100 / 70 / 10 / 10 / 7 / 3 / 0  Epidemiology Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive. Epidemiological comment: seized Chinese giant salamanders from suspected illegal trade developed signs of disease while undergoing quarantine. There is no evidence of the spreading of disease inside or outside the quarantine facility.  Control measures Measures applied: quarantine, disinfection, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals Measures to be applied: no other measures  Diagnostic test results Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result Tai Lung Veterinary Laboratory, Agriculture, Fisheries & Conservation Department (national laboratory) / Chinese giant salamander (_Andrias davidianus_) / histopathological examination / 31 Mar 2017 / Positive Australian Animal Health Laboratory (OIE Reference Laboratory) / Chinese giant salamander (_Andrias davidianus_) / gene sequencing / 11 Aug 2017 / Positive Australian Animal Health Laboratory (OIE reference laboratory) / Chinese giant salamander (_Andrias davidianus_) / pathogen isolation on cell culture / 11 Aug 2017 / Positive Australian Animal Health Laboratory (OIE reference laboratory) / Chinese giant salamander (_Andrias davidianus_) / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 11 Aug 2017 / Positive Australian Animal Health Laboratory (OIE reference laboratory) / Chinese giant salamander (_Andrias davidianus_) / real-time PCR / 11 Aug 2017 / Positive  Future reporting The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.  The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The Chinese giant salamander (_Andrias davidianus_) is the largest amphibian in the world. It can grow to more than one meter (3.3 ft) in length. This species used to be widespread in central, south western, and southern China, but it is considered to be critically endangered. It has declined catastrophically over the last 30 years, principally due to over-exploitation, and it is now very rare, with few surviving populations known. Commercial over-exploitation for human consumption is the main threat to this species. It has also suffered from habitat destruction (such as from the construction of dams) and habitat degradation (such as water pollution from mines). For a picture go to (http://www.factzoo.com/sites/all/img/amphibians/salamander/chinese-giant-salamander.jpg).  In 2010, an outbreak of disease occurred amongst farmed Chinese giant salamanders in Shanxi Province, China. Clinical signs included anorexia, lethargy, ecchymosis, and swollen areas on the head and limbs and skin ulceration. An investigation was carried out and they isolated for the 1st time a ranavirus infection associated with mass mortality in Chinese giant salamanders. This virus was named Chinese giant salamander virus (CGSV-L). This virus has not been studied in the wild. It might be possible that it circulates causing little impact, but under the stressing circumstances that might arise in captivity the virulence increases. - Mod.PMB  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58595).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"115":{"title":"Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nDENGUE/DHF UPDATE (10): ASIA, PACIFIC, AFRICA, RESEARCH, WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries Asia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National\n- National\n- National\nIndia\n- National\n- Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Assam\n- Delhi\n- Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore)\n- Tamil Nadu\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Kerala\n- Karnataka\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- West Bengal (Kolkata)\n- West Bengal (Birbhum)\n- West Bengal (Siliguri)\n- Odisha (Ganjam)\n- Odisha\n- Gujarat (Ahmedabad)\n- Jharkhand (Jamshedpur)\n- Telangana (Hyderabad)\nPakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\nChina\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp)\n- Hong Kong SAR\n- Macau SAR\n- Macau SAR\nTaiwan\nMyanmar\n- National\n- Kayah\nIndonesia\n- Papua (Jayapura)\nViet Nam\n- National\n- National\n- Mekong Delta\n- Hanoi\n- Ha Nam\nPhilippines\n- National\n- Cebu\n- Negros Occidental\n- Negros Occidental (Bacolod City)\n- Cavite (Trece Martires City)\nLaos\n- National\nJapan ex Côte d'Ivoire Pacific\n\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Fiji\n- French Polynesia (Tahiti) Africa\n\n- Côte d'Ivoire\n- Côte d'Ivoire <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence\n- Air travel related spread of dengue\n- Visual impact <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> World Health Organization update \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries\nAsia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National. 26 Jul 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. Out of total 402 infected persons, 67 were tested positive\nin Bhadrak district, 61 in Cuttack district, and 59 in Balasore\ndistrict. Similarly, 35 people have been infected in Khordha, 34 in\nJajpur, 24 in Puri, 20 in Jagatsinghpur . While Nayagarh, Sonepur, Kalahandi,\nAngul, and Bargarh registered 3 cases each, Nuapada and Kandhamal\nwitnessed 2 cases. Boudh, Rayagada, Sundargarh and Deogarh districts\nrecorded with single case each. However, 12 patients have come to the\nstate from neighbouring states.\n(http://pragativadi.com/dengue-claims-two-lives-affects-402-odisha/) - Gujarat (Ahmedabad). 1 Aug 2017. A total of 59 cases in July 2017.\nThe actual number of cases is said to be 'far more'; it takes at least\n15 days to confirm cases.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/59-dengue-cases-in-july-amc/articleshow/59853414.cms) - Jharkhand (Jamshedpur). 30 Jul 2017. 75 positive cases in Kolhan and\nadjoining area of Jamshedpur.\n(http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/dengue-cases-rise-positive-cases-shoot-75-kolhan/111026/) - Telangana (Hyderabad). 25 Jul 2017. All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. As per a weekly report issued by Prevention and Control\nProgram for Dengue in Sindh, as many as 27 new dengue fever cases\nsurfaced in the city from 1 to 7 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/08/363624/a27-more-dengue-cases-surface-in-karachi/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 8 Aug 2017. 3rd death due to dengue\nhemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. Most of the affected patients were\nbrought from the Tehkal Payan area from where water samples have been\ncollected to determine the situation.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1476245/third-dengue-death-\nreported-k-p/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 16 Aug 2017. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. Dengue continues in\nPeshawar, claiming 7 lives with 69 new cases reported from different\nareas of the city during the last 24 hours, raising the number of\ntotal cases to 1703. So far, he said, 7 deaths including 6 from Khyber\nTeaching Hospital and one in Hayatabad Medical Complex were reported\nfrom dengue epidemics in Peshawar. Out of 69 new cases, 41 were\nreported in Khyber Teaching Hospital (KTH), 13 in Hayatabad Medical\nComplex (HMC), 12 in Lady Reading Hospital (LRH), and 3 in Naseerullah\nKhan Babar Teaching Hospital (NBTH), Peshawar, he said. A rapid\nresponse team has also been set up with mandate to swiftly reach to\nthe affected areas from where new cases were surfaced besides helping\nthe field staff in conduct of fumigation spray, removal of larvae, and\nprovision of other necessary medicines.\n(https://dnd.com.pk/dengue-rampage-in-peshawar-kills-seven-69-new-cases-surface/133250) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://pakistanmap.facts.co/pakistanmapof/PakistanAdministrativeMap.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ China\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp). 16 Aug 2017.\nGuangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in south China has reported its 1st\nimported dengue case this year 2017, local inspection and quarantine\nbureau said. The man had stayed in Hanoi, Viet Nam, for 2 months but\ndenied having been bitten by mosquitoes or having any infectious\ndisease.\n(http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/16/c_136531179.htm) - Hong Kong SAR Special Administrative Region. 9 Aug 2017. 1st\nlocally transmitted case of dengue in Hong Kong, this year 2017.\n(https://today.mims.com/topic/chp-investigates-first-local-dengue-fever-case-of-the-year) - Macau SAR. 1 Aug 2017. 1st locally acquired case this year 2017\nconfirmed. 53 imported cases in 2017, including 18 from Thailand, 10\nfrom Sri Lanka, and 7 from the Philippines.\n(https://macaunews.mo/first-local-dengue-case-year-confirmed/) - Macau SAR. 24 Aug 2017. A 48 year old domestic worker from the\nPhilippines is now in hospital after health authorities confirmed she\nhas dengue fever; the 7th imported case reported in Macau this year\n2017.\n(http://menafn.com/1095765055/Tests-show-that-Filipino-maid-in-Macau-has-dengue-fever) Maps of China can be seen at (http://www.sacu.org/maps/provmap.png)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Taiwan. 3 Aug 2017. 2 more indigenous dengue fever cases have been\nconfirmed in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, making that 3 cases this\nyear, said a statement issued by Kaohsiung City's Department of Health\non Thu 3 Aug 2017. The 3 cases were all members of the same family,\nhusband, wife and son, who lived together in the southern Taiwanese\nport city, according to the department. The 3 have recovered\n(http://focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201708030028.aspx) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Taiwan can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/193). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Myanmar\n- National. 1 Aug 2017. From 1 Jan to 22 Jul 2017, 14 919 cases and 81\ndeaths of dengue recorded. Most of the deaths were from Ayeyarwady\nregion, followed by Yangon and Bago regions. The current reported\ncases are higher than those of 2016, yet still lower than that of\n2015, according to Dr Zaw Lin, dengue program manager of Ministry of\nHealth and Sports. In Rakhine State, about 1800 people are infected\nand 18 died from the infection. High occurrence was observed in\nMinbya, Sittwe, and Toungup townships. Only over 1500 cases were identified during 2014 in\nRakhine State.\n(http://www.thithtoolwin.com/2017/08/blog-post_23.html) in Myanmar,\ntrans. Mod.YMA, edited - Kayah. 3 Aug 2017. 370 cases as of 27 Jul 2017, 1 death. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed strain homology with the Burkina Faso 2016 strain. On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. Sir Gangaram Hospital reported the rare case,\nwhere the woman, who went to the eye OPD outpatient department,\ncomplained of \"sudden blurring of vision in the left eye,\" as reported\nby IE Indian Express. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017. The number of cases reported is lower\nthan that reported during the same time period in the previous years\n(2012-2016). Pacific Islands countries and areas\n\nFrench Polynesia\nIn French Polynesia, 12 cases (including 1 death) in week 29 and 12\ncases in week 30 (week ending 29 Jul 2017). Among these, 15 cases were\nconfirmed as DENV-1 infection. New Caledonia (no update)\nAs of 1 Aug 2017, 4,452 dengue cases were reported in 2017. There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Hungary":{},"Iceland":{},"India":{"14":{"title":"Japanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (UP) AES due to\r\n\tscrub typhus ","date":["16","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Japanese encephalitis & other - India (15): (UP) AES due to\r\n\tscrub typhus [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 16 Aug 2017. Source: The Hindu (edited) (http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/only-some-children-with-fever-progress-to-aes-says-doctor/article19499880.ece)   Based on a study carried out in 2015, a team led by Dr Manoj V Murhekar, Director of the Chennai-based National Institute of Epidemiology, found scrub typhus to be responsible for acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) in 63 percent of patients admitted to the Baba Raghav Das Medical College Hospital in Gorakhpur Uttar Pradesh state, UP.  The study was repeated last year 2016 by the same team by comparing children with AES and healthy children who are siblings of the patients or living in the same village.  It found that AES patients had 35 times greater possibility of having antibodies against scrub typhus compared with healthy children thereby confirming that AES was caused by scrub typhus.  Excerpts from an interview with Dr Manoj Murhekar: - Have you carried out any studies this year 2017 on children admitted to BRD hospital with AES? How likely is scrub typhus to have caused AES this year as well? The causation of the disease or etiology will not change from year to year. In 2015 and 2016 we have seen that scrub typhus was responsible for over 60 percent of AES and Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) causes less than 10 percent of AES in children below 15 years. Scrub typhus was responsible for over 60 percent of AES even in 2014. There is vaccination for JE virus but no intervention has been implemented widely for scrub typhus. So the etiology wouldn't have changed compared with last year.  - Besides BRD hospital, is there any other referral hospital in that region? What is the extent of population that BRD hospital caters to? Except BRD hospital, there is no referral hospital in the Gorakhpur Division in Uttar Pradesh. The hospital caters to people living in Gorakhpur Division (4 districts) and Basti division in UP, Bihar, West Bengal, Assam, and even Nepal.  - Why do we see a large number of children with AES each year at BRD hospital? There is a lot of scrub typhus fever in the community. Between 20-25 percent of fever in children being attended to at PHCs primary health centres is caused by scrub typhus. Only a small percentage of these children progress to AES. Most of the cases in the community are sub-clinical with no symptoms or very mild fever. Only some children with fever will progress to AES. The hospital sees 1500-2000 cases each year and 80 percent of these cases are during July to October.  About 1/4 of patients with AES are adults. Generally, adults develop immunity against scrub typhus, so only those who have not been exposed to scrub typhus will progress to AES.  - Is there any specific reason why scrub typhus is found only in this region? It is not correct to say it is restricted only to this region. Scrub typhus is found even in Uttarakhand, Himachal Pradesh, and Tamil Nadu. In Tamil Nadu it is found in Vellore and Thiruvallur districts. About 7-10 percent of fever in these 2 districts is caused by scrub typhus. The reason why it is found only in these 2 districts in Tamil Nadu is because researchers have investigated for scrub typhus in these 2 districts.  - Is it possible to treat scrub typhus and prevent the infection from progressing to AES? In the beginning of this year 2017, the Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) recommended to the Uttar Pradesh government to use doxycycline antibiotic to treat children with fever for 5 days. The ICMR shared an algorithm with the Uttar Pradesh government which tells which fever should be treated with doxycycline and the dosage. If treated early with doxycycline, then children will not progress to AES. This prevention strategy has to be implemented widely and even by doctors in the private sector before we see results. In July 2017, ICMR and doctors from the Christian Medical College, Vellore went to Gorakhpur and conducted awareness campaign for Indian Medical Association (IMA) and Indian Association of Paediatrics (IAP) doctors, chief medical officers, and programme officers.  - Why is the death rate high at 20 percent in children with AES? At BRD hospital, we have observed patients with AES. The mortality is about 20 percent due to multi-organ involvement. In the case of AES caused by scrub typhus, the mortality is about 15-17 percent compared with AES caused by JE. This is because treatment started early with azithromycin can treat AES caused by scrub typhus. Azithromycin is in the class of medicines as doxycycline but easy to administer in sick children as it is given intravenously.  - What is vaccine coverage for Japanese encephalitis and why don't we see herd immunity with this vaccine? In 2012, the vaccine coverage for Japanese encephalitis was only 50 percent but has improved to 75 percent now. A study we carried out in 2015 found 75 percent coverage for the 1st dose and only 42 percent for the 2nd dose. 3 of the 4 children aged 25-36 months in Gorakhpur region had received at least one dose of the vaccine. We need 2 doses of the vaccine  during 9-12 months for the 1st dose and 16-24 months for the 2nd dose  for optimal protection. With just one dose, the efficacy is over 80 percent. No studies have been done to find the duration of protection. With increasing vaccine coverage the incidence of JE has dropped from about 20 percent a few years ago to less than 10 percent now.  In the case of mosquito-borne diseases, herd immunity will not play a major role. So increasing the vaccine coverage should be a priority.  Byline: R Prasad   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  As with cases of encephalitis in Uttar Pradesh and other states in northeastern India, as noted in the report above, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus infections and are classified as AES with undetermined etiology. AES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. The report above implicates scrub typhus as a major cause of AES. It is not clear why most of the AES cases are in children, but scrub typhus infections occur in people of all ages.  Scrub typhus in India has been receiving additional attention in recent years. a 2013 review article indicated that scrub typhus is seriously neglected and under-reported ((http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.13-0064)). ProMED-mail has posted multiple reports of scrub typhus in several Indian states in the past, especially since 2011. For background information, see ProMED-mail post Scrub typhus - India (05): background http://promedmail.org/post/20111208.3546.  The report above indicates that JE vaccination campaigns have been active there this year (2017) but have not provided complete coverage. Other etiologies for AES, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus (_Orientia tsutsugamushi_), lychee fruit consumption, and agricultural-related toxicants have been proposed. The above report is another implicating scrub typhus as an important etiology of the AES cases. However, getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing. Prospective studies are required to confirm the degree of scrub typhus involvement in AES cases.  Maps of India can be accessed at (http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm). A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of India can be accessed at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). The HealthMap/ProMED map of Uttar Pradesh state, India can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322). - Mod.TY  A recent report in the journal Emerging Infectious Diseases (1), which ProMED-mail posted (2), indicated that the scrub typhus may account for a significant proportion of acute encephalitis syndrome in the northeastern Indian state of Assam. ProMED-mail has posted multiple reports of scrub typhus in several Indian states, especially since 2011 (3), so that it is not surprising that scrub typhus could account for many cases of acute encephalitis in other Indian states (4). However, I noted at the time in the moderator comments (2) that although headache is a common part of the symptom complex of scrub typhus, acute encephalitis or meningoencephalitis, with a history of altered sensorium, seizures or neck stiffness, and abnormal neuroimaging and cerebrospinal fluid findings, complicates a minority of scrub typhus cases (5-7).  \nPlease also see prior ProMED-mail posts that have discussed the occurrence of acute encephalitis complicating scrub typhus (Acute encephalitis syndrome - India (03): (UP) comment http://promedmail.org/post/20151011.3707371 and Acute encephalitis syndrome - India (02): (UP) http://promedmail.org/post/20151008.3698951).  1. ProMED-mail post Japanese encephalitis & other - India (01): (AS) Archive Number: http://promedmail.org/post/20170101.4733821 \n3. Emerg Infect Dis. 2010;16(10):1641-1643. \n(https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/16/10/10-0456_article) \n6. Pai H, Sohn S, Yeonsun Seong Y, et al. Central Nervous System Involvement in Patients with Scrub Typhus. Clin Infect Dis 1997; 24:436-40 (http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/24/3/436.full.pdf). \n7. Jamil MD, Hussain M, Lyngdoh M, et al. Scrub typhus meningoencephalitis, a diagnostic challenge for clinicians: A hospital based study from North-East India. J Neuroscience in Rural Practice 2015; 6 (4):488-493. (http://www.ruralneuropractice.com/article.asp?issn=0976-3147;year=2015;volume=6;issue=4;spage=488;epage=493;aulast=Jamil). - Mod.ML   ","keywordsMatched":[]},"31":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (86): Africa,\r\n\tAsia ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (86): Africa,\r\n\tAsia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (86): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR, West Africa\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Tanzania\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab Province) \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR, West Africa.\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: CAJ News Africa (edited)\n(http://cajnewsafrica.com/2017/08/18/hundreds-dead-in-raging-cholera-outbreak/) \nAt least 462 people have died in the conflict-torn Democratic Republic\nof Congo following a cholera outbreak sweeping through Central and\nWest Africa. The deaths from more than 16 539 cases reported so far in\n2017 represent 94 percent of the overall incidence in the regions of\nAfrica. This follows a major epidemic reported mainly in the North\nKivu province, which is the epicentre of the conflict between rebel\ngroups and the government. In the region, health delivery services have come to a standstill\nowing to the conflict. Civilians have been forced to flee their homes,\nadding to the tens of thousands already living in camps for internally\ndisplaced people. Meanwhile, In West Africa, similarly to 2016, several countries report\nsporadic cases. Terror-ridden Nigeria is also battling a severe\noutbreak of the water borne disease with 20 deaths recorded from 809\ncases in 2017. Liberia, a hotspot for diseases, is also affected with\n6 deaths from 129 cases. There have also been outbreaks in Cameroon,\nGhana and Ivory Cast but no casualties have been reported. Overall,\n488 deaths have been reported from 17 548 cases in the affected\nregions. The United Nations Children's Fund stressed the need for increasing\nvigilance and implementing preventative measures in the current\nat-risk seasonal period. \"This highlights the importance of regular\ninformation exchange within countries sharing the same epidemiological\nbasin.\" Byline: Jean Kassongo \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Tanzania.\nDate: Wed 16 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/united-republic-tanzania/taking-stock-lessons-learnt-cholera-outbreak-response-tanzania) \nTaking stock of lessons learnt from the Cholera outbreak response in\nTanzania\n\nThe United Republic of Tanzania is battling an outbreak of Cholera\nthat has since August 2015 affected 26 046 people and claimed 410\nlives. Ending the outbreak and preventing its spread beyond Tanzania's\nborders is a high priority for WHO. To that end, WHO and partners\nsupport a well-coordinated multisectoral response through the National\nCholera Task Force which plans, coordinates and support subnational\nauthorities. Indeed, learning requires a continuous assessment of performance, a\nreview of successes and failures and a robust support for improvement.\nAn After Action Review (AAR) is a simple methodology for facilitating\nthis assessment. It provides for a qualitative review of actions taken\nto respond to an emergency as a means of identifying best practices,\ngaps and lessons learned. As a component of the IHR Monitoring and\nEvaluation Framework (IHR MEF) and part of the preparedness and\nresponse cycle, an AAR seeks to identify what worked well or not and\nhow these practices can be maintained, improved, institutionalized and\nshared with relevant stakeholders. It is within this context that WHO\nsupported the Ministry of Health to convene a meeting of experts to\nconduct an After Action Review following the national response to the\ncholera outbreak. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/cholera-new-deaths-and-infections-across-sudan) \nSinga Hospital in Sudan's Sennar received 16 new cases of cholera\nduring the 1st half of this week week of Sun 13 Aug 2017. A woman\nhas died before she could be transferred to hospital, and 9 others\nwere infected with cholera at El Matateib in North Delta locality in\nSudan's Kassala state. Sennar State\nA medical source told Radio Dabanga that most of the cases in Sennar\ncame from Um Benin village southeast of the city except for 2 cases\nfrom El Dindir and El Souki. From Saturday to Monday 12-14 Aug 2017,\n26 cases of cholera arrived from Um Benin village. This led the local\nhealth authorities to open a new cholera isolation centre at the\nvillage. El Gedaref State\nEl Gedaref Hospital in East Sudan recorded 15 cases of cholera on\nTuesday and Wednesday 15-16 Aug 2017. A medical source told Radio\nDabanga that the hospital received 9 cases on Tue 15 Aug 2017, while\n6 cases were recorded on Wed 16Aug 2017. The medic said that all\ncases of cholera came from Uktuber, El Tadamon, El Geneina, and\nKadugli districts in El Gedaref. Kassala State\nA woman has died before she could be transferred to hospital, and 9\nothers were infected with cholera at El Matateib in North Delta\nlocality in Sudan's Kassala state. Youth activist Mohamed Seyidna told\nRadio Dabanga that \"the woman died in the village before she could be\ntransferred to the hospital\". He said that the hospitalised cases at\nWagar Hospital have risen to 9. He attributed the spread of cholera in the area to water pollution and\ncalled on the health authorities to make efforts to sterilize drinking\nwater and raise awareness of the residents. National epidemic\nThe National Epidemiological Corporation reported in early July 2017\nthat nearly 24 000 Sudanese have been infected and 940 cholera\npatients have died since the outbreak of the infectious disease in\nBlue Nile state in August 2016. The Sudanese authorities however,\nrefuse to call the disease by its name, and instead refer to it as\n\"Acute Watery Diarrhea\". The National Intelligence and Security\nService has repeatedly warned medics and the press in the country not\nto make mention of cholera. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab Province).\nDate: Wed 16 Aug 2017.\nSource: The News (edited)\n(https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/223756-Number-of-cholera-cases-continues-to-swell) \nThe number of cases of cholera, a highly contagious and fatal disease\nis continuously on the rise and there is a threat that spread of the\ninfection may take shape of an epidemic if proper preventive and\ncontrol measures are not taken well in time. The 1st 2 cases of\ncholera were tested positive by National Institute of Health Islamabad\non Mon 31 Jul 2017 and another 2 confirmed positive for the\ninfection on Fri 4 Aug 2017. All the 4 patients were undergoing\ntreatment at Benazir Bhutto Hospital BH where as many as 4 more\nsuspects of the infection have been admitted for treatment. Data collected by 'The News' on Mon 14 Aug 2017 reveals that the\nallied hospitals have sent stool samples of over 10 child patients to\nNIH for confirmation of cholera in last week week of Sun 6 Aug\n2017. On Sat 12 Aug 2017, as many as 20 child patients with severe\ndiarrhoea were admitted at the BBH of which 4 were suspected as\npatients of cholera and their stool samples were sent to NIH for\nconfirmation, said Associate Professor of Paediatrics at Rawalpindi\nMedical University Dr Tariq Saeed when contacted by 'The News' on Mon\n14 Aug 2017. He added the hospital has not received confirmation reports from the\nNIH because of holidays there from Saturday to Monday. However, we\nhave been keeping the suspects in isolation under strict monitoring,\nhe said. He added that repeated rainfalls in the region and water inundation\ninside and outside homes in a number of localities particularly in\nthickly populated areas of the city are causing contamination of water\nand foodstuff that increases chances of spread of a number of\ninfections among population while children are at greater risk of\ncontracting life-threatening infections including cholera. It is important that the transmission of cholera occurs primarily by\ndrinking water or eating food that has been contaminated by the feces\n(waste product) of an infected person, including one with no apparent\nsymptoms. It is observed that heavy rainfall causes collection of heavily\ncontaminated water in streets and houses and the waste water flooding\nout of various nullahs watercourses including Nullah Leh in town\ncauses infections including cholera, typhoid, dysentery,\ngastroenteritis, hepatitis A and E, shigellosis and giardiasis. Professor Tariq said the consumption of contaminated water and\nfoodstuff causes cholera, an infection in the small intestine caused\nby bacterium _Vibrio cholerae_. Its main symptoms are watery diarrhea\nand vomiting that can lead to rapid dehydration and electrolyte\nimbalance, and death in cases which are not treated in time, he said. Health experts say that to avoid cholera and other infections, one\nmust use boiled water for drinking and should use vegetables after\nwashing with clean water and it must be kept in mind that raw\nvegetables should not be eaten in the existing weather conditions\ninstead these should be used after cooking. To a query, Professor Tariq said the heavy rainfall and water\naccumulation may contaminate water at sources and there may be chances\nof contamination of water at tube wells so individuals must boil water\nbefore drinking to avoid cholera and other infections. He added the appearance of cholera is alarming and it is time for\npeople to take extra ordinary preventive measures to safeguard their\nchildren and themselves from the disease. In case water is accumulated inside home due to heavy rainfall and\nflooded out of sewage lines, it must be wiped out immediately and the\nspace should be washed with clean water as soon as possible to avoid\ninfections. Avoiding inundation of contaminated water inside homes is\na must to avoid cholera and other infections, said Professor Tariq. Byline: Muhammad Qasim \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-SoAs\n(promed-SoAs@promedmail.org) Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 percent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are: - Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 percent (95 percent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam; - Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n-\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. WHO prequalified vaccines.\n(https://extranet.who.int/gavi/PQ_Web/).\n61. Balk YO, Choi SK, Olveda RM, et al. A randomized, non-inferiority\ntrial comparing two bivalent killed, whole cell, oral cholera vaccines\n(Euvichol vs Shanchol) in the Philippines. Vaccine 2015; 33(46):\n6350-65; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26348402).\n62. Freedman DO. Re-born in the USA: another cholera vaccine for\ntravellers. Travel Med Infect Dis. 2016; 14(4): 295-6; abstract\navailable at\n(http://www.travelmedicinejournal.com/article/S1477-8939(16)30087-4/abstract).\n63. Qadri F, Wierzba TF, Ali M, et al. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. A 12 Aug 2017 report quotes USA health\nofficials indicating that the Zika outbreaks in the Caribbean and\nSouth America are waning and that has helped slow the spread of the\nmosquito-borne virus to Florida and other localities in the USA this\nyear (2017).\n(http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/experts-herd-immunity-us-slows-zika-florida-49179180) Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in\nthe Americas mentioned above and below can be accessed at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574);\nNorth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106);\nCentral America (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455);\nCaribbean (http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/); and\nSouth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186). - Mod.TY Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. Increased herd immunity from previous Zika virus\ninfections has been suggested as one reason for the decline.\n(http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/08/zika-has-all-disappeared-americas-why) North America\n\nUSA\n- Hidalgo county, Texas. 3 Aug 2017. South America\n\nArgentina (Salta province). 13 Aug 2017. November 2016-May 2017, 1st\nlocally acquired outbreak (conf.) 203 cases of which 7 pregnant.\nDepartment most affected: San Martín (Tartagal, General Mosconi,\nAguaray, and Embarcación), and Morillo.\n(http://www.eltribuno.info/salta/nota/2017-8-13-0-0-0-hubo-203-casos-de-zika-en-el-primer-brote-autoctono)\n Brazil\n- Origin and spread. 15 Jun 2017. (reported) Analyses of viral genomes\nwith ecological and epidemiological data yield an estimate that ZIKV\nwas present in northeast Brazil by February 2014 and is likely to have\ndisseminated from there, nationally and internationally, before the\n1st detection of ZIKV in the Americas. Estimated dates for the\ninternational spread of ZIKV from Brazil indicate the duration of\npre-detection cryptic transmission in recipient regions. The role of\nnortheast Brazil in the establishment of ZIKV in the Americas is\nfurther supported by geographic analysis of ZIKV transmission.\n(http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v546/n7658/full/nature22402.html) - Eye lesions. 17 Jul 2017 (reported) of 112 infants born to Zika\nvirus infected mothers in Brazil, 24 (21 percent) had eye\nabnormalities; 10 infants (42 percent) with abnormal eye examination\nfindings did not have microcephaly, 8 (33 percent) did not have any\ncentral nervous system findings, and 2 (8 percent) had eye\nabnormalities despite maternal 3rd trimester infection. Eye\nabnormalities may be the only initial finding in congenital Zika virus\ninfection, and all infants with potential Zika virus exposure should\nundergo screening eye examinations.\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/article-abstract/2636587) Peru\n- National. 22 Jul 2017. 2016-22 Jul 2017 (susp.) 6432 cases, (conf.)\n1438 cases with 264 pregnant with 17 cases of suspected Zika\nvirus-related microcephaly.
