Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-16 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html) State / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 20 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 29 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 6 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 4 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 40 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 4 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 2 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 203 / 9 - Texas. 11 Aug 2017. 1 Jan 2016-31 July 2017, 219 pregnant women with\nlaboratory evidence of possible recent Zika virus infection were\nidentified in Texas, including 49 (22 percent) with\nlaboratory-confirmed Zika virus). One woman was infected in Texas; all\nothers were exposed outside the United States and its territories.\nZika virus testing was completed for 80 (43 percent) of the 185\ninfants or fetuses, and Zika virus-associated birth defects were\ndocumented in 15 (8 percent) pregnancies (14 live-born infants and one\nfetal loss), including 6 (17 percent) of the 36 infants or fetal\nlosses delivered by women with laboratory-confirmed Zika virus\ninfection. Of these, 10 infants or fetuses had microcephaly; 5 of\nthose with microcephaly had additional birth defects, including\nholoprosencephaly the brain doesn't properly divide into the right\nand left hemispheres, hydranencephaly brain's cerebral hemispheres\nreplaced by sacs filled with cerebrospinal fluid, craniosynostosis\npremature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, often resulting in\nan abnormal head shape, and clubfeet feet turned inward. Zika\nvirus-associated birth defects identified in the remaining 3 infants\nincluded holoprosencephaly, cataracts, and ventral pons hypoplasia.\n(https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6631a5.htm?s_cid=mm6631a5_e) Neurological effects not only occur in fetuses and neonates, there\nare occasional cases in adults as well. A report describes a case of\nZIKV meningoencephalitis and probable myelitis and its associated\nmagnetic resonance imaging findings that rapidly resolved during\nrecovery in a previously healthy adult.\n((http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0921)). -\nMod. TY - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 40 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 39 / 0\nTotal 554 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Evaluation of diagnostic tests.\nDate: September 2017 (ahead of print).\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/9/16-2043_article) \nref: Safronetz D, Sloan A, Stein DR, et al. Evaluation of 5\ncommercially available Zika virus immunoassays. Emerg Infect Dis.\n2017; 23(9): 1577-80. doi: 10.3201/eid2309.162043. Epub 2017 Sep 17\n-\nAbstract\n\nBecause of global spread of Zika virus, accurate and high-throughput\ndiagnostic immunoassays are needed. We compared the sensitivity and\nspecificity of 5 commercially available Zika virus serologic assays to\nthe recommended protocol of Zika virus IgM-capture ELISA and\nplaque-reduction neutralization tests. Most commercial immunoassays\nshowed low sensitivity, which can be increased. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The low sensitivity is a significant concern. Readers interested in\nthe evaluation of the specific tests may wish to see the full report\navailable at the source URL above. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Saliva transmission unlikely.\nDate: Tue 1 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Communications (edited)\n(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5539107/? \nref: Newman CM, Dudley DM, Aliota MT, et al. Oropharyngeal mucosal\ntransmission of Zika virus in rhesus macaques. Nat Commun. 2017; 8(1):\n169. doi: 10.1038/s41467-017-00246-8\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus is present in urine, saliva, tears, and breast milk, but\nthe transmission risk associated with these body fluids is currently\nunknown. Here we evaluate the risk of Zika virus transmission through\nmucosal contact in rhesus macaques. Application of high-dose Zika\nvirus directly to the tonsils of 3 rhesus macaques results in\ndetectable plasma viremia in all animals by 2 days post-exposure;\nvirus replication kinetics are similar to those observed in animals\ninfected subcutaneously. 3 additional macaques inoculated\nsubcutaneously with Zika virus served as saliva donors to assess the\ntransmission risk from contact with oral secretions from an infected\nindividual. 7 naive animals repeatedly exposed to donor saliva via the\nconjunctivae, tonsils, or nostrils did not become infected. Our\nresults suggest that there is a risk of Zika virus transmission via\nthe mucosal route, but that the risk posed by oral secretions from\nindividuals with a typical course of Zika virus infection is low. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall It is good to learn that Zika virus transmission via mucosa is\nunlikely. It will be interesting to know if virus shedding in saliva\nis a common occurrence in infected humans. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> CDC guidance for pregnancy.\nDate: Mon 24 Jul 2017.\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2017; 66(29): 781-93(edited)\n(https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6629e1.htm) \nref: Oduyebo T, Polen KD, Walke HT, et al. Update: Interim guidance\nfor health care providers caring for pregnant women with possible Zika\nvirus exposure  United States (including US Territories), July 2017.\nMMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2017; 66(29): 781-93. doi:\n10.15585/mmwr.mm6629e1\n-\nCDC has updated the interim guidance for US health care providers\ncaring for pregnant women with possible Zika virus exposure in\nresponse to 1) declining prevalence of Zika virus disease in the World\nHealth Organization's Region of the Americas (Americas) and 2)\nemerging evidence indicating prolonged detection of Zika virus\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies. Zika virus cases were 1st reported\nin the Americas during 2015-2016; however, the incidence of Zika virus\ndisease has since declined. As the prevalence of Zika virus disease\ndeclines, the likelihood of false-positive test results increases. In\naddition, emerging epidemiologic and laboratory data indicate that, as\nis the case with other flaviviruses, Zika virus IgM antibodies can\npersist beyond 12 weeks after infection. Therefore, IgM test results\ncannot always reliably distinguish between an infection that occurred\nduring the current pregnancy and one that occurred before the current\npregnancy, particularly for women with possible Zika virus exposure\nbefore the current pregnancy. These limitations should be considered\nwhen counseling pregnant women about the risks and benefits of testing\nfor Zika virus infection during pregnancy. This updated guidance\nemphasizes a shared decision-making model for testing and screening\npregnant women, one in which patients and providers work together to\nmake decisions about testing and care plans based on patient\npreferences and values, clinical judgment, and a balanced assessment\nof risks and expected outcomes. For these recommendations, the definition of possible Zika virus\nexposure has not changed and includes travel to, or residence in an\narea with risk for mosquito-borne Zika virus transmission or sex with\na partner who has traveled to or resides in an area with risk for\nmosquito-borne Zika virus transmission. These areas can be found on\nthe CDC \"Zika Travel Information\" webpage. Key recommendations include the following:\n1- All pregnant women in the United States and US territories should\nbe asked about possible Zika virus exposure before and during the\ncurrent pregnancy, at every prenatal care visit. CDC recommends that\npregnant women not travel to any area with risk for Zika virus\ntransmission. It is also recommended that pregnant women with a sex\npartner who has traveled to or lives in an area with risk for Zika\nvirus transmission use condoms or abstain from sex for the duration of\nthe pregnancy.\n2- Pregnant women with recent possible Zika virus exposure and\nsymptoms of Zika virus disease should be tested to diagnose the cause\nof their symptoms. The updated recommendations include concurrent Zika\nvirus nucleic acid test (NAT) and serologic testing as soon as\npossible through 12 weeks after symptom onset.\n3- Asymptomatic pregnant women with ongoing possible Zika virus\nexposure should be offered Zika virus NAT testing 3 times during\npregnancy. IgM testing is no longer routinely recommended because IgM\ncan persist for months after infection; therefore, IgM results cannot\nreliably determine whether an infection occurred during the current\npregnancy. The optimal timing and frequency of testing of asymptomatic\npregnant women with NAT alone is unknown. For pregnant women who have\nreceived a diagnosis of laboratory-confirmed Zika virus infection (by\neither NAT or serology positive/equivocal Zika virus or dengue virus\nIgM and Zika virus plaque reduction neutralization test (PRNT) 10 and\nhigher and dengue virus PRNT less than 10 results) any time before or\nduring the current pregnancy, additional Zika virus testing is not\nrecommended. For pregnant women without a prior laboratory-confirmed\ndiagnosis of Zika virus, NAT testing should be offered at the\ninitiation of prenatal care, and if Zika virus RNA is not detected on\nclinical specimens, 2 additional tests should be offered during the\ncourse of the pregnancy coinciding with prenatal visits.\n4- Asymptomatic pregnant women who have recent possible Zika virus\nexposure (that is, through travel or sexual exposure) but without\nongoing possible exposure are not routinely recommended to have Zika\nvirus testing. Testing should be considered using a shared\npatient-provider decision-making model, one in which patients and\nproviders work together to make decisions about testing and care plans\nbased on patient preferences and values, clinical judgment, a balanced\nassessment of risks and expected outcomes, and the jurisdiction's\nrecommendations. Based on the epidemiology of Zika virus transmission\nand other epidemiologic considerations (such as, seasonality),\njurisdictions might recommend testing of asymptomatic pregnant women,\neither for clinical care or as part of Zika virus surveillance. With\nthe decline in the prevalence of Zika virus disease, the updated\nrecommendations for the evaluation and testing of pregnant women with\nrecent possible Zika virus exposure but without ongoing possible\nexposure are now the same for all areas with any risk for Zika virus\ntransmission.\n5- Pregnant women who have recent possible Zika virus exposure and who\nhave a fetus with prenatal ultrasound findings consistent with\ncongenital Zika virus syndrome should receive Zika virus testing to\nassist in establishing the etiology of the birth defects. Testing\nshould include both NAT and IgM tests.\n6- The comprehensive approach to testing placental and fetal tissues\nhas been updated. Testing placental and fetal tissue specimens can be\nperformed for diagnostic purposes in certain scenarios (e.g., women\nwithout a diagnosis of laboratory-confirmed Zika virus infection and\nwho have a fetus or infant with possible Zika virus-associated birth\ndefects). However, testing of placental tissues for Zika virus\ninfection is not routinely recommended for asymptomatic pregnant women\nwho have recent possible Zika virus exposure but without ongoing\npossible exposure and who have a live born infant without evidence of\npossible Zika virus-associated birth defects.\n7- Zika virus IgM testing as part of preconception counseling to\nestablish baseline IgM results for non pregnant women with ongoing\npossible Zika virus exposure is not warranted because Zika virus IgM\ntesting is no longer routinely recommended for asymptomatic pregnant\nwomen with ongoing possible Zika virus exposure. also at the source URL above:\nAdditional interim guidance:\n- Laboratory testing of pregnant women with exposure to areas with\nrisk for Zika virus transmission\n- Prenatal management of pregnant women with laboratory evidence of\npossible Zika virus infection\n- Evaluation of placental and fetal tissue specimens for Zika virus\ninfection \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be)(promed@promedmail.org) Readers interested in accessing the full report can find it at the\nsource URL above. Interestingly, a malaria drug has been shown to\ninhibit autophagy which limits vertical transmission of Zika virus in\npregnant mice. (http://dx.doi.org/10.1084/jem.20170957). Roland\nHübner is thanked for sending in this report. - Mod. TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Neurologic complications in adults.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: JAMA Neurology (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamaneurology/fullarticle/2647256) \nref: da Silva IRF, Frontera JA, Bispo de Filippis AM, et al.\nNeurologic complications associated with the Zika virus in Brazilian\nadults. JAMA Neurol. 2017. doi: 10.1001/jamaneurol.2017.1703. Epub\nahead of print\n-\nKey points\n-\nQuestion. What is the spectrum of neurologic manifestations in adults\nwith Zika virus infection?\nFindings. This cohort study evaluated adult patients with new-onset\nparainfectious or neuroinflammatory disease for the presence of acute\nZika virus infection in both serum and cerebrospinal fluid samples\nusing molecular and serological testing. An increase in the incidence\nof Guillain-Barré syndrome and encephalitis was observed compared\nwith the period before the outbreak of the Zika virus.\nMeaning The Zika virus may be associated with a rapid increase in the\nincidence of life-threatening neurologic syndromes; serologic and\nmolecular testing using blood and cerebrospinal fluid samples can\nserve as an alternative diagnostic strategy. Abstract\n\nImportance. There are no prospective cohort studies assessing the\nincidence and spectrum of neurologic manifestations secondary to Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) infection in adults.\nObjective. To evaluate the rates of acute ZIKV infection among\npatients hospitalized with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS),\nmeningoencephalitis, or transverse myelitis.\nDesign, setting, and participants. A prospective, observational cohort\nstudy was conducted at a tertiary referral center for neurological\ndiseases in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, between 5 Dec 2015-10 May 2016,\namong consecutive hospitalized adults (older than 18 years of age)\nwith new-onset acute parainfectious or neuroinflammatory disease. All\nparticipants were tested for a series of arbovirosis. 3-month\nfunctional outcome was assessed.\nInterventions. Samples of serum and cerebrospinal fluid were tested\nfor ZIKV using real-time reverse-transcriptase-polymerase chain\nreaction and an IgM antibody-capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent\nassay. Clinical, radiographic (magnetic resonance imaging),\nelectrophysiological, and 3-month functional outcome data were\ncollected.\nMain outcomes and measures. The detection of neurologic complications\nsecondary to ZIKV infection.\nResults. 40 patients (15 women and 25 men; median age, 44 years\nrange, 22-72 years) were enrolled, including 29 patients (73\npercent) with GBS (90 percent Brighton level 1 certainty), 7 (18\npercent) with encephalitis, 3 (8 percent) with transverse myelitis,\nand 1 (3 percent) with newly diagnosed chronic inflammatory\ndemyelinating polyneuropathy. Of these, 35 patients (88 percent) had\nmolecular and/or serologic evidence of recent ZIKV infection in the\nserum and/or cerebrospinal fluid. Of the patients positive for ZIKV\ninfection, 27 had GBS (18 demyelinating, 8 axonal, and 1 Miller Fisher\nsyndrome), 5 had encephalitis (3 with concomitant acute neuromuscular\ndisease), 2 had transverse myelitis, and 1 had chronic inflammatory\ndemyelinating polyneuropathy. Admission to the intensive care unit was\nrequired for 9 patients positive for ZIKV infection (26 percent), and\n5 (14 percent) required mechanical ventilation. Compared with\nadmission during the period from 5 Dec 2013 - 10 May 2014 (before the\nBrazilian outbreak of ZIKV), admissions for GBS increased from a mean\nof 1.0 per month to 5.6 per month, admissions for encephalitis\nincreased from 0.4 per month to 1.4 per month, and admissions for\ntransverse myelitis remained constant at 0.6 per month. At 3 months, 2\npatients positive for ZIKV infection (6 percent) died (1 with GBS and\n1 with encephalitis), 18 (51 percent) had chronic pain, and the median\nmodified Rankin score among survivors was 2 (range, 0-5).\nConclusions and relevance. In this single-center Brazilian cohort,\nZIKV infection was associated with an increase in the incidence of a\ndiverse spectrum of serious neurologic syndromes. The data also\nsuggest that serologic and molecular testing using blood and\ncerebrospinal fluid samples can serve as a less expensive, alternative\ndiagnostic strategy in developing countries, where plaque reduction\nneutralization testing is impractical. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) This study illustrates the need to consider post-Zika virus infection\nas a cause of a variety of neurological diseases. Further neurological\nfollow up of adults convalescent from acute Zika virus infection would\nbe of interest. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Persistence in brain cells.\nDate: Tue 11 Jul 2017.\nSource: mBio (edited)\n(http://mbio.asm.org/content/8/4/e00952-17.long) \nMladinich MC, Schwedes J, Mackow ER. Zika virus persistently infects\nand is basolaterally released from primary human brain microvascular\nendothelial cells. MBio. 2017; 8(4). pii: e00952-17. doi:\n10.1128/mBio.00952-17\n-\nZIKV persists in patients, crossing placental and neuronal barriers,\ndamaging neurons, and causing fetal microencephaly. We found that ZIKV\npersistently infects brain endothelial cells that normally protect\nneurons from viral exposure. hBMECs are not damaged by ZIKV infection\nand, analogous to persistent HCV infection, ZIKV constitutively\ninduces and evades antiviral ISG IFN-stimulated genes and IFN\ninterferon responses to continuously replicate in hBMECs. As a\nresult, hBMECs provide a protective niche for systemic ZIKV spread and\na viral reservoir localized in the normally protective blood-brain\nbarrier. Consistent with the spread of ZIKV into neuronal\ncompartments, ZIKV was released basolaterally from hBMECs. Our\nfindings define hBMEC responses that contribute to persistent ZIKV\ninfection and potential targets for clearing ZIKV infections from\nhBMECs. These results further suggest roles for additional\nZIKV-infected ECs to facilitate viral spread and persistence in the\nprotected placental, retinal, and testicular compartments. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Prior flavivirus infection and Zika virus infection.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Pathogens (edited)\n(http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1006487) \nMcCracken MK, Gromowski GD, Friberg HL, et al. Impact of prior\nflavivirus immunity on Zika virus infection in rhesus macaques. PLoS\nPathog. 2017; 13(8): e1006487. doi: 10.1371/journal.ppat.1006487\n-\nAbstract\n\nStudies have demonstrated cross-reactivity of anti-dengue virus (DENV)\nantibodies in human sera against Zika virus (ZIKV), promoting\nincreased ZIKV infection in vitro. However, the correlation between in\nvitro and in vivo findings is not well characterized. Thus, we\nevaluated the impact of heterotypic flavivirus immunity on ZIKV titers\nin biofluids of rhesus macaques. Animals previously infected (420 days\nor longer) with DENV2, DENV4, or yellow fever virus were compared to\nflavivirus-naïve animals following infection with a Brazilian ZIKV\nstrain. Sera from DENV-immune macaques demonstrated cross-reactivity\nwith ZIKV by antibody-binding and neutralization assays prior to ZIKV\ninfection, and promoted increased ZIKV infection in cell culture\nassays. Despite these findings, no significant differences between\nflavivirus-naïve and immune animals were observed in viral titers,\nneutralizing antibody levels, or immune cell kinetics following ZIKV\ninfection. These results indicate that prior infection with\nheterologous flaviviruses neither conferred protection nor increased\nobserved ZIKV titers in this non-human primate ZIKV infection model. Author summary\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne, emerging flavivirus. In\naddition to asymptomatic or mild febrile manifestations, ZIKV\ninfection in humans is associated with comparatively rare congenital\nand neurological abnormalities. Previous in vitro studies have\ndemonstrated cross-reactivity of antibodies derived from dengue virus\ninfections with ZIKV, as well as antibody-mediated enhancement of\ninfection in cell culture. Therefore, there is concern among\nvaccinologists and the public health community that the more severe\ndisease manifestations could result from prior immunity, either from\nnatural infection or vaccination, to antigenically-related\nflaviviruses (such as, dengue, yellow fever, Japanese encephalitis).\nIn this study, we evaluated the impact of prior immunity to dengue or\nyellow fever virus on ZIKV infection in a non-human primate model.\nAfter confirming that our immune cohorts were capable of\nrecapitulating the published in vitro observations of cross-reactivity\nand enhancement, we looked for alteration of viral titers in\nperipheral blood, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, saliva, and vaginal\nsecretions, as well as alterations in gross pathology, clinical\nparameters, and immune response, as compared to our flavivirus-naïve\ncohort. Importantly, no significant differences between\nflavivirus-naïve and primed animals were observed in viral titers or\nbiofluid distribution, neutralizing antibody levels, or immune cell\nkinetics following ZIKV infection. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be)(promed@promedmail.org) Previous dengue infection, whether acquired naturally or antibody\nelicited by vaccines, has been a concern due to the possibility of\nantibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) with more severe disease. This\nconcern also relates to Zika virus antibody from vaccination for\nenhancement of dengue virus infections with resulting more severe\ndisease. The monkey studies reported above indicated that this may not\nbe a problem for Zika virus vaccinated individuals. Another effort to\navoid ADE is development of a vaccine that has epitopes specific for\nZika virus that are not shared by other flaviviruses. A group of\nresearchers developed a recombinant vaccine targeting a viral envelope\nsub-unit specific to the Zika virus\n((http://www.pharmaceutical-journal.com/news-and-analysis/news-in-brief/researchers-find-way-to-overcome-zika-vaccinedengue-virus-conundrum/20203379.article)).\nRoland Hübner is thanked for calling this latter reference to our\nattention. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Virus inhibition.\nDate: 25 Jul 2017.\nSource: Nature Communications (edited)\n(https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms15672) \nref: Yu Y, Deng YQ, Zou P, et al. A peptide-based viral inactivator\ninhibits Zika virus infection in pregnant mice and fetuses. Nat\nCommun. 2017; 8: 15672. doi: 10.1038/ncomms15672\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV), a re-emerging flavivirus associated with\nneurological disorders, has spread rapidly to more than 70 countries\nand territories. However, no specific vaccines or antiviral drugs are\ncurrently available to prevent or treat ZIKV infection. Here we report\nthat a synthetic peptide derived from the stem region of ZIKV envelope\nprotein, designated Z2, potently inhibits infection of ZIKV and other\nflaviviruses in vitro. We show that Z2 interacts with ZIKV surface\nprotein and disrupts the integrity of the viral membrane. Z2 can\npenetrate the placental barrier to enter fetal tissues and is safe for\nuse in pregnant mice. Intraperitoneal administration of Z2 inhibits\nvertical transmission of ZIKV in pregnant C57BL/6 mice and protects\ntype I or type I/II interferon receptor-deficient mice against lethal\nZIKV challenge. Thus, Z2 has potential to be further developed as an\nantiviral treatment against ZIKV infection in high-risk populations,\nparticularly pregnant women. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall It will be interesting to see if the same protective effect occurs\nwhen tested with Zika virus infections of non-human primates. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{9}</strong> Female reproductive tract infection.\nDate: Wed 26 Jul 2017.\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Pathogens (edited)\n(http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1006537) \nCarroll T, Lo M, Lanteri M, et al. Zika virus preferentially\nreplicates in the female reproductive tract after vaginal inoculation\nof rhesus macaques. PLoS Pathog. 2017; 13(7): e1006537. doi:\n10.1371/journal.ppat.1006537\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-transmitted virus that can cause\nsevere defects in an infected fetus. ZIKV is also transmitted by\nsexual contact, although the relative importance of sexual\ntransmission is unclear. To better understand the role of sexual\ntransmission in ZIKV pathogenesis, a nonhuman primate (NHP) model of\nvaginal transmission was developed. ZIKV was readily transmitted to\nmature cycling female rhesus macaque (RM) by vaginal inoculation was\nreadily transmitted to mature cycling female rhesus macaque (RM) by\nvaginal individual RM with 1-5 vaginal inoculations required to\nestablish infection. After treatment with Depoprovera, a widely used\ncontraceptive progestin, 2 RM that initially resisted 8 vaginal ZIKV\ninoculations became infected after one ZIKV inoculation. Thus,\nDepoprovera seemed to enhance susceptibility to vaginal ZIKV\ntransmission. Unexpectedly, the kinetics of virus replication and\ndissemination after intravaginal ZIKV inoculation were markedly\ndifferent from RM infected with ZIKV by subcutaneous (SQ) virus\ninoculation. Several groups have reported that after SQ ZIKV\ninoculation vRNA is rapidly detected in blood plasma with vRNA less\ncommon in urine and saliva and only rarely detected in female\nreproductive tract (FRT) secretions. In contrast, in vaginally\ninoculated RM, plasma vRNA is delayed for several days and ZIKV\nreplication in, and vRNA shedding from, the FRT was found in all 6\nanimals. Further, after intravaginal transmission ZIKV RNA shedding\nfrom FRT secretions was detected before or simultaneously with plasma\nvRNA, and persisted for at least as long. Thus, ZIKV replication in\nthe FRT was independent of, and often preceded virus replication in\nthe tissues contributing to plasma vRNA. These results support the\nconclusion that ZIKV preferentially replicates in the FRT after\nvaginal transmission, but not after SQ transmission, and raise the\npossibility that there is enhanced fetal infection and pathology after\nvaginal ZIKV transmission compared to a mosquito transmitted ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{10}</strong> _Aedes albopictus_ populations as vectors.\nDate: 2 Aug 2017.\nSource: American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (edited)\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0969) \nref: Azar SR, Roundy CM, Rossi SL, et al. Differential vector\ncompetency of _Aedes albopictus_ populations from the Americas for\nZika virus. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2017; 97(2): 330-9;\ndoi.org/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0969\n-\nAbstract\n\nTo evaluate the potential role of _Aedes albopictus_ (Skuse) as a\nvector of Zika virus (ZIKV), colonized mosquitoes of low generation\nnumber (less than or F5) from Brazil, Houston, and the Rio Grande\nValley of Texas engorged on viremic mice infected with ZIKV strains\noriginating from Senegal, Cambodia, Mexico, Brazil, or Puerto Rico.\nVector competence was established by monitoring infection,\ndissemination, and transmission potential after 3, 7, and 14 days of\nextrinsic incubation. Positive saliva samples were assayed for\ninfectious titer. Although all 3 mosquito populations were susceptible\nto all ZIKV strains, rates of infection, dissemination, and\ntransmission differed among mosquito and virus strains. _Aedes\nalbopictus_ from Salvador, Brazil, were the least efficient vectors,\ndemonstrating susceptibility to infection to 2 American strains of\nZIKV but failing to shed virus in saliva. Mosquitoes from the Rio\nGrande Valley were the most efficient vectors and were capable of\nshedding all 3 tested ZIKV strains into saliva after 14 days of\nextrinsic incubation. In particular, ZIKV strain DakAR 41525 (Senegal\n1954) was significantly more efficient at dissemination and saliva\ndeposition than the others tested in Rio Grande mosquitoes. Overall,\nour data indicate that, while _Ae. albopictus_ is capable of\ntransmitting ZIKV, its competence is potentially dependent on\ngeographic origin of both the mosquito population and the viral\nstrain. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) This study illustrates that fact that not all Zika virus strains and\n_Ae. albopictus_ populations are created equal in terms of efficiency\nof transmission of this virus. Although some populations of this\nmosquito are able to efficiently transmits some Zika viruses, the fact\nthat _Ae. albopictus _ are not strictly human biters, further reduces\ntheir role as transmitters of this virus to people. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{11}</strong> _Culex quinquefasciatus_ as vectors.\nDate: Wed 9 Aug 2017.\nSource: Emerging Microbes & Infections (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/emi/journal/v6/n8/full/emi201759a.html?foxtrotcallback=true) \nref: Guedes DR, Paiva MH, Donato MM, et al. Zika virus replication in\nthe mosquito _Culex quinquefasciatus_ in Brazil. Emerg Microbes\nInfect. 2017; 6(8): e69. doi: 10.1038/emi.2017.59\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a flavivirus that has recently been associated\nwith an increased incidence of neonatal microcephaly and other\nneurological disorders. The virus is primarily transmitted by mosquito\nbite, although other routes of infection have been implicated in some\ncases. The _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito is considered to be the main\nvector to humans worldwide; however, there is evidence that other\nmosquito species, including _Culex quinquefasciatus_, transmit the\nvirus. To test the potential of _Cx. quinquefasciatus_ to transmit\nZIKV, we experimentally compared the vector competence of\nlaboratory-reared _Ae. aegypti_ and _Cx. quinquefasciatus_.\nInterestingly, we were able to detect the presence of ZIKV in the\nmidgut, salivary glands and saliva of artificially fed _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_. In addition, we collected ZIKV-infected _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_ from urban areas with high microcephaly incidence in\nRecife, Brazil. Corroborating our experimental data from artificially\nfed mosquitoes, ZIKV was isolated from field-caught _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_, and its genome was partially sequenced.\nCollectively, these findings indicate that there may be a wider range\nof ZIKV vectors than anticipated. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be) Finding a virus in field-collected mosquitoes in areas of active\nvirus transmission is highly suggestive, but not conclusive, of their\nability to transmit that virus. The study above goes the next step\ntoward proving vector capability by infecting _Culex quinquefasciatus_\nfed with Zika virus and subsequently demonstrating the virus in\nsaliva, implicating their ability to transmit it. The role of _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_ in Zika virus transmission is currently confusing.\nThe study above and one done in China indicate that this species is a\ncompetent vector. Several other studies have shown this species to be\ninefficient vectors or refractory to Zika virus infection. One wonders\nif the specific _Cx. quinquefasciatus_ used or the Zika virus isolates\nwith which they were tested could account for these very different\nresults. Resolving these discrepancies is important because this\nmosquito species is very widely distributed around the world and bears\ndirectly on risk of outbreaks in geographic areas where _Aedes\naegypti_ or _Ae. albopictus_ , Zika virus vectors, do not occur. -\nMod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"49":{"title":"Chlorine gas - India: (UT) waterworks, RFI ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Chlorine gas - India: (UT) waterworks, RFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017. Source: India Times (edited) (http://www.indiatimes.com/news/india/17-people-fall-ill-after-chlorine-gas-leakage-in-dehradun-328089.html)   In the early hours of Fri 18 Aug 2017, 17 people, including 5 children, were taken ill after chlorine gas leakage from a cylinder at a waterworks unit of Uttarakhand Jal Sansthan in Dehradun.  Police rushed to the spot immediately and threw the leaking cylinder into the water to neutralise it, SP (City) Pradeep Kumar Rai, told PTI.  People living in the waterworks area including children, mostly sleeping at that hour, were rushed to different hospitals in the city after they complained of difficulty in breathing and some of them especially children even fainted, the SP (city) said.  Altogether 17 people were hospitalized: 8 were admitted in Mahanth Indresh hospital, 5 in Max Hospital, and 4 in CMI hospital, the SP said.  However, all of them are out of danger with a majority already discharged from hospitals, he said.  The Managing Director of Jan Sansthan said an inquiry is being conducted into the gas leak at the waterworks.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  I am not quite sure how children got exposed from a leaking canister at a waterworks unit, especially since this was in the early hours of the morning. Where the homes near there? Perhaps above the waterworks unit? How big was the cylinder to cause this kind of problem? These are likely rhetorical questions but answers would provide insight into what really happened.  Maps of India can be seen at (http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1475).  Chlorine gas is a pulmonary irritant with intermediate water solubility that causes acute damage in the upper and lower respiratory tract.  Exposure to low concentrations of chlorine for prolonged periods may have destructive effects, as might very short-term exposure to high concentrations.  Long-term complications may occur after breathing in high concentrations of chlorine. Complications are more likely to be seen in people who develop severe health problems such as fluid in the lungs (pulmonary edema) following the initial exposure.  How chlorine works - The extent of poisoning caused by chlorine depends on the amount of chlorine a person is exposed to, how the person was exposed, and the length of time of the exposure. - When chlorine gas comes into contact with moist tissues such as the eyes, throat, and lungs, an acid is produced that can damage these tissues.  Immediate signs and symptoms of chlorine exposure During or immediately after exposure to dangerous concentrations of chlorine, the following signs and symptoms may develop: - blurred vision; - burning pain, redness, and blisters on the skin if exposed to gas. Skin injuries similar to frostbite can occur if it is exposed to liquid chlorine; - burning sensation in the nose, throat, and eyes; - coughing; - chest tightness; - difficulty breathing or shortness of breath. These may appear immediately if high concentrations of chlorine gas are inhaled, or they may be delayed if low concentrations of chlorine gas are inhaled; - fluid in the lungs (pulmonary edema) that may be delayed for a few hours; - nausea and vomiting; - watery eyes; - wheezing  Long-term health effects Long-term complications may occur after breathing in high concentrations of chlorine. Complications are more likely to be seen in people who develop severe health problems such as fluid in the lungs (pulmonary edema) following the initial exposure.  Portions of this comment have been extracted from (http://emergency.cdc.gov/agent/chlorine/basics/facts.asp). - Mod.TG  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"53":{"title":"Japanese encephalitis and other - India (16): (OR)\r\n\t","date":["19","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis and other - India (16): (OR)\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Sat 19 Aug 2017, 2:24 AM. Source: The New Indian Express, Press Trust of India (PTI) (edited) (http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/aug/19/odisha-government-blames-consumption-of-cassia-seeds-for-encephalitis-outbreak-1645232.html)   Monsoon fevers are de rigueur in Odisha. While swine flu and dengue are spreading in the urban areas, the tribal hinterland has been beset with outbreaks of encephalitis since 2012. Though no Japanese encephalitis (JE) mortalities have been registered as yet in the official records, 473 acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) cases have been diagnosed so far. Odisha stands 5th in AES mortality after Uttar Pradesh, Assam, West Bengal and Bihar.  According to the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme, AES had taken 13 lives by the 1st week of August 2017. Apart from AES, 8 persons have fallen victim to swine flu in Odisha in the last 2 weeks. More than 100 positive cases have been detected. Dengue is the other scourge in the state with 2 deaths and 367 positive cases.  Both AES and JE have been regular in Odisha since 2012. Last year, the state grabbed the national headlines when 115 children died of AES and 42 fell to JE. Most of the deaths were reported from Malkangiri district.  But the state government has been equivocating on the incidence of AES. It went to the extent of claiming that consumption of seeds of a plant called _Cassia occidentalis_, locally known as Bada Chakunda, caused death of a 3rd of the children who fell to encephalitis in Malkangiri district.  An expert committee suggested that JE could not be blamed for all the deaths because \"encephalopathy\" was the culprit. Encephalopathy, it said, is a non-infectious biochemical syndrome that can be aggravated by the consumption of _Cassia_ seeds. The fact is the Naveen Patnaik government remained aloof to the spread of AES, which is caused by a vector-borne virus hosted by pigs.  The Regional Medical Research Centre (RMRC), Bhubaneswar, carried out a study on the outbreak of AES in Malkangiri in 2015 but its findings were not paid heed to. From 38 deaths in 2012 to 115 in 2016, the AES surge was waiting to happen.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  As of the end of May 2017, there were 313 cases of AES with 10 deaths in Odisha and now the case count is 473 with 13 deaths in the 1st week of August 2017. Odisha state is endemic for Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, and cases occur there frequently. As with cases of encephalitis mentioned above and in other states in northeastern India, not all encephalitis cases are due to JE virus and are classified as acute encephalitis syndrome (AES) with undetermined etiology.  As noted in previous ProMED-mail comments, AES is a term used for multiple etiologies or often when no etiology has been determined. The encephalitis picture in northeastern India is complicated. Although JE virus etiology of some previously reported encephalitis cases has been confirmed by laboratory tests, many cases go undiagnosed, or JE virus infection is ruled out, and other etiologies, including Reye syndrome-like disease, possible enterovirus infection from polluted water, heat stroke, scrub typhus (_O. tsutsugamushi_) and lychee fruit consumption, have been proposed.  \nHowever, in November 2016 the Odisha state government formed the 6-member panel, led by eminent virologist Dr Jacob John from Vellore's Christian Medical College. In the interim report, Dr John said that anthraquinone, a toxin found in the plant _Cassia occidentalis_, was found in the urine sample of 5 deceased children. \"This indicates that the children (had) consumed the seeds of the plant,\" he said. Getting to an accurate diagnosis in these cases of AES will require active field surveillance with epidemiological studies supported by timely laboratory testing.  Maps of India can be accessed at (http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and for Odisha state at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/315). - Mod.TY  _Cassia occidentalis_, also called _Senna occidentalis_, produces seeds, in long seed pods that are sometimes roasted and made into a coffee-like beverage, Its roots, leaves, flowers, and seeds have been used medicinally as, for example, a laxative (attributed to the actions of anthraquinones found in the plant), an antipyretic, a tonic , and a diuretic ((http://www.rain-tree.com/fedegosa.htm#.WZoIOsaZPjA)). - Mod.ML  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"72":{"title":"Chikungunya (27) - Americas, Europe, Asia ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Chikungunya (27) - Americas, Europe, Asia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHIKUNGUNYA (27) - AMERICAS, EUROPE, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n\nAmericas\n\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO report Mexico and Central America\n\nMexico (Jalisco state)\nCosta Rica South America\n\nArgentina (Salto province)\nBrazil:\n- Roraima state\n- Ceara state\nPeru (Piura region) Europe\n\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region in Provence) Asia\n\nTaiwan (Tainan)\nIndia:\n- Delhi\n- Ludhiana, Punjab\n- Chandigarh, Haryana and Punjab states\n- Tamil Nadu state\n- Baramati tehsil, Pune, Maharastra state\n- Pune Maharashtra state ex Assam state\n- Kerala state\nBangladesh (Dhaka)\nNepal (Bhaktapur, province 3) \nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n\nAmericas\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n18 Aug 2017\n(http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8975&Itemid=40931&lang=en) \nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or\nterritory - 2017 to EW 33 week ending 18 Aug 2017. (conf) 30\ncases.\n(http://punemirror.indiatimes.com/pune/others/30-chikungunya-cases-in-baramati-put-health-officials-on-the-alert/articleshow/59935032.cms) - Pune Maharashtra state ex Assam state. 4 Aug 2017. (reported) severe\ncase. A 69 year old from Assam was diagnosed with chikungunya around a\nweek ago. The disease had affected almost all his vital organs \nheart, brain, liver and kidney. The patient had blisters across his\nbody and swelling on his joints. He was diagnosed positive for\nchikungunya last Thu 3 Aug 2017.\n(http://punemirror.indiatimes.com/pune/civic/rare-chikungunya-strain-affects-multiple-organs/articleshow/59906724.cms) Cases of severe, multi-organ disease from chikungunya virus infection\nare rare. Although the above report indicates that there was a\npositive diagnosis for chikungunya virus infection, it does not\nindicate if that diagnosis was based on laboratory results or was\nclinically based. In an unusual case such as this one, laboratory\nconfirmation is necessary for a conclusive diagnosis. - Mod.TY - Kerala state. 30 Jul 2017. (conf) 44 cases; district most affected:\nThiruvananthapuram 41 cases.\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/thiruvananthapuram/882191/capital-still-a-chikungunya-hotspot/) Bangladesh (Dhaka). 17 Jul 2017. (reported) 2748 cases. Almost every\nday in recent weeks, as with the Dhaka Medical College and Hospital,\nmany other government and private hospitals in the capital city have\nbeen swamped by hundreds of patients suffering from Chikungunya viral\ndisease.\n(http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-07/17/c_136450945.htm) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map showing the location of Bangladesh can be\naccessed at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/153). - Mod. TY Nepal (Bhaktapur, province 3). (conf) 5 cases, the most recent a 14\nyear old girl.\nThis report is provided by Dr Anup Bastola, MD, MCTM, consultant\ntropical medicine physician Sukraraj Tropical and Infectious Disease\nHospital, Kathmandu, Nepal, who ProMED-mail thanks for the submission.\n- Mod. TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be) The number of reported cases of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection\nin the Americas appears to have declined this year (2017). Given the\noutbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) infections in the region, and the\nclinical similarity of cases of that virus infection and CHIKV\ninfection, one wonders how many cases that were not laboratory\nconfirmed but clinically diagnosed as ZIKV infections were, in\nreality, CHIKV infections. It is also possible that a significant\nproportion of the population have been infected by CHIKV in the\nprevious 3 years and are now immune. It seems likely, however, that\nCHIKV is now endemic in the Americas, and sporadic, small outbreaks\nmay continue to occur as they do in Asia and Africa. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"75":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (88): Africa,\r\n\tAsia ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (88): Africa,\r\n\tAsia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (88): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Malawi (Southern region)\n2,3 Cholera - Sudan\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR (Kwilu, South Kivu)\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - India (Punjab)\n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Diarrhea - Nepal (Kapilvastu district) \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Malawi (Southern region).\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Capital Radio Malawi summ., edited\n(https://www.capitalradiomalawi.com/index.php/blog/local-news/local-news/item/8352-chikwawa-hit-by-cholera-outbreak) \nA total of 9 people are admitted to Chikwawa district Southern\nregion hospital following a cholera outbreak. This comes barely 4\nmonths after another outbreak hit the district's 2 villages in the\narea of Paramount Chief Lundu, affecting 38 people. The Environmental\nHealth Office for Chikwawa district has confirmed the development,\nciting poor access to safe water and poor quality of sanitary\nfacilities in villages. There are fears that the cholera outbreak may\nspread to other areas where communities do not have access to portable\nwater supply as well as toilets. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Malawi can be seen at\n(http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/malawi.pdf) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8665). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(http://allafrica.com/stories/201708220596.html) \nSouth Darfur\n\nIn 2 months, 42 people have died of cholera in Kalma camp for\ndisplaced people in South Darfur. 539 others have been infected. The\ndeaths occurred between 26 Jun and 20 Aug 2017, the coordinator of\nthe camp in Nyala, Yagoub Abdallah Furi, informed Radio Dabanga\nyesterday 21 Aug 2017. \"There are 3 medical isolation centres\nbelonging to 2 organizations from the USA that have been established\nin the camp since the cholera broke out in Nyala in June 2017.\" Currently there are 37 hospitalized cases at the camp's isolation\nwards. \"There is a large shortage of intravenous solutions. We hope\norganisations working in the medical field and the Ministry of Health\nto provide us with medicines.\" The epidemic reached Manawashi, north\nof Nyala city, at the beginning of August 2017. Central Darfur\n\nAt least 36 people have been infected with cholera in Central Darfur's\nNierteti in the past 11 days. 4 of them died, sources reported to\nRadio Dabanga. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian\nAffairs (OCHA) reported in its latest biweekly bulletin that\n\"humanitarian access and insecurity remain major challenges for the\nimplementation of key health and protection interventions\" in Central\nDarfur. \"Nierteti's hospital faces gaps in medicines, including oral and\nintravenous re-hydration solutions .,\" OCHA stated. \"In Zalingei\nhospital, there are several sanitation issues, including lack of\nlatrines and evidence of improper solid waste management..\" National epidemic\n\nThe National Epidemiological Corporation reported in early July 2017\nthat nearly 24 000 Sudanese have been infected and 940 cholera\npatients have died since the outbreak of the infectious disease in\nBlue Nile state in August 2016. The Sudanese authorities refuse to\ncall the disease by its name, however, and instead refer to it as\n\"acute watery diarrhea\". The National Intelligence and Security\nService has repeatedly warned medics and the press in the country not\nto make mention of cholera. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) *\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/fifteen-cholera-dead-in-west-darfur-camp) \nWest Darfur\n\n15 people have died of cholera while 18 others have been infected in\nMurnei, West Darfur, in the past 3 days. A sheikh in Murnei camp for\ndisplaced people told this station, \"18 people are now in the\nisolation ward in the camp.\" The 18 infected people came from Um Tajok\nvillage near Murnei on 9 Aug 2017. 6 people died of cholera at the\nvillage that day, a sheikh reported from the camp last week week of 7\nAug 2017. Blue Nile\n\nIn Blue Nile state, 3 brothers died in the hospital of Ed Damazin on\nTue 15 Aug 2017. A relative of the deceased told Radio Dabanga that\nthe 3 family members died of the same disease in the hospital, in El\nHijra district. Sennar\n\nMeanwhile in Sennar, 18 people contracted cholera in El Dindir\nlocality this week week of 14 Aug 2017. A medical source told this\nstation that on Thu 17 Aug 2017, El Dindir's hospital received 13\nnews cases of cholera, 8 of which were received earlier this week. 5\nothers arrived on Thu 17 Aug 2017. The medical isolation centre at\nBardana village, south of the city, also recorded 5 new cases of\ncholera. The hospital in Singa received 3 new cases of cholera on Thu 17 Aug\n2017. A medical source informed Radio Dabanga that the 3 patients had\ncome from Um Benin village, south east of Singa. \"16 people suffering\nfrom cholera are still in the isolation ward.\" Northern state\n\nThe 1st cases of cholera have been reported in the southern part of El\nMahas in Northern state, at Arduan health centre. The patients arrived\nfrom Maljab area on Thu 17 Aug 2017, while El Tura health centre of\nEl Mahas received another case. Nubian activist Adham Nasr told Radio Dabanga that the woman has been\nisolated in a room at Arduan health centre to receive treatment. There\nare concerns that the disease might break out in the area during the\nrainy season, which makes it difficult to move from and to Arduan. Red Sea\n-\nA health centre in Arayab area in Ganab, Red Sea state, received 5\nchildren suffering from cholera on Wed 16 Aug 2017. Journalist Osman\nHashim told Radio Dabanga that the one of them has been transferred to\nPort Sudan Hospital. The doctors were unable to give information about\nthe cases. The hospital's administration has not allocated a ward to\nisolate the cholera patients. Earlier in August 2017 a volunteer of one of the cholera awareness\nraising campaigns in Sudan told Radio Dabanga that the reality in the\nhospitals is very poor. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of the Republic of the Sudan can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR (Kwilu, South Kivu).\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Voice of America (VOA) News, Afrique, Agence France-Presse\n(AFP) report in French, machine trans., edited\n(https://www.voaafrique.com/a/seize-morts-du-cholera-en-une-semaine-dans-le-sud-ouest-de-la-rdc/3991609.html) \nA total of 16 people died of cholera in one week in a region in the\nsouth west of the Democratic Republic of the Congo DRC, where about\n100 cases have been recorded, it was learned Fri 18 Aug 2017 from\nthe provincial authorities. \"We have recorded 16 cases of deaths and about 100 people are infected\nwith cholera\" in 3 zones of the province of Kwilu, governor Nicholas\nBulukungu told reporters. \"The province does not have a center\nspecializing in the treatment of cholera. The isolation of the\npatients is a serious problem,\" he said. The town of Bandundu and the\n2 affected localities are inhabited by nearly a million people,\ninvited to \"strict observance of the basic rules of hygiene.\" Another Congolese province (South Kivu in the east) is facing an\noutbreak of cholera with 2 deaths and several tens of cases reported\nfor nearly 3 weeks. According to the UN, cholera has become a major public health problem\nin the DRC with thousands of cases recorded every year in many\nprovinces in this vast country without infrastructure and where most\nof the population lives in poverty. More than 700 deaths of cholera were recorded in 2016 in the DRC. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n(promed-fra@promedmail.org) Maps of the Democratic Republic of the Congo can be seen at\n(http://goo.gl/DM2AT8) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42129). -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - India (Punjab).\nDate: Sat 19 Aug 2017 03:09 PM IST.\nSource: Times of India (edited)\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ludhiana/cholera-outbreak-18-fresh-cases-reported-on-day-5/articleshow/60126504.cms) \n18 fresh cholera cases were reported at Guru Har Rai Nagar Ludhiana,\nPunjab on on day 5 of the outbreak. District epidemiologist Ramesh\nKumar said more than 500 people contracted the disease over the past\nfew days. Health officials are taking all possible measures to stem\nthe outbreak, including organizing medical camps to engender public\nawareness about the disease. Meanwhile, sources said the health department is still trying to hide\nthe exact number of cases reported in the camp. \"No water samples have\nbeen collected on the 5th day of the outbreak. All the 18 patients\nhave been admitted to private hospitals. Health officials are not\npaying attention to affected areas as a number of cases are being\nstill being reported.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1789). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Diarrhea - Nepal (Kapilvastu district).\nDate: Sun 20 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Himalayan Times (edited)\n(https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/child-loses-life-in-outbreak-of-diarrhoea-in-flood-hit-kapilvastu/) \nA child has reportedly succumbed to diarrhea in Sattbhara, of\nMaharajgunj Municipality-7 in Kapilvastu district Province Five on\nSun 20 Aug 2017. According to Jayasawal, more than 50 persons have\nbeen affected in the outbreak of diarrhoea in the municipality since\nThu 17 Aug 2017. He said the consumption of water and fish obtained\nfrom contaminated water sources could be the cause of the outbreak. The health workers deputed from the District Health Office (DHO) have\nbeen treating locals with preventive medicines while the critical ones\nhave been undergoing treatment in the Bahadurgunj Hospital in the\ndistrict. Meanwhile, the DHO has urged the general public to take\nprecautions and preventive measures as there is high risk of diarrhoea\nspreading in the flood-hit areas. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-SoAs\n(promed-SoAs@promedmail.org) Maps of Nepal can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/ydf8ojtj) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38712). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 per cent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are:\n- Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 per cent (95 per cent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam;\n- Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. WHO prequalified vaccines.\n(https://extranet.who.int/gavi/PQ_Web/).\n61. Balk YO, Choi SK, Olveda RM, et al. A randomized, non-inferiority\ntrial comparing two bivalent killed, whole cell, oral cholera vaccines\n(Euvichol vs Shanchol) in the Philippines. Vaccine 2015; 33(46):\n6350-65; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26348402).\n62. Freedman DO. Re-born in the USA: another cholera vaccine for\ntravellers. Travel Med Infect Dis. 2016; 14(4): 295-6; abstract\navailable at\n(http://www.travelmedicinejournal.com/article/S1477-8939(16)30087-4/abstract).\n63. Qadri F, Wierzba TF, Ali M, et al. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]},"77":{"title":"Typhoid fever - South Korea: (HN) ex India,\r\n\tstudent ","date":["21","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Typhoid fever - South Korea: (HN) ex India,\r\n\tstudent [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Korea Times (edited) (http://m.koreatimes.co.kr/phone/news/view.jsp?req_newsidx=235072)   5 Korean students who visited India have been stricken with typhoid fever. The students are from Sangmyung University's Cheonan Campus in South Chungcheong Province, according to the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Mon 21 Aug 2017. They had visited India's northern region, including the cities of Agra and New Delhi, with 18 other students and 2 instructors as part of the school's overseas education program from 19 to 27 Jul 2017.  After they returned, 7 sought medical attention for fever, chills, and diarrhea. 4 were diagnosed with typhoid. In a follow-up check, another student was diagnosed with the disease. 4 of the 5 students remain in a hospital. One student was released on Fri 18 Aug 2017.  Of 225 Koreans who caught typhoid fever abroad between 2011-2016, 23 per cent had visited India. The health authority has advised that people planning to visit India should be vaccinated against the waterborne disease, which is also infectious through food.  Health officials also said that people who experience fever, chills, and diarrhea within 60 days  the disease's maximum latency period  after returning from India must report to a hospital to be checked for the disease.  byline: Ko Dong-hwan   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Typhoid fever, so-called enteric fever caused by _Salmonella enterica_ serotype Typhi, often has a totally different presentation from that of the commoner kinds of salmonellosis. Epidemiologically, usually spread by contaminated food or water, typhoid is not a zoonosis like the commoner types of salmonellosis. Clinically, vomiting and diarrhea are typically absent; indeed, constipation is frequently reported. As it is a systemic illness, blood cultures are at least as likely to be positive as stool in enteric fever, particularly early in the course of the infection, and bone marrow cultures may be the most sensitive.  The symptoms of classical typhoid fever typically include fever, anorexia, lethargy, malaise, dull continuous headache, non-productive cough, vague abdominal pain, and constipation. Despite the often high fever, the pulse is often only slightly elevated. During the 2nd week of the illness, there is protracted fever and mental dullness, classically called coma vigil. Diarrhea may develop but usually does not. Many patients develop hepatosplenomegaly both liver and spleen enlarged. After the 1st week or so, many cases develop a maculopapular rash on the upper abdomen. These lesions (\"rose spots\") are about 2 cm 0.78 in in diameter and blanch on pressure. They persist for 2-4 days and may come and go. Mild and atypical infections are common.  The word typhoid (as in typhus-like) reflects the similarity of the louseborne rickettsial disease epidemic typhus and that of typhoid fever; in fact, in some areas, typhoid fever is still referred to as abdominal typhus.  Maps of South Korea can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/jvukf5u) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15392 ). South Chungcheong province, officially Chungcheongnam-do; abbreviated Chungnam), is a province in the west of South Korea. - Mod.LL  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"84":{"title":"Foot & mouth disease - Nepal: (CH) bovine, new, st A, gt VII,\r\n\tOIE ","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Foot & mouth disease - Nepal: (CH) bovine, new, st A, gt VII,\r\n\tOIE [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 23 Aug 2017. Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(34) (edited) (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24622)   Foot and mouth disease, Nepal  Information received on 23 Aug 2017 from Dr Bimal Kumar Nirmal, Department of Livestock Services, Ministry of Livestock Development, Nepal  Summary Report type: immediate notification (final report) Date of start of the event: 2 Apr 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 6 Apr 2017 Report date: 22 Aug 2017 Date event resolved: 3 May 2017 Reason for notification: new strain of a listed disease in the country Causal agent: foot and mouth disease virus (lineage G-VII) Serotype: A Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced) This event pertains to the whole country.  New outbreaks (1) Summary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1 Outbreak 1: Chitwan, Bharatpur 4, Chitwan, Narayani Province Three Date of start of the outbreak: 2 Apr 2017 Outbreak status: resolved on 3 May 2017 Epidemiological unit: village Total animals affected: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0 / 0 Buffaloes / 3 / 3 / 0 / 0 / 0 Affected population: cattle and buffaloes reared in semi commercial small holder farms of Bharatpur 4, Chitwan were affected.  Outbreak statistics rates apparent, expressed as percentages Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost* Cattle / 100 / 0 / 0 / 0 Buffaloes / 100 / 0 / 0 / 0 *Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter  Epidemiology Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive, Illegal movement of animals Epidemiological comments: 15 per cent of young (1-1.5 years old) and 85 per cent of adult (3-5 years old) cross breed cattle and buffaloes of 4 farms were affected with typical signs and symptoms of foot and mouth disease (FMD) such as high fever, drooling of saliva, champing of jaws, lameness, off feed, lesions on tongue. All the cattle and buffaloes in the village were affected; however there was no mortality observed even in the young ones. The animals have not been vaccinated against FMD since few years in these farms. There was a buffalo collection and selling center 100 meters close to the village. There was a collection of buffaloes from different neighboring districts and international bordering districts. Further investigation is ongoing.  Control measures Measures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, quarantine, disinfection, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals  Diagnostic test results Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result National foot-and-mouth disease and transboundary animal diseases Laboratory, Kathmandu (national laboratory) / Buffaloes / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 6 Apr 2017 / Positive National foot-and-mouth disease and transboundary animal diseases Laboratory, Kathmandu (national laboratory) / Cattle / PCR / 6 Apr 2017 / Positive National foot-and-mouth disease and transboundary animal diseases Laboratory, Kathmandu (national laboratory) / Cattle / serotyping / 6 Apr 2017 / Positive Pirbright Institute, United Kingdom (OIE reference laboratory) / Cattle / gene sequencing / 14 Aug 2017 / Positive Pirbright Institute, United Kingdom (OIE reference laboratory) / Cattle / serotyping / 14 Aug 2017 / Positive Measures to be applied: no other measures  Future reporting The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.  The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  According to the Nepal page on WRLFMD website, the last occurrence of FMD serotype A in Nepal took place in 1997. Since 2010, and as of March 2017, the FMDV strain circulating in Nepal has continuously been O/ME-SA/Ind-2001d (in 2015, there was also a single detection of O/ME-SA/PanAsia-2 KAT-15). For the said and additional information on Nepal's FMD past records, including genotyping results (though not yet of the newly introduced A/ASIA/G-VII lineage), see (http://www.wrlfmd.org/fmd_genotyping/asia/nep.htm).  The identification of the A/ASIA/G-VII lineage in Nepal represents further spread of this virus, which had been evolving in India many years back (\"A/IND/40/2000\", genotyped A/ASIA/G-VII, was collected in 1999). In 2010, this strain was detected in Myanmar. In 2015, it appeared for the 1st time in the Middle East (\"FMD Pool 3\"), being detected in Saudi Arabia followed, during the same year, by Iran, Turkey and Armenia. Most recently (May 2017), this virus was identified in Northern Israel, on the Lebanese and Syrian borders.  According to the information included in the Guest Editor's comments to EuFMD's (European Commission for the control of Foot-and-Mouth Disease) monthly report \"Global Foot-and-Mouth Disease Situation\", June 2017, there were reports of poor performance of vaccine strains derived from the A/ASIA/Iran-05 strain against the A/ASIA/G-VII lineage. The guest editor, Don King (head of the Vesicular Disease Reference Laboratory Group in the Pirbright Institute and WRLFMD), disclosed that WRLFMD, in partnership with the FMD Reference Laboratories in Lelystad (The Netherlands) and Geelong (Australia), has undertaken vaccine potency trials for alternative candidate vaccines; preliminary data indicated that the A-May-97 vaccine may provide protection in cattle, in contrast to the A22 vaccine, which does not appear to induce a protective response. The said data were to \"be presented in more detail shortly\". The said and additional information is available at (http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/user_upload/eufmd/docs/FMD_monthly_reports/2017/June2017.pdf).  The Indian subcontinent (\"FMD Pool 2\") is the source of 2 FMD strains which have demonstrated, in recent years, a long-distance (trans-regional) transmission, causing losses in \"FMD Pool 3\" countries and threatening Europe. These are FMDV serotype O, topotype ME-SA, strain Ind-2001d and FMDV serotype A, topotype Asia, genotype (strain) VII. While the routes of dissemination are yet to be clarified, the FMD situation within India, a major beef exporter, including its vaccination policy and vaccines efficacy, deserves being visited. - Mod.AS  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/19830).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"107":{"title":"Glanders, equine - India (04): (UP) ","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Glanders, equine - India (04): (UP) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017, 8:53 IST. Source: The Times of India (TOI), Times News Network (TNN) summarised, edited \n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/meerut/alert-in-bijnor-after-two-horses-die-of-glander-persian-disease/articleshow/60224902.cms)   The animal husbandry department here Bijnor has sounded an alert after 2 horses in Bijnor's Najibabad succumbed to the deadly glanders disease, while 4 other equines are suspected to be suffering from the disease. As a precautionary measure, as many as 100 blood samples of horses have been taken so far and sent for testing.  The infectious disease is caused by a bacterium which spreads from animal to animal. Humans who come in contact with the affected animals can also contract this disease. There are 6000 horses and other equines in the district. The detection of the disease has spread panic among owners.  Giving details, deputy chief veterinary officer Yogendra Panwar said, \"In 2011, some 5 horses were diagnosed with this disease in Chandpur area of Bijnor district. They were put to sleep to save other equines. Since then, our department has been running a drive in this regard to make horse owners aware about this disease. We have been taking blood samples of horses repeatedly in the district. Last month July 2017, 2 horses were diagnosed with Glanders in Najibabad area. Both horses had to be killed by a team of veterinary doctors..\"  The veterinary officer explained since there is no known treatment or vaccine for Glanders, an animal that tests positive is put to sleep to prevent the disease from spreading. It is a fatal disease. Government compensates the equine owner after killing a sick animal. The compensation for horses and mules range from Rs 16 000 to Rs 25 000 USD 250.00 to 390.00 he added.  byline: Harveer Dabas   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  India and Brazil are known to lead the list of countries where glanders, a zoonotic, OIE-listed equids disease, is endemic. Media reports on cases of the traditionally fearsome glanders, are often published by the Indian press. This is not fully reflected in India's official reports to the OIE. According to the recent ones, the annual numbers of recorded glanders outbreaks (in equidae) countrywide were as follows: 2010 - 1; 2011 - 3; 2012 - 1; 2013 - 1; 2014 - 0; 2015 - 5. During the 1st semester of 2016, 9 outbreaks were reported, involving 45 cases of which 36 died. India's OIE semi-annual report for the period Jul-Dec 2016 is not yet available.  No statistics on the incidence of glanders in humans in India could be obtained.  Glanders is a contagious and fatal disease of horses, donkeys, and mules, caused by infection with the bacterium _Burkholderia mallei_. The pathogen causes nodules and ulcerations in the upper respiratory tract and lungs. A skin form also occurs, known as 'farcy'. Control of glanders requires testing of suspect clinical cases, screening of apparently normal equids, and elimination of reactors. _B. mallei_ can be transmitted to humans, but such cases, which were known to be often fatal, have become rather uncommon (see ref 1). In view of its zoonotic potential, all infected or contaminated (or potentially infected or contaminated) material must be handled in a laboratory with appropriate biosafety and biosecurity controls following a biorisk analysis.  The above and additional information on glanders, its causative agent and its diagnosis is available at (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.05.11_GLANDERS.pdf). A useful updated review on the disease, including its recent global distribution, is available in ref 1.  No vaccine against this disease is available.  Reference Elschner MC, Neubauer H and Sprague LD. The resurrection of glanders in a new epidemiological scenario: a beneficiary of \"global change\". Current Clinical Microbiology Reports 2017(March); 4(1): 54-60. Abstract available at (https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s40588-017-0058-6). - Mod.AS  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/322). All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot.
