The index case had just returned from visiting family in the Ukraine\nwhere he likely contracted the disease. When he returned to Israel he\nvisited a clinic where he infected 8 other soldiers who were waiting\nin line to see a physician. \"The IDF, together with the Health\nMinistry, carried out an investigation to locate the cases and\nidentify the source of the infection,\" the army said in a statement,\nadding that all those who had contact with the soldiers had been\ngiven preventative treatment. An IDF spokesman told The Jerusalem Post\nthat the soldier who contracted the disease had 2 stopovers in Europe\non his way back to Israel from the Ukraine but was not able to specify\nwhich countries. WHO in March 2017 warned of a measles outbreak sweeping across\nEurope in places where immunization rates have plummeted. The figures\ncover the agency's entire European region  53 countries including\nIsrael, Kazakhstan, and Russia. According to WHO 559 measles cases\nwere reported in Europe between January and March 2017. While the\nlargest current measles outbreaks in Europe were reported in Romania\nand Italy, other countries reporting cases were France, Germany,\nPoland, Switzerland, and the Ukraine. \"With steady progress toward\nelimination over the past 2 years, it is of particular concern that\nmeasles cases are climbing in Europe,\" said Dr Zsuzsanna Jakab, WHO\nregional director for Europe. \"Today's travel patterns put no person\nor country beyond the reach of the measles virus. Outbreaks will\ncontinue in Europe, as elsewhere, until every country reaches the\nlevel of immunization needed to fully protect their populations.\" Israeli children are routinely immunized with the MMR measles, mumps,\nrubella vaccine which are given in 2 doses, at 1 year and a booster\nin the 1st grade. But while it is highly recommended\nby medical professionals and the Health Ministry, the vaccine is not\nmandatory and according to the IDF the measles vaccine is not part of\nthe vaccines given to new recruits. \"We cannot afford to have soldiers\nwho are severely ill with a highly contagious disease. It would be\nappropriate for the IDF to verify and update immunizations of all\npersonnel and new recruits,\" the infectious disease specialist told\nthe Post. Measles is spread by coughing and sneezing and close contact with\ninfected individuals. While most infected people usually experience\nonly mild symptoms it is one of the leading causes of death among\nyoung children globally. Measles takes about 8-12 days following\ncontact before the individual will show symptoms which include a\nfever, bad cough, red eyes, and a runny nose. A few days after the\nrespiratory symptoms, the infected individual will get a bad rash.\nOther complications of measles include gastroenteritis (diarrhea and\nvomiting), pneumonia, severe bleeding problems, and in some rare cases\nencephalitis (brain infections). But these outbreaks won't be able to expand to cause\nsignificant disease in the protected population. HealthMap/ProMED-mail maps\nIsrael: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90)\nUkraine: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/123)\n- Mod.LK \nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Uganda (Kampala, Wakiso).\nDate: Tue 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, The EastAfrican report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/uganda/uganda-plans-mass-measles-vaccination) \nUganda's Health Ministry has said it is rolling out a mass\nimmunisation campaign against measles for children under the age of\nfive, as a measure to control an outbreak of the disease in the\ncapital Kampala and the neighbouring district of Wakiso, where 67\ncases were reported in July 2017. \"The Ministry of Health is\nundertaking a number of measures to control the spread of the disease,\nincluding investigating the extent of its spread in Kampala and\nWakiso,\" said director of health services, Prof Anthony Mbonye. Measles is an airborne disease that affects mostly children between\nthe ages of 6 months and 10 years, although it can also affect\nadults. Although Prof Mbonye said there was no cause for alarm, he urged the\npublic to be vigilant and report any suspected cases to the nearest\nhealth facilities. Despite previous\nmass vaccination campaigns, Uganda has had several outbreaks of the\ndisease. Prof Mbonye blamed it on parents who do not take their\nchildren for immunisation at the right time. It is generally thought that because\nmeasles is such a highly transmissible disease, that 90-95 per cent of\npeople must be vaccinated in order to protect the entire population,\nor achieve herd immunity. Date: Wed 23 Aug 2017, 1:38 PM. Source: Express (edited) (http://www.express.co.uk/news/nature/844891/Asian-mosquitos-Britain-Eurotunnel-dengue-fever-chikungunya-virus-UK)   Health specialists have blitzed a clutch of notorious Asian tiger mosquitoes suspected to have smuggled their way into Britain through the Eurotunnel. The invasive Asiatic mosquitoes can carry dengue fever and the chikungunya virus, and attack in daylight.  Experts from Public Health England destroyed the batch of mosquito eggs and larvae at the busy Ashford International truck stop earlier this month August 2017. This is the 2nd time that one of the planet's most dangerous insects  so-named because of its striped body and legs  has been discovered entering into the UK during the last year.  Asian tiger mosquitoes  scientific name, _Aedes albopictus_  have been spreading across Europe and are blamed for up to a million global cases of chikungunya globally every year. The disease has no cure and leaves victims in a fever and with excruciating joint pains as well as headaches, nausea and rashes. There is a death risk of one in a thousand cases. France confirmed 4 cases in 2014 and there was an epidemic in Italy a decade ago.  Asian tiger mosquitoes are spreading the disease through the way their eggs and larvae have been exported from native forest haunts in south east Asia in tyre imports. The grubs eggs can survive for months and larvae and pupae develop in small pockets of water retained by tyres.  To counter the threat, the authorities are maintaining a \"mosquito surveillance programme\" at 30 UK ports and airports as well as checks at motorway services on routes from south coast ports and Eurotunnel. Dr Jenny Harries, deputy medical director at Public Health England, said: \"Through these activities we identified a small number of eggs and larvae from the _Aedes albopictus_ mosquito in traps at Ashford International truck stop.  byline: Stuart Winter   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  This report of the discovery of _Aedes albopictus_ at a truck stop in Kent appears to be valid this time and illustrates how this species can be moved internationally. A 2014 report of _Aedes aegypti_ in southern England was rejected. A statement by Jolyon Medlock, head of Medical Entomology & Zoonoses Ecology, Public Health England, Microbiological Research Authority (MRA), Emergency Response Department, Health Protection and Medical Directorate, Porton Down, Salisbury stated, \"This is misleading information as no invasive aedes mosquitoes have been found in the UK. There have been a number of news articles in British newspapers recently 2014 about invasive mosquitoes, reporting mainly on efforts to increase surveillance for _Aedes albopictus_, however no confirmed reports of any invasive aedes mosquito have been found during this surveillance, nor have any reports been submitted to the Medical Entomology group at Public Health England.\" (see Invasive mosquito - UK (02): (England) comment http://promedmail.org/post/20140923.2795988).  Intensive surveillance will be carried out this time as well. One hopes that successful aggressive efforts to eliminate the mosquitoes before they can become established, as they have become established in Italy and southern France. - Mod.TY  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6406).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"113":{"title":"Invasive mosquito - Gibraltar ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Invasive mosquito - Gibraltar [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nINVASIVE MOSQUITO - GIBRALTAR\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017.\nSource: Gibraltar Chronicle (edited)\n(http://chronicle.gi/2017/08/tiger-mosquito-found-in-gibraltar-but-no-cause-for-concern-officials-say/) \nAn aggressive species of mosquito known to transmit viral diseases has\nbeen detected in Gibraltar, but public health officials insist there\nis no cause for alarm. Public Health Gibraltar and the Environmental\nAgency confirmed that the mosquito of the species _Aedes albopictus_,\nalso known as the tiger mosquito, has been found in Gibraltar. Last June 2017 after 9 months of intensive surveillance, officials\nsaid no tiger mosquito had been found in Gibraltar. But this has now\nchanged after the 1st tiger mosquito was found in the urban domestic\nenvironment within Gibraltar. \"This finding alone does not however\nmaterially alter any health risks in Gibraltar and there is no\nimmediate cause for public concern,\" the government said in a\nstatement. Public Health Gibraltar was first alerted in January 2016 to the\ndiscovery of the mosquito in Málaga and Algeciras in Andalusia,\nSpain. Since then, together with the Environmental Agency, it began\nworking with international experts to mount surveillance in Gibraltar.\nWorld Health Organization experts visited Gibraltar and gave advice on\nsetting traps and monitoring locations, but no tiger mosquito had been\ndetected until now. The tiger mosquito is not native to Gibraltar and has not been\npreviously found here. It is common in other countries where it\ntransmits viral diseases like Zika, dengue, and chikungunya. It is a\ndomestic species, breeds in water in urban areas  water butts,\nblocked drains, rainwater gullies  and is able to reach high\nabundance around residential areas. It is also a day-time mosquito,\nthat aggressively bites humans. \"Health risks to the public only arise if the virus causing these\ndiseases is also present, which is not the case in Gibraltar,\" the\ngovernment said. \"The virus can, however, be imported by travellers\nreturning from an overseas country and if this happens, there is a\nrisk of spread, but only if the mosquito bites within a small window\nperiod of about a week after the fever starts.\" Public Health Gibraltar has been raising awareness of travel risk\namongst travellers through its publication A Factsheet for Travellers\nand recommends the following precautions:\n- before travelling to affected areas, consult your doctor or seek\nadvice from a travel clinic, especially if you have an immune disorder\nor severe chronic illness;\n- if you are pregnant or are considering pregnancy, consider\npostponing non-essential travel;\n- when staying in a mosquito-prone area, wear mosquito repellents and\ntake mosquito bite prevention measures;\n- if you have symptoms within 3 weeks of return from an affected\ncountry, contact your doctor;\n- if you have been diagnosed with any of the diseases Zika, dengue, or\nchikungunya, take strict mosquito bite prevention measures for 10 days\nafter the fever starts. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) The appearance of _Aedes albopictus_ in Gibraltar is not surprising.\nA map of the distribution of this species as of April this year (2017)\nshows it present around the Mediterranean Basin and up to Gibraltar on\nthe west\n((https://ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications-data/aedes-albopictus-current-known-distribution-europe-april-2017)).\nNow it has been found in Gibraltar. The concerns are real about\ntransmission of dengue, chikungunya, and Zika viruses should\npopulations of _Ae. albopictus_ become established. In 2015 there were\na few locally acquired cases of dengue in the south of France. This\nalso happened on a larger scale in Emilia Romagna, Italy, when a\nviremic man introduced chikungunya virus into Italy and sparked an\noutbreak. One hopes that mosquito surveillance will continue in\nGibraltar, perhaps be intensified, and help guide vector control\nefforts. - Mod.TY A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/517). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"114":{"title":"Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t","date":["26","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy  Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15 <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania  Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics   Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert. Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Mainichi (edited) (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170821/p2g/00m/0dm/077000c)   Japan's health ministry has issued a warning for people traveling to Europe on the back of an outbreak of measles in countries such as Italy and Romania. The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is advising tourists to go to hospital if they develop a high fever or generalized rash after returning to Japan.  Although the World Health Organization verified that Japan has eliminated infections of endemic measles strains in 2015, group infections originating from people who contracted the disease abroad are spreading in the country. As of 6 Aug 2017, the number of patients reached 169 this year in Japan, already eclipsing the figure in the previous year.  About 4100 patients in Italy and around 6500 patients in Romania have already been confirmed as of August 2017 compared with about 860 and 2000, respectively, throughout 2016, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.  Symptoms of the highly contagious disease include runny nose, red and watery eyes, high fever, and rash. The virus is spread through coughing and sneezing and can cause complications such as pneumonia and can even result in death in one in 1000 patients, according to the ministry. The ministry recommends people traveling overseas to check their vaccination records and take an additional shot if they have only been vaccinated once.  The disease was prevalent about a decade ago in Japan with the number of patients soaring to over 10 000 in 2008 but the country was later considered as free from infections of the virus.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy. Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017 5:36 PM AEST. Source: News.com.au, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report (edited) (http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/fourth-case-of-measles-at-perth-school/news-story/ece041f55111645e10f70046d92479dd)   A 4th child has been diagnosed with measles at Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, more than a week after the health department gave an on-site vaccine to students. A Health Department spokeswoman confirmed the latest case, which came 3 weeks after the highly contagious disease was first detected in an unvaccinated year 10 student who had returned from Italy.  Revelations that about half the school's 400 students were unvaccinated against the disease led the Health Department to offer a voluntary, free on-site vaccine to students, but it is unknown how many took up the offer.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK   Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15. Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2017; 22(34) (edited) (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22861)   ref: Werber D, Hoffmann A, Santibanez S, et al. Large measles outbreak introduced by asylum seekers and spread among the insufficiently vaccinated resident population, Berlin, October 2014 to August 2015. Euro Surveill. 2017; 22(34): pii=30599 - Abstract  The largest measles outbreak in Berlin since 2001 occurred from October 2014 to August 2015. Overall, 1344 cases were ascertained, 86 per cent (with available information) unvaccinated, including 146 (12 per cent) asylum seekers. Median age was 17 years (interquartile range: 4-29 years), 26 per cent were hospitalised and a 1 year old child died. Measles virus genotyping uniformly revealed the variant 'D8-Rostov-Don' and descendants. The virus was likely introduced by and initially spread among asylum seekers before affecting Berlin's resident population. Among Berlin residents, the highest incidence was in children younger than 2 years, yet most cases (52 per cent) were adults. Post-exposure vaccinations in homes for asylum seekers, not always conducted, occurred later (median: 7.5 days) than the recommended 72 hours after onset of the 1st case and reached only half of potential contacts. Asylum seekers should not only have non-discriminatory, equitable access to vaccination, they also need to be offered measles vaccination in a timely fashion, that is, immediately upon arrival in the receiving country. Supplementary immunisation activities targeting the resident population, particularly adults, are urgently needed in Berlin.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5857). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania. Date: Fri 25 August 2017. Source: Romania Insider (edited) (https://www.romania-insider.com/measles-kills-iraqi-refugee/)   The ongoing measles outbreak keeps making victims in Romania. A 10 month old girl, who was a refugee from Iraq, became the 33rd person to die of the infection, reports local Digi24. The girl arrived in Romania on 7 Jul 2017 with her family, and the doctors diagnosed her with measles in August. They also discovered that the child was suffering from malnutrition and severe psychomotor retardation.  The measles outbreak is still a major problem in Romania, with more than 8900 cases reported across the country until 25 Aug 2017, including 33 deaths, according to data from the National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT). Most deaths were registered in Timis (9), Dolj (7), and Arad (6) counties.  Measles is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by a virus. It causes a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and runny nose. According to information posted on WHO's website, the virus is highly contagious, spreading by coughing and sneezing, close personal contact, and direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions. Unvaccinated young children pose the highest risk of measles and its complications, including death.  The Romanian Government adopted earlier this month August 2017 a draft bill on the organization and financing of population vaccination (https://www.romania-insider.com/romania-draft-bill-vaccination/). The project was sent to the Parliament for approval and could come into force in January 2018.  byline: Irina Marica   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Measles tends to be more severe in children who are malnourished, especially children who are also vitamin A deficient. And complications are commoner and more serious in malnourished children. Because of complications such as diarrhoea, measles may lead to failure to thrive. Infection with measles virus may lead to kwashiorkor or marasmus in children who are underweight at the time that they get infected. Therefore, measles may result in, or aggravate, malnutrition.  Maps of Romania can be found at (http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK   Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics. Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017. Source: News-Medical/Life Sciences (edited) (https://www.news-medical.net/news/20170826/New-study-highlights-role-played-by-demographics-in-the-spread-of-measles.aspx)   Even if the incidence of measles infection has decreased by at least 90 per cent worldwide since the introduction of the vaccine, measles is still one of the major causes of death in children among vaccine-preventable diseases. Regular measles epidemics are reported in developing countries and recurrent episodic outbreaks occur in the developed world.  A new study by Bocconi University and Bruno Kessler Foundation analyzing 9 countries (Australia, Ethiopia, Kenya, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases see reference below, highlights the role played by demographics in the spread of measles and concludes that future vaccination strategies in high-fertility countries should focus on increasing childhood immunization rates, while immunization campaigns targeting adolescents and young adults are required in low fertility countries.  Using a transmission model calibrated on historical serological data the authors estimate that the susceptible proportion of the population (that is, unprotected against the infection) varies from about 3 per cent in the UK to more than 12.5 per cent in Ethiopia, with astonishing differences in its age composition, due to different vaccination strategies and divergent demographic trends. While the percentage of over-15 among susceptible individuals in Ethiopia and Kenya is, respectively, 28 per cent and 43 per cent, adolescents and young adults represent 74 per cent of unprotected individuals in South Korea, 66 per cent in Italy and 53 per cent in the US, with considerable immunity gaps in individuals aged 30-40 years.  \"Every effort to increase the vaccination coverage rate among children is praiseworthy\", says Alessia Melegaro, a Bocconi professor and principal investigator of DECIDE, the ERC European Research Council-funded project which produced the article, \"but in some developed countries it's the lack of coverage among adolescents and adults that poses a serious threat to the goal of eliminating measles.\"  \"Measles incidence could increase, in the next decades, in Italy, Australia, and Singapore and Ethiopia is at high risk of future large epidemics\", says Stefano Merler from Bruno Kessler Foundation, \"and this is particularly worrying considering that individuals get infected later in life when the disease is more severe. The median age at infection for 2015 was estimated to be 5-10 years in the UK, Ireland, and Ethiopia; 10-15 years in the USA, Australia, Singapore, and Kenya; and older than 20 years in Italy and South Korea\".  The proposed model shows that the introduction of the measles vaccine, which occurred at different times in the 9 countries, has considerably reduced the disease burden in terms of disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs), a measure expressed as the number of years lost because of illness, disability, or early death. Every vaccine dose averts 2 or 3 weeks of DALYs in the developed world and around 20 weeks in Kenya and Ethiopia. Which translates into 2-mln years 2 million DALYs since the vaccine introduction in the UK, 13-mln 13 million DALYs in the US, and 36-mln 36 million DALYs in Ethiopia.  \"Vaccination has undoubtedly achieved incredible results in terms of public health. In particular,\" continues Prof Melegaro \"our analysis showed that routine 1st dose vaccine administration has been responsible for more than 90 per cent of the overall number of vaccine-immunized individuals in most countries. In Ethiopia and Kenya, catch-up and follow-up campaigns substantially mitigated the effect of suboptimum routine vaccine coverage, generating 25-45 per cent of the immunized fraction of the population. Tailoring immunization campaigns to achieve measles eradication goals is essential and currently, for some countries, this means considering also the role of unprotected adolescents and young adults.\"   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Reference - Trentini F, Poletti P, Merler S, Melegaro A. Measles immunity gaps and the progress towards elimination: a multi-country modelling analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30421-8. Epub ahead of print; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28807627).   While it is recommended that children get 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12 through 15 months of age, and the 2nd dose at 4 through 6 years of age, this study emphasizes that it is important that adolescents and young adults also are up to date on their MMR vaccination. - Mod.LK  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"156":{"title":"Anthrax - Italy: (LZ) bovine ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Anthrax - Italy: (LZ) bovine [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017. Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(35) (edited) (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24702)   Anthrax, Italy  Information received on and dated 31 Aug 2017 from Prof. Dr. Romano Marabelli, Chief Veterinary Officer, Secretary General, Ministry of Health, Rome, Italy   Report type: immediate notification Date of start of the event: 26 Aug 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 29 Aug 2017 Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease Date of previous occurrence: December 2016 Manifestation of disease: clinical disease Causal agent: _Bacillus anthracis_ Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic) This event pertains to a defined zone within the country  New outbreaks (1) Summary of outbreaks: \nTotal outbreaks: 1 Outbreak 1 (ANTH_1_RM_2017), Rocca di Papa, Roma, Lazio Date of start of the outbreak: 26 Aug 2017 Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: farm Affected animals: \nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / 73 / 9 / 9 / 0 / 0  Outbreak statistics rates apparent, expressed as percentages Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost* Cattle / 12.33 / 12.33 / 100 / 12.33 *Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter  Epidemiology: Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive  Control measures: Measures applied: official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.  The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above. Lazio is on the SE coast of central Italy. - Mod.MHJ   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Losing 9 animals to acute anthrax suggests that the owner was unaware of what was happening as normally dead cows are reported as soon as the first case occurs. And with 9 sick and dead animals there would have been plenty of blood sources for female haemorrphagic flies. An investigation of this event will probably reveal subsequent cases in neighbouring herds, and maybe a previous case in the area.  Past outbreaks were reported in Lazio in cattle in 1997 and 2000, and in sheep in 2016 and 2005. - Mod.MHJ  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11401).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"165":{"title":"Anthrax - Italy (02): (LZ) comment ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Anthrax - Italy (02): (LZ) comment [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 1 Sep 2017. From: Antonio Battisti (antonio.battisti@izslt.it) (edited)   The diagnosis of Anthrax was done at Istituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale del Lazio e della Toscana (IZSLT), in Rome, Italy (same province of the outbreak) after an onsite inspection by vets from IZSLT who were called by the Local Veterinary Services, on Fri 25 Aug 2017.  During the inspection, IZSLT decided that Anthrax was the main etiology to be firstly investigated. Four bovine animals found dead at inspection site (a pasture in the municipality of Grottaferrata, province of Rome, Italy), most probably dead in the latter 4-5 hours, were sampled (blood samples, following the international consensus procedures). The Veterinary Services disposed of fallen stock (destruction) according to EU legislation (the 4 animals plus another one that was found dead nearby by the Veterinary Services).  All 4 cases investigated were preliminarly diagnosed as Anthrax cases on the same day, by microscopic examination of blood smears stained with polychrome methylene blue (McFedyan's reaction), and confirmed by cultures and PCR (chromosomal target, pXO1 and pXO2 plasmidic targets) by the next Mon 28 Aug 2017. These are the only cases that were confirmed as Anthrax by a laboratory diagnosis.  The area is an historical Anthrax site and pastures are located in the crater of an extinct volcano, not far from the Albano Lake, itself a lake of volcanic origin. Anthrax cases in livestock living in the area are considered absolutely sporadic nowadays, thanks to the intense vaccine prevention measures of the past decades (from the late 1950s of the 20th century). The outbreak may have been favored by the severe drought ongoing in Central Italy. This is the only outbreak notified in 2017 in the Latium Region. In 2016 one case only was notified in the Rome province, Latium Region (Artena Municipality).   Antonio Battisti DVM, ECVPH PM \non behalf of Istituto Zooprofilattico Sperimentale del Lazio e della Toscana, \nVia Appia Nuova 1411, \n00178 Rome, Italy (antonio.battisti@izslt.it)  We greatly appreciate Antonio's comments and corrections to the information posted yesterday Thu 31 Aug 2017 from Paris and Rome. - Mod.MHJ  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/11401).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"306":{"title":"PRO/EDR> Malaria - Italy (02): fatal case, non-travel related","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Malaria - Italy (02): fatal case, non-travel related","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 6 Sep 2017. From: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project (edited)   ProMED circulated a request for further information through the Epi-Core network, and this is a summary of the various responses we received:  Reconstruction of the history 1. Prior to onset of illness, the family was staying at Bibione, Province of Venice (seaside resort) and on 13 Aug 2017, the girl was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus at the Portogruaro hospital (40 km approx 28 mi north of Venice). 2. The family including the girl returned to Trento where they live on 16 Aug 2017 and she was admitted to the hospital for the diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. She was discharged on 21 Aug 2017. 3. On 16 Aug 2017, 2 children from Burkina Faso with falciparum malaria were admitted to the same children's ward in Trento hospital. 4. Fever was reported in the girl on 28 Aug 2017, the fever then disappeared but returned on 30 Aug 2017 when she was again hospitalized at Trento hospital. Malaria was diagnosed and treatment was started. On 2 Sep 2017 she was air-lifted to the University Hospital in Brescia with a diagnosis of cerebral malaria.   \n<br><br>Communicated by: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project (promed@promedmail.org)  ProMED-mail would like to thank all of the EpiCore members who responded to the request for more information on this event.   The overlap with the 2 cases from Burkina Faso was 5 days and thus infection would have had to have beeen through direct transmission by blood and not through mosquitoes. If the needle used for blood sugar testing in some manner was shared between the known malaria patients and the young girl who had been hospitalized for diabetes, then nosocomial transmission is a possibility.  An alternative possibility is that the infection occurred from local Italian mosquitoes that had been infected by an asymptomatic gametocyte carrier. This is well known to happen and malaria was endemic in northern Italy in the past especially in the period between both world wars when there was a high prevalence of the disease, but it was _P.vivax_ and not _P. falciparum_. Whether the local mosquitoes (_A. maculipennis_ complex) are capable of transmitting _P. falciparum_ malaria is not known, but the possibility is not excluded.  )From infection to the debut of symptoms, the incubation period is usually 7 - 10 days in non-immune individuals. If the hospitalization for the suspected diabetes mellitus in Portogruaro hospital was in fact when she presented with the 1st symptoms of malaria, then she was most likely infected 7 - 10 days previously, however, fever would have been a key presenting symptom.  Thus the key question is when did the 1st symptoms of malaria actually appear  and the only certain point in the information we presently have is that she was febrile on 28 Aug 2017.  There is a huge variability from the time the symptoms started to the time of death in imported (non-immune) malaria cases. A large study of 22 fatal outcomes of patient with _P. falciparum_ malaria returning to Switzerland (Christen et al. Am J Trop Med Hyg 2006;75:1188-94) reported an average of 8 days with a low of 3 days. Thus if the 1st symptoms of malaria were on 28 Aug 2017, the date of actual infection must have taken place within the 10 prior days.  Does the climate allow development of the malaria parasite in the mosquito? The average temperature for Trento in August 2017 is found here: (https://www.accuweather.com/en/it/trento/216357/august-weather/216357). The average night temperature is only reaching 20 C (approx. 68 F) on 18 Aug 2017, otherwise it was well below 20 C (approx. 68 F) with a low of 13 C (approx. 55 F). In order to allow _P.falciparum_ to develop in mosquitoes, the average night temperature must be 20 C (approx. 68 F) or more for 8 - 10 days. Thus the temperature in Trento in August 2017 excludes the possibility the 2 patients from Burkina Faso infected local mosquitoes, which then infected the patient.  The average temperature for Bibione in August 2017 is found here: (https://www.accuweather.com/en/it/bibione/2550920/august-weather/2550920). )From 1 Aug 2017 to 20 Aug 2017 the average night temperature was above 20 C approx. 68 F except for 2 days (12 and 13 Aug 2017) and thus the _P. falciparum_ parasite had the climatic conditions to develop in the mosquito if local mosquitoes are able to transmit _p. falciparum_ and were infected by a gametocyte carrier.  The risk of reintroducing malaria in Italy was discussed in Romi et al. in 2012 (Romi R et al. Probable autochthonous introduced malaria cases in Italy in 2009-2011 and the risk of local vector-borne transmission. Euro Surveill. 2012 Nov 29;17(48). pii: 20325). In Trento (Province of Trentino) the _Anopheles_ species in _A. maculipennis_ complex is present which is regarded as zoophilic (not preferring humans).  In conclusion, it is a possibility that the girl was infected by mosquitoes during her stay in Bibione, but nosocomial infection in Trento is an alternative explanation. - Mod.EP  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/75).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Jamaica":{},"Japan":{"33":{"title":"Food poisoning, fatalities - Ghana: (TV) puffer fish susp.\r\n\t","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Food poisoning, fatalities - Ghana: (TV) puffer fish susp.\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong>. Date: Thu 17 Aug 2017. Source: Graphic.com (edited) (http://www.graphic.com.gh/news/general-news/food-poisoning-kills-four-in-alavanyo.html)   A total of 4 people have died in Alavanyo in the Volta Region in what has been described as food poisoning from a fish which looks like a puffer fish.  Up to 3 others have also been hospitalised at the Margaret Marquart Catholic Hospital in Kpando after they ate the fish which is known by the local people as \"Gedde\".  According to the Hospital Administrator, Emmanuel Hanson Torde, similar cases were reported 2 weeks ago after residents reportedly ate the same kind of fish. He told Citi FM in an interview on Thu 17 Aug 2017 post-mortems conducted on the deceased indicated they died from fish poisoning but could not ascertain whether it was as a result of eating the fish. He said the hospital had informed the Food and Drugs Authority about the development.  \"In all, the 2 communities where the people died, we have the samples but I cannot state categorically that it was as a result of the consumption of the fish until further investigation has been done. But I can state that we've lost 4 people as a result of eating the fish. Doctors' diagnosis said it was due to food poisoning.\"  \"It is not a common fish on the market. What the residents told me was that when the fish is captured in the river and hit with a stick, it expands. It is not a normal fish that is sold on the market,\" he added.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong>. Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017. Source: Pulse.com (edited) (http://www.pulse.com.gh/health/pufferfish-all-you-need-to-know-about-the-poisonous-fish-that-killed-4-in-volta-region-id7168042.html)   When news broke on Thu 17 Aug 2017 that 4 people had died in the Volta region after allegedly eating puffer fish, many have since been wondering what kind of fish that is.  It is important to note puffer fish are highly poisonous and should only prepared by trained, licensed chefs who know one bad cut means almost certain death for a customer.  Surprisingly, the meat of some puffer fish is considered a delicacy, especially in Japan.  But here's why you should perhaps avoid it completely:   - According to National Geographic, tetrodotoxin is deadly, up to 1200 times more poisonous than cyanide. One puffer fish has enough toxin to kill 30 adults.   - The puffer fish is the 2nd most poisonous vertebrate on the planet. Its poison has no antidote and kills by paralyzing the diaphragm, causing suffocation.   - Almost all puffer fish contain tetrodotoxin, a substance that makes them taste bad (and sometimes lethal) to other fish.   - Tetrodotoxin does not cross the blood-brain barrier, so the victims remain fully conscious while their central nervous system gradually shuts down. Symptoms such as numbness in the mouth, lips, and tongue occur within 30 minutes to 3 hours from an intake and after that, the victim begins to experience headaches, nausea and even vomiting. The rest of the body slowly becomes paralysed, causing death when the heart and lung muscles are also paralysed.   - In Japan, the most lethal part, the liver, cannot be sold, and the whole fish is banned in the European Union.  - There are more than 120 species of puffer fish worldwide. Most of them are found in tropical and subtropical ocean waters. However, some species live in brackish and even fresh water. They have long, tapered bodies with bulbous heads.  - The puffer fish protects itself in the wild by gulping down water and swelling up its belly to make itself look bigger. It does this because, apparently, it can't find a way to communicate the simple message, \"I am poisonous,\"(io9.gizmodo.com) says  Byline: Mildred Europa Taylor   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org) And Epicore member Addo Michael Brown  Tetrodotoxin is a colorless crystal substance that darkens when heated above 400 degrees F or approximately 220 C.  Tetrodotoxin is an extremely potent toxin (poison) found mainly in the liver and gonads of some fish, notably puffer fish, or fugu, but also globefish (sometimes puffer fish are also called globefish), and toadfish as well as some amphibians, octopus, and shellfish species. Human poisonings occur when the flesh and/or organs of the fish are improperly prepared and eaten. Tetrodotoxin interferes with the transmission of signals from nerves to muscles and causes an increasing paralysis of the muscles of the body. Tetrodotoxin poisoning can be fatal.  These creatures are likely fatal when prepared inappropriately, and should be handled with extreme caution for the everyday untrained person. We are sorry for the families of these individuals.  Portions of this comment were extracted from: (https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/ershdb/emergencyresponsecard_29750019.html)  For more indepth comment, readers are referred to the moderator's comments on ProMED-mail posting Tetrodotoxin poisoning, puffer fish - China: (Hong Kong) http://promedmail.org/post/20160822.4432069. - Mod.TG  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/16921).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"65":{"title":"E. coli EHEC - Japan: (ST) O157, potato salad,\r\n\tRFI ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> E. coli EHEC - Japan: (ST) O157, potato salad,\r\n\tRFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 22 Aug 2017. Source: The Japan Times (edited) (https://tinyurl.com/yaujlfzu)  . A 5 year old girl is in a critical condition and 2 others are severely ill after eating a supermarket potato salad product infected with _Escherichia coli_ O157, Saitama Prefecture said on Mon 21 Aug 2017. The victims all ate potato salad sold at the Shokusaikan Marche Kagohara supermarket in the city of Kumagaya, Saitama prefecture, the prefecture said. In addition to the girl, who remains unconscious, a 4 year old boy and a 60 year old woman have been hospitalized. All 3 are not expected to be discharged soon.  According to Saitama prefecture, the supermarket's deli  Derishasu Kagohara  procured the potato salad from a food-processing factory from outside the prefecture, then mixed cut pieces of ham and apples. The Kumagaya Public Health Center has ordered that the deli be closed for 3 days amid an investigation into the food poisoning, including what caused the _E. coli_ infection and the routes through which the salad was distributed.  The incident came to light after the prefecture was notified of a boy being admitted to a Gunma prefecture hospital on 14 Aug 2017. The Kumagaya Public Health Center learned that 8 Saitama residents, who all ate the potato salad sold on 7 and 8 Aug 2017, complained of stomach pains. 3 others ranging in age from 7 to 12 were also hospitalized for symptoms such as diarrhea, but have been released from hospitals already.  The 5 year old girl who remains in critical condition has been diagnosed with hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), a condition caused by an abnormal destruction of red blood cells.  Fresh Corp, a Gunma-based supermarket and deli store chain, said no other outlets have reported cases of food poisoning. The firm has apologized for the incident on its website.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  It is not clear if the individuals who became ill earlier in the month also suffered from enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ infection. Potato salad seems to be the vehicle for transmission of the infection. Since potatoes are served after cooking, the likely source is not the potatoes themselves but rather an ingredient added to the food. Pork products are not common carriers of EHEC but this has been reported (E. coli EHEC - Canada (04): (AB) O157, pork products, recall http://promedmail.org/post/20140909.2759887). Apples can carry EHEC especially if harvested after falling from the tree and outbreaks have occurred from unpasteurized apple juice or cider (E. coli EHEC - USA (19): (CA) O111, unpasteurized apple juice, alert, recall http://promedmail.org/post/20151107.3774944; E. coli, toxigenic, apple cider - USA (Oklahoma) http://promedmail.org/post/19991019.1857). It is also possible that cross contamination during preparation from other foods could have occurred related to poor kitchen hygiene. ProMED-mail would like more information regarding this outbreak.  It may be recalled by ProMED-mail readers and evident from the flurry of ProMED-mail postings from Japan in 1996 and 1997 shown below that substantially more cases of this disease occurred in that time frame. The following is from FAO/WHO Global Forum of Food Safety Regulators, Marrakesh, Morocco, 28-30 Jan 2002, Investigation system for foodborne outbreaks in Japan: ((http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/MEETING/004/X6924E.HTM)). \"..in 1996, many outbreaks of _Escherichia coli_ O157:H7 infection, involved 11 826 cases and 12 deaths, occurred in Japan. 16 outbreaks among them affected more than 10 people and comprised 10 275 cases. Epidemiological investigations revealed that the sources of infection in these 16 outbreaks included school lunches served at elementary schools and child care centers (9 outbreaks, 9845 patients), nursing home meals (3 outbreaks, 123 patients), a meal served at an industrial facility (1 outbreak, 47 patients), a commercially prepared box lunch (1 outbreak, 191 patients), and unknown sources (2 outbreaks, 58 patients).\"  Maps of Japan can be seen at (http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/cities_of_japan_map.png) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5021). Saitama prefecture is in central Japan on Honshu Island. - Mod.LL  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"85":{"title":"E. coli EHEC - Japan (03): (KN) restaurant, O157, RFI\r\n\t","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> E. coli EHEC - Japan (03): (KN) restaurant, O157, RFI\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: The Japan Times (edited) (https://tinyurl.com/ybnoxqha)   The city of Yokohama has ordered a grilled-meat restaurant in the area to suspend operation Wed 23 Aug 2017, after 2 people who had dined there were infected with the O157 strain of the _Escherichia coli_ bacterium. A teenage girl and a man in his 80s had symptoms of food poisoning, including diarrhea, after eating separately at the restaurant Anrakutei on 30 Jul 2017. Both were hospitalized and are recovering, according to the local government. The O157 strain of the bacterium was found at the restaurant outlet or from the employees, it said.  The announcement followed an outbreak of _E. coli_ food poisoning in Gunma and Saitama prefectures this week week of Aug 2017. The city of Takasaki, Gunma Prefecture, conducted on-site inspections at a food processing plant after potato salad produced there infected 12 people in the 2 prefectures, including a 5 year old girl who became gravely ill and temporarily lost consciousness. During the inspections, officials looked into the manufacturing processes at the plant, which shipped the potato salad that found its way to delicatessens in Gunma and Saitama prefectures, according to the city.  Officials also took samples of the salad made during the same period to conduct further tests. The Takasaki Municipal Government later announced that no _E. coli_ bacteria had been found from the samples. The operator of the businesses, based in Ota, Gunma, sold bagged potato salad shipped from the plant after mixing it with ham and apple pieces, according to the Saitama Prefectural Government.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  ProMED-mail would appreciate more information about the Yokohama cases (Yokohama is the capital city of Kanagawa prefecture) and to know if they are linked to the cases, now 12 in all, in Saitama and Gunma Prefectures. - Mod.LL  Maps of Japan can be seen at (http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/cities_of_japan_map.png) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9764). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"100":{"title":"E. coli EHEC - Japan (04): O157, outbreaks ","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> E. coli EHEC - Japan (04): O157, outbreaks [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this posting: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> EpiCore response <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> News report    <br><br><strong>{1}</strong>. Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: EpiCore Global Surveillance Project (edited)   No release on EHEC strain analysis from the 2 Japanese outbreaks yet. Below is confirmation of the genetic type of 2 cases (teenage female and 80s male) from Yokohama matched to each other (1,2), but they were not able to isolate pathogen nor identify its genetic material in the food commodity collected from the restaurant (3). Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017. Source: Food Safety News (edited) (http://www.foodsafetynews.com/2017/08/two-e-coli-o157h7-illness-clusters-under-scrutiny-in-japan/#.WaAgYoWcFPY)   Japan health authorities are dealing with 2 new clusters of _Escherichia coli_ O157:H7 infections.  The 1st involves a suspended grilled-meat restaurant in Yokohama Kanagawa prefecture, linked to the illnesses of a teenage girl and a man in his 80s who ate there on 30 Jul 2017.  The 2nd involves a deli in the Saitama Prefecture and a potato salad product sold at the Shokusaikan Marche Kagohara supermarket in Kumagaya. The potato salad has sickened 14, including a 5 year old girl who is in a critical condition along with 2 others who are severely ill.  The supermarket's deli  known as Derishasu Kagohara  purchased the potato salad from a food processing facility located outside the prefecture and then mixed it with cut pieces of ham and apples. Kumagaya Public Health has ordered the deli closed for 3 days while it investigates the source of the _E. coli_ infection and its distribution.  The investigation into the illness of a boy admitted to the Gunma Prefecture hospital on 14 Aug 2017 led to the deli's contamination. The deli appears to have sold the 1st suspect potato salad on 7-8 Aug 2017, after which 8 Saitama residents reported stomach pains. Others, ages 7 to 12, were treated for diarrhea. The 5 year old has developed the kidney-threatening disease known as a hemolytic uremic syndrome or HUS.  The potato salad distribution is apparently limited to the Gunma and Saitama prefectures. Businesses in Ota, Gunma apparently re-sold the bagged potato salad, also after mixing it with ham and apple pieces. Health officials from the Takasaki Municipal government took salad samples for additional testing.  The teenage girl and man in his 80s both dined at the suspected restaurant on 30 Jul 2017 and both required hospitalization. Their O157 strain matched bacteria found in the suspended restaurant.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The Gunma and Saitama Prefectures outbreak is now up to 14 cases. It is not clear that the Yokohama cases are related to it. - Mod.LL  Maps of Japan can be seen at (http://mapsof.net/uploads/static-maps/cities_of_japan_map.png) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/9764). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"114":{"title":"Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t","date":["26","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy  Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15 <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania  Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics   Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert. Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Mainichi (edited) (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170821/p2g/00m/0dm/077000c)   Japan's health ministry has issued a warning for people traveling to Europe on the back of an outbreak of measles in countries such as Italy and Romania. The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is advising tourists to go to hospital if they develop a high fever or generalized rash after returning to Japan.  Although the World Health Organization verified that Japan has eliminated infections of endemic measles strains in 2015, group infections originating from people who contracted the disease abroad are spreading in the country. As of 6 Aug 2017, the number of patients reached 169 this year in Japan, already eclipsing the figure in the previous year.  About 4100 patients in Italy and around 6500 patients in Romania have already been confirmed as of August 2017 compared with about 860 and 2000, respectively, throughout 2016, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.  Symptoms of the highly contagious disease include runny nose, red and watery eyes, high fever, and rash. The virus is spread through coughing and sneezing and can cause complications such as pneumonia and can even result in death in one in 1000 patients, according to the ministry. The ministry recommends people traveling overseas to check their vaccination records and take an additional shot if they have only been vaccinated once.  The disease was prevalent about a decade ago in Japan with the number of patients soaring to over 10 000 in 2008 but the country was later considered as free from infections of the virus.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy. Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017 5:36 PM AEST. Source: News.com.au, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report (edited) (http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/fourth-case-of-measles-at-perth-school/news-story/ece041f55111645e10f70046d92479dd)   A 4th child has been diagnosed with measles at Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, more than a week after the health department gave an on-site vaccine to students. A Health Department spokeswoman confirmed the latest case, which came 3 weeks after the highly contagious disease was first detected in an unvaccinated year 10 student who had returned from Italy.  Revelations that about half the school's 400 students were unvaccinated against the disease led the Health Department to offer a voluntary, free on-site vaccine to students, but it is unknown how many took up the offer.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK   Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15. Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2017; 22(34) (edited) (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22861)   ref: Werber D, Hoffmann A, Santibanez S, et al. Large measles outbreak introduced by asylum seekers and spread among the insufficiently vaccinated resident population, Berlin, October 2014 to August 2015. Euro Surveill. 2017; 22(34): pii=30599 - Abstract  The largest measles outbreak in Berlin since 2001 occurred from October 2014 to August 2015. Overall, 1344 cases were ascertained, 86 per cent (with available information) unvaccinated, including 146 (12 per cent) asylum seekers. Median age was 17 years (interquartile range: 4-29 years), 26 per cent were hospitalised and a 1 year old child died. Measles virus genotyping uniformly revealed the variant 'D8-Rostov-Don' and descendants. The virus was likely introduced by and initially spread among asylum seekers before affecting Berlin's resident population. Among Berlin residents, the highest incidence was in children younger than 2 years, yet most cases (52 per cent) were adults. Post-exposure vaccinations in homes for asylum seekers, not always conducted, occurred later (median: 7.5 days) than the recommended 72 hours after onset of the 1st case and reached only half of potential contacts. Asylum seekers should not only have non-discriminatory, equitable access to vaccination, they also need to be offered measles vaccination in a timely fashion, that is, immediately upon arrival in the receiving country. Supplementary immunisation activities targeting the resident population, particularly adults, are urgently needed in Berlin.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5857). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania. Date: Fri 25 August 2017. Source: Romania Insider (edited) (https://www.romania-insider.com/measles-kills-iraqi-refugee/)   The ongoing measles outbreak keeps making victims in Romania. A 10 month old girl, who was a refugee from Iraq, became the 33rd person to die of the infection, reports local Digi24. The girl arrived in Romania on 7 Jul 2017 with her family, and the doctors diagnosed her with measles in August. They also discovered that the child was suffering from malnutrition and severe psychomotor retardation.  The measles outbreak is still a major problem in Romania, with more than 8900 cases reported across the country until 25 Aug 2017, including 33 deaths, according to data from the National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT). Most deaths were registered in Timis (9), Dolj (7), and Arad (6) counties.  Measles is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by a virus. It causes a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and runny nose. According to information posted on WHO's website, the virus is highly contagious, spreading by coughing and sneezing, close personal contact, and direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions. Unvaccinated young children pose the highest risk of measles and its complications, including death.  The Romanian Government adopted earlier this month August 2017 a draft bill on the organization and financing of population vaccination (https://www.romania-insider.com/romania-draft-bill-vaccination/). The project was sent to the Parliament for approval and could come into force in January 2018.  byline: Irina Marica   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Measles tends to be more severe in children who are malnourished, especially children who are also vitamin A deficient. And complications are commoner and more serious in malnourished children. Because of complications such as diarrhoea, measles may lead to failure to thrive. Infection with measles virus may lead to kwashiorkor or marasmus in children who are underweight at the time that they get infected. Therefore, measles may result in, or aggravate, malnutrition.  Maps of Romania can be found at (http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK   Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics. Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017. Source: News-Medical/Life Sciences (edited) (https://www.news-medical.net/news/20170826/New-study-highlights-role-played-by-demographics-in-the-spread-of-measles.aspx)   Even if the incidence of measles infection has decreased by at least 90 per cent worldwide since the introduction of the vaccine, measles is still one of the major causes of death in children among vaccine-preventable diseases. Regular measles epidemics are reported in developing countries and recurrent episodic outbreaks occur in the developed world.  A new study by Bocconi University and Bruno Kessler Foundation analyzing 9 countries (Australia, Ethiopia, Kenya, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases see reference below, highlights the role played by demographics in the spread of measles and concludes that future vaccination strategies in high-fertility countries should focus on increasing childhood immunization rates, while immunization campaigns targeting adolescents and young adults are required in low fertility countries.  Using a transmission model calibrated on historical serological data the authors estimate that the susceptible proportion of the population (that is, unprotected against the infection) varies from about 3 per cent in the UK to more than 12.5 per cent in Ethiopia, with astonishing differences in its age composition, due to different vaccination strategies and divergent demographic trends. While the percentage of over-15 among susceptible individuals in Ethiopia and Kenya is, respectively, 28 per cent and 43 per cent, adolescents and young adults represent 74 per cent of unprotected individuals in South Korea, 66 per cent in Italy and 53 per cent in the US, with considerable immunity gaps in individuals aged 30-40 years.  \"Every effort to increase the vaccination coverage rate among children is praiseworthy\", says Alessia Melegaro, a Bocconi professor and principal investigator of DECIDE, the ERC European Research Council-funded project which produced the article, \"but in some developed countries it's the lack of coverage among adolescents and adults that poses a serious threat to the goal of eliminating measles.\"  \"Measles incidence could increase, in the next decades, in Italy, Australia, and Singapore and Ethiopia is at high risk of future large epidemics\", says Stefano Merler from Bruno Kessler Foundation, \"and this is particularly worrying considering that individuals get infected later in life when the disease is more severe. The median age at infection for 2015 was estimated to be 5-10 years in the UK, Ireland, and Ethiopia; 10-15 years in the USA, Australia, Singapore, and Kenya; and older than 20 years in Italy and South Korea\".  The proposed model shows that the introduction of the measles vaccine, which occurred at different times in the 9 countries, has considerably reduced the disease burden in terms of disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs), a measure expressed as the number of years lost because of illness, disability, or early death. Every vaccine dose averts 2 or 3 weeks of DALYs in the developed world and around 20 weeks in Kenya and Ethiopia. Which translates into 2-mln years 2 million DALYs since the vaccine introduction in the UK, 13-mln 13 million DALYs in the US, and 36-mln 36 million DALYs in Ethiopia.  \"Vaccination has undoubtedly achieved incredible results in terms of public health. In particular,\" continues Prof Melegaro \"our analysis showed that routine 1st dose vaccine administration has been responsible for more than 90 per cent of the overall number of vaccine-immunized individuals in most countries. In Ethiopia and Kenya, catch-up and follow-up campaigns substantially mitigated the effect of suboptimum routine vaccine coverage, generating 25-45 per cent of the immunized fraction of the population. Tailoring immunization campaigns to achieve measles eradication goals is essential and currently, for some countries, this means considering also the role of unprotected adolescents and young adults.\"   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Reference - Trentini F, Poletti P, Merler S, Melegaro A. Measles immunity gaps and the progress towards elimination: a multi-country modelling analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30421-8. Epub ahead of print; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28807627).   While it is recommended that children get 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12 through 15 months of age, and the 2nd dose at 4 through 6 years of age, this study emphasizes that it is important that adolescents and young adults also are up to date on their MMR vaccination. - All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. Dengue continues in\nPeshawar, claiming 7 lives with 69 new cases reported from different\nareas of the city during the last 24 hours, raising the number of\ntotal cases to 1703. So far, he said, 7 deaths including 6 from Khyber\nTeaching Hospital and one in Hayatabad Medical Complex were reported\nfrom dengue epidemics in Peshawar. A rapid\nresponse team has also been set up with mandate to swiftly reach to\nthe affected areas from where new cases were surfaced besides helping\nthe field staff in conduct of fumigation spray, removal of larvae, and\nprovision of other necessary medicines.\n(https://dnd.com.pk/dengue-rampage-in-peshawar-kills-seven-69-new-cases-surface/133250) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://pakistanmap.facts.co/pakistanmapof/PakistanAdministrativeMap.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ China\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp). 16 Aug 2017.\nGuangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in south China has reported its 1st\nimported dengue case this year 2017, local inspection and quarantine\nbureau said. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. Sir Gangaram Hospital reported the rare case,\nwhere the woman, who went to the eye OPD outpatient department,\ncomplained of \"sudden blurring of vision in the left eye,\" as reported\nby IE Indian Express. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017.
