There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]},"173":{"title":"E. coli EHEC - Japan (05): O157, more widespread strain,\r\n\tRFI ","date":["20","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> E. coli EHEC - Japan (05): O157, more widespread strain,\r\n\tRFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Sat 2 Sep 2017. Source: The Mainichi (edited) (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170902/p2a/00m/0na/010000c)   The genotype of the O157 strain of _E. coli_ found in people with foodborne illness after eating potato salad from deli counters in Gunma and Saitama prefectures is consistent, the Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare has revealed. The same bacterial genotype has also been detected in people as far away as Shiga, Mie and Niigata prefectures.  Keen to ascertain the sources of infection as well as the extent to which the O157 strain has spread, the health ministry sent out a notification on Fri 1 Sep 2017 to local authorities across the country. The notice encourages local authorities to ask people infected with the strain what they have eaten and whether or not they have traveled. This summer, the number of O157 _E. coli_ cases has been higher than in an ordinary year. In response, the National Institute of Infectious Diseases examined the bacterial genotype of the strain in infected people in 144 cases between 14 and 20 Aug 2017, and found that it was consistent in most cases.  \nThe health ministry has deemed that food and other items from the same source of contamination are being distributed across a wide area. As a result, it is feared that patients coming into contact with these items are spreading the O157 strain.  To tackle the issue, the health ministry has told local authorities across the country to perform a genotype test and to confirm detailed information relating to the use of swimming pools and any contact with animals in patients found to have the same strain as that found in Saitama and Gunma prefectures. In addition, it has asked companies that provide meals to schools to take robust preventative measures against possible infection, especially as children across the country are now returning to class from summer vacation.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  ProMED would like more information regarding the number of cases related to the particular genotype of the enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ and if potato salad was the reservoir involved.  Japan has 47 prefectures. They form the 1st level of jurisdiction and administrative division of Japan. They consist of 43 prefectures proper, 2 urban prefectures (Osaka and Kyoto), one \"circuit\" or \"territory\" (Hokkaido) and one \"metropolis\" (Tokyo). A map of the prefectures can be seen at (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prefectures_of_Japan#/media/File:Regions_and_Prefectures_of_Japan_2.svg). The prefectures reported to have cases of the same genotype are Saitama, Gunma, Shiga, Mie and Niigata. Saitama, Niigata and Gunma are adjacent to each other and close to Tokyo. Shiga and Mie are adjacent to each other and close to Kyoto. - Mod.LL  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Jordan":{},"Kazakhstan":{"101":{"title":"Lumpy skin disease, bovine - Kazakhstan (02): (WK) spread susp,\r\n\tRFI ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Lumpy skin disease, bovine - Kazakhstan (02): (WK) spread susp,\r\n\tRFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Sun 20 Aug 2017. Source: Kloop (Kyrgyzstan) in Russian, machine trans., edited (https://kloop.kg/blog/2017/08/20/kazahstan-veterinary-ishhut-prichinu-massovoj-gibeli-korov/)   At least 120 head of cattle have been killed in the Atyrau region West Kazakhstan; the cause of the death of the animals is unknown. The Kazakh edition of \"Ak Zhayik\" states that 120 cows died in the Isatay district of Atyrau region in the west of Kazakhstan map at (http://tinyurl.com/y9ksmu2x) in the period from 20 Jul to August 2017.  Veterinarians do not know the cause of the animal's deaths.\"Since the cattle are still in the pastures, the owners themselves bring sick animals to us. Although they do not have a high temperature, they still cannot save them,\" said veterinarian Islamgali Mardashev.  The meat of the dead cows was sent for testing in the laboratories of Astana and Almaty, but so far there are no results see comment below. It is only known that before dying the temperature of the animals rises, and there is weakness and lumps under the skin.  In the summer of 2016, the Atyrau oblast similarly suffered a massive loss of livestock; more than 800 cattle died. All of them had nodular dermatitis. More than 6000 cattle were infected with the disease.  byline: Alexandra Titova   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  From 10 to 15 Jun 2016, a disease which later was recognized as lumpy skin disease (LSD) was recorded in a cattle holding on the territory adjacent to the village of Chapayevo, West Kazakhstan (see archive no. http://promedmail.org/post/20160717.4350687; at this point in time, laymen, followed by the media, erroneously related to the undiagnosed and most probably unfamiliar new disease as foot and mouth disease. Please see relevant commentary in the subsequent postings no. http://promedmail.org/post/20160722.4362368 and http://promedmail.org/post/20160723.4365082).  On 7 Jul 2016, Kazakhstan reported (see archive no. http://promedmail.org/post/20160722.4363497) a single LSD outbreak in Makasch, Kurmangazinskiy, Mangashlak (western to Atyrau; map at (http://tinyurl.com/ycb4j9h7)), stating that it had started on 7 Jul 2016. According to the report, the susceptible population was 3557 head including 459 clinical cases of which 34 died, the 425 remaining sick animals \"killed and disposed of\". No stamping out applied and no additional case reported in the 12 follow-up reports, the last of which, no.12, submitted on 26 Nov 2017, stated: 1. Compensation to the animals' owners for dead cattle at the market price is being developed and will be implemented soon. All 459 diseased cattle heads were destroyed and the final disinfection was carried out. 2. The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted. Follow-up report no.12, with links to all previous reports, is available at (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=21682).  Although according to media reports vaccination was applied, no details of such were included in the 12 follow-up reports nor in Kazakhstan's semi-annual summary report to the OIE (July-December 2016), which included the epidemiological statistics above; the item \"control measures\" (against LSD) did not include \"vaccination\".  The current media report, from a Kyrgyz source (citing a Kazakh newspaper), says that during the 2016 event, 6000 animals were infected, of which 600 died. An earlier media report, from Kazakhstan, dated 27 Jul 2016, said that the number of diseased animals \"exceeded 2000, of which 50 head of cattle died\" (see archive no. http://promedmail.org/post/20160727.4374008).  Kazakhstan is the world's largest landlocked country, and the 9th largest in the world. The belated diagnosis in 2016, and its continued absence, so far, during the current event, is puzzling; following the acquiring of independence in Dec 1991, Kazakhstan obtained support from the West, particularly USA, in the establishment of state-of-the-art laboratories for research and diagnosis of infectious diseases in man and animals.  Early report on the factual circulation and distribution of LSD within Kazakhstan is anticipated. Neighboring countries may take steps to prevent its introduction; those countries include China, Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. Russia is LSD-infected (last follow-up report addressing 2 new outbreaks in Saratov oblast, adjacent to West Kazakhstan, published 24 Aug 2017).  For the diagnosis of LSD, samples from clinically affected animals should preferably be derived from their typical dermal lesions; organs from dead animals which should be sent for laboratory tests are specified in OIE's Manual. The submission of \"meat of dead cows\" for testing in the laboratories, as reported, may not be ideal for timely diagnosis of LSD. - Mod.AS  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46186).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"135":{"title":"Lumpy skin disease,\r\n\tbovine - Kazakhstan (03): (AR) spread susp, \r\n\tvaccination, RFI ","date":["29","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Lumpy skin disease,\r\n\tbovine - Kazakhstan (03): (AR) spread susp, \r\n\tvaccination, RFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 29 Aug 2017. From: a subscriber whose identity is known to ProMED, but who preferred to remain unnamed (edited)   In response to ProMED-mail's RFI's in postings http://promedmail.org/post/20170815.5251541 and http://promedmail.org/post/20170825.5274779 about lumpy skin disease in Kazakhstan:  1. It is understood that the government of Kazakhstan officially announced the presence, in 2017, of nodular dermatitis aka lumpy skin disease, LSD.  2. Russian and Kenyan LSD vaccines have been mentioned as the ones applied, and their effectiveness discussed.  3. Private owners of livestock suffer most, because the compensation for each sick cow is minimal. It is necessary to develop an effective compensation scheme for the smallholder livestock owners.  4. The following information on the 2016 LSD event in Kazakhstan was included in a report for the population, by the Minister of Agriculture of the Republic of Kazakhstan, AI Myrzahmetov, published on 2 Jun 2017: \"In 2016, 4 foci of nodular dermatitis outbreaks in cattle were reported in the Atyrau oblast. Amendments were made to the legislation and 185 million tenge (USD 551 300) were paid from the republican budget as compensation for the cost of animals that died from this disease. To date, all liquidation measures have been completed. Preventive vaccination of livestock in Atyrau oblast, as well as in 6 border areas of Aktobe Aqtobe (2) and West Kazakhstan (4) oblasts, are coming to an end.\"   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  ProMED-mail is very grateful to the submitter of the information above, addressing 4 issues raised in earlier postings on LSD in Kazakhstan.  The following comments address the issues as numbered above: 1. Additional details (link?) of the mentioned official confirmation, by Kazakhstan's authorities, of the current (2017) LSD event will be helpful. The internationally customary (in fact, required) route for such an announcement is an immediate notification to the OIE.  2. The LSD vaccine applied in Russia (and exported) is, in fact, a sheep-pox vaccine which, following a testing procedure, was recently licensed also for the vaccination of cattle against LSD (see http://promedmail.org/post/20170511.5028821).  The Kenyan O-240 vaccine has been recently found to include an LSD virus which underwent a low level of attenuation which may be not sufficient for safe use in cattle. It was suspected to cause clinical disease in vaccinated animals (see in http://promedmail.org/post/20140820.2708273).  EU countries currently use a live-homologous LSD vaccine (South-Africa's Neetling virus strain). A European Union LSD vaccine bank has become operational since April 2016. Trials assessing an inactivated vaccine were reportedly undertaken, currently in their final stages.  For a recent assessment of LSD vaccines, please see http://promedmail.org/post/20160812.4410864, including the commentary. OIE's Manual chapter on LSD, including exhaustive updated information, is available at (http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.04.13_LSD.pdf).  3. This comment is of high significance. Small-holders, worldwide, may be slow, or even tempted to refrain altogether from reporting the appearance of early signs of a reportable animal disease, if they expect compensations to be under the real damages and payments delayed. Such animals may be (illegally) sold, with consequent spread of disease and  eventually  higher national losses and expenditures.  4. The original text, in Kazakh and Russian, is available in Kazakhstan's Ministry of Agriculture blog, at (http://tinyurl.com/ydbgtg6k). In case the recent media reports on LSD spreading in Western Kazakhstan are confirmed, it will be of interest to note if the affected farms included vaccinated animals and which vaccines were used.  Kazakhstan's official reporting on the 2016 LSD event was limited to a solitary notification on a single outbreak; no details of the vaccination (numbers and vaccinated animals, geography) were included.  According to the recent official update, LSD was recorded, during 2016, in 4 locations within the Atyrau oblast.  Timely and detailed information on the LSD situation in Kazakhstan is essential for the entire region. This applies also for another livestock disease suspected to be spreading in central Asia, namely PPR (peste des petits ruminants) in small ruminants. - Mod.AS  Maps of Kazakhstan can be seen at (https://kazakhstan.orexca.com/img/kazakhstan_map.gif) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46186). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"154":{"title":"Lumpy skin disease - Europe (08): Russia (OB) bovine,\r\n\tKazakhstan (AR) susp. ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Lumpy skin disease - Europe (08): Russia (OB) bovine,\r\n\tKazakhstan (AR) susp. [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Russia, Orenburg oblast, spread <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Kazakhstan, vaccines applied, compensations to farmers.   <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Russia, Orenburg oblast, spread. Date: Wed, 30 Aug 2017. Source: Rosselkhoznadzor (Russia's Federal Service for Veterinary and Phytosanitary Surveillance) - News in Russian, machine trans. edited (http://www.fsvps.ru/fsvps/news/22614.html)   Outbreaks of the cattle disease nodular dermatitis lumpy skin disease were 1st recorded on the territory of the Orenburg oblast in July of this year 2017. The 7 affected districts were Tashlinsky District (2 named villages), Sol-Iletsky District (3 villages), Novosergievsky District (1 village), Akbulaksky District (1 village), Ileksky District (1 village), Orenburg District (1 village) and Belyaevsky District (1 village). In the 10 affected locations, quarantines including restrictive measures were implemented.  The veterinary department of the Ministry of Agriculture and the food and processing industry of the Orenburg region took timely preventive and control measures to protect the livestock. Currently, the quarantine has been removed from affected holdings in the districts Novosergievsky, Tashlinsky and Ileksky. In the remaining locations, the quarantine measures will remain in force up to 30 days after the date of recovery or slaughter (destruction) of the last case on the premises.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. \n(promed@promedmail.org)  The continued spread of LSD in the 3 Russian provinces along Kazakhstan's western and northern borders is visually apparent in OIE's interactive map at (http://tinyurl.com/y7y5xhf2) (click on the cluster, then zoom in). Since the start, on 5 Jun 2017, of the current LSD epizootic in Russia's provinces bordering Kazakhstan (the Saratovskaya, Samarkanskaya and Orenburskaya oblasts), 36 outbreaks have been reported as of 24 Aug 2017.  According to media reports and direct information from reliable sources, LSD is, most likely, currently circulating in western regions of Kazakhstan (Atyrau, probably also Aqtobe and West Kazakhstan) without being officially confirmed or duly reported to the OIE. The following information has been received in reponse to yesterday's (30 Aug 2017) RFI (see http://promedmail.org/post/20170830.5282993). - Mod.AS  * <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Kazakhstan, vaccines applied, compensations to farmers. Date: Thu, 31 Aug 2017. From: A reliable source known to ProMED who preferred to remain unnamed   In response to ProMED-mail's RFI in http://promedmail.org/post/20170830.5282993:  1. Two vaccines are being applied in Kazakhstan to protect cattle against LSD: a. A Russian sheep pox vaccine (effectiveness under question) with unknown dosage; b. Neethling homologous live attenuated vaccine Lumpivax (MSD Animal Health). This vaccine is produced in South Africa.  The information on a Kenyan vaccine as being applied in Kazakhstan is not confirmed.  2. In the absence of official diagnosis of LSD, farmers will not be entitled to receive compensation. However, in Kazakhstan, they may diagnose \"pasteurellosis,\" and people will get their compensation that way. In such case, one will not know whether the actual case was related to LSD or another etiological disease agent.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. \n(promed@promedmail.org)  ProMED-mail is indebted to the submitter of the above information.  The comment on pasteurellosis (sometimes termed as hemorrhagic septicaemia), which is often a secondary infection, as a potentially substitutional diagnosis is rather concerning (see http://promedmail.org/post/20160717.4350687, http://promedmail.org/post/20160722.4362368, http://promedmail.org/post/20160723.4365082).  Kazakhstan's compliance with OIE standards, the quality of its national Veterinary Services for a timely and accurate diagnosis of suspected animal diseases, which is essential for their control, prevention and official notification; and the appropriateness of the country's veterinary legislation have been visited in the framework of OIE's PVS Pathway (see (http://www.oie.int/support-to-oie-members/pvs-pathway/)). Following visits of OIE's experts missions, comprehensive evaluation reports of the visited countries are issued, indicating and allowing required improvements or, ideally, confirming the satisfactory prevailing situations.  Out of the 131 missions already implemented, 33 countries have opted to waive the confidentiality of their evaluation reports and/or follow-up reports, which have thus become available on OIE's website at (http://www.oie.int/support-to-oie-members/pvs-evaluations/oie-pvs-evaluation-reports/) and (http://www.oie.int/support-to-oie-members/pvs-evaluations/follow-up-pvs-evaluations/)).  The following 5 Central-Asian countries have been PVS-evaluated: Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan. Kyrgyzstan's report is publicly available. - Mod.AS  ProMED HealthMaps: Orenburg Oblast, Russia: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/420) Atyrau, Kazakhstan: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46186)  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Kenya":{"99":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (90): Africa ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (90): Africa [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (90): AFRICA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Burundi (Makamba province)\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Kilifi county)\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Burundi (Makamba province).\nDate: Wed 23 Aug 2017.\nSource: IWACU English News (edited)\n(http://www.iwacu-burundi.org/englishnews/nyanza-lac-13-suspected-cases-of-cholera-detected/) \nSince 18 Aug 2017, 13 suspected cases of cholera have been recorded in\nNyanza-Lac Commune of Makamba southern province of Burundi. Nyanza-Lac\nresidents say the lack of clean water for the past 2 weeks is the main\ncause of the disease. All 13 suspected cases of cholera are receiving\ntreatment in Bukeye Adventist Health Center, said the director of\nNyanza-Lac health district, Désiré Nibizi. He also said the\nsituation is stabilized for the moment. \"The level of contamination\nhas significantly reduced,\" said Nibizi. Cholera patients come from the localities of Mvugo, Bukeye,\nKazirabageni, Nyabutare, and Nyanza-Lac urban zone, located on the\nshores of Lake Tanganyika also bordering the Democratic Republic of\nCongo. Nyanza-Lac inhabitants say cholera outbreak is due to the recurrent\nproblems of access to drinking water. \"We have just spent 2 weeks\nwithout water. We are forced to use water from Lake Tanganyika, \"says\none inhabitant of Nyanza-Lac. Nibizi calls on the population to avoid\ndrinking water from Lake Tanganyika without boiling it. byline: Lorraine Josiane Manishatse \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Burundi can be seen at\n(http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/burundi.pdf) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/17805) - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Kilifi county).\nDate: Thu 24 Aug 2017.\nSource: AllAfrica, Daily Nation report (edited)\n(http://allafrica.com/stories/201708240402.html) \nA cholera outbreak has been reported in Kilifi county with 8 cases\nunder watch. Kilifi town and its environs have been put on high alert\nfollowing the outbreak at Kiwandani village. This was after 5 people\nwho came into contact with a child who died as a result of acute\ndiarrhea and vomiting on 14 Aug 2017 tested positive for _Vibrio\ncholerae_, the bacterium that causes cholera. 3 more cases were\nreported on Wed 23 Aug 2017, at the same village, according to\nKilifi County director of health Bilali Mazoya. 2 of the 3 patients\nwere treated and discharged and the 3rd one was admitted. Dr Mazoya on\nThu 24 Aug 2017 said they had put all medical facilities in the 7\nsub-counties of Kilifi on high alert. Hospitals and dispensaries have been asked to watch out for cholera\nsymptoms and educate patients on measures to stop the spread of the\ndisease. Dr Mazoya said a team of public health officers had been\ndispatched to treat the 5 patients at Kiwandani Village and keep watch\non the disease. \"We have set up a cholera treatment centre at\nKiwandani Dispensary to manage the identified cases and any other\nsubsequent cases from the locality,\" he said. Dr Mazoya said the 5\nyear old child who died as a result of acute diarrhea and vomiting did\nnot test positive for cholera. \"The child had been admitted to a private health institution but soon\nafter the death, 5 of the family members who came into contact with\nthe child later tested positive of cholera and admitted to the\nKiwandani Dispensary,\" said Dr Mazoya. The outbreak in Kilifi comes after the disease ravaged Nairobi,\nNakuru, and Kisumu counties. byline: Kalume Kazungu \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Kenya can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/kck73tk) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/3927) - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Wed 23 Aug 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, Radio Dabanga report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/more-fatalities-infections-sudan-cholera-epidemic-rallies) \nSouth Darfur\n\nOn Monday and Tuesday 21-22 Aug 2017 4 displaced people died of\ncholera and 49 others have been infected at camp Kalma in Nyala,\ncapital of South Darfur. More deaths and infections have been reported\nfrom across the country as rates resurge along the Nile. Yagoub\nAbdallah, the general coordinator of displaced persons and refugee\ncamps, told Radio Dabanga that \"the camp has seen a wide spread of\ncholera over the past 2 days.\" On Mon 21 Aug 2017, the camp's 2 health centers reported 1 death and\n18 new cholera cases, and 3 deaths and 31 new cases on Tue 22 Aug\n2017. Abdallah explained that the number of hospitalized cases in the 2\ncenters has amounted to 78 and pointed to the acute shortage of\nmedicines in both centers. He appealed to the Ministry of Health and\nthe WHO to speed up the provision of medicines and intravenous\nsolutions. Central Darfur\n\nOn Monday and Tuesday 21-22 Aug 2017, Nierteti in Central Darfur\nrecorded 5 new cases of cholera. One of the Sheikhs of Nierteti camps\ntold Radio Dabanga that 3 cases were recorded on 21 Aug 2017, 2 from\nthe camps and 1 from neighboring villages of Nierteti. On 22 Aug\n2017, 2 cases were recorded in Nierteti camps, bringing the number of\nhospitalized cases to 12. Sennar\n\nFrom Friday to Tuesday 18-22 Aug 2017, 18 people have been infected\nwith cholera at El Dindir area in Sennar. Yesterday 22 Aug 2017, a\nmedical source told Radio Dabanga that El Dindir Hospital received 2\nnew cases, this in addition to the existence of 6 hospitalized cases\nin the isolation ward. A medical source reported from El Bardana\nvillage entry of 1 case on Tue 22 Aug 2017, bringing the total\nnumber of cases in the isolation centre to 10 cases since 18 Aug\n2017. Singa area reportedly witnessed a marked decrease in recent cases. The\nhealth source said Singa Hospital recorded 3 cases of cholera on\nMonday and Tuesday 21-22 Aug 2017. Khartoum\n\nCholera in Khartoum state has re-spread after seeing a significant\ndecrease during the past month. Yesterday 22 Aug 2017, an activist\nfrom the emergency room of Teiba El Ahamda told Radio Dabanga that El\nEzba district health center has recorded 4 cases of cholera during the\npast 2 days. The activist attributed the emergence of cases to the\nrainfall and the terrible environmental degradation witnessed by the\ndistrict due to the accumulation of waste. He pointed out that Bahri\nlocality has stopped transporting the waste from Teiba El Ahamda for\nunknown reasons for 3 years. El Azhari Widaatallah, the chairman of the Legislative and Justice\nCommittee of the Parliament, representative of Constituency 30 of\nKhartoum state of the districts of El Azhari, El Shajara, El Azozab,\nLamab, Hamadab, pointed to the emergence of watery diarrhea in his\nconstituency, especially at El Shajara. He attributed the\ndeterioration of the health situation in the area to the lack of\nsewage system and the stagnation of rainwater. Health sources revealed the emergence of a number of cases of cholera\nin the academic hospital in Khartoum. Northern state\n\nIn the Northern state, the isolation centre at Delgo Hospital received\n3 new cases of cholera on Sun 20 Aug 2017. Nubian activist Ashraf\nAbdelwedoud warned in an interview with Radio Dabanga of the\nincreasing rates of the disease following the rains and floods in the\narea in the past few days. He called on the authorities to make\nefforts to curb the spread of the disease. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of the Republic of the Sudan can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ The mortality from cholera and most diarrheal illnesses is related to\nnon-replacement of fluid and electrolytes from the diarrheal illness. As stated in Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In: Chronic illness\nand disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract. Greydanus DE,\nAtay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in press), oral\nrehydration therapy can be life-saving in outbreaks of cholera and\nother forms of diarrhea: \"As reviewed by Richard Guerrant et al (1), it was in 1831 that\ncholera treatment could be accomplished by intravenous replacement,\nand, although this therapy could produce dramatic improvements, not\nuntil 1960 was it 1st recognized that there was no true destruction of\nthe intestinal mucosa, and gastrointestinal rehydration therapy could\nbe effective, and the therapy could dramatically reduce the\nintravenous needs for rehydration. Indeed, that this rehydration could\nbe just as effective given orally as through an orogastric tube (for\nexample, refs 2 and 3) made it possible for oral rehydration therapy\n(ORT) to be used in rural remote areas and truly impact on the\nmorbidity and mortality of cholera. Indeed, Guerrant et al (1)\nhighlights the use of oral glucose-salt packets in war-torn\nBangladeshi refugees, which reduced the mortality rate from 30 per\ncent to 3.6 per cent (4) and quotes sources referring to ORT as\n\"potentially the most important medical advance\" of the 20th century.\nA variety of formulations of ORT exist, generally glucose or rice\npowder-based, which contain a variety of micronutrients, especially\nzinc (5). \"The assessment of the degree of volume loss in those with diarrhea to\napproximate volume and fluid losses can be found in ref 6 below. Those\nwith severe hypovolemia should be initially rehydrated intravenously\nwith a fluid bolus of normal saline or Ringer's lactate solution of\n20-30 ml/kg followed by 100 ml/kg in the 1st 4 hours and 100 ml/kg\nover the next 18 hours with regular reassessment. Those with lesser\ndegrees of hypovolemia can be rehydrated orally with a glucose or\nrice-derived formula with up to 4 liters in the 1st 4 hours, and those\nwith no hypovolemia can be given ORT after each liquid stool with\nfrequent reevaluation. \"References\n-\n1. Guerrant RL, Carneiro-Filho BA, Dillingham RA. Cholera, diarrhea,\nand oral rehydration therapy: triumph and indictment. Clin Infect Dis.\n2003; 37(3): 398-405; available at\n(http://cid.oxfordjournals.org/content/37/3/398.long).\n2. Gregorio GV, Gonzales ML, Dans LF, Martinez EG. Polymer-based oral\nrehydration solution for treating acute watery diarrhoea. Cochrane\nDatabase Syst Rev. 2009; (2): CD006519. doi:\n10.1002/14651858.CD006519.pub2; available at\n(http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD006519.pub3/full).\n3. Gore SM, Fontaine O, Pierce NF. Impact of rice based oral\nrehydration solution on stool output and duration of diarrhoea:\nmeta-analysis of 13 clinical trials. BMJ 1992; 304(6822): 287-91;\navailable at (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1881081/).\n4. Mahalanabis D, Choudhuri AB, Bagchi NG, et al. Oral fluid therapy\nof cholera among Bangladesh refugees. Johns Hopkins Med 1973; 132(4):\n197-205; available at\n(http://www.searo.who.int/publications/journals/seajph/media/2012/seajph_v1n1/whoseajphv1i1p105.pdf).\n5. Atia AN, Buchman AL. Oral rehydration solutions in non-cholera\ndiarrhea: a review. Am J Gastroenterol 2009; 104(10): 2596-604;\nabstract available at (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19550407).\n6. WHO. The treatment of diarrhoea, a manual for physicians and other\nsenior health workers. 4th ed. 2005; available at:\n(http://whqlibdoc.who.int/publications/2005/9241593180.pdf).\n- Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]},"114":{"title":"Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t","date":["26","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy  Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15 <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania  Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics   Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert. Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Mainichi (edited) (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170821/p2g/00m/0dm/077000c)   Japan's health ministry has issued a warning for people traveling to Europe on the back of an outbreak of measles in countries such as Italy and Romania. The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is advising tourists to go to hospital if they develop a high fever or generalized rash after returning to Japan.  Although the World Health Organization verified that Japan has eliminated infections of endemic measles strains in 2015, group infections originating from people who contracted the disease abroad are spreading in the country. As of 6 Aug 2017, the number of patients reached 169 this year in Japan, already eclipsing the figure in the previous year.  About 4100 patients in Italy and around 6500 patients in Romania have already been confirmed as of August 2017 compared with about 860 and 2000, respectively, throughout 2016, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.  Symptoms of the highly contagious disease include runny nose, red and watery eyes, high fever, and rash. The virus is spread through coughing and sneezing and can cause complications such as pneumonia and can even result in death in one in 1000 patients, according to the ministry. The ministry recommends people traveling overseas to check their vaccination records and take an additional shot if they have only been vaccinated once.  The disease was prevalent about a decade ago in Japan with the number of patients soaring to over 10 000 in 2008 but the country was later considered as free from infections of the virus.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy. Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017 5:36 PM AEST. Source: News.com.au, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report (edited) (http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/fourth-case-of-measles-at-perth-school/news-story/ece041f55111645e10f70046d92479dd)   A 4th child has been diagnosed with measles at Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, more than a week after the health department gave an on-site vaccine to students. A Health Department spokeswoman confirmed the latest case, which came 3 weeks after the highly contagious disease was first detected in an unvaccinated year 10 student who had returned from Italy.  Revelations that about half the school's 400 students were unvaccinated against the disease led the Health Department to offer a voluntary, free on-site vaccine to students, but it is unknown how many took up the offer.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK   Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15. Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2017; 22(34) (edited) (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22861)   ref: Werber D, Hoffmann A, Santibanez S, et al. Large measles outbreak introduced by asylum seekers and spread among the insufficiently vaccinated resident population, Berlin, October 2014 to August 2015. Euro Surveill. 2017; 22(34): pii=30599 - Abstract  The largest measles outbreak in Berlin since 2001 occurred from October 2014 to August 2015. Overall, 1344 cases were ascertained, 86 per cent (with available information) unvaccinated, including 146 (12 per cent) asylum seekers. Median age was 17 years (interquartile range: 4-29 years), 26 per cent were hospitalised and a 1 year old child died. Measles virus genotyping uniformly revealed the variant 'D8-Rostov-Don' and descendants. The virus was likely introduced by and initially spread among asylum seekers before affecting Berlin's resident population. Among Berlin residents, the highest incidence was in children younger than 2 years, yet most cases (52 per cent) were adults. Post-exposure vaccinations in homes for asylum seekers, not always conducted, occurred later (median: 7.5 days) than the recommended 72 hours after onset of the 1st case and reached only half of potential contacts. Asylum seekers should not only have non-discriminatory, equitable access to vaccination, they also need to be offered measles vaccination in a timely fashion, that is, immediately upon arrival in the receiving country. Supplementary immunisation activities targeting the resident population, particularly adults, are urgently needed in Berlin.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5857). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania. Date: Fri 25 August 2017. Source: Romania Insider (edited) (https://www.romania-insider.com/measles-kills-iraqi-refugee/)   The ongoing measles outbreak keeps making victims in Romania. A 10 month old girl, who was a refugee from Iraq, became the 33rd person to die of the infection, reports local Digi24. The girl arrived in Romania on 7 Jul 2017 with her family, and the doctors diagnosed her with measles in August. They also discovered that the child was suffering from malnutrition and severe psychomotor retardation.  The measles outbreak is still a major problem in Romania, with more than 8900 cases reported across the country until 25 Aug 2017, including 33 deaths, according to data from the National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT). Most deaths were registered in Timis (9), Dolj (7), and Arad (6) counties.  Measles is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by a virus. It causes a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and runny nose. According to information posted on WHO's website, the virus is highly contagious, spreading by coughing and sneezing, close personal contact, and direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions. Unvaccinated young children pose the highest risk of measles and its complications, including death.  The Romanian Government adopted earlier this month August 2017 a draft bill on the organization and financing of population vaccination (https://www.romania-insider.com/romania-draft-bill-vaccination/). The project was sent to the Parliament for approval and could come into force in January 2018.  byline: Irina Marica   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Measles tends to be more severe in children who are malnourished, especially children who are also vitamin A deficient. And complications are commoner and more serious in malnourished children. Because of complications such as diarrhoea, measles may lead to failure to thrive. Infection with measles virus may lead to kwashiorkor or marasmus in children who are underweight at the time that they get infected. Therefore, measles may result in, or aggravate, malnutrition.  Maps of Romania can be found at (http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK   Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics. Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017. Source: News-Medical/Life Sciences (edited) (https://www.news-medical.net/news/20170826/New-study-highlights-role-played-by-demographics-in-the-spread-of-measles.aspx)   Even if the incidence of measles infection has decreased by at least 90 per cent worldwide since the introduction of the vaccine, measles is still one of the major causes of death in children among vaccine-preventable diseases. Regular measles epidemics are reported in developing countries and recurrent episodic outbreaks occur in the developed world.  A new study by Bocconi University and Bruno Kessler Foundation analyzing 9 countries (Australia, Ethiopia, Kenya, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases see reference below, highlights the role played by demographics in the spread of measles and concludes that future vaccination strategies in high-fertility countries should focus on increasing childhood immunization rates, while immunization campaigns targeting adolescents and young adults are required in low fertility countries.  Using a transmission model calibrated on historical serological data the authors estimate that the susceptible proportion of the population (that is, unprotected against the infection) varies from about 3 per cent in the UK to more than 12.5 per cent in Ethiopia, with astonishing differences in its age composition, due to different vaccination strategies and divergent demographic trends. While the percentage of over-15 among susceptible individuals in Ethiopia and Kenya is, respectively, 28 per cent and 43 per cent, adolescents and young adults represent 74 per cent of unprotected individuals in South Korea, 66 per cent in Italy and 53 per cent in the US, with considerable immunity gaps in individuals aged 30-40 years.  \"Every effort to increase the vaccination coverage rate among children is praiseworthy\", says Alessia Melegaro, a Bocconi professor and principal investigator of DECIDE, the ERC European Research Council-funded project which produced the article, \"but in some developed countries it's the lack of coverage among adolescents and adults that poses a serious threat to the goal of eliminating measles.\"  \"Measles incidence could increase, in the next decades, in Italy, Australia, and Singapore and Ethiopia is at high risk of future large epidemics\", says Stefano Merler from Bruno Kessler Foundation, \"and this is particularly worrying considering that individuals get infected later in life when the disease is more severe. The median age at infection for 2015 was estimated to be 5-10 years in the UK, Ireland, and Ethiopia; 10-15 years in the USA, Australia, Singapore, and Kenya; and older than 20 years in Italy and South Korea\".  The proposed model shows that the introduction of the measles vaccine, which occurred at different times in the 9 countries, has considerably reduced the disease burden in terms of disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs), a measure expressed as the number of years lost because of illness, disability, or early death. Every vaccine dose averts 2 or 3 weeks of DALYs in the developed world and around 20 weeks in Kenya and Ethiopia. Which translates into 2-mln years 2 million DALYs since the vaccine introduction in the UK, 13-mln 13 million DALYs in the US, and 36-mln 36 million DALYs in Ethiopia.  \"Vaccination has undoubtedly achieved incredible results in terms of public health. In particular,\" continues Prof Melegaro \"our analysis showed that routine 1st dose vaccine administration has been responsible for more than 90 per cent of the overall number of vaccine-immunized individuals in most countries. In Ethiopia and Kenya, catch-up and follow-up campaigns substantially mitigated the effect of suboptimum routine vaccine coverage, generating 25-45 per cent of the immunized fraction of the population. Tailoring immunization campaigns to achieve measles eradication goals is essential and currently, for some countries, this means considering also the role of unprotected adolescents and young adults.\"   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Reference - Trentini F, Poletti P, Merler S, Melegaro A. Measles immunity gaps and the progress towards elimination: a multi-country modelling analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30421-8. Epub ahead of print; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28807627).   While it is recommended that children get 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12 through 15 months of age, and the 2nd dose at 4 through 6 years of age, this study emphasizes that it is important that adolescents and young adults also are up to date on their MMR vaccination. - Mod.LK  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"299":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (95): Africa, Asia","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (95): Africa, Asia","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (95): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi)\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi) police\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Tana River county)\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong>, <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - Nigeria (Borno state) IDPs\n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Cholera - Sudan\n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Cholera, diarrhea - Eastern and Southern Africa Region\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab) \nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi).\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017 9:09 AM EAT.\nSource: Capital FM (edited)\n(https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/2017/09/cholera-cases-in-nairobi-rise-to-88/) \nThe number of people admitted to various hospitals in Nairobi after\ntesting positive for cholera has now risen to 88. Nairobi Governor\nMike Sonko stated that as at 8 pm Sunday night, 3 Sep 2017, Sinai\nHospital in Rongai had admitted 50 patients who tested positive, while\nNairobi Women's Hospital had 26. Sonko indicated that those admitted\nto Kenyatta National Hospital were 12 and that \"teams from the\nnational and county governments have been on the ground all day.\" He\nsaid that investigations are still ongoing to ascertain and confirm\nthe diagnosis and the sources of the infection. \"The status of all patients is reported to be stable and under\ncontrol.\" He further appealed to city residents not to panic, as\nadequate controls have been put in place to prevent the spread of the\ndisease. \"Above all, let's continue observing high standards of\nhygiene, while ensuring we eat properly cooked food, cleaned\nvegetables and fruits,\" he stated. Byline: Simon Ndonga \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Kenya can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/kck73tk) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/174). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi) police.\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, EstAfrican report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/kenya/more-90-police-officers-hit-cholera-nairobi) \nAt least 95 police officers have been hospitalized in Kenya with\nsuspected cases of cholera. According to the Health ministry, the\nofficers are said to have been infected after taking meals at the\nNairobi Area Police Canteen. On Sun 3 Sep 2017, some 59 officers were hospitalised in various\nhospitals in Nairobi with another 36 admitted Mon 4 Sep 2017, after\ncontracting the disease. They were part of a group of 430 officers\ndeployed to Nairobi ahead of the Supreme Court ruling on presidential\npoll petition on Fri 1 Sep 2017. They were residing at the\nMultimedia University Hotel in Rongai, about 17 kilometers 10.6 mi\nsouth of the capital. \"Those infected did not get the disease from the Multimedia University\nsince they had their lunch away from the institution. Investigations\nshow that the source is the Nairobi Area Police Canteen,\" said Dr\nRalph Muli, the Nairobi County head of Diseases Surveillance.\nConsequently, the City has temporarily closed the canteen. The Health Cabinet Secretary Cleopa Mailu said the officers were in\nstable condition. Dr Mailu said investigations were underway to\nestablish whether the canteen had outsourced services to cater for the\nlarge number of officers. He said the ministry was concerned that\ninstead of eliminating cholera, new cases were emerging. Nairobi was first hit by the outbreak on 19 May 2017, with 56 cases\nhaving been reported. One of the police officers who requested anonymity said they ate ugali\n(a Kenyan staple made of maize flour) and meat stew at the canteen on\nSat 2 Sep 2017. He said he started feeling sick in the evening. Byline: Lillian Mutavi \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Tana River county).\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017 10:33 AM.\nSource: KDRTV News, The Daily Nation report (edited)\n(http://www.kdrtv.com/21-people-test-positive-for-cholera-in-tana-river/) \nAt least 20 National Youth Service (NYS) officers have been infected\nwith cholera in Tana River county. County health officials said the 20\nofficers from Bura NYS camp have been admitted to the Bura Sub-County\nHospital. According to Oscar Endekwa, the County Director for Public\nHealth, 21 cholera cases have been reported in the county. Speaking to Nation in his office in Hola, Dr Endekwa said the\nsituation at the NYS camp was under control. \"The officers are\nresponding well to treatment. The other case is of a resident and he\nhas been placed under treatment,\" he said. He added that the symptoms\nwere noted on August 30, though they had not been confirmed, adding\nthat health officials are investigating the cause of the disease. Besides isolating victims, Dr Endekwa said the county is also\nsensitizing residents on hygiene and sanitation. \"We are trying to\ncombat it before it spreads to a larger population,\" he added. He\nasked residents to report any suspicious cases and urged them to drink\nclean water and wash their hands after visiting toilets. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Nigeria (Borno state) IDPs.\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017 2:10 AM WAT.\nSource: Daily Trust (edited)\n(https://www.dailytrust.com.ng/cholera-outbreak-kills-7-idps-in-borno.html) \nOn 3 Sep 2017, 7 internally displaced persons (IDPs) were confirmed\ndead as a result of a cholera outbreak at some IDP camps in Borno\nState This came just 3 weeks after about 100 others were discharged\nfrom Muna and Dala Lawanti Cholera treatment centers. The Médecins\nSans Frontières (MSF) in Maiduguri said the cholera outbreak was due\nto downpours in the last 3 days that caused flood at the affected IDP\ncamps. The Commissioner of Health in the state, Dr Haruna Mshelia said\nmeasures had been taken to contain it from further spread. \"I cannot\ntell you the death toll, as I continue to visit all camps in Maiduguri\nand ensure that the epidemic does not further spread to claim more\nlives,\" he said. One of the rescue workers at Muna Garage IDP camp told newsmen that\nfor only yesterday 3 Sep 2017, they had admitted over 50 patients. \"We have holistic measures to address this cholera outbreak urgently\nalthough people are dying day by day. More than 100 people are\naffected so far, and 51 people were admitted. In the last 24 hours, we\nhave received over 50 patients at MSF's Cholera Treatment Unit at\nDala. Total patients admitted from the start of the outbreak till now\nis over 200 with 100 discharges and 7 dead,\" the rescue worker who\nspoke in confidence, said. The Medical Director of the Médecins Sans Frontières, Anna Cillers,\nalso told newsmen in Maiduguri measures had been put in place to\nprevent further spread of cholera across the metropolis and IDP\ncamps. On Sat 2 Sep 2017, the ministry had said the cholera toll was 14 in\nthe town of Maiduguri, with most of the victims living in a camp for\npeople displaced by Boko Haram violence. \"As of 4 Sep 2017, 21 deaths\nhave been reported,\" the Borno state health ministry said, as the toll\nmounts. \"The total number of suspected cholera cases is now 375 in\nMaiduguri,\" it said, up from 186 at the weekend. Most of the suspected\ncases and deaths are in Muna Garage, a camp for displaced people on\nthe outskirts of Maiduguri, while other victims come from neighboring\ndistricts, it said. From 27 Aug until 31 Aug 2017, 17 people\nreportedly succumbed to cholera. In Zamzam camp, south of El Fasher\ncity, 4 new cases of cholera were recorded on 1 and 2 Sep 2017. A camp\nelder told this station that the isolation ward was closed on the 1st\nday of Eid Al Adha Sacrifice Feast, 31 Aug-4 Sep 2017, \"because of\nthe absence of medical personnel, so the 4 new patients had to be\ntransferred to El Fasher for treatment.\" Central Darfur\n\nIsolation centers in Zalingei and Abta village, Central Darfur,\nrecorded 3 deaths and 37 new infection cases from 1-3 Sep 2017,\naccording to the coordinator of camps in the state, El Shafee\nAbdallah. In Hamidiya camp, 3 cholera patients died and 13 people\ninfected with cholera reported to the isolation centre. The people are from Abta, Tiri, Dirlo, and\nKalgo,\" El Shafee said. A medical source in the area told Radio Dabanga that\nthe Royal Hospital in Ed Damazin received 4 cholera cases of cholera,\nfrom Arquette North. \"2 of them died on Wed 30 Aug 2017.\" Another medical source reported that last week week of 28 Aug 2017,\nthe hospital received 25 cases of cholera from different parts of El\nRoseires. 4 cases were recorded in Gisan locality. \"El Roseires\nlocality recorded the highest number of casualties of all localities\nin Blue Nile. There is a severe neglect of the number of staff in the\nisolation wards, because they were off for the Eid Al Adha holiday.\" Blue Nile was the 1st state to report cases of cholera in September\n2016, or 'acute watery diarrhea' as the Sudanese government has\nreferred to it since the start of the cholera outbreak. A UK-based\nSudanese specialist told Radio Dabanga in January 2017 that cholera\n\"seems to be a stigma for the government.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Sudan can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Cholera, diarrhea - Eastern and Southern Africa Region.\nDate: Thu 31 Aug 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, UNICEF report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/somalia/bulletin-choleraawd-outbreaks-eastern-and-southern-africa-regional-update-31-august) \nMore than 100 780 cholera/AWD acute watery diarrhea cases and 1496\ndeaths (CFR: 1.5 percent) have been reported in 12 of 21 countries of\nEastern and Southern Africa Region (ESAR) since the beginning of 2017.\nThese countries include: Somalia, Kenya, South Sudan, Tanzania,\nBurundi, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Angola, Uganda, Zambia, and\nRwanda. Somalia accounts for 76.6 percent of the total cases reported\nin the outbreak in 2017, followed by South Sudan at 15.7 percent. In the past 2-3 weeks (weeks 32-34/6-27 Aug 2017), 6 out of the 21\ncountries in ESAR have reported active transmission of cholera/AWD\n(Burundi, Malawi, Somalia, South Sudan, Kenya, and Tanzania). Tanzania\nhas recorded the highest CFR (1.8 percent) followed by South Sudan\n(1.7 percent) in 2017. CFR for Somalia was above 2 percent at the\nbeginning of 2017 but has since dropped to 1.4 percent. Somalia\n-\nThere has been a decrease in the epidemic trend. During week 33 (week\nending 20 Aug 2017), 222 new cases and no deaths were reported in the\ncountry; compared to 282 cases reported in week 32 (week ending 13 Aug\n2017). Out of the 222 new cases, 97 were reported from South Central\nand 125 were from Somali land. Most affected regions are Banadir,\nTogdheer, Awdal, Mjeex, and Lower Jubba. Kenya\n\n4 out of the 47 counties (Garissa, Nairobi, Turkana, and Nakuru) have\nan active cholera outbreak. During week 33, 19 new cases were reported\ncompared to 69 cases in week 32. South Sudan\n\nMost affected populations are nomadic pastoralists and communities\nliving in hard to reach villages and cattle camps. There has been a\ndecrease in the epidemic trend over the past 3 weeks. During week 32,\n30 new cases were reported; compared to 102 cases including 1 death\n(CFR 1 percent) in week 31 (week ending 6 Aug 2017). Active\ntransmission reported in Kapoeta East, South and North, Tonj East,\nYirol East, Nyirol, Ayod, Duk, and Juba. Tanzania\n\nAn increase in epidemic trend. During week 34 (week ending 27 Aug\n2017), 102 new cases have been reported in Tanzanian mainland;\ncompared to 67 cases in week 33. Cases emerged from Mbeya, Iringa, and\nKatavi regions. Malawi\n\nThe current outbreak started within the catchment area of the Chikwawa\nHospital. 11 new cases have been reported in week 34; compared to 2\ncases reported in week 33. Burundi\n-\nThe first case of the current outbreak was identified on 13 Aug 2017\nfrom Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Since then there has been an\nincrease in the epidemic trend with 24 cases reported in week 34; as\ncompared to 13 cases reported in week 33. No death has been reported\nand most of the cases emerged from the city center of Nyanza Lac. Uganda\n\nNo confirmed case of cholera in 2017, only AWD cases reported. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The countries mentioned above can be seen located on the map of\nAfrica at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6075). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \nAsia\n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab).\nDate: Tue 5 Sep 2017 12:32 AM IST.\nSource: The Tribune India (edited)\n(http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/this-day-that-year/cholera-in-lahore/462284.html) \nWe understand that cholera is assuming a virulent form in Lahore\nPunjab and that strong and effective measures are called for to\ncombat and stamp out the disease. In Kucha Kharasian in Haveli Mian\nKhan it is said 4 persons were taken ill at about noon and died the\nsame day. The next day, 5 persons were taken ill of the same disease.\nIt is, of course, impossible for laymen to make out whether all these\ncases were of cholera, but the nature of the deaths would seem to\nsuggest the urgent need of effective action. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofworld.com/pakistan/pakistan-political-map.html) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2128). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 per cent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are:\n- Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 per cent (95 per cent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam;\n- Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. WHO prequalified vaccines.\n(https://extranet.who.int/gavi/PQ_Web/).\n61. Balk YO, Choi SK, Olveda RM, et al. A randomized, non-inferiority\ntrial comparing two bivalent killed, whole cell, oral cholera vaccines\n(Euvichol vs Shanchol) in the Philippines. Vaccine 2015; 33(46):\n6350-65; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26348402).\n62. Freedman DO. Re-born in the USA: another cholera vaccine for\ntravellers. Travel Med Infect Dis. 2016; 14(4): 295-6; abstract\navailable at\n(http://www.travelmedicinejournal.com/article/S1477-8939(16)30087-4/abstract).\n63. Qadri F, Wierzba TF, Ali M, et al. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Kiribati":{},"Kosovo":{},"Kuwait":{},"Kyrgyzstan":{"101":{"title":"Lumpy skin disease, bovine - Kazakhstan (02): (WK) spread susp,\r\n\tRFI ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Lumpy skin disease, bovine - Kazakhstan (02): (WK) spread susp,\r\n\tRFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Sun 20 Aug 2017. Source: Kloop (Kyrgyzstan) in Russian, machine trans., edited (https://kloop.kg/blog/2017/08/20/kazahstan-veterinary-ishhut-prichinu-massovoj-gibeli-korov/)   At least 120 head of cattle have been killed in the Atyrau region West Kazakhstan; the cause of the death of the animals is unknown. The Kazakh edition of \"Ak Zhayik\" states that 120 cows died in the Isatay district of Atyrau region in the west of Kazakhstan map at (http://tinyurl.com/y9ksmu2x) in the period from 20 Jul to August 2017.  Veterinarians do not know the cause of the animal's deaths.\"Since the cattle are still in the pastures, the owners themselves bring sick animals to us. Although they do not have a high temperature, they still cannot save them,\" said veterinarian Islamgali Mardashev.  The meat of the dead cows was sent for testing in the laboratories of Astana and Almaty, but so far there are no results see comment below. It is only known that before dying the temperature of the animals rises, and there is weakness and lumps under the skin.  In the summer of 2016, the Atyrau oblast similarly suffered a massive loss of livestock; more than 800 cattle died. All of them had nodular dermatitis. More than 6000 cattle were infected with the disease.  byline: Alexandra Titova   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  From 10 to 15 Jun 2016, a disease which later was recognized as lumpy skin disease (LSD) was recorded in a cattle holding on the territory adjacent to the village of Chapayevo, West Kazakhstan (see archive no. http://promedmail.org/post/20160717.4350687; at this point in time, laymen, followed by the media, erroneously related to the undiagnosed and most probably unfamiliar new disease as foot and mouth disease. Please see relevant commentary in the subsequent postings no. http://promedmail.org/post/20160722.4362368 and http://promedmail.org/post/20160723.4365082).  On 7 Jul 2016, Kazakhstan reported (see archive no. http://promedmail.org/post/20160722.4363497) a single LSD outbreak in Makasch, Kurmangazinskiy, Mangashlak (western to Atyrau; map at (http://tinyurl.com/ycb4j9h7)), stating that it had started on 7 Jul 2016. According to the report, the susceptible population was 3557 head including 459 clinical cases of which 34 died, the 425 remaining sick animals \"killed and disposed of\". No stamping out applied and no additional case reported in the 12 follow-up reports, the last of which, no.12, submitted on 26 Nov 2017, stated: 1. Compensation to the animals' owners for dead cattle at the market price is being developed and will be implemented soon. All 459 diseased cattle heads were destroyed and the final disinfection was carried out. 2. The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted. Follow-up report no.12, with links to all previous reports, is available at (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?reportid=21682).  Although according to media reports vaccination was applied, no details of such were included in the 12 follow-up reports nor in Kazakhstan's semi-annual summary report to the OIE (July-December 2016), which included the epidemiological statistics above; the item \"control measures\" (against LSD) did not include \"vaccination\".  The current media report, from a Kyrgyz source (citing a Kazakh newspaper), says that during the 2016 event, 6000 animals were infected, of which 600 died. An earlier media report, from Kazakhstan, dated 27 Jul 2016, said that the number of diseased animals \"exceeded 2000, of which 50 head of cattle died\" (see archive no. http://promedmail.org/post/20160727.4374008).  Kazakhstan is the world's largest landlocked country, and the 9th largest in the world. The belated diagnosis in 2016, and its continued absence, so far, during the current event, is puzzling; following the acquiring of independence in Dec 1991, Kazakhstan obtained support from the West, particularly USA, in the establishment of state-of-the-art laboratories for research and diagnosis of infectious diseases in man and animals.  Early report on the factual circulation and distribution of LSD within Kazakhstan is anticipated. Neighboring countries may take steps to prevent its introduction; those countries include China, Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan. Russia is LSD-infected (last follow-up report addressing 2 new outbreaks in Saratov oblast, adjacent to West Kazakhstan, published 24 Aug 2017).  For the diagnosis of LSD, samples from clinically affected animals should preferably be derived from their typical dermal lesions; organs from dead animals which should be sent for laboratory tests are specified in OIE's Manual. The submission of \"meat of dead cows\" for testing in the laboratories, as reported, may not be ideal for timely diagnosis of LSD. - Mod.AS  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/46186).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Laos":{"115":{"title":"Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nDENGUE/DHF UPDATE (10): ASIA, PACIFIC, AFRICA, RESEARCH, WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries Asia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National\n- National\n- National\nIndia\n- National\n- Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Assam\n- Delhi\n- Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore)\n- Tamil Nadu\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Kerala\n- Karnataka\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- West Bengal (Kolkata)\n- West Bengal (Birbhum)\n- West Bengal (Siliguri)\n- Odisha (Ganjam)\n- Odisha\n- Gujarat (Ahmedabad)\n- Jharkhand (Jamshedpur)\n- Telangana (Hyderabad)\nPakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\nChina\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp)\n- Hong Kong SAR\n- Macau SAR\n- Macau SAR\nTaiwan\nMyanmar\n- National\n- Kayah\nIndonesia\n- Papua (Jayapura)\nViet Nam\n- National\n- National\n- Mekong Delta\n- Hanoi\n- Ha Nam\nPhilippines\n- National\n- Cebu\n- Negros Occidental\n- Negros Occidental (Bacolod City)\n- Cavite (Trece Martires City)\nLaos\n- National\nJapan ex Côte d'Ivoire Pacific\n\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Fiji\n- French Polynesia (Tahiti) Africa\n\n- Côte d'Ivoire\n- Côte d'Ivoire <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence\n- Air travel related spread of dengue\n- Visual impact <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> World Health Organization update \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries\nAsia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National. 26 Jul 2017. Sri Lanka has now notified 107 015 cases,\nwhich WHO estimates is 4.3 times more than the average number of cases\nusually reported (http://tinyurl.com/ycvszzs8). - National. 19 Aug 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. This compares with about 39 000 cases reported from January\nto August 2016, and 55 150 cases during the entire year 2016.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - National. 25 Aug 2017. The total has risen to 28 702, with 2536 cases\nand 10 deaths last week week of 24 Jul 2017. Floods continued to wreak\nhavoc in the 3 states, which reported 88 more dengue-related deaths.\nOfficials said 33 more dengue-related deaths had been reported in\nUttar Pradesh over the last 2 days.\n(http://www.christianmessenger.in/floods-in-bihar-up-assam-88-die-in-dengue-related-deaths/) - Delhi. 31 Jul 2017. As of 29 Jul 2017, 180 cases of dengue (monsoon\narrived early).\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/882984/dengue-malaria-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise-in-delhi/) - Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore). 4 Aug 2017. Deaths rise to 16 in last 2\nmonths; new admissions increasing.\n(http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/2-more-dengue-deaths-in-coimbatore-total-deaths-now-16-117080401128_1.html) - Tamil Nadu. 11 Aug 2017. Prevalence of dengue in Tamil Nadu is\ndecreasing. Dengue scare at RG Kar Hospital\nMedical College hostel; at least 8 test positive over the last week.\nIn 2015, more than 30 were affected in the hostel campus and one died.\nOn 2016 too, more than a dozen inmates were affected.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/dengue-scare-at-rg-kar-hostel-8-test-positive/articleshow/60029232.cms) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nAnirban Ghosh\nKasturba Medical College\n(m_anirbanghosh@hotmail.com) - West Bengal (Birbhum). 21 Aug 2017. At least 100 cases dengue have\nbeen reported from West Bengal's Birbhum district. \"We have received\nreports of at least 100 cases of dengue since 23 Jul 2017. While\nabout 60 of these cases are from the Dubrajpur town in the district's\nSuri Sadar sub-division, the rest are from other areas such as Bolpur\nand Rampurhat towns. But no one has died so far,\" the chief medical\nofficer of Birbhum, Himadri Ari, told The Hindu.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/bengal-records-100-dengue-cases/article19535541.ece) - West Bengal (Siliguri). 23 Aug 2017. The number of people suffering\nfrom dengue is rising at an alarming rate in Siliguri. According to\nrecords, the highest number of dengue cases reported was 54. This year\n2017, the mark has been crossed.\n(http://siliguritimes.com/number-dengue-patients-rise-siliguri/) - Odisha (Ganjam). 22 Jul 2017. Blood samples of 116 people of the\ndistrict were recently tested and 4 dengue positive cases were\ndetected. Last year 2016 4348\npersons were tested positive for the dengue virus by this period with\n8 deaths. Out of total 402 infected persons, 67 were tested positive\nin Bhadrak district, 61 in Cuttack district, and 59 in Balasore\ndistrict. Similarly, 35 people have been infected in Khordha, 34 in\nJajpur, 24 in Puri, 20 in Jagatsinghpur . Meanwhile, Kendrapara has\nregistered 20, Ganjam 13, Keonjhar 10, Dhenkanal 11, Bolangir 6, and\nMayurbhanj 5 cases of dengue. While Nayagarh, Sonepur, Kalahandi,\nAngul, and Bargarh registered 3 cases each, Nuapada and Kandhamal\nwitnessed 2 cases. Boudh, Rayagada, Sundargarh and Deogarh districts\nrecorded with single case each. However, 12 patients have come to the\nstate from neighbouring states.\n(http://pragativadi.com/dengue-claims-two-lives-affects-402-odisha/) - Gujarat (Ahmedabad). 1 Aug 2017. A total of 59 cases in July 2017.\nThe actual number of cases is said to be 'far more'; it takes at least\n15 days to confirm cases.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/59-dengue-cases-in-july-amc/articleshow/59853414.cms) - Jharkhand (Jamshedpur). 30 Jul 2017. 75 positive cases in Kolhan and\nadjoining area of Jamshedpur.\n(http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/dengue-cases-rise-positive-cases-shoot-75-kolhan/111026/) - Telangana (Hyderabad). 25 Jul 2017. All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. As per a weekly report issued by Prevention and Control\nProgram for Dengue in Sindh, as many as 27 new dengue fever cases\nsurfaced in the city from 1 to 7 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/08/363624/a27-more-dengue-cases-surface-in-karachi/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 8 Aug 2017. 3rd death due to dengue\nhemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. Most of the affected patients were\nbrought from the Tehkal Payan area from where water samples have been\ncollected to determine the situation.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1476245/third-dengue-death-\nreported-k-p/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 16 Aug 2017. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. Dengue continues in\nPeshawar, claiming 7 lives with 69 new cases reported from different\nareas of the city during the last 24 hours, raising the number of\ntotal cases to 1703. So far, he said, 7 deaths including 6 from Khyber\nTeaching Hospital and one in Hayatabad Medical Complex were reported\nfrom dengue epidemics in Peshawar. Out of 69 new cases, 41 were\nreported in Khyber Teaching Hospital (KTH), 13 in Hayatabad Medical\nComplex (HMC), 12 in Lady Reading Hospital (LRH), and 3 in Naseerullah\nKhan Babar Teaching Hospital (NBTH), Peshawar, he said. A rapid\nresponse team has also been set up with mandate to swiftly reach to\nthe affected areas from where new cases were surfaced besides helping\nthe field staff in conduct of fumigation spray, removal of larvae, and\nprovision of other necessary medicines.\n(https://dnd.com.pk/dengue-rampage-in-peshawar-kills-seven-69-new-cases-surface/133250) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://pakistanmap.facts.co/pakistanmapof/PakistanAdministrativeMap.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ China\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp). 16 Aug 2017.\nGuangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in south China has reported its 1st\nimported dengue case this year 2017, local inspection and quarantine\nbureau said.
