Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.  The location of these outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  As reported in EUFMD's most recent Global FMD situation report (July 2017), the WRLFMD at Pirbright has sequenced a field isolate received there from Mongolia (O/MOG/10/2017), genotyped as 'O/ME-SA/PanAsia'. The Mongolian virus was subjected to vaccine matching strain differentiation (VMSD) test, with the following results: \"good matching results with O/TUR/5/2009 but not with O 3039 and Manisa\". It will be interesting to note if the vaccine applied in Mongolia has been selected according to the said VMSD test results. The genotyping results above are not yet available on the WRLFMD website.  An OIE interactive map showing the locations of the 20 FMDV-O outbreaks reported from Mongolia since the start of the event (20 Jan 2017) is available at (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?fupser=&dothis=&reportid=22811).  According to Mongolia's National Broadcast, dated 30 Aug 2017 (machine-translated from (https://www.mnb.mn/i/121355)), FMD is also circulating in the eastern province (aimag) of Sukhbaatar, as well as the central province of Tuv (Tov), and in 2 districts (soums) (Songino Khairkhan and Khan-Uul) of the Mongolian capital of Ulaanbaatar. This presents a spread of the virus westwards, not yet reported to the OIE (map at (http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Mongolia.gif)).  The media report also includes the following data on vaccination: \"The vaccination program was implemented from 11 Aug 2017 in 934 427 livestock . Currently, vaccinations of 750 363 heads of livestock in 6 districts are being implemented, of which 83.7 percent have already been completed.\" It is not clear if the said vaccinations cover also the recently infected central regions. - Mod.AS  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Montenegro":{},"Morocco":{},"Mozambique":{"71":{"title":"Anthrax - Mozambique: (MP) wildlife, OIE ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Anthrax - Mozambique: (MP) wildlife, OIE [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nANTHRAX - MOZAMBIQUE: (MAPUTO) WILDLIFE, OIE\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2017; 30(34) (edited)\n(http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24609) \nAnthrax, Mozambique\n-\nInformation received on 22 Aug 2017 from Dr Américo Da Conceicao,\nnational director, Veterinary Services, Ministry of Agriculture,\nMaputo, Mozambique \nReport type: immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 11 Aug 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 11 Aug 2017\nReport date: 21 Aug 2017\nReason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: August 2008\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Bacillus anthracis_\nNature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country New outbreaks (1)\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak 1 (1/w-Moz/2017): Karingani game reserve, Mapulanguene,\nMagude, Maputo\nDate of start of the outbreak: 11 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nAffected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of /\nSlaughtered\nAfrican Elephant: _Loxodonta Africana_ (Elephantidae)/ / 2 / 2 / 0 /\n0\nGreater kudu:_Tragelaphus strepsiceros_ (Bovidae)/ / 1 / 1 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: Two elephants were found dead close to the dried\nwater pan with blood flowing from the trunks and mouth. The first\nanimal fell down in sternal decubitus with both tusks supporting its\nhead straight. The second elephant fell on its side with no sign of\nstruggle. The blood was unclotted even almost 10 hours after the\nestimated time of death. Information from the rangers indicated that\nthere was one kudu found dead also in the game farm with similar\nsigns. Outbreak statistics rates apparent, expressed as percentages\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate /\nProportion susceptible animals lost*\nAfrican Elephant:_Loxodonta Africana_ (Elephantidae) /  /  / 100 /\n\nGreater kudu:_Tragelaphus strepsiceros_ (Bovidae) /  /  / 100 /\n\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction\nand/or slaughter\nNot calculated because of missing information Epidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: endemic foci Control measures:\nMeasures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection\nzone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone;\nquarantine; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste;\nvaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected\nanimals\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures Diagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nKruger National Park State Laboratory (Foreign laboratory) / African\nElephant / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / Pending\nMagudi District Veterinary Laboratory (Private Laboratory) / African\nElephant / microscopic examination / 11 Aug 2017 / Positive Future Reporting: the event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports\nwill be submitted. The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map\nincluded in the OIE report at the source URL above. The outbreak is in\nsouthern Mozambique close to the Soutrh African border. - Mod.MJH \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) The reporting of anthrax in Mozambique is sporadic at best,\nreflecting government service infrastructure problems, but this is a\nbreakthrough facilitated by their South Africa neighbour. May it lay\nthe groundwork for improved reporting. Elephants acquire this disease through grazing though they are\nprimarily browsers. Because of the difficulties of controlling\nwildlife anthrax in African national parks, it is a widespread problem\nin the parks. And this presents a threat to livestock grazing in\nproximity to such parks. If I were to guess it would be that this kudu\npaid the price of its curiosity in investigating these elephant\ncarcasses and maybe from consuming some of their extravasated blood. -\nMod.MHJ A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/177). Sri Lanka has now notified 107 015 cases,\nwhich WHO estimates is 4.3 times more than the average number of cases\nusually reported (http://tinyurl.com/ycvszzs8). - National. 19 Aug 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. This compares with about 39 000 cases reported from January\nto August 2016, and 55 150 cases during the entire year 2016.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - National. 25 Aug 2017. Through Fri 25 Aug 2017, Sri Lanka has\nofficially reported 144 052 cases and, as of 3 Aug 2017, 3327 people\nhave died.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-epidemic-waning-sri-lanka-university-jaffna-science-faculty-closed-september-83024/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sri Lanka can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/144). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ India\n- National. 31 Jul 2017. 11 832 more cases than in 2016 and 46 deaths,\n11 more than in 2016. The total has risen to 28 702, with 2536 cases\nand 10 deaths last week week of 24 Jul 2017. Kerala reported the\nmaximum dengue cases with 13 913 cases, followed by Tamil Nadu with\n5474 cases, Karnataka with 4186 cases, Andhra Pradesh with 798 cases,\nWest Bengal with 571 cases, and Maharashtra with 460 cases.\n(http://www.india.com/news/agencies/dengue-cases-in-india-up-by-11832-over-last-year-2366955/) - Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Assam. 21 Aug 2017. Floods continued to wreak\nhavoc in the 3 states, which reported 88 more dengue-related deaths.\nOfficials said 33 more dengue-related deaths had been reported in\nUttar Pradesh over the last 2 days.\n(http://www.christianmessenger.in/floods-in-bihar-up-assam-88-die-in-dengue-related-deaths/) - Delhi. 31 Jul 2017. As of 29 Jul 2017, 180 cases of dengue (monsoon\narrived early).\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/882984/dengue-malaria-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise-in-delhi/) - Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore). 4 Aug 2017. Deaths rise to 16 in last 2\nmonths; new admissions increasing.\n(http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/2-more-dengue-deaths-in-coimbatore-total-deaths-now-16-117080401128_1.html) - Tamil Nadu. 11 Aug 2017. Prevalence of dengue in Tamil Nadu is\ndecreasing. So far, 5000 people have been affected and due to proper\ntreatment by doctors in government and private hospitals, almost all\ndengue patients have been saved, health minister C Vijaya Baskar said\ntoday 11 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.dnaindia.com/\nhealth/report-prevalence-of-dengue-in-tn-down-health-minister-2526936) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 18 Aug 2017. At least 1500 new cases in 10\ndays. Neighbouring state, Kerala, which has recorded the highest\nnumber of dengue cases with around 15 612 cases and 25 deaths, is\nanother reason for several districts of Tamil Nadu such as Coimbatore,\nMadurai, Theni, Toothukudi, and Virudhunagar facing its brunt.\n(http://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/current-affairs/180817/more-rains-more-cases-of-dengue.html) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 4 Aug 2017. 5 new positive cases every day\nnow; around 100 cases of 'suspicious fever' reported. 629 cases in\nJuly 2017 alone, according to National Vector Borne Diseases Control\nProgramme.\n(http://www.deccanchronicle.com/lifestyle/health-and-wellbeing/040817/dengue-breeds-in-north-chennai.html) - Kerala. 31 Jul 2017. Over 6000 patients have been confirmed and\ntreated as in-patients; mortality has been kept to 1 per cent.\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/thiruvananthapuram/882347/mch-keeps-dengue-mortality-rate-to-1/#) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 4 Aug 2017. 235 cases in Gulbarga district\nfrom January to July 2017. Of the 235, 171 cases were reported from\nKalaburagi taluk sub district alone, 32 from Chincholli taluk, 13\nfrom Chittapur taluk, 4 cases each from Afzalpur, Aland, and Sedam\ntaluks, and 3 cases from Jewargi taluk.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/235-dengue-cases-in-kalaburagi-dist/article19423638.ece) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 23 Aug 2017. A total of 474 confirmed cases in\nGulbarga district, with 1927 suspected cases; 368 cases confirmed in\nKalaburagi sub district. Only 43 cases were reported in the district\ntill the end of June 2017 and 191 cases were reported between 1 and\n10 Aug 2017, while 240 new cases have been registered, taking the\ntotal to 474.\n(http://www.uniindia.com/dengue-474-confirmed-cases-reported-in-kalaburagi-district/health-and-medicine/fullstory/968353.html) - Karnataka. 18 Aug 2017. Nearly 8000 cases in Karnataka so far in\n2017. Kerala has reported 16 000 cases and Tamil Nadu 9500 cases.\nDengue spreads easily between the 3 adjacent states.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/central-team-to-review-dengue-outbreak-in-state/article19512224.ece) - West Bengal (Kolkata). 12 Aug 2017. Out of total 402 infected persons, 67 were tested positive\nin Bhadrak district, 61 in Cuttack district, and 59 in Balasore\ndistrict. While Nayagarh, Sonepur, Kalahandi,\nAngul, and Bargarh registered 3 cases each, Nuapada and Kandhamal\nwitnessed 2 cases. A total of 59 cases in July 2017.\nThe actual number of cases is said to be 'far more'; it takes at least\n15 days to confirm cases.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/59-dengue-cases-in-july-amc/articleshow/59853414.cms) - Jharkhand (Jamshedpur). 30 Jul 2017. 75 positive cases in Kolhan and\nadjoining area of Jamshedpur.\n(http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/dengue-cases-rise-positive-cases-shoot-75-kolhan/111026/) - Telangana (Hyderabad). 25 Jul 2017. All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed strain homology with the Burkina Faso 2016 strain. On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. Sir Gangaram Hospital reported the rare case,\nwhere the woman, who went to the eye OPD outpatient department,\ncomplained of \"sudden blurring of vision in the left eye,\" as reported\nby IE Indian Express. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017. The total number of reported dengue cases including\ndengue haemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome was lower than the\n3 year-threshold of the same period from 2014-2016. China\nAs of 31 Jul 2017, there were 503 cases of dengue reported in China in\n2017. This number is higher than that reported during the same period\nsince 2012 but follows historical trend. Lao PDR People's Democratic Republic\nAs of 4 Aug 2017, there were 5740 cases of dengue with 7 deaths\nreported in Lao PDR in 2017, with 406 cases reported in epi week 31\n(week ending 5 Aug 2017). Dengue activity is high with the number of\ndengue cases reported this year 2017 being higher than the cases\nreported for same period since 2014. Malaysia\nIn week 31 of 2017 (week ending 5 Aug 2017), 1899 dengue cases were\nreported with 2 deaths, an increase of 1.1 per cent compared with week\n30. As of week 31, the cumulative number of dengue cases in 2017 were\n59 521 with 135 deaths compared with 67 437 cases with 147 deaths\nduring the same period in 2016. Philippines (no update)\nA total of 43 770 dengue cases were reported nationwide from 1 Jan to\n1 Jul 2017. This number is 36.8 per cent lower (25 527) compared with\nthe same time period in 2016. Singapore\nAs of 5 Aug 2017, there were 1732 dengue cases reported in Singapore\nsince January 2017. This is lower than the number of reported cases\nduring the same period since 2013. During week 31, there were 61 cases\nreported and the number of reported cases in 2017 remains lower than\nthose reported for the same time period in 2016 . Viet Nam\nAs of 3 Aug 2017, there were 80 555 cases of dengue reported in Viet\nNam including 22 deaths. Compared with the same period in 2016, the\ncumulative number of cases increased by 33.5 per cent, and the number\nof deaths rose by 5. Most cases were reported from the South (59 per\ncent). A sharp increase in the number of reported cases has been\nobserved in the North (almost 25 times higher than the same period\nlast year 2016), especially from Ha Noi, with about 13 440 cases. Southern hemisphere\n-\nAustralia\nAs of 31 Jul 2017, there were 695 laboratory-confirmed dengue cases\nreported in Australia in 2017. The number of cases reported is lower\nthan that reported during the same time period in the previous years\n(2012-2016). Pacific Islands countries and areas\n\nFrench Polynesia\nIn French Polynesia, 12 cases (including 1 death) in week 29 and 12\ncases in week 30 (week ending 29 Jul 2017). Among these, 15 cases were\nconfirmed as DENV-1 infection. New Caledonia (no update)\nAs of 1 Aug 2017, 4,452 dengue cases were reported in 2017. There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Namibia":{},"Nauru":{},"Nepal":{"27":{"title":"Scrub typhus - Nepal (08): (KT) more cases ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Scrub typhus - Nepal (08): (KT) more cases [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017. From: Sher Bahadur Pun (drsherbdr@yahoo.com) (edited)   As of Tue 15 Aug 2017 (until Aug 18), at least 17 scrub typhus (ST) cases have been found positive among suspected cases who visited the outpatient department of Sukraraj Tropical and Infectious Disease Hospital (STIDH). as well as those who were referred from different hospitals in Kathmandu for laboratory testing. It indicates that ST is becoming more common in Kathmandu than we previously thought. It raises a critical question whether ST is shifting its geographic range or was frequently under-diagnosed previously or was under-diagnosed in urban areas like Kathmandu; this deserves further studies. Because, in the past, the majority of scrub typhus cases were reported from non-urban remote areas than urban areas of Nepal.   <br><br>Communicated by: Dr. Sher Bahadur Pun, MD, PhD Clinical Research Unit, Sukraraj Tropical and Infectious Disease Hospital, Kathmandu, Nepal. (drsherbdr@yahoo.com)  ProMED-mail thanks Dr Sher Bahadur Pun for continued contributions to ProMED-mail on scrub typhus in Nepal.  Scrub typhus is caused by _Orientia tsutsugamushi_, a rickettsia-like microorganism that is transmitted by chiggers, the larval stage of trombiculid mites, which feed on the skin cells of animals, including humans and rodents. After feeding on their hosts, chiggers drop to the ground and become nymphs, which then mature into adults that feed only on plant materials. The cutaneous reaction to chiggers leaves a characteristic black eschar that is useful for making the diagnosis. Humans become infected when they accidentally encroach in an area where the infected chigger-rodent cycle is occurring, most often areas of low-lying scrub brush or transitional vegetation. Rodents may serve as reservoirs, although transovarial transmission in mites is the dominant mechanism for maintenance of _O. tsutsugamushi_ in nature ((http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/EID/vol9no12/03-0212.htm)).  Maps of Nepal can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/ydf8ojtj) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/139). - Mod.ML  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"72":{"title":"Chikungunya (27) - Americas, Europe, Asia ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Chikungunya (27) - Americas, Europe, Asia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHIKUNGUNYA (27) - AMERICAS, EUROPE, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n\nAmericas\n\nRegional summary\nWHO/PAHO report Mexico and Central America\n\nMexico (Jalisco state)\nCosta Rica South America\n\nArgentina (Salto province)\nBrazil:\n- Roraima state\n- Ceara state\nPeru (Piura region) Europe\n\nFrance (Provence-Alpes-Côte d'Azur region in Provence) Asia\n\nTaiwan (Tainan)\nIndia:\n- Delhi\n- Ludhiana, Punjab\n- Chandigarh, Haryana and Punjab states\n- Tamil Nadu state\n- Baramati tehsil, Pune, Maharastra state\n- Pune Maharashtra state ex Assam state\n- Kerala state\nBangladesh (Dhaka)\nNepal (Bhaktapur, province 3) \nCases in various countries:\nRegional summaries\n\nAmericas\n\nWHO/PAHO report\n18 Aug 2017\n(http://www.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_topics&view=rdmore&cid=8975&Itemid=40931&lang=en) \nReported cases of chikungunya fever in the Americas, by country or\nterritory - 2017 to EW 33 week ending 18 Aug 2017. TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be) The number of reported cases of chikungunya virus (CHIKV) infection\nin the Americas appears to have declined this year (2017). Given the\noutbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) infections in the region, and the\nclinical similarity of cases of that virus infection and CHIKV\ninfection, one wonders how many cases that were not laboratory\nconfirmed but clinically diagnosed as ZIKV infections were, in\nreality, CHIKV infections. It is also possible that a significant\nproportion of the population have been infected by CHIKV in the\nprevious 3 years and are now immune. It seems likely, however, that\nCHIKV is now endemic in the Americas, and sporadic, small outbreaks\nmay continue to occur as they do in Asia and Africa. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"75":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (88): Africa,\r\n\tAsia ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (88): Africa,\r\n\tAsia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (88): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Malawi (Southern region)\n2,3 Cholera - Sudan\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR (Kwilu, South Kivu)\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - India (Punjab)\n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Diarrhea - Nepal (Kapilvastu district) \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Malawi (Southern region).\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Capital Radio Malawi summ., edited\n(https://www.capitalradiomalawi.com/index.php/blog/local-news/local-news/item/8352-chikwawa-hit-by-cholera-outbreak) \nA total of 9 people are admitted to Chikwawa district Southern\nregion hospital following a cholera outbreak. This comes barely 4\nmonths after another outbreak hit the district's 2 villages in the\narea of Paramount Chief Lundu, affecting 38 people. The Environmental\nHealth Office for Chikwawa district has confirmed the development,\nciting poor access to safe water and poor quality of sanitary\nfacilities in villages. There are fears that the cholera outbreak may\nspread to other areas where communities do not have access to portable\nwater supply as well as toilets. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Malawi can be seen at\n(http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/malawi.pdf) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8665). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(http://allafrica.com/stories/201708220596.html) \nSouth Darfur\n\nIn 2 months, 42 people have died of cholera in Kalma camp for\ndisplaced people in South Darfur. 539 others have been infected. The\ndeaths occurred between 26 Jun and 20 Aug 2017, the coordinator of\nthe camp in Nyala, Yagoub Abdallah Furi, informed Radio Dabanga\nyesterday 21 Aug 2017. \"There are 3 medical isolation centres\nbelonging to 2 organizations from the USA that have been established\nin the camp since the cholera broke out in Nyala in June 2017.\" Currently there are 37 hospitalized cases at the camp's isolation\nwards. \"There is a large shortage of intravenous solutions. We hope\norganisations working in the medical field and the Ministry of Health\nto provide us with medicines.\" The epidemic reached Manawashi, north\nof Nyala city, at the beginning of August 2017. Central Darfur\n\nAt least 36 people have been infected with cholera in Central Darfur's\nNierteti in the past 11 days. 4 of them died, sources reported to\nRadio Dabanga. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian\nAffairs (OCHA) reported in its latest biweekly bulletin that\n\"humanitarian access and insecurity remain major challenges for the\nimplementation of key health and protection interventions\" in Central\nDarfur. \"Nierteti's hospital faces gaps in medicines, including oral and\nintravenous re-hydration solutions .,\" OCHA stated. \"In Zalingei\nhospital, there are several sanitation issues, including lack of\nlatrines and evidence of improper solid waste management..\" National epidemic\n\nThe National Epidemiological Corporation reported in early July 2017\nthat nearly 24 000 Sudanese have been infected and 940 cholera\npatients have died since the outbreak of the infectious disease in\nBlue Nile state in August 2016. The Sudanese authorities refuse to\ncall the disease by its name, however, and instead refer to it as\n\"acute watery diarrhea\". The National Intelligence and Security\nService has repeatedly warned medics and the press in the country not\nto make mention of cholera. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) *\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/fifteen-cholera-dead-in-west-darfur-camp) \nWest Darfur\n\n15 people have died of cholera while 18 others have been infected in\nMurnei, West Darfur, in the past 3 days. A sheikh in Murnei camp for\ndisplaced people told this station, \"18 people are now in the\nisolation ward in the camp.\" The 18 infected people came from Um Tajok\nvillage near Murnei on 9 Aug 2017. 6 people died of cholera at the\nvillage that day, a sheikh reported from the camp last week week of 7\nAug 2017. Blue Nile\n\nIn Blue Nile state, 3 brothers died in the hospital of Ed Damazin on\nTue 15 Aug 2017. A relative of the deceased told Radio Dabanga that\nthe 3 family members died of the same disease in the hospital, in El\nHijra district. Sennar\n\nMeanwhile in Sennar, 18 people contracted cholera in El Dindir\nlocality this week week of 14 Aug 2017. A medical source told this\nstation that on Thu 17 Aug 2017, El Dindir's hospital received 13\nnews cases of cholera, 8 of which were received earlier this week. 5\nothers arrived on Thu 17 Aug 2017. The medical isolation centre at\nBardana village, south of the city, also recorded 5 new cases of\ncholera. The hospital in Singa received 3 new cases of cholera on Thu 17 Aug\n2017. A medical source informed Radio Dabanga that the 3 patients had\ncome from Um Benin village, south east of Singa. \"16 people suffering\nfrom cholera are still in the isolation ward.\" Northern state\n\nThe 1st cases of cholera have been reported in the southern part of El\nMahas in Northern state, at Arduan health centre. The patients arrived\nfrom Maljab area on Thu 17 Aug 2017, while El Tura health centre of\nEl Mahas received another case. Nubian activist Adham Nasr told Radio Dabanga that the woman has been\nisolated in a room at Arduan health centre to receive treatment. There\nare concerns that the disease might break out in the area during the\nrainy season, which makes it difficult to move from and to Arduan. Red Sea\n-\nA health centre in Arayab area in Ganab, Red Sea state, received 5\nchildren suffering from cholera on Wed 16 Aug 2017. Journalist Osman\nHashim told Radio Dabanga that the one of them has been transferred to\nPort Sudan Hospital. The doctors were unable to give information about\nthe cases. The hospital's administration has not allocated a ward to\nisolate the cholera patients. Earlier in August 2017 a volunteer of one of the cholera awareness\nraising campaigns in Sudan told Radio Dabanga that the reality in the\nhospitals is very poor. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of the Republic of the Sudan can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR (Kwilu, South Kivu).\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Voice of America (VOA) News, Afrique, Agence France-Presse\n(AFP) report in French, machine trans., edited\n(https://www.voaafrique.com/a/seize-morts-du-cholera-en-une-semaine-dans-le-sud-ouest-de-la-rdc/3991609.html) \nA total of 16 people died of cholera in one week in a region in the\nsouth west of the Democratic Republic of the Congo DRC, where about\n100 cases have been recorded, it was learned Fri 18 Aug 2017 from\nthe provincial authorities. \"We have recorded 16 cases of deaths and about 100 people are infected\nwith cholera\" in 3 zones of the province of Kwilu, governor Nicholas\nBulukungu told reporters. \"The province does not have a center\nspecializing in the treatment of cholera. The isolation of the\npatients is a serious problem,\" he said. The town of Bandundu and the\n2 affected localities are inhabited by nearly a million people,\ninvited to \"strict observance of the basic rules of hygiene.\" Another Congolese province (South Kivu in the east) is facing an\noutbreak of cholera with 2 deaths and several tens of cases reported\nfor nearly 3 weeks. According to the UN, cholera has become a major public health problem\nin the DRC with thousands of cases recorded every year in many\nprovinces in this vast country without infrastructure and where most\nof the population lives in poverty. More than 700 deaths of cholera were recorded in 2016 in the DRC. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n(promed-fra@promedmail.org) Maps of the Democratic Republic of the Congo can be seen at\n(http://goo.gl/DM2AT8) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42129). -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - India (Punjab).\nDate: Sat 19 Aug 2017 03:09 PM IST.\nSource: Times of India (edited)\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ludhiana/cholera-outbreak-18-fresh-cases-reported-on-day-5/articleshow/60126504.cms) \n18 fresh cholera cases were reported at Guru Har Rai Nagar Ludhiana,\nPunjab on on day 5 of the outbreak. Health officials are not\npaying attention to affected areas as a number of cases are being\nstill being reported.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1789). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Diarrhea - Nepal (Kapilvastu district).\nDate: Sun 20 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Himalayan Times (edited)\n(https://thehimalayantimes.com/nepal/child-loses-life-in-outbreak-of-diarrhoea-in-flood-hit-kapilvastu/) \nA child has reportedly succumbed to diarrhea in Sattbhara, of\nMaharajgunj Municipality-7 in Kapilvastu district Province Five on\nSun 20 Aug 2017. He said the consumption of water and fish obtained\nfrom contaminated water sources could be the cause of the outbreak. The health workers deputed from the District Health Office (DHO) have\nbeen treating locals with preventive medicines while the critical ones\nhave been undergoing treatment in the Bahadurgunj Hospital in the\ndistrict. Meanwhile, the DHO has urged the general public to take\nprecautions and preventive measures as there is high risk of diarrhoea\nspreading in the flood-hit areas. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-SoAs\n(promed-SoAs@promedmail.org) Maps of Nepal can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/ydf8ojtj) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/38712). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 per cent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are:\n- Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 per cent (95 per cent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam;\n- Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. A randomized, non-inferiority\ntrial comparing two bivalent killed, whole cell, oral cholera vaccines\n(Euvichol vs Shanchol) in the Philippines. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]},"84":{"title":"Foot & mouth disease - Nepal: (CH) bovine, new, st A, gt VII,\r\n\tOIE ","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Foot & mouth disease - Nepal: (CH) bovine, new, st A, gt VII,\r\n\tOIE [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 23 Aug 2017. Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(34) (edited) (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24622)   Foot and mouth disease, Nepal  Information received on 23 Aug 2017 from Dr Bimal Kumar Nirmal, Department of Livestock Services, Ministry of Livestock Development, Nepal  Summary Report type: immediate notification (final report) Date of start of the event: 2 Apr 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 6 Apr 2017 Report date: 22 Aug 2017 Date event resolved: 3 May 2017 Reason for notification: new strain of a listed disease in the country Causal agent: foot and mouth disease virus (lineage G-VII) Serotype: A Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced) This event pertains to the whole country.  New outbreaks (1) Summary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1 Outbreak 1: Chitwan, Bharatpur 4, Chitwan, Narayani Province Three Date of start of the outbreak: 2 Apr 2017 Outbreak status: resolved on 3 May 2017 Epidemiological unit: village Total animals affected: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0 / 0 Buffaloes / 3 / 3 / 0 / 0 / 0 Affected population: cattle and buffaloes reared in semi commercial small holder farms of Bharatpur 4, Chitwan were affected.  Outbreak statistics rates apparent, expressed as percentages Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost* Cattle / 100 / 0 / 0 / 0 Buffaloes / 100 / 0 / 0 / 0 *Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter  Epidemiology Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive, Illegal movement of animals Epidemiological comments: 15 per cent of young (1-1.5 years old) and 85 per cent of adult (3-5 years old) cross breed cattle and buffaloes of 4 farms were affected with typical signs and symptoms of foot and mouth disease (FMD) such as high fever, drooling of saliva, champing of jaws, lameness, off feed, lesions on tongue. All the cattle and buffaloes in the village were affected; however there was no mortality observed even in the young ones. The animals have not been vaccinated against FMD since few years in these farms. There was a buffalo collection and selling center 100 meters close to the village. There was a collection of buffaloes from different neighboring districts and international bordering districts. Further investigation is ongoing.  Control measures Measures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, quarantine, disinfection, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals  Diagnostic test results Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result National foot-and-mouth disease and transboundary animal diseases Laboratory, Kathmandu (national laboratory) / Buffaloes / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 6 Apr 2017 / Positive National foot-and-mouth disease and transboundary animal diseases Laboratory, Kathmandu (national laboratory) / Cattle / PCR / 6 Apr 2017 / Positive National foot-and-mouth disease and transboundary animal diseases Laboratory, Kathmandu (national laboratory) / Cattle / serotyping / 6 Apr 2017 / Positive Pirbright Institute, United Kingdom (OIE reference laboratory) / Cattle / gene sequencing / 14 Aug 2017 / Positive Pirbright Institute, United Kingdom (OIE reference laboratory) / Cattle / serotyping / 14 Aug 2017 / Positive Measures to be applied: no other measures  Future reporting The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.  The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  According to the Nepal page on WRLFMD website, the last occurrence of FMD serotype A in Nepal took place in 1997. Since 2010, and as of March 2017, the FMDV strain circulating in Nepal has continuously been O/ME-SA/Ind-2001d (in 2015, there was also a single detection of O/ME-SA/PanAsia-2 KAT-15). For the said and additional information on Nepal's FMD past records, including genotyping results (though not yet of the newly introduced A/ASIA/G-VII lineage), see (http://www.wrlfmd.org/fmd_genotyping/asia/nep.htm).  The identification of the A/ASIA/G-VII lineage in Nepal represents further spread of this virus, which had been evolving in India many years back (\"A/IND/40/2000\", genotyped A/ASIA/G-VII, was collected in 1999). In 2010, this strain was detected in Myanmar. In 2015, it appeared for the 1st time in the Middle East (\"FMD Pool 3\"), being detected in Saudi Arabia followed, during the same year, by Iran, Turkey and Armenia. Most recently (May 2017), this virus was identified in Northern Israel, on the Lebanese and Syrian borders.  According to the information included in the Guest Editor's comments to EuFMD's (European Commission for the control of Foot-and-Mouth Disease) monthly report \"Global Foot-and-Mouth Disease Situation\", June 2017, there were reports of poor performance of vaccine strains derived from the A/ASIA/Iran-05 strain against the A/ASIA/G-VII lineage. The guest editor, Don King (head of the Vesicular Disease Reference Laboratory Group in the Pirbright Institute and WRLFMD), disclosed that WRLFMD, in partnership with the FMD Reference Laboratories in Lelystad (The Netherlands) and Geelong (Australia), has undertaken vaccine potency trials for alternative candidate vaccines; preliminary data indicated that the A-May-97 vaccine may provide protection in cattle, in contrast to the A22 vaccine, which does not appear to induce a protective response. The said data were to \"be presented in more detail shortly\". The said and additional information is available at (http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/user_upload/eufmd/docs/FMD_monthly_reports/2017/June2017.pdf).  The Indian subcontinent (\"FMD Pool 2\") is the source of 2 FMD strains which have demonstrated, in recent years, a long-distance (trans-regional) transmission, causing losses in \"FMD Pool 3\" countries and threatening Europe. These are FMDV serotype O, topotype ME-SA, strain Ind-2001d and FMDV serotype A, topotype Asia, genotype (strain) VII. While the routes of dissemination are yet to be clarified, the FMD situation within India, a major beef exporter, including its vaccination policy and vaccines efficacy, deserves being visited. - Mod.AS  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/19830).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"137":{"title":"Scrub typhus - Nepal (09): (KT) urban cases ","date":["30","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Scrub typhus - Nepal (09): (KT) urban cases [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 30 Aug 2017. From: Sher Bahadur Pun (drsherbdr@yahoo.com) (edited)   During a 2-week period (15 through 29 Aug 2017), at least 86 scrub typhus (ST) cases (including 9 children) have been identified by laboratory testing at Sukraraj Tropical & Infectious Disease Hospital (STIDH). Majority of these patients are being treated in different hospitals in Kathmandu. 9 children with laboratory confirmed ST received treatment at STIDH and recovered uneventfully.  It is quite surprising for me observing such a large number of ST cases being detected in Kathmandu, the biggest and most densely populated area of Nepal. Because ST has previously been almost exclusively detected in rural areas of Nepal. What is not yet clear is the impact of ST between the years 2004 and 2015. ST was first well documented in 2004 in Kathmandu (1), while the significant number of ST cases has only been detected since 2015.  The widespread use of antibiotics, such as ciprofloxacin, could be one possible explanation. In other words, healthcare workers in Nepal usually view any fever as typhoid fever, thus used to treat febrile patients with ciprofloxacin, which might have also worked simultaneously against ST too. However, nowadays, cefixime has become the drug of choice for typhoid fever, and it may, however, not work effectively against ST, resulting in emergence of ST in Nepal.  Reference  1. Murdoch DR, Woods CW, Zimmerman MD et al. The etiology of febrile illness in adults presenting to Patan Hospital in Kathmandu. Nepal. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2004; 70(6): 670-5; (http://tinyurl.com/ybyfpqyx).   Dr Sher Bahadur Pun, MD, PhD Clinical Research Unit Sukraraj Tropical and Infectious Disease Hospital Kathmandu Nepal (drsherbdr@yahoo.com)  ProMED-mail thanks Dr Sher Bahadur Pun for his continued contributions on scrub typhus in Nepal.  Doxycycline is the drug of choice and it is preferred over other tetracyclines for treatment of scrub typhus; it is rarely associated with staining of teeth in children younger than 8 years (1). Macrolides, such as azithromycin, are also reported to be efficacious (2). Fluoroquinolones, such as ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin, have been reported to be clinically effective in the treatment of scrub typhus in a few patients. However, some clinical studies suggest that fluoroquinolones are not as effective in patients with scrub typhus as other antibiotics (3,4).  In vitro testing of some strains of _Orientia tsutsugamushi_, the cause of scrub typhus, has been reported to show resistance to ciprofloxacin and ofloxacin (minimum inhibitory concentration=8 micrograms/mL) (5) and mutation in the quinolone resistance-determining region (QRDR) of the gyrA gene associated with fluoroquinolone resistance has been found (3,5).  These findings suggest that fluoroquinolones are likely not appropriate for the treatment of scrub typhus.  References - 1. Panpanich R, Garner P. Antibiotics for treating scrub typhus. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2000; (2): CD002150. Available at (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/10796680). 2. Kim YS, Yun HJ, Shim SK, et al. A comparative trial of a single dose of azithromycin versus doxycycline for the treatment of mild scrub typhus. Clin Infect Dis. 2004; 39(9): 1329-35 Epub 2004 Oct 11. Available at (https://academic.oup.com/cid/article-lookup/doi/10.1086/425008). 3. Jang HC, Choi SM, Jang MO, et al. Inappropriateness of quinolone in scrub typhus treatment due to gyrA mutation in _Orientia tsutsugamushi_ Boryong strain. J Korean Med Sci. 2013; 28(5): 667-71. doi: 10.3346/jkms.2013.28.5.667. Epub 2013 May 2. Available at (https://jkms.org/DOIx.php?id=10.3346/jkms.2013.28.5.667). 4. Tsai CC, Lay CJ, Wang CL, et al. Levofloxacin versus tetracycline antibiotics for the treatment of scrub typhus. Int J Infect Dis. 2010; 14(1): e62-7. doi: 10.1016/j.ijid.2009.03.012. Epub 2009 Jun 4. Available at (http://www.ijidonline.com/article/S1201-9712(09)00147-7/fulltext). 5. Tantibhedhyangkul W, Angelakis E, Tongyoo N, et al. Intrinsic fluoroquinolone resistance in _Orientia tsutsugamushi_. Int J Antimicrob Agents. 2010; 35(4): 338-41. Available at (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20138477).  Maps of Nepal can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/ydf8ojtj) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2877). - Mod.ML  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Netherlands":{},"New Caledonia":{"146":{"title":"Invasive mosquito - New Caledonia ","date":["17","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Invasive mosquito - New Caledonia [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 17 Aug 2017 10:03 NCT. Source: Radio New Zealand (edited) (http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/337426/malaria-mosquito-found-in-new-caledonia)   Health officials in New Caledonia have discovered the presence of the type of mosquito which can carry malaria.  But the officials say there is no risk to the public because the parasite that triggers the disease is not present in the territory.  It is not known when and how the _Anopheles_ mosquitoes entered New Caledonia but they are now established in the area of La Tontouta, north of Noumea.  Malaria is found in other parts of Melanesia.  Reports say the mosquitoes were found during checks as part of efforts to fight dengue fever.  Another mosquito type, the _Aedes aegypti_, has been a major health concern in New Caledonia, having spread dengue and Zika viruses.  Plans have been drawn up to introduce the _Wolbachia_ bacteria which should prevent that mosquito from being able to pass on the diseases pathogens.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  It would be of interest to know which species of _Anopheles_ mosquitoes have been found in New Caledonia. _Aedes aegypti_ has been an active vector of dengue and Zika viruses on New Caledonia. The 1st locally acquired case of Zika virus infection was reported in mid-January 2014, the number of confirmed cases as of 18 Mar 2014 was 276. Dengue fever has been a frequent problem on New Caledonia. According to the authorities, nearly 5000 cases have been reported since 1 Sep 2016. The peak of the epidemic was reached in March 2017. The number of clinical cases or suspects has been declining since.  Maps of New Caledonia can be accessed at (https://media1.britannica.com/eb-media/93/3293-004-8AA31F9B.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/459). - Mod.TY  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"182":{"title":"Invasive mosquito - New Caledonia (02): comment ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Invasive mosquito - New Caledonia (02): comment [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017. From: Michael J. Bangs (mbangs@fmi.com) (edited)   It stands to reason that the presence of _Anopheles farauti_ as the new entrant into New Caledonia is presumably recent. The nearest neighbor is Vanuatu, a malaria-endemic country that has but one anopheline species present in that island group, _Anopheles farauti_ sensu stricto, an effective malaria vector provided you add _Plasmodium_ to the mix.  _Anopheles farauti_ is one member of 8 known sibling species in the _Farauti_ Complex (closely related species that are morphologically identical, thus confounding accurate identification without the use of molecular techniques). It is by far the most widely distributed species in the complex in the southwest Pacific region (Maluku island group, eastern Indonesia to northern Australia, PNG, Solomon Islands and Vanuatu). The species' ability to inhabit brackish water environments (predominantly a coastal inhabitant) has aided in its dispersal throughout the region.  The origin of the anopheline population in New Caledonia might remain a mystery, but this discovery is of concern. If the area of establishment is relatively confined, it might be possible to eliminate this species before it extends further into the country. Foremost, identify the species.   Michael J. Bangs, MSPH, PhD. Public Health & Malaria Control International SOS Kuala Kencana, Papua, Indonesia (mbangs@fmi.com)  ProMED thanks Dr. Bangs for his comments.  The _Anopheles_ reported in the previous posting was found in an area of La Tontouta, north of Noumea. One hopes that the area of discovery is small enough to permit control.  Maps of New Caledonia can be accessed at (https://media1.britannica.com/eb-media/93/3293-004-8AA31F9B.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/459). - Mod.TY  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"New Zealand":{"51":{"title":"Mumps update (24): Australia (QL), New Zealand (OT),\r\n\tBrazil (AM) ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Mumps update (24): Australia (QL), New Zealand (OT),\r\n\tBrazil (AM) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Australia (Cairns, Queensland) <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago) <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas)   <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Australia (Cairns, Queensland). Date: Fri 11 Aug 2017 9:00 PM AEST. Source: The Cairns Post (edited) (https://tinyurl.com/y9nepfk5)   Far North Queenslanders have been urged to vaccinate their children following a spike in mumps cases in Cairns. There have been 14 cases of the highly infectious disease identified by Queensland Health since 24 Jul 2017, compared to the yearly average of only one case in the Cairns and Hinterland health district.  Tropical Public Health director Dr Steven Donohue said the mumps outbreak had spilled over to Cairns from northwest Queensland and the Northern Territory's Top End.  \"Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households,\" he said.  He said the viral illness was spread just like influenza, by coughing or sneezing near other people and through unwashed hands.  \"Symptoms may occur around 2 weeks after exposure if the person is not immune,\" he said. \"The illness usually lasts between 5-9 days.  \"One person in 3 who contracts mumps does not have any symptoms and doesn't realise they are sick, but they may still be contagious and infect may other people.\"  Northern Queensland Primary Health Network chief executive Robin Moore said immunisation was a simple, safe and highly effective way to protect children and adults from preventable diseases like mumps.  \"This year's 2017 increase in the number of mumps cases in the Cairns region is a timely reminder to parents that immunisation is the best protection against preventable diseases such as these.  \"We urge all members of the community to be fully vaccinated.\" ..  The disease is uncommon in developed countries, including Australia, because of the widespread use of the measles, mumps, rubella (MMR) vaccine.  This is given to children at 12 and 18 months, but free catch-up doses are available to anyone born after 1965 who may not have 2 recorded doses.  Outbreaks of mumps mainly occur because of low vaccination rates, missed doses in the past, waning immunity, or pressure of infection in overcrowded households.  Byline: Daniel Bateman   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/australia-political-map.gif) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2954). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ    <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> New Zealand (Dunedin, Otago). Date: Thu 17 Aug 2017 19:45 NZST. Source: Stuff (edited) (http://tinyurl.com/y7a56fv5)   University of Otago students are being offered free booster shots after about 10 confirmed or suspected cases were reported in Dunedin Otago, South Island.  Three young people in Marlborough have contracted the contagious illness, with at least 1 case linked to an Auckland outbreak, while 2 have been confirmed in Nelson.  Nationally, an unusually high number of cases were reported from September 2016 to early 2017, and the Ministry of Health warned of \"an increased risk of further outbreaks\".  Auckland reported 51 cases of mumps in the past month  most aged 10 to 19  while several were recorded in Waikato earlier this year 2017.  The Auckland Regional Public Health Service said last month July 2017 it was concerned not enough people were immunised in the face of the mumps outbreak.  The MMR vaccine is usually given in 2 doses, one at 15 months old and one at 4 years old.  Most people recover from mumps, but it can have serious complications. The disease can cause inflammation of tissue surrounding the brain (meningitis), inflamed testicles or ovaries and deafness.  Men hospitalised from the Auckland outbreak had pain and swelling in their testicles, known as orchitis, which in rare cases may lead to infertility.  The outbreak in Dunedin has prompted the Otago tertiary institution's student health team to offer free measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) booster shots to students who have not had two MMR vaccinations since 1990, or are unsure of their vaccination history.  Pro-vice-chancellor of health sciences Professor Peter Crampton, the convener of the university's pandemic planning group, said the group was \"determining our ongoing response as the situation develops.\"  The outbreak coincided with a large-scale boil water notice issued for parts of Dunedin, including the student quarter, after untreated water got into part of the town's drinking water supply on Mon 14 Aug 2017.  All students and staff had been sent information about mumps. Information had been posted on social media.  Marlborough medical officer of health Dr Andrew Lindsay said mumps is \"highly contagious\". It spreads through the air by breathing, coughing and sneezing, or through contact with infected saliva; by kissing or sharing food and drink. It usually takes 12-25 days before symptoms appear  including pain in the jaw, fever, headache, and swollen glands around the face and body. People with mumps re infectious for 7 days before swelling starts and for 5 days after they cease.  Personal hygiene is essential to avoid catching mumps, including frequent hand washing, stopping coughs and sneezes in tissues, keeping at least 1 metre 3 ft away from others and ensuring kitchens and bathrooms are clean.  Dr Jill Sherwood, public health physician with the ESR (the Institute of Environmental Science and Research), earlier said the MMR vaccine was not as effective in mumps as it was in measles and rubella. \"The mumps component is only about 85 per cent effective, whereas the measles component will most likely give you lifetime coverage,\" Sherwood said.  There have been no reported cases of mumps in Canterbury, a health board spokeswoman said.  Byline: Hamish Mcneilly, Jennifer Eder   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of New Zealand can be seen at (http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/oceania/political-map-of-New-Zealan.gif) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/738). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ   <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Brazil (Manaus, Amazonas). The 1st outbreak was reported in April 2017 and the occurrence of cases is continuing until the month of August, according to the municipal health secretary. ..
