Byline: Uthman Abubakar, Ibrahim Sawab, Omirin Olatunji \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Nigeria can be seen at\n(ttp://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12103). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - Nigeria (Borno state) IDPs.\nDate: Tue 5 Sep 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-09-death-toll-nigeria-cholera.html) \nThe death toll from a cholera outbreak in restive northeast Nigeria\nhas risen to 21, with most of the victims living in a camp for people\ndisplaced by Boko Haram violence, the health ministry said Tue 5 Sep\n2017. On Sat 2 Sep 2017, the ministry had said the cholera toll was 14 in\nthe town of Maiduguri, with most of the victims living in a camp for\npeople displaced by Boko Haram violence. \"As of 4 Sep 2017, 21 deaths\nhave been reported,\" the Borno state health ministry said, as the toll\nmounts. \"The total number of suspected cholera cases is now 375 in\nMaiduguri,\" it said, up from 186 at the weekend. Most of the suspected\ncases and deaths are in Muna Garage, a camp for displaced people on\nthe outskirts of Maiduguri, while other victims come from neighboring\ndistricts, it said. The government and NGOs are working to contain the outbreak which has\nspread to the town of Dikwa, 60 kilometres (40 miles) away, where 5\ncases had been reported, it added. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, Radio Dabanga report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/west-darfur-camp-records-six-cholera-deaths) \nWest Darfur\n\nA sheikh in Murnei camp for displaced people told Radio Dabanga that\nby Sun 3 Sep 2017, a total of 22 patients were admitted to the\ncamp's isolation ward. From 27 Aug until 31 Aug 2017, 17 people\nreportedly succumbed to cholera. In Zamzam camp, south of El Fasher\ncity, 4 new cases of cholera were recorded on 1 and 2 Sep 2017. A camp\nelder told this station that the isolation ward was closed on the 1st\nday of Eid Al Adha Sacrifice Feast, 31 Aug-4 Sep 2017, \"because of\nthe absence of medical personnel, so the 4 new patients had to be\ntransferred to El Fasher for treatment.\" Central Darfur\n\nIsolation centers in Zalingei and Abta village, Central Darfur,\nrecorded 3 deaths and 37 new infection cases from 1-3 Sep 2017,\naccording to the coordinator of camps in the state, El Shafee\nAbdallah. In Hamidiya camp, 3 cholera patients died and 13 people\ninfected with cholera reported to the isolation centre. Meanwhile in\nthe last 3 days, the Hassahissa, Khamsa Degaig and Teiba camps\nrecorded 17 new cases. The total number of hospitalized cholera cases\nin the Zalingei Royal Hospital amounted to 76 people as of Sun, 3 Sep\n2017. \"From 1-3 Sep 2017, the isolation center in Abta village near Zalingei\nrecorded 7 new cases. The people are from Abta, Tiri, Dirlo, and\nKalgo,\" El Shafee said. Blue Nile\n\nIn Blue Nile state, 2 people died from cholera and 31 people\ncontracted the disease in the localities Ed Damazin and El Roseires in\nthe last week. A medical source in the area told Radio Dabanga that\nthe Royal Hospital in Ed Damazin received 4 cholera cases of cholera,\nfrom Arquette North. \"2 of them died on Wed 30 Aug 2017.\" Another medical source reported that last week week of 28 Aug 2017,\nthe hospital received 25 cases of cholera from different parts of El\nRoseires. 4 cases were recorded in Gisan locality. \"El Roseires\nlocality recorded the highest number of casualties of all localities\nin Blue Nile. There is a severe neglect of the number of staff in the\nisolation wards, because they were off for the Eid Al Adha holiday.\" Blue Nile was the 1st state to report cases of cholera in September\n2016, or 'acute watery diarrhea' as the Sudanese government has\nreferred to it since the start of the cholera outbreak. A UK-based\nSudanese specialist told Radio Dabanga in January 2017 that cholera\n\"seems to be a stigma for the government.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Sudan can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Cholera, diarrhea - Eastern and Southern Africa Region.\nDate: Thu 31 Aug 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, UNICEF report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/somalia/bulletin-choleraawd-outbreaks-eastern-and-southern-africa-regional-update-31-august) \nMore than 100 780 cholera/AWD acute watery diarrhea cases and 1496\ndeaths (CFR: 1.5 percent) have been reported in 12 of 21 countries of\nEastern and Southern Africa Region (ESAR) since the beginning of 2017.\nThese countries include: Somalia, Kenya, South Sudan, Tanzania,\nBurundi, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Angola, Uganda, Zambia, and\nRwanda. Somalia accounts for 76.6 percent of the total cases reported\nin the outbreak in 2017, followed by South Sudan at 15.7 percent. In the past 2-3 weeks (weeks 32-34/6-27 Aug 2017), 6 out of the 21\ncountries in ESAR have reported active transmission of cholera/AWD\n(Burundi, Malawi, Somalia, South Sudan, Kenya, and Tanzania). Tanzania\nhas recorded the highest CFR (1.8 percent) followed by South Sudan\n(1.7 percent) in 2017. CFR for Somalia was above 2 percent at the\nbeginning of 2017 but has since dropped to 1.4 percent. Somalia\n-\nThere has been a decrease in the epidemic trend. During week 33 (week\nending 20 Aug 2017), 222 new cases and no deaths were reported in the\ncountry; compared to 282 cases reported in week 32 (week ending 13 Aug\n2017). Out of the 222 new cases, 97 were reported from South Central\nand 125 were from Somali land. Most affected regions are Banadir,\nTogdheer, Awdal, Mjeex, and Lower Jubba. Kenya\n\n4 out of the 47 counties (Garissa, Nairobi, Turkana, and Nakuru) have\nan active cholera outbreak. During week 33, 19 new cases were reported\ncompared to 69 cases in week 32. South Sudan\n\nMost affected populations are nomadic pastoralists and communities\nliving in hard to reach villages and cattle camps. There has been a\ndecrease in the epidemic trend over the past 3 weeks. During week 32,\n30 new cases were reported; compared to 102 cases including 1 death\n(CFR 1 percent) in week 31 (week ending 6 Aug 2017). Active\ntransmission reported in Kapoeta East, South and North, Tonj East,\nYirol East, Nyirol, Ayod, Duk, and Juba. Tanzania\n\nAn increase in epidemic trend. During week 34 (week ending 27 Aug\n2017), 102 new cases have been reported in Tanzanian mainland;\ncompared to 67 cases in week 33. Cases emerged from Mbeya, Iringa, and\nKatavi regions. Malawi\n\nThe current outbreak started within the catchment area of the Chikwawa\nHospital. 11 new cases have been reported in week 34; compared to 2\ncases reported in week 33. Burundi\n-\nThe first case of the current outbreak was identified on 13 Aug 2017\nfrom Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Since then there has been an\nincrease in the epidemic trend with 24 cases reported in week 34; as\ncompared to 13 cases reported in week 33. No death has been reported\nand most of the cases emerged from the city center of Nyanza Lac. Uganda\n\nNo confirmed case of cholera in 2017, only AWD cases reported. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The countries mentioned above can be seen located on the map of\nAfrica at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6075). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \nAsia\n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab).\nDate: Tue 5 Sep 2017 12:32 AM IST.\nSource: The Tribune India (edited)\n(http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/this-day-that-year/cholera-in-lahore/462284.html) \nWe understand that cholera is assuming a virulent form in Lahore\nPunjab and that strong and effective measures are called for to\ncombat and stamp out the disease. In Kucha Kharasian in Haveli Mian\nKhan it is said 4 persons were taken ill at about noon and died the\nsame day. The next day, 5 persons were taken ill of the same disease.\nIt is, of course, impossible for laymen to make out whether all these\ncases were of cholera, but the nature of the deaths would seem to\nsuggest the urgent need of effective action. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofworld.com/pakistan/pakistan-political-map.html) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2128). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 per cent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are:\n- Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 per cent (95 per cent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam;\n- Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. WHO prequalified vaccines.\n(https://extranet.who.int/gavi/PQ_Web/).\n61. Balk YO, Choi SK, Olveda RM, et al. A randomized, non-inferiority\ntrial comparing two bivalent killed, whole cell, oral cholera vaccines\n(Euvichol vs Shanchol) in the Philippines. Vaccine 2015; 33(46):\n6350-65; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26348402).\n62. Freedman DO. Re-born in the USA: another cholera vaccine for\ntravellers. Travel Med Infect Dis. 2016; 14(4): 295-6; abstract\navailable at\n(http://www.travelmedicinejournal.com/article/S1477-8939(16)30087-4/abstract).\n63. Qadri F, Wierzba TF, Ali M, et al. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"North Korea":{"289":{"title":"Foodborne illness - South Korea: (NJ) fast food restaurant\r\n\tburger, poss EHEC, RFI ","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Foodborne illness - South Korea: (NJ) fast food restaurant\r\n\tburger, poss EHEC, RFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Mon 4 Sep 2017. Source: Korea JoongAng Daily (edited) (https://tinyurl.com/ya9hnp4n)   Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is conducting an epidemiological investigation into a case of 7 children and 1 adult who showed symptoms of food poisoning with vomiting and diarrhea after eating McDonald's hamburgers on 25 Aug 2017 at a Jeonju branch in North Jeolla.  Authorities are not ruling out the possibility that the 8 individuals contracted hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS), widely known as \"hamburger disease,\" a bacterial infection that can leave the renal system severely damaged. Many cases are caused by _E. coli_, which can be found in undercooked meat like hamburgers. Children under the age of 5 are particularly vulnerable. On 25 Aug 2017, a group of 15 adults and elementary school students from the same church in Jeonju visited McDonald's Jeonju branch and ate bulgogi burgers together. A day later, 7 children and 1 adult experienced diarrhea and vomiting. The authorities declared an epidemiological probe into the case on Sat 2 Sep 2017.  As the case was publicized, McDonald's Korea halted selling bulgogi burgers nationwide starting on Sat 2 Sep 2017. On its website, a notice says, \"We have decided to stop selling bulgogi burgers pending the outcome of the ongoing investigation by authorities,\" adding that the multinational company's Korean branch was taking the issue seriously. It also said the company will do its best to help patients recover, though without elaborating on how or when.  The outcome of the ongoing probe is expected to be made public around Wed 6 Sep 2017.  The case in Jeonju is not the only incident that the corporation, which has 440 branches in Korea alone, has recently found itself in. In July 2017, the mother of a 5-year-old girl filed a complaint claiming irreparable harm was done to her child because of the fast food chain's mismanagement of its food products. The mother, claimed her daughter contracted HUS after eating a Happy Meal in September 2016, and she now must undergo peritoneal dialysis on a daily basis.  McDonald's Korea branch also received a complaint from the parents of a 2-year-old girl, who began to have diarrhea and bloody excrement after eating a hamburger patty on 17 May 2017 at a Jamsil branch in southern Seoul. On 19 May 2017, the child was admitted to a local emergency room. The child's condition improved and she was discharged later that day.  Byline: Kang Jin-kyu   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Whether this cluster of illnesses is caused by enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ is unknown as yet and ProMED would appreciate more information about the illnesses. A one day incubation period is short for EHEC but the outbreak is occurring in the wake of several cases of EHEC linked to the chain in South Korea.  Classic bulgogi recipes use a marinade of soy, ginger, garlic, and gochujang (Korean chili paste) to flavor and tenderize strips of meat. Because combining a marinade into ground beef would change the consistency of the hamburger, making it more of a \"sloppy-joe\", usually a bulgogi inspired sauce is used on top of the burger although a Korean inspired spice combination can be added to the ground beef.  North Jeolla province or Jeollabuk-do is a province in the southwest of South Korea and can be found on a map at (http://tinyurl.com/jvukf5u). A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21702). - Mod.LL  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Northern Cyprys":{},"Northern Mariana Island":{},"Norway":{},"Oman":{},"Pakistan":{"16":{"title":"Poliomyelitis update (22): Syria, Afghanistan, Somalia,\r\n\tglobal ","date":["16","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Poliomyelitis update (22): Syria, Afghanistan, Somalia,\r\n\tglobal [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Syria: WHO situation report no. 9, 15 Aug 2017 <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Somalia: declared polio free <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Global: Global Polio Eradication Initiative, Syria, Afghanistan   <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Syria: WHO situation report no. 9, 15 Aug 2017. Date: Tue 15 Aug 2017. Source: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), ReliefWeb, WHO/UNICEF report (edited) (http://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syria-cvdpv2-outbreak-situation-report-9-15-august-2017)   Syria cVDPV2 outbreak situation report no. 9, 15 Aug 2017  Key highlights  Three new cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week from 3 new districts: 1 case from Deir ez-Zor district, Deir ez-Zor governorate; 1 from Boukamal district, Deir ez-Zor governorate; and 1 from Tadmour district, Homs governorate.  Five districts in 3 governorates are now infected.  The total number of cVDPV2 cases is 33 (this includes the previously reported 29 cases from Mayadeen district, Deir ez-Zor governorate, and 1 case from Tell Abyad district, Raqqa governorate). All confirmed cases to date have had onset of paralysis before 11 Jul 2017.  Final lab results for an additional 9 poliovirus type-2 (PV2) isolates from Deir ez-Zor are pending.  Discussions around expanding the scope of the immunization response to include accessible areas of a Tadmour sub-district in Homs, bordering Deir ez-Zor , will be held in light of the confirmation of the cases in this area.  Raqqa governorate commenced its 1st immunization round on 12 Aug 2017 (Raqqa and Thawra districts) and 13 Aug 2017 (Tell Abyad district). The immunization round aims to reach 120 000 children under 5 years of age. Preliminary information suggests the rounds are reaching children in all 3 districts.  Preparations continue for the 2nd round in Deir ez-Zor governorate, scheduled for 19-23 Aug 2017. IPV inactivated polio vaccine for use in the 2nd rounds in Deir ez-Zor and Raqqa governorates has arrived in Damascus.  The total number of AFP acute flaccid paralysis cases detected in Deir ez-Zor governorate since the beginning of 2017 is 113 (83 from Mayadeen, 11 from Deir ez-Zor, and 19 from Boukamal districts). Raqqa governorate has reported 16 AFP cases (5 from Raqqa, 10 from Tell Abyad, and 1 from Thawra districts). Homs governorate has reported 26 AFP cases (11 from Homs city, 12 from Rastan, 1 from Tadmour, and 2 from Talkalakh districts).  The Eradication and Outbreak Management Group (EOMG) has approved the release of additional doses of IPV to cover high risk population groups in northwest Syria, Turkey, and Lebanon. Lebanon requested 144 000 doses and has begun to implement IPV campaigns across the country.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Unfortunately transmission of the cVDPV2 in Syria has continued. With each report, the date of onset of the most recent case shifts to a date approximately one month preceding the report, probably reflecting the time it takes from specimen collection to appropriate reference laboratory. We are fairly sure there will be an additional 9 cases confirmed from Deir ez-Zor, as the report above mentions that there are 9 poliovirus isolates pending typing (WPV vs cVDPV). The report also mentions a significant number of AFP cases identified in the 3 governorates, suggesting there may be more cases in the pipeline for confirmation. The control activities have been implemented during this week and will be implemented in additional areas next week week of 21 Aug 2017, so hopefully there will be interruption of transmission going forward.  The disturbing news in the situation report above, is that there is now involvement of 3 governorates. Deir ez-Zor, Raqqa, and now Homs. On a map of Syria showing provinces/governorates ((http://www.freeworldmaps.net/asia/syria/syria-political-map.jpg)), one can see that Deir ez-Zor, the main governorate involved in this outbreak is located in the northeast of the country sharing it's eastern border with Iraq. It shares a southern border with Homs, and a western border with Raqqa (Ar-Raqqah on this map) governorate. Hopefully the cVDPV2 will not continue to travel in the country outside of the currently 3 affected areas. - Mod.MPP   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Somalia: declared polio free. Date: Mon 14 Aug 2017. Source: AllAfrica, Shabelle Media Network (Mogadishu) report (edited) (http://allafrica.com/stories/201708150227.html)   The UN World Health Organisation (WHO) said it had not recorded any case of polio disease in Somalia in the last 3 years, declaring the country polio free.  The WHO said the country recorded the last case of polio in 2014 in the central part of the country but has since then remained free of the paralyzing disease.  The UN health agency, however, warned Somalia remained vulnerable, calling for continued vaccination campaign, Xinhua News Agency reported.  The head of the WHO Eastern Mediterranean, which covers Somalia, Mohamed Fiqi said that massive vaccination campaigns and commitment from government and international actors had ensured the polio virus did not recur in the Horn of Africa country.  \"As the world edges closer to eradicating polio, keeping alert in countries that have high risk of polio importation like Somalia is more of priority than ever,\" Fiqi said.  \"As we move forward, the polio programme in Somalia needs to continue to work to maintain and improve the level of population immunity against polio through target vaccination campaign and strengthening of the routine immunisation services and infrastructure,\" Fiqi added.  The declaration by WHO keeps Somalia outside the last group of countries which still record cases of polio in the world.  Afghanistan, Nigeria, and Pakistan are the remaining countries where polio is still being recorded. The WHO chief warned Somalia remains at risk of importation of the virus from these countries.  Somalia President Mohamed Abdullahi Farmaajo praised efforts to rid his country of the polio disease which he noted had subjected many children into suffering.  \"No cases were found for the past 3 years and no child was affected by this disease. Many of our children have suffered from polio for many years.  \"To eradicate polio was a big success and it was collective effort and commitment by many young men and women who sacrificed their lives,\" Farmaajo noted.  The 3 year polio-free celebration comes amidst the worst outbreak of measles the country has seen in years.  Somalia is also still responding to an outbreak of acute watery diarrhoea/cholera, which began in January 2017. Polio systems and networks are being used in both interventions.  \"Polio infrastructure has been critical in responding to these other serious outbreaks,\" said Fiqi.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Achieving 3 years with no new cases of polio reported is a significant achievement for Somalia. That being said, it's important to remember that this too is a country with internal civil strife and warring factions, which may impede the identification of poliovirus associated disease either due to infrastructural challenges in good specimen collection and transport, or access of the population to the healthcare infrastructure. A reminder is the identification of WPV associated cases in Borno, Nigeria last year (2016), involving a virus last seen 5 years before in the same state.  The HealthMap/ProMED map of Somalia can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/125).- Mod.MPP   <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Global: Global Polio Eradication Initiative, Syria, Afghanistan. Date: Wed 16 Aug 2017. Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative (edited) (http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/)   Poliovirus weekly update  as of 16-Aug-2017  New wild poliovirus cases reported this week: 1 Total number of wild poliovirus cases in 2017: 9 Total number of wild poliovirus cases in 2016: 37  New cVDPV cases reported this week: 3 Total number of cVDPV cases in 2017: 40 Total number of cVDPV cases in 2016: 5  Headlines  - Marking Pakistan's Independence Day 14 August this week, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau paid tribute to both countries' ongoing collaboration, including on the effort to eradicate polio.\" Our 2 countries established a diplomatic relationship shortly after Pakistan was declared a sovereign nation in 1947. We continue to work together to advance shared priorities, including governance and democracy, regional security, poverty reduction, polio eradication, trade, defense, and the fight against climate change.\"  - The 14th Emergency Committee for polio eradication under the International Health Regulations met on 3 Aug 2017 and has made its recommendations to the WHO Director-General, who has accepted them. The Committee unanimously agreed that the risk of international spread of poliovirus remains a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), and recommended the extension of revised Temporary Recommendations for a further 3 months. The key change is the inclusion of DR Congo and Syria in the category 'States infected with cVDPV2s, with potential risk of international spread'.  - Summary of newly-reported viruses this week: Afghanistan: 1 new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) case; Pakistan: 1 new WPV1-positive environmental sample; Syrian Arab Republic: 3 new circulating vaccine-derived polio type 2 (cVDPV2) from Syria, 2 from Deir ez-Zor and 1 from Homs governorates. Details in country-specific sections below.  Afghanistan  - One new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) case was reported in the past week, bringing the total number of WPV1 cases for 2017 to 6. It is the most recent case in the country, and had onset of paralysis on 10 Jul 2017, from Zabul province, neighbouring Kandahar province and Pakistan. - Afghanistan continues to coordinate activities with neighbouring Pakistan, to address both cross-border transmission and focus on reaching mobile populations with oral polio vaccine (OPV). Transmission linking both countries runs primarily across 3 corridors, namely: eastern Afghanistan and Khyber-Peshawar, Pakistan; greater Kandahar/Helmand and Quetta, Pakistan; and, Paktika/Patkya/Khost and Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa/Federally Administered Tribal Areas, Pakistan.  Pakistan  - No new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) case was reported in the past week; the total number of WPV1 cases for 2017 remains 3. The most recent case in the country had onset of paralysis on 11 Jun 2017, from Killa Abdullah, Balochistan. - 1 new WPV1-positive environmental sample was reported in the past week, collected on 28 Jul 2017, from Quetta, Balochistan. - A special vaccination round is being implemented during August 2017 targeting areas with recent polio cases and positive environmental samples. These include Rawalpindi/Islamabad and demographically connected areas of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Quetta Block, and parts of Karachi. - Under the National Emergency Action Plan for polio eradication, the country is planning to implement 2 nation-wide and 2 sub-national vaccination rounds from September to December 2017.  Nigeria - - No new cases of wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) were reported in the past week. The total number of WPV1 cases for 2016 remains 4 and no cases have been reported in 2017. The most recent case had onset of paralysis on 21 Aug 2016 in Monguno Local Government Area (LGA), Borno. - Nigeria continues to implement emergency response to the detected WPV1 strain and circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) strains affecting the country (last detected in 2016). - Detection of the polio cases in Nigeria underscores the risk posed by low-level undetected transmission and the urgent need to strengthen subnational surveillance.  Lake Chad Basin  - The detection of wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) (Borno, Nigeria in 2016) and circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) (Borno and Sokoto provinces in Nigeria in 2016) continue to pose a risk to the neighbouring countries of the Lake Chad basin and hence an outbreak response plan is being implemented as part of the response to the Nigeria outbreak. - Emergency outbreak response efforts continue across the Lake Chad basin, together with activities to fill subnational surveillance gaps across the region.  Central Africa  - No new cases of type 2 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV2) were reported in the past week in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DR Congo). The total number of cVDPV2 cases this year 2017 remains 7, in 2 separate outbreaks: in Haut Lomami province (5 cases, with onset of paralysis of the most recent case on 13 Jun 2017); and in Maniema province (2 cases with onset of paralysis on 26 Mar 2017 and 18 Apr 2017, with an additional isolate detected in a healthy individual with sample collection on 2 May 2017). - Confirmation of additional cases is not unexpected at this time. Outbreak response is taking place, including use of monovalent oral polio vaccine type 2 (mOPV2) in line with internationally-agreed outbreak response protocols, targeting more than 750 000 children under the age of 5 across the 2 provinces. - The 1st mOPV2 round was implemented on 27-29 Jun 2017 in the 2 affected provinces; and the 2nd mOPV2 round ran from 13-15 Jul 2017 in Haut Lomami and 20-22 Jul 2017 in Maniema. - Surveillance and immunization activities are being strengthened in neighbouring countries.  Middle East  - In Syria, 3 new cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) were officially reported in the past week. The total number of cases in this outbreak is 33. Onset of paralysis of these cases is between 3 Mar 2017 and 10 Jul 2017. 31 of the cases are from Deir ez-Zor governorate (29 from Mayadeen district, one from Deir ez-Zor district, and one from Boukamal district); 1 case is from Talabyad district, Raqqa governorate; and, 1 is from Tadmour district in Homs governorate. - Confirmation of additional cases is not unexpected at this time and would not change the operational situation, as outbreak response plans are being finalized and implemented, in line with internationally-agreed outbreak response protocols. Two vaccination campaigns are planned for both Deir ez-Zor and Raqqa governorates. If there is geographic spread, the extent of these campaigns will have to be adjusted. - The 1st mOPV2 round in Deir ez-Zor was successfully carried out between 22-26 Jul 2017. Independent post-campaign monitoring reflected coverage of 88.4 percent (based on caregiver recall). The 2nd round is planned for 19-23 Aug 2017, and will include mOPV2 and IPV. - Raqqa Governorate started mOPV2 campaigns on 12 Aug 2017. - Plans are being finalized to mitigate the risks of further spread from the outbreak zone to neighbouring areas and countries, including immunization of at-risk populations in northwest Syria, Turkey and Lebanon. Following confirmation of the case in Homs, discussions are ongoing to further extend the geographic reach of the outbreak response.  Officially reported wild poliovirus cases as of 15 Aug 2017  Total global cases in 2017: 9 (compared with 21 for the same period in 2016) Total in endemic countries in 2017: 9 (compared with 21 for the same period in 2016) - Afghanistan: 6 cases in 2017 (compared with 6 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 10 Jul 2017 - Pakistan: 3 cases in 2017 (compared with 13 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 11 Jun 2017 - Nigeria: 0 cases in 2017 (compared with 2 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 21 Aug 2016 Total in non-endemic countries in 2017: 0 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016)  Total global cases in 2016: 37 - Total in endemic countries: 37 - Total in non-endemic countries: 0  Officially reported cVDPV cases as of 15 Aug 2017 - Total global cases in 2017: 40 (compared with 3 for the same period in 2016) - Syrian Arab Republic: 33 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 10 Jul 2017 - Democratic Republic of the Congo: 7 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 13 Jun 2017 - Pakistan: 0 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 17 Dec 2016 - Nigeria: 0 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 28 Oct 2016 - Lao People's Democratic Republic: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 3 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 11 Jan 2016  Total global cases in 2016: 5 - Total in endemic countries: 2 - Total in non-endemic countries: 3   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  This week's global update is similar to prior weeks in terms of low level identification of WPV1 associated disease (a single case confirmed in Afghanistan this past week), one positive WPV1 isolated from an environmental sample in Pakistan, and 3 newly confirmed cVDPV2 associated cases in Syria.  That being said, there have only been 9 confirmed cases of WPV1 associated paralytic disease worldwide this year (2017), compared with 37 cases reported last year (2016). In contrast there have been 40 confirmed cases of cVDPV2 confirmed this year (2017) compared with 5 last year (2016). As a reminder, outbreaks due to cVDPV's are considered as significant in the big picture of polio eradication, as they are due to vaccine polioviruses that have reverted in neurovirulence following passage through multiple individuals while circulating in the susceptible population. The goal of the polio eradication initiative is to interrupt transmission of both the WPV's and the cVDPVs. The presence of cVDPVs occurs when there are areas with low vaccination coverage where the vaccine virus (from the OPV) can continue circulating through the susceptible population.  HealthMap/ProMED-mail maps can be found at Syria: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/86) Afghanistan: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/137) Pakistan: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140).  An interactive map showing the geographic locations of all WPV and cVDPV associated cases can be found at (http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/). - Mod.MPP  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"31":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (86): Africa,\r\n\tAsia ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (86): Africa,\r\n\tAsia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (86): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR, West Africa\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Tanzania\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab Province) \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR, West Africa.\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: CAJ News Africa (edited)\n(http://cajnewsafrica.com/2017/08/18/hundreds-dead-in-raging-cholera-outbreak/) \nAt least 462 people have died in the conflict-torn Democratic Republic\nof Congo following a cholera outbreak sweeping through Central and\nWest Africa. The deaths from more than 16 539 cases reported so far in\n2017 represent 94 percent of the overall incidence in the regions of\nAfrica. This follows a major epidemic reported mainly in the North\nKivu province, which is the epicentre of the conflict between rebel\ngroups and the government. In the region, health delivery services have come to a standstill\nowing to the conflict. Civilians have been forced to flee their homes,\nadding to the tens of thousands already living in camps for internally\ndisplaced people. Meanwhile, In West Africa, similarly to 2016, several countries report\nsporadic cases. Terror-ridden Nigeria is also battling a severe\noutbreak of the water borne disease with 20 deaths recorded from 809\ncases in 2017. Liberia, a hotspot for diseases, is also affected with\n6 deaths from 129 cases. There have also been outbreaks in Cameroon,\nGhana and Ivory Cast but no casualties have been reported. Overall,\n488 deaths have been reported from 17 548 cases in the affected\nregions. The United Nations Children's Fund stressed the need for increasing\nvigilance and implementing preventative measures in the current\nat-risk seasonal period. \"This highlights the importance of regular\ninformation exchange within countries sharing the same epidemiological\nbasin.\" Byline: Jean Kassongo \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Tanzania.\nDate: Wed 16 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/united-republic-tanzania/taking-stock-lessons-learnt-cholera-outbreak-response-tanzania) \nTaking stock of lessons learnt from the Cholera outbreak response in\nTanzania\n\nThe United Republic of Tanzania is battling an outbreak of Cholera\nthat has since August 2015 affected 26 046 people and claimed 410\nlives. Ending the outbreak and preventing its spread beyond Tanzania's\nborders is a high priority for WHO. To that end, WHO and partners\nsupport a well-coordinated multisectoral response through the National\nCholera Task Force which plans, coordinates and support subnational\nauthorities. Indeed, learning requires a continuous assessment of performance, a\nreview of successes and failures and a robust support for improvement.\nAn After Action Review (AAR) is a simple methodology for facilitating\nthis assessment. It provides for a qualitative review of actions taken\nto respond to an emergency as a means of identifying best practices,\ngaps and lessons learned. As a component of the IHR Monitoring and\nEvaluation Framework (IHR MEF) and part of the preparedness and\nresponse cycle, an AAR seeks to identify what worked well or not and\nhow these practices can be maintained, improved, institutionalized and\nshared with relevant stakeholders. It is within this context that WHO\nsupported the Ministry of Health to convene a meeting of experts to\nconduct an After Action Review following the national response to the\ncholera outbreak. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/cholera-new-deaths-and-infections-across-sudan) \nSinga Hospital in Sudan's Sennar received 16 new cases of cholera\nduring the 1st half of this week week of Sun 13 Aug 2017. A woman\nhas died before she could be transferred to hospital, and 9 others\nwere infected with cholera at El Matateib in North Delta locality in\nSudan's Kassala state. Sennar State\nA medical source told Radio Dabanga that most of the cases in Sennar\ncame from Um Benin village southeast of the city except for 2 cases\nfrom El Dindir and El Souki. From Saturday to Monday 12-14 Aug 2017,\n26 cases of cholera arrived from Um Benin village. This led the local\nhealth authorities to open a new cholera isolation centre at the\nvillage. El Gedaref State\nEl Gedaref Hospital in East Sudan recorded 15 cases of cholera on\nTuesday and Wednesday 15-16 Aug 2017. A medical source told Radio\nDabanga that the hospital received 9 cases on Tue 15 Aug 2017, while\n6 cases were recorded on Wed 16Aug 2017. The medic said that all\ncases of cholera came from Uktuber, El Tadamon, El Geneina, and\nKadugli districts in El Gedaref. Kassala State\nA woman has died before she could be transferred to hospital, and 9\nothers were infected with cholera at El Matateib in North Delta\nlocality in Sudan's Kassala state. Youth activist Mohamed Seyidna told\nRadio Dabanga that \"the woman died in the village before she could be\ntransferred to the hospital\". He said that the hospitalised cases at\nWagar Hospital have risen to 9. He attributed the spread of cholera in the area to water pollution and\ncalled on the health authorities to make efforts to sterilize drinking\nwater and raise awareness of the residents. National epidemic\nThe National Epidemiological Corporation reported in early July 2017\nthat nearly 24 000 Sudanese have been infected and 940 cholera\npatients have died since the outbreak of the infectious disease in\nBlue Nile state in August 2016. The Sudanese authorities however,\nrefuse to call the disease by its name, and instead refer to it as\n\"Acute Watery Diarrhea\". The National Intelligence and Security\nService has repeatedly warned medics and the press in the country not\nto make mention of cholera. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab Province).\nDate: Wed 16 Aug 2017.\nSource: The News (edited)\n(https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/223756-Number-of-cholera-cases-continues-to-swell) \nThe number of cases of cholera, a highly contagious and fatal disease\nis continuously on the rise and there is a threat that spread of the\ninfection may take shape of an epidemic if proper preventive and\ncontrol measures are not taken well in time. The 1st 2 cases of\ncholera were tested positive by National Institute of Health Islamabad\non Mon 31 Jul 2017 and another 2 confirmed positive for the\ninfection on Fri 4 Aug 2017. All the 4 patients were undergoing\ntreatment at Benazir Bhutto Hospital BH where as many as 4 more\nsuspects of the infection have been admitted for treatment. Data collected by 'The News' on Mon 14 Aug 2017 reveals that the\nallied hospitals have sent stool samples of over 10 child patients to\nNIH for confirmation of cholera in last week week of Sun 6 Aug\n2017. On Sat 12 Aug 2017, as many as 20 child patients with severe\ndiarrhoea were admitted at the BBH of which 4 were suspected as\npatients of cholera and their stool samples were sent to NIH for\nconfirmation, said Associate Professor of Paediatrics at Rawalpindi\nMedical University Dr Tariq Saeed when contacted by 'The News' on Mon\n14 Aug 2017. He added the hospital has not received confirmation reports from the\nNIH because of holidays there from Saturday to Monday. However, we\nhave been keeping the suspects in isolation under strict monitoring,\nhe said. He added that repeated rainfalls in the region and water inundation\ninside and outside homes in a number of localities particularly in\nthickly populated areas of the city are causing contamination of water\nand foodstuff that increases chances of spread of a number of\ninfections among population while children are at greater risk of\ncontracting life-threatening infections including cholera. It is important that the transmission of cholera occurs primarily by\ndrinking water or eating food that has been contaminated by the feces\n(waste product) of an infected person, including one with no apparent\nsymptoms. It is observed that heavy rainfall causes collection of heavily\ncontaminated water in streets and houses and the waste water flooding\nout of various nullahs watercourses including Nullah Leh in town\ncauses infections including cholera, typhoid, dysentery,\ngastroenteritis, hepatitis A and E, shigellosis and giardiasis. Professor Tariq said the consumption of contaminated water and\nfoodstuff causes cholera, an infection in the small intestine caused\nby bacterium _Vibrio cholerae_. Its main symptoms are watery diarrhea\nand vomiting that can lead to rapid dehydration and electrolyte\nimbalance, and death in cases which are not treated in time, he said. Health experts say that to avoid cholera and other infections, one\nmust use boiled water for drinking and should use vegetables after\nwashing with clean water and it must be kept in mind that raw\nvegetables should not be eaten in the existing weather conditions\ninstead these should be used after cooking. To a query, Professor Tariq said the heavy rainfall and water\naccumulation may contaminate water at sources and there may be chances\nof contamination of water at tube wells so individuals must boil water\nbefore drinking to avoid cholera and other infections. He added the appearance of cholera is alarming and it is time for\npeople to take extra ordinary preventive measures to safeguard their\nchildren and themselves from the disease. In case water is accumulated inside home due to heavy rainfall and\nflooded out of sewage lines, it must be wiped out immediately and the\nspace should be washed with clean water as soon as possible to avoid\ninfections. Avoiding inundation of contaminated water inside homes is\na must to avoid cholera and other infections, said Professor Tariq. Byline: Muhammad Qasim \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-SoAs\n(promed-SoAs@promedmail.org) Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 percent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are: - Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 percent (95 percent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam; - Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n-\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. WHO prequalified vaccines.\n(https://extranet.who.int/gavi/PQ_Web/).\n61. Balk YO, Choi SK, Olveda RM, et al. A randomized, non-inferiority\ntrial comparing two bivalent killed, whole cell, oral cholera vaccines\n(Euvichol vs Shanchol) in the Philippines. Vaccine 2015; 33(46):\n6350-65; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26348402).\n62. Freedman DO. Re-born in the USA: another cholera vaccine for\ntravellers. Travel Med Infect Dis. 2016; 14(4): 295-6; abstract\navailable at\n(http://www.travelmedicinejournal.com/article/S1477-8939(16)30087-4/abstract).\n63. Qadri F, Wierzba TF, Ali M, et al. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5626). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"59":{"title":"Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Pakistan (10): (PB) advice\r\n\tissued ","date":["20","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Pakistan (10): (PB) advice\r\n\tissued [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Case from Rawalpindi Punjab. Date: Sun 20 Aug 2017. Source: The News (edited) (https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/224669-Patient-tested-positive-at-HFH)   A patient undergoing treatment at one of the 3 teaching hospitals in town, Holy Family Hospital, tested positive for Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) on Sat 19 Aug 2017. The patient was taken to the Holy Family Hospital on Mon 14 Aug 2017 from Tehsil Hazro of District Attock, some 80 kilometres 49.70 mi from Rawalpindi.  The confirmation of the patient has strengthened doubts that the population in the region may face a possible spike of CCHF ahead of Eidul Azha Islamic festival when sacrificial animals are being brought to the town in bulk.  However, it is important that this is not the 1st confirmed case of CCHF this year 2017 at the HFH. Data reveal that this year, 2017, a total of 22 suspected cases of CCHF were admitted to HFH, 5 of whom tested positive for the disease while 17 were negative. Studies show that the CCHF is caused by Nairovirus of the Bunyaviridae family transmitted to humans by the bite of hyalomma tick found on the skin of animals including goat and sheep or by direct contact with the blood of an infected animal or human. The case fatality rate ranges from 2 to 50 per cent. CCHF was 1st described in Crimea in 1944 and identified in 1956 in Congo.  It is worth mentioning here that the disease was 1st reported in Pakistan in 1976 but the numbers of cases have risen dramatically since 2000, with 50 to 60 patients being reported annually. It is important that the CCHF is endemic in Pakistan.  The patient is undergoing treatment at the HFH in isolation. He is stable, said the head of the Department of Infectious Diseases at Rawalpindi Medical University, assistant professor Dr Muhammad Mujeeb Khan while talking to 'The News' on Sat 19 Aug 2017. To avoid CCHF, he suggested that proper preventive measures should be taken while handling animals. It is better to establish water ponds carrying DEET or potassium permanganate and animals should be passed through it to clear their skin, he said.  byline: Muhammad Qasim   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> CCHF advisory notice. Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017. Source: Pakistan Today (edited) (https://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/08/18/nih-issues-advisory-on-congo-fever-for-eid-ul-azha/)   The National Institute of Health (NIH) issued an advisory notice on Fri 18 Aug 2017 on prevention and control of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) for upcoming Eid-ul-Azha.  According to NIH, the objective of this advice was to sensitize human and animal health care authorities to further strengthen and improve the level of preparedness in prevention and control of CCHF.  The notice, which was issued by the NIH Field Epidemiology and Disease Surveillance Division, said that the CCHF is a widespread disease caused by a tickborne virus (Nairovirus) of the Bunyaviridae family with a case fatality rate of 10 to 40 per cent. It added that the ticks, especially of the _Hyalomma_ genus, are both a reservoir and a vector for the CCHF while numerous wild and domestic animals such as cattle, buffaloes, goats and sheep are silent carriers of this virus, and the adult ticks feed on these animals.  The notice said that although Balochistan remains the most affected province, cases have been reported from almost all parts of the country.  During 2016, out of 101 confirmed cases, 33 patients died. During 2017, till date, a total of 41 confirmed cases have been reported including 16 from Balochistan, 15 from Punjab, 7 from Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) and 3 from FATA.  The advisory notice said that the virus is transmitted to the people either through tick bites or through contact with the infected animal blood or tissues during and immediately after slaughtering them. Public health workers along with animal herders, veterinarians, para-veterinary staff, livestock workers, animal merchants, butchers and slaughterhouse workers are at risk of the disease. Apart from the above mentioned, people close to or taking care of a suspected patient, and individuals involved in burial practices are also at a risk of getting infected, it added. There is currently no vaccine available for humans and the only way to reduce infection is by raising awareness.  The notice further added that public health advice should focus on several aspects including wearing protective clothing  such as long sleeves and trousers. People should be advised to wear light coloured clothes during a visit to the animal market to allow easy detection of ticks, and to regularly examine clothing and skin for ticks and if found, removing them safely and using approved repellents on clothing and skin.  Similarly, citizens have been asked not to crush the ticks, wear gloves and other protective clothing while handling animals or their tissues, notably during slaughtering, butchering and culling procedures in slaughterhouses or at home. They have also been asked to avoid close physical contact with infected people, wearing gloves and protective equipment when taking care of them. People are also asked to wash hands frequently during caring or after visiting a patient.  The notice stated that insect repellents are the most effective in warding off ticks in human populations.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The National Institute of Health Pakistan has issued this CCHF advisory notice in view of the upcoming Eid Ul Adha, when large numbers of livestock and cattle are moved from rural areas to urban markets for sale and subsequent slaughter.  More spatial repellent products are becoming commercially available. These products, containing active ingredients such as metofluthrin and allethrin, augment aerosol insecticide sprays, vaporizing mats, and mosquito coils, which have been available for some time. Such products can help to clear rooms or areas of mosquitoes (spray aerosols) or repel mosquitoes from a circumscribed area (coils, spatial repellents). Although many of these products appear to have repellent or insecticidal activity under particular conditions, they have not yet been adequately evaluated in peer-reviewed studies for their efficacy in preventing vectorborne disease. Travelers should supplement the use of these products with repellent on skin or clothing and using bed nets in areas where vectorborne diseases are a risk or biting arthropods are noted (https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2018/the-pre-travel-consultation/protection-against-mosquitoes-ticks-other-arthropods).  CDC has evaluated information published in peer-reviewed scientific literature and data available from EPA to identify several types of EPA-registered products that provide repellent activity sufficient to help people reduce the bites of disease-carrying mosquitoes. Products containing the following active ingredients typically provide reasonably long-lasting protection:   - DEET (chemical name: N,N-diethyl-m-toluamide or N,N-diethyl-3-methyl-benzamide). Products containing DEET include, but are not limited to, Off!, Cutter, Sawyer, and Ultrathon.  - Picaridin (KBR 3023 Bayrepel and icaridin outside the US; chemical name: 2-(2-hydroxyethyl)-1-piperidinecarboxylic acid 1-methylpropyl ester). Products containing picaridin include, but are not limited to, Cutter Advanced, Skin So Soft Bug Guard Plus, and Autan (outside the US).  - Oil of lemon eucalyptus (OLE) or PMD (chemical name: para-menthane-3,8-diol), the synthesized version of OLE. Products containing OLE and PMD include, but are not limited to, Repel and Off ! Botanicals. This recommendation refers to EPA-registered products containing the active ingredient OLE (or PMD). \"Pure\" oil of lemon eucalyptus (essential oil not formulated as a repellent) is not recommended; it has not undergone similar, validated testing for safety and efficacy and is not registered with EPA as an insect repellent.  - IR3535 (chemical name: 3-N-butyl-N-acetyl-aminopropionic acid, ethyl ester). Products containing IR3535 include, but are not limited to, Skin So Soft Bug Guard Plus Expedition and SkinSmart.  - 2-undecanone (chemical name: methyl nonyl ketone). The product BioUD contains 2-undecanone.  Published data indicate that repellent efficacy and duration of protection vary considerably among products and among mosquito and tick species. Product efficacy and duration of protection are also markedly affected by ambient temperature, level of activity, amount of perspiration, exposure to water, abrasive removal, and other factors. In general, higher concentrations of active ingredient provide longer duration of protection, regardless of the active ingredient. Products with less than 10 per cent active ingredient may offer only limited protection, often 1-2 hours. Products that offer sustained-release or controlled-release (microencapsulated) formulations, even with lower active ingredient concentrations, may provide longer protection times. Studies suggest that concentrations of DEET above approximately 50 per cent do not offer a marked increase in protection time against mosquitoes; DEET efficacy tends to plateau at a concentration of about 50 per cent. CDC recommends using products with at least 20 per cent DEET on exposed skin to reduce biting by ticks that may spread disease. DEET-containing repellents prevent both mosquito and tick bites. Health Canada recommends using a product containing no more than 10 per cent DEET for children up to 12 years of age. However, products with a DEET concentration of 10 per cent or less should not be used for exposures lasting longer than 1 h to 2 h because they may not be effective in preventing tick bites. For children over 12 years of age and adults, a repellent containing up to 30 per cent DEET can be used as recommended on the product label. In the United States, 30 per cent DEET is approved for children aged 2 months of age and older. Reapplication of DEET is indicated only if the estimated protection period has passed and a significant risk of arthropod bites remains. Adverse events from DEET are rare. Contact dermatitis and eye irritation are the commonest side effects. Toxic encephalopathy has been reported, usually with prolonged or excessive use, or occasional DEET ingestion (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4173961/pdf/pch-19-326.pdf).  Permethrin, a synthetic pyrethroid , is highly effective both as an insecticide and as a repellent. It is not licensed to be used as a topical repellent but can be sprayed on clothing (mesh jackets, hats, shoes) bed nets and camping gear to repel and kill ticks, mosquitoes and other insects. - Mod.UBA  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/941).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"78":{"title":"Anthrax - Pakistan (03): (TA) bovine ","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Anthrax - Pakistan (03): (TA) bovine [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 23 Aug 2017. Source: Dawn (edited) (https://www.dawn.com/news/1353357/anthrax-outbreak-kills-several-cattle-in-bajaur)   An outbreak of anthrax has reportedly killed several animals in Mamund and Salarzai tehsils sub districts of Bajaur Agency Federally Administered Tribal Areas, FATA, local people and officials said on Tue 22 Aug 2017. They said at least 26 cattle heads had been killed and several others infected by the disease in the 2 mountainous subdivisions. The locals said the disease had spread fear and panic among them.  Meanwhile, sources in the local livestock department confirmed the death of cattle due to the outbreak of anthrax. They said teams had been dispatched to the affected areas to administer anti-anthrax vaccines to animals.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Pakistan can be seen at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/pakistan/pakistan-political-map.html) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/32964).  For a description of Bajaur, go to (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bajaur_Agency) Bajaur is on the NE border of Pakistan with Afghanistan. \"Bajaur is inhabited almost exclusively by Tarkani (Tarkalani) Pashtuns, and there are their main sub-tribes in Bajaur: Utman Khel, Tarkalanri, Mamund (Kakazai, Wur, and Salarzai) as well as a small population of Safis. The Utman Khel are at the south east of Bajaur, while Mamund are at the south west, and the Tarkani are at the north of Bajaur. Its border with Afghanistan's Kunar province makes it of strategic importance to Pakistan and the region.\"  In June 2017, the veterinary service was vaccinating livestock in Toda Cheena area of central Kurram Agency of the Federally Administered Tribal Areas, in response to a suspected outbreak of anthrax; see 11 Jun 2017 Anthrax - Pakistan (02): (TA) livestock vaccinated http://promedmail.org/post/20170611.5098784. This was well received by the locals and that experience will have aided the reporting of cattle deaths in the Mamond and Salarzai sub districts. Now that they are acquiring information on affected areas the veterinary service can start planning to proactively vaccinate cattle in these areas next year 2018, in advance of the \"anthrax season\". - Mod.MHJ  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"115":{"title":"Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Dengue/DHF update (10): Asia, Pacific, Africa, research, WHO\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nDENGUE/DHF UPDATE (10): ASIA, PACIFIC, AFRICA, RESEARCH, WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries Asia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National\n- National\n- National\nIndia\n- National\n- Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Assam\n- Delhi\n- Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore)\n- Tamil Nadu\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Tamil Nadu (Chennai)\n- Kerala\n- Karnataka\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- Karnataka (Gulbarga)\n- West Bengal (Kolkata)\n- West Bengal (Birbhum)\n- West Bengal (Siliguri)\n- Odisha (Ganjam)\n- Odisha\n- Gujarat (Ahmedabad)\n- Jharkhand (Jamshedpur)\n- Telangana (Hyderabad)\nPakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\n- Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar)\nChina\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp)\n- Hong Kong SAR\n- Macau SAR\n- Macau SAR\nTaiwan\nMyanmar\n- National\n- Kayah\nIndonesia\n- Papua (Jayapura)\nViet Nam\n- National\n- National\n- Mekong Delta\n- Hanoi\n- Ha Nam\nPhilippines\n- National\n- Cebu\n- Negros Occidental\n- Negros Occidental (Bacolod City)\n- Cavite (Trece Martires City)\nLaos\n- National\nJapan ex Côte d'Ivoire Pacific\n\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Samoa\n- Fiji\n- French Polynesia (Tahiti) Africa\n\n- Côte d'Ivoire\n- Côte d'Ivoire <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence\n- Air travel related spread of dengue\n- Visual impact <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> World Health Organization update \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries\nAsia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National. 26 Jul 2017. Sri Lanka has now notified 107 015 cases,\nwhich WHO estimates is 4.3 times more than the average number of cases\nusually reported (http://tinyurl.com/ycvszzs8). - National. 19 Aug 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. This compares with about 39 000 cases reported from January\nto August 2016, and 55 150 cases during the entire year 2016.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - National. 25 Aug 2017. Through Fri 25 Aug 2017, Sri Lanka has\nofficially reported 144 052 cases and, as of 3 Aug 2017, 3327 people\nhave died.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-epidemic-waning-sri-lanka-university-jaffna-science-faculty-closed-september-83024/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sri Lanka can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/144). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ India\n- National. 31 Jul 2017. 11 832 more cases than in 2016 and 46 deaths,\n11 more than in 2016. The total has risen to 28 702, with 2536 cases\nand 10 deaths last week week of 24 Jul 2017. Floods continued to wreak\nhavoc in the 3 states, which reported 88 more dengue-related deaths.\nOfficials said 33 more dengue-related deaths had been reported in\nUttar Pradesh over the last 2 days.\n(http://www.christianmessenger.in/floods-in-bihar-up-assam-88-die-in-dengue-related-deaths/) - Delhi. 31 Jul 2017. As of 29 Jul 2017, 180 cases of dengue (monsoon\narrived early).\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/882984/dengue-malaria-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise-in-delhi/) - Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore). 4 Aug 2017. Deaths rise to 16 in last 2\nmonths; new admissions increasing.\n(http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/2-more-dengue-deaths-in-coimbatore-total-deaths-now-16-117080401128_1.html) - Tamil Nadu. 11 Aug 2017. Prevalence of dengue in Tamil Nadu is\ndecreasing. So far, 5000 people have been affected and due to proper\ntreatment by doctors in government and private hospitals, almost all\ndengue patients have been saved, health minister C Vijaya Baskar said\ntoday 11 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.dnaindia.com/\nhealth/report-prevalence-of-dengue-in-tn-down-health-minister-2526936) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 18 Aug 2017. At least 1500 new cases in 10\ndays.
