(conf.) 368 cases; Provinces most\naffected: Tumbes (84 cases), La Cruz y Zarumilla.\n(http://larepublica.pe/sociedad/892895-tumbes-certifican-368-casos-de-dengue-93-casos-de-chikungunya-y-106-de-leptospirosis)\n. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Philippines":{"20":{"title":"Japanese encephalitis - Philippines: (PM) ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis - Philippines: (PM) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017. Source: Sun Star (edited) (http://www.sunstar.com.ph/pampanga/local-news/2017/08/18/22-cases-japanese-encephalitis-recorded-pampanga-559150)   The Department of Health (DOH) has recorded a total of 149 cases of the deadly Japanese encephalitis with at least 22 cases in noted Pampanga , the highest in the Central Luzon region during the 1st quarter of 2017.  Japanese encephalitis is a viral disease spread by blood-sucking insects, particularly mosquitoes. The mosquitoes of the _Culex_ species are known to be the viral carriers.  The DOH said it affects the nervous system, causes severe complications and even death. The disease can infect not only humans but domestic animals, birds, bats, snakes, and frogs as well.  Among the symptoms of Japanese encephalitis, according to the DOH, are flu-like illnesses, fever, chills, headache, nausea, vomiting, and tiredness. The symptoms usually appear 6-8 days after the mosquito bite.  If untreated, patients could suffer brain damage or paralysis as it also affects the spinal cord. In 30 percent of the cases, death could occur. Young children are more vulnerable due to their weak immune system.  While there is no cure, the virus could be prevented through vaccination.  A separate report from the World Health Organization (WHO) said that Japanese encephalitis is an illness that is endemic in the Philippines and is fatal in almost 3 out of 10 serious cases.  The WHO report also said that nearly all survivors of this mosquito-borne disease experience permanent damage, including physical disabilities, cognitive and language problems, learning disabilities and behavioral problems.  Byline: Ian Ocampo Flora   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  This is a cluster of Japanese encephalitis in central Luzon Island. Clusters have been relatively rare in the Philippines. There have been relatively few reports of human Japanese encephalitis (JE) cases in the Philippines in recent years, although the islands are within the JE virus endemic zone.  Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is the leading cause of vaccine-preventable encephalitis in Asia and the western Pacific. It is caused by a virus transmitted by culicine mosquitoes. Ardeid birds (including herons) are the reservoir species in nature.  Most human infections are asymptomatic or result in only mild symptoms. However, a small percentage of infected persons develop encephalitis, with symptoms including sudden onset of headache, high fever, disorientation, coma, tremors, and convulsions. About 1 in 4 encephalitis cases is fatal. Apparently, none of the cases in the report above died. There is no specific treatment for JE. Patient management focuses on supportive care and management of complications. Steps to prevent JE virus infections include vaccination and use of personal protective measures to prevent mosquito bites.  Maps of the Philippines can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/z4y3p5v) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/19797). - Mod.TY  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"91":{"title":"Avian influenza, human (68): Philippines, H5N6 ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Avian influenza, human (68): Philippines, H5N6 [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nAVIAN INFLUENZA, HUMAN (68): PHILIPPINES, H5N6\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Thu 24 Aug 2016.\nSource: CNN Philippines (edited)\n(http://cnnphilippines.com/news/2017/08/24/Pampanga-bird-flu-strain-transmissible-to-humans.html) \nThe bird flu that has hit parts of the Philippines has been confirmed\nto be H5N6  a strain that can be transmitted to humans. This was\nconfirmed upon receipt of laboratory results from test samples that\nwere sent to Australia. Agriculture officials were quick to assure,\nhowever, that the strain is slow to spread and causes few deaths. \"The rate of transmission is very, very low,\" Arlene Vytiaco, who\nheads animal disease control in the Bureau of Animal Industry, said in\na press briefing on Thursday. She explained that countries like Japan\nand Myamnar have been affected by H5N6 but have reported no humans\ninfected by the avian influenza. \"The mortality rate is also low,\"\nVytiaco said. Since H5N6 started in 2014, only 20 deaths have been\nreported worldwide. The Department of Health has been conducting regular check-ups on\nfarmers and workers in areas hit by the bird flu outbreak. Vytiaco\nsaid no new patients have been admitted since 2 farm workers reported\nflu-like symptoms last week week of Sun 13 Aug 2017 but eventually\ntested negative for bird flu. The government had been waiting to see what the bird flu's specific N\nstrain was - particularly on the lookout for the N1 and N6 strains,\nwhich can be passed on to humans. Local tests had confirmed it was not\nthe far deadlier H5N1 virus. However, it had to send samples to\nAustralia to check whether it was H5N6, since the government did not\nhave its own test kits here. This was said by Dr Arlene Vytiaco, who\noversees disease control for the Bureau of Animal Industry. Reports of bird flu being present were 1st reported earlier this month\nAugust 2017. The virus was found in birds from 7 farms in San Luis,\nPampanga. The Department of Agriculture DA earlier said the virus\nhad been present since April 2017, but was only reported in August\n2017 after 37 000 birds had died. It added the strain of avian flu\npresent in these birds was not transmissible to humans. On Sun 13 Aug 2017, agriculture secretary Manny Piñol said another\nround of tests was under way to determine whether H5N6  the strain\nof the virus that can be passed on to humans  was present. The DA imposed a ban on the shipment of poultry and poultry products\nfrom Luzon to other parts of the country on Sun 13 Aug 2017 as a\nprecautionary measure, but it was lifted on Tue 22 Aug 2017. byline: Claire Jiao \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The above report provides follow-up information on an earlier post\nAvian influenza, human (66): Philippines, H5\nhttp://promedmail.org/post/20170818.5254521, in which 2 human cases\nwere suspected to have avian influenza H5, but were confirmed as\nnegative. However, the presence of avian Influenza A/H5N6 in affected poultry\nhas been confirmed. The last human cases of infections with avian\ninfluenza A(H5N6) virus were reported in Nov and Dec 2016\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/07-december-2016-ah5n6-china/en/). -\nMod.UBA A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/158). Sri Lanka has now notified 107 015 cases,\nwhich WHO estimates is 4.3 times more than the average number of cases\nusually reported (http://tinyurl.com/ycvszzs8). - National. 19 Aug 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. This compares with about 39 000 cases reported from January\nto August 2016, and 55 150 cases during the entire year 2016.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - National. 25 Aug 2017. Through Fri 25 Aug 2017, Sri Lanka has\nofficially reported 144 052 cases and, as of 3 Aug 2017, 3327 people\nhave died.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-epidemic-waning-sri-lanka-university-jaffna-science-faculty-closed-september-83024/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sri Lanka can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/144). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ India\n- National. 31 Jul 2017. 11 832 more cases than in 2016 and 46 deaths,\n11 more than in 2016. The total has risen to 28 702, with 2536 cases\nand 10 deaths last week week of 24 Jul 2017. Floods continued to wreak\nhavoc in the 3 states, which reported 88 more dengue-related deaths.\nOfficials said 33 more dengue-related deaths had been reported in\nUttar Pradesh over the last 2 days.\n(http://www.christianmessenger.in/floods-in-bihar-up-assam-88-die-in-dengue-related-deaths/) - Delhi. 31 Jul 2017. As of 29 Jul 2017, 180 cases of dengue (monsoon\narrived early).\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/882984/dengue-malaria-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise-in-delhi/) - Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore). 4 Aug 2017. Deaths rise to 16 in last 2\nmonths; new admissions increasing.\n(http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/2-more-dengue-deaths-in-coimbatore-total-deaths-now-16-117080401128_1.html) - Tamil Nadu. 11 Aug 2017. Prevalence of dengue in Tamil Nadu is\ndecreasing. So far, 5000 people have been affected and due to proper\ntreatment by doctors in government and private hospitals, almost all\ndengue patients have been saved, health minister C Vijaya Baskar said\ntoday 11 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.dnaindia.com/\nhealth/report-prevalence-of-dengue-in-tn-down-health-minister-2526936) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 18 Aug 2017. Over 6000 patients have been confirmed and\ntreated as in-patients; mortality has been kept to 1 per cent.\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/thiruvananthapuram/882347/mch-keeps-dengue-mortality-rate-to-1/#) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 4 Aug 2017. 235 cases in Gulbarga district\nfrom January to July 2017. Of the 235, 171 cases were reported from\nKalaburagi taluk sub district alone, 32 from Chincholli taluk, 13\nfrom Chittapur taluk, 4 cases each from Afzalpur, Aland, and Sedam\ntaluks, and 3 cases from Jewargi taluk.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/235-dengue-cases-in-kalaburagi-dist/article19423638.ece) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 23 Aug 2017. A total of 474 confirmed cases in\nGulbarga district, with 1927 suspected cases; 368 cases confirmed in\nKalaburagi sub district. Only 43 cases were reported in the district\ntill the end of June 2017 and 191 cases were reported between 1 and\n10 Aug 2017, while 240 new cases have been registered, taking the\ntotal to 474.\n(http://www.uniindia.com/dengue-474-confirmed-cases-reported-in-kalaburagi-district/health-and-medicine/fullstory/968353.html) - Karnataka. 18 Aug 2017. Nearly 8000 cases in Karnataka so far in\n2017. Dengue scare at RG Kar Hospital\nMedical College hostel; at least 8 test positive over the last week.\nIn 2015, more than 30 were affected in the hostel campus and one died.\nOn 2016 too, more than a dozen inmates were affected.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/dengue-scare-at-rg-kar-hostel-8-test-positive/articleshow/60029232.cms) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nAnirban Ghosh\nKasturba Medical College\n(m_anirbanghosh@hotmail.com) - West Bengal (Birbhum). 21 Aug 2017. At least 100 cases dengue have\nbeen reported from West Bengal's Birbhum district. \"We have received\nreports of at least 100 cases of dengue since 23 Jul 2017. While\nabout 60 of these cases are from the Dubrajpur town in the district's\nSuri Sadar sub-division, the rest are from other areas such as Bolpur\nand Rampurhat towns. But no one has died so far,\" the chief medical\nofficer of Birbhum, Himadri Ari, told The Hindu.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/bengal-records-100-dengue-cases/article19535541.ece) - West Bengal (Siliguri). 23 Aug 2017. The number of people suffering\nfrom dengue is rising at an alarming rate in Siliguri. According to\nrecords, the highest number of dengue cases reported was 54. This year\n2017, the mark has been crossed.\n(http://siliguritimes.com/number-dengue-patients-rise-siliguri/) - Odisha (Ganjam). 22 Jul 2017. Blood samples of 116 people of the\ndistrict were recently tested and 4 dengue positive cases were\ndetected. Disinfecting water bodies in the district has already\nstarted and a 3-member team has been entrusted with spreading\nawareness on dengue in the district.\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jul/22/4-found-dengue-positive-in-odishas-ganjam-district-1632062.html) - Odisha. 18 Aug 2017. 402 cases and 2 deaths. Last year 2016 4348\npersons were tested positive for the dengue virus by this period with\n8 deaths. Out of total 402 infected persons, 67 were tested positive\nin Bhadrak district, 61 in Cuttack district, and 59 in Balasore\ndistrict. Similarly, 35 people have been infected in Khordha, 34 in\nJajpur, 24 in Puri, 20 in Jagatsinghpur . Meanwhile, Kendrapara has\nregistered 20, Ganjam 13, Keonjhar 10, Dhenkanal 11, Bolangir 6, and\nMayurbhanj 5 cases of dengue. While Nayagarh, Sonepur, Kalahandi,\nAngul, and Bargarh registered 3 cases each, Nuapada and Kandhamal\nwitnessed 2 cases. Boudh, Rayagada, Sundargarh and Deogarh districts\nrecorded with single case each. However, 12 patients have come to the\nstate from neighbouring states.\n(http://pragativadi.com/dengue-claims-two-lives-affects-402-odisha/) - Gujarat (Ahmedabad). 1 Aug 2017. A total of 59 cases in July 2017.\nThe actual number of cases is said to be 'far more'; it takes at least\n15 days to confirm cases.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/59-dengue-cases-in-july-amc/articleshow/59853414.cms) - Jharkhand (Jamshedpur). 30 Jul 2017. 75 positive cases in Kolhan and\nadjoining area of Jamshedpur.\n(http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/dengue-cases-rise-positive-cases-shoot-75-kolhan/111026/) - Telangana (Hyderabad). 25 Jul 2017. All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. As per a weekly report issued by Prevention and Control\nProgram for Dengue in Sindh, as many as 27 new dengue fever cases\nsurfaced in the city from 1 to 7 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/08/363624/a27-more-dengue-cases-surface-in-karachi/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 8 Aug 2017. 3rd death due to dengue\nhemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. Most of the affected patients were\nbrought from the Tehkal Payan area from where water samples have been\ncollected to determine the situation.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1476245/third-dengue-death-\nreported-k-p/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 16 Aug 2017. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. Dengue continues in\nPeshawar, claiming 7 lives with 69 new cases reported from different\nareas of the city during the last 24 hours, raising the number of\ntotal cases to 1703. So far, he said, 7 deaths including 6 from Khyber\nTeaching Hospital and one in Hayatabad Medical Complex were reported\nfrom dengue epidemics in Peshawar. Out of 69 new cases, 41 were\nreported in Khyber Teaching Hospital (KTH), 13 in Hayatabad Medical\nComplex (HMC), 12 in Lady Reading Hospital (LRH), and 3 in Naseerullah\nKhan Babar Teaching Hospital (NBTH), Peshawar, he said. A rapid\nresponse team has also been set up with mandate to swiftly reach to\nthe affected areas from where new cases were surfaced besides helping\nthe field staff in conduct of fumigation spray, removal of larvae, and\nprovision of other necessary medicines.\n(https://dnd.com.pk/dengue-rampage-in-peshawar-kills-seven-69-new-cases-surface/133250) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://pakistanmap.facts.co/pakistanmapof/PakistanAdministrativeMap.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ China\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp). 16 Aug 2017.\nGuangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in south China has reported its 1st\nimported dengue case this year 2017, local inspection and quarantine\nbureau said. The man had stayed in Hanoi, Viet Nam, for 2 months but\ndenied having been bitten by mosquitoes or having any infectious\ndisease.\n(http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/16/c_136531179.htm) - Hong Kong SAR Special Administrative Region. 9 Aug 2017. 1st\nlocally transmitted case of dengue in Hong Kong, this year 2017.\n(https://today.mims.com/topic/chp-investigates-first-local-dengue-fever-case-of-the-year) - Macau SAR. 1 Aug 2017. 1st locally acquired case this year 2017\nconfirmed. 53 imported cases in 2017, including 18 from Thailand, 10\nfrom Sri Lanka, and 7 from the Philippines.\n(https://macaunews.mo/first-local-dengue-case-year-confirmed/) - Macau SAR. 24 Aug 2017. The 3 cases were all members of the same family,\nhusband, wife and son, who lived together in the southern Taiwanese\nport city, according to the department. From 1 Jan to 22 Jul 2017, 14 919 cases and 81\ndeaths of dengue recorded. Most of the deaths were from Ayeyarwady\nregion, followed by Yangon and Bago regions. Over the past 2\nmonths, around 90 patients were taken to HCM Paediatrics Hospital No 1\nper week on average.\n(http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/182701/rising-dengue-fever-cases-leave-17-dead.html) - National. 19 Aug 2017. The number of dengue fever cases in Viet Nam\nspiked by some 10 000 cases in the past week. Tran Đac Phu, head of\nthe ministry's preventive medicine department, said the country had\nrecorded 90 626 dengue cases since the beginning of 2017, a\nyear-on-year rise of 67.8 per cent, including 24 fatalities, local\nmedia reports. This is up by about 10 000 since the last total case\ncount was released on 3 Aug 207. The outbreak is stretching the\ncountry's medical system as more than 78 000 of the cases required\nhospitalization. In the capital city of Hanoi, there have been 17 027\nrecorded dengue cases, 7 of whom died since the beginning of the year\n2017.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - Mekong Delta. 24 Jul 2017. Cases increased by 125 per cent in 1st 15\ndays of July 2017 compared with same period 2016. An Giang province\nalone recorded the highest number of 120 hospitalised cases in the 1st\n10 days of July 2017, followed by Soc Trang province with 110 cases\nand Dong Thap province, 100 cases. Since the beginning of 2017,\ndengue-related deaths have been reported in Dong Thap, Tien Giang, and\nTra Vinh provinces. Dengue fever has increased sharply this year among\nchildren aged between 10-15 in the Mekong Delta, especially in Can Tho\ncity.\n(http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/182533/dengue-fever-on-the-rise-in-mekong-delta.html) - Hanoi. 5 Aug 2017. Nearly 9000 cases of dengue fever have now been\nreported in Hanoi since the beginning of the year 2017, with 2300\nreported from 24 to 30 Jul 2017 alone, state media said. From the\nbeginning of this year 2017 through July, there was a 23 per cent\nincrease in cases in the city over the number reported during the same\nperiod last year 2016, while 46 per cent more cases were reported in\nJuly than in June, the city's health department said. According to\nWHO, as of 18 Jun 2017, there were 45 074 cases of dengue reported in\nViet Nam including 13 deaths. Compared to the same period in 2016 (40\n511 cases including 12 deaths), the cumulative number of cases\nincreased by 11.3 per cent.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/vietnam-dengue-news-emergency-declared-ha-nam-hanoi-outbreak-32326/) - Hanoi. 11 Aug 2017. Nearly 5000 new cases in Hanoi, with more than\n13 200 infected and with 6 deaths since early 2017.\n(http://www.elevenmyanmar.com/world-news/11037) - Ha Nam. 5 Aug 2017. More than 10 cases a day being reported largest\noutbreak in history of Province. The Ha Nam Province People's\nCommittee declared a state of emergency on 3 Aug 2017, to deal with a\ngrowing outbreak of dengue fever, spread by infected mosquitoes, with\n100 cases confirmed year-to-date, according to local media.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/vietnam-dengue-news-emergency-declared-ha-nam-hanoi-outbreak-32326/) Maps of Viet Nam can be seen at\n(http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Philippines\n- National. 11 Aug 2017. The Department of Health (DoH) reported a\nconsiderable decrease of dengue fever cases in the 1st half of 2017 in\nwhich only 43 770 nationwide have been tallied from 1 Jan to 1 Jul\n2017. This is 36.8 per cent lower than the 69 297 recorded in the\nsame period in 2016. Among the 43 770 cases, 250 deaths were reported,\nwhich is 84 fewer than the 334 recorded in the same period in 2016.\nThe report showed that all regions, except in Metro Manila, showed\ndecreasing trends in dengue cases as compared to 2016. Majority of the\ndengue cases were recorded in Central Visayas (6281), Metro Manila\n(5567), Central Luzon (5147), Calabarzon (5007), and Soccsksargen\n(4861). Provinces with the most number of cases are Cebu with 11 per\ncent, followed by South Cotabato with 6.3 per cent, and Pampanga with\n4.6 per cent. Metro Manila is the lone region with an upward trend of\ncases, recording a 24.9 per cent increase from 4457 in 2016.\n(http://www.manilatimes.net/dengue-cases-drop-first-half-2017-report/343788/) - Cebu. 11 Aug 2017. Talisay City, Cebu Province Central Visayas,\nPhilippines 296 cases and 9 deaths; Consolacion 260 cases and 4\ndeaths; Argao 187 cases and 1 death.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/local-news/2017/08/10/talisay-tops-number-dengue-cases-557829) - Negros Occidental. 2 Aug 2017. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed strain homology with the Burkina Faso 2016 strain. This case\nmay serve as an alert to possible disease spread outside Africa.\n(https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/17-1132_article) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pacific\n\n- Samoa. 22 Jul 2017. On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. Sir Gangaram Hospital reported the rare case,\nwhere the woman, who went to the eye OPD outpatient department,\ncomplained of \"sudden blurring of vision in the left eye,\" as reported\nby IE Indian Express. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017. There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]},"138":{"title":"Japanese encephalitis - Philippines (02): (LG) ","date":["29","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Japanese encephalitis - Philippines (02): (LG) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 29 Aug 2017 5:19 PM PHT. Source: Inquirer (edited) (http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/926510/japanese-encephalities-deaths-calabarzon-laguna)   The provincial health office in Laguna said 2 children succumbed to Japanese encephalitis, the 1st confirmed cases of the mosquito-borne disease in the Southern Tagalog province this year 2017.  On Tue 29 Aug 2017, Dr Rene Bagamasbad, Laguna health officer, said the victims were a 9-year-old boy in Calauan town and a 6-year-old boy in San Pablo City. He said the children died around 2 weeks ago.  Calauan and San Pablo City, being adjacent to each other, were also placed under investigation by the health office.  Only the Calauan case has so far reached the Calabarzon office of the Department of Health, according to Dr Rio Magpantay, DOH regional director.  The regional office, however, had also started monitoring \"signs and symptoms\" of possible Japanese encephalitis incidence in other parts of Laguna.  Calabarzon stands for the provinces of Cavite, Laguna, Batangas, Rizal, and Quezon.  The disease, which is transmitted by the _Culex_ mosquito, commonly causes abdominal pains, fever, and seizures. It may also cause a part of the brain to swell.  Vaccines are available. But there is no cure yet for the disease. Vaccines are currently not part of the government's immunization program.  Magpantay said there was no declaration of an outbreak. But the DOH regional office would strengthen the surveillance of communities and hospitals.  It usually takes some time to confirm a case of Japanese encephalitis because specimens, such as the patient's blood sample, would have to be collected and submitted for testing at the Research Institute for Tropical Medicine in Muntinlupa in Metro Manila.  Byline: Maricar Cinco   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  There have been relatively few reports of human Japanese encephalitis (JE) cases in the Philippines in recent years, although the islands are within the JE virus endemic zone. The report above is of 2 cases. Also on Luzon Island this year (2017), the Department of Health (DOH) has recorded a total of 149 cases of JE with at least 22 cases in noted Pampanga, the highest in the Central Luzon region (see Japanese encephalitis - Philippines: (PM) http://promedmail.org/post/20170818.5257940).  A report from the World Health Organization (WHO) said that JE is an illness that is endemic in the Philippines and is fatal in almost 3 out of 10 serious cases. The report also said that nearly all survivors of this mosquito-borne disease experience permanent damage, including physical disabilities, cognitive and language problems, learning disabilities and behavioral problems.  Maps of the Philippines can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/z4y3p5v) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/51664). - Mod.TY  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"157":{"title":"Leptospirosis - Philippines (02): increased cases\r\n\t","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Leptospirosis - Philippines (02): increased cases\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017, 4:36 PM. Source: Manila Bulletin (edited) (http://news.mb.com.ph/2017/08/31/leptospirosis-cases-deaths-increase-doh/)   The number of leptospirosis cases and deaths in the Philippines has increased, the Department of Health (DOH) disclosed Thu 31 Aug 2017. According to the latest disease surveillance report of the DOH, 910 leptospirosis cases were recorded from 1 Jan to 5 Aug 2017. \"This is 71.1 percent higher compared to what was recorded in the same period as last year 2016, which was 532,\" said the DOH report.  Leptospirosis is an infectious disease caused by the _Leptospira interrogans_ bacteria. The leptospira bacteria are transmitted through wounds when in contact with floodwaters, vegetation, and moist soil contaminated with the urine of infected animals, especially rats. Leptospirosis is characterized by fever, muscle pain, reddish-yellowish body discoloration, dark-colored urine, light stools, low urine output, and severe headache.  There was also a higher number of deaths; with 96 or a 10.55 percent case fatality rate. In the same period last year 2016, there were only 50 deaths or 9.40 percent case fatality rate.  The majority of the leptospirosis cases were recorded in the National Capital Region with 172 cases; Davao Region with 112 cases; Western Visayas with 98; Central Luzon with 80; and Eastern Visayas with 72. Regions with the highest increase in cases were Eastern Visayas with 620 percent increase; Davao Region with 558 percent increase; Central Visayas with 390 percent increase; Caraga with 240 percent increase; and Cagayan Valley with 103 percent increase.  \nByline: Charina Clarisse Echaluce   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Currently, the Philippines is divided into 17 regions (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regions_of_the_Philippines). A map showing the regions of the Philippines can be found at: (https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f6/Labelled_map_of_the_Philippines_-_Provinces_and_Regions.png).  Leptospirosis is an infection transmitted to humans by exposure to soil or fresh water contaminated with the urine of wild and domestic animals (including dogs, cattle, swine, and especially rodents) that are chronically infected with pathogenic _Leptospira_. The spirochete _Leptospira_ may survive in contaminated fresh water or moist soil for weeks to months. Outbreaks of leptospirosis frequently follow heavy rainfall, flooding with fresh water, and increasing rodent numbers.  For a discussion of leptospirosis in Philippines, see my moderator comments in ProMED-mail post Leptospirosis - Philippines (02): (Manila,ZN) http://promedmail.org/post/20110716.2154.  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/r/1z-3). - Mod.ML  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Poland":{"38":{"title":"African swine fever - Europe (18): Czech Republic (ZK)\r\n\twild boar, spread, control ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> African swine fever - Europe (18): Czech Republic (ZK)\r\n\twild boar, spread, control [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nAFRICAN SWINE FEVER - EUROPE (18): CZECH REPUBLIC (ZLIN) WILD BOAR,\nSPREAD, CONTROL\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Web-site of the Czech State Veterinary Administration Czech,\nMach transl, edited\n(https://www.svscr.cz/africky-mor-prasat-aktualni-informace/) \nAs of the above date, 159 dead feral pigs have been recorded by the\nState Veterinary Administration in the Zlín Region. African swine\nfever ASF has been confirmed in 90 of them; in 69 cases, the test\nwas negative. The number of feral pigs caught in the part of the infected area where\nthey may be hunted (green zone) for map, see commentary increased to\n96; all tested ASF negative. In the area with intensive catches, 1917 wild boars have been shot.\nMost of them, in the districts of Kroměříž (454), Uherské\nHradiště (401) and Vsetín (263). In all cases, the result of the\nASF examination was negative. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n(http://www.cvlonghorns.de)\n(cvlonghorns@aol.com) Maps presenting the various zones as implemented in the Czech\nRepublic in relation to ASF, including the ones with prescribed\ncatching intensities of feral pigs, and the numbers/locations of the\nshot/collected animals, are available at\n(https://www.svscr.cz/amp-mapy/). The titles of the (8) maps can be\ngoogle-translated; please note that AMP (in Czech) stands for ASF. The Czech Republic has submitted to the OIE its most recent follow-up\nreport on ASF (No 8) on Thu 17 Aug 2017, reporting 3 new outbreaks\nin feral pigs. The said report, as well as new follow-up ASF reports\nfrom Ukraine, Russia and Poland, submitted to the OIE on 17-18 Aug\n2017, can be accessed at\n(http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/WI/index/newlang/en). A global, interactive OIE map presenting all ASF outbreaks since the\nstart of 2017, updated Fri 18 Aug 2017, is available at\n(http://tinyurl.com/y8hgscdh) (click on the central-European cluster,\nzoom in). The Czech event is currently the most western one, causing\nconcerns of further spread in Western Europe. It is separated by (so\nfar, uninfected) Slovakia from the closest outbreak on its east,\nsouth-western Ukraine. Poland, where ASF has been circulating on the eastern regions since\nFeb 2014, is now confronting the virus also on its south-west, namely\nthe Czech event. Krzysztof Jurgiel, Minister of Agriculture and Rural\nDevelopmentthe, has responded this week week of Sun 13 Aug 2017 to\nstatements by politicians who related to ASF as a zoonotic disease\nrisking human health. The Minister denied any publich health risk in\nrelation to ASF, quoting a detailed letter from Prof. Krzysztof\nNiemczuk, the Director of Poland's State Scientific Institute of\nVeterinary Medicine. See, in Polish, at\n(http://www.minrol.gov.pl/pol/Ministerstwo/Biuro-Prasowe/Informacje-Prasowe/Nieodpowiedzialne-wypowiedzi-nt.-ASF).\n(thanks to Sabine Zentis for the link). According to OIE's Manual of Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines for\nTerrestrial Animals, \"ASF is not a zoonotic disease and does not\naffect public health (Sánchez-Vizcaíno et al., 2009)\". - Mod.AS A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62211). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"56":{"title":"African swine fever - Europe (20): update,\r\n\tinternational impact ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> African swine fever - Europe (20): update,\r\n\tinternational impact [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017. Source: The Pirbright Institute, UK, News (edited) (https://www.pirbright.ac.uk/news/2017/08/african-swine-fever-advance-through-europe)   The continued advance of African swine fever (ASF) through eastern European countries has triggered concern amongst pig farmers and governing bodies. DEFRA UK Department for Environment, Food, and Rural Affairs has upgraded the threat to the UK from 'very low' to 'low'  meaning the risk is \"rare but could occur\" (EFSA European Food Safety Authority terminology). This severe disease of pigs entered Europe through Georgia in 2007, and has since continued to the Russian Federation and eastern Europe, including EU countries in the Baltic States, Poland and very recently the Czech Republic, in wild boar. In early August 2017, an outbreak was confirmed for the 1st time in Romania among backyard pigs.  African swine fever is caused by infection with ASF virus (ASFV), which can have fatality rates of up to 100 per cent. The virus causes acute disease in domestic pigs and wild boar, and may cause varying clinical signs that are similar to other pig diseases such as high fever, lethargy and loss of appetite. Pigs may also die suddenly without clinical signs.  Although the virus does not cause disease in humans, the impact it has on the economy, especially through trade and farming, is substantial. As a consequence of ASF in Poland and the Baltic States the value of pork and pig exports was reduced by USD 960 million (2014-2015). In Denmark, the predicted impact of an ASF outbreak is estimated at USD 12 million in direct losses and USD 349 million in exports.  Unless the appropriate control measures are put in place, additional outbreaks could occur across Europe, further into Russia and beyond to Asia. An outbreak in the UK is unlikely as imports of meat and pigs are extremely well regulated and the UK does not have a wild boar population substantial enough or widespread enough to maintain an outbreak. However, personal imports of pork products from affected areas could result in disease incursion if deliberately or accidently fed to pigs or wild boar, actions which are illegal.  The seriousness of an outbreak for some countries could be far worse than others; China is home to over half the world's pig population and an outbreak of ASF could result in devastating consequences. In a Veterinary Record article see reference below world-expert on ASF Dr Linda Dixon leader of the ASF group at The Pirbright Institute, outlines the factors that increase the likelihood of ASF spreading to China and highlights areas that could be improved to reduce the risk of an outbreak including biosecurity.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Subscribers may refer to more data in the article above, addressing the following questions: - how does ASF spread? - how quickly does it spread? - how can the spread of ASFV be prevented? - what is The Pirbright Institute doing to help?  The last item includes the following statement: \"The vaccine research is crucial for the prevention and control of ASF, and good progress has so far been made. An effective vaccine will enable better control and prevention measures to be put in place in the future, helping stem the losses currently being suffered by farmers around the world.\"  The editorial \"Preparing for the worst: African swine fever in China\", by Linda K Dixon, was recently published in the Veterinary Record  Vet Rec. 2017; 181: 115-6, doi: 10.1136/vr.j3525. (http://veterinaryrecord.bmj.com/content/vetrec/181/5/115.full.pdf).  The European Commission's working document SANTE-2017-10272 (36 pages) of 31 Jan 2017, titled \"Blueprint and roadmap on the possible development of a vaccine for African swine fever prepared by the African Swine Fever EU reference laboratory on Commission request\" is available at (https://ec.europa.eu/food/sites/food/files/safety/docs/cff_animal_vet-progs_asf_blue-print-road-map.pdf). - Mod.AS  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6010).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"170":{"title":"Listeriosis - Denmark, Poland: smoked salmon,\r\n\trecall ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Listeriosis - Denmark, Poland: smoked salmon,\r\n\trecall [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nLISTERIOSIS - DENMARK, POLAND: SMOKED SALMON, RECALL\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017.\nSource: HealthMap (edited)\n(http://healthmap.org/ln.php?5286790&u8901) \nDansk Supermarket Group issued a recall after Fødevarestyrelsen\n(Danish Veterinary and Food Administration) detected _Listeria\nmonocytogenes_ in 2 packs of cold-smoked salmon. Byline: Joe Withworth \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) The original article, available at the source URL\n((http://www.foodqualitynews.com/Food-Outbreaks/Listeria-outbreak-from-salmon-in-Denmark)),\nis copyrighted and cannot be reproduced. However, it is summarized\nbelow: The Dansk Supermarket Group (DSG) recalled cold-packed smoked salmon,\nmanufactured in Poland, after _Listeria monocytogenes_ was identified\nin the product. The isolate from the product was almost identical by\nwhole genome sequencing to isolates from 3 of 4 patients, whose food\nhistory in 3 of the patients identified the smoked salmon as the\nlikely source. The smoked salmon product was recalled from about 600 stores in\nDenmark and a limited number in Metro Poland. Up to 3 of the 4 patients had become ill in the same week in August\n2017 and the 4th had become ill in May 2017. One of the 4 patients has\ndied. All 4 patients had severe underlying disease. DSG consists of chains (fotex, Bilka, Netto, and Salling) with more\nthan 1400 stores in Denmark, Germany, Poland and Sweden. Refrigerated smoked salmon is a recognized potential source for\nlisteriosis, similar to other cold cut meats and non-heat treated\ncured smoked meats, being a ready-to-eat product that does not require\nfurther cooking before eating. The news report said that more cases\nrelated to this outbreak were expected, despite the recall, as the\nincubation period for listeriosis is up to 3 weeks actually symptoms\ncan start up to as 70 days after exposure. - Mod.ML A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/113). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"175":{"title":"African swine fever - Europe (21): Czech Rep, Romania,\r\n\tPoland, wild boar, spread ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> African swine fever - Europe (21): Czech Rep, Romania,\r\n\tPoland, wild boar, spread [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nAFRICAN SWINE FEVER - EUROPE (21): CZECH REPUBLIC, ROMANIA, POLAND,\nWILD BOAR, SPREAD\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this posting:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Czech Rep, Romania\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Poland, fence considered \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Czech Rep, Romania.\nDate: Wed 30 Aug 2017.\nSource: Pig Progress net (edited)\n(http://www.pigprogress.net/Health/Articles/2017/8/ASF-update-Czech-Republic-approaches-100-reports-177268E/) \nAlthough the outbreaks seem to be contained to one region of the Czech\nRepublic, African Swine Fever ASF continues to make victims among\nthe country's wild boar population. The total amount of dead wild boars discovered in the woods around\nZlín, in the far east of the Czech Republic, stood at 94 at the end\nof August 2017. In this month, 23 new infected carcasses were found,\nwhich is a downward trend from July 2017, when 68 reports were sent\nto the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE). The 1st report of\nASF in Czech wild boars was on Wed 21 Jun 2017. Many neighbouring countries have alerted their local pig producers to\nbe very careful what to feed their pigs - and their inhabitants what\nto purchase and how to dispose of it. So did Slovakia, according to\nthe Slovak Spectator. Zlín is only a few km away from the western\nSlovak border, to its north is Poland where ASF has been around since\n2014 and on its eastern border is Ukraine, where ASF has been\nconfirmed since 2011. In a presentation, given in mid-July 2017 to the European\nCommission's Standing Committee On Animals, Plants, Food and Feed\n(SCoPAFF), Dr Petr Šatrán of the Czech State Veterinary\nAdministration indicated that human activities are most likely the\ncause of the spread of the virus, seeing that the nearest reported\ncases of ASF were roughly 500 km 310.68 mi away and that the\npositive dead wild boars were found in inhabited areas. In the other country where ASF was found for the 1st time in 2017,\nRomania, things appear relatively quiet. News broke early this month\nAugust 2017 that ASF was also found on 2 backyard farms in the north\nof the country. Ever since, the Romanian authorities did not report\nany further outbreaks of ASF to the OIE. Of all other countries in the European Union, especially Poland has\ncontinued to report outbreaks of African Swine Fever in smaller and\nmiddle-sized operations. In August alone, on 23 farm sites of various\nsizes, ASF was found to have infected at least one animal, after which\nthe entire herd would have to be culled. The biggest operation in this respect was a farm near Monki, Podlaskie\nprovince, where all remaining 431 pigs had to be culled after 11 had\ndied as a result of ASF, on Sat 19 Aug 2017. Noteworthy as well was\nthe ASF-related closure of 2 farms in Lack, Lubelskie province, in\nearly August. These farms had 136 and 141 pigs respectively see also\nitem 2. Byline: Vincent ter Beek \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n(http://www.cvlonghorns.de)\n(cvlonghorns@aol.com) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Poland, fence considered.\nDate: Sat 2 Sep 2017.\nSource: Current News summ., edited\n(http://currentlynews.us/articles/poland-will-18857) \nPoland wants to build along the border with Belarus and Ukraine a\nfence preventing migration of wild boars  carriers of the African\nSwine fever ASF. This was said by Poland's Minister of Agriculture,\nKrzysztof Yurgel, Niezalezna reports. As reported, the length of the fence will be 729 km 452.98 mi,\ncosting Poland 130 million zloties (more than 36.2 million USD). The\nfinal decision on a fence will be made within the next 3 weeks. According to experts, ASF has developed in the territory of Poland\n\"thanks to\" the wild boars who entered from Belarus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The accumulated ASF OIE data from Poland as of Thu 31 Aug 2017, are\nas follows (start of event 22 May 2014):\nNumber of follow-up reports: 189\nTotal outbreaks: 550 (Submitted)\nSpecies/ Susceptible/ Cases/ Deaths/ Killed and disposed of/\nSlaughtered\nWild boar/ - / 620 / 620 / 0 / 0\nDomestic Swine/ 6303/ 402/ 188/ 6097/ 0 A map showing ASF cases reported globally to the OIE since 1 Jan 2017,\nas of Thu 31 Aug 2017, is available at (http://tinyurl.com/ybexasqm).\nClick on the European cluster, zoom in to each of the countries of\ninterest. EU disease control measures require designation of risk areas as Part\nI (wild boar at risk, but no cases found), Part II (wild boar testing\npositive but no spill over into domestic pigs), Part III (cases in\nwild boar and occasional spill over into domestic pigs) and Part IV\nwhich concerns the island of Sardinia only. Consignments of live pigs,\nlive wild boars, meat of either source and animal by-products of\neither source are only allowed under certain derogations. For a full\nexplanation, see European Commission Implementing Decision\n2014/708/EU. ASF, a viral disease against which no vaccine has become available so\nfar, is currently threatening central and western Europe, where dense\npopulations of wild boar are present. According to a recent update of DEFRA (UK) ASF situation assessment,\nthe continuing cases in the Czech Republic, the spread in Poland which\nappears to be due to several breakdowns in biosecurity and the new\noutbreaks in Romania are \"concerning\". This signifies a spread in\ngeographic distribution, a possible drop in biosecurity awareness and\ntherefore an increase in the weight of infection in East Europe. Despite the relatively low level of trade in live pigs, there could be\na substantial movement of people, vehicles and personal imports of\npork products, therefore the risk of ASF introduction to the UK has\nbeen raised from \"very low\" (that is, \"rare but could occur\") to\n\"low\". The Russian veterinary watchdog Rosselkhoznadzor believes ASF will\nkeep moving west via 2 main pathways. The southerly route, has already\nseen the virus spread from Ukraine to Moldova. Russian vets believe it\ncould penetrate central Romania, then move to the Balkans, including\nBulgaria and Serbia. On the northern route, now that ASF has been found in the Czech\nRepublic, Rosselkhoznadzor believes, if it gains a foothold, it is\nlikely to head further west, with Germany next in the firing line. The\nsaid is included in a recent update by the Russian journalist\nVladislav Vorotnikov, available at\n(http://www.pig-world.co.uk/comment/where-next-for-african-swine-fever.html).\n- Mod.AS ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Portugal":{},"Puerto Rico":{"45":{"title":"Zika virus (16): Americas, Asia, research,\r\n\tobservations ","date":["17","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Zika virus (16): Americas, Asia, research,\r\n\tobservations [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nZIKA VIRUS (16): AMERICAS, ASIA, RESEARCH, OBSERVATIONS\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries:\nWHO tool kit for the care and support of people affected by\ncomplications associated with Zika virus \nAmericas\n\nAmericas cumulative case numbers\nCaribbean and South America Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. A 12 Aug 2017 report quotes USA health\nofficials indicating that the Zika outbreaks in the Caribbean and\nSouth America are waning and that has helped slow the spread of the\nmosquito-borne virus to Florida and other localities in the USA this\nyear (2017).\n(http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/experts-herd-immunity-us-slows-zika-florida-49179180) Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in\nthe Americas mentioned above and below can be accessed at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574);\nNorth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106);\nCentral America (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455);\nCaribbean (http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/); and\nSouth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186). - Mod.TY Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. South America\n\nArgentina (Salta province). 13 Aug 2017. November 2016-May 2017, 1st\nlocally acquired outbreak (conf.) 203 cases of which 7 pregnant.\nDepartment most affected: San Martín (Tartagal, General Mosconi,\nAguaray, and Embarcación), and Morillo.\n(http://www.eltribuno.info/salta/nota/2017-8-13-0-0-0-hubo-203-casos-de-zika-en-el-primer-brote-autoctono)\n Brazil\n- Origin and spread. 15 Jun 2017. (reported) Analyses of viral genomes\nwith ecological and epidemiological data yield an estimate that ZIKV\nwas present in northeast Brazil by February 2014 and is likely to have\ndisseminated from there, nationally and internationally, before the\n1st detection of ZIKV in the Americas. Estimated dates for the\ninternational spread of ZIKV from Brazil indicate the duration of\npre-detection cryptic transmission in recipient regions. The role of\nnortheast Brazil in the establishment of ZIKV in the Americas is\nfurther supported by geographic analysis of ZIKV transmission.\n(http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v546/n7658/full/nature22402.html) - Eye lesions. 17 Jul 2017 (reported) of 112 infants born to Zika\nvirus infected mothers in Brazil, 24 (21 percent) had eye\nabnormalities; 10 infants (42 percent) with abnormal eye examination\nfindings did not have microcephaly, 8 (33 percent) did not have any\ncentral nervous system findings, and 2 (8 percent) had eye\nabnormalities despite maternal 3rd trimester infection. Eye\nabnormalities may be the only initial finding in congenital Zika virus\ninfection, and all infants with potential Zika virus exposure should\nundergo screening eye examinations.\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/article-abstract/2636587) Peru\n- National. 22 Jul 2017. 2016-22 Jul 2017 (susp.) 6432 cases, (conf.)\n1438 cases with 264 pregnant with 17 cases of suspected Zika\nvirus-related microcephaly. For 2017 up to 23 Jul 2017 (susp.) 5552\ncases, (conf.) 649 cases with 172 pregnant, 5 cases of suspected Zika\nvirus-related microcephaly. Epidemic peak on week 15 week ending 14\nApr 2017, then sharp decline.\n(http://www.dge.gob.pe/portal/docs/vigilancia/boletines/2017/29.pdf)\n - Piura region. 29 Jul 2017. (susp.) 94 cases, (conf.) 13 cases of\nwhom 5 pregnant.\n(http://diariocorreo.pe/edicion/piura/casos-de-dengue-y-zika-aumentan-ligeramente-semana-a-semana-764780/)\n Asia\n\nThailand (Phichit province). 4 Jul 2017. (susp.) 27 cases, (conf.) 11\ncases.\n(http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/1280835/11-zika-cases-confirmed-in-phichit-27-under-watch) Maps of Thailand can be accessed at\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_Thailand) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1371). - Mod.TY Taiwan. 31 Jul 2017. (conf.) 1 imported case ex Viet Nam.\n(http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/taiwan/archives/2017/07/31/2003675659) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Taiwan can be accessed at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/193). - Mod.TY  Viet Nam (Dak Lak province). August 2017. (reported) in June, 2016, a\ngirl was born with microcephaly in Dak Lak Province, in the Central\nHighlands region of Viet Nam, at 37 weeks of gestation. The infant's\nmother (aged 23 years) had experienced symptoms of fever and rash\nassociated with Zika virus infection during her 2nd trimester. The\nsymptoms resolved uneventfully.\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30412-7/fulltext) Maps of Viet Nam can be seen at\n(http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png) and\n(ttp://healthmap.org/promed/p/62774). - Mod.TY Singapore (Serangoon). 14 Aug 2014. (conf.) 2 new cases of locally\ntransmitted Zika virus infection in Serangoon, the 3rd cluster in the\narea in less than 1 month.\n(http://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/2-new-cases-of-locally-transmitted-zika-virus-in-serangoon-nea) A 26 Jul 2017 previous report confirmed a cluster of 3 locally\nacquired cases at Serangoon North Avenue 1.\n(http://www.nea.gov.sg/corporate-functions/newsroom/news-releases/three-case-zika-cluster-reported-at-serangoon-north-avenue-1) Maps of Singapore can be accessed at\n(http://www.studies-overseas.com/WebForms/Singapore%20Map%20Places.png)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/33319). - Mod.TY India\n- National. 25 Jul 2017. (susp.) 1 case, (conf.) 3 cases, one of whom\nis pregnant.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/health/four-zika-cases-reported-in-india-so-far-govt/article19358623.ece) Maps of India can be accessed at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Mod.TY - Tamil Nadu state. 11 Jul 2017. (reported) 1st case reported in state\nin a 27-year-old man in the Krishnagiri district.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/tamil-nadu-reports-first-case-of-zika-virus/article19254690.ece) Imported cases with little or no possibility of ongoing mosquito\ntransmission\n\nCanada. 26 Jul 2017.
