Africa\n\n- Côte d'Ivoire\n- Côte d'Ivoire <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence\n- Air travel related spread of dengue\n- Visual impact <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> World Health Organization update \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries\nAsia\n\nSri Lanka\n- National. 26 Jul 2017. Sri Lanka has now notified 107 015 cases,\nwhich WHO estimates is 4.3 times more than the average number of cases\nusually reported (http://tinyurl.com/ycvszzs8). - National. 19 Aug 2017. Since the beginning of 2017, Sri Lanka has\nreported 137 279 suspected dengue cases and more than 300 deaths.\nAbout 44.5 per cent of dengue cases were reported from the Western\nprovince. This compares with about 39 000 cases reported from January\nto August 2016, and 55 150 cases during the entire year 2016.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - National. 25 Aug 2017. Through Fri 25 Aug 2017, Sri Lanka has\nofficially reported 144 052 cases and, as of 3 Aug 2017, 3327 people\nhave died.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-epidemic-waning-sri-lanka-university-jaffna-science-faculty-closed-september-83024/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Sri Lanka can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/144). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ India\n- National. 31 Jul 2017. 11 832 more cases than in 2016 and 46 deaths,\n11 more than in 2016. The total has risen to 28 702, with 2536 cases\nand 10 deaths last week week of 24 Jul 2017. Kerala reported the\nmaximum dengue cases with 13 913 cases, followed by Tamil Nadu with\n5474 cases, Karnataka with 4186 cases, Andhra Pradesh with 798 cases,\nWest Bengal with 571 cases, and Maharashtra with 460 cases.\n(http://www.india.com/news/agencies/dengue-cases-in-india-up-by-11832-over-last-year-2366955/) - Bihar, Uttar Pradesh, Assam. 21 Aug 2017. Floods continued to wreak\nhavoc in the 3 states, which reported 88 more dengue-related deaths.\nOfficials said 33 more dengue-related deaths had been reported in\nUttar Pradesh over the last 2 days.\n(http://www.christianmessenger.in/floods-in-bihar-up-assam-88-die-in-dengue-related-deaths/) - Delhi. 31 Jul 2017. As of 29 Jul 2017, 180 cases of dengue (monsoon\narrived early).\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/882984/dengue-malaria-chikungunya-cases-on-the-rise-in-delhi/) - Tamil Nadu (Coimbatore). 4 Aug 2017. Deaths rise to 16 in last 2\nmonths; new admissions increasing.\n(http://www.business-standard.com/article/pti-stories/2-more-dengue-deaths-in-coimbatore-total-deaths-now-16-117080401128_1.html) - Tamil Nadu. 11 Aug 2017. Prevalence of dengue in Tamil Nadu is\ndecreasing. So far, 5000 people have been affected and due to proper\ntreatment by doctors in government and private hospitals, almost all\ndengue patients have been saved, health minister C Vijaya Baskar said\ntoday 11 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.dnaindia.com/\nhealth/report-prevalence-of-dengue-in-tn-down-health-minister-2526936) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 18 Aug 2017. At least 1500 new cases in 10\ndays. Neighbouring state, Kerala, which has recorded the highest\nnumber of dengue cases with around 15 612 cases and 25 deaths, is\nanother reason for several districts of Tamil Nadu such as Coimbatore,\nMadurai, Theni, Toothukudi, and Virudhunagar facing its brunt.\n(http://www.deccanchronicle.com/nation/current-affairs/180817/more-rains-more-cases-of-dengue.html) - Tamil Nadu (Chennai). 4 Aug 2017. 5 new positive cases every day\nnow; around 100 cases of 'suspicious fever' reported. 629 cases in\nJuly 2017 alone, according to National Vector Borne Diseases Control\nProgramme.\n(http://www.deccanchronicle.com/lifestyle/health-and-wellbeing/040817/dengue-breeds-in-north-chennai.html) - Kerala. 31 Jul 2017. Over 6000 patients have been confirmed and\ntreated as in-patients; mortality has been kept to 1 per cent.\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/thiruvananthapuram/882347/mch-keeps-dengue-mortality-rate-to-1/#) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 4 Aug 2017. 235 cases in Gulbarga district\nfrom January to July 2017. Of the 235, 171 cases were reported from\nKalaburagi taluk sub district alone, 32 from Chincholli taluk, 13\nfrom Chittapur taluk, 4 cases each from Afzalpur, Aland, and Sedam\ntaluks, and 3 cases from Jewargi taluk.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/235-dengue-cases-in-kalaburagi-dist/article19423638.ece) - Karnataka (Gulbarga). 23 Aug 2017. A total of 474 confirmed cases in\nGulbarga district, with 1927 suspected cases; 368 cases confirmed in\nKalaburagi sub district. Only 43 cases were reported in the district\ntill the end of June 2017 and 191 cases were reported between 1 and\n10 Aug 2017, while 240 new cases have been registered, taking the\ntotal to 474.\n(http://www.uniindia.com/dengue-474-confirmed-cases-reported-in-kalaburagi-district/health-and-medicine/fullstory/968353.html) - Karnataka. 18 Aug 2017. Nearly 8000 cases in Karnataka so far in\n2017. Kerala has reported 16 000 cases and Tamil Nadu 9500 cases.\nDengue spreads easily between the 3 adjacent states.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/karnataka/central-team-to-review-dengue-outbreak-in-state/article19512224.ece) - West Bengal (Kolkata). 12 Aug 2017. Dengue scare at RG Kar Hospital\nMedical College hostel; at least 8 test positive over the last week.\nIn 2015, more than 30 were affected in the hostel campus and one died.\nOn 2016 too, more than a dozen inmates were affected.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/dengue-scare-at-rg-kar-hostel-8-test-positive/articleshow/60029232.cms) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nAnirban Ghosh\nKasturba Medical College\n(m_anirbanghosh@hotmail.com) - West Bengal (Birbhum). 21 Aug 2017. At least 100 cases dengue have\nbeen reported from West Bengal's Birbhum district. \"We have received\nreports of at least 100 cases of dengue since 23 Jul 2017. While\nabout 60 of these cases are from the Dubrajpur town in the district's\nSuri Sadar sub-division, the rest are from other areas such as Bolpur\nand Rampurhat towns. But no one has died so far,\" the chief medical\nofficer of Birbhum, Himadri Ari, told The Hindu.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/other-states/bengal-records-100-dengue-cases/article19535541.ece) - West Bengal (Siliguri). 23 Aug 2017. The number of people suffering\nfrom dengue is rising at an alarming rate in Siliguri. According to\nrecords, the highest number of dengue cases reported was 54. This year\n2017, the mark has been crossed.\n(http://siliguritimes.com/number-dengue-patients-rise-siliguri/) - Odisha (Ganjam). 22 Jul 2017. Blood samples of 116 people of the\ndistrict were recently tested and 4 dengue positive cases were\ndetected. Disinfecting water bodies in the district has already\nstarted and a 3-member team has been entrusted with spreading\nawareness on dengue in the district.\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/odisha/2017/jul/22/4-found-dengue-positive-in-odishas-ganjam-district-1632062.html) - Odisha. 18 Aug 2017. 402 cases and 2 deaths. Last year 2016 4348\npersons were tested positive for the dengue virus by this period with\n8 deaths. Out of total 402 infected persons, 67 were tested positive\nin Bhadrak district, 61 in Cuttack district, and 59 in Balasore\ndistrict. Similarly, 35 people have been infected in Khordha, 34 in\nJajpur, 24 in Puri, 20 in Jagatsinghpur . Meanwhile, Kendrapara has\nregistered 20, Ganjam 13, Keonjhar 10, Dhenkanal 11, Bolangir 6, and\nMayurbhanj 5 cases of dengue. While Nayagarh, Sonepur, Kalahandi,\nAngul, and Bargarh registered 3 cases each, Nuapada and Kandhamal\nwitnessed 2 cases. Boudh, Rayagada, Sundargarh and Deogarh districts\nrecorded with single case each. However, 12 patients have come to the\nstate from neighbouring states.\n(http://pragativadi.com/dengue-claims-two-lives-affects-402-odisha/) - Gujarat (Ahmedabad). 1 Aug 2017. A total of 59 cases in July 2017.\nThe actual number of cases is said to be 'far more'; it takes at least\n15 days to confirm cases.\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ahmedabad/59-dengue-cases-in-july-amc/articleshow/59853414.cms) - Jharkhand (Jamshedpur). 30 Jul 2017. 75 positive cases in Kolhan and\nadjoining area of Jamshedpur.\n(http://www.avenuemail.in/jamshedpur/dengue-cases-rise-positive-cases-shoot-75-kolhan/111026/) - Telangana (Hyderabad). 25 Jul 2017. All 4 dengue serotypes are\npresent this year 2017. A total of 15 samples found to be\nco-infected. In an earlier study done in New Delhi, such multiple\ndengue serotype infections were reported in only 19 per cent of cases.\nAll 4 dengue serotypes were detected in almost equal number in blood\nsamples, unlike in an earlier study conducted in New Delhi wherein one\nserotype was found to be dominating. This has been indicated as a\npossible reason for the high prevalence of infection due to more than\none dengue serotype. Another finding of concern is that DEN-4 strain,\nresembling the one detected in Pune in 2009, was detected in as many\nas 11 samples. DEN-4 is associated with unusual symptoms like\nrespiratory distress, pleural effusion, and elevated levels of liver\nenzymes. Also, detection of a DEN-1 strain found closely related to a\nstrain from Thailand detected in 1980 that causes high severity\ninfection has been reported. Dr Musturi Venkataramana, assistant\nprofessor of biotechnology of UoH, who led the study, said, \"When a\nperson is infected with more than one serotype of dengue, it may lead\nto dengue haemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome which can cause\nsevere health problems, and even death. Finding 45 per cent patients\nwith such infections is worrisome.\"\n(http://www.newindianexpress.com/cities/hyderabad/2017/jul/25/all-four-dengue-serotypes-prevalent-in-city-1633171.html) Maps of India can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofindia.com/maps/india/india-political-map.htm) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/142). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pakistan\n- Sindh (Karachi). 8 Aug 2017. 422 dengue fever cases have been\nreported in Sindh province so far in 2017, out of them 410 were\nreported in Karachi, 5 in Hyderabad, 5 in Tharparkar/Mithi, and 2 in\nUmerkot. As per a weekly report issued by Prevention and Control\nProgram for Dengue in Sindh, as many as 27 new dengue fever cases\nsurfaced in the city from 1 to 7 Aug 2017.\n(http://www.brecorder.com/2017/08/08/363624/a27-more-dengue-cases-surface-in-karachi/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 8 Aug 2017. 3rd death due to dengue\nhemorrhagic fever and encephalitis. Most of the affected patients were\nbrought from the Tehkal Payan area from where water samples have been\ncollected to determine the situation.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1476245/third-dengue-death-\nreported-k-p/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 16 Aug 2017. The number of dengue\npatients in the city has reached 600 in almost a month. Most of the\ncases are from Tehkal, the rear of which is a rural area, where there\nis a large number of automobile repair shops. The water kept in open\ncontainers to wash tyres and for other related work serves as the\nbreeding ground for mosquitoes that transmit dengue.\nAs per the administration of Khyber Teaching Hospital, 5 of the\npatients brought to the facility since June 2017 have succumbed to\nthe dengue virus.\n(https://www.geo.tv/latest/153878-peshawar-admin-busy-in-photo-shoot-as-dengue-cases-soar-to-600) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 22 Aug 2017. An investigation report\nby WHO on the dengue outbreak in Peshawar has revealed that the\npresence of a huge number of uncovered water containers used in houses\nand at workshops is the main reason for the outbreak. Following the\ncases reported from Peshawar, a 5-member WHO team moved to the city to\ninvestigate the reasons behind the dengue epidemic. The team collected\nsamples from 2 main areas  Tehkal and Gujran Muhalla. The report\nrevealed that 87 per cent of the samples collected from 23 water\ncontainers in the Civil Dispensary area of Tehkal tested positive for\ndengue virus. Similarly, 79 per cent of the total 19 samples of water\ncontainers in Gujran Muhallah also tested positive.\nThe data compiled by the WHO team, the total number of reported cases\nexceeded 4320 which were screened for dengue in the Khyber Teaching\nHospital from 14 Jun to 17 Aug 2017. A total of 699 people tested\npositive for dengue, of which 5 have died. Of the total patients\nscreened, 325 were admitted to the hospital while 200 were discharged.\nBy 17 Aug 2017, a total of 120 patients were admitted to the facility.\n(https://tribune.com.pk/story/1487967/reveals-water-storage-containers-behind-dengue-surge-peshawar/) - Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (Peshawar). 24 Aug 2017. Dengue continues in\nPeshawar, claiming 7 lives with 69 new cases reported from different\nareas of the city during the last 24 hours, raising the number of\ntotal cases to 1703. So far, he said, 7 deaths including 6 from Khyber\nTeaching Hospital and one in Hayatabad Medical Complex were reported\nfrom dengue epidemics in Peshawar. Out of 69 new cases, 41 were\nreported in Khyber Teaching Hospital (KTH), 13 in Hayatabad Medical\nComplex (HMC), 12 in Lady Reading Hospital (LRH), and 3 in Naseerullah\nKhan Babar Teaching Hospital (NBTH), Peshawar, he said. A rapid\nresponse team has also been set up with mandate to swiftly reach to\nthe affected areas from where new cases were surfaced besides helping\nthe field staff in conduct of fumigation spray, removal of larvae, and\nprovision of other necessary medicines.\n(https://dnd.com.pk/dengue-rampage-in-peshawar-kills-seven-69-new-cases-surface/133250) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://pakistanmap.facts.co/pakistanmapof/PakistanAdministrativeMap.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ China\n- Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region ex Viet Nam (susp). 16 Aug 2017.\nGuangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region in south China has reported its 1st\nimported dengue case this year 2017, local inspection and quarantine\nbureau said. The man had stayed in Hanoi, Viet Nam, for 2 months but\ndenied having been bitten by mosquitoes or having any infectious\ndisease.\n(http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-08/16/c_136531179.htm) - Hong Kong SAR Special Administrative Region. 9 Aug 2017. 1st\nlocally transmitted case of dengue in Hong Kong, this year 2017.\n(https://today.mims.com/topic/chp-investigates-first-local-dengue-fever-case-of-the-year) - Macau SAR. 1 Aug 2017. 1st locally acquired case this year 2017\nconfirmed. 53 imported cases in 2017, including 18 from Thailand, 10\nfrom Sri Lanka, and 7 from the Philippines.\n(https://macaunews.mo/first-local-dengue-case-year-confirmed/) - Macau SAR. 24 Aug 2017. A 48 year old domestic worker from the\nPhilippines is now in hospital after health authorities confirmed she\nhas dengue fever; the 7th imported case reported in Macau this year\n2017.\n(http://menafn.com/1095765055/Tests-show-that-Filipino-maid-in-Macau-has-dengue-fever) Maps of China can be seen at (http://www.sacu.org/maps/provmap.png)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Taiwan. 3 Aug 2017. 2 more indigenous dengue fever cases have been\nconfirmed in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, making that 3 cases this\nyear, said a statement issued by Kaohsiung City's Department of Health\non Thu 3 Aug 2017. The 3 cases were all members of the same family,\nhusband, wife and son, who lived together in the southern Taiwanese\nport city, according to the department. The 3 have recovered\n(http://focustaiwan.tw/news/asoc/201708030028.aspx) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Taiwan can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/193). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Myanmar\n- National. 1 Aug 2017. From 1 Jan to 22 Jul 2017, 14 919 cases and 81\ndeaths of dengue recorded. Most of the deaths were from Ayeyarwady\nregion, followed by Yangon and Bago regions. The current reported\ncases are higher than those of 2016, yet still lower than that of\n2015, according to Dr Zaw Lin, dengue program manager of Ministry of\nHealth and Sports. In Rakhine State, about 1800 people are infected\nand 18 died from the infection. High occurrence was observed in\nMinbya, Sittwe, and Toungup townships. The majority of the deaths aged\nunder 5 and 2 adults (over 40 and 60 years old) also died of dengue,\naccording to Dr San Kyawt Khine, assistant director of State Public\nHealth Department. Only over 1500 cases were identified during 2014 in\nRakhine State.\n(http://www.thithtoolwin.com/2017/08/blog-post_23.html) in Myanmar,\ntrans. Mod.YMA, edited - Kayah. 3 Aug 2017. 370 cases as of 27 Jul 2017, 1 death. From\nJanuary to the of May 2017, 3304 cases with 19 deaths.\n(http://www.bnionline.net/news/karenni-state/item/3327-dengue-fever-cases-spike-in-kayah-state.html) Maps of Myanmar can be seen at\n(http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/myanmar_map.jpg) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/148). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Indonesia\n- Papua (Jayapura). 11 Aug 2017. 37 cases of DHF in Jayapura from\nJanuary to July 2017.\n(http://www.en.netralnews.com/news/currentnews/read/9570/37.residents.in.jayapura.affected.by.dengue.hemorrhagic.fever) Maps of Indonesia can be seen at\n(http://www.ezilon.com/maps/images/asia/political-map-of-Indonesia.gif)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1340). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Viet Nam\n- National. 26 Jul 2017. 52 246 dengue cases this year 2017;\nnorthern region has seen a rapid increase with 6699 cases and 3 deaths\nin Hanoi: 7 have died in Ho Chi Minh City HCMC. Over the past 2\nmonths, around 90 patients were taken to HCM Paediatrics Hospital No 1\nper week on average.\n(http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/182701/rising-dengue-fever-cases-leave-17-dead.html) - National. 19 Aug 2017. The number of dengue fever cases in Viet Nam\nspiked by some 10 000 cases in the past week. Tran Đac Phu, head of\nthe ministry's preventive medicine department, said the country had\nrecorded 90 626 dengue cases since the beginning of 2017, a\nyear-on-year rise of 67.8 per cent, including 24 fatalities, local\nmedia reports. This is up by about 10 000 since the last total case\ncount was released on 3 Aug 207. The outbreak is stretching the\ncountry's medical system as more than 78 000 of the cases required\nhospitalization. In the capital city of Hanoi, there have been 17 027\nrecorded dengue cases, 7 of whom died since the beginning of the year\n2017.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/dengue-updates-vietnam-sri-lanka-32087/) - Mekong Delta. 24 Jul 2017. Cases increased by 125 per cent in 1st 15\ndays of July 2017 compared with same period 2016. An Giang province\nalone recorded the highest number of 120 hospitalised cases in the 1st\n10 days of July 2017, followed by Soc Trang province with 110 cases\nand Dong Thap province, 100 cases. Since the beginning of 2017,\ndengue-related deaths have been reported in Dong Thap, Tien Giang, and\nTra Vinh provinces. Dengue fever has increased sharply this year among\nchildren aged between 10-15 in the Mekong Delta, especially in Can Tho\ncity.\n(http://english.vietnamnet.vn/fms/society/182533/dengue-fever-on-the-rise-in-mekong-delta.html) - Hanoi. 5 Aug 2017. Nearly 9000 cases of dengue fever have now been\nreported in Hanoi since the beginning of the year 2017, with 2300\nreported from 24 to 30 Jul 2017 alone, state media said. From the\nbeginning of this year 2017 through July, there was a 23 per cent\nincrease in cases in the city over the number reported during the same\nperiod last year 2016, while 46 per cent more cases were reported in\nJuly than in June, the city's health department said. According to\nWHO, as of 18 Jun 2017, there were 45 074 cases of dengue reported in\nViet Nam including 13 deaths. Compared to the same period in 2016 (40\n511 cases including 12 deaths), the cumulative number of cases\nincreased by 11.3 per cent.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/vietnam-dengue-news-emergency-declared-ha-nam-hanoi-outbreak-32326/) - Hanoi. 11 Aug 2017. Nearly 5000 new cases in Hanoi, with more than\n13 200 infected and with 6 deaths since early 2017.\n(http://www.elevenmyanmar.com/world-news/11037) - Ha Nam. 5 Aug 2017. More than 10 cases a day being reported largest\noutbreak in history of Province. The Ha Nam Province People's\nCommittee declared a state of emergency on 3 Aug 2017, to deal with a\ngrowing outbreak of dengue fever, spread by infected mosquitoes, with\n100 cases confirmed year-to-date, according to local media.\n(http://outbreaknewstoday.com/vietnam-dengue-news-emergency-declared-ha-nam-hanoi-outbreak-32326/) Maps of Viet Nam can be seen at\n(http://www.onlineasiatravel.com/images/vn/vietnam-map.png) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Philippines\n- National. 11 Aug 2017. The Department of Health (DoH) reported a\nconsiderable decrease of dengue fever cases in the 1st half of 2017 in\nwhich only 43 770 nationwide have been tallied from 1 Jan to 1 Jul\n2017. This is 36.8 per cent lower than the 69 297 recorded in the\nsame period in 2016. Among the 43 770 cases, 250 deaths were reported,\nwhich is 84 fewer than the 334 recorded in the same period in 2016.\nThe report showed that all regions, except in Metro Manila, showed\ndecreasing trends in dengue cases as compared to 2016. Majority of the\ndengue cases were recorded in Central Visayas (6281), Metro Manila\n(5567), Central Luzon (5147), Calabarzon (5007), and Soccsksargen\n(4861). Provinces with the most number of cases are Cebu with 11 per\ncent, followed by South Cotabato with 6.3 per cent, and Pampanga with\n4.6 per cent. Metro Manila is the lone region with an upward trend of\ncases, recording a 24.9 per cent increase from 4457 in 2016.\n(http://www.manilatimes.net/dengue-cases-drop-first-half-2017-report/343788/) - Cebu. 11 Aug 2017. Talisay City, Cebu Province Central Visayas,\nPhilippines 296 cases and 9 deaths; Consolacion 260 cases and 4\ndeaths; Argao 187 cases and 1 death.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/cebu/local-news/2017/08/10/talisay-tops-number-dengue-cases-557829) - Negros Occidental. 2 Aug 2017. The Provincial Health Office (PHO)\nreported that dengue cases this year 2017 in Negros Occidental have\nreached 14 from January to July. The latest death was reported in\nBarangay Mambulac, Silay City. Deaths were monitored in San Carlos\nCity, with 4; Sagay City and Kabankalan City, 2 each; Escalante City,\nVictorias City, Bago City, Silay City, Hinigaran, and Calatrava, one\neach.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/bacolod/local-news/2017/08/02/provincial-health-office-dengue-deaths-negocc-now-14-556270) - Negros Occidental (Bacolod City).17 Aug 2017. A total of 9 barangays\nFilipino term for a village, district or ward identified as dengue\nhot spots: Mandalagan with 31 cases from January to 12 Aug 2017;\nVillamonte, 24; Mansilingan, 22; Banago, 18; Alijis, 17; Estefania,\n17; Vista Alegre, 14; Taculing, 13; and Sum-ag, 12.\n(http://www.sunstar.com.ph/bacolod/local-news/2017/08/17/9-barangays-bacolod-tag-dengue-hot-spots-558972) - Cavite (Trece Martires City). 23 Aug 2017. Dengue fever cases have\nbeen on the rise, particularly in the past 2 months in Cavite\nprovince's 7 districts the Provincial Epidemiology Surveillance Unit\n(PESU) reported. PESU records showed that in the 1st 8 months of the\nyear, 2193 cases and 8 deaths were reported, although only 1260 cases\nand 3 deaths were reported and recorded from 1 Jan to 24 Jun 2017.\nCavite, a 1st class province with 7 districts comprising 7 cities and\n16 municipalities, has an estimated population of 4.3 million. The\nprovincial government declared a dengue fever outbreak in all\ndistricts and placed the entire area under a state of calamity in\nSeptember 2015. The year ended with 48 deaths and 12 007 cases, PESU\nrecords showed.\n(http://news.mb.com.ph/2017/08/23/dengue-fever-cases-in-cavite-rising/) Maps of the Philippines can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/z4y3p5v)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/158). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Laos\n- National. 4 Aug 2017. Over 5000 people infected and one death in the\ncapital Vientiane. June 2017. Suzuki T, Kutsuna S, Taniguchi S,\net al. Dengue virus exported from Côte d'Ivoire to Japan, June 2017.\nEmerg Infect Dis. 2017 date cited.\nAbstract. Since April 2017, a dengue fever outbreak has been ongoing\nin Côte d'Ivoire. We diagnosed dengue fever (type 2 virus) in a\ntraveler returning to Japan from Côte d'Ivoire. Phylogenetic analysis\nrevealed strain homology with the Burkina Faso 2016 strain. This case\nmay serve as an alert to possible disease spread outside Africa.\n(https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/10/17-1132_article) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Pacific\n\n- Samoa. 22 Jul 2017. From 6 to 17 Jul 2017, there were 43 suspected\ncases of dengue fever seen at the LBJ hospital and community health\ncenters. 15 cases confirmed from laboratory work on samples sent to\nHonolulu for testing. Physicians at LBJ hospital said they are seeing\napprox 30-50 cases per month, with symptoms related to dengue.\nAccording to a senior nurse, 10-15 patients with dengue like symptoms\nor tested positive for dengue, are admitted to LBJ per month.\n(http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/335595/dengue-fever-on-the-rise-in-american-samoa) - Samoa. 14 Aug 2017. Current surveillance information; between 7-11\nAug 2017 doctors from the 2 main hospitals reported what appears to be\na dengue outbreak in presenting patients. The investigations continue.\nThe main hospital ICU unit and acute ward reported a sudden increase\nin cases with prolonged illness, severe headache, nausea and vomiting,\nabdominal pains, and at least one painful joint. As many as 2\nsuspected deaths have been reported. Surveillance data on PATIS\nPatient Information System shows that from January to July 2017, 37\nclinical cases and 560 requests to the lab with 5 positive cases.\nAugust 2017; 54 requests with 25 positive cases. The MoH recommends\ngeneral hygiene and source reduction of breeding sites. Drain\nlongstanding water, clean up rubbish, wear protective clothing, use\nrepellents, and mosquito nets. The public is advised to see a doctor\nas soon as possible when symptoms arise.\nThis is from an outbreak notice issued by Samoa MoH \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nMargaret Lesjak\nEpidemiology Advisor at Samoa MoH\n(margaret.lesjak@health.gov.ws) - Samoa. 16 Aug 2017. The Ministry of Health has issued an alert dated\n12 Aug 2017, about an outbreak of dengue fever in the country. As many\nas 25 cases with 2 suspected deaths. It says that the National Disease\nSurveillance and International Health Regulations Division has been\nnotified of severely ill cases from Tupua Tamasese Meaole Hospital.\n(http://sobserver.ws/en/16_08_2017/local/23251/Dengue-outbreak-warning.htm) - Samoa. 23 Aug 2017. The 2 deaths were suspected to be\nfrom the dengue fever. There were also 2217 laboratory confirmed\ncases.\n(http://fijivillage.com/news/6-people-died-from-dengue-fever-in-first-6-months-of-this-year-srk952/) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Fiji can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/167). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ - French Polynesia. 9 Aug 2017. Tahiti: 1st death of 2017, a 7 year\nold boy. In the 2nd half of July 2017, 25 cases were recorded across 5\nof French Polynesia's main islands. Half of those infected were\nchildren under the age of 15.\n(http://www.radionz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/336820/seven-year-old-boy-dies-of-dengue-in-tahiti) Maps of French Polynesia can be seen at\n(http://www.spc.int/aquaculture/images/countries/large/french_polynesia_b1.gif)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31048). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Africa\n\n- Côte d'Ivoire. 4 Aug 2017. On 6 May 2017, the Ministry of Health\n(MoH) of Côte d'Ivoire WHO of a dengue fever outbreak in Abidjan, the\ncapital city of Côte d'Ivoire. Suspected cases of dengue were first\nreported on 22 Apr 2017 and confirmed by the Institut Pasteur de Côte\nd'Ivoire (IPCI) laboratory on 28 Apr 2017. As of 11 Jul 2017, a total\nof 623 suspected cases including 2 deaths (case fatality rate: 0.3 per\ncent) have been reported. A total of 192 cases have been confirmed by\nPCR, of which 66 per cent were dengue virus serotype 2 (DENV-2), 29\nper cent were DENV-3, and 5 per cent were DENV-1. In addition, 90\nsamples were confirmed IgM positive by serology. The majority of cases\nhave been reported from Abidjan city. Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted for 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. The general trend of suspected cases of dengue fever\nis increasing. From 27 Jun to 4 Jul 2017, 37 new cases were reported\nand from 4 to 11 Jul 2017, 142 new suspected cases were reported. A\ntotal of 27 per cent of the suspected cases are aged between 15 and 29\nyears old, 55 per cent are 30 years old and above. 54 per cent of the\ncases are female. Coinfection with yellow fever was suspected in 68\ncases and confirmed in one case. Further laboratory confirmation is\nongoing.\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/04-august-2017-dengue-cote-d-ivoire/en/) - Côte d'Ivoire. 8 Aug 2017. Ivory Coast continues to affect multiple\nregions: 623 cases by mid July serotype DEN-2 (66 per cent), and DEN-3\n(29 per cent). Ninety cases were also confirmed positive for\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM), an antibody produced in the body as an immune\nresponse to dengue infection. According to WHO, the majority of cases\nhave appeared in Abidjan City, while the Cocody Bingerville health\ndistrict accounted 78 per cent of cases and 80 per cent of all\nconfirmed cases. Additionally, the general trend of suspected cases of\ndengue fever has been increasing, growing from 37 new cases from 27\nJun to 4 Jul to 142 new suspected cases appearing from 4 to 11 Jul\n2017.\n(https://homelandprepnews.com/ stories/23646-dengue-outbreak-\nivory-coast-continues- increase-according-world-\nhealth-organization/) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Côte d'Ivoire can be seen at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/52). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Research\n- Viral persistence, organ transplant-related transmission.\nDate: Sun 13 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Star Online (edited)\n(http://tinyurl.com/yd4vv2bj) \nThere is now a concern that the dengue virus can reside in the body\neven after one has recovered and the virus is non-detectable in the\nblood, said a well-known dengue scientist. This came about after 2\nkidney recipients in Taiwan were diagnosed with dengue 2 days after\nreceiving a kidney each from the same donor, said National Cheng Kung\nUniversity microbiology and immunology professor Dr Oscar Perng\nGuey-chuen. \"This indicates a potential risk,\" the Taiwan-based\nscientist said, adding that no dengue virus was detected in the\ndonor's blood. He said the donor contracted dengue in 2015 and in mid-2016, he died\nin an accident. His family donated his corneas, liver, heart, and\nkidneys. Both patients had the same strain of the dengue virus the\ndonor had in 2015 and one of the recipients died of dengue\nhaemorrhagic fever, he said. Asked where the virus could be hiding since it could not be detected\nin the blood, he said it was a question scientists are trying to\nanswer. Interestingly, those who received the donor's corneas, liver,\nand heart did not develop dengue, Dr Perng said on the sidelines of\nthe National Dengue And Arboviruses Infection Conference 2017\nyesterday 12 Aug 2017. He said although there was not enough\nevidence to show the virus came from the donor as the kidneys were not\ntested for dengue before the transplant, the same virus was found in\nthe patients' bodies after that. Dr Perng said his team had studied mice for dengue virus in the blood\ntestes, kidney, liver, spleen and brain, and found the virus present\nin the kidneys and brain. \"We believe the virus probably resided in\nthe kidneys and was not cleared by the body,\" he said, adding that the\nvirus could have been activated after transplant. He said this raised\nconcerns about asymptomatic people who are dengue carriers. Health Ministry deputy director, general Datuk Dr S Jeyaindran said\npatients with severe dengue would have better recovery if they were\ngiven colloids, a more concentrated fluid, at the early stage in fluid\nmanagement for dengue patients. Dr Jeyaindran, who was representing\nHealth Minister Datuk Seri Dr S Subramaniam, said colloids may be\nintroduced at an earlier stage, instead of saline because it has not\nbeen successful in treating patients with severe dengue. He said more\nstudies will be conducted to find out at which stage the colloids\nshould be given. byline: Loh Foon Fong \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Air travel related spread of dengue.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-08-air-responsible-dengue-asia.html) \nWhile the incidences of many other infectious diseases have declined\nover the past decade, the number of cases and outbreaks of dengue\nvirus have continued to increase. The spread of dengue to new areas is\nlikely due in large part to trends in air travel, researchers now\nreport in PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases. Dengue virus affects as estimated 390 million people around the globe\neach year, and can cause symptoms ranging from a mild fever and\nheadache to severe low blood pressure. The virus has mostly caused\ndisease in tropical and subtropical areas of the world, but a 2014\noutbreak in Japan broke that pattern. Overall, the geographic area\naffected by dengue has been growing in recent years. In the new work, Huaiyu Tian and Bing Xu, both of Beijing Normal\nUniversity, China, together with colleagues from the University of\nOxford and elsewhere analyzed the spread of dengue viruses in Asia\nfrom 1956 to 2015. They used 2202 genetic sequences of dengue viruses,\ncollected in 20 countries or regions of Asia over the 59 years, to\ndetermine how different strains were related. They also investigated\ntrends in air travel, maritime mobility, migration, and\nsocio-economics to determine what factors impact the spread of\ndengue. The spread of 3 different dengue virus serotypes, DENV-1, -2, and -3,\nis associated with air traffic more so than any other factors, the\ndata revealed. Air traffic hubs such as Thailand and India, the\nresearchers found, help seed dengue epidemics, while China, Cambodia,\nIndonesia, and Singapore help diffuse the virus to other Asian\ncountries. \"Future trends in global mobility could potentially accelerate the\nappearance and diffusion of DENV worldwide,\" the researchers say.\n\"Prevention and control of dengue epidemics requires a better\nunderstanding of its mode of geographic dissemination, especially for\ncountries in the tropics.\" Reference: Tian H, Sun Z, Faria NR, et al. Increasing airline travel\nmay facilitate co-circulation of multiple dengue virus serotypes in\nAsia. PLoS Negl Trop Dis. 2017; 11(8): e0005694;\n(http://journals.plos.org/plosntds/article?id=10.1371/journal.pntd.0005694) \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) - Visual impact.\nDate: Fri 25 Aug 2017.\nSource: NYOOOZ, The Indian Express report (edited)\n(https://www.nyoooz.com/news/delhi/902768/drop-in-vision-traced-to-inflammation-caused-by-dengue-fever-say-doctors/) \nIn a rare symptom of dengue, a 20 year old in the capital developed\n\"ophthalmic complications\" due to which she complained of a \"drop in\nvision\". Typical symptoms of dengue range from sore throat, cough,\njoint pain, and rashes. Sir Gangaram Hospital reported the rare case,\nwhere the woman, who went to the eye OPD outpatient department,\ncomplained of \"sudden blurring of vision in the left eye,\" as reported\nby IE Indian Express. According to the newspaper, doctors eventually discovered that the\ndrop in vision was due to \"inflammation of blood vessels in the\nretina\", as a result of dengue fever. The woman had earlier tested\npositive for the vectorborne disease. \"The patient tested positive for\ndengue and had fever for the past 8 days. She did not have any rashes\non her body, or any other systemic manifestation.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> WHO update.\nDate: The 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region (edited)\n(http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/dengue_biweekly_20170815.pdf) \nDengue situation update no. 523\n-\nNorthern hemisphere\n-\nCambodia\nAs of 8 Aug 2017, a total of 1604 suspected dengue fever cases were\nreported in 2017. The total number of reported dengue cases including\ndengue haemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome was lower than the\n3 year-threshold of the same period from 2014-2016. China\nAs of 31 Jul 2017, there were 503 cases of dengue reported in China in\n2017. This number is higher than that reported during the same period\nsince 2012 but follows historical trend. Lao PDR People's Democratic Republic\nAs of 4 Aug 2017, there were 5740 cases of dengue with 7 deaths\nreported in Lao PDR in 2017, with 406 cases reported in epi week 31\n(week ending 5 Aug 2017). Dengue activity is high with the number of\ndengue cases reported this year 2017 being higher than the cases\nreported for same period since 2014. Malaysia\nIn week 31 of 2017 (week ending 5 Aug 2017), 1899 dengue cases were\nreported with 2 deaths, an increase of 1.1 per cent compared with week\n30. As of week 31, the cumulative number of dengue cases in 2017 were\n59 521 with 135 deaths compared with 67 437 cases with 147 deaths\nduring the same period in 2016. Philippines (no update)\nA total of 43 770 dengue cases were reported nationwide from 1 Jan to\n1 Jul 2017. This number is 36.8 per cent lower (25 527) compared with\nthe same time period in 2016. Singapore\nAs of 5 Aug 2017, there were 1732 dengue cases reported in Singapore\nsince January 2017. This is lower than the number of reported cases\nduring the same period since 2013. During week 31, there were 61 cases\nreported and the number of reported cases in 2017 remains lower than\nthose reported for the same time period in 2016 . Viet Nam\nAs of 3 Aug 2017, there were 80 555 cases of dengue reported in Viet\nNam including 22 deaths. Compared with the same period in 2016, the\ncumulative number of cases increased by 33.5 per cent, and the number\nof deaths rose by 5. Most cases were reported from the South (59 per\ncent). A sharp increase in the number of reported cases has been\nobserved in the North (almost 25 times higher than the same period\nlast year 2016), especially from Ha Noi, with about 13 440 cases. Southern hemisphere\n-\nAustralia\nAs of 31 Jul 2017, there were 695 laboratory-confirmed dengue cases\nreported in Australia in 2017. The number of cases reported is lower\nthan that reported during the same time period in the previous years\n(2012-2016). Pacific Islands countries and areas\n\nFrench Polynesia\nIn French Polynesia, 12 cases (including 1 death) in week 29 and 12\ncases in week 30 (week ending 29 Jul 2017). Among these, 15 cases were\nconfirmed as DENV-1 infection. New Caledonia (no update)\nAs of 1 Aug 2017, 4,452 dengue cases were reported in 2017. There is a\ndownward trend in the number of reported cases since week 16 (week\nending 22 Apr 2017). \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"San Marino":{},"Sao Tome and Principe":{},"Saudi Arabia":{"32":{"title":"MERS-CoV (55): Saudi Arabia (MK, MD, BA), WHO ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> MERS-CoV (55): Saudi Arabia (MK, MD, BA), WHO [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nMERS-COV (55): SAUDI ARABIA (MAKKAH, AL MADINAH, AL BAHA), WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Saudi Arabia, 4 new cases - Saudi MOH, 12-18 Aug 2017\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Saudi Arabia - WHO update 17 Aug 2017 \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Saudi Arabia, 4 new cases - Saudi MOH, 12-18 Aug 2017.\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Saudi MOH 12-18 Aug 2017 (edited)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/default.aspx?PageIndex=1) \nAs of Fri 18 Aug 2017, there have been a total of:\n1701 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection, including\n687 deaths reported case fatality rate 40.4 percent,\n991 recoveries, and\n23 currently active cases/infections. As previously mentioned, the numbers of deaths, recoveries, and\ncurrently active cases come from my spreadsheet tallies and differ\nfrom those listed on the Saudi MOH website; my spreadsheet counts\nasymptomatic infections. One complication is the reporting of cases as\neither recoveries or deaths that cannot be confirmed as previously\nreported newly confirmed cases. - Mod.MPP Since the last ProMED-mail update Fri 11 Aug 2017, there have been a\ntotal of:\n4 newly confirmed cases\n1 newly reported fatality, and\n2 newly reported recoveries. Date: 15 Aug 2017\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-08-15-001.aspx) 2- A 44-year-old expat female, non-healthcare worker from Jeddah\nMakkah region with a history of pre-existing co-morbidities.\nreported as a newly confirmed case on Tue 15 Aug 2017 at which time\nshe was noted to be in stable condition. Classified as a secondary\ncase in a household contact. - Mod.MPP \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) In the one week period since the last update, there have been 4 newly\nconfirmed cases reported, 2 from Jeddah (in Makkah region), and one\neach from Beljershi Albaha (in Al Bāhah region) and Madinah (in Al\nMadinah region). The 2 newly confirmed cases from Jeddah are of\ninterest for the observation that they are still under review for\nclassification. The last time there were 2 cases from the same\nlocation reported as \"under review\" within a few days of each other\nwas the beginning of the identified outbreak in Wadi Aldawasir (in\nRiyadh region) back in March of 2017. Looking for other recently\nreported cases in Jeddah, on Wed 2 Aug 2017 there was a 57-year-old\nexpat male reported in critical condition who was reported as a\nfatality on Fri 4 Aug 2017, having been classified as a primary case\nwith high risk exposure history still under investigation. On Fri 4\nAug 2017 there was the 44-year-old expat female classified as a\nsecondary household contact case (see recovery No. 2 listed above).\nand now, 12 and 14 days after the 2nd case was reported from Jeddah\nthere are 2 additional cases reported, both under review. An obvious\nquestion is whether there is a new healthcare associated cluster of\nMERS-CoV transmission occurring in Jeddah.. perhaps associated with\neither a renal dialysis unit or another mixed inpatient/outpatient\nfacility?.. Maps showing the locations of each of the cases discussed above can be\nfound at the source URLs. The HealthMap/ProMED map of Saudi Arabia can\nbe found at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/131). - Mod.MPP \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Saudi Arabia - WHO update 17 Aug 2017.\nDate: 17 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News\n17 Aug 2017 (edited)\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/17-august-2017-mers-saudi-arabia/en/) \nMiddle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) - Saudi Arabia\n17 Aug 2017\n-\nBetween 4 Jul 2017 and 12 Aug 2017, the national IHR Focal Point of\nSaudi Arabia reported 26 additional cases of Middle East respiratory\nsyndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infection including 6 deaths, and 2\ndeaths among previously reported cases. Dawmet Aljandal / 70 / M / No / Yes / No / No /\nYes† / 2017-08-05 / 2017-07-27 / 2017-08-07 / Deceased /\n2017-08-11\n20 / 2017-08-08 / Khamis Mushait / 58 / M / No / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\n2017-07-25 / 2017-08-03 / 2017-08-06 / Deceased / 2017-08-10\n21 / 2017-08-08 / Aloula / 55 / M / No / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\n2017-08-03 / 2017-08-05 / 2017-08-07 / Alive\n22 / 2017-08-10 / Dawmet Aljandal / 38 / F / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\nYes† / NA / NA / 2017-06-09 / Alive\n23 / 2017-08-10 / Dawmet Aljandal / 42 / F / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\nYes† / NA / NA / 2017-06-09 / Alive\n24 / 2017-08-11 / Dawmet Aljandal / 55 / M / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\nYes† / NA / NA / 2017-08-10 / Alive\n25 / 2017-08-11 / Dawmet Aljandal / 52 / M / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\nYes† / NA / NA / 2017-08-10 / Alive\n26 / 2017-08-12 / Baljurashi / 89 / M / No / Yes / NA / NA / No /\n2017-08-08 / 2017-08-10 / 2017-08-11 / Alive\n†Case was detected through contact tracing of a previous MERS-CoV\ncase.\nHospitalized for other unrelated condition prior to symptom onset. Among the 26 newly reported cases, 13 are associated with a cluster in\na hospital in Al Jawf Region, Saudi Arabia. The initial case was a\n51-year-old reported on Wed 2 Aug 2017. To date, 12 cases have been\nidentified through contact tracing. These cases include 8 health care\nworkers (all asymptomatic) in the hospital where the initial case was\ntreated, one hospital contact (a 70-year-old male) and 3 household\ncontacts. Follow up of health care workers, hospital and household\ncontacts are ongoing. Globally, 2066 laboratory-confirmed cases of infection with MERS-CoV\nincluding at least 720 related deaths have been reported to WHO. Public health response\nThe Ministry of Health of Saudi Arabia evaluates each case and their\ncontacts and implements measures to limit further human-to-human\ntransmission and bring Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS)\noutbreaks under control. The measures taken by Ministry of Health\nofficials in Saudi Arabia include:  - Risk stratification and active tracing for contacts in healthcare\nand in communities. High risk contacts (e.g. unprotected exposure to a\ncase or engagement in an aerosol generating procedure) are tested by\nPCR regardless of having symptoms. Health care workers are exempted\nfrom work until they are cleared by infection control experts. - Trained hospital epidemiologists have been deployed to sites within\n24 hours of identifying an outbreak. - Enforcement of strict adherence to environmental disinfection and\nterminal cleaning of affected areas. - Enforcement of visual triage for respiratory diseases in emergency\ndepartment and outpatient departments and ensuring the 24/7\navailability of trained nurses for early detection of patients with\nrespiratory symptoms, and proper documentation on triage forms. - Extensive training of all health care workers on case definition\nfor early detection, implementation of isolation precautions, proper\nselection, donning and doffing of personal protective equipment (PPE),\nhand hygiene and environmental cleaning and disinfection. - Ensuring availability of infection prevention supplies including\nhand sanitizer, PPEs, surface disinfectants, portable HEPA filters and\nfumigation machines. - Ensuring that all health care workers are fit tested for high\nefficiency respirators. - Implementing the policy of not allowing health care personnel\nworking in a facility affected by an outbreak to travel or work in\nHajj premises or in any healthcare facility until they are medical\ncleared. WHO risk assessment\nMERS-CoV causes severe human infections resulting in high mortality\nand has demonstrated the ability to transmit between humans. So far,\nthe observed non-sustained human-to-human transmission has occurred\nmainly in health care settings. The notification of additional cases does not change the overall risk\nassessment. WHO expects that additional cases of MERS-CoV infection\nwill be reported from the Middle East, and that cases will continue to\nbe exported to other countries by individuals who might acquire the\ninfection after exposure to animals or animal products (for example,\nfollowing contact with dromedaries) or human source (for example, in a\nhealth care setting). WHO continues to monitor the epidemiological\nsituation and conducts risk assessment based on the latest available\ninformation. WHO advice\nBased on the current situation and available information, WHO\nencourages all Member States to continue their surveillance for acute\nrespiratory infections and to carefully review any unusual patterns. Infection prevention and control measures are critical to prevent the\npossible spread of MERS-CoV in health care facilities. It is not\nalways possible to identify patients with MERS-CoV early because like\nother respiratory infections, the early symptoms of MERS-CoV are\nnon-specific. Therefore, health-care workers should always apply\nstandard precautions consistently with all patients, regardless of\ntheir diagnosis. Droplet precautions should be added to the standard\nprecautions when providing care to patients with symptoms of acute\nrespiratory infection; contact precautions and eye protection should\nbe added when caring for probable or confirmed cases of MERS-CoV\ninfection; airborne precautions should be applied when performing\naerosol generating procedures. Until more is understood about MERS-CoV, people with diabetes, renal\nfailure, chronic lung disease, and immunocompromised persons are\nconsidered to be at high risk of severe disease from MERS-CoV\ninfection. Therefore, in addition to avoiding close contact with\nsuspected or confirmed human cases of the disease, people with these\nconditions should avoid close contact with animals, particularly\ncamels, when visiting farms, markets, or barn areas where the virus is\nknown to be potentially circulating. General hygiene measures, such as\nregular hand washing before and after touching animals and avoiding\ncontact with sick animals, should be adhered to. Food hygiene practices should be observed. People should avoid\ndrinking raw camel milk or camel urine, or eating meat that has not\nbeen properly cooked. WHO does not advise special screening at points of entry with regard\nto this event nor does it currently recommend the application of any\ntravel or trade restrictions. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp In summary, according to the WHO update, as of Sat 12 Aug 2017,\nthere have been a total of 2066 laboratory confirmed cases of MERS-CoV\ninfection reported to WHO, including at least 720 related deaths\n(reported case fatality rate 34.8 percent). In the period covered by\nthe above update (4 Jul - 12 Aug 2017), there were 26 newly confirmed\nlaboratory confirmed infections with the MERS-CoV including 8\nasymptomatic infections associated with the outbreak in Dawmet\nAljandal (Asir region). In addition to the 6 fatalities among these 26 newly confirmed\ninfections, official recovery reports from the MOH were available for\ncases no. 1 (on Tue 11 Jul 2017), no. 3 (on Mon 31 Jul 2017), no 5 (on\nThu 17 Aug 2017), and no. 9 (Tue 15 Aug 2017). Classifications of the 26 cases reported by the MOH included:\nA total of 8 primary cases with high risk exposures still under\ninvestigation (cases nos. 1, 2, 3, 7, 11, 20, 21, and 26)\nOne primary case with no known high risk exposure (case no. 6)\nUp to 4 primary cases with contact with camels (3 direct contact, one\nindirect contact  cases nos. 4, 5, 8 and 12)\nA total of 8 secondary healthcare associated cases in healthcare\nworkers (cases nos. 10, 15, 16, 17, 22, 23, 24, and 25)\nOne secondary healthcare associated case in a patient (case no.19)\nUp to 4 secondary cases in household contacts (cases nos. 9, 13, 14\nand 18) According to the WHO update, case no. 11 had a history of contact with\ncamels that was not known at the time of the MOH report. Interpretation of the details above is that outside of the outbreak in\nAsir region, the pattern of transmission was primarily sporadic cases,\naround the country, the majority of whom were classified as primary\ncases with unidentified high risk exposures (8 out of 13) and the\nremaining 5 cases had a history of known contact with camels and camel\nproducts in the 14 days preceding onset of illness. So the question\nremains, what is the high risk exposure that is not being identified?\n....- Mod.MPP ","keywordsMatched":[]},"129":{"title":"MERS-CoV (56): UAE, Saudi Arabia (JF, HA, RI),\r\n\tWHO ","date":["29","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> MERS-CoV (56): UAE, Saudi Arabia (JF, HA, RI),\r\n\tWHO [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nMERS-COV (56): UNITED ARAB EMIRATES, SAUDI ARABIA (AL JAWF, HAIL,\nRIYADH), WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> UAE, 1 new case - WHO\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Saudi Arabia, 7 new cases - Saudi MOH 19-29 Aug 2017 \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> UAE, 1 new case - WHO.\nDate: Mon 28 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News\n(DONs) (edited)\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/28-august-2017-mers-uae/en/) \nMiddle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) - United Arab\nEmirates\n\nOn 29 Jul 2017, the national IHR focal point of the United Arab\nEmirates reported one additional case of Middle East Respiratory\nSyndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) Details of the case\n-\nMERS-CoV case reported on 29 July 2017*\nPlease note, data corresponds to Disease Outbreak News as published on\n28 Aug 2017.\n* Data subject to change due to ongoing investigations. Fields related\nto the final status of the case are updated as information is\navailable.\nNA = Not available Date of notification to WHO / Reporting country / City of residence /\nAge / Sex / Health care worker / Comorbidities / Exposure to camels /\nCamel milk consumption / Exposure to MERS-CoV cases / Date of symptoms\nonset / Date of 1st hospitalization / Date of laboratory confirmation\n/ Status\n29 Jul 2017 / United Arab Emirates / Al Ain / 54 / M / No / No / NA /\nNA / No / 11 Jul 2017 / 25 Jul 2017 / Alive The patient, who lives and works in Al Ain, United Arab Emirates,\npresented at a hospital in Al Ain on 16 Jul 2017. On 16 Jul 2017,\na chest X-ray showed pneumonia and he was treated with antibiotics and\nnon-invasive ventilation. On 25 Jul 2017, his symptoms worsened and\na sputum sample was collected and tested for MERS-CoV and influenza.\nOn 26 Jul 2017, showing no signs of improvement, the patient was\ntransferred to a 2nd hospital in Al Ain and placed in an intensive\ncare unit. A 2nd sputum sample was collected on 26 Jul 2017 and both samples\ntested positive for MERS-CoV on 27 Jul 2017. The patient is\ncurrently in ICU on mechanical ventilation. Investigations into the\nsource of infection are ongoing. At the time of writing the results of\nthe investigation were not yet provided to WHO. Globally, 2067 laboratory-confirmed cases of infection with MERS-CoV\nincluding at least 720 related deaths have been reported to WHO. Public health response\n-\nThe Ministry of Health in Abu Dhabi carried out contact tracing and\nfollowed up 89 health care workers and 95 contacts at his place of\nemployment. All identified contacts were monitored for 14 days from\nthe last date of exposure. No additional cases were detected. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp I have been unable to find additional information on both official\nsources as well as unofficial sources of information related to the\ncase described in the UAE in the above WHO report. Of note is that the\nevent (identification of a MERS-CoV infected individual) actually\noccurred a month ago  the date of report of this case to WHO was 29\nJul 2017, with the date of onset of symptoms 11 Jul 2017 and date of\npositive laboratory testing for MERS-CoV of 25 Jul 2017. Information\non results of contact tracing continuing until 14 days following last\nknown contact with the case (one incubation period) was available for\nall contacts. Hence, this is a nice historical archive of\nidentification of a sporadic case of MERS-CoV infection, although the\ninformation on the investigation of possible high risk exposures of\nthe actual case is not available at present. This is now the 5th case of MERS-CoV infection identified in the UAE\nthis year, with 2 previous cases in May 2017 from Al Ain, and 2\nadditional previous cases from Abu Dhabi reported in April 2017,\nbringing the total number of cases reported by the UAE since 2012 up\nto 84. Al Ain is a major inland city of the UAE, belonging to the Abu Dhabi\nemirate (see\n(https://www.mapsofworld.com/united-arab-emirates/maps/united-arab-emirates-cities-map.jpg)). The HealthMap/ProMED map of the United Arab Emirates is available at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/132). - Mod.MPP \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Saudi Arabia, 7 new cases - Saudi MOH 19-29 Aug 2017.\nDate: Tue 29 Aug 2017.\nSource: Saudi MOH 19-29 Aug 2017 (edited)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/default.aspx?PageIndex=1) \nAs of Tue 29 Aug 2017, there have been a total of:\n1708 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection, including\n688 deaths reported case fatality rate 40.3 percent,\n997 recoveries, and\n22 currently active cases/infections. As previously mentioned, the numbers of deaths, recoveries, and\ncurrently active cases come from my spreadsheet tallies and differ\nfrom those listed on the Saudi MOH website; my spreadsheet counts\nasymptomatic infections. One complication is the reporting of cases as\neither recoveries or deaths that cannot be confirmed as previously\nreported newly confirmed cases. - Mod.MPP Since the last ProMED-mail update Fri 18 Aug 2017, there have been a\ntotal of:\n7 newly confirmed cases\n1 newly reported fatality, and\n6 newly reported recoveries. Classified as a primary case with a history of\nindirect contact with camels in the 14 days preceding onset of\nillness. - Mod.MPP Information on newly reported recoveries (6 recoveries).\nDate: 25 Aug 2017 (1 recovery)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-08-25-001.aspx) 1- A 17-year-old Saudi male, non-healthcare worker from Dawmat\nAljandal Al Jawd region with no history of co-morbidities. reported\nas a newly confirmed case on 7 Aug 2017 at which time he was noted\nto be in stable condition. Classified as a secondary case in a\nhousehold contact. - Mod.MPP. Date: 24 Aug 2017 (1 recovery)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-08-24-001.aspx) 2- A 12-year-old Saudi male, non-healthcare worker from Dawmat\nAljandal Al Jawd region with no history of co-morbidities. reported\nas a newly confirmed case on 7 Aug 2017 at which time he was noted\nto be in stable condition having been identified as an asymptomatic\ncontact of a previously confirmed case. Classified as a secondary\ninfection in a household contact. - Mod.MPP. Classified as a secondary healthcare\nacquired infection in a healthcare worker. - Mod.MPP 4- A 27-year-old expat female, healthcare worker from Dawmat Aljandal\nAl Jawd region with no history of co-morbidities. reported as a\nnewly confirmed case on 8 Aug 2017 at which time she was noted to be\nin stable condition having been identified as an asymptomatic contact\nof a previously confirmed case. Classified as a secondary healthcare\nacquired infection in a healthcare worker. - Mod.MPP 5- A 49-year-old expat male, healthcare worker from Dawmat Aljandal\nAl Jawd region with no history of co-morbidities. reported as a\nnewly confirmed case on 8 Aug 2017 at which time he was noted to be\nin stable condition having been identified as an asymptomatic contact\nof a previously confirmed case. Classified as a secondary healthcare\nacquired infection in a healthcare worker. - Mod.MPP. Date: 20 Aug 2017 (1 recovery)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-08-20-001.aspx) 6- A 44-year-old expat female, non-healthcare worker from Jeddah\nMakkah region with a history of pre-existing co-morbidities.\nreported as a newly confirmed case on 4 Aug 2017 at which time she\nwas noted to be in stable condition. Classified as a secondary case in\na household contact. Note that there was a recovery reported in a\n44-year-old expat female on 15 Aug 2017, suggesting either this is a\nduplicate report or there was a 2nd 44 year old expat female from\nJeddah reported that did not appear on the newly confirmed case\nreports on the Saudi MOH website. - Mod.MPP \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) In the 11 day period since the last update, there have been 7 newly\nconfirmed cases reported of whom 5 were from Dawmat Aljandal (Al Jawf\nregion), the location that had nosocomial transmission identified\nsince the beginning of this past month July 2017. Clearly\ntransmission is continuing in this area, with 3 newly confirmed\nsecondary cases in household contacts - at least 2 of whom were\nidentified through screening of asymptomatic household contacts, and 2\nadditional cases in which high risk exposures are still under\ninvestigation. We do not know if these household contacts are\nassociated with the earlier identified transmission chain in Dawmat\nAljandal or if these are newly identified chains of transmission. The\nother 2 newly confirmed cases involve \"sporadic\" cases - an individual\nin Hail whose high risk exposure history is still under investigation,\nand an individual from Alaflaj (Riyadh region) with a history of\ndirect contact with camels in the 14 days preceding onset of illness. As to be expected, concern is being voiced on the international level\nwith the upcoming Hajj and this recent increase in cases reported both\nin Saudi Arabia and in the UAE. We now have gone through 5 Hajj\nperiods since the identification of the MERS-CoV and to date there\nhave been no cases of MERS-CoV infection identified in returning\nHajjis. The case in the UAE (see section <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> above) actually had onset\nof illness over 1 month ago with no secondary cases/infections\nidentified among known contacts of this case. As for the cases in\nSaudi Arabia, and more specifically the Hajj, population movement is\nvery well defined during the Hajj, no camels are permitted in the\nareas where Hajjis are congregated, and there are Hajj specific health\nservices that are separate from those that are available for the\ngeneral Saudi population, all factors that are reducing the likelihood\nof Hajjis having inadvertent (or intentional) high risk exposures.\nHopefully my optimism is well placed and we will pass through a 6th\nHajj period without impact on international transmission of the\nMERS-CoV associated with this Hajj. Maps of Saudi Arabia showing the locations of the reported cases,\nfatality and recoveries can be found at the given URL's. The\nHealthMap/ProMED map of Saudi Arabia can be found at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/131). - Mod.MPP ","keywordsMatched":[]},"178":{"title":"MERS-CoV (57): Saudi Arabia (HA, JF) ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> MERS-CoV (57): Saudi Arabia (HA, JF) [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nMERS-COV (57): SAUDI ARABIA (HAIL, AL JAWF)\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Sat 2 Sep 2017.\nSource: Saudi MOH 30 Aug 2017 - 2 Sep 2017 (edited)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/default.aspx?PageIndex=1) \nAs of Sat 2 Sep 2017, there have been a total of:\n1712 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection, including\n690 deaths reported case fatality rate 40.3 percent,\n1001 recoveries, and\n21 currently active cases/infections. As previously mentioned, the numbers of deaths, recoveries, and\ncurrently active cases come from my spreadsheet tallies and differ\nfrom those listed on the Saudi MOH website; my spreadsheet counts\nasymptomatic infections. One complication is the reporting of cases as\neither recoveries or deaths that cannot be confirmed as previously\nreported newly confirmed cases. - Mod.MPP Since the last ProMED-mail update Tue 29 Aug 2017, there have been a\ntotal of:\n4 newly confirmed cases\n2 newly reported fatalities, and\n4 newly reported recoveries. Information on newly reported cases (4 cases):.\nDate: 2 Sep 2017 (1 case)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-09-02-001.aspx) 1 - A 57-year-old Saudi male, non-healthcare worker from Hail Hail\nregion noted to be in critical condition. Classified as a primary\ncase with a history of indirect contact with camels in the 14 days\npreceding onset of illness. Date: 1 Sep 2017 (1 case)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-09-01-001.aspx) 2 - A 21-year-old Saudi female, non-healthcare worker from Dawmat\nAljandal Al Jawf region noted to be in stable condition, having been\nidentified as an asymptomatic contact of a previously confirmed case.\nClassified as a secondary case in a household contact. Date: 30 Aug 2017 (2 cases)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-08-30-001.aspx) 3 - A 22-year-old Saudi female, non-healthcare worker from Dawmat\nAljandal Al Jawf region noted to be in stable condition, having been\nidentified as an asymptomatic contact of a previously confirmed case.\nClassified as a secondary case in a household contact. 4- An 18-year-old Saudi female, non-healthcare worker from Dawmat\nAljandal Al Jawf region noted to be in stable condition, having been\nidentified as an asymptomatic contact of a previously confirmed case.\nClassified as a secondary case in a household contact. Information on newly reported fatality (2 fatalities).\nDate: 1 Sep 2017\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-09-01-001.aspx) 1 - A 36-year-old Saudi male, non-healthcare worker from Buraidah Al\nQaṣīm region with no history of co-morbidities reported as a\nnewly confirmed case on 27 Jul 2017 noted to be in critical\ncondition. Classified as a primary case with a history of direct\ncontact with camels in the 14 days preceding onset of illness. -\nMod.MPP. Date: 31 Aug 2017\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-08-31-001.aspx) 2 - A 69-year-old expat male, non-healthcare worker from Jeddah\nMakkah region with a history of pre-existing co-morbidities\nreported as a newly confirmed case on Wed 16 Aug 2017 at which time\nhe was noted to be in critical condition. Classification still under\nreview at the time of initial report. - Mod.MPP Information on newly reported recoveries (4 recoveries).\nDate: 1 Sep 2017 (2 recoveries)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-09-01-001.aspx) 1 - A 10-year-old Saudi female, non-healthcare worker from Dawmat\nAljandal Al Jawd region with no history of co-morbidities. reported\nas a newly confirmed case on Sun 26 Aug 2017 at which time she was\nnoted to be in stable condition, having been identified as an\nasymptomatic contact of a previously confirmed case. Classified as a\nsecondary case in a household contact. - Mod.MPP 2 - A 50-year-old Saudi male, non-healthcare worker from Dawmat\nAljandal Al Jawd region with a history of pre-existing\nco-morbidities. reported as a newly confirmed case on Sun 26 Aug\n2017 at which time he was noted to be in stable condition. Classified\nas a secondary infection in a household contact. - Mod.MPP. Date: 31 Aug 2017 (2 recoveries)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-08-31-001.aspx) 3 - A 30-year-old Saudi female, non-healthcare worker from Dammam Ash\nSharqīyah region with a history of pre-existing co-morbidities.\nreported as a newly confirmed case on Sun 25 Jun 2017 at which time\nshe was noted to be in critical condition. Classified as a primary\ncase with a history of indirect contact with camels in the 14 days\npreceding onset of symptoms. - Mod.MPP 4 - A 46-year-old Saudi male, non-healthcare worker from Hail Hail\nregion with a history of pre-existing co-morbidities. reported as a\nnewly confirmed case on Thu 24 Aug 2017 at which time he was noted\nto be in critical condition. Classification was still under review at\nthe time of initial confirmation report. - Mod.MPP \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) In the past 4 days since the last update Tue 29 Aug 2017 there have\nbeen 4 newly confirmed cases - 3 of whom were asymptomatic secondary\nhousehold contacts of a previously confirmed case in Dawmat Aljandal\n(Al Jawf region), and the 4th, a primary case in Hail (Hail region)\nwith a history of indirect contact with camels. Since Sun 26 Aug\n2017 there have been 6 laboratory confirmed cases of MERS-CoV\ninfection in household contacts of a previously confirmed case in\nDawmat Aljandal (Al Jawf region), perhaps related to the \"primary\"\ncase reported on Thu 24 Aug 2017, presumably not related to the\nearlier healthcare associated outbreak in the same town earlier in\nAugust, but specific details on these cases have not been available. In the month of August 2017, there were a total of 33 laboratory\nconfirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection, 8 fatalities and 11 recoveries\nreported by the Saudi MOH. 20 of the 33 newly confirmed cases were\nfrom Dawmat Aljandal (Al Jawf region), of whom 13 were asymptomatic\ncontacts (6 of whom were household contacts and 7 were healthcare\nacquired infections). The 13 additional cases reported outside of Dawmat Aljandal involved\nindividuals from Makkah region (Jeddah, 4 cases, one of whom was a\nhousehold contact), Riyadh region (Aldelem one case, Alaflaj one\ncase), Hail region (Hail 2 cases), Al Madinah region (Al Ula one case,\nMadinah one case), Najran region (Najran one case), `Asīr region\n(Khamis Mushayet one case) and Al Bāhah region (Beljershi Albaha one\ncase). Maps of Saudi Arabia showing the locations of the cases, fatalities\nand recoveries reported in this update can be found at the source URL.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED map of Saudi Arabia can be found at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/131). - Mod.MPP ","keywordsMatched":[]},"328":{"title":"MERS-CoV (58): Saudi Arabia (RI, SH), WHO","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> MERS-CoV (58): Saudi Arabia (RI, SH), WHO","summary":"\nMERS-COV (58): SAUDI ARABIA (RIYADH, ASH SHARQIYAH), WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Saudi Arabia, 3 new cases - Saudi MOH, 3-7 Sep 2017\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Saudi Arabia WHO update 6 Sep 2017 \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Saudi Arabia, 3 new cases - Saudi MOH, 3-7 Sep 2017.\nDate: Thu 7 Sep 2017.\nSource: Saudi MOH 3 - 7 Sep 2017 (edited)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/default.aspx?PageIndex=1) \nAs of Thu 7 Sep 2017, there have been a total of:\n1715 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS-CoV infection, including\n690 deaths reported case fatality rate 40.2 percent,\n1003 recoveries, and\n22 currently active cases/infections. As previously mentioned, the numbers of deaths, recoveries, and\ncurrently active cases come from my spreadsheet tallies and differ\nfrom those listed on the Saudi MOH website; my spreadsheet counts\nasymptomatic infections. One complication is the reporting of cases as\neither recoveries or deaths that cannot be confirmed as previously\nreported newly confirmed cases. - Mod.MPP Since the last ProMED-mail update Sat 2 Sep 2017, there have been a\ntotal of:\n3 newly confirmed cases\n0 newly reported fatalities, and\n2 newly reported recoveries. Information on newly reported cases (3 cases):.\nDate: 7 Sep 2017 (1 case)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-09-07-001.aspx) 1 - A 48-year-old expat male, non-healthcare worker from Riyadh\nRiyadh region noted to be in critical condition. Classified as a\nprimary case with high risk exposure history still under\ninvestigation. Date: 6 Sep 2017 (1 case)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-09-06-001.aspx) 2 - A 78-year-old Saudi male, non-healthcare worker from Riyadh\nRiyadh region noted to be in stable condition. Classified as a\nprimary case with a history of direct contact with camels in the 14\ndays preceding onset of illness. Date: 5 Sep 2017 (1 case)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-09-05-001.aspx) 3 - A 37-year-old Saudi male, non-healthcare worker from Hufoof Ash\nSharqīyah region noted to be in critical condition. Classified as a\nprimary case with high risk exposure history still under\ninvestigation. Information on newly reported recoveries (2 recoveries).\nDate: 6 Sep 2017 (2 recoveries)\n(http://www.moh.gov.sa/en/CCC/PressReleases/Pages/statistics-2017-09-06-001.aspx) 1 - A 21-year-old Saudi female, non-healthcare worker from Dawmat\nAljandal Al Jawd region with no history of co-morbidities. reported\nas a newly confirmed case on 1 Sep 2017 at which time she was noted\nto be in stable condition, having been identified as an asymptomatic\ncontact of a previously confirmed case. Classified as a secondary case\nin a household contact. - Mod.MPP 2 - A 48-year-old Saudi male, non-healthcare worker from Alaflaj\nRiyadh region with a history of pre-existing co-morbidities.\nreported as a newly confirmed case on 21 Aug 2017 at which time he\nwas noted to be in stable condition. Classified as a primary case with\na history of direct contact with camels in the 14 days preceding onset\nof illness. - Mod.MPP \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) From the above summary report from Saudi Arabia, with the absence of\nnew cases reported from Dawmat Aljandal (Al Jawf region), the\nepidemiologic picture has returned to sporadic cases reported, with a\nmix of history of contact with camels in the 14 days preceding onset\nof illness, and those where high risk exposure histories have not been\nfully investigated by the time of the report of the case. Maps showing the geographic location of all reports mentioned above\ncan be found at the source URLs. - Mod.MPP \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Saudi Arabia WHO update 6 Sep 2017.\nDate: 6 Sep 2017.\nSource: WHO, Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News\n(edited)\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/6-september-2017-mers-saudi-arabia/en/) \nMiddle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) - Saudi Arabia\n6 Sep 2017 Between 13 and 30 Aug 2017, the National IHR Focal Point of Saudi\nArabia reported 12 additional cases of Middle East respiratory\nsyndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV), including one death and, and one\ndeath from a previously reported case. Details of the cases\nMERS-CoV cases reported between 15 Aug 2017 and 30 Aug 2017 * Data subject to change due to ongoing investigations. Fields related\nto the final status of the case are updated as information is\navailable. \nNA = Not available \nCase no. / Date of notification to WHO (yyyy/mm/dd) / City of\nresidence / Age / Sex / Health care worker / Comorbidities / Exposure\nto camels / Camel milk consumption / Exposure to MERS-CoV cases / Date\nof symptoms onset (yyyy/mm/dd) / Date of 1st hospitalization\n(yyyy/mm/dd) / Date of laboratory confirmation (yyyy/mm/dd) / Status /\nDate of outcome (yyyy/mm/dd) 1 / 2017-08-15 / Madinah / 67 / M / No / Yes / Yes / NA / No /\n2017-08-12 / 2017-08-14 / 2017-08-14 / Deceased / 8/27/2017\n2 / 2017-08-16 / Jeddah / 69 / M / No / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\n2017-08-13 / 2017-08-15 / 2017-08-15 / Alive\n3 / 2017-08-18 / Jeddah / 51 / M / No / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\n2017-08-11 / 2017-08-17 / 2017-08-17 / Alive\n4 / 2017-08-21 / Riyadh / 48 / M / No / Yes / Yes / Yes / NA /\n2017-08-18 / 2017-08-20 / 2017-08-20 / Alive\n5 / 2017-08-24 / Dawmet Aljandal / 40 / F / No / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\n2017-08-17 / 2017-08-21 / 2017-08-22 / Alive\n6 / 2017-08-24 / Hail / 46 / M / No / No / Yes / NA / NA / 2017-08-21\n/ 2017-08-23 / 2017-08-24 / Alive\n7 / 2017-08-26 / Dawmet Aljandal / 10 / F / No / NR / NA / NA / Yes†\n/ NA / NA / 2017-08-26 / Alive\n8 / 2017-08-26 / Dawmet Aljandal / 14 / F / No / NR / NA / NA / Yes†\n/ NA / NA / 2017-08-26 / Alive\n9 / 2017-08-26 / Dawmet Aljandal / 50 / M / No / Yes / NA / NA /\nYes† / 2017-08-24 / 2017-08-25 / 2017-08-26 / Alive\n10 / 2017-08-27 / Dawmet Aljandal / 33 / F / No / Yes / NA / NA / NA /\n2017-08-23 / 2017-08-24 / 2017-08-26 / Alive\n11 / 2017-08-30 / Dawmet Aljandal / 22 / F / No / NR / NA / NA /\nYes† / NA / NA / 2017-08-29 / Alive\n12 / 2017-08-30 / Dawmet Aljandal / 18 / F / No / NR / NA / NA /\nYes† / NA / NA / 2017-08-29 / Alive †Case was detected through contact tracing of a previous MERS-CoV\ncase.\nHospitalized for other unrelated condition prior to symptom onset. Among the 12 newly reported cases, 6 were associated with a MERS\ncluster in Dawmet Aljandal City Al Jawf region, Saudi Arabia. This\ncluster is not linked to the cluster of MERS that was previously\nreported in Al Jawf in the Disease Outbreak News posted on Thu 17 Aug\n2017. In this new cluster, the 6 cases are among 17 household\ncontacts who were being followed up by the Saudi Arabian Ministry of\nHealth. Globally, 2079 laboratory-confirmed cases with MERS-CoV, including at\nleast 722 related deaths have been reported to WHO. Public health response\nThe source of infection of this cluster is under investigation by the\nMinistry of Health and Ministry of Agriculture in Saudi Arabia. The\nSaudi Arabian Ministry of Health has identified and is following up\nhealth care workers and household contacts of known MERS patients. As\nper Saudi Arabian policy, listed contacts are not allowed to attend\nHajj. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp As per the above update, there have now been 2079 laboratory\nconfirmed cases/infection with MERS-CoV reported to the WHO including\nat least 722 related deaths (reported case fatality rate: 34.7\npercent). Additional outcome information available for some of the above\nmentioned cases includes: case No.2 reported as a fatality on Thu 31\nAug 2017, and cases Nos. 4, 6, 7 and 9 were reported as recoveries on\n6 Sep 2017, 31 Aug 2017, 1 Sep 2017 and 1 Sep 2017 respectively. The above report also confirms a 2nd cluster of cases in Dawmat\nAljandal (Al Jawf region) all associated with household contacts. It\ndoes appear that since Saudi Arabia changed its contact\ntracing/testing policy to include all individuals with known contact\nwith a laboratory confirmed case of MERS-CoV infection,, irrespective\nof clinical status/illness (including asymptomatic individuals) there\nhave been more and larger clusters of cases identified. So, either\nthe virus is changing and now producing more asymptomatic infections,\nor, there have always been many more asymptomatic infections that were\nmissed because they did not meet the clinical criteria for testing.\n(seek and you shall find). The HealthMap/ProMED map of Saudi Arabia can be found at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/131). - Mod.MPP ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Senegal":{"45":{"title":"Zika virus (16): Americas, Asia, research,\r\n\tobservations ","date":["17","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Zika virus (16): Americas, Asia, research,\r\n\tobservations [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nZIKA VIRUS (16): AMERICAS, ASIA, RESEARCH, OBSERVATIONS\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries:\nWHO tool kit for the care and support of people affected by\ncomplications associated with Zika virus \nAmericas\n\nAmericas cumulative case numbers\nCaribbean and South America Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers.
