Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]},"312":{"title":"PRO/EDR> Influenza (19): WHO global update","date":["20","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Influenza (19): WHO global update","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: 4 Sep 2017. Source: WHO Surveillance and monitoring, influenza updates (edited) (http://www.who.int/influenza/surveillance_monitoring/updates/latest_update_GIP_surveillance/en/)   Update number 297 (based on data up to 20 Aug 2017)  Summary \n- In the temperate zone of the southern hemisphere and in some countries of South and South East Asia, high levels of influenza activity continued to be reported. In Central America and the Caribbean, influenza activity continued to be reported in a few countries. Influenza activity remained at low levels in the temperate zone of the northern hemisphere. Worldwide, influenza A(H3N2) viruses are predominating.  In temperate South America, respiratory illness indicators and influenza activity decreased in most of the sub-region, with influenza A(H3N2) viruses predominating.  In Southern Africa, influenza activity appeared to have plateaued in South Africa, with influenza A(H3N2) viruses predominantly detected.  In Oceania, seasonal influenza activity continued to increase, with influenza A(H3N2) and B viruses present in the region.  In tropical South America, influenza and other respiratory virus activity remained low.  In the Caribbean and Central American countries, respiratory illness indicators and influenza activity remained low in general, but respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) activity was increasing.  In Southern Asia, increased influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus detections were reported in India. Severe acute respiratory infection (SARI) and influenza like illness (ILI) indicators remained high in Bhutan.  In South East Asia, increased influenza activity was reported in recent weeks, with all seasonal influenza subtypes present in the region.  In East and Western Asia, influenza activity remained low in general.  In Western Africa, influenza activity continued to be reported, with all seasonal influenza subtypes present in the region. Few influenza detections were reported in Eastern Africa.  In Northern Africa, no influenza virus detections were reported.  In Central Asia, there were no updated reports on virus detections or respiratory illness indicators.  In Europe and North America, little to no influenza activity was reported.  National Influenza Centres (NICs) and other national influenza laboratories from 64 countries, areas or territories reported data to FluNet for the period from 7-20 Aug 2017 (data as of 2017-09-01 04:28:36 UTC). The WHO GISRS laboratories tested more than 48522 specimens during that period. 7438 were positive for influenza viruses, of which 6637 (89.2 percent) were typed as influenza A and 801 (10.8 percent) as influenza B. Of the sub-typed influenza A viruses, 746 (14 percent) were influenza A(H1N1)pdm09, and 4586 (86 percent) were influenza A(H3N2). Of the characterized B viruses, 99 (53.8 percent) belonged to the B-Yamagata lineage and 85 (46.2 percent) to the B-Victoria lineage.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. Rapporteur Marianne Hopp  The southern hemisphere continues to report high influenza activity, while most of northern hemisphere except some parts of south Asia (India, Bhutan) have reported little or no activity thus far, which is a fairly consistent pattern. Influenza A/H3N2 viruses have been predominant globally. However, there have been recent reports of high numbers of cases and deaths associated with influenza A/H1N1pdm09 from various states of India ProMED SoAs posts: Influenza (63): India, H1N1, update http://promedmail.org/post/20170904.5293172; Influenza (62): India (Rajasthan) H1N1, increased incidence, fatal http://promedmail.org/post/20170901.5289510, which require detailed investigation, particularly with reference to any new mutations in the virus that may render it a mismatch to the vaccine strain. - Mod.UBA  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"South Korea":{"77":{"title":"Typhoid fever - South Korea: (HN) ex India,\r\n\tstudent ","date":["21","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Typhoid fever - South Korea: (HN) ex India,\r\n\tstudent [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Korea Times (edited) (http://m.koreatimes.co.kr/phone/news/view.jsp?req_newsidx=235072)   5 Korean students who visited India have been stricken with typhoid fever. The students are from Sangmyung University's Cheonan Campus in South Chungcheong Province, according to the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Mon 21 Aug 2017. They had visited India's northern region, including the cities of Agra and New Delhi, with 18 other students and 2 instructors as part of the school's overseas education program from 19 to 27 Jul 2017.  After they returned, 7 sought medical attention for fever, chills, and diarrhea. 4 were diagnosed with typhoid. In a follow-up check, another student was diagnosed with the disease. 4 of the 5 students remain in a hospital. One student was released on Fri 18 Aug 2017.  Of 225 Koreans who caught typhoid fever abroad between 2011-2016, 23 per cent had visited India. The health authority has advised that people planning to visit India should be vaccinated against the waterborne disease, which is also infectious through food.  Health officials also said that people who experience fever, chills, and diarrhea within 60 days  the disease's maximum latency period  after returning from India must report to a hospital to be checked for the disease.  byline: Ko Dong-hwan   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Typhoid fever, so-called enteric fever caused by _Salmonella enterica_ serotype Typhi, often has a totally different presentation from that of the commoner kinds of salmonellosis. Epidemiologically, usually spread by contaminated food or water, typhoid is not a zoonosis like the commoner types of salmonellosis. Clinically, vomiting and diarrhea are typically absent; indeed, constipation is frequently reported. As it is a systemic illness, blood cultures are at least as likely to be positive as stool in enteric fever, particularly early in the course of the infection, and bone marrow cultures may be the most sensitive.  The symptoms of classical typhoid fever typically include fever, anorexia, lethargy, malaise, dull continuous headache, non-productive cough, vague abdominal pain, and constipation. Despite the often high fever, the pulse is often only slightly elevated. During the 2nd week of the illness, there is protracted fever and mental dullness, classically called coma vigil. Diarrhea may develop but usually does not. Many patients develop hepatosplenomegaly both liver and spleen enlarged. After the 1st week or so, many cases develop a maculopapular rash on the upper abdomen. These lesions (\"rose spots\") are about 2 cm 0.78 in in diameter and blanch on pressure. They persist for 2-4 days and may come and go. Mild and atypical infections are common.  The word typhoid (as in typhus-like) reflects the similarity of the louseborne rickettsial disease epidemic typhus and that of typhoid fever; in fact, in some areas, typhoid fever is still referred to as abdominal typhus.  Maps of South Korea can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/jvukf5u) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/15392 ). South Chungcheong province, officially Chungcheongnam-do; abbreviated Chungnam), is a province in the west of South Korea. - Mod.LL  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"114":{"title":"Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t","date":["26","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (43): Asia and Pacific, Europe, demographics\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy  Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15 <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania  Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics   Asia and Pacific  <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Japan: travel alert. Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: The Mainichi (edited) (https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20170821/p2g/00m/0dm/077000c)   Japan's health ministry has issued a warning for people traveling to Europe on the back of an outbreak of measles in countries such as Italy and Romania. The Ministry of Health, Labor and Welfare is advising tourists to go to hospital if they develop a high fever or generalized rash after returning to Japan.  Although the World Health Organization verified that Japan has eliminated infections of endemic measles strains in 2015, group infections originating from people who contracted the disease abroad are spreading in the country. As of 6 Aug 2017, the number of patients reached 169 this year in Japan, already eclipsing the figure in the previous year.  About 4100 patients in Italy and around 6500 patients in Romania have already been confirmed as of August 2017 compared with about 860 and 2000, respectively, throughout 2016, according to the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control.  Symptoms of the highly contagious disease include runny nose, red and watery eyes, high fever, and rash. The virus is spread through coughing and sneezing and can cause complications such as pneumonia and can even result in death in one in 1000 patients, according to the ministry. The ministry recommends people traveling overseas to check their vaccination records and take an additional shot if they have only been vaccinated once.  The disease was prevalent about a decade ago in Japan with the number of patients soaring to over 10 000 in 2008 but the country was later considered as free from infections of the virus.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Japan can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/156). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia): ex Italy. Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017 5:36 PM AEST. Source: News.com.au, Australian Associated Press (AAP) report (edited) (http://www.news.com.au/national/breaking-news/fourth-case-of-measles-at-perth-school/news-story/ece041f55111645e10f70046d92479dd)   A 4th child has been diagnosed with measles at Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, more than a week after the health department gave an on-site vaccine to students. A Health Department spokeswoman confirmed the latest case, which came 3 weeks after the highly contagious disease was first detected in an unvaccinated year 10 student who had returned from Italy.  Revelations that about half the school's 400 students were unvaccinated against the disease led the Health Department to offer a voluntary, free on-site vaccine to students, but it is unknown how many took up the offer.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Maps of Australia can be seen at (http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK   Europe  <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Germany (Berlin): 2014-15. Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017. Source: Eurosurveillance edition 2017; 22(34) (edited) (http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=22861)   ref: Werber D, Hoffmann A, Santibanez S, et al. Large measles outbreak introduced by asylum seekers and spread among the insufficiently vaccinated resident population, Berlin, October 2014 to August 2015. Euro Surveill. 2017; 22(34): pii=30599 - Abstract  The largest measles outbreak in Berlin since 2001 occurred from October 2014 to August 2015. Overall, 1344 cases were ascertained, 86 per cent (with available information) unvaccinated, including 146 (12 per cent) asylum seekers. Median age was 17 years (interquartile range: 4-29 years), 26 per cent were hospitalised and a 1 year old child died. Measles virus genotyping uniformly revealed the variant 'D8-Rostov-Don' and descendants. The virus was likely introduced by and initially spread among asylum seekers before affecting Berlin's resident population. Among Berlin residents, the highest incidence was in children younger than 2 years, yet most cases (52 per cent) were adults. Post-exposure vaccinations in homes for asylum seekers, not always conducted, occurred later (median: 7.5 days) than the recommended 72 hours after onset of the 1st case and reached only half of potential contacts. Asylum seekers should not only have non-discriminatory, equitable access to vaccination, they also need to be offered measles vaccination in a timely fashion, that is, immediately upon arrival in the receiving country. Supplementary immunisation activities targeting the resident population, particularly adults, are urgently needed in Berlin.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Germany can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/5857). - Mod.LK   <br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Romania. Date: Fri 25 August 2017. Source: Romania Insider (edited) (https://www.romania-insider.com/measles-kills-iraqi-refugee/)   The ongoing measles outbreak keeps making victims in Romania. A 10 month old girl, who was a refugee from Iraq, became the 33rd person to die of the infection, reports local Digi24. The girl arrived in Romania on 7 Jul 2017 with her family, and the doctors diagnosed her with measles in August. They also discovered that the child was suffering from malnutrition and severe psychomotor retardation.  The measles outbreak is still a major problem in Romania, with more than 8900 cases reported across the country until 25 Aug 2017, including 33 deaths, according to data from the National Center for Surveillance and Control of Communicable Diseases (CNSCBT). Most deaths were registered in Timis (9), Dolj (7), and Arad (6) counties.  Measles is a highly contagious respiratory infection caused by a virus. It causes a total-body skin rash and flu-like symptoms, including fever, cough, and runny nose. According to information posted on WHO's website, the virus is highly contagious, spreading by coughing and sneezing, close personal contact, and direct contact with infected nasal or throat secretions. Unvaccinated young children pose the highest risk of measles and its complications, including death.  The Romanian Government adopted earlier this month August 2017 a draft bill on the organization and financing of population vaccination (https://www.romania-insider.com/romania-draft-bill-vaccination/). The project was sent to the Parliament for approval and could come into force in January 2018.  byline: Irina Marica   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Measles tends to be more severe in children who are malnourished, especially children who are also vitamin A deficient. And complications are commoner and more serious in malnourished children. Because of complications such as diarrhoea, measles may lead to failure to thrive. Infection with measles virus may lead to kwashiorkor or marasmus in children who are underweight at the time that they get infected. Therefore, measles may result in, or aggravate, malnutrition.  Maps of Romania can be found at (http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK   Measles immunity gaps  <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Role of demographics. Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017. Source: News-Medical/Life Sciences (edited) (https://www.news-medical.net/news/20170826/New-study-highlights-role-played-by-demographics-in-the-spread-of-measles.aspx)   Even if the incidence of measles infection has decreased by at least 90 per cent worldwide since the introduction of the vaccine, measles is still one of the major causes of death in children among vaccine-preventable diseases. Regular measles epidemics are reported in developing countries and recurrent episodic outbreaks occur in the developed world.  A new study by Bocconi University and Bruno Kessler Foundation analyzing 9 countries (Australia, Ethiopia, Kenya, Ireland, Italy, South Korea, Singapore, the United Kingdom, and the United States) and published in The Lancet Infectious Diseases see reference below, highlights the role played by demographics in the spread of measles and concludes that future vaccination strategies in high-fertility countries should focus on increasing childhood immunization rates, while immunization campaigns targeting adolescents and young adults are required in low fertility countries.  Using a transmission model calibrated on historical serological data the authors estimate that the susceptible proportion of the population (that is, unprotected against the infection) varies from about 3 per cent in the UK to more than 12.5 per cent in Ethiopia, with astonishing differences in its age composition, due to different vaccination strategies and divergent demographic trends. While the percentage of over-15 among susceptible individuals in Ethiopia and Kenya is, respectively, 28 per cent and 43 per cent, adolescents and young adults represent 74 per cent of unprotected individuals in South Korea, 66 per cent in Italy and 53 per cent in the US, with considerable immunity gaps in individuals aged 30-40 years.  \"Every effort to increase the vaccination coverage rate among children is praiseworthy\", says Alessia Melegaro, a Bocconi professor and principal investigator of DECIDE, the ERC European Research Council-funded project which produced the article, \"but in some developed countries it's the lack of coverage among adolescents and adults that poses a serious threat to the goal of eliminating measles.\"  \"Measles incidence could increase, in the next decades, in Italy, Australia, and Singapore and Ethiopia is at high risk of future large epidemics\", says Stefano Merler from Bruno Kessler Foundation, \"and this is particularly worrying considering that individuals get infected later in life when the disease is more severe. The median age at infection for 2015 was estimated to be 5-10 years in the UK, Ireland, and Ethiopia; 10-15 years in the USA, Australia, Singapore, and Kenya; and older than 20 years in Italy and South Korea\".  The proposed model shows that the introduction of the measles vaccine, which occurred at different times in the 9 countries, has considerably reduced the disease burden in terms of disability-adjusted life-years (DALYs), a measure expressed as the number of years lost because of illness, disability, or early death. Every vaccine dose averts 2 or 3 weeks of DALYs in the developed world and around 20 weeks in Kenya and Ethiopia. Which translates into 2-mln years 2 million DALYs since the vaccine introduction in the UK, 13-mln 13 million DALYs in the US, and 36-mln 36 million DALYs in Ethiopia.  \"Vaccination has undoubtedly achieved incredible results in terms of public health. In particular,\" continues Prof Melegaro \"our analysis showed that routine 1st dose vaccine administration has been responsible for more than 90 per cent of the overall number of vaccine-immunized individuals in most countries. In Ethiopia and Kenya, catch-up and follow-up campaigns substantially mitigated the effect of suboptimum routine vaccine coverage, generating 25-45 per cent of the immunized fraction of the population. Tailoring immunization campaigns to achieve measles eradication goals is essential and currently, for some countries, this means considering also the role of unprotected adolescents and young adults.\"   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Reference - Trentini F, Poletti P, Merler S, Melegaro A. Measles immunity gaps and the progress towards elimination: a multi-country modelling analysis. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii: S1473-3099(17)30421-8. Epub ahead of print; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28807627).   While it is recommended that children get 2 doses of MMR (measles, mumps, rubella) vaccine, starting with the 1st dose at 12 through 15 months of age, and the 2nd dose at 4 through 6 years of age, this study emphasizes that it is important that adolescents and young adults also are up to date on their MMR vaccination. - Mod.LK  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"289":{"title":"Foodborne illness - South Korea: (NJ) fast food restaurant\r\n\tburger, poss EHEC, RFI ","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Foodborne illness - South Korea: (NJ) fast food restaurant\r\n\tburger, poss EHEC, RFI [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Mon 4 Sep 2017. Source: Korea JoongAng Daily (edited) (https://tinyurl.com/ya9hnp4n)   Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention is conducting an epidemiological investigation into a case of 7 children and 1 adult who showed symptoms of food poisoning with vomiting and diarrhea after eating McDonald's hamburgers on 25 Aug 2017 at a Jeonju branch in North Jeolla.  Authorities are not ruling out the possibility that the 8 individuals contracted hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS), widely known as \"hamburger disease,\" a bacterial infection that can leave the renal system severely damaged. Many cases are caused by _E. coli_, which can be found in undercooked meat like hamburgers. Children under the age of 5 are particularly vulnerable. On 25 Aug 2017, a group of 15 adults and elementary school students from the same church in Jeonju visited McDonald's Jeonju branch and ate bulgogi burgers together. A day later, 7 children and 1 adult experienced diarrhea and vomiting. The authorities declared an epidemiological probe into the case on Sat 2 Sep 2017.  As the case was publicized, McDonald's Korea halted selling bulgogi burgers nationwide starting on Sat 2 Sep 2017. On its website, a notice says, \"We have decided to stop selling bulgogi burgers pending the outcome of the ongoing investigation by authorities,\" adding that the multinational company's Korean branch was taking the issue seriously. It also said the company will do its best to help patients recover, though without elaborating on how or when.  The outcome of the ongoing probe is expected to be made public around Wed 6 Sep 2017.  The case in Jeonju is not the only incident that the corporation, which has 440 branches in Korea alone, has recently found itself in. In July 2017, the mother of a 5-year-old girl filed a complaint claiming irreparable harm was done to her child because of the fast food chain's mismanagement of its food products. The mother, claimed her daughter contracted HUS after eating a Happy Meal in September 2016, and she now must undergo peritoneal dialysis on a daily basis.  McDonald's Korea branch also received a complaint from the parents of a 2-year-old girl, who began to have diarrhea and bloody excrement after eating a hamburger patty on 17 May 2017 at a Jamsil branch in southern Seoul. On 19 May 2017, the child was admitted to a local emergency room. The child's condition improved and she was discharged later that day.  Byline: Kang Jin-kyu   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Whether this cluster of illnesses is caused by enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ is unknown as yet and ProMED would appreciate more information about the illnesses. A one day incubation period is short for EHEC but the outbreak is occurring in the wake of several cases of EHEC linked to the chain in South Korea.  Classic bulgogi recipes use a marinade of soy, ginger, garlic, and gochujang (Korean chili paste) to flavor and tenderize strips of meat. Because combining a marinade into ground beef would change the consistency of the hamburger, making it more of a \"sloppy-joe\", usually a bulgogi inspired sauce is used on top of the burger although a Korean inspired spice combination can be added to the ground beef.  North Jeolla province or Jeollabuk-do is a province in the southwest of South Korea and can be found on a map at (http://tinyurl.com/jvukf5u). A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21702). - Mod.LL  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"302":{"title":"Foodborne illness - South Korea (02): (NJ) fast food\r\n\trestaurant burger, poss EHEC","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Foodborne illness - South Korea (02): (NJ) fast food\r\n\trestaurant burger, poss EHEC","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 5 Sep 2017. From: Sangwoo Tak (edited)   re: ProMED-mail Foodborne illness - South Korea: (NJ) fast food restaurant burger, poss EHEC, RFI http://promedmail.org/post/20170905.5296852 - It is confirmed that there was a foodborne illness outbreak attributed to consumption of hamburger at a fast food restaurant in Jeonju, Korea on 25 Aug 2017. The suspected pathogen is not norovirus but _E. coli_. There has been no report of norovirus related outbreak or cases in the past few months in Korea.   EpiCore Global Surveillance Project Member Sangwoo Tak Korea University  ProMED-mail thanks EpiCore Global Surveillance Project member Sangwoo Tak for this information. _E. coli_, and presumptively EHEC, appears to be the pathogen in these cases. - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21702).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"South Sudan":{"31":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (86): Africa,\r\n\tAsia ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (86): Africa,\r\n\tAsia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (86): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR, West Africa\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Tanzania\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab Province) \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR, West Africa.\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: CAJ News Africa (edited)\n(http://cajnewsafrica.com/2017/08/18/hundreds-dead-in-raging-cholera-outbreak/) \nAt least 462 people have died in the conflict-torn Democratic Republic\nof Congo following a cholera outbreak sweeping through Central and\nWest Africa. The deaths from more than 16 539 cases reported so far in\n2017 represent 94 percent of the overall incidence in the regions of\nAfrica. This follows a major epidemic reported mainly in the North\nKivu province, which is the epicentre of the conflict between rebel\ngroups and the government. In the region, health delivery services have come to a standstill\nowing to the conflict. Civilians have been forced to flee their homes,\nadding to the tens of thousands already living in camps for internally\ndisplaced people. Meanwhile, In West Africa, similarly to 2016, several countries report\nsporadic cases. Terror-ridden Nigeria is also battling a severe\noutbreak of the water borne disease with 20 deaths recorded from 809\ncases in 2017. Liberia, a hotspot for diseases, is also affected with\n6 deaths from 129 cases. There have also been outbreaks in Cameroon,\nGhana and Ivory Cast but no casualties have been reported. Overall,\n488 deaths have been reported from 17 548 cases in the affected\nregions. The United Nations Children's Fund stressed the need for increasing\nvigilance and implementing preventative measures in the current\nat-risk seasonal period. \"This highlights the importance of regular\ninformation exchange within countries sharing the same epidemiological\nbasin.\" Byline: Jean Kassongo \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Tanzania.\nDate: Wed 16 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/united-republic-tanzania/taking-stock-lessons-learnt-cholera-outbreak-response-tanzania) \nTaking stock of lessons learnt from the Cholera outbreak response in\nTanzania\n\nThe United Republic of Tanzania is battling an outbreak of Cholera\nthat has since August 2015 affected 26 046 people and claimed 410\nlives. Ending the outbreak and preventing its spread beyond Tanzania's\nborders is a high priority for WHO. To that end, WHO and partners\nsupport a well-coordinated multisectoral response through the National\nCholera Task Force which plans, coordinates and support subnational\nauthorities. Indeed, learning requires a continuous assessment of performance, a\nreview of successes and failures and a robust support for improvement.\nAn After Action Review (AAR) is a simple methodology for facilitating\nthis assessment. It provides for a qualitative review of actions taken\nto respond to an emergency as a means of identifying best practices,\ngaps and lessons learned. As a component of the IHR Monitoring and\nEvaluation Framework (IHR MEF) and part of the preparedness and\nresponse cycle, an AAR seeks to identify what worked well or not and\nhow these practices can be maintained, improved, institutionalized and\nshared with relevant stakeholders. It is within this context that WHO\nsupported the Ministry of Health to convene a meeting of experts to\nconduct an After Action Review following the national response to the\ncholera outbreak. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/cholera-new-deaths-and-infections-across-sudan) \nSinga Hospital in Sudan's Sennar received 16 new cases of cholera\nduring the 1st half of this week week of Sun 13 Aug 2017. A woman\nhas died before she could be transferred to hospital, and 9 others\nwere infected with cholera at El Matateib in North Delta locality in\nSudan's Kassala state. Sennar State\nA medical source told Radio Dabanga that most of the cases in Sennar\ncame from Um Benin village southeast of the city except for 2 cases\nfrom El Dindir and El Souki. From Saturday to Monday 12-14 Aug 2017,\n26 cases of cholera arrived from Um Benin village. This led the local\nhealth authorities to open a new cholera isolation centre at the\nvillage. El Gedaref State\nEl Gedaref Hospital in East Sudan recorded 15 cases of cholera on\nTuesday and Wednesday 15-16 Aug 2017. A medical source told Radio\nDabanga that the hospital received 9 cases on Tue 15 Aug 2017, while\n6 cases were recorded on Wed 16Aug 2017. The medic said that all\ncases of cholera came from Uktuber, El Tadamon, El Geneina, and\nKadugli districts in El Gedaref. Kassala State\nA woman has died before she could be transferred to hospital, and 9\nothers were infected with cholera at El Matateib in North Delta\nlocality in Sudan's Kassala state. Youth activist Mohamed Seyidna told\nRadio Dabanga that \"the woman died in the village before she could be\ntransferred to the hospital\". He said that the hospitalised cases at\nWagar Hospital have risen to 9. He attributed the spread of cholera in the area to water pollution and\ncalled on the health authorities to make efforts to sterilize drinking\nwater and raise awareness of the residents. National epidemic\nThe National Epidemiological Corporation reported in early July 2017\nthat nearly 24 000 Sudanese have been infected and 940 cholera\npatients have died since the outbreak of the infectious disease in\nBlue Nile state in August 2016. The Sudanese authorities however,\nrefuse to call the disease by its name, and instead refer to it as\n\"Acute Watery Diarrhea\". The National Intelligence and Security\nService has repeatedly warned medics and the press in the country not\nto make mention of cholera. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab Province).\nDate: Wed 16 Aug 2017.\nSource: The News (edited)\n(https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/223756-Number-of-cholera-cases-continues-to-swell) \nThe number of cases of cholera, a highly contagious and fatal disease\nis continuously on the rise and there is a threat that spread of the\ninfection may take shape of an epidemic if proper preventive and\ncontrol measures are not taken well in time. The 1st 2 cases of\ncholera were tested positive by National Institute of Health Islamabad\non Mon 31 Jul 2017 and another 2 confirmed positive for the\ninfection on Fri 4 Aug 2017. All the 4 patients were undergoing\ntreatment at Benazir Bhutto Hospital BH where as many as 4 more\nsuspects of the infection have been admitted for treatment. Data collected by 'The News' on Mon 14 Aug 2017 reveals that the\nallied hospitals have sent stool samples of over 10 child patients to\nNIH for confirmation of cholera in last week week of Sun 6 Aug\n2017. On Sat 12 Aug 2017, as many as 20 child patients with severe\ndiarrhoea were admitted at the BBH of which 4 were suspected as\npatients of cholera and their stool samples were sent to NIH for\nconfirmation, said Associate Professor of Paediatrics at Rawalpindi\nMedical University Dr Tariq Saeed when contacted by 'The News' on Mon\n14 Aug 2017. He added the hospital has not received confirmation reports from the\nNIH because of holidays there from Saturday to Monday. However, we\nhave been keeping the suspects in isolation under strict monitoring,\nhe said. He added that repeated rainfalls in the region and water inundation\ninside and outside homes in a number of localities particularly in\nthickly populated areas of the city are causing contamination of water\nand foodstuff that increases chances of spread of a number of\ninfections among population while children are at greater risk of\ncontracting life-threatening infections including cholera. It is important that the transmission of cholera occurs primarily by\ndrinking water or eating food that has been contaminated by the feces\n(waste product) of an infected person, including one with no apparent\nsymptoms. It is observed that heavy rainfall causes collection of heavily\ncontaminated water in streets and houses and the waste water flooding\nout of various nullahs watercourses including Nullah Leh in town\ncauses infections including cholera, typhoid, dysentery,\ngastroenteritis, hepatitis A and E, shigellosis and giardiasis. Professor Tariq said the consumption of contaminated water and\nfoodstuff causes cholera, an infection in the small intestine caused\nby bacterium _Vibrio cholerae_. Its main symptoms are watery diarrhea\nand vomiting that can lead to rapid dehydration and electrolyte\nimbalance, and death in cases which are not treated in time, he said. Health experts say that to avoid cholera and other infections, one\nmust use boiled water for drinking and should use vegetables after\nwashing with clean water and it must be kept in mind that raw\nvegetables should not be eaten in the existing weather conditions\ninstead these should be used after cooking. To a query, Professor Tariq said the heavy rainfall and water\naccumulation may contaminate water at sources and there may be chances\nof contamination of water at tube wells so individuals must boil water\nbefore drinking to avoid cholera and other infections. He added the appearance of cholera is alarming and it is time for\npeople to take extra ordinary preventive measures to safeguard their\nchildren and themselves from the disease. In case water is accumulated inside home due to heavy rainfall and\nflooded out of sewage lines, it must be wiped out immediately and the\nspace should be washed with clean water as soon as possible to avoid\ninfections. Avoiding inundation of contaminated water inside homes is\na must to avoid cholera and other infections, said Professor Tariq. Byline: Muhammad Qasim \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-SoAs\n(promed-SoAs@promedmail.org) Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 percent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are: - Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 percent (95 percent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam; - Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n-\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. ","keywordsMatched":[]},"61":{"title":"Malaria - South Sudan ","date":["21","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Malaria - South Sudan [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017. Source: Sudan Tribune (edited) (http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article63300)   An outbreak of malaria in South Sudan has killed over 4000 people since February 2017, a senior health official disclosed last week week of Sun 13 Aug 2017. \"This year's malaria is the most severe the country has ever seen,\" Dr Isaac Mapeer, the deputy head of the Malaria Control Program at South Sudan's Ministry of Health, told Anadolu Agency on Thu 17 Aug 2017. A total of over 900 000 malaria cases had so far been registered, according to Mapeer. \"Up to 4073 deaths were recorded since February 2017, while 2000 deaths were reported in 2016\", he stressed.  Malaria is a life-threatening mosquitoborne blood disease caused by a plasmodium parasite, which is usually transmitted to humans through the bite of the anopheles mosquito. Once an infected mosquito bites a human, the parasites multiply in the host's liver before infecting and destroying red blood cells.  According to the senior health official, the country's Epidemic Task Force, headed by the Ministry of Health in partnership with United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) and other partners has also stepped up efforts to fight the disease.  The health official, however, decried the lack of funds to fight malaria and appealed for donations to help fight the disease. In July 2017, OCHA said more than 76 per cent of disease-related deaths in South Sudan are from malaria.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  According to the WHO 2016 World Malaria Report ((http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/252038/1/9789241511711-eng.pdf?ua=1)), malaria control in South Sudan was entirely dependent on foreign aid donations and the report stated that 60 per cent of the population sleeps under an impregnated bed net.  However, the civil war in the country probably means that malaria control activities and probably drug distribution have been impaired, which could be one explanation for the reported outbreak. - Mod.EP  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8402).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"75":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (88): Africa,\r\n\tAsia ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (88): Africa,\r\n\tAsia [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (88): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Malawi (Southern region)\n2,3 Cholera - Sudan\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR (Kwilu, South Kivu)\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - India (Punjab)\n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Diarrhea - Nepal (Kapilvastu district) \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Malawi (Southern region).\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Capital Radio Malawi summ., edited\n(https://www.capitalradiomalawi.com/index.php/blog/local-news/local-news/item/8352-chikwawa-hit-by-cholera-outbreak) \nA total of 9 people are admitted to Chikwawa district Southern\nregion hospital following a cholera outbreak. This comes barely 4\nmonths after another outbreak hit the district's 2 villages in the\narea of Paramount Chief Lundu, affecting 38 people. The Environmental\nHealth Office for Chikwawa district has confirmed the development,\nciting poor access to safe water and poor quality of sanitary\nfacilities in villages. There are fears that the cholera outbreak may\nspread to other areas where communities do not have access to portable\nwater supply as well as toilets. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Malawi can be seen at\n(http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/malawi.pdf) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/8665). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(http://allafrica.com/stories/201708220596.html) \nSouth Darfur\n\nIn 2 months, 42 people have died of cholera in Kalma camp for\ndisplaced people in South Darfur. 539 others have been infected. The\ndeaths occurred between 26 Jun and 20 Aug 2017, the coordinator of\nthe camp in Nyala, Yagoub Abdallah Furi, informed Radio Dabanga\nyesterday 21 Aug 2017. \"There are 3 medical isolation centres\nbelonging to 2 organizations from the USA that have been established\nin the camp since the cholera broke out in Nyala in June 2017.\" Currently there are 37 hospitalized cases at the camp's isolation\nwards. \"There is a large shortage of intravenous solutions. We hope\norganisations working in the medical field and the Ministry of Health\nto provide us with medicines.\" The epidemic reached Manawashi, north\nof Nyala city, at the beginning of August 2017. Central Darfur\n\nAt least 36 people have been infected with cholera in Central Darfur's\nNierteti in the past 11 days. 4 of them died, sources reported to\nRadio Dabanga. The UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian\nAffairs (OCHA) reported in its latest biweekly bulletin that\n\"humanitarian access and insecurity remain major challenges for the\nimplementation of key health and protection interventions\" in Central\nDarfur. \"Nierteti's hospital faces gaps in medicines, including oral and\nintravenous re-hydration solutions .,\" OCHA stated. \"In Zalingei\nhospital, there are several sanitation issues, including lack of\nlatrines and evidence of improper solid waste management..\" National epidemic\n\nThe National Epidemiological Corporation reported in early July 2017\nthat nearly 24 000 Sudanese have been infected and 940 cholera\npatients have died since the outbreak of the infectious disease in\nBlue Nile state in August 2016. The Sudanese authorities refuse to\ncall the disease by its name, however, and instead refer to it as\n\"acute watery diarrhea\". The National Intelligence and Security\nService has repeatedly warned medics and the press in the country not\nto make mention of cholera. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) *\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Radio Dabanga (edited)\n(https://www.dabangasudan.org/en/all-news/article/fifteen-cholera-dead-in-west-darfur-camp) \nWest Darfur\n\n15 people have died of cholera while 18 others have been infected in\nMurnei, West Darfur, in the past 3 days. A sheikh in Murnei camp for\ndisplaced people told this station, \"18 people are now in the\nisolation ward in the camp.\" The 18 infected people came from Um Tajok\nvillage near Murnei on 9 Aug 2017. 6 people died of cholera at the\nvillage that day, a sheikh reported from the camp last week week of 7\nAug 2017. Blue Nile\n\nIn Blue Nile state, 3 brothers died in the hospital of Ed Damazin on\nTue 15 Aug 2017. A relative of the deceased told Radio Dabanga that\nthe 3 family members died of the same disease in the hospital, in El\nHijra district. Sennar\n\nMeanwhile in Sennar, 18 people contracted cholera in El Dindir\nlocality this week week of 14 Aug 2017. A medical source told this\nstation that on Thu 17 Aug 2017, El Dindir's hospital received 13\nnews cases of cholera, 8 of which were received earlier this week. 5\nothers arrived on Thu 17 Aug 2017. The medical isolation centre at\nBardana village, south of the city, also recorded 5 new cases of\ncholera. The hospital in Singa received 3 new cases of cholera on Thu 17 Aug\n2017. A medical source informed Radio Dabanga that the 3 patients had\ncome from Um Benin village, south east of Singa. \"16 people suffering\nfrom cholera are still in the isolation ward.\" Northern state\n\nThe 1st cases of cholera have been reported in the southern part of El\nMahas in Northern state, at Arduan health centre. The patients arrived\nfrom Maljab area on Thu 17 Aug 2017, while El Tura health centre of\nEl Mahas received another case. Nubian activist Adham Nasr told Radio Dabanga that the woman has been\nisolated in a room at Arduan health centre to receive treatment. There\nare concerns that the disease might break out in the area during the\nrainy season, which makes it difficult to move from and to Arduan. Red Sea\n-\nA health centre in Arayab area in Ganab, Red Sea state, received 5\nchildren suffering from cholera on Wed 16 Aug 2017. Journalist Osman\nHashim told Radio Dabanga that the one of them has been transferred to\nPort Sudan Hospital. The doctors were unable to give information about\nthe cases. The hospital's administration has not allocated a ward to\nisolate the cholera patients. Earlier in August 2017 a volunteer of one of the cholera awareness\nraising campaigns in Sudan told Radio Dabanga that the reality in the\nhospitals is very poor. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of the Republic of the Sudan can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Congo DR (Kwilu, South Kivu).\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Voice of America (VOA) News, Afrique, Agence France-Presse\n(AFP) report in French, machine trans., edited\n(https://www.voaafrique.com/a/seize-morts-du-cholera-en-une-semaine-dans-le-sud-ouest-de-la-rdc/3991609.html) \nA total of 16 people died of cholera in one week in a region in the\nsouth west of the Democratic Republic of the Congo DRC, where about\n100 cases have been recorded, it was learned Fri 18 Aug 2017 from\nthe provincial authorities. \"We have recorded 16 cases of deaths and about 100 people are infected\nwith cholera\" in 3 zones of the province of Kwilu, governor Nicholas\nBulukungu told reporters. \"The province does not have a center\nspecializing in the treatment of cholera. The isolation of the\npatients is a serious problem,\" he said. The town of Bandundu and the\n2 affected localities are inhabited by nearly a million people,\ninvited to \"strict observance of the basic rules of hygiene.\" Another Congolese province (South Kivu in the east) is facing an\noutbreak of cholera with 2 deaths and several tens of cases reported\nfor nearly 3 weeks. According to the UN, cholera has become a major public health problem\nin the DRC with thousands of cases recorded every year in many\nprovinces in this vast country without infrastructure and where most\nof the population lives in poverty. More than 700 deaths of cholera were recorded in 2016 in the DRC. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-FRA\n(promed-fra@promedmail.org) Maps of the Democratic Republic of the Congo can be seen at\n(http://goo.gl/DM2AT8) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/42129). -\nSr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - India (Punjab).\nDate: Sat 19 Aug 2017 03:09 PM IST.\nSource: Times of India (edited)\n(http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/ludhiana/cholera-outbreak-18-fresh-cases-reported-on-day-5/articleshow/60126504.cms) \n18 fresh cholera cases were reported at Guru Har Rai Nagar Ludhiana,\nPunjab on on day 5 of the outbreak. District epidemiologist Ramesh\nKumar said more than 500 people contracted the disease over the past\nfew days. Health officials are taking all possible measures to stem\nthe outbreak, including organizing medical camps to engender public\nawareness about the disease.
