Jessada advised people coming into regular contact with floodwater to wear boots, drink only water that has been boiled, avoid raw and partially cooked food, wash immediately after exposure and seek medical attention if a fever persists for more than 5 days or abscesses become chronic.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Melioidosis is a disease of the rainy season in its endemic areas. It mainly affects people who have direct contact with soil and water. Many have an underlying predisposing condition such as diabetes (commonest risk factor), renal disease, cirrhosis, thalassemia, alcohol dependence, immunosuppressive therapy, chronic obstructive lung disease, cystic fibrosis, and excess kava consumption. Kava is an herbal member of the pepper family that can be associated with chronic liver disease.  Melioidosis may present at any age, but peaks in the 4th and 5th decades of life, affecting men more than women. In addition, although severe fulminating infection can and does occur in healthy individuals, severe disease and fatalities are much less common in those without risk factors.  The most commonly recognized presentation of melioidosis is pneumonia, associated with high fever, significant muscle aches, chest pain, and  although the cough can be nonproductive  respiratory secretions can be purulent, significant in quantity, and associated with on-and-off bright, red blood. The lung infection can be rapidly fatal  with bacteremia and shock  or somewhat more indolent.  Acute melioidosis septicemia is the most severe complication of the infection. It presents as a typical sepsis syndrome with hypotension, high cardiac output, and low systemic vascular resistance. In many cases, a primary focus in the soft tissues or lung can be found. The syndrome, usually in patients with risk factor comorbidities, is characteristically associated with multiple abscesses involving the cutaneous tissues, the lung, the liver, and spleen, and a very high mortality rate of 80 to 95 percent. With prompt optimal therapy, the case fatality rate can be decreased to 40 to 50 percent.  The melioidosis bacillus is intrinsically insensitive to many antimicrobials. It should be noted that bioterrorism strains may be engineered to be even more resistant. _Burkholderia pseudomallei_ is usually inhibited by tetracyclines, chloramphenicol, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (SXT), antipseudomonal penicillins, carbapenems, ceftazidime, and amoxicillin/clavulanate or ampicillin/sulbactam. Ceftriaxone and cefotaxime have good in vitro activity but poor efficacy; and cefepime did not appear, as well, to be equivalent to ceftazidime in a mouse model. The unusual antimicrobial profile of resistance to colistin and polymyxin B and the aminoglycosides but sensitivity to amoxicillin/clavulanate is a useful tool to consider in treatment of infection with the organism.  The randomized and quasi-randomized trials comparing melioidosis treatment have been reviewed, and it was found that the formerly standard therapy of chloramphenicol, doxycycline, and SXT combination had a higher mortality rate than therapy with ceftazidime, imipenem/cilastatin, or amoxicillin/clavulanate (or ampicillin/sulbactam). The betalactam-betalactamase inhibitor therapy, however, seemed to have a higher failure rate. . Source: Tolaney P, Lutwick LI: Melioidosis. In: Lutwick LI, Lutwick SM (eds). Bioterror: the weaponization of infectious diseases. Totowa NJ: Humana Press, 2008 pp 145-58.  For the microbiologists among our readers, a new (and 5th) member of the _B. pseudomallei_ complex has been described, _B. humptydooensis_ , from the Northern Territory of Australia and named after the small town of Humpty Doo near to where the isolate was found (Tuanyok A, Mayo M, Scholz H, et al: _Burkholderia humptydooensis_ sp. nov., a new species related to _Burkholderia thailandensis_ and the fifth member of the _Burkholderia pseudomallei_ complex. App Environ Microbiol 2017; 83(5): e02802-16); (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5311406/). - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"East Timor":{},"Togo":{},"Tonga":{},"Trinidad and Tobago":{},"Tunisia":{},"Turkey":{"16":{"title":"Poliomyelitis update (22): Syria, Afghanistan, Somalia,\r\n\tglobal ","date":["16","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Poliomyelitis update (22): Syria, Afghanistan, Somalia,\r\n\tglobal [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Syria: WHO situation report no. 9, 15 Aug 2017 <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Somalia: declared polio free <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Global: Global Polio Eradication Initiative, Syria, Afghanistan   <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Syria: WHO situation report no. 9, 15 Aug 2017. Date: Tue 15 Aug 2017. Source: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), ReliefWeb, WHO/UNICEF report (edited) (http://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syria-cvdpv2-outbreak-situation-report-9-15-august-2017)   Syria cVDPV2 outbreak situation report no. 9, 15 Aug 2017  Key highlights  Three new cases of cVDPV2 were reported this week from 3 new districts: 1 case from Deir ez-Zor district, Deir ez-Zor governorate; 1 from Boukamal district, Deir ez-Zor governorate; and 1 from Tadmour district, Homs governorate.  Five districts in 3 governorates are now infected.  The total number of cVDPV2 cases is 33 (this includes the previously reported 29 cases from Mayadeen district, Deir ez-Zor governorate, and 1 case from Tell Abyad district, Raqqa governorate). All confirmed cases to date have had onset of paralysis before 11 Jul 2017.  Final lab results for an additional 9 poliovirus type-2 (PV2) isolates from Deir ez-Zor are pending.  Discussions around expanding the scope of the immunization response to include accessible areas of a Tadmour sub-district in Homs, bordering Deir ez-Zor , will be held in light of the confirmation of the cases in this area.  Raqqa governorate commenced its 1st immunization round on 12 Aug 2017 (Raqqa and Thawra districts) and 13 Aug 2017 (Tell Abyad district). The immunization round aims to reach 120 000 children under 5 years of age. Preliminary information suggests the rounds are reaching children in all 3 districts.  Preparations continue for the 2nd round in Deir ez-Zor governorate, scheduled for 19-23 Aug 2017. IPV inactivated polio vaccine for use in the 2nd rounds in Deir ez-Zor and Raqqa governorates has arrived in Damascus.  The total number of AFP acute flaccid paralysis cases detected in Deir ez-Zor governorate since the beginning of 2017 is 113 (83 from Mayadeen, 11 from Deir ez-Zor, and 19 from Boukamal districts). Raqqa governorate has reported 16 AFP cases (5 from Raqqa, 10 from Tell Abyad, and 1 from Thawra districts). Homs governorate has reported 26 AFP cases (11 from Homs city, 12 from Rastan, 1 from Tadmour, and 2 from Talkalakh districts).  The Eradication and Outbreak Management Group (EOMG) has approved the release of additional doses of IPV to cover high risk population groups in northwest Syria, Turkey, and Lebanon. Lebanon requested 144 000 doses and has begun to implement IPV campaigns across the country.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  Unfortunately transmission of the cVDPV2 in Syria has continued. With each report, the date of onset of the most recent case shifts to a date approximately one month preceding the report, probably reflecting the time it takes from specimen collection to appropriate reference laboratory. We are fairly sure there will be an additional 9 cases confirmed from Deir ez-Zor, as the report above mentions that there are 9 poliovirus isolates pending typing (WPV vs cVDPV). The report also mentions a significant number of AFP cases identified in the 3 governorates, suggesting there may be more cases in the pipeline for confirmation. The control activities have been implemented during this week and will be implemented in additional areas next week week of 21 Aug 2017, so hopefully there will be interruption of transmission going forward.  The disturbing news in the situation report above, is that there is now involvement of 3 governorates. Deir ez-Zor, Raqqa, and now Homs. On a map of Syria showing provinces/governorates ((http://www.freeworldmaps.net/asia/syria/syria-political-map.jpg)), one can see that Deir ez-Zor, the main governorate involved in this outbreak is located in the northeast of the country sharing it's eastern border with Iraq. It shares a southern border with Homs, and a western border with Raqqa (Ar-Raqqah on this map) governorate. Hopefully the cVDPV2 will not continue to travel in the country outside of the currently 3 affected areas. - Mod.MPP   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Somalia: declared polio free. Date: Mon 14 Aug 2017. Source: AllAfrica, Shabelle Media Network (Mogadishu) report (edited) (http://allafrica.com/stories/201708150227.html)   The UN World Health Organisation (WHO) said it had not recorded any case of polio disease in Somalia in the last 3 years, declaring the country polio free.  The WHO said the country recorded the last case of polio in 2014 in the central part of the country but has since then remained free of the paralyzing disease.  The UN health agency, however, warned Somalia remained vulnerable, calling for continued vaccination campaign, Xinhua News Agency reported.  The head of the WHO Eastern Mediterranean, which covers Somalia, Mohamed Fiqi said that massive vaccination campaigns and commitment from government and international actors had ensured the polio virus did not recur in the Horn of Africa country.  \"As the world edges closer to eradicating polio, keeping alert in countries that have high risk of polio importation like Somalia is more of priority than ever,\" Fiqi said.  \"As we move forward, the polio programme in Somalia needs to continue to work to maintain and improve the level of population immunity against polio through target vaccination campaign and strengthening of the routine immunisation services and infrastructure,\" Fiqi added.  The declaration by WHO keeps Somalia outside the last group of countries which still record cases of polio in the world.  Afghanistan, Nigeria, and Pakistan are the remaining countries where polio is still being recorded. The WHO chief warned Somalia remains at risk of importation of the virus from these countries.  Somalia President Mohamed Abdullahi Farmaajo praised efforts to rid his country of the polio disease which he noted had subjected many children into suffering.  \"No cases were found for the past 3 years and no child was affected by this disease. Many of our children have suffered from polio for many years.  \"To eradicate polio was a big success and it was collective effort and commitment by many young men and women who sacrificed their lives,\" Farmaajo noted.  The 3 year polio-free celebration comes amidst the worst outbreak of measles the country has seen in years.  Somalia is also still responding to an outbreak of acute watery diarrhoea/cholera, which began in January 2017. Polio systems and networks are being used in both interventions.  \"Polio infrastructure has been critical in responding to these other serious outbreaks,\" said Fiqi.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Achieving 3 years with no new cases of polio reported is a significant achievement for Somalia. That being said, it's important to remember that this too is a country with internal civil strife and warring factions, which may impede the identification of poliovirus associated disease either due to infrastructural challenges in good specimen collection and transport, or access of the population to the healthcare infrastructure. A reminder is the identification of WPV associated cases in Borno, Nigeria last year (2016), involving a virus last seen 5 years before in the same state.  The HealthMap/ProMED map of Somalia can be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/125).- Mod.MPP   <br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Global: Global Polio Eradication Initiative, Syria, Afghanistan. Date: Wed 16 Aug 2017. Source: Global Polio Eradication Initiative (edited) (http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/this-week/)   Poliovirus weekly update  as of 16-Aug-2017  New wild poliovirus cases reported this week: 1 Total number of wild poliovirus cases in 2017: 9 Total number of wild poliovirus cases in 2016: 37  New cVDPV cases reported this week: 3 Total number of cVDPV cases in 2017: 40 Total number of cVDPV cases in 2016: 5  Headlines  - Marking Pakistan's Independence Day 14 August this week, Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau paid tribute to both countries' ongoing collaboration, including on the effort to eradicate polio.\" Our 2 countries established a diplomatic relationship shortly after Pakistan was declared a sovereign nation in 1947. We continue to work together to advance shared priorities, including governance and democracy, regional security, poverty reduction, polio eradication, trade, defense, and the fight against climate change.\"  - The 14th Emergency Committee for polio eradication under the International Health Regulations met on 3 Aug 2017 and has made its recommendations to the WHO Director-General, who has accepted them. The Committee unanimously agreed that the risk of international spread of poliovirus remains a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), and recommended the extension of revised Temporary Recommendations for a further 3 months. The key change is the inclusion of DR Congo and Syria in the category 'States infected with cVDPV2s, with potential risk of international spread'.  - Summary of newly-reported viruses this week: Afghanistan: 1 new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) case; Pakistan: 1 new WPV1-positive environmental sample; Syrian Arab Republic: 3 new circulating vaccine-derived polio type 2 (cVDPV2) from Syria, 2 from Deir ez-Zor and 1 from Homs governorates. Details in country-specific sections below.  Afghanistan  - One new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) case was reported in the past week, bringing the total number of WPV1 cases for 2017 to 6. It is the most recent case in the country, and had onset of paralysis on 10 Jul 2017, from Zabul province, neighbouring Kandahar province and Pakistan. - Afghanistan continues to coordinate activities with neighbouring Pakistan, to address both cross-border transmission and focus on reaching mobile populations with oral polio vaccine (OPV). Transmission linking both countries runs primarily across 3 corridors, namely: eastern Afghanistan and Khyber-Peshawar, Pakistan; greater Kandahar/Helmand and Quetta, Pakistan; and, Paktika/Patkya/Khost and Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa/Federally Administered Tribal Areas, Pakistan.  Pakistan  - No new wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) case was reported in the past week; the total number of WPV1 cases for 2017 remains 3. The most recent case in the country had onset of paralysis on 11 Jun 2017, from Killa Abdullah, Balochistan. - 1 new WPV1-positive environmental sample was reported in the past week, collected on 28 Jul 2017, from Quetta, Balochistan. - A special vaccination round is being implemented during August 2017 targeting areas with recent polio cases and positive environmental samples. These include Rawalpindi/Islamabad and demographically connected areas of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Quetta Block, and parts of Karachi. - Under the National Emergency Action Plan for polio eradication, the country is planning to implement 2 nation-wide and 2 sub-national vaccination rounds from September to December 2017.  Nigeria - - No new cases of wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) were reported in the past week. The total number of WPV1 cases for 2016 remains 4 and no cases have been reported in 2017. The most recent case had onset of paralysis on 21 Aug 2016 in Monguno Local Government Area (LGA), Borno. - Nigeria continues to implement emergency response to the detected WPV1 strain and circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) strains affecting the country (last detected in 2016). - Detection of the polio cases in Nigeria underscores the risk posed by low-level undetected transmission and the urgent need to strengthen subnational surveillance.  Lake Chad Basin  - The detection of wild poliovirus type 1 (WPV1) (Borno, Nigeria in 2016) and circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) (Borno and Sokoto provinces in Nigeria in 2016) continue to pose a risk to the neighbouring countries of the Lake Chad basin and hence an outbreak response plan is being implemented as part of the response to the Nigeria outbreak. - Emergency outbreak response efforts continue across the Lake Chad basin, together with activities to fill subnational surveillance gaps across the region.  Central Africa  - No new cases of type 2 circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV2) were reported in the past week in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DR Congo). The total number of cVDPV2 cases this year 2017 remains 7, in 2 separate outbreaks: in Haut Lomami province (5 cases, with onset of paralysis of the most recent case on 13 Jun 2017); and in Maniema province (2 cases with onset of paralysis on 26 Mar 2017 and 18 Apr 2017, with an additional isolate detected in a healthy individual with sample collection on 2 May 2017). - Confirmation of additional cases is not unexpected at this time. Outbreak response is taking place, including use of monovalent oral polio vaccine type 2 (mOPV2) in line with internationally-agreed outbreak response protocols, targeting more than 750 000 children under the age of 5 across the 2 provinces. - The 1st mOPV2 round was implemented on 27-29 Jun 2017 in the 2 affected provinces; and the 2nd mOPV2 round ran from 13-15 Jul 2017 in Haut Lomami and 20-22 Jul 2017 in Maniema. - Surveillance and immunization activities are being strengthened in neighbouring countries.  Middle East  - In Syria, 3 new cases of circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus type 2 (cVDPV2) were officially reported in the past week. The total number of cases in this outbreak is 33. Onset of paralysis of these cases is between 3 Mar 2017 and 10 Jul 2017. 31 of the cases are from Deir ez-Zor governorate (29 from Mayadeen district, one from Deir ez-Zor district, and one from Boukamal district); 1 case is from Talabyad district, Raqqa governorate; and, 1 is from Tadmour district in Homs governorate. - Confirmation of additional cases is not unexpected at this time and would not change the operational situation, as outbreak response plans are being finalized and implemented, in line with internationally-agreed outbreak response protocols. Two vaccination campaigns are planned for both Deir ez-Zor and Raqqa governorates. If there is geographic spread, the extent of these campaigns will have to be adjusted. - The 1st mOPV2 round in Deir ez-Zor was successfully carried out between 22-26 Jul 2017. Independent post-campaign monitoring reflected coverage of 88.4 percent (based on caregiver recall). The 2nd round is planned for 19-23 Aug 2017, and will include mOPV2 and IPV. - Raqqa Governorate started mOPV2 campaigns on 12 Aug 2017. - Plans are being finalized to mitigate the risks of further spread from the outbreak zone to neighbouring areas and countries, including immunization of at-risk populations in northwest Syria, Turkey and Lebanon. Following confirmation of the case in Homs, discussions are ongoing to further extend the geographic reach of the outbreak response.  Officially reported wild poliovirus cases as of 15 Aug 2017  Total global cases in 2017: 9 (compared with 21 for the same period in 2016) Total in endemic countries in 2017: 9 (compared with 21 for the same period in 2016) - Afghanistan: 6 cases in 2017 (compared with 6 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 10 Jul 2017 - Pakistan: 3 cases in 2017 (compared with 13 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 11 Jun 2017 - Nigeria: 0 cases in 2017 (compared with 2 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 21 Aug 2016 Total in non-endemic countries in 2017: 0 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016)  Total global cases in 2016: 37 - Total in endemic countries: 37 - Total in non-endemic countries: 0  Officially reported cVDPV cases as of 15 Aug 2017 - Total global cases in 2017: 40 (compared with 3 for the same period in 2016) - Syrian Arab Republic: 33 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 10 Jul 2017 - Democratic Republic of the Congo: 7 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 13 Jun 2017 - Pakistan: 0 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 17 Dec 2016 - Nigeria: 0 cases in 2017 (compared with 0 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 28 Oct 2016 - Lao People's Democratic Republic: 0 case in 2017 (compared with 3 for the same period in 2016), onset of paralysis of most recent case: 11 Jan 2016  Total global cases in 2016: 5 - Total in endemic countries: 2 - Total in non-endemic countries: 3   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  This week's global update is similar to prior weeks in terms of low level identification of WPV1 associated disease (a single case confirmed in Afghanistan this past week), one positive WPV1 isolated from an environmental sample in Pakistan, and 3 newly confirmed cVDPV2 associated cases in Syria.  That being said, there have only been 9 confirmed cases of WPV1 associated paralytic disease worldwide this year (2017), compared with 37 cases reported last year (2016). In contrast there have been 40 confirmed cases of cVDPV2 confirmed this year (2017) compared with 5 last year (2016). As a reminder, outbreaks due to cVDPV's are considered as significant in the big picture of polio eradication, as they are due to vaccine polioviruses that have reverted in neurovirulence following passage through multiple individuals while circulating in the susceptible population. The goal of the polio eradication initiative is to interrupt transmission of both the WPV's and the cVDPVs. The presence of cVDPVs occurs when there are areas with low vaccination coverage where the vaccine virus (from the OPV) can continue circulating through the susceptible population.  HealthMap/ProMED-mail maps can be found at Syria: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/86) Afghanistan: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/137) Pakistan: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/140).  An interactive map showing the geographic locations of all WPV and cVDPV associated cases can be found at (http://polioeradication.org/polio-today/polio-now/). - Mod.MPP  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Turkmenistan":{},"Tuvalu":{},"Uganda":{"54":{"title":"Measles update (42): Europe, Middle East, Africa, Pacific\r\n\t","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (42): Europe, Middle East, Africa, Pacific\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nMEASLES UPDATE (42): EUROPE, MIDDLE EAST, AFRICA, PACIFIC\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nEurope\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Romania\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> France (Ardèche) Middle East\n\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Israel ex Ukraine Africa\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Uganda (Kampala, Wakiso) Pacific\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia) \n\nEurope\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Romania.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Romanian Business News-ACT Media (edited)\n(http://actmedia.eu/daily/healthmin-bodog-measles-epidemic-consequence-of-major-malfunctions-in-vaccination-public-policy/70944) \nA total of 8493 confirmed measles cases had been reported by Fri 11\nAug 2017, since the outbreak of the disease in 2016, informs a\nrelease on the website of the National Center for the Surveillance and\nControl of Communicable Diseases of the National Public Health\nInstitute. Among these cases there were 32 deaths, as follows: 8 in\nTimis County, 6 in Arad, 7 in Dolj, 3 in Caras-Severin, and one in\neach Bihor, Cluj, Calarasi, Satu Mare, Vaslui, Galati, Mures, and\nBucharest. Measles outbreaks have been registered in all 41 counties,\nthe most affected  with over 1000 cases each  being Timis (1215\ncases), Caras-Severin (1110), and Arad (1002). The measles outbreak in Romania in 2016 is not circumstantial, but a\ndirect consequence of the \"major\" malfunctions in public policy\nregarding vaccination, minister of health Florian Bodog stated on Fri\n11 Aug in a press release. \"For years now Romania has been below the\nsafety threshold of vaccination coverage. That is, the risk of a\nmeasles outbreak was imminent. Which is what actually happened. The\noutbreak of the measles epidemic in 2016 is not conjectural, it is a\ndirect consequence of major malfunctions in the public policy on\nvaccination,\" the minister of health stated. According to him, the Vaccination Law corrects the irregularities that\nled to the epidemic, providing the best conditions for protecting\nchildren's health. \"For Romania, the stake of the vaccination bill is\nhuge. Ensuring a healthy future for 4 million children lies in our\nhands. The Romanian parliament, the highest institution of democracy,\nwill decide on the final content of this law. However, beyond the\ndebates in parliament, it is important that all the public opinion be\ninformed and understand the true meaning of the law and the profound\nchanges it brings. (..) We have a moral duty towards our children, to\nprevent harm before it happens. As we also have a moral duty to the\ncommunity in which we live to prevent harm before it happens to other\nchildren or parents,\" Bodog said, quoted in the press release. He added that any bill is amendable and that is why it is open to any\npublic debates as long as they are carried out with honesty, good\nsense and decency. \"But this project is the day-to-day work of\nspecialists in the field of vaccination and who have faced all the\nflaws of the current framework. That is why the law has been carefully\nand correctly thought through by those who best understand how to\nregulate the vaccination policy,\" the minister of health also said. The bill on the organisation and funding of public vaccination in\nRomania was adopted by the government on Wed 9 Aug 2017. The bill\nwas submitted to parliament for debate and adoption. The normative act\nwould come into force on 1 Jan 2018. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) A similar report can be found in El Pais (12 Aug 2017) which states\nin addition that, of the 95 per cent vaccine coverage recommended by\nthe World Health Organization (WHO), 86 per cent have been\nvaccinated since 2007, according to its national epidemiological\ncentre. \"Highly worrying\" figures, acknowledged the prime minister,\nMihai Tudose, this week. \"More than 180 000 children in our country,\nfrom 9 months to 9 years, are not immunized against measles. In some\nregions, the rate of immunization of the 2nd dose does not reach 50\nper cent; and this is very serious.\" Timis and Caras-Severin, Arad\n(all to the west of the country, near the border with Serbia or\nHungary), are the most affected, with more than 1000 measles cases\neach, reported in the last 10 months when the outbreak was declared. According to official estimates, nearly 50 000 children without\nimmunization are not even registered with a family doctor. Most is due\nto serious problems of social exclusion. Submitted by Kathryn Soderholm (kathryn.soderholm@gmail.com) from\nProMED-ESP archive no http://promedmail.org/post/20170814.5248771 and\ntranslated by Mod.LK Maps of Romania can be found at\n(http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> France (Ardèche).\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 11:39 CEST.\nSource: Silver Times (edited)\n(https://sivertimes.com/ardeche-four-hospitalizations-related-to-a-measles-outbreak/64380) \nA measles outbreak was declared in Ardoix, in the northern Ardèche,\nreports France Blue. 6 people  2 adults and 4 children, including\nsome infants  were infected by the virus between early July and 9\nAug 2017. 4 patients had to be hospitalized. The 6 people are now\nout of danger, and the 4 hospitalised patients were able to return\nhome, says the regional Agency of health (ARS), Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes,\ncited by France Bleu. These are all people who live or work in this\nsmall town of 1100 habitats. The ARS called for vigilance and prompted the inhabitants of the\nnorthern Ardèche, to consult a doctor in case of fever and appearance\nof buttons rash. It alerted on the very high contagiousness of the\nvirus that can infect up to 20 people around a sick person, and they\ncan produce severe, even life-threatening disease  in fact, there is\nno curative treatment for measles. In addition, the ARS has been reported to France Bleu that the recent\nconfirmed cases of measles in Ardoix were unvaccinated. According to\nthe figures of the LRA, 71 per cent of the inhabitants of the Ardèche\nregion are vaccinated against measles, which is 10 per cent less than\nthe national average. The government has confirmed its willingness to make mandatory 8\nvaccines, including measles. On this disease, \"Vaccination coverage\namong children at 2 years of age reaches only 78 per cent. As long as\nit does not reach the 95 per cent the risk of epidemic wave periodic\nwill persist\", has declared Agnès Buzyn. Measles has made its 1st victim in France at the end of July 2017. A\nyoung girl, a 16 year old native of Nice, has succumbed to this\ninfectious disease in the hospital North of Marseille, after having\nbeen hospitalized in intensive care for 3 weeks. The girl had never\nbeen vaccinated against measles. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of France can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France#Administrative_divisions) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62734). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \nMiddle East\n\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Israel ex Ukraine.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017 18:11 IDT.\nSource: The Jerusalem Post (edited)\n(http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Politics-And-Diplomacy/Nine-soldiers-recover-after-being-infected-with-measles-502391) \nThe IDF Israeli Defense Forces said on Mon 14 Aug 2017 that 9\nsoldiers diagnosed last week week of 7 Aug 2017 with the highly\ninfectious measles are all recovering and have returned to duty.\nAccording to the IDF, the soldiers all had mild cases of the disease\nand did not serve in the same unit. The index case had just returned from visiting family in the Ukraine\nwhere he likely contracted the disease. When he returned to Israel he\nvisited a clinic where he infected 8 other soldiers who were waiting\nin line to see a physician. \"The IDF, together with the Health\nMinistry, carried out an investigation to locate the cases and\nidentify the source of the infection,\" the army said in a statement,\nadding that all those who had contact with the soldiers had been\ngiven preventative treatment. An IDF spokesman told The Jerusalem Post\nthat the soldier who contracted the disease had 2 stopovers in Europe\non his way back to Israel from the Ukraine but was not able to specify\nwhich countries. WHO in March 2017 warned of a measles outbreak sweeping across\nEurope in places where immunization rates have plummeted. The figures\ncover the agency's entire European region  53 countries including\nIsrael, Kazakhstan, and Russia. According to WHO 559 measles cases\nwere reported in Europe between January and March 2017. While the\nlargest current measles outbreaks in Europe were reported in Romania\nand Italy, other countries reporting cases were France, Germany,\nPoland, Switzerland, and the Ukraine. \"With steady progress toward\nelimination over the past 2 years, it is of particular concern that\nmeasles cases are climbing in Europe,\" said Dr Zsuzsanna Jakab, WHO\nregional director for Europe. \"Today's travel patterns put no person\nor country beyond the reach of the measles virus. Outbreaks will\ncontinue in Europe, as elsewhere, until every country reaches the\nlevel of immunization needed to fully protect their populations.\" Israeli children are routinely immunized with the MMR measles, mumps,\nrubella vaccine which are given in 2 doses, at 1 year and a booster\nin the 1st grade. The Health Ministry has stated that the level of\nvaccine coverage in Israel is among the highest in the West, with 97\nper cent coverage for 1st and 2nd doses MMR and chickenpox vaccine. While no vaccine is 100 per cent effective, an infectious disease\nspecialist told the Post that measles is \"a nasty illness\" that is\npreventable by proper immunization. But while it is highly recommended\nby medical professionals and the Health Ministry, the vaccine is not\nmandatory and according to the IDF the measles vaccine is not part of\nthe vaccines given to new recruits. \"We cannot afford to have soldiers\nwho are severely ill with a highly contagious disease. It would be\nappropriate for the IDF to verify and update immunizations of all\npersonnel and new recruits,\" the infectious disease specialist told\nthe Post. Measles is spread by coughing and sneezing and close contact with\ninfected individuals. While most infected people usually experience\nonly mild symptoms it is one of the leading causes of death among\nyoung children globally. Measles takes about 8-12 days following\ncontact before the individual will show symptoms which include a\nfever, bad cough, red eyes, and a runny nose. A few days after the\nrespiratory symptoms, the infected individual will get a bad rash.\nOther complications of measles include gastroenteritis (diarrhea and\nvomiting), pneumonia, severe bleeding problems, and in some rare cases\nencephalitis (brain infections). In June 2017, 5 cases of measles were reported to the Health\nMinistry  all of them women between the ages of 20-40 who lived in\nJerusalem. byline: Anna Ahronheim \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Even with 97 per cent vaccine coverage, measles virus can cause small\noutbreaks. But these outbreaks won't be able to expand to cause\nsignificant disease in the protected population. HealthMap/ProMED-mail maps\nIsrael: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90)\nUkraine: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/123)\n- Mod.LK \nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Uganda (Kampala, Wakiso).\nDate: Tue 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, The EastAfrican report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/uganda/uganda-plans-mass-measles-vaccination) \nUganda's Health Ministry has said it is rolling out a mass\nimmunisation campaign against measles for children under the age of\nfive, as a measure to control an outbreak of the disease in the\ncapital Kampala and the neighbouring district of Wakiso, where 67\ncases were reported in July 2017. \"The Ministry of Health is\nundertaking a number of measures to control the spread of the disease,\nincluding investigating the extent of its spread in Kampala and\nWakiso,\" said director of health services, Prof Anthony Mbonye. Measles is an airborne disease that affects mostly children between\nthe ages of 6 months and 10 years, although it can also affect\nadults. Although Prof Mbonye said there was no cause for alarm, he urged the\npublic to be vigilant and report any suspected cases to the nearest\nhealth facilities. The public has also been urged to look out for\ncommon early symptoms associated with the disease, which include high\nfever, cough, red swelling eyelids and muscle and body irritability. According to the Ministry of Health, an estimated 20 per cent of\npeople who get infected with measles often develop complications,\nwhich if not managed early enough can lead to death. Despite previous\nmass vaccination campaigns, Uganda has had several outbreaks of the\ndisease. Prof Mbonye blamed it on parents who do not take their\nchildren for immunisation at the right time. Current national\nimmunisation coverage stands at 85 per cent. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) According to WHO, in 2016 global vaccination coverage (all vaccines)\nwas stalled at 86 per cent, with no significant changes during the\npast year. For measles alone, by the end of 2016, 85 per cent of\nchildren had received 1 dose of vaccine by their 2nd birthday, and 164\ncountries had included a 2nd dose as part of routine immunization; 64\nper cent of children received 2 doses of measles vaccine according to\nnational immunization schedules. It is generally thought that because\nmeasles is such a highly transmissible disease, that 90-95 per cent of\npeople must be vaccinated in order to protect the entire population,\nor achieve herd immunity. Maps of Uganda can be seen at\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97) - Mod.LK \nPacific\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia).\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017 9:58 AM AWST.\nSource: The West Australian (edited)\n(https://thewest.com.au/news/wa/third-case-of-measles-among-students-at-steiner-school-ng-b88572888z) \nHealth authorities have confirmed a 3rd case of measles in a student\nfrom the Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, WA and warned there\ncould be more. This is the 2nd student to be infected from an\nunvaccinated high school student at the Bibra Lake school who\ncontracted measles while on holiday in Italy. Before being diagnosed,\nand while still infectious, the student was at the school and other\nlocations in Perth. The WA Health Department's Virus Watch bulletin said the 2 confirmed\nsecondary measles cases were in unvaccinated students. \"All 3 attend a\nsouthern suburbs school with a low rate of vaccination, and further\ncases remain possible,\" it said. byline: Cathy O'Leary \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Australia can be seen at\n(http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK ","keywordsMatched":[]},"117":{"title":"Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Uganda: (QO, NK) ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Uganda: (QO, NK) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 24 Aug 2017 at 15:34:33 BST. Source: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA), ReliefWeb, Monitor-Uganda report (edited) (http://reliefweb.int/report/uganda/uganda-viral-haemorrhagic-fever-alert)   Uganda has been placed on high alert as the Ministry of Health investigates and monitors suspected cases of the deadly Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever in the central districts of Kiboga and Nakaseke. On 20 Aug 2017, the ministry received blood samples of 2 patients from Kiboga and Nakaseke hospital suspected Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF).  According to a 21 Aug 2017 statement signed by the acting Director General, health services Dr Anthony Mbonye, the 2 victims tested positive to Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever CCFH.  CCHF is a common disease among humans and animals caused by caused by a tick-borne virus (_Nairovirus_); the virus causes severe viral haemorrhagic fever outbreaks, with a case fatality rate of 10-40 percent.  Dr Mbonye says that the general supportive care with treatment of symptoms is the main approach to managing CCFH among humans. The statement warns that while its symptoms do not appear in the infected animal, it appears in a very dangerous way in human beings.  \"You are required to work with the office of the District Veterinary Officer to strengthen measures against CCHF control in animals, implement interventions to reduce the risk of CCHF infections among humans, and interventions to control CCFH in health care settings.  You are also reminded to immediately report and investigate any CCFH suspected cases in your district,\" reads the statement in part signed by Dr Mbonye.  CCHF virus is transmitted to people either by tick bites or through contact with infected animal blood or tissues during and immediately after slaughter.  According to Ministry of health, the majority of cases have occurred in people involved in the livestock industry, such as agricultural workers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians and that human-to-human transmission occurs from close contact with the blood, secretions, organs, or other bodily fluids of infected persons.  Hospital-acquired infections can also occur due to improper sterilization of medical equipment, reuse of needles, and contamination of medical supplies.  Records indicate that since 2000, Uganda has experienced repeated outbreaks of viral hemorrhagic fevers (VHF). Ebola VHF outbreak occurred in the districts of Gulu in 2000, Bundibugyo, 2007, Luwero, 2011, Kibaale in July 2012, Luwero in November 2012. Marburg VHF was earlier reported in Ibanda in 2007. More recently in 2012, 2 outbreaks of Marburg VHF have occurred in Ibanda and Kabale districts.  Signs and symptoms of CCHF  Sudden, with fever, myalgia, (muscle ache), dizziness, neck pain and stiffness, backache, headache, sore eyes and photophobia (sensitivity to light), nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and sore throat early on, followed by sharp mood swings and confusion.  After 2 to 4 days, the agitation may be replaced by sleepiness, depression, and lassitude, and the abdominal pain may localize to the upper right quadrant, with detectable hepatomegaly (liver enlargement).  Byline: David Mafabi   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  CCHF is endemic in Africa, the Balkans, the Middle East, and Asian countries south of the 50th parallel north  the geographical limit of the principal tick vector. The hosts of the CCHF virus include a wide range of wild and domestic animals such as cattle, sheep, and goats.  Animals become infected by the bite of infected ticks and the virus remains in their bloodstream for about one week after infection, allowing the tick-animal-tick cycle to continue when another tick bites. Although a number of tick genera are capable of becoming infected with CCHF virus, ticks of the genus _Hyalomma_ are the principal vector. The CCHF virus is transmitted to people either by tick bites or through contact with infected animal blood or tissues during and immediately after slaughter. The majority of cases have occurred in people involved in the livestock industry, such as agricultural workers, slaughterhouse workers, and veterinarians. Human-to-human transmission is possible.  The report above does not mention any clinical features of the cases.  ProMED has not posted reports of cases of CCHF in Uganda since 2013. - Mod.UBA  Maps of Uganda can be seen at (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"299":{"title":"Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (95): Africa, Asia","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera, diarrhea & dysentery update (95): Africa, Asia","summary":"\nCHOLERA, DIARRHEA AND DYSENTERY UPDATE (95): AFRICA, ASIA\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi)\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi) police\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Tana River county)\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong>, <br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - Nigeria (Borno state) IDPs\n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Cholera - Sudan\n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Cholera, diarrhea - Eastern and Southern Africa Region\nAsia\n\n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab) \nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi).\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017 9:09 AM EAT.\nSource: Capital FM (edited)\n(https://www.capitalfm.co.ke/news/2017/09/cholera-cases-in-nairobi-rise-to-88/) \nThe number of people admitted to various hospitals in Nairobi after\ntesting positive for cholera has now risen to 88. Nairobi Governor\nMike Sonko stated that as at 8 pm Sunday night, 3 Sep 2017, Sinai\nHospital in Rongai had admitted 50 patients who tested positive, while\nNairobi Women's Hospital had 26. Sonko indicated that those admitted\nto Kenyatta National Hospital were 12 and that \"teams from the\nnational and county governments have been on the ground all day.\" He\nsaid that investigations are still ongoing to ascertain and confirm\nthe diagnosis and the sources of the infection. \"The status of all patients is reported to be stable and under\ncontrol.\" He further appealed to city residents not to panic, as\nadequate controls have been put in place to prevent the spread of the\ndisease. \"Above all, let's continue observing high standards of\nhygiene, while ensuring we eat properly cooked food, cleaned\nvegetables and fruits,\" he stated. Byline: Simon Ndonga \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Kenya can be seen at (http://tinyurl.com/kck73tk) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/174). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Nairobi) police.\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, EstAfrican report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/kenya/more-90-police-officers-hit-cholera-nairobi) \nAt least 95 police officers have been hospitalized in Kenya with\nsuspected cases of cholera. According to the Health ministry, the\nofficers are said to have been infected after taking meals at the\nNairobi Area Police Canteen. On Sun 3 Sep 2017, some 59 officers were hospitalised in various\nhospitals in Nairobi with another 36 admitted Mon 4 Sep 2017, after\ncontracting the disease. They were part of a group of 430 officers\ndeployed to Nairobi ahead of the Supreme Court ruling on presidential\npoll petition on Fri 1 Sep 2017. They were residing at the\nMultimedia University Hotel in Rongai, about 17 kilometers 10.6 mi\nsouth of the capital. \"Those infected did not get the disease from the Multimedia University\nsince they had their lunch away from the institution. Investigations\nshow that the source is the Nairobi Area Police Canteen,\" said Dr\nRalph Muli, the Nairobi County head of Diseases Surveillance.\nConsequently, the City has temporarily closed the canteen. The Health Cabinet Secretary Cleopa Mailu said the officers were in\nstable condition. Dr Mailu said investigations were underway to\nestablish whether the canteen had outsourced services to cater for the\nlarge number of officers. He said the ministry was concerned that\ninstead of eliminating cholera, new cases were emerging. Nairobi was first hit by the outbreak on 19 May 2017, with 56 cases\nhaving been reported. One of the police officers who requested anonymity said they ate ugali\n(a Kenyan staple made of maize flour) and meat stew at the canteen on\nSat 2 Sep 2017. He said he started feeling sick in the evening. Byline: Lillian Mutavi \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Cholera - Kenya (Tana River county).\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017 10:33 AM.\nSource: KDRTV News, The Daily Nation report (edited)\n(http://www.kdrtv.com/21-people-test-positive-for-cholera-in-tana-river/) \nAt least 20 National Youth Service (NYS) officers have been infected\nwith cholera in Tana River county. County health officials said the 20\nofficers from Bura NYS camp have been admitted to the Bura Sub-County\nHospital. According to Oscar Endekwa, the County Director for Public\nHealth, 21 cholera cases have been reported in the county. Speaking to Nation in his office in Hola, Dr Endekwa said the\nsituation at the NYS camp was under control. \"The officers are\nresponding well to treatment. The other case is of a resident and he\nhas been placed under treatment,\" he said. He added that the symptoms\nwere noted on August 30, though they had not been confirmed, adding\nthat health officials are investigating the cause of the disease. Besides isolating victims, Dr Endekwa said the county is also\nsensitizing residents on hygiene and sanitation. \"We are trying to\ncombat it before it spreads to a larger population,\" he added. He\nasked residents to report any suspicious cases and urged them to drink\nclean water and wash their hands after visiting toilets. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Cholera - Nigeria (Borno state) IDPs.\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017 2:10 AM WAT.\nSource: Daily Trust (edited)\n(https://www.dailytrust.com.ng/cholera-outbreak-kills-7-idps-in-borno.html) \nOn 3 Sep 2017, 7 internally displaced persons (IDPs) were confirmed\ndead as a result of a cholera outbreak at some IDP camps in Borno\nState This came just 3 weeks after about 100 others were discharged\nfrom Muna and Dala Lawanti Cholera treatment centers. The Médecins\nSans Frontières (MSF) in Maiduguri said the cholera outbreak was due\nto downpours in the last 3 days that caused flood at the affected IDP\ncamps. The Commissioner of Health in the state, Dr Haruna Mshelia said\nmeasures had been taken to contain it from further spread. \"I cannot\ntell you the death toll, as I continue to visit all camps in Maiduguri\nand ensure that the epidemic does not further spread to claim more\nlives,\" he said. One of the rescue workers at Muna Garage IDP camp told newsmen that\nfor only yesterday 3 Sep 2017, they had admitted over 50 patients. \"We have holistic measures to address this cholera outbreak urgently\nalthough people are dying day by day. More than 100 people are\naffected so far, and 51 people were admitted. In the last 24 hours, we\nhave received over 50 patients at MSF's Cholera Treatment Unit at\nDala. Total patients admitted from the start of the outbreak till now\nis over 200 with 100 discharges and 7 dead,\" the rescue worker who\nspoke in confidence, said. The Medical Director of the Médecins Sans Frontières, Anna Cillers,\nalso told newsmen in Maiduguri measures had been put in place to\nprevent further spread of cholera across the metropolis and IDP\ncamps. Byline: Uthman Abubakar, Ibrahim Sawab, Omirin Olatunji \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Nigeria can be seen at\n(ttp://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/nigeria.pdf) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12103). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Cholera - Nigeria (Borno state) IDPs.\nDate: Tue 5 Sep 2017.\nSource: Medical Xpress (edited)\n(https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-09-death-toll-nigeria-cholera.html) \nThe death toll from a cholera outbreak in restive northeast Nigeria\nhas risen to 21, with most of the victims living in a camp for people\ndisplaced by Boko Haram violence, the health ministry said Tue 5 Sep\n2017. On Sat 2 Sep 2017, the ministry had said the cholera toll was 14 in\nthe town of Maiduguri, with most of the victims living in a camp for\npeople displaced by Boko Haram violence. \"As of 4 Sep 2017, 21 deaths\nhave been reported,\" the Borno state health ministry said, as the toll\nmounts. \"The total number of suspected cholera cases is now 375 in\nMaiduguri,\" it said, up from 186 at the weekend. Most of the suspected\ncases and deaths are in Muna Garage, a camp for displaced people on\nthe outskirts of Maiduguri, while other victims come from neighboring\ndistricts, it said. The government and NGOs are working to contain the outbreak which has\nspread to the town of Dikwa, 60 kilometres (40 miles) away, where 5\ncases had been reported, it added. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Cholera - Sudan.\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, Radio Dabanga report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/west-darfur-camp-records-six-cholera-deaths) \nWest Darfur\n\nA sheikh in Murnei camp for displaced people told Radio Dabanga that\nby Sun 3 Sep 2017, a total of 22 patients were admitted to the\ncamp's isolation ward. From 27 Aug until 31 Aug 2017, 17 people\nreportedly succumbed to cholera. In Zamzam camp, south of El Fasher\ncity, 4 new cases of cholera were recorded on 1 and 2 Sep 2017. A camp\nelder told this station that the isolation ward was closed on the 1st\nday of Eid Al Adha Sacrifice Feast, 31 Aug-4 Sep 2017, \"because of\nthe absence of medical personnel, so the 4 new patients had to be\ntransferred to El Fasher for treatment.\" Central Darfur\n\nIsolation centers in Zalingei and Abta village, Central Darfur,\nrecorded 3 deaths and 37 new infection cases from 1-3 Sep 2017,\naccording to the coordinator of camps in the state, El Shafee\nAbdallah. In Hamidiya camp, 3 cholera patients died and 13 people\ninfected with cholera reported to the isolation centre. Meanwhile in\nthe last 3 days, the Hassahissa, Khamsa Degaig and Teiba camps\nrecorded 17 new cases. The total number of hospitalized cholera cases\nin the Zalingei Royal Hospital amounted to 76 people as of Sun, 3 Sep\n2017. \"From 1-3 Sep 2017, the isolation center in Abta village near Zalingei\nrecorded 7 new cases. The people are from Abta, Tiri, Dirlo, and\nKalgo,\" El Shafee said. Blue Nile\n\nIn Blue Nile state, 2 people died from cholera and 31 people\ncontracted the disease in the localities Ed Damazin and El Roseires in\nthe last week. A medical source in the area told Radio Dabanga that\nthe Royal Hospital in Ed Damazin received 4 cholera cases of cholera,\nfrom Arquette North. \"2 of them died on Wed 30 Aug 2017.\" Another medical source reported that last week week of 28 Aug 2017,\nthe hospital received 25 cases of cholera from different parts of El\nRoseires. 4 cases were recorded in Gisan locality. \"El Roseires\nlocality recorded the highest number of casualties of all localities\nin Blue Nile. There is a severe neglect of the number of staff in the\nisolation wards, because they were off for the Eid Al Adha holiday.\" Blue Nile was the 1st state to report cases of cholera in September\n2016, or 'acute watery diarrhea' as the Sudanese government has\nreferred to it since the start of the cholera outbreak. A UK-based\nSudanese specialist told Radio Dabanga in January 2017 that cholera\n\"seems to be a stigma for the government.\" \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Sudan can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/States_of_Sudan) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/96). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Cholera, diarrhea - Eastern and Southern Africa Region.\nDate: Thu 31 Aug 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, UNICEF report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/somalia/bulletin-choleraawd-outbreaks-eastern-and-southern-africa-regional-update-31-august) \nMore than 100 780 cholera/AWD acute watery diarrhea cases and 1496\ndeaths (CFR: 1.5 percent) have been reported in 12 of 21 countries of\nEastern and Southern Africa Region (ESAR) since the beginning of 2017.\nThese countries include: Somalia, Kenya, South Sudan, Tanzania,\nBurundi, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Angola, Uganda, Zambia, and\nRwanda. Somalia accounts for 76.6 percent of the total cases reported\nin the outbreak in 2017, followed by South Sudan at 15.7 percent. In the past 2-3 weeks (weeks 32-34/6-27 Aug 2017), 6 out of the 21\ncountries in ESAR have reported active transmission of cholera/AWD\n(Burundi, Malawi, Somalia, South Sudan, Kenya, and Tanzania). Tanzania\nhas recorded the highest CFR (1.8 percent) followed by South Sudan\n(1.7 percent) in 2017. CFR for Somalia was above 2 percent at the\nbeginning of 2017 but has since dropped to 1.4 percent. Somalia\n-\nThere has been a decrease in the epidemic trend. During week 33 (week\nending 20 Aug 2017), 222 new cases and no deaths were reported in the\ncountry; compared to 282 cases reported in week 32 (week ending 13 Aug\n2017). Out of the 222 new cases, 97 were reported from South Central\nand 125 were from Somali land. Most affected regions are Banadir,\nTogdheer, Awdal, Mjeex, and Lower Jubba. Kenya\n\n4 out of the 47 counties (Garissa, Nairobi, Turkana, and Nakuru) have\nan active cholera outbreak. During week 33, 19 new cases were reported\ncompared to 69 cases in week 32. South Sudan\n\nMost affected populations are nomadic pastoralists and communities\nliving in hard to reach villages and cattle camps. There has been a\ndecrease in the epidemic trend over the past 3 weeks. During week 32,\n30 new cases were reported; compared to 102 cases including 1 death\n(CFR 1 percent) in week 31 (week ending 6 Aug 2017). Active\ntransmission reported in Kapoeta East, South and North, Tonj East,\nYirol East, Nyirol, Ayod, Duk, and Juba. Tanzania\n\nAn increase in epidemic trend. During week 34 (week ending 27 Aug\n2017), 102 new cases have been reported in Tanzanian mainland;\ncompared to 67 cases in week 33. Cases emerged from Mbeya, Iringa, and\nKatavi regions. Malawi\n\nThe current outbreak started within the catchment area of the Chikwawa\nHospital. 11 new cases have been reported in week 34; compared to 2\ncases reported in week 33. Burundi\n-\nThe first case of the current outbreak was identified on 13 Aug 2017\nfrom Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Since then there has been an\nincrease in the epidemic trend with 24 cases reported in week 34; as\ncompared to 13 cases reported in week 33. No death has been reported\nand most of the cases emerged from the city center of Nyanza Lac. Uganda\n\nNo confirmed case of cholera in 2017, only AWD cases reported. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The countries mentioned above can be seen located on the map of\nAfrica at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6075). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \nAsia\n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Cholera - Pakistan (Punjab).\nDate: Tue 5 Sep 2017 12:32 AM IST.\nSource: The Tribune India (edited)\n(http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/this-day-that-year/cholera-in-lahore/462284.html) \nWe understand that cholera is assuming a virulent form in Lahore\nPunjab and that strong and effective measures are called for to\ncombat and stamp out the disease. In Kucha Kharasian in Haveli Mian\nKhan it is said 4 persons were taken ill at about noon and died the\nsame day. The next day, 5 persons were taken ill of the same disease.\nIt is, of course, impossible for laymen to make out whether all these\ncases were of cholera, but the nature of the deaths would seem to\nsuggest the urgent need of effective action. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Pakistan can be seen at\n(http://www.mapsofworld.com/pakistan/pakistan-political-map.html) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2128). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ Aggressive interventions to stem outbreaks of cholera include\nproviding sources of clean water and a vaccination campaign. The\nfollowing is extracted from Lutwick LI, Preis J, Choi P: Cholera. In:\nChronic illness and disability: the pediatric gastrointestinal tract.\nGreydanus DE, Atay O, Merrick J (eds). NY: Nova Bioscience, 2017 (in\npress): \"For a variety of logistic, financial, and historical reasons,\nvaccines have not been available for cholera control programs outside\nof Viet Nam. Given as 2 or 3 dose courses, efficacy can be as high as\n60-80 per cent for at least 2-3 years but much shorter protection\nlengths in children younger than 5 years of age. Cost-effectiveness,\nespecially once an outbreak has occurred, had remained unproven until\nreports from Guinea (57) and Haiti (58) demonstrated utility. \"The current vaccines prequalified for use by WHO (59) are:\n- Dukoral (produced in Sweden) that contains several biotypes of O1\nwith recombinant cholera toxin B subunit, which also offers some\nprotection against enterotoxigenic _E. coli_;\n- Shanchol (produced in India) that contains biotypes of both O1 and\nO139 without the recombinant B unit. In a large study in Kolkata,\nIndia, a cluster-randomized, double blind, placebo-controlled study of\nthis product (60), the cumulative efficacy of the vaccine at 5 years\nwas 65 per cent (95 per cent CI 52-74, p less than 0.0001). A\nlocally-produced vaccine similar to this vaccine (mORCVAX) is produced\nin Viet Nam;\n- Euvichol (produced in South Korea) that, like Shanchol, contains\nboth O1 and O139 without recombinant B subunit. This vaccine has been\nreported to be non-inferior to Shanchol in a Philippine study (61). \"In June 2016, the US FDA for the 1st time approved a cholera vaccine\nfor use locally in travelers to cholera-endemic areas. This vaccine,\nVaxchora, is an oral live, attenuated biologic (62) that is a\nreformulation of a previous product. This product, a single dose\nimmunization also referred to as CVD 102-HgR, must be stored in the\nfrozen state and as a live, attenuated bacterial vaccine is not given\nuntil at least 14 days after antibacterials were used and should be\ngiven at least 10 days before oral chloroquine antimalarial\nprophylaxis. Single dose use is an advantage over the older\ninactivated products which are given in 2 doses. Studies, however,\nhave suggested that one dose of these inactivated oral vaccines can be\neffective when the vaccines are in short supply in both endemic and\noutbreak situations (63, 64). \"References\n\n57. Luquero FJ, Grout L, Ciglenecki I, et al. Use of _Vibrio cholerae_\nvaccine in an outbreak in Guinea. N Engl J Med. 2014; 370(22):\n2111-2120; (http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1312680).\n58. Sévère K, Rouzier V, Anglade SB, et al. Effectiveness of oral\ncholera vaccine in Haiti: 37-month follow-up. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2016;\n94(5): 1136-1142;\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.15-0700).\n59. Bhattacharya SK, Sur D, Ali M, et al. 5 year efficacy of a\nbivalent killed whole-cell oral cholera vaccine in Kolkata, India: a\ncluster-randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Lancet Inf\nDis. 2013; 13(12): 1050-1056;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(13)70273-1/fulltext).\n60. WHO. WHO prequalified vaccines.\n(https://extranet.who.int/gavi/PQ_Web/).\n61. Balk YO, Choi SK, Olveda RM, et al. A randomized, non-inferiority\ntrial comparing two bivalent killed, whole cell, oral cholera vaccines\n(Euvichol vs Shanchol) in the Philippines. Vaccine 2015; 33(46):\n6350-65; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26348402).\n62. Freedman DO. Re-born in the USA: another cholera vaccine for\ntravellers. Travel Med Infect Dis. 2016; 14(4): 295-6; abstract\navailable at\n(http://www.travelmedicinejournal.com/article/S1477-8939(16)30087-4/abstract).\n63. Qadri F, Wierzba TF, Ali M, et al. Efficacy of a single dose,\ninactivated oral cholera vaccine in Bangladesh. N Engl J Med. 2016;\n374(18): 1723-32;\n(http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1510330).\n64. Azman AS, Parker LA, Rumunu J, et al. Effectiveness of one dose of\noral cholera vaccine in response to an outbreak: a case-cohort study.\nLancet Global Health 2016; 4(11): e856-e863;\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/langlo/article/PIIS2214-109X(16)30211-X/fulltext).\"\n- Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]},"311":{"title":"PRO/AH/EDR> Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Uganda (02)","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Crimean-Congo hem. fever - Uganda (02)","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: 4 Sep 2017. Source: Outbreak News Today (edited) (http://outbreaknewstoday.com/crimean-congo-hemorrhagic-fever-outbreak-central-uganda-98860/)   There has been a Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever CCHF outbreak in central Uganda. Eight cases, including 2 deaths have been reported from Nakaseke and Kiboga districts as of 28 Aug 2017.  The Ministry of Health, the Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries, and CDC deployed a multi-disciplinary rapid response team to the 2 districts to conduct outbreak investigation and rapid risk assessment. The epidemiology team is in the field to investigate the source of the outbreak and conduct contact tracing.  CCHF is known to be endemic in Uganda, especially in the cattle corridor, which is a strip of land spanning across 18 districts, from the southwest to the northeast of the country. Smaller intermittent outbreaks have been reported in the past. The last outbreak occurred in August 2013, during which 6 cases were reported.  The simultaneous occurrence of the current outbreak in 2 neighboring districts may be indicative of a larger burden of the disease than expected. The current drought in some parts of the country could heighten the risk of the disease spreading to other areas as a result of livestock movement in search of pasture and water.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The current report indicates that at least 2 adjacent districts have reported CCHF cases, located mainly in cattle raising areas. It is important to reach out with public health education focusing on several aspects, including use of protective clothing such as long sleeves and trousers. People should be advised to wear light coloured clothes during a visit to the animal market to allow easy detection of ticks, and to regularly examine clothing and skin for ticks, and, if found, removing them safely, and using approved repellents on clothing and skin. Furthermore, studies may be planned to map the distribution of the tick species, particularly in the cattle belt region. - Mod.UBA  A map showing the districts of Uganda can be found at: (http://guidetouganda.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/03/UgandaBig.jpg).- Mod.MPP  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Ukraine":{"38":{"title":"African swine fever - Europe (18): Czech Republic (ZK)\r\n\twild boar, spread, control ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> African swine fever - Europe (18): Czech Republic (ZK)\r\n\twild boar, spread, control [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nAFRICAN SWINE FEVER - EUROPE (18): CZECH REPUBLIC (ZLIN) WILD BOAR,\nSPREAD, CONTROL\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org). Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017.\nSource: Web-site of the Czech State Veterinary Administration Czech,\nMach transl, edited\n(https://www.svscr.cz/africky-mor-prasat-aktualni-informace/) \nAs of the above date, 159 dead feral pigs have been recorded by the\nState Veterinary Administration in the Zlín Region. African swine\nfever ASF has been confirmed in 90 of them; in 69 cases, the test\nwas negative. The number of feral pigs caught in the part of the infected area where\nthey may be hunted (green zone) for map, see commentary increased to\n96; all tested ASF negative. In the area with intensive catches, 1917 wild boars have been shot.\nMost of them, in the districts of Kroměříž (454), Uherské\nHradiště (401) and Vsetín (263). In all cases, the result of the\nASF examination was negative. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n(http://www.cvlonghorns.de)\n(cvlonghorns@aol.com) Maps presenting the various zones as implemented in the Czech\nRepublic in relation to ASF, including the ones with prescribed\ncatching intensities of feral pigs, and the numbers/locations of the\nshot/collected animals, are available at\n(https://www.svscr.cz/amp-mapy/). The titles of the (8) maps can be\ngoogle-translated; please note that AMP (in Czech) stands for ASF. The Czech Republic has submitted to the OIE its most recent follow-up\nreport on ASF (No 8) on Thu 17 Aug 2017, reporting 3 new outbreaks\nin feral pigs. The said report, as well as new follow-up ASF reports\nfrom Ukraine, Russia and Poland, submitted to the OIE on 17-18 Aug\n2017, can be accessed at\n(http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/WI/index/newlang/en). A global, interactive OIE map presenting all ASF outbreaks since the\nstart of 2017, updated Fri 18 Aug 2017, is available at\n(http://tinyurl.com/y8hgscdh) (click on the central-European cluster,\nzoom in). The Czech event is currently the most western one, causing\nconcerns of further spread in Western Europe. It is separated by (so\nfar, uninfected) Slovakia from the closest outbreak on its east,\nsouth-western Ukraine. Poland, where ASF has been circulating on the eastern regions since\nFeb 2014, is now confronting the virus also on its south-west, namely\nthe Czech event. Krzysztof Jurgiel, Minister of Agriculture and Rural\nDevelopmentthe, has responded this week week of Sun 13 Aug 2017 to\nstatements by politicians who related to ASF as a zoonotic disease\nrisking human health. The Minister denied any publich health risk in\nrelation to ASF, quoting a detailed letter from Prof. Krzysztof\nNiemczuk, the Director of Poland's State Scientific Institute of\nVeterinary Medicine. See, in Polish, at\n(http://www.minrol.gov.pl/pol/Ministerstwo/Biuro-Prasowe/Informacje-Prasowe/Nieodpowiedzialne-wypowiedzi-nt.-ASF).\n(thanks to Sabine Zentis for the link). According to OIE's Manual of Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines for\nTerrestrial Animals, \"ASF is not a zoonotic disease and does not\naffect public health (Sánchez-Vizcaíno et al., 2009)\". - Mod.AS A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62211). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"43":{"title":"African swine fever - Europe (19): Ukraine (DP), domestic\r\n\tswine, OIE ","date":["17","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> African swine fever - Europe (19): Ukraine (DP), domestic\r\n\tswine, OIE [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 17 Aug 2017. Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(33) (edited) (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24583)   African swine fever (ASF), Ukraine - Information received on and dated 17 Aug 2017 from Dr Andrii Zhuk, first deputy head of the State Service of Ukraine on Food Safety and Consumer Production, International Cooperation of the State Service of Ukraine on Food Safety and Consumer Protection, UKR Ministry of Agrarian Policy and Food, Kiev, Ukraine  Summary Report type: immediate notification Date of start of the event: 14 Aug 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 16 Aug 2017 Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease Date of previous occurrence: 12 Mar 2017 Manifestation of disease: clinical disease Causal agent: African swine fever virus Nature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic) This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.  New outbreaks (1) Summary of outbreaks: \nTotal outbreaks: 1 Outbreak 1: Slovyanka, Apostolivskyi, Dnepropetrovsk Dnipro Date of start of the outbreak: 14 Aug 2017 Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: backyard Affected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Swine / 2 / 2 / 2 / 0 / 0  Outbreak statistics rates apparent, expressed as percentages Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost* Swine / 100 / 100 / 100 / 100 *Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter  Epidemiology Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive  Control measures Measures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, traceability, quarantine, official destruction of animals products, official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste, control of wildlife reservoirs, zoning, disinfection, disinfestations, ante and post mortem inspections, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals Measures to be applied: no other measures  Diagnostic test results Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result State Scientific and Research Institute of Laboratory Diagnosis and Veterinary and Sanitary Expertise (national laboratory) / swine / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 16 Aug 2017 / Positive  Future reporting The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.  The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  On 17 Aug 2017 new outbreaks of ASF have also been reported in the provinces of Zakarpats'ka Zakarpattia (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24580) and Rovno (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24584).  Maps of Ukraine can be seen at (http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/ukraine-political-map.htm), (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/57627) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/123). Maps of Dnipro, Dnipropetrovsk, Ukraine can be seen at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/58111). - Mod.CRD  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"54":{"title":"Measles update (42): Europe, Middle East, Africa, Pacific\r\n\t","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Measles update (42): Europe, Middle East, Africa, Pacific\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nMEASLES UPDATE (42): EUROPE, MIDDLE EAST, AFRICA, PACIFIC\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\nEurope\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Romania\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> France (Ardèche) Middle East\n\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Israel ex Ukraine Africa\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Uganda (Kampala, Wakiso) Pacific\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia) \n\nEurope\n\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Romania.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Romanian Business News-ACT Media (edited)\n(http://actmedia.eu/daily/healthmin-bodog-measles-epidemic-consequence-of-major-malfunctions-in-vaccination-public-policy/70944) \nA total of 8493 confirmed measles cases had been reported by Fri 11\nAug 2017, since the outbreak of the disease in 2016, informs a\nrelease on the website of the National Center for the Surveillance and\nControl of Communicable Diseases of the National Public Health\nInstitute. Among these cases there were 32 deaths, as follows: 8 in\nTimis County, 6 in Arad, 7 in Dolj, 3 in Caras-Severin, and one in\neach Bihor, Cluj, Calarasi, Satu Mare, Vaslui, Galati, Mures, and\nBucharest. Measles outbreaks have been registered in all 41 counties,\nthe most affected  with over 1000 cases each  being Timis (1215\ncases), Caras-Severin (1110), and Arad (1002). The measles outbreak in Romania in 2016 is not circumstantial, but a\ndirect consequence of the \"major\" malfunctions in public policy\nregarding vaccination, minister of health Florian Bodog stated on Fri\n11 Aug in a press release. \"For years now Romania has been below the\nsafety threshold of vaccination coverage. That is, the risk of a\nmeasles outbreak was imminent. Which is what actually happened. The\noutbreak of the measles epidemic in 2016 is not conjectural, it is a\ndirect consequence of major malfunctions in the public policy on\nvaccination,\" the minister of health stated. According to him, the Vaccination Law corrects the irregularities that\nled to the epidemic, providing the best conditions for protecting\nchildren's health. \"For Romania, the stake of the vaccination bill is\nhuge. Ensuring a healthy future for 4 million children lies in our\nhands. The Romanian parliament, the highest institution of democracy,\nwill decide on the final content of this law. However, beyond the\ndebates in parliament, it is important that all the public opinion be\ninformed and understand the true meaning of the law and the profound\nchanges it brings. (..) We have a moral duty towards our children, to\nprevent harm before it happens. As we also have a moral duty to the\ncommunity in which we live to prevent harm before it happens to other\nchildren or parents,\" Bodog said, quoted in the press release. He added that any bill is amendable and that is why it is open to any\npublic debates as long as they are carried out with honesty, good\nsense and decency. \"But this project is the day-to-day work of\nspecialists in the field of vaccination and who have faced all the\nflaws of the current framework. That is why the law has been carefully\nand correctly thought through by those who best understand how to\nregulate the vaccination policy,\" the minister of health also said. The bill on the organisation and funding of public vaccination in\nRomania was adopted by the government on Wed 9 Aug 2017. The bill\nwas submitted to parliament for debate and adoption. The normative act\nwould come into force on 1 Jan 2018. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) A similar report can be found in El Pais (12 Aug 2017) which states\nin addition that, of the 95 per cent vaccine coverage recommended by\nthe World Health Organization (WHO), 86 per cent have been\nvaccinated since 2007, according to its national epidemiological\ncentre. \"Highly worrying\" figures, acknowledged the prime minister,\nMihai Tudose, this week. \"More than 180 000 children in our country,\nfrom 9 months to 9 years, are not immunized against measles. In some\nregions, the rate of immunization of the 2nd dose does not reach 50\nper cent; and this is very serious.\" Timis and Caras-Severin, Arad\n(all to the west of the country, near the border with Serbia or\nHungary), are the most affected, with more than 1000 measles cases\neach, reported in the last 10 months when the outbreak was declared. According to official estimates, nearly 50 000 children without\nimmunization are not even registered with a family doctor. Most is due\nto serious problems of social exclusion.
