Submitted by Kathryn Soderholm (kathryn.soderholm@gmail.com) from\nProMED-ESP archive no http://promedmail.org/post/20170814.5248771 and\ntranslated by Mod.LK Maps of Romania can be found at\n(http://www.geoatlas.com/medias/maps/countries/romania/ro111aa/romania_pol.jpg)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/122). - Mod.LK \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> France (Ardèche).\nDate: Thu 17 Aug 2017 11:39 CEST.\nSource: Silver Times (edited)\n(https://sivertimes.com/ardeche-four-hospitalizations-related-to-a-measles-outbreak/64380) \nA measles outbreak was declared in Ardoix, in the northern Ardèche,\nreports France Blue. 6 people  2 adults and 4 children, including\nsome infants  were infected by the virus between early July and 9\nAug 2017. 4 patients had to be hospitalized. The 6 people are now\nout of danger, and the 4 hospitalised patients were able to return\nhome, says the regional Agency of health (ARS), Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes,\ncited by France Bleu. These are all people who live or work in this\nsmall town of 1100 habitats. The ARS called for vigilance and prompted the inhabitants of the\nnorthern Ardèche, to consult a doctor in case of fever and appearance\nof buttons rash. It alerted on the very high contagiousness of the\nvirus that can infect up to 20 people around a sick person, and they\ncan produce severe, even life-threatening disease  in fact, there is\nno curative treatment for measles. In addition, the ARS has been reported to France Bleu that the recent\nconfirmed cases of measles in Ardoix were unvaccinated. According to\nthe figures of the LRA, 71 per cent of the inhabitants of the Ardèche\nregion are vaccinated against measles, which is 10 per cent less than\nthe national average. The government has confirmed its willingness to make mandatory 8\nvaccines, including measles. On this disease, \"Vaccination coverage\namong children at 2 years of age reaches only 78 per cent. As long as\nit does not reach the 95 per cent the risk of epidemic wave periodic\nwill persist\", has declared Agnès Buzyn. Measles has made its 1st victim in France at the end of July 2017. A\nyoung girl, a 16 year old native of Nice, has succumbed to this\ninfectious disease in the hospital North of Marseille, after having\nbeen hospitalized in intensive care for 3 weeks. The girl had never\nbeen vaccinated against measles. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of France can be seen at\n(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/France#Administrative_divisions) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62734). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ \nMiddle East\n\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Israel ex Ukraine.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017 18:11 IDT.\nSource: The Jerusalem Post (edited)\n(http://www.jpost.com/Israel-News/Politics-And-Diplomacy/Nine-soldiers-recover-after-being-infected-with-measles-502391) \nThe IDF Israeli Defense Forces said on Mon 14 Aug 2017 that 9\nsoldiers diagnosed last week week of 7 Aug 2017 with the highly\ninfectious measles are all recovering and have returned to duty.\nAccording to the IDF, the soldiers all had mild cases of the disease\nand did not serve in the same unit. The index case had just returned from visiting family in the Ukraine\nwhere he likely contracted the disease. When he returned to Israel he\nvisited a clinic where he infected 8 other soldiers who were waiting\nin line to see a physician. \"The IDF, together with the Health\nMinistry, carried out an investigation to locate the cases and\nidentify the source of the infection,\" the army said in a statement,\nadding that all those who had contact with the soldiers had been\ngiven preventative treatment. An IDF spokesman told The Jerusalem Post\nthat the soldier who contracted the disease had 2 stopovers in Europe\non his way back to Israel from the Ukraine but was not able to specify\nwhich countries. WHO in March 2017 warned of a measles outbreak sweeping across\nEurope in places where immunization rates have plummeted. The figures\ncover the agency's entire European region  53 countries including\nIsrael, Kazakhstan, and Russia. According to WHO 559 measles cases\nwere reported in Europe between January and March 2017. While the\nlargest current measles outbreaks in Europe were reported in Romania\nand Italy, other countries reporting cases were France, Germany,\nPoland, Switzerland, and the Ukraine. \"With steady progress toward\nelimination over the past 2 years, it is of particular concern that\nmeasles cases are climbing in Europe,\" said Dr Zsuzsanna Jakab, WHO\nregional director for Europe. \"Today's travel patterns put no person\nor country beyond the reach of the measles virus. Outbreaks will\ncontinue in Europe, as elsewhere, until every country reaches the\nlevel of immunization needed to fully protect their populations.\" Israeli children are routinely immunized with the MMR measles, mumps,\nrubella vaccine which are given in 2 doses, at 1 year and a booster\nin the 1st grade. The Health Ministry has stated that the level of\nvaccine coverage in Israel is among the highest in the West, with 97\nper cent coverage for 1st and 2nd doses MMR and chickenpox vaccine. While no vaccine is 100 per cent effective, an infectious disease\nspecialist told the Post that measles is \"a nasty illness\" that is\npreventable by proper immunization. But while it is highly recommended\nby medical professionals and the Health Ministry, the vaccine is not\nmandatory and according to the IDF the measles vaccine is not part of\nthe vaccines given to new recruits. \"We cannot afford to have soldiers\nwho are severely ill with a highly contagious disease. It would be\nappropriate for the IDF to verify and update immunizations of all\npersonnel and new recruits,\" the infectious disease specialist told\nthe Post. Measles is spread by coughing and sneezing and close contact with\ninfected individuals. While most infected people usually experience\nonly mild symptoms it is one of the leading causes of death among\nyoung children globally. Measles takes about 8-12 days following\ncontact before the individual will show symptoms which include a\nfever, bad cough, red eyes, and a runny nose. A few days after the\nrespiratory symptoms, the infected individual will get a bad rash.\nOther complications of measles include gastroenteritis (diarrhea and\nvomiting), pneumonia, severe bleeding problems, and in some rare cases\nencephalitis (brain infections). In June 2017, 5 cases of measles were reported to the Health\nMinistry  all of them women between the ages of 20-40 who lived in\nJerusalem. byline: Anna Ahronheim \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Even with 97 per cent vaccine coverage, measles virus can cause small\noutbreaks. But these outbreaks won't be able to expand to cause\nsignificant disease in the protected population. HealthMap/ProMED-mail maps\nIsrael: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90)\nUkraine: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/123)\n- Mod.LK \nAfrica\n\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Uganda (Kampala, Wakiso).\nDate: Tue 15 Aug 2017.\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, The EastAfrican report (edited)\n(http://reliefweb.int/report/uganda/uganda-plans-mass-measles-vaccination) \nUganda's Health Ministry has said it is rolling out a mass\nimmunisation campaign against measles for children under the age of\nfive, as a measure to control an outbreak of the disease in the\ncapital Kampala and the neighbouring district of Wakiso, where 67\ncases were reported in July 2017. \"The Ministry of Health is\nundertaking a number of measures to control the spread of the disease,\nincluding investigating the extent of its spread in Kampala and\nWakiso,\" said director of health services, Prof Anthony Mbonye. Measles is an airborne disease that affects mostly children between\nthe ages of 6 months and 10 years, although it can also affect\nadults. Although Prof Mbonye said there was no cause for alarm, he urged the\npublic to be vigilant and report any suspected cases to the nearest\nhealth facilities. The public has also been urged to look out for\ncommon early symptoms associated with the disease, which include high\nfever, cough, red swelling eyelids and muscle and body irritability. According to the Ministry of Health, an estimated 20 per cent of\npeople who get infected with measles often develop complications,\nwhich if not managed early enough can lead to death. Despite previous\nmass vaccination campaigns, Uganda has had several outbreaks of the\ndisease. Prof Mbonye blamed it on parents who do not take their\nchildren for immunisation at the right time. Current national\nimmunisation coverage stands at 85 per cent. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) According to WHO, in 2016 global vaccination coverage (all vaccines)\nwas stalled at 86 per cent, with no significant changes during the\npast year. For measles alone, by the end of 2016, 85 per cent of\nchildren had received 1 dose of vaccine by their 2nd birthday, and 164\ncountries had included a 2nd dose as part of routine immunization; 64\nper cent of children received 2 doses of measles vaccine according to\nnational immunization schedules. It is generally thought that because\nmeasles is such a highly transmissible disease, that 90-95 per cent of\npeople must be vaccinated in order to protect the entire population,\nor achieve herd immunity. Maps of Uganda can be seen at\n(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Districts_of_Uganda) and\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/97) - Mod.LK \nPacific\n\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Australia (Perth, Western Australia).\nDate: Fri 18 Aug 2017 9:58 AM AWST.\nSource: The West Australian (edited)\n(https://thewest.com.au/news/wa/third-case-of-measles-among-students-at-steiner-school-ng-b88572888z) \nHealth authorities have confirmed a 3rd case of measles in a student\nfrom the Perth Waldorf School Western Australia, WA and warned there\ncould be more. This is the 2nd student to be infected from an\nunvaccinated high school student at the Bibra Lake school who\ncontracted measles while on holiday in Italy. Before being diagnosed,\nand while still infectious, the student was at the school and other\nlocations in Perth. The WA Health Department's Virus Watch bulletin said the 2 confirmed\nsecondary measles cases were in unvaccinated students. \"All 3 attend a\nsouthern suburbs school with a low rate of vaccination, and further\ncases remain possible,\" it said. byline: Cathy O'Leary \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) Maps of Australia can be seen at\n(http://maps.unomaha.edu/peterson/funda/MapLinks/Australia/Australia_files/image001.gi)\nand (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/62426). - Mod.LK ","keywordsMatched":[]},"175":{"title":"African swine fever - Europe (21): Czech Rep, Romania,\r\n\tPoland, wild boar, spread ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> African swine fever - Europe (21): Czech Rep, Romania,\r\n\tPoland, wild boar, spread [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nAFRICAN SWINE FEVER - EUROPE (21): CZECH REPUBLIC, ROMANIA, POLAND,\nWILD BOAR, SPREAD\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this posting:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Czech Rep, Romania\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Poland, fence considered \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Czech Rep, Romania.\nDate: Wed 30 Aug 2017.\nSource: Pig Progress net (edited)\n(http://www.pigprogress.net/Health/Articles/2017/8/ASF-update-Czech-Republic-approaches-100-reports-177268E/) \nAlthough the outbreaks seem to be contained to one region of the Czech\nRepublic, African Swine Fever ASF continues to make victims among\nthe country's wild boar population. The total amount of dead wild boars discovered in the woods around\nZlín, in the far east of the Czech Republic, stood at 94 at the end\nof August 2017. In this month, 23 new infected carcasses were found,\nwhich is a downward trend from July 2017, when 68 reports were sent\nto the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE). The 1st report of\nASF in Czech wild boars was on Wed 21 Jun 2017. Many neighbouring countries have alerted their local pig producers to\nbe very careful what to feed their pigs - and their inhabitants what\nto purchase and how to dispose of it. So did Slovakia, according to\nthe Slovak Spectator. Zlín is only a few km away from the western\nSlovak border, to its north is Poland where ASF has been around since\n2014 and on its eastern border is Ukraine, where ASF has been\nconfirmed since 2011. In a presentation, given in mid-July 2017 to the European\nCommission's Standing Committee On Animals, Plants, Food and Feed\n(SCoPAFF), Dr Petr Šatrán of the Czech State Veterinary\nAdministration indicated that human activities are most likely the\ncause of the spread of the virus, seeing that the nearest reported\ncases of ASF were roughly 500 km 310.68 mi away and that the\npositive dead wild boars were found in inhabited areas. In the other country where ASF was found for the 1st time in 2017,\nRomania, things appear relatively quiet. News broke early this month\nAugust 2017 that ASF was also found on 2 backyard farms in the north\nof the country. Ever since, the Romanian authorities did not report\nany further outbreaks of ASF to the OIE. Of all other countries in the European Union, especially Poland has\ncontinued to report outbreaks of African Swine Fever in smaller and\nmiddle-sized operations. In August alone, on 23 farm sites of various\nsizes, ASF was found to have infected at least one animal, after which\nthe entire herd would have to be culled. The biggest operation in this respect was a farm near Monki, Podlaskie\nprovince, where all remaining 431 pigs had to be culled after 11 had\ndied as a result of ASF, on Sat 19 Aug 2017. Noteworthy as well was\nthe ASF-related closure of 2 farms in Lack, Lubelskie province, in\nearly August. These farms had 136 and 141 pigs respectively see also\nitem 2. Byline: Vincent ter Beek \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nSabine Zentis\nCastleview English Longhorns\nGut Laach\nD-52385 Nideggen\nGermany\n(http://www.cvlonghorns.de)\n(cvlonghorns@aol.com) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Poland, fence considered.\nDate: Sat 2 Sep 2017.\nSource: Current News summ., edited\n(http://currentlynews.us/articles/poland-will-18857) \nPoland wants to build along the border with Belarus and Ukraine a\nfence preventing migration of wild boars  carriers of the African\nSwine fever ASF. This was said by Poland's Minister of Agriculture,\nKrzysztof Yurgel, Niezalezna reports. As reported, the length of the fence will be 729 km 452.98 mi,\ncosting Poland 130 million zloties (more than 36.2 million USD). The\nfinal decision on a fence will be made within the next 3 weeks. According to experts, ASF has developed in the territory of Poland\n\"thanks to\" the wild boars who entered from Belarus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The accumulated ASF OIE data from Poland as of Thu 31 Aug 2017, are\nas follows (start of event 22 May 2014):\nNumber of follow-up reports: 189\nTotal outbreaks: 550 (Submitted)\nSpecies/ Susceptible/ Cases/ Deaths/ Killed and disposed of/\nSlaughtered\nWild boar/ - / 620 / 620 / 0 / 0\nDomestic Swine/ 6303/ 402/ 188/ 6097/ 0 A map showing ASF cases reported globally to the OIE since 1 Jan 2017,\nas of Thu 31 Aug 2017, is available at (http://tinyurl.com/ybexasqm).\nClick on the European cluster, zoom in to each of the countries of\ninterest. EU disease control measures require designation of risk areas as Part\nI (wild boar at risk, but no cases found), Part II (wild boar testing\npositive but no spill over into domestic pigs), Part III (cases in\nwild boar and occasional spill over into domestic pigs) and Part IV\nwhich concerns the island of Sardinia only. Consignments of live pigs,\nlive wild boars, meat of either source and animal by-products of\neither source are only allowed under certain derogations. For a full\nexplanation, see European Commission Implementing Decision\n2014/708/EU. ASF, a viral disease against which no vaccine has become available so\nfar, is currently threatening central and western Europe, where dense\npopulations of wild boar are present. According to a recent update of DEFRA (UK) ASF situation assessment,\nthe continuing cases in the Czech Republic, the spread in Poland which\nappears to be due to several breakdowns in biosecurity and the new\noutbreaks in Romania are \"concerning\". This signifies a spread in\ngeographic distribution, a possible drop in biosecurity awareness and\ntherefore an increase in the weight of infection in East Europe. Despite the relatively low level of trade in live pigs, there could be\na substantial movement of people, vehicles and personal imports of\npork products, therefore the risk of ASF introduction to the UK has\nbeen raised from \"very low\" (that is, \"rare but could occur\") to\n\"low\". The Russian veterinary watchdog Rosselkhoznadzor believes ASF will\nkeep moving west via 2 main pathways. The southerly route, has already\nseen the virus spread from Ukraine to Moldova. Russian vets believe it\ncould penetrate central Romania, then move to the Balkans, including\nBulgaria and Serbia. On the northern route, now that ASF has been found in the Czech\nRepublic, Rosselkhoznadzor believes, if it gains a foothold, it is\nlikely to head further west, with Germany next in the firing line. The\nsaid is included in a recent update by the Russian journalist\nVladislav Vorotnikov, available at\n(http://www.pig-world.co.uk/comment/where-next-for-african-swine-fever.html).\n- Mod.AS ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"United Arab Emirates":{"129":{"title":"MERS-CoV (56): UAE, Saudi Arabia (JF, HA, RI),\r\n\tWHO ","date":["29","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> MERS-CoV (56): UAE, Saudi Arabia (JF, HA, RI),\r\n\tWHO [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nMERS-COV (56): UNITED ARAB EMIRATES, SAUDI ARABIA (AL JAWF, HAIL,\nRIYADH), WHO\n\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> UAE, 1 new case - WHO\n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Saudi Arabia, 7 new cases - Saudi MOH 19-29 Aug 2017 \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> UAE, 1 new case - WHO.\nDate: Mon 28 Aug 2017.\nSource: WHO Emergencies preparedness, response, Disease Outbreak News\n(DONs) (edited)\n(http://www.who.int/csr/don/28-august-2017-mers-uae/en/) \nMiddle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) - United Arab\nEmirates\n\nOn 29 Jul 2017, the national IHR focal point of the United Arab\nEmirates reported one additional case of Middle East Respiratory\nSyndrome Coronavirus (MERS-CoV) Details of the case\n-\nMERS-CoV case reported on 29 July 2017*\nPlease note, data corresponds to Disease Outbreak News as published on\n28 Aug 2017.\n* Data subject to change due to ongoing investigations. Fields related\nto the final status of the case are updated as information is\navailable.\nNA = Not available Date of notification to WHO / Reporting country / City of residence /\nAge / Sex / Health care worker / Comorbidities / Exposure to camels /\nCamel milk consumption / Exposure to MERS-CoV cases / Date of symptoms\nonset / Date of 1st hospitalization / Date of laboratory confirmation\n/ Status\n29 Jul 2017 / United Arab Emirates / Al Ain / 54 / M / No / No / NA /\nNA / No / 11 Jul 2017 / 25 Jul 2017 / Alive The patient, who lives and works in Al Ain, United Arab Emirates,\npresented at a hospital in Al Ain on 16 Jul 2017. On 16 Jul 2017,\na chest X-ray showed pneumonia and he was treated with antibiotics and\nnon-invasive ventilation. On 25 Jul 2017, his symptoms worsened and\na sputum sample was collected and tested for MERS-CoV and influenza.\nOn 26 Jul 2017, showing no signs of improvement, the patient was\ntransferred to a 2nd hospital in Al Ain and placed in an intensive\ncare unit. A 2nd sputum sample was collected on 26 Jul 2017 and both samples\ntested positive for MERS-CoV on 27 Jul 2017. The patient is\ncurrently in ICU on mechanical ventilation. Investigations into the\nsource of infection are ongoing. At the time of writing the results of\nthe investigation were not yet provided to WHO. Globally, 2067 laboratory-confirmed cases of infection with MERS-CoV\nincluding at least 720 related deaths have been reported to WHO. Public health response\n-\nThe Ministry of Health in Abu Dhabi carried out contact tracing and\nfollowed up 89 health care workers and 95 contacts at his place of\nemployment. All identified contacts were monitored for 14 days from\nthe last date of exposure. No additional cases were detected. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp I have been unable to find additional information on both official\nsources as well as unofficial sources of information related to the\ncase described in the UAE in the above WHO report. Of note is that the\nevent (identification of a MERS-CoV infected individual) actually\noccurred a month ago  the date of report of this case to WHO was 29\nJul 2017, with the date of onset of symptoms 11 Jul 2017 and date of\npositive laboratory testing for MERS-CoV of 25 Jul 2017. Information\non results of contact tracing continuing until 14 days following last\nknown contact with the case (one incubation period) was available for\nall contacts. Hence, this is a nice historical archive of\nidentification of a sporadic case of MERS-CoV infection, although the\ninformation on the investigation of possible high risk exposures of\nthe actual case is not available at present. This is now the 5th case of MERS-CoV infection identified in the UAE\nthis year, with 2 previous cases in May 2017 from Al Ain, and 2\nadditional previous cases from Abu Dhabi reported in April 2017,\nbringing the total number of cases reported by the UAE since 2012 up\nto 84. Al Ain is a major inland city of the UAE, belonging to the Abu Dhabi\nemirate (see\n(https://www.mapsofworld.com/united-arab-emirates/maps/united-arab-emirates-cities-map.jpg)). Note that there was a recovery reported in a\n44-year-old expat female on 15 Aug 2017, suggesting either this is a\nduplicate report or there was a 2nd 44 year old expat female from\nJeddah reported that did not appear on the newly confirmed case\nreports on the Saudi MOH website. - Mod.MPP \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) In the 11 day period since the last update, there have been 7 newly\nconfirmed cases reported of whom 5 were from Dawmat Aljandal (Al Jawf\nregion), the location that had nosocomial transmission identified\nsince the beginning of this past month July 2017. Clearly\ntransmission is continuing in this area, with 3 newly confirmed\nsecondary cases in household contacts - at least 2 of whom were\nidentified through screening of asymptomatic household contacts, and 2\nadditional cases in which high risk exposures are still under\ninvestigation. We do not know if these household contacts are\nassociated with the earlier identified transmission chain in Dawmat\nAljandal or if these are newly identified chains of transmission. The\nother 2 newly confirmed cases involve \"sporadic\" cases - an individual\nin Hail whose high risk exposure history is still under investigation,\nand an individual from Alaflaj (Riyadh region) with a history of\ndirect contact with camels in the 14 days preceding onset of illness. As to be expected, concern is being voiced on the international level\nwith the upcoming Hajj and this recent increase in cases reported both\nin Saudi Arabia and in the UAE. We now have gone through 5 Hajj\nperiods since the identification of the MERS-CoV and to date there\nhave been no cases of MERS-CoV infection identified in returning\nHajjis. The case in the UAE (see section <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> above) actually had onset\nof illness over 1 month ago with no secondary cases/infections\nidentified among known contacts of this case. As for the cases in\nSaudi Arabia, and more specifically the Hajj, population movement is\nvery well defined during the Hajj, no camels are permitted in the\nareas where Hajjis are congregated, and there are Hajj specific health\nservices that are separate from those that are available for the\ngeneral Saudi population, all factors that are reducing the likelihood\nof Hajjis having inadvertent (or intentional) high risk exposures.\nHopefully my optimism is well placed and we will pass through a 6th\nHajj period without impact on international transmission of the\nMERS-CoV associated with this Hajj. Maps of Saudi Arabia showing the locations of the reported cases,\nfatality and recoveries can be found at the given URL's. Date: Wed 23 Aug 2017. Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(34) (edited) (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24622)   Foot and mouth disease, Nepal  Information received on 23 Aug 2017 from Dr Bimal Kumar Nirmal, Department of Livestock Services, Ministry of Livestock Development, Nepal  Summary Report type: immediate notification (final report) Date of start of the event: 2 Apr 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 6 Apr 2017 Report date: 22 Aug 2017 Date event resolved: 3 May 2017 Reason for notification: new strain of a listed disease in the country Causal agent: foot and mouth disease virus (lineage G-VII) Serotype: A Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic and advanced) This event pertains to the whole country.  New outbreaks (1) Summary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1 Outbreak 1: Chitwan, Bharatpur 4, Chitwan, Narayani Province Three Date of start of the outbreak: 2 Apr 2017 Outbreak status: resolved on 3 May 2017 Epidemiological unit: village Total animals affected: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / 17 / 17 / 0 / 0 / 0 Buffaloes / 3 / 3 / 0 / 0 / 0 Affected population: cattle and buffaloes reared in semi commercial small holder farms of Bharatpur 4, Chitwan were affected.  Outbreak statistics rates apparent, expressed as percentages Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost* Cattle / 100 / 0 / 0 / 0 Buffaloes / 100 / 0 / 0 / 0 *Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and/or slaughter  Epidemiology Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: unknown or inconclusive, Illegal movement of animals Epidemiological comments: 15 per cent of young (1-1.5 years old) and 85 per cent of adult (3-5 years old) cross breed cattle and buffaloes of 4 farms were affected with typical signs and symptoms of foot and mouth disease (FMD) such as high fever, drooling of saliva, champing of jaws, lameness, off feed, lesions on tongue. All the cattle and buffaloes in the village were affected; however there was no mortality observed even in the young ones. The animals have not been vaccinated against FMD since few years in these farms. There was a buffalo collection and selling center 100 meters close to the village. There was a collection of buffaloes from different neighboring districts and international bordering districts. Further investigation is ongoing.  Control measures Measures applied: movement control inside the country, surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, quarantine, disinfection, vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists), no treatment of affected animals  Diagnostic test results Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result National foot-and-mouth disease and transboundary animal diseases Laboratory, Kathmandu (national laboratory) / Buffaloes / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 6 Apr 2017 / Positive National foot-and-mouth disease and transboundary animal diseases Laboratory, Kathmandu (national laboratory) / Cattle / PCR / 6 Apr 2017 / Positive National foot-and-mouth disease and transboundary animal diseases Laboratory, Kathmandu (national laboratory) / Cattle / serotyping / 6 Apr 2017 / Positive Pirbright Institute, United Kingdom (OIE reference laboratory) / Cattle / gene sequencing / 14 Aug 2017 / Positive Pirbright Institute, United Kingdom (OIE reference laboratory) / Cattle / serotyping / 14 Aug 2017 / Positive Measures to be applied: no other measures  Future reporting The event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.  The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  According to the Nepal page on WRLFMD website, the last occurrence of FMD serotype A in Nepal took place in 1997. Since 2010, and as of March 2017, the FMDV strain circulating in Nepal has continuously been O/ME-SA/Ind-2001d (in 2015, there was also a single detection of O/ME-SA/PanAsia-2 KAT-15). For the said and additional information on Nepal's FMD past records, including genotyping results (though not yet of the newly introduced A/ASIA/G-VII lineage), see (http://www.wrlfmd.org/fmd_genotyping/asia/nep.htm).  The identification of the A/ASIA/G-VII lineage in Nepal represents further spread of this virus, which had been evolving in India many years back (\"A/IND/40/2000\", genotyped A/ASIA/G-VII, was collected in 1999). In 2010, this strain was detected in Myanmar. In 2015, it appeared for the 1st time in the Middle East (\"FMD Pool 3\"), being detected in Saudi Arabia followed, during the same year, by Iran, Turkey and Armenia. Most recently (May 2017), this virus was identified in Northern Israel, on the Lebanese and Syrian borders.  According to the information included in the Guest Editor's comments to EuFMD's (European Commission for the control of Foot-and-Mouth Disease) monthly report \"Global Foot-and-Mouth Disease Situation\", June 2017, there were reports of poor performance of vaccine strains derived from the A/ASIA/Iran-05 strain against the A/ASIA/G-VII lineage. The guest editor, Don King (head of the Vesicular Disease Reference Laboratory Group in the Pirbright Institute and WRLFMD), disclosed that WRLFMD, in partnership with the FMD Reference Laboratories in Lelystad (The Netherlands) and Geelong (Australia), has undertaken vaccine potency trials for alternative candidate vaccines; preliminary data indicated that the A-May-97 vaccine may provide protection in cattle, in contrast to the A22 vaccine, which does not appear to induce a protective response. The said data were to \"be presented in more detail shortly\". The said and additional information is available at (http://www.fao.org/fileadmin/user_upload/eufmd/docs/FMD_monthly_reports/2017/June2017.pdf).  The Indian subcontinent (\"FMD Pool 2\") is the source of 2 FMD strains which have demonstrated, in recent years, a long-distance (trans-regional) transmission, causing losses in \"FMD Pool 3\" countries and threatening Europe. These are FMDV serotype O, topotype ME-SA, strain Ind-2001d and FMDV serotype A, topotype Asia, genotype (strain) VII. While the routes of dissemination are yet to be clarified, the FMD situation within India, a major beef exporter, including its vaccination policy and vaccines efficacy, deserves being visited. - Mod.AS  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/19830).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"United States of America":{"5":{"title":"Cyclosporiasis - USA (04): background ","date":["15","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cyclosporiasis - USA (04): background [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 15 Aug 2017. Source: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease Epidemiology Network) (edited)   The following background information on cyclosporiasis in the United States is abstracted from Gideon and the Gideon e-book series <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> (primary references are available on request).  Cyclosporiasis is the least-common reportable protozoan infection in the United States. In 2008, the reported disease rate among 10 states was 2.25 per 100 000 population.  The true incidence of foodborne cyclosporiasis in the United States has been estimated at 11 407 to 19 808 cases per year (15 hospitalizations), accounting for 0.1 percent of all foodborne illness. Approximately 42 percent of cases are imported.  1110 individual cases of cyclosporiasis were reported during 1997 to 2008. 849 (76.5 percent) of the cases occurred in 7 states, including 498 (44.9 percent of total) in Florida. 51.7 percent of cases with known travel history were autochthonous.  No fatal cases were reported during 1998 to 2006.  During 1998 to 2002, 9 foodborne outbreaks (325 cases) of cyclosporiasis were reported; 0 in 2007; 3 (66 total cases) in 2008; 1 (8 cases) in 2009; 0 in 2010. 11 outbreaks (3533 cases) related to imported food were reported during 1996 to 2014.  Reported disease rates have increased somewhat since 2012. See graph at (https://www.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/cyclosporiasis.png)  Chronology of reported outbreaks: - 1990. Outbreak (20 cases) among health-care workers at a hospital in Chicago, Illinois. Related to contaminated water - 1995. Outbreak at a country club in New York State - 1995. Outbreak in Florida associated with consumption of contaminated fresh raspberries. - 1996. Multiple outbreaks (1465 cases, 978 confirmed) in at least 15 states including New York (307), Florida (220), Massachusetts (170), New Jersey (103), South Carolina (38). Vehicles included raspberries and other fruit. The raspberries were imported from Guatemala and were thought to have been contaminated by water used in pesticide sprays. - 1997. Outbreak (56 cases) at a hotel in Texas. - 1997. Outbreaks (25 event-associated case clusters encompassing 370 cases) reported from 8 states (California, Florida, Maryland, Nebraska, Nevada, Rhode Island, New York, and Texas) and Canada (Ontario). - 1997. Outbreaks (26 clusters encompassing 228 cases) reported from Virginia, Washington DC, and Baltimore. Fresh basil and basil-pesto sauce implicated as the source. An additional 20 possible clusters (75 cases) were under investigation at the time. - 1997. Outbreaks (over 1700 cases during a 5-month period) associated with raspberries, mesclun lettuce, and basil. Fresh raspberries, imported from Guatemala, were implicated in 19 of 21 outbreaks/70 sporadic cases confirmed in the United States and Canada during this period. - 1998. Outbreak (57 cases) at a wedding in Massachusetts was associated with contaminated berries. - 1999. Outbreaks (62 cases in 2 outbreaks) in Missouri were associated with fresh basil, grown in either the United States of Mexico. - 2000. Outbreak (54 cases) at a wedding in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania was ascribed to imported (Guatemalan) raspberries in a wedding cake. This was the 5th year that outbreaks associated with Guatemalan raspberries had occurred in North America during the spring months. - 2004. Outbreak (96 cases) at a residential facility in Pennsylvania was associated with contaminated raw snow peas imported from Guatemala - 2004. Outbreak (90 cases) in Illinois and Texas was caused by contaminated basil and spring mix salad. - 2005. Outbreak (70 cases) in Florida - 2011. Outbreak (100 cases) in Georgia among persons who had visited an aquarium - 2013. Outbreak (643 cases) involving multiple locations was related to contaminated bagged salad imported from Mexico. - 2014. Outbreak (202 cases, including 49 in Texas) involved multiple locations. - 2015. Outbreak (72 cases) in Texas - 2015. Outbreak (495 cases) in 30 states was related to ingestion of contaminated cilantro imported from Mexico. - 2016. Outbreak (72 cases) in Texas.  Reference  1. Berger SA. Cyclosporiasis: Global Status, 2017. 35 pages, 8 graphs, 435 references. Gideon e-books, (https://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/cyclosporiasis-global-status/)   <br><br>Communicated by: Stephen Berger Geographic Medicine Tel Aviv Medical Center Tel Aviv, Israel (steve@gideononline.com)  ProMED thanks Professor Steve Berger for providing this background information extracted from the GIDEON database. The numbers most probably represent an underestimation as mild, self limiting cases probably would never be investigated by a feces microscopy for protozoan parasites. - Mod.EP  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"36":{"title":"Glanders, equine - USA: (FL) ex Europe sporting events\r\n\t","date":["23","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Glanders, equine - USA: (FL) ex Europe sporting events\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 17 Aug 2017. Source: The Horse (edited) (http://www.thehorse.com/articles/39562/dressage-horse-detained-after-positive-glanders-test)   An American dressage horse returning to the United States after a competition tour in Europe has tested positive for Glanders. Shipped from Amsterdam to Miami after participating in Sweden and UK  An American dressage horse returning to the United States after a competition tour in Europe could be euthanized or shipped back out of the country after testing positive for glanders during routine USDA equine import quarantine.  Glanders is a highly contagious upper respiratory disease that can be passed from horse-to-horse as well as to human handlers. Acute clinical signs include fever; cough; difficulty breathing; nasal discharge; swollen and painful submaxillary lymph nodes (the \"glands\" in \"glanders\"); rapidly spreading ulcers on the nasal mucosa, nodules, and chronic abscesses; and small abscesses in the lung and/or abscesses in the liver or spleen, among others. Clinical signs of chronic glanders include coughing; malaise; weight loss; intermittent fever; possible thick nasal discharge, usually out of one nostril; ulcers and nodules on the nasal mucosa; enlarged submaxillary lymph nodes; chronic enlargement and induration (hardening) of lymphatics and lymph nodes; joint swelling and painful leg edema (fluid swelling); and nodules, particularly on the legs, that rupture, release pus, and ulcerate. Glanders has been eradicated from North American and was last reported in the United States in the 1940s. It's recently been reported in several areas around the world, however, including South America, Eastern Africa, Asia, the Middle East, and a rare case in Germany in 2014.  Earlier this month August 2017, the 18-year-old Dutch Warmblood gelding Sagacious HF was shipped from Amsterdam to the Miami International Airport after participating in competitions in Sweden and England with Chase Hickok. Under USDA rules, all horses entering the United States, except those coming from Canada, must be quarantined and tested for 4 diseases  dourine, glanders, equine piroplasmosis, and equine infectious anemia  upon arrival.  Jeanine Neskey, interim public affairs specialist for the USDA Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service (APHIS), said an animal that produces a positive test result is denied entry to the United States.  \"Denied entry means that it must be either removed from the U.S. or be euthanized,\" she said. \"If the horse is denied entry into the U.S. (and not euthanized), the owner is free to take the horse to any other country that will accept it.\"  Scott Leibsle, DVM, Idaho's deputy state veterinarian, said Sagacious could have contracted the disease through contaminated feed or through water buckets also used by other horses participating in competitions. The gelding might also have been an asymptomatic carrier of the disease, possibly developing signs after experiencing stress  \"Transport is the most stressful thing you can do to a horse,\" he said. \"At the same time, you're putting it with new animals in a new area, and putting it under the stress of competition.\"  Currently APHIS uses a complement fixation test (CFT) to detect glanders. However, the agency is evaluating other testing methods, including the Western Blot procedure.  \"Advancing research and improved technology continue to develop new or improved testing methods for animal diseases,\" Neskey said. \"USDA routinely evaluates all testing methods available and incorporates the methods most appropriate to the needs of import quarantine testing.\"  After Sagacious produced a 2nd positive CFT glanders test, he produced a negative Western Blot glanders test. Arrangements were made to place him on extended quarantine pending the results of additional testing with both tests, slated for Wed 23 Aug 2017.  Byline: Pat Raia   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Glanders, also known as farcy, is a contagious infectious disease of equines, acute or chronic, usually fatal, caused by the bacterium _Burkholderia mallei_, and characterized by the development of ulcerated nodules that are most commonly found in the upper airway, lungs ,and skin. Felines and other animals are susceptible to infection, which is usually fatal. Humans can be infected and the microorganism (_B. mallei_) is considered a potential bioterrorism agent.  The disease, one among the oldest known and that used to be prevalent worldwide, is currently eradicated or effectively controlled in many countries. Recently the disease has been reported in some countries, including Iraq, Turkey, Pakistan, India, Mongolia, China, Brazil, United Arab Emirates, and countries in Africa. Glanders is one of the diseases contained in the list of diseases for mandatory reporting to the World Animal Health Organization (OIE).  The bacterium _Burkholderia mallei_ a clonal pathogen, can be found in nasal secretions and skin ulcers of infected animals. The transmission of glanders occurs commonly from intake of water or food contaminated with nasal secretions and exudates eliminated from infected animals, contact with contaminated equipment (saddles, harness) and by eating contaminated equine meat.  In the nasal form, nodules arise in septum and turbinates. Nodules progress to irregular edged ulcers; star-shaped scars are characteristic after the resolution of the ulcers. In the early stage, submandibular lymph nodes are enlarged and edematous, adhering to the skin and deep tissues in advanced stages of the disease. In the pulmonary form, inflammatory nodules with caseous or calcified centers are found in the lungs. With the progression of the disease areas of consolidation and pneumonia may be present. The nodules may break and eliminate the inflammatory content into the bronchial tree, spreading the infection to the upper respiratory tract. In the cutaneous form, nodules arise along the lymphatic vessels, especially on the extremities. The nodules may degenerate to form ulcers with drainage of highly infectious purulent material. The liver and spleen may have typical nodular lesions. Histologically, vasculitis, thrombosis, inflammatory cell infiltration and degeneration can be seen.  A test based on complement fixation can also be used for screening, but the ELISA test, although more sensitive, is not being routinely used. PCR can be used for specific identification ((https://www.merckvetmanual.com/generalized-conditions/glanders/overview-of-glanders)).  There are no vaccines. Prevention and control depend on early detection and eliminating infected animals in addition to quarantine and complete disinfection. Treatment, administered only in endemic areas, which does not lead to microbiological cure, is the use of doxycycline, ceftazidime, gentamycin, or streptomycin. Sulfa drugs (including in combination with trimethoprim) seem to be effective in prevention and glanders treatment ((http://www.merckmanuals.com/vet/generalized_conditions/glanders/overview_of_glanders.html?qt=glanders&alt=sh#Diagnosis)).  For glanders-free countries, there are OIE recommendations on importing equines. An international veterinary certificate is required attesting that the animals showed no clinical signs of glanders and were kept in an exporting country free of the disease for at least 6 months prior to shipment ((http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/GLA-EN.pdf)). It appears foreign horse owners will not be able to comply, therefore will be unable to repatriate their show horses? Further information would be welcome.  OIE WAHID's latest information shows continuing glanders in Sao Paulo and Minas Gerais states in 2014 (red circles on map; zoom in), but there have been no immediate or continuing event reports for Brazil in 2015. The OIE report and map are available at (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review/viewsummary?reportid=11974).  As a horse owner, this would be devastating. We certainly hope Sagacious test later this month August 2017 clears him of this disease. - Mod.TG  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/212).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"42":{"title":"Influenza, swine - USA (07): H3N2v ","date":["18","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Influenza, swine - USA (07): H3N2v [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 18 Aug 2017. Source: CIDRAP News (edited) (http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/news-perspective/2017/08/cdc-reports-3-more-fair-linked-variant-flu-cases)   The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) announced today Fri 18 Aug 2017 3 variant influenza cases among fairgoers in North Dakota, Ohio, and Pennsylvania. Information about the cases appears in this week's FluView report.  The cases bring the number of novel flu infections reported this year 2017 to 19, all but 1 reported in the last 30 days.  The CDC said all 3 patients had contact with swine at agricultural fairs. At this time, 2 of the viruses have been fully characterized and are influenza A H3N2 variant (H3N2v) viruses. The 3rd virus has been characterized as an influenza A (H3) variant, and tests are under way to further characterize it. A variant influenza strain occurs when an influenza A virus that normally circulates in swine is detected in humans.  A total of 4 states now report cases Texas, Ohio, North Dakota, and Pennsylvania are the only states to report variant strains this year 2017, with Ohio reporting 15 H3 variant viruses and one H1N2 variant virus (the other states have reported one H3N2v case each).  Of the 3 cases announced todayFri 18 Aug 2017, 2 people attended the same fair. The Pennsylvania resident's exposure occurred out of state, according to FluView. The North Dakota Department of Health released a statement on Tue 15 Aug 2017 that said 2 people, one an out-of-state visitor, contracted the variant virus at the North Dakota State Fair in Minot.  Two of the 3 patients were hospitalized, and all 3 have fully recovered from their infections. One patient was older than 64; the other 2 were children.  H3N2v was 1st detected in humans in 2011. In 2012, the CDC confirmed 309 United States cases, most linked to exposure at swine exhibits. Last year 2016, 18 cases were reported.  Byline: Stephanie Soucheray   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The total number of Influenza A/H3N2v cases reported in 2017 reported during 2017 is 18 to date Fri 18 Aug 2017 (according to the latest update on CDC webpage (https://www.cdc.gov/flu/swineflu/h3n2v-case-count.htm) with 2 hospitalizations.  Clinical characteristics of the A/H3N2v cases are generally consistent with those of seasonal influenza including fever, cough, pharyngitis, myalgia, and headache.  Rapid detection and characterization of novel influenza viruses are important components of national efforts in the United States to prevent further cases and evaluate clinical illness associated with these viruses. As a result, clinicians are reminded to consider influenza as a possible diagnosis when evaluating patients with acute respiratory illnesses, and clinicians should consider the possibility of H3N2v in persons presenting with respiratory illness and recent swine contact or attendance at an agricultural fair ((https://emergency.cdc.gov/HAN/han00351.asp)). - Mod.UBA  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/240). A 12 Aug 2017 report quotes USA health\nofficials indicating that the Zika outbreaks in the Caribbean and\nSouth America are waning and that has helped slow the spread of the\nmosquito-borne virus to Florida and other localities in the USA this\nyear (2017).\n(http://abcnews.go.com/Health/wireStory/experts-herd-immunity-us-slows-zika-florida-49179180) Maps showing the location of the affected islands and countries in\nthe Americas mentioned above and below can be accessed at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/35574);\nNorth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106);\nCentral America (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39455);\nCaribbean (http://www.mapsofworld.com/caribbean-islands/); and\nSouth America at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/6186). - Mod.TY Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. Americas. 16 Aug 2017. (reported) case numbers have fallen\ndramatically from their peak in January-March 2016 and not recovered\nthis year (2017). Increased herd immunity from previous Zika virus\ninfections has been suggested as one reason for the decline.\n(http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2017/08/zika-has-all-disappeared-americas-why) North America\n\nUSA\n- Hidalgo county, Texas. 3 Aug 2017. South America\n\nArgentina (Salta province). 13 Aug 2017. November 2016-May 2017, 1st\nlocally acquired outbreak (conf.) 203 cases of which 7 pregnant.\nDepartment most affected: San Martín (Tartagal, General Mosconi,\nAguaray, and Embarcación), and Morillo.\n(http://www.eltribuno.info/salta/nota/2017-8-13-0-0-0-hubo-203-casos-de-zika-en-el-primer-brote-autoctono)\n Brazil\n- Origin and spread. 15 Jun 2017. (reported) Analyses of viral genomes\nwith ecological and epidemiological data yield an estimate that ZIKV\nwas present in northeast Brazil by February 2014 and is likely to have\ndisseminated from there, nationally and internationally, before the\n1st detection of ZIKV in the Americas. Estimated dates for the\ninternational spread of ZIKV from Brazil indicate the duration of\npre-detection cryptic transmission in recipient regions. The role of\nnortheast Brazil in the establishment of ZIKV in the Americas is\nfurther supported by geographic analysis of ZIKV transmission.\n(http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v546/n7658/full/nature22402.html) - Eye lesions. 17 Jul 2017 (reported) of 112 infants born to Zika\nvirus infected mothers in Brazil, 24 (21 percent) had eye\nabnormalities; 10 infants (42 percent) with abnormal eye examination\nfindings did not have microcephaly, 8 (33 percent) did not have any\ncentral nervous system findings, and 2 (8 percent) had eye\nabnormalities despite maternal 3rd trimester infection. Eye\nabnormalities may be the only initial finding in congenital Zika virus\ninfection, and all infants with potential Zika virus exposure should\nundergo screening eye examinations.\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/article-abstract/2636587) Peru\n- National. 22 Jul 2017. 2016-22 Jul 2017 (susp.) 6432 cases, (conf.)\n1438 cases with 264 pregnant with 17 cases of suspected Zika\nvirus-related microcephaly. For 2017 up to 23 Jul 2017 (susp.) 5552\ncases, (conf.) 649 cases with 172 pregnant, 5 cases of suspected Zika\nvirus-related microcephaly. Epidemic peak on week 15 week ending 14\nApr 2017, then sharp decline.\n(http://www.dge.gob.pe/portal/docs/vigilancia/boletines/2017/29.pdf)\n - Piura region. 29 Jul 2017.
