(reported) 1st case reported in state\nin a 27-year-old man in the Krishnagiri district.\n(http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/tamil-nadu/tamil-nadu-reports-first-case-of-zika-virus/article19254690.ece) Imported cases with little or no possibility of ongoing mosquito\ntransmission\n\nCanada. 26 Jul 2017. As of 4 May 2017 (reported) 499 cases with 2\naffected newborn babies. 103 cases in Quebec as of 12 May 2017.\n(https://sherbrooktimes.com/nine-cases-of-zika-in-the-region-of-the-capitale-nationale/20262) A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Canada can be accessed at\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12). - Mod.TY USA\n- Case numbers mainland. Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-16 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html) State / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 20 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 29 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 6 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 4 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 40 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 4 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 2 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 203 / 9 - Texas. 11 Aug 2017. 1 Jan 2016-31 July 2017, 219 pregnant women with\nlaboratory evidence of possible recent Zika virus infection were\nidentified in Texas, including 49 (22 percent) with\nlaboratory-confirmed Zika virus). One woman was infected in Texas; all\nothers were exposed outside the United States and its territories.\nZika virus testing was completed for 80 (43 percent) of the 185\ninfants or fetuses, and Zika virus-associated birth defects were\ndocumented in 15 (8 percent) pregnancies (14 live-born infants and one\nfetal loss), including 6 (17 percent) of the 36 infants or fetal\nlosses delivered by women with laboratory-confirmed Zika virus\ninfection. Of these, 10 infants or fetuses had microcephaly; 5 of\nthose with microcephaly had additional birth defects, including\nholoprosencephaly the brain doesn't properly divide into the right\nand left hemispheres, hydranencephaly brain's cerebral hemispheres\nreplaced by sacs filled with cerebrospinal fluid, craniosynostosis\npremature fusion of one or more cranial sutures, often resulting in\nan abnormal head shape, and clubfeet feet turned inward. Zika\nvirus-associated birth defects identified in the remaining 3 infants\nincluded holoprosencephaly, cataracts, and ventral pons hypoplasia.\n(https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6631a5.htm?s_cid=mm6631a5_e) Neurological effects not only occur in fetuses and neonates, there\nare occasional cases in adults as well. A report describes a case of\nZIKV meningoencephalitis and probable myelitis and its associated\nmagnetic resonance imaging findings that rapidly resolved during\nrecovery in a previously healthy adult.\n((http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0921)). -\nMod. TY - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 40 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 39 / 0\nTotal 554 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Evaluation of diagnostic tests.\nDate: September 2017 (ahead of print).\nSource: Emerging Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/23/9/16-2043_article) \nref: Safronetz D, Sloan A, Stein DR, et al. Evaluation of 5\ncommercially available Zika virus immunoassays. Emerg Infect Dis.\n2017; 23(9): 1577-80. doi: 10.3201/eid2309.162043. Epub 2017 Sep 17\n-\nAbstract\n\nBecause of global spread of Zika virus, accurate and high-throughput\ndiagnostic immunoassays are needed. We compared the sensitivity and\nspecificity of 5 commercially available Zika virus serologic assays to\nthe recommended protocol of Zika virus IgM-capture ELISA and\nplaque-reduction neutralization tests. Most commercial immunoassays\nshowed low sensitivity, which can be increased. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) The low sensitivity is a significant concern. Readers interested in\nthe evaluation of the specific tests may wish to see the full report\navailable at the source URL above. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Saliva transmission unlikely.\nDate: Tue 1 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Communications (edited)\n(https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5539107/? \nref: Newman CM, Dudley DM, Aliota MT, et al. Oropharyngeal mucosal\ntransmission of Zika virus in rhesus macaques. Nat Commun. 2017; 8(1):\n169. doi: 10.1038/s41467-017-00246-8\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus is present in urine, saliva, tears, and breast milk, but\nthe transmission risk associated with these body fluids is currently\nunknown. Here we evaluate the risk of Zika virus transmission through\nmucosal contact in rhesus macaques. Application of high-dose Zika\nvirus directly to the tonsils of 3 rhesus macaques results in\ndetectable plasma viremia in all animals by 2 days post-exposure;\nvirus replication kinetics are similar to those observed in animals\ninfected subcutaneously. 3 additional macaques inoculated\nsubcutaneously with Zika virus served as saliva donors to assess the\ntransmission risk from contact with oral secretions from an infected\nindividual. 7 naive animals repeatedly exposed to donor saliva via the\nconjunctivae, tonsils, or nostrils did not become infected. Our\nresults suggest that there is a risk of Zika virus transmission via\nthe mucosal route, but that the risk posed by oral secretions from\nindividuals with a typical course of Zika virus infection is low. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall It is good to learn that Zika virus transmission via mucosa is\nunlikely. It will be interesting to know if virus shedding in saliva\nis a common occurrence in infected humans. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> CDC guidance for pregnancy.\nDate: Mon 24 Jul 2017.\nSource: CDC. MMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep 2017; 66(29): 781-93(edited)\n(https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/66/wr/mm6629e1.htm) \nref: Oduyebo T, Polen KD, Walke HT, et al. Update: Interim guidance\nfor health care providers caring for pregnant women with possible Zika\nvirus exposure  United States (including US Territories), July 2017.\nMMWR Morb Mortal Wkly Rep. 2017; 66(29): 781-93. doi:\n10.15585/mmwr.mm6629e1\n-\nCDC has updated the interim guidance for US health care providers\ncaring for pregnant women with possible Zika virus exposure in\nresponse to 1) declining prevalence of Zika virus disease in the World\nHealth Organization's Region of the Americas (Americas) and 2)\nemerging evidence indicating prolonged detection of Zika virus\nimmunoglobulin M (IgM) antibodies. Zika virus cases were 1st reported\nin the Americas during 2015-2016; however, the incidence of Zika virus\ndisease has since declined. As the prevalence of Zika virus disease\ndeclines, the likelihood of false-positive test results increases. In\naddition, emerging epidemiologic and laboratory data indicate that, as\nis the case with other flaviviruses, Zika virus IgM antibodies can\npersist beyond 12 weeks after infection. Therefore, IgM test results\ncannot always reliably distinguish between an infection that occurred\nduring the current pregnancy and one that occurred before the current\npregnancy, particularly for women with possible Zika virus exposure\nbefore the current pregnancy. These limitations should be considered\nwhen counseling pregnant women about the risks and benefits of testing\nfor Zika virus infection during pregnancy. This updated guidance\nemphasizes a shared decision-making model for testing and screening\npregnant women, one in which patients and providers work together to\nmake decisions about testing and care plans based on patient\npreferences and values, clinical judgment, and a balanced assessment\nof risks and expected outcomes. For these recommendations, the definition of possible Zika virus\nexposure has not changed and includes travel to, or residence in an\narea with risk for mosquito-borne Zika virus transmission or sex with\na partner who has traveled to or resides in an area with risk for\nmosquito-borne Zika virus transmission. These areas can be found on\nthe CDC \"Zika Travel Information\" webpage. Key recommendations include the following:\n1- All pregnant women in the United States and US territories should\nbe asked about possible Zika virus exposure before and during the\ncurrent pregnancy, at every prenatal care visit. CDC recommends that\npregnant women not travel to any area with risk for Zika virus\ntransmission. It is also recommended that pregnant women with a sex\npartner who has traveled to or lives in an area with risk for Zika\nvirus transmission use condoms or abstain from sex for the duration of\nthe pregnancy.\n2- Pregnant women with recent possible Zika virus exposure and\nsymptoms of Zika virus disease should be tested to diagnose the cause\nof their symptoms. The updated recommendations include concurrent Zika\nvirus nucleic acid test (NAT) and serologic testing as soon as\npossible through 12 weeks after symptom onset.\n3- Asymptomatic pregnant women with ongoing possible Zika virus\nexposure should be offered Zika virus NAT testing 3 times during\npregnancy. IgM testing is no longer routinely recommended because IgM\ncan persist for months after infection; therefore, IgM results cannot\nreliably determine whether an infection occurred during the current\npregnancy. The optimal timing and frequency of testing of asymptomatic\npregnant women with NAT alone is unknown. For pregnant women who have\nreceived a diagnosis of laboratory-confirmed Zika virus infection (by\neither NAT or serology positive/equivocal Zika virus or dengue virus\nIgM and Zika virus plaque reduction neutralization test (PRNT) 10 and\nhigher and dengue virus PRNT less than 10 results) any time before or\nduring the current pregnancy, additional Zika virus testing is not\nrecommended. For pregnant women without a prior laboratory-confirmed\ndiagnosis of Zika virus, NAT testing should be offered at the\ninitiation of prenatal care, and if Zika virus RNA is not detected on\nclinical specimens, 2 additional tests should be offered during the\ncourse of the pregnancy coinciding with prenatal visits.\n4- Asymptomatic pregnant women who have recent possible Zika virus\nexposure (that is, through travel or sexual exposure) but without\nongoing possible exposure are not routinely recommended to have Zika\nvirus testing. Testing should be considered using a shared\npatient-provider decision-making model, one in which patients and\nproviders work together to make decisions about testing and care plans\nbased on patient preferences and values, clinical judgment, a balanced\nassessment of risks and expected outcomes, and the jurisdiction's\nrecommendations. Based on the epidemiology of Zika virus transmission\nand other epidemiologic considerations (such as, seasonality),\njurisdictions might recommend testing of asymptomatic pregnant women,\neither for clinical care or as part of Zika virus surveillance. With\nthe decline in the prevalence of Zika virus disease, the updated\nrecommendations for the evaluation and testing of pregnant women with\nrecent possible Zika virus exposure but without ongoing possible\nexposure are now the same for all areas with any risk for Zika virus\ntransmission.\n5- Pregnant women who have recent possible Zika virus exposure and who\nhave a fetus with prenatal ultrasound findings consistent with\ncongenital Zika virus syndrome should receive Zika virus testing to\nassist in establishing the etiology of the birth defects. Testing\nshould include both NAT and IgM tests.\n6- The comprehensive approach to testing placental and fetal tissues\nhas been updated. Testing placental and fetal tissue specimens can be\nperformed for diagnostic purposes in certain scenarios (e.g., women\nwithout a diagnosis of laboratory-confirmed Zika virus infection and\nwho have a fetus or infant with possible Zika virus-associated birth\ndefects). However, testing of placental tissues for Zika virus\ninfection is not routinely recommended for asymptomatic pregnant women\nwho have recent possible Zika virus exposure but without ongoing\npossible exposure and who have a live born infant without evidence of\npossible Zika virus-associated birth defects.\n7- Zika virus IgM testing as part of preconception counseling to\nestablish baseline IgM results for non pregnant women with ongoing\npossible Zika virus exposure is not warranted because Zika virus IgM\ntesting is no longer routinely recommended for asymptomatic pregnant\nwomen with ongoing possible Zika virus exposure. also at the source URL above:\nAdditional interim guidance:\n- Laboratory testing of pregnant women with exposure to areas with\nrisk for Zika virus transmission\n- Prenatal management of pregnant women with laboratory evidence of\npossible Zika virus infection\n- Evaluation of placental and fetal tissue specimens for Zika virus\ninfection \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be)(promed@promedmail.org) Readers interested in accessing the full report can find it at the\nsource URL above. Interestingly, a malaria drug has been shown to\ninhibit autophagy which limits vertical transmission of Zika virus in\npregnant mice. (http://dx.doi.org/10.1084/jem.20170957). Roland\nHübner is thanked for sending in this report. - Mod. TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Neurologic complications in adults.\nDate: Mon 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: JAMA Neurology (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamaneurology/fullarticle/2647256) \nref: da Silva IRF, Frontera JA, Bispo de Filippis AM, et al.\nNeurologic complications associated with the Zika virus in Brazilian\nadults. JAMA Neurol. 2017. doi: 10.1001/jamaneurol.2017.1703. Epub\nahead of print\n-\nKey points\n-\nQuestion. What is the spectrum of neurologic manifestations in adults\nwith Zika virus infection?\nFindings. This cohort study evaluated adult patients with new-onset\nparainfectious or neuroinflammatory disease for the presence of acute\nZika virus infection in both serum and cerebrospinal fluid samples\nusing molecular and serological testing. An increase in the incidence\nof Guillain-Barré syndrome and encephalitis was observed compared\nwith the period before the outbreak of the Zika virus.\nMeaning The Zika virus may be associated with a rapid increase in the\nincidence of life-threatening neurologic syndromes; serologic and\nmolecular testing using blood and cerebrospinal fluid samples can\nserve as an alternative diagnostic strategy. Abstract\n\nImportance. There are no prospective cohort studies assessing the\nincidence and spectrum of neurologic manifestations secondary to Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) infection in adults.\nObjective. To evaluate the rates of acute ZIKV infection among\npatients hospitalized with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS),\nmeningoencephalitis, or transverse myelitis.\nDesign, setting, and participants. A prospective, observational cohort\nstudy was conducted at a tertiary referral center for neurological\ndiseases in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, between 5 Dec 2015-10 May 2016,\namong consecutive hospitalized adults (older than 18 years of age)\nwith new-onset acute parainfectious or neuroinflammatory disease. All\nparticipants were tested for a series of arbovirosis. 3-month\nfunctional outcome was assessed.\nInterventions. Samples of serum and cerebrospinal fluid were tested\nfor ZIKV using real-time reverse-transcriptase-polymerase chain\nreaction and an IgM antibody-capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent\nassay. Clinical, radiographic (magnetic resonance imaging),\nelectrophysiological, and 3-month functional outcome data were\ncollected.\nMain outcomes and measures. The detection of neurologic complications\nsecondary to ZIKV infection.\nResults. 40 patients (15 women and 25 men; median age, 44 years\nrange, 22-72 years) were enrolled, including 29 patients (73\npercent) with GBS (90 percent Brighton level 1 certainty), 7 (18\npercent) with encephalitis, 3 (8 percent) with transverse myelitis,\nand 1 (3 percent) with newly diagnosed chronic inflammatory\ndemyelinating polyneuropathy. Of these, 35 patients (88 percent) had\nmolecular and/or serologic evidence of recent ZIKV infection in the\nserum and/or cerebrospinal fluid. Of the patients positive for ZIKV\ninfection, 27 had GBS (18 demyelinating, 8 axonal, and 1 Miller Fisher\nsyndrome), 5 had encephalitis (3 with concomitant acute neuromuscular\ndisease), 2 had transverse myelitis, and 1 had chronic inflammatory\ndemyelinating polyneuropathy. Admission to the intensive care unit was\nrequired for 9 patients positive for ZIKV infection (26 percent), and\n5 (14 percent) required mechanical ventilation. Compared with\nadmission during the period from 5 Dec 2013 - 10 May 2014 (before the\nBrazilian outbreak of ZIKV), admissions for GBS increased from a mean\nof 1.0 per month to 5.6 per month, admissions for encephalitis\nincreased from 0.4 per month to 1.4 per month, and admissions for\ntransverse myelitis remained constant at 0.6 per month. At 3 months, 2\npatients positive for ZIKV infection (6 percent) died (1 with GBS and\n1 with encephalitis), 18 (51 percent) had chronic pain, and the median\nmodified Rankin score among survivors was 2 (range, 0-5).\nConclusions and relevance. In this single-center Brazilian cohort,\nZIKV infection was associated with an increase in the incidence of a\ndiverse spectrum of serious neurologic syndromes. The data also\nsuggest that serologic and molecular testing using blood and\ncerebrospinal fluid samples can serve as a less expensive, alternative\ndiagnostic strategy in developing countries, where plaque reduction\nneutralization testing is impractical. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) This study illustrates the need to consider post-Zika virus infection\nas a cause of a variety of neurological diseases. Further neurological\nfollow up of adults convalescent from acute Zika virus infection would\nbe of interest. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Persistence in brain cells.\nDate: Tue 11 Jul 2017.\nSource: mBio (edited)\n(http://mbio.asm.org/content/8/4/e00952-17.long) \nMladinich MC, Schwedes J, Mackow ER. Zika virus persistently infects\nand is basolaterally released from primary human brain microvascular\nendothelial cells. MBio. 2017; 8(4). pii: e00952-17. doi:\n10.1128/mBio.00952-17\n-\nZIKV persists in patients, crossing placental and neuronal barriers,\ndamaging neurons, and causing fetal microencephaly. We found that ZIKV\npersistently infects brain endothelial cells that normally protect\nneurons from viral exposure. hBMECs are not damaged by ZIKV infection\nand, analogous to persistent HCV infection, ZIKV constitutively\ninduces and evades antiviral ISG IFN-stimulated genes and IFN\ninterferon responses to continuously replicate in hBMECs. As a\nresult, hBMECs provide a protective niche for systemic ZIKV spread and\na viral reservoir localized in the normally protective blood-brain\nbarrier. Consistent with the spread of ZIKV into neuronal\ncompartments, ZIKV was released basolaterally from hBMECs. Our\nfindings define hBMEC responses that contribute to persistent ZIKV\ninfection and potential targets for clearing ZIKV infections from\nhBMECs. These results further suggest roles for additional\nZIKV-infected ECs to facilitate viral spread and persistence in the\nprotected placental, retinal, and testicular compartments. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{7}</strong> Prior flavivirus infection and Zika virus infection.\nDate: Thu 3 Aug 2017.\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Pathogens (edited)\n(http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1006487) \nMcCracken MK, Gromowski GD, Friberg HL, et al. Impact of prior\nflavivirus immunity on Zika virus infection in rhesus macaques. PLoS\nPathog. 2017; 13(8): e1006487. doi: 10.1371/journal.ppat.1006487\n-\nAbstract\n\nStudies have demonstrated cross-reactivity of anti-dengue virus (DENV)\nantibodies in human sera against Zika virus (ZIKV), promoting\nincreased ZIKV infection in vitro. However, the correlation between in\nvitro and in vivo findings is not well characterized. Thus, we\nevaluated the impact of heterotypic flavivirus immunity on ZIKV titers\nin biofluids of rhesus macaques. Animals previously infected (420 days\nor longer) with DENV2, DENV4, or yellow fever virus were compared to\nflavivirus-naïve animals following infection with a Brazilian ZIKV\nstrain. Sera from DENV-immune macaques demonstrated cross-reactivity\nwith ZIKV by antibody-binding and neutralization assays prior to ZIKV\ninfection, and promoted increased ZIKV infection in cell culture\nassays. Despite these findings, no significant differences between\nflavivirus-naïve and immune animals were observed in viral titers,\nneutralizing antibody levels, or immune cell kinetics following ZIKV\ninfection. These results indicate that prior infection with\nheterologous flaviviruses neither conferred protection nor increased\nobserved ZIKV titers in this non-human primate ZIKV infection model. Author summary\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-borne, emerging flavivirus. In\naddition to asymptomatic or mild febrile manifestations, ZIKV\ninfection in humans is associated with comparatively rare congenital\nand neurological abnormalities. Previous in vitro studies have\ndemonstrated cross-reactivity of antibodies derived from dengue virus\ninfections with ZIKV, as well as antibody-mediated enhancement of\ninfection in cell culture. Therefore, there is concern among\nvaccinologists and the public health community that the more severe\ndisease manifestations could result from prior immunity, either from\nnatural infection or vaccination, to antigenically-related\nflaviviruses (such as, dengue, yellow fever, Japanese encephalitis).\nIn this study, we evaluated the impact of prior immunity to dengue or\nyellow fever virus on ZIKV infection in a non-human primate model.\nAfter confirming that our immune cohorts were capable of\nrecapitulating the published in vitro observations of cross-reactivity\nand enhancement, we looked for alteration of viral titers in\nperipheral blood, urine, cerebrospinal fluid, saliva, and vaginal\nsecretions, as well as alterations in gross pathology, clinical\nparameters, and immune response, as compared to our flavivirus-naïve\ncohort. Importantly, no significant differences between\nflavivirus-naïve and primed animals were observed in viral titers or\nbiofluid distribution, neutralizing antibody levels, or immune cell\nkinetics following ZIKV infection. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org)\nand\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be)(promed@promedmail.org) Previous dengue infection, whether acquired naturally or antibody\nelicited by vaccines, has been a concern due to the possibility of\nantibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) with more severe disease. This\nconcern also relates to Zika virus antibody from vaccination for\nenhancement of dengue virus infections with resulting more severe\ndisease. The monkey studies reported above indicated that this may not\nbe a problem for Zika virus vaccinated individuals. Another effort to\navoid ADE is development of a vaccine that has epitopes specific for\nZika virus that are not shared by other flaviviruses. A group of\nresearchers developed a recombinant vaccine targeting a viral envelope\nsub-unit specific to the Zika virus\n((http://www.pharmaceutical-journal.com/news-and-analysis/news-in-brief/researchers-find-way-to-overcome-zika-vaccinedengue-virus-conundrum/20203379.article)).\nRoland Hübner is thanked for calling this latter reference to our\nattention. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{8}</strong> Virus inhibition.\nDate: 25 Jul 2017.\nSource: Nature Communications (edited)\n(https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms15672) \nref: Yu Y, Deng YQ, Zou P, et al. A peptide-based viral inactivator\ninhibits Zika virus infection in pregnant mice and fetuses. Nat\nCommun. 2017; 8: 15672. doi: 10.1038/ncomms15672\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV), a re-emerging flavivirus associated with\nneurological disorders, has spread rapidly to more than 70 countries\nand territories. However, no specific vaccines or antiviral drugs are\ncurrently available to prevent or treat ZIKV infection. Here we report\nthat a synthetic peptide derived from the stem region of ZIKV envelope\nprotein, designated Z2, potently inhibits infection of ZIKV and other\nflaviviruses in vitro. We show that Z2 interacts with ZIKV surface\nprotein and disrupts the integrity of the viral membrane. Z2 can\npenetrate the placental barrier to enter fetal tissues and is safe for\nuse in pregnant mice. Intraperitoneal administration of Z2 inhibits\nvertical transmission of ZIKV in pregnant C57BL/6 mice and protects\ntype I or type I/II interferon receptor-deficient mice against lethal\nZIKV challenge. Thus, Z2 has potential to be further developed as an\nantiviral treatment against ZIKV infection in high-risk populations,\nparticularly pregnant women. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall It will be interesting to see if the same protective effect occurs\nwhen tested with Zika virus infections of non-human primates. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{9}</strong> Female reproductive tract infection.\nDate: Wed 26 Jul 2017.\nSource: PLoS (Public Library of Science) Pathogens (edited)\n(http://journals.plos.org/plospathogens/article?id=10.1371/journal.ppat.1006537) \nCarroll T, Lo M, Lanteri M, et al. Zika virus preferentially\nreplicates in the female reproductive tract after vaginal inoculation\nof rhesus macaques. PLoS Pathog. 2017; 13(7): e1006537. doi:\n10.1371/journal.ppat.1006537\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a mosquito-transmitted virus that can cause\nsevere defects in an infected fetus. ZIKV is also transmitted by\nsexual contact, although the relative importance of sexual\ntransmission is unclear. To better understand the role of sexual\ntransmission in ZIKV pathogenesis, a nonhuman primate (NHP) model of\nvaginal transmission was developed. ZIKV was readily transmitted to\nmature cycling female rhesus macaque (RM) by vaginal inoculation was\nreadily transmitted to mature cycling female rhesus macaque (RM) by\nvaginal individual RM with 1-5 vaginal inoculations required to\nestablish infection. After treatment with Depoprovera, a widely used\ncontraceptive progestin, 2 RM that initially resisted 8 vaginal ZIKV\ninoculations became infected after one ZIKV inoculation. Thus,\nDepoprovera seemed to enhance susceptibility to vaginal ZIKV\ntransmission. Unexpectedly, the kinetics of virus replication and\ndissemination after intravaginal ZIKV inoculation were markedly\ndifferent from RM infected with ZIKV by subcutaneous (SQ) virus\ninoculation. Several groups have reported that after SQ ZIKV\ninoculation vRNA is rapidly detected in blood plasma with vRNA less\ncommon in urine and saliva and only rarely detected in female\nreproductive tract (FRT) secretions. In contrast, in vaginally\ninoculated RM, plasma vRNA is delayed for several days and ZIKV\nreplication in, and vRNA shedding from, the FRT was found in all 6\nanimals. Further, after intravaginal transmission ZIKV RNA shedding\nfrom FRT secretions was detected before or simultaneously with plasma\nvRNA, and persisted for at least as long. Thus, ZIKV replication in\nthe FRT was independent of, and often preceded virus replication in\nthe tissues contributing to plasma vRNA. These results support the\nconclusion that ZIKV preferentially replicates in the FRT after\nvaginal transmission, but not after SQ transmission, and raise the\npossibility that there is enhanced fetal infection and pathology after\nvaginal ZIKV transmission compared to a mosquito transmitted ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{10}</strong> _Aedes albopictus_ populations as vectors.\nDate: 2 Aug 2017.\nSource: American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (edited)\n(http://www.ajtmh.org/content/journals/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0969) \nref: Azar SR, Roundy CM, Rossi SL, et al. Differential vector\ncompetency of _Aedes albopictus_ populations from the Americas for\nZika virus. Am J Trop Med Hyg. 2017; 97(2): 330-9;\ndoi.org/10.4269/ajtmh.16-0969\n-\nAbstract\n\nTo evaluate the potential role of _Aedes albopictus_ (Skuse) as a\nvector of Zika virus (ZIKV), colonized mosquitoes of low generation\nnumber (less than or F5) from Brazil, Houston, and the Rio Grande\nValley of Texas engorged on viremic mice infected with ZIKV strains\noriginating from Senegal, Cambodia, Mexico, Brazil, or Puerto Rico.\nVector competence was established by monitoring infection,\ndissemination, and transmission potential after 3, 7, and 14 days of\nextrinsic incubation. Positive saliva samples were assayed for\ninfectious titer. Although all 3 mosquito populations were susceptible\nto all ZIKV strains, rates of infection, dissemination, and\ntransmission differed among mosquito and virus strains. _Aedes\nalbopictus_ from Salvador, Brazil, were the least efficient vectors,\ndemonstrating susceptibility to infection to 2 American strains of\nZIKV but failing to shed virus in saliva. Mosquitoes from the Rio\nGrande Valley were the most efficient vectors and were capable of\nshedding all 3 tested ZIKV strains into saliva after 14 days of\nextrinsic incubation. In particular, ZIKV strain DakAR 41525 (Senegal\n1954) was significantly more efficient at dissemination and saliva\ndeposition than the others tested in Rio Grande mosquitoes. Overall,\nour data indicate that, while _Ae. albopictus_ is capable of\ntransmitting ZIKV, its competence is potentially dependent on\ngeographic origin of both the mosquito population and the viral\nstrain. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) This study illustrates that fact that not all Zika virus strains and\n_Ae. albopictus_ populations are created equal in terms of efficiency\nof transmission of this virus. Although some populations of this\nmosquito are able to efficiently transmits some Zika viruses, the fact\nthat _Ae. albopictus _ are not strictly human biters, further reduces\ntheir role as transmitters of this virus to people. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{11}</strong> _Culex quinquefasciatus_ as vectors.\nDate: Wed 9 Aug 2017.\nSource: Emerging Microbes & Infections (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/emi/journal/v6/n8/full/emi201759a.html?foxtrotcallback=true) \nref: Guedes DR, Paiva MH, Donato MM, et al. Zika virus replication in\nthe mosquito _Culex quinquefasciatus_ in Brazil. Emerg Microbes\nInfect. 2017; 6(8): e69. doi: 10.1038/emi.2017.59\n-\nAbstract\n\nZika virus (ZIKV) is a flavivirus that has recently been associated\nwith an increased incidence of neonatal microcephaly and other\nneurological disorders. The virus is primarily transmitted by mosquito\nbite, although other routes of infection have been implicated in some\ncases. The _Aedes aegypti_ mosquito is considered to be the main\nvector to humans worldwide; however, there is evidence that other\nmosquito species, including _Culex quinquefasciatus_, transmit the\nvirus. To test the potential of _Cx. quinquefasciatus_ to transmit\nZIKV, we experimentally compared the vector competence of\nlaboratory-reared _Ae. aegypti_ and _Cx. quinquefasciatus_.\nInterestingly, we were able to detect the presence of ZIKV in the\nmidgut, salivary glands and saliva of artificially fed _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_. In addition, we collected ZIKV-infected _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_ from urban areas with high microcephaly incidence in\nRecife, Brazil. Corroborating our experimental data from artificially\nfed mosquitoes, ZIKV was isolated from field-caught _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_, and its genome was partially sequenced.\nCollectively, these findings indicate that there may be a wider range\nof ZIKV vectors than anticipated. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nRoland Hübner\nSuperior Health Council\nBrussels\nBelgium\n(roland.hubner@sante.belgique.be) Finding a virus in field-collected mosquitoes in areas of active\nvirus transmission is highly suggestive, but not conclusive, of their\nability to transmit that virus. The study above goes the next step\ntoward proving vector capability by infecting _Culex quinquefasciatus_\nfed with Zika virus and subsequently demonstrating the virus in\nsaliva, implicating their ability to transmit it. The role of _Cx.\nquinquefasciatus_ in Zika virus transmission is currently confusing.\nThe study above and one done in China indicate that this species is a\ncompetent vector. Several other studies have shown this species to be\ninefficient vectors or refractory to Zika virus infection. One wonders\nif the specific _Cx. quinquefasciatus_ used or the Zika virus isolates\nwith which they were tested could account for these very different\nresults. Resolving these discrepancies is important because this\nmosquito species is very widely distributed around the world and bears\ndirectly on risk of outbreaks in geographic areas where _Aedes\naegypti_ or _Ae. albopictus_ , Zika virus vectors, do not occur. -\nMod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"52":{"title":"Equine infectious anemia - USA (04): (KS) ","date":["20","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Equine infectious anemia - USA (04): (KS) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Sun 20 Aug 2017. Source: Horsetalk.co.nz (edited) (https://www.horsetalk.co.nz/2017/08/20/six-horses-positive-equine-infectious-anemia-kansas/#axzz4qJ68LWBR)   A horse property in southwest Kansas is under quarantine following confirmation of 6 cases of equine infectious anemia in horses. The infected horses on the property in Finney County will be euthanized because there is no cure and there is a risk the animals may infect other horses.  The Kansas Department of Agriculture's Division of Animal Health was told this month August 2017 of the initial positive test for the disease, also known as Swamp fever. The horse facility was quarantined and all the exposed horses were tested, with 5 additional positive cases detected. The remaining horses at the facility will be observed and retested in 60 days.  Equine infectious anemia is most commonly spread by biting flies and ticks, or sometimes through the shared used of blood-contaminated instruments or needles. The disease does not affect people, but it can be spread to horses, mules and donkeys.  The virus attacks the immune system, with signs including bleeding in mucus membranes and a gradual loss of condition and muscle weakness. Other signs include fever, depression and anemia. Infected horses can run a low-grade fever or become lethargic, but often there are no clinical signs. Infected horses continue to carry the virus and can be the source of further infections, hence the protocol to euthanize infected animals.  All infected horses, including those who have no signs, are carriers of the disease. There is no vaccine or treatment.  There are typically a small number of cases in the United States every year, although the disease is common in other parts of the world. The disease is controlled in the US by regular testing before horses are allowed to travel across state lines and/or to shows.  The pathogen causing the disease is categorized as a lentivirus: it contains genetic RNA material, which it uses to produce DNA. This DNA is then incorporated into the genetic makeup of infected cells.  The disease was first identified in France in 1843 and first tentatively diagnosed in the United States in 1888.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  This seems like a lot of animals to euthanize from one facility and surely horse owners and the facility managers are immensely affected.  How sad that this disease continues and there is no vaccine for it. We pour millions into other research projects, some of which seem to have little usefulness, but why no vaccine?  \"Under natural conditions, the most important mode of transmission of equine infectious anemia (EIA) is by the transfer of virus-infective blood by blood-feeding insects between horses in close proximity. Virus is found free in the plasma or cell associated, principally in monocytes and macrophages of infected animals. Although infection is considered primarily blood borne, all tissues and body fluids are potentially infectious, especially during episodes of clinical disease when viral burdens are high. Transmission of EIA by biting flies is purely mechanical; the virus does not replicate in the vector. The chance of transmission of EIA is directly proportional to the volume of blood retained on the mouthparts of the insect after feeding. In that respect, horse flies, deer flies, and to a lesser extent, stable flies are likely the most efficient vectors. It is also because they are capable of triggering host defensive behavior that interrupts feeding and results in their seeking a new susceptible host to complete their blood meal.\"  Fly control is very important, in the barn and on the animal.  Currently there is no vaccine for EIA in the US. There is a vaccine developed in China and used in other places (see: Equine infectious anemia - USA (04): (KY) unlicensed vaccine http://promedmail.org/post/20150915.3645562).  Portions of this comment were extracted from: (http://www.merckvetmanual.com/generalized-conditions/equine-infectious-anemia/overview-of-equine-infectious-anemia). - Mod.TG  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/219).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"67":{"title":"Foodborne illness - USA (03): sprouts,\r\n\tFDA report ","date":["21","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Foodborne illness - USA (03): sprouts,\r\n\tFDA report [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Mon 21 Aug 2017 12:56 pm EDT. Source: The Packer (edited) (http://www.thepacker.com/news/fda-sprout-program-halts-outbreak-leads-recalls)   The United States' Food and Drug Administration's 2-year sampling program for sprouts has produced both enforcement actions  prompting 6 product recalls and helping stop an outbreak of listeriosis  and long-term insights on the prevalence of pathogens on sprout seeds and finished product.  The FDA's \"fiscal year 2014-16 microbiological sampling assignment summary report: sprouts\" collected and tested sprouts as part of a \"proactive and preventive approach\" to help protect food safety, according to the report. Samples were tested for salmonella, _Listeria monocytogenes_, and _Escherichia coli_ O157:H7. Collecting 825 samples of domestic product, virtually all fresh sprouts eaten in the United States are grown in the USA, the sampling program tested sprout seeds, fresh sprouts, and spent irrigation water, according to the summary.  FDA's sprout sampling program found: - salmonella was found in 0.21 per cent of the sprouts, 2.35 per cent of seeds and 0.54 per cent of used irrigation water; - _L. monocytogenes_ was in 1.28 per cent of the tested sprouts, similar to the percentage found in seeds and used irrigation water; - no sprouts/spent irrigation water tested positive for _E. coli_ O157:H7. Seeds weren't tested for that strain due to limitations associated with the test method; - samples with pathogens were from a small number of companies, with positives at 8 (8.5 per cent) of the 94 sprouting operations tested;  According to the summary, many firms still have progress to make in sprout safety. \"The fact that the agency found multiple positive samples at some of these operations underscores the need for sprouting operations to comply with the agency's Produce Safety Regulation (published November 2015), which seeks to prevent outbreaks of foodborne illness and improve sprout safety,\" according to the report.  During the testing process, the FDA worked with firms that owned or released the sprouts/seeds to conduct recalls or to have the product destroyed, and then followed up with inspections. The sampling program helped stop a listeriosis outbreak before it spread beyond a few cases, and it also prompted 6 recalls.  While no large-scale testing of sprouts is planned, the FDA will determine if more sampling is needed. Criteria include whether a firm has a history of uncorrected contamination and observations from food safety inspectors who visit the facilities, according to the report. \"The presence of harmful bacteria in the commodity remains a concern to the agency in view of the history of reported outbreaks associated with sprouts, including 5 in 2016, and the fact that this assignment resulted in 6 product recalls,\" it said.  byline: Tom Karst   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The report \"FY 2014-2016 microbiological sampling assignment summary report: sprouts\" from the FDA's Office of Compliance, Center for Food Safety and Applied Nutrition can be found at (https://www.fda.gov/downloads/Food/ComplianceEnforcement/Sampling/UCM566981.pdf).  \"Executive summary  \"The FDA set out to collect and test sprouts in 2014 as part of a new proactive and preventive approach to deploying its sampling resources with the ultimate goal of keeping contaminated food from reaching consumers.  \"The new approach, detailed in the Background section of this report (page 4 available at the URL above), centers on the testing of a statistically determined number of samples of targeted foods over a relatively short period of time, 12 to 18 months, to ensure a statistically valid amount of data is available for decision making. This approach helps the agency determine if there are common factors  such as origin, season, or variety  associated with pathogen findings.  \"The FDA issued the sprouts assignment in January 2014 under its new sampling model. The assignment targeted sprouts at 3 points in the production process (seeds, finished product, and spent irrigation water), with the aim of collecting and testing 1600 samples to determine the prevalence of select pathogens in the commodity. As background, the FDA designed its sampling plan such that if contamination of one per cent or greater was present in the commodity, the agency would detect it. The FDA monitored the assignment closely to gather lessons learned and make changes to its sampling procedures if needed to address trends or food safety issues. About one year into the assignment, the FDA decided to stop its collection and testing at 825 samples because it had already collected samples on more than one occasion from many of the sprouting operations known to the agency and its state partners. The sample set acquired was sufficient for the FDA to estimate the bacterial prevalences in the commodity with a 95 percent confidence interval of 0 per cent to 2 per cent for a one percent contamination rate.  \"The FDA tested only domestically grown sprouts for this assignment because virtually all sprouts eaten in the United States are grown domestically due to the commodity's delicate nature and relatively short shelf-life. Of note, the industry features a preponderance of relatively small operations.  \"The FDA tested the sprout samples for 3 pathogens: salmonella, _Listeria monocytogenes_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7. Based on the test results, the FDA found the prevalence of salmonella in the finished product sprouts to be 0.21 per cent. The agency also found that the prevalence of salmonella in seeds (2.35 per cent) was significantly higher than in finished product (0.21 per cent) and in spent irrigation water (0.54 per cent). Based on the test results, the FDA found the prevalence of _L. monocytogenes_ in the finished product to be 1.28 per cent. There was no significant difference in the prevalence of _L. monocytogenes_ based on point in the production process. None of the samples tested positive for _E. coli_ O157:H7. The agency did not test seed for _E. coli_ O157:H7 due to limitations associated with the test method.  \"Among the FDA's other findings, the agency found most of the positive samples at a small number of sprouting operations. Specifically, the FDA found violative samples at eight (8.5 per cent) of the 94 sprouting operations visited for purposes of this assignment. The fact that the agency found multiple positive samples at some of these operations underscores the need for sprouting operations to comply with the agency's Produce Safety Regulation (published November 2015), which seeks to prevent outbreaks of foodborne illness and improve sprout safety.  \"To address the positive samples, the FDA worked with the firms that owned or released the affected product to conduct voluntary recalls or to have their consignees destroy it, and then followed up with inspections. Of particular note, this sampling assignment helped detect and stop an outbreak of listeriosis while it still entailed a small number of cases, as described in the public health Impact section of this report (page 14 available at the URL above). This assignment also prompted 6 product recalls.  \"The FDA will continue to consider microbial contamination of sprouts and how best to reduce it. Such contamination remains a concern to the FDA given the aforementioned outbreak and the recalls initiated. Going forward, the FDA intends to inspect sprouting operations to ensure they are complying, as applicable, with the Produce Safety Rule, which includes new requirements for sprouts growers. The agency has no plans to conduct additional large-scale sampling of sprouts at this time but may sample the commodity in accordance with its longstanding approach to food sampling, which centers on (but is not limited to) the following criteria: - a firm has a previous history of unmitigated microbial contamination in the environment (such as, human illness, recalled or seized product, previous inspectional history, or environmental pathogens without proper corrective actions by the facility), or - inspectional observations that warrant collection of samples for microbiological analyses.\" - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106). Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted. The location of the outbreak can be seen on the interactive map\nincluded in the OIE report at the source URL above. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \"Acute hepatopancreatic necrosis disease (AHPND), initially referred\nto as early mortality syndrome (EMS), is a shrimp disease caused by\nsome pathogenic strains of _Vibrio parahaemolyticus_ and likely some\npathogenic strains of other _Vibrio_ species in the _Vibrio harveyi_\ngroup. AHPND emerged as a new disease in 2009; it has resulted in\nsevere mortality in farmed penaeid shrimp and significant economic\nlosses in South East Asia and Mexico. AHPND most frequently occurs\nwithin the first 30 days after stocking a newly prepared shrimp pond. \"Infected shrimp show lethargy, slow growth, an empty stomach and\nmidgut and a pale to white atrophied hepatopancreas. \"AHPND has caused severe mortalities in farmed penaeid shrimp\nthroughout South East Asia and Mexico. Countries reporting AHPND\ninclude China, Vietnam, Thailand, the Philippines and Mexico\".\n(http://www.cabi.org/isc/datasheet/121558). - Mod CRD A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\n(http://healthmap.org/promed/p/245). ","keywordsMatched":[]},"106":{"title":"Obituary: Louisa Elaine Chapman ","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/ALL> Obituary: Louisa Elaine Chapman [EXTERNAL]","summary":" Visit ProMED-mail's web site at (http://www.promedmail.org). For assistance from  a  human  being, send mail to: (postmaster@promedmail.org). ############################################################ ############################################################  List-Unsubscribe: http://ww4.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.php ","keywordsMatched":[]},"112":{"title":"Equine infectious anemia - USA (05): (NC) mule ","date":["25","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH> Equine infectious anemia - USA (05): (NC) mule [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 25 Aug 2017. Source: The Horse (edited) (http://www.thehorse.com/articles/39611/equine-infectious-anemia-found-in-north-carolina-mule)   A 14 year old female mule in Johnston county, North Carolina, has tested positive for equine infectious anemia (EIA). The disease was discovered during a routine blood test by the North Carolina Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory, in Raleigh, and confirmed by the USDA United States Department of Agriculture. This is the 1st new case of EIA documented in North Carolina since 2005.  \"The Johnston County facility is under a quarantine order that restricts movement of equines until further testing is completed by the NC Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services,\" said Michael Neault, DVM, director of livestock and animal health programs. \"Because the disease is not curable, the affected mule has been euthanized. The remaining equines at the facility were tested and were negative for EIA. They will be observed and retested in 60 days, and we are monitoring neighboring facilities for the disease.\"  Equine infectious anemia is an incurable disease most commonly spread between equids  such as horses, mules, and donkeys  in close proximity to biting flies and ticks. Clinical signs of EIA include fever, weakness, weight loss, anemia, edema, and death; however, not all affected equids show clinical signs. All infected equids, including those that are asymptomatic, are carriers of the disease.  There are typically a small number of EIA cases in the United States every year, although the disease is common in other parts of the world. The disease is controlled in the United States by regular testing before traveling across state lines, exhibition, and other events. A Coggins test screens horses' blood for antibodies that are indicative of the presence of EIA.  There is no approved vaccine for EIA in the United States. To help prevent infection, owners can: - use sterile, disposable needles and syringes, one per horse, for all vaccines and medications; - test all horses for EIA every year, and at the time they enter a new premises; - keep stables and other facilities sanitary. Regularly clean stalls and properly dispose of manure away from horse stabling areas; - implement approved insect controls, such as insecticides and good drainage of standing water, to minimize fly presence; - only participate in events that require evidence of negative Coggins test for every equine entering the event to prevent disease introduction and spread; - isolate new horses on a property until they are tested for EIA; - never mix infected and healthy animals. Do not breed horses infected with EIA; and - follow state laws covering EIA.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  How sad that this disease continues and there is no vaccine for it. We pour millions into other research projects, some of which seem to have little value, but why no vaccine?  \"Under natural conditions, the most important mode of transmission of equine infectious anemia (EIA) is by the transfer of virus-infective blood by blood-feeding insects between horses in close proximity. Virus is found free in the plasma or cell associated, principally in monocytes and macrophages of infected animals. Although infection is considered primarily blood borne, all tissues and body fluids are potentially infectious, especially during episodes of clinical disease when viral burdens are high. Transmission of EIA by biting flies is purely mechanical; the virus does not replicate in the vector. The chance of transmission of EIA is directly proportional to the volume of blood retained on the mouthparts of the insect after feeding. In that respect, horse flies, deer flies, and to a lesser extent, stable flies are likely the most efficient vectors. It is also because they are capable of triggering host defensive behavior that interrupts feeding and results in their seeking a new susceptible host to complete their blood meal.\"  Fly control is very important, in the barn and on the animal.  Currently there is no vaccine for EIA in the US. There is a vaccine developed in China and used in other places (see Equine infectious anemia - USA (04): (KY) unlicensed vaccine http://promedmail.org/post/20150915.3645562).  Portions of this comment were extracted from: (http://www.merckvetmanual.com/generalized-conditions/equine-infectious-anemia/overview-of-equine-infectious-anemia). - Mod.TG  The state of North Carolina can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/21375). Johnston county in east central North Carolina can be seen on the map at (http://geology.com/county-map/north-carolina-county-map.gif). - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"131":{"title":"Respiratory syncytial virus - Chile ","date":["28","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Respiratory syncytial virus - Chile [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Mon 28 Aug 2017. Source: Diario Aysen , trans. Mod.JG, edited (https://goo.gl/8k5UZP)   Last weekend, more than 20 children with severe respiratory symptoms were admitted to the Regional Hospital, and they were diagnosed with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection.  During the last week, 2 3-year-old children with severe respiratory illness were admitted to the intensive care unit, and one of them was waiting to be referred to Puerto Montt.  Therefore, with information updated until last Sat 26 Aug 2017, more than 30 children with RSV infection have been reported, and all of them are hospitalized in pediatrics, pediatric intensive care, and neonatal intensive care units. Meanwhile, because of the severity of their condition  most of them being infants  7 children have been referred to hospitals in Santiago and Concepcion so they may receive adequate care, since Coyhaique Regional Hospital (CRH) does not have a pediatric intensive care unit (ICU).  This is what Dr. Jaime Lopez-Quintana, Head of the CRH reported: \"This year 2017, RSV is behaving quite aggressively, and our adult intensive care unit is completely full with children. This is not an adequate condition for taking care of these children; this is not what our children in this region deserve,\" as he reported this situation to Ms. Gisela Alarcon-Rojas, Subsecretary of Healthcare Networks of the Chilean Ministry of Health, who verified the condition of children being taken care of in the (adult) ICU.  So, with this complex situation, Dr. Lopez-Quintana added that specialists from important children referral centers, particularly from Dr. Luis Calvo-Mackenna and Dr. Exequiel Fernandez-Cortes hospitals, will soon arrive to this region. \"We hope to have for the next 2 weeks the support of pediatricians trained in intensive medicine who may help the team we have here in Coyhaique,\" emphasized Dr. Lopez-Quintana.  According to information brought by the medical sub-direction from the Coyhaique Regional Hospital, the affected children are hospitalized in the following areas: pediatrics, neonatal intensive care unit, and (general) intensive care unit.  There are 10 infants hospitalized in the pediatrics service, while another 11 children have already been discharged; so now there are 14 beds available. In the neonatal ICU, 7 children are hospitalized; 2 of them are severely ill, and the capacity of the unit is 2 beds; while in the general ICU, 6 infants are hospitalized, and there are 2 beds available.  \"With respect to bed availability, the hospital is still able to cope with the situation. However, a working overload for the personnel has been observed, so that extra personnel have been recruited to cover the work shifts,\" explained Dr. Joaquin Garcia-Gay, Medical Subdirector of the CRH.  Also, Dr. Garcia-Gay explained that if a child develops a febrile illness, respiratory distress, intercostal retraction and malaise for 2 days, these are some of the symptoms that may indicate the presence of RSV, which mainly affects infants less than 2 years old.  \"So, if such symptoms occur, then the child must be brought to the Urgency Service. However, for those patients that develop mild respiratory symptoms, such as common cold or other similar conditions, it is preferable they are not brought to the Urgency Service, since they may be at risk for becoming infected with RSV from patients that are being hospitalized,\" the specialist advised.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. from HealthMap Alerts (promed@promedmail.org)  RSV is the most common cause of lower respiratory tract infections among young children worldwide. Most infants are infected before one year of age, and virtually everyone gets an RSV infection by 2 years of age.  Each year, on average, in the United States, RSV leads to: - 57 527 hospitalizations among children younger than 5 years old - 2.1 million outpatient visits among children younger than 5 years old - 177 000 hospitalizations and 14 000 deaths among adults older than 65 years.  In the United States and other areas with similar climates, RSV infections occur primarily during fall, winter, and spring (https://www.cdc.gov/rsv/research/us-surveillance.html). It is currently winter in Chile.  It is not clear what may have led to this current RSV outbreak in Chile. In 2001, an outbreak of RSV struck Santiago, Chile. 150 hospital admissions were registered daily during the height of the southern hemisphere winter. It was speculated that pollution may have played a role as Santiago is one of the world's most polluted cities. Chile's geography of surrounding mountains and heat inversions in winter dramatically increases the concentration of pollutants. Pollution leads to irritation of the respiratory tract making it more difficult for the immune system to respond to infections. (Excerpted from C Orellana. Respiratory syncytial virus outbreak in Chile. The Lancet Infec Dis. News desk. October 2001 DOI: (http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S1473-3099(01)00088-3)). - Mod.LK  A HealthMap of Chile may be found at (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/7)/.  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"134":{"title":"Salmonellosis, st Agbeni - USA: pet turtles ","date":["29","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Salmonellosis, st Agbeni - USA: pet turtles [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 29 Aug 2017. Source: CDC, _Salmonella_ Homepage, 2017 Outbreaks (edited) (https://www.cdc.gov/salmonella/agbeni-08-17/index.html)   Multistate outbreak of _Salmonella_ Agbeni infections linked to pet turtles, 2017 - CDC and multiple states are investigating a multistate outbreak of human Salmonellosis linked to contact with pet turtles. 37 people infected with the outbreak strain of _Salmonella_ enterica_ serotype Agbeni have been reported from 13 states. Illnesses started on dates ranging from 1 Mar 2017 to 3 Aug 2017. Of 33 people with available information, 16 have been hospitalized. No deaths have been reported. 12 (32 percent) ill people are children 5 years of age or younger.  States / Case count California / 1 Connecticut / 3 Illinois / 4 Louisiana / 2 Maryland / 2 Massachusetts / 2 Mississippi / 1 New Jersey / 1 New York / 11 Ohio / 3 Pennsylvania / 5 Texas / 1 Washington / 1 Total / 37  Epidemiologic and laboratory findings link the outbreak of human _Salmonella_ Agbeni infections to contact with turtles or their environments, such as water from a turtle habitat. In interviews, ill people answered questions about contact with animals during the week before becoming ill. 15 (45 percent) of the 33 people interviewed reported contact with turtles or their environments, such as water from a turtle habitat, before getting sick. In interviews with 9 ill people about where their turtles came from, 6 reported buying a turtle from a flea market or street vendor, or receiving the turtle as a gift.  In 2015, state and local health officials collected samples from turtles at a street vendor. Whole genome sequencing showed that the _Salmonella_ Agbeni isolated from ill people in this outbreak is closely related genetically to the _S._ Agbeni isolates from turtles. This close genetic relationship means that people in this outbreak are more likely to share a common source of infection.  Do not buy small turtles as pets or give them as gifts. Since 1975, the FDA has banned selling and distributing turtles with shells less than 4 inches long as pets because they are often linked to _Salmonella_ infections, especially in young children. All turtles, regardless of size, can carry _Salmonella_ bacteria even if they look healthy and clean. These outbreaks are a reminder to follow simple steps to enjoy pet reptiles and keep your family healthy.  This outbreak is expected to continue since consumers might be unaware of the risk of _Salmonella_ infection from small turtles. If properly cared for, turtles have a long life expectancy.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  In 2008, CDC reported on an ongoing outbreak of _S._ Paratyphi B var. Java (CDC: _Salmonella_ Infections Associated with Exposure to Turtles  USA, 2007-2008. Morbid Mortal Weekly Rep 2008; 57(03): 69-72; (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5703a3.htm). Some of the discussion of the report is reproduced below:  \"The prohibition on the sale and distribution of small turtles was enacted in 1975, after public health investigations demonstrated that small turtles were a major source of human _Salmonella_ infections, particularly in children. In 1972, a study in New Jersey indicated that small pet turtles accounted for approximately 23 percent of _Salmonella_ infections in children (4). In 1980, the 1975 prohibition was estimated to have prevented 100 000 _Salmonella_ infections in American children each year since going into effect (5). However, this prohibition has an exception: small turtles may be sold legally for scientific, educational, or exhibition purposes. During 2001-2006, the number of turtles kept as pets in the USA increased 86 percent to nearly 2 million turtles (6), suggesting that this exception might provide a mechanism by which small turtles become household pets.  \"Turtles, like other reptiles, commonly carry _Salmonella_, and fecal carriage rates can be as high as 90 percent (1). Small turtles sold as pets frequently come from breeding farms, where turtles are housed in crowded ponds and nesting areas in a way that promotes _Salmonella_ transmission (7). Attempts to treat turtles, turtle eggs, and turtle breeding ponds with antibiotics to eliminate _Salmonella_ have not been successful and have resulted in a high prevalence of antibiotic resistance (7,8). Other treatments reduce but do not eliminate shedding from turtles (8), and the turtles that continue to shed might recontaminate other turtles during rearing or shipment. Because shedding might be intermittent and stress related, determining whether turtles are free of the bacteria is difficult (1).  \"Direct or indirect contact with a reptile is associated with an estimated 6 percent of human salmonellosis in the USA (9). Persons coming into contact with reptiles, reptile habitats, or surfaces contaminated with reptile fecal matter risk infection from salmonellae shed by the reptile (10). Although most reptiles carry _Salmonella_, small turtles are likely to be handled differently than other reptiles and thus carry a greater risk of transmitting _Salmonella_ to children. In contrast to the obvious risk for a bite or scratch, for example, from a snake or an iguana, a small turtle is likely to be perceived as safe, and thus might be given directly to small children to play with. In addition, a young child placed in charge of caring for a turtle has direct contact with water in the turtle habitat, where salmonellae are likely to multiply to high numbers. Although approximately half of the infections associated with this outbreak occurred in young children, who are at greater risk for severe illness from salmonellosis (2,10), several illnesses occurred in adults with turtle exposure, demonstrating that turtle-associated salmonellosis is not unique to children. Additionally, only 20 percent of case-patients interviewed reported awareness of the link between salmonellosis and contact with reptiles, indicating that measures to educate the public about this link have not been successful. CDC has provided recommendations to prevent reptile-associated salmonellosis in humans (2). However, because of the particular hazard associated with small turtles, prohibiting the sale and distribution of small turtles likely remains the most effective public health action to prevent turtle-associated salmonellosis.  References - 1. Chiodini RJ, Sundberg JP: Salmonellosis in reptiles: a review. Am J Epidemiol 1981; 113(5): 494-9. 2. CDC: Turtle-associated salmonellosis in humans  United States, 2006-2007. MMWR 2007; 56(26): 649-52. Available at (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5626a1.htm). 3. CDC: Salmonellosis associated with pet turtles  Wisconsin and Wyoming, 2004. MMWR 2005; 54(09): 223-6. Available at (http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm5409a3.htm). 4. Lamm S, Taylor A, Gangarosa E, et al. Turtle-associated salmonellosis. I. An estimation of the magnitude of the problem in the United States, 1970-1971. Am J Epidemiol 1972; 95(6): 511-7. Abstract available at (http://aje.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/95/6/511). 5. Cohen ML, Potter M, Pollard R, Feldman RA: Turtle-associated salmonellosis in the United States: effect of public health action, 1970 to 1976. JAMA 1980; 243(12): 1247-9. Abstract available at (http://jama.ama-assn.org/content/243/12/1247.full.pdf). 6. American Veterinary Medical Association: US pet ownership and demographics sourcebook. Schaumburg, IL: American Veterinary Medical Association; 2007:2. 7. D'Aoust JY, Daley E, Crozier M, Sewell AM. Pet turtles: a continuing international threat to public health. Am J Epidemiol 1990; 132(2): 233-8. Abstract available at (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2372004). 8. Mitchell MA, Adamson T, Singleton C, et al: Evaluation of a combination of sodium hypochlorite and polyhexamethylene biguanide as an egg wash for red-eared slider turtles (_Trachemys scripta elegans_) to suppress or eliminate _Salmonella_ organisms on egg surfaces and in hatchlings. Am J Vet Res 2007; 68: 158-64. Abstract available at (http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=18496347). 9. Mermin J, Hutwagner L, Vugia D, et al. Reptiles, amphibians, and human _Salmonella_ infection: a population-based, case-control study. Clin Infect Dis 2004; 38: S253-61. Abstract available at (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15095197). 10. Mermin J, Hoar B, Angulo FJ: Iguanas and _Salmonella_ Marina infection in children: a reflection of the increasing incidence of reptile-associated salmonellosis in the United States. Pediatrics 1997; 99(3): 399-402. Abstract available at (http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/content/abstract/99/3/399).\"  A photograph of the red-eared slider turtle, the small turtle usually involved in this issue, is available at (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red-eared_slider). - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"136":{"title":"Zika virus (17): Americas, research, observations ","date":["24","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Zika virus (17): Americas, research, observations [EXTERNAL]","summary":"\nZIKA VIRUS (16): AMERICAS, RESEARCH, OBSERVATIONS\n*\nA ProMED-mail post\n(http://www.promedmail.org)\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n(http://www.isid.org) In this update:\n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries: Americas\n\nAmericas cumulative case numbers Cases in various countries not mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers. Mexico\n- Coahuila state Caribbean\n\nSint Maarten ex Saba South America\n\nBolivia (Santa Cruz department) Imported cases with little or no possibility of ongoing mosquito\ntransmission\nUSA\n- Case numbers mainland\n- Territories and Commonwealth <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ribavirin inhibits Zika virus\n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Zika virus skewed immunosuppression\n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Virus alters mosquito genes\n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Virus effects on sperm, body fluids\n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Vaccine update \n<br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Cases in various countries\nAmericas cumulative case numbers\nAs of 24 Aug mentioned above or more recent case\nnumbers.\nMexico\n\nMexico (Coahuila state). 24 Aug 2017.
