Zika virus disease in the United States, 1\nJan 2017-23 Aug 2017\n(http://www.cdc.gov/zika/geo/united-states.html)\nState / Symptomatic cases / Viremic blood donors\nAlabama 3 / 0\nAlaska 1 / 0\nArizona 1 / 0\nArkansas 0 / 0\nCalifornia 22 / 2\nColorado 4 / 0\nConnecticut 0 / 0\nDelaware 0 / 0\nDistrict of Columbia 0 / 0\nFlorida 31 / 3\nGeorgia 2 / 0\nHawaii 1 / 0\nIdaho 0 / 0\nIllinois 3 / 0\nIndiana 1 / 0\nIowa 1 / 0\nKansas 2 / 0\nKentucky 1 / 0\nLouisiana 1 / 0\nMaine 1 / 0\nMaryland 8 / 0\nMassachusetts 7 / 0\nMichigan 7 / 0\nMinnesota 5 / 0\nMississippi 2 / 0\nMissouri 1 / 0\nMontana 0 / 0\nNebraska 1 / 0\nNevada 1 / 0\nNew Hampshire 0 / 0\nNew Jersey 6 / 0\nNew Mexico 0 / 0\nNew York 43 / 1\nNorth Carolina 5 / 0\nNorth Dakota 0 / 0\nOhio 3 / 0\nOklahoma 1 / 0\nOregon 3 / 0\nPennsylvania 4 / 1\nRhode Island 3 / 0\nSouth Carolina 2 / 0\nSouth Dakota 0 / 0\nTennessee 0 / 0\nTexas 18 / 1\nUtah 3 / 0\nVermont 3 / 0\nVirginia 5 / 0\nWashington 3 / 0\nWest Virginia 1 / 1\nWisconsin 3 / 0\nWyoming 2 / 0\nTotals 215 / 9 - Territories and Commonwealth with local transmission:\nSymptomatic / Blood donors\nAmerican Samoa 39 / 0\nPuerto Rico 475 / 3\nUS Virgin Islands 41 / 0\nTotal 555 / 3 A map of the USA showing the states and territories mentioned above\ncan be accessed at (http://www.mapsofworld.com/usa/). - Mod.TY \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ribavirin inhibits Zika virus.\nDate: 14 Aug 2017.\nSource: Antiviral Research journal (edited)\n(http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166354217301973) \nref: Kamiyama N, Soma R, Hidano S, et al. Ribavirin inhibits Zika\nvirus (ZIKV) replication in vitro and suppresses viremia in\nZIKV-infected STAT1-deficient mice. Antiviral Res. 2017; 146: 1-11.\ndoi: 10.1016/j.antiviral.2017.08.007\n-\nHighlights\n- Ribavirin inhibits ZIKV replication in mammalian cells.\n- Ribavirin prevents ZIKV-induced apoptosis and cell death.\n- Ribavirin administration abrogates viremia in ZIKV-infected\nSTAT1-deficient mice.\n- Leading to a prolonged survival.\nAbstract\nZika fever, a mosquito-borne infectious disease caused by Zika virus\n(ZIKV), is an epidemic disease for which no effective therapy has been\nestablished. The recent outbreaks of ZIKV in Brazil and French\nPolynesia have been linked to a considerable increase in the incidence\nof fetal microcephaly and other diseases such as Guillain-Barre\nsyndrome. Because there is currently no specific therapy or vaccine,\nthe early exploitation of a method to prevent expansion of ZIKV is a\nhigh priority. To validate commonly used antiviral drugs, we evaluated\nthe effect of ribavirin, a drug used to treat hepatitis C with\ninterferon-beta (IFN-beta), on ZIKV replication. In mammalian cells,\nwe observed an inhibitory effect of ribavirin on ZIKV replication and\nZIKV-induced cell death without cytotoxic effect. Furthermore, we\nfound that STAT1-deficient mice, which lack type I IFN signaling, were\nhighly sensitive to ZIKV infection and exhibited lethal outcome.\nRibavirin abrogated viremia in ZIKV-infected STAT-1-deficient mice.\nThese data suggest that the inhibition of viral RNA-dependent RNA\npolymerases may be effective for treatment of ZIKV infection. Our data\nprovide a new insight into the mechanisms for inhibition of ZIKV\nreplication and prevention of Zika fever. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It will be interesting to see if these encouraging results showing\ninhibition of Zika virus replication can be replicated in non-human\nprimates. The challenge for use of drugs to inhibit Zika virus\ninfection in humans is that most (around 80 percent) Zika virus\ninfections are asymptomatic or have very mild symptoms. These\nindividuals will probably not seek medical treatment, even though\ntheir fetuses are at risk of infection with teratogenic effects. -\nMod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{3}</strong> Zika virus skewed immunosuppression.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: Nature Microbiology journal (edited)\n(http://www.nature.com/articles/s41564-017-0016-3) \nref: Foo SS, Chen W, Chan Y, et al. Asian Zika virus strains target\nCD14+ blood monocytes and induce M2-skewed immunosuppression during\npregnancy. Nat Microbiol. 2017. doi: 10.1038/s41564-017-0016-3\n-\nAbstract\nBlood CD14+ monocytes are frontline immunomodulators categorized into\nclassical, intermediate or non-classical subsets, and subsequently\ndifferentiated into M1 pro- or M2 anti-inflammatory macrophages on\nstimulation. Although the Zika virus (ZIKV) rapidly establishes\nviraemia, the target cells and immune responses, particularly during\npregnancy, remain elusive. Furthermore, it is unknown whether African-\nand Asian-lineage ZIKV have different phenotypic impacts on host\nimmune responses. Using human blood infection, we identified CD14+\nmonocytes as the primary target for African- or Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection. When immunoprofiles of human blood infected with ZIKV were\ncompared, a classical/intermediate monocyte-mediated M1-skewed\ninflammation by the African-lineage ZIKV infection was observed, in\ncontrast to a non-classical monocyte-mediated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression by the Asian-lineage ZIKV infection. Importantly,\ninfection of the blood of pregnant women revealed an enhanced\nsusceptibility to ZIKV infection. Specifically, Asian-lineage ZIKV\ninfection of pregnant women's blood led to an exacerbated M2-skewed\nimmunosuppression of non-classical monocytes in conjunction with a\nglobal suppression of type I interferon-signaling pathway and an\naberrant expression of host genes associated with pregnancy\ncomplications. Also, 30 ZIKV+ sera from symptomatic pregnant patients\nshowed elevated levels of M2-skewed immunosuppressive cytokines and\npregnancy-complication-associated fibronectin-1. This study\ndemonstrates the differential immunomodulatory responses of blood\nmonocytes, particularly during pregnancy, on infection with different\nlineages of ZIKV. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n(promed@promedmail.org) \n<br><br><strong>{4}</strong> Virus alters mosquito genes.\nDate: Tue 22 Aug 2017.\nSource: bioRxiv journal (edited)\n(http://www.biorxiv.org/content/early/2017/08/22/179416) \nref: Etebari K, Hegde S, Saldana MA, et al. Global transcriptome\nanalysis of _Aedes aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to Zika virus\ninfection. bioRxiv 179416; doi:10.1101/179416\n-\nZika virus (ZIKV) of the Flaviviridae family is a recently emerged\nmosquito-borne virus that has been implicated in the surge of the\nnumber of microcephaly instances in South America. The recent rapid\nspread of the virus led to its declaration as a global health\nemergency by the World Health Organization. The virus is transmitted\nmainly by the mosquito _Aedes aegypti_ that also vectors dengue virus,\nhowever little is known about the interactions of the virus with the\nmosquito vector. In this study, we investigated the transcriptome\nprofiles of whole _Ae. aegypti_ mosquitoes in response to ZIKV\ninfection at 2, 7, and 14 days post-infection using RNA-Seq. Results\nshowed changes in the abundance of a large number of transcripts at\neach time point following infection, with 18 transcripts commonly\nchanged among the 3 time points. Gene ontology analysis revealed that\nmost of the altered genes are involved in metabolic process, cellular\nprocess and proteolysis. In addition, 486 long intergenic non-coding\nRNAs were identified altered upon ZIKV infection. Further, we found\ncorrelational changes of a number of potential mRNA target genes with\nthat of altered host microRNAs. The outcomes provide a basic\nunderstanding of _Ae. aegypti_ responses to ZIKV and helps to\ndetermine host factors involved in replication or mosquito host\nanti-viral response against the virus. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) Mosquito vector competence depends on the relationship of virus and\nthe mosquito, and the defenses that the mosquito can mobilize against\nthe virus infection. Studies, such as the one above, can document the\nchanges that occur when the virus infects the mosquito, and if\ndifferences in relative vector efficiency of different geographic\nstrains of this mosquito might be related to alternations in mosquito\ngenes when infected. It would be interesting to know if these gene\nchanges affect fitness, and especially longevity of infected\nmosquitoes. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{5}</strong> Virus effects on sperm, body fluids.\nDate: Mon 21 Aug 2017.\nSource: The Lancet Infectious Diseases journal (edited)\n(http://www.thelancet.com/journals/laninf/article/PIIS1473-3099(17)30444-9/abstract) \nref: Joguet G, Mansuy JM, Matusali G, et al. Effect of acute Zika\nvirus infection on sperm and virus clearance in body fluids: a\nprospective observational study. Lancet Infect Dis. 2017. pii:\nS1473-3099(17)30444-9. doi: 10.1016/S1473-3099(17)30444-9\n-\nSummary\nBackground\nEvidence of human sexual transmission during Zika virus emergence is a\nmatter of concern, particularly in procreation, but to date, kinetics\nof seminal shedding and the effects of infection on human reproductive\nfunction have not been described. To investigate the effects of Zika\nvirus infection on semen and clearance of Zika virus from semen and\nbody fluids, we aimed to study a cohort of Zika virus-infected men. Methods\nThis prospective observational study recruited men presenting with\nacute Zika virus infection at Pointe-Ã -Pitre University Hospital in\nGuadeloupe, French Caribbean, where a Zika virus outbreak occurred\nbetween April and November, 2016. Blood, urine, and semen were\ncollected at days 7, 11, 20, 30, 60, 90, and 120 after symptom onset,\nand semen characteristics, such as total sperm count, sperm motility,\nvitality, and morphology, and reproductive hormone concentrations,\nsuch as testosterone, inhibin, follicle-stimulating hormone, and\nluteinising hormone, were assessed. At days 7, 11, and 20, semen was\nprocessed to isolate motile spermatozoa. Zika virus RNA was detected\nby RT-PCR using whole blood, serum, urine, seminal plasma, semen\ncells, and motile spermatozoa fractions. Zika virus was isolated from\ndifferent sperm fractions on Vero E6 cultures. Findings\n15 male volunteers (mean age 35 years SD 5; range 25-44) with acute\nZika virus infection and positive Zika virus RNA detection in blood or\nurine were enrolled. Total sperm count was decreased from median\n119âÃâ10^6 spermatozoa (IQR interquartile range 22-234)\nat day 7, to 45.2âÃâ10^6 (16.5-89.6) at day 30, and 70\nÃ 10^6 (28.5-81.4) at day 60, respectively, after Zika virus\ninfection. Inhibin values increased from 93.5 pg/mL (IQR 55-162) at\nday 7 to 150 pg/mL (78-209) at day 120 when total sperm count\nrecovered. In motile spermatozoa obtained after density gradient\nseparation, Zika virus RNA was found in 3 of 14 patients at day 7, 4\nof 15 at day 11, and 4 of 15 at day 20, and replication-competent\nvirus was found in the tested patient. Seminal shedding kinetics\nseemed heterogeneous among patients. Whole blood was the fluid most\nfrequently positive for Zika virus RNA (62 of 92 samples) and 3\npatients remained positive at day 120. Interpretation\nSemen alterations early after acute Zika virus infection might affect\nfertility and could be explained by virus effects on the testis and\nepididymis. Frequency of shedding and high viral load in semen,\ntogether with the presence of replicative virus in a motile\nspermatozoa fraction, can lead to Zika virus transmission during\nsexual contact and assisted reproduction procedures. Whole blood seems\nto be the best specimen for Zika virus RNA detection, diagnosis, and\nfollow-up. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall In a new study that included 12 men in French Guiana who had Zika\nvirus, 4 never had any detectable Zika in their semen, 1 excreted Zika\nvirus in his semen for at least 3 days, and 7 had Zika virus in semen\nfor at least 1 month. The maximum duration of detectable Zika in semen\nin the study was 45 days ((http://tinyurl.com/y9nhtgtk)). This report\nwas provided by Roland HÃ¼bner. - Mod.TY \n<br><br><strong>{6}</strong> Vaccine update.\nDate: 22/29 Aug 2017.\nSource: Journal of the American Medical Association, JAMA (edited)\n(http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullarticle/2649168) \nref: Lyon J. Vaccines protect fetus from Zika. JAMA. 2017; 318(8):\n689. doi:10.1001/jama.2017.11200\n-\nResearchers funded in part by the National Institutes of Health have\nrecently demonstrated that 2 experimental vaccines can restrict\ntransmission of Zika virus from pregnant mice to their fetuses,\nthereby shielding offspring from congenital damage or death. Multiple candidate Zika vaccines have been shown protective against\ninfection with the virus in animal studies, with several now in human\ntrials, but none were tested in the context of pregnancy, according to\nthe authors of the study published in Cell\n(http://www.cell.com/cell/fulltext/S0092-8674(17)30759-6). The 2\nvaccine candidates investigated in the new study are the 1st to\ndemonstrate efficacy in preventing vertical transmission of the virus\nand related fetal death in an animal model. Although the vaccines were\nadministered to female mice prior to pregnancy, the result is\nconsidered an important step toward developing a vaccine that could be\nsafely given to pregnant women. One of the 2 candidates is a modified messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine\nencoding Zika genes, developed by the biotechnology company Moderna.\nIt is already in safety trials in women who are not pregnant. The\nother is a live-attenuated Zika strain developed by researchers at the\nUniversity of Texas Medical Branch (UTMB). The testing was carried out by scientists from the National Institute\nof Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Washington University School of\nMedicine, and UTMB. The researchers 1st vaccinated the mice with 1 of\nthe vaccines or a placebo. After mating, the animals were challenged\nwith the virus 6 days into pregnancy. A week later, more than 50\npercent of placentas and fetuses from mice administered the mRNA\nvaccine had virtually no Zika RNA. The remainder had \"substantially\nlower\" levels relative to placebo.\nThe live vaccine provided broader protection: 78 percent of placentas\nand 83 percent of fetuses had Zika RNA at or below the level of\ndetection, while the placebo group exhibited significantly higher\nlevels of placental and fetal Zika RNA. Mice vaccinated with either\nvaccine had significantly higher rates of fetal viability; whereas 100\npercent of fetuses from mice vaccinated with the mRNA vaccine were\nborn, none survived to term in the placebo group. A working group funded by the Wellcome Trust recently approved ethical\nguidelines for testing such vaccines in pregnant women, normally\nexcluded from drug trials. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) It is reassuring to learn that at least 2 vaccines are now entering\nclinical trials in women. Although anti-Zika virus drugs are under\ndevelopment, preventing infection through vaccination seems to be the\nmost effective measure to prevent fetal infection and adverse effects\nof the virus infection in adults. - Mod.TY ","keywordsMatched":[]},"180":{"title":"Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (08): (GA, OH) equine\r\n\t","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Eastern equine encephalitis - USA (08): (GA, OH) equine\r\n\t[EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org)  In this update: <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Georgia <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ohio   <br><br><strong>{1}</strong> Georgia. Date: 29 Aug 2017. Source: WSAV (edited) (http://wsav.com/2017/08/29/health-dept-horse-in-bryan-county-tests-positive-for-eee/)   According to the Bryan County Health Department, a horse in Bryan County has tested positive for eastern equine encephalitis (EEE).  EEE virus is a mosquito-borne virus that causes swelling of the brain and is fatal in horses 70 to 90 percent of the time. EEE has also been detected in the mosquito population in western Chatham County, and a horse in Effingham County tested positive for EEE earlier this month August 2017.  The health department encourages horse and large animal owners to vaccinate their animals against the virus and to clean out watering sources, such as buckets and troughs every 3 to 4 days to prevent mosquitoes from breeding in those areas.  For more information on EEE, see: (http://www.cdc.gov/EasternEquineEncephalitis/).   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)   <br><br><strong>{2}</strong> Ohio. Date: 31 Aug 2017. Source: North West Signal (edited) (http://www.northwestsignal.net/news/ag_business/article_455ad7f1-41e9-555a-9d2b-70451f258b60.html)   A horse from Ashtabula County was recently confirmed to have eastern equine encephalitis (EEE) by the Ohio Department of Agriculture's (ODA) Animal Disease Diagnostic Laboratory.  The animal was euthanized in late July 2017 after showing neurological signs. The animal was not vaccinated against the disease and lived near a low-lying area typically prone to harboring mosquitoes. EEE is often transmitted by mosquitoes and can be transmitted to humans; however, only a few cases are reported each year, and most infected persons report no apparent illness.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  The arbovirus season is upon us. The watch word is \"vaccinate!\"  The EEE vaccination is usually combined with western EE, West Nile virus and tetanus. This is cheap insurance to protect your animal from these diseases. If you have not already vaccinated, please do so now. If you vaccinated longer than 6 months ago, please revaccinate, as EEE immunity wanes the fastest. - Mod.TG  ProMED HealthMaps: Georgia, United States: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/213) Ohio, United States: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/237)  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Uruguay":{},"Uzbekistan":{},"Vanuatu":{"182":{"title":"Invasive mosquito - New Caledonia (02): comment ","date":["31","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Invasive mosquito - New Caledonia (02): comment [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017. From: Michael J. Bangs (mbangs@fmi.com) (edited)   It stands to reason that the presence of _Anopheles farauti_ as the new entrant into New Caledonia is presumably recent. The nearest neighbor is Vanuatu, a malaria-endemic country that has but one anopheline species present in that island group, _Anopheles farauti_ sensu stricto, an effective malaria vector provided you add _Plasmodium_ to the mix.  _Anopheles farauti_ is one member of 8 known sibling species in the _Farauti_ Complex (closely related species that are morphologically identical, thus confounding accurate identification without the use of molecular techniques). It is by far the most widely distributed species in the complex in the southwest Pacific region (Maluku island group, eastern Indonesia to northern Australia, PNG, Solomon Islands and Vanuatu). The species' ability to inhabit brackish water environments (predominantly a coastal inhabitant) has aided in its dispersal throughout the region.  The origin of the anopheline population in New Caledonia might remain a mystery, but this discovery is of concern. If the area of establishment is relatively confined, it might be possible to eliminate this species before it extends further into the country. Foremost, identify the species.   Michael J. Bangs, MSPH, PhD. Public Health & Malaria Control International SOS Kuala Kencana, Papua, Indonesia (mbangs@fmi.com)  ProMED thanks Dr. Bangs for his comments.  The _Anopheles_ reported in the previous posting was found in an area of La Tontouta, north of Noumea. One hopes that the area of discovery is small enough to permit control.  Maps of New Caledonia can be accessed at (https://media1.britannica.com/eb-media/93/3293-004-8AA31F9B.jpg) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/459). - Mod.TY  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Venezuela":{},"Vietnam":{"260":{"title":["Dengue in Vietnam"],"date":["24","August","2017"],"url":"wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/watch/dengue-vietnam","summary":" (!DOCTYPE html)  (!if lt IE 8)(html class=\"no-js nav theme-teal lt-ie10 lt-ie9 lt-ie8\" lang=\"en-us\")(!endif) (!if IE 8)(html class=\"no-js nav theme-teal lt-ie10 lt-ie9\" lang=\"en-us\")(!endif) (!if IE 9)(html class=\"no-js nav theme-teal lt-ie10\" lang=\"en-us\")(!endif) (!if !IE)(!) End Left Nav )  (div class=\"breadcrumbs hidden-one span19\")   (div class=\"bread-crumb hidden-one\")(/div) (/div)        (div class=\"span19 pagetitle\")       (h1)Dengue in Vietnam(/h1)      (/div)     (div id=\"share-bar\" class=\"span19\")   (div class=\"socialmediabar\")     (div class=\"row\")       (div class=\"hidden-one pull-right\")(/div)        (div class=\"span8\")         (div id=\"socialMediaShareContainer\") \t(div class=\"share_container noLinking\")  \t(a class=\"share_button_facebook\" title=\"Facebook\" href=\"#\")(span class=\"tp-sr-only\")Recommend on Facebook(/span)(span id=\"share_facebook\" class=\"facebookRecommend\") (/span)(/a)  \t(a class=\"share_button_twitter\" title=\"Twitter\" href=\"#\")(span class=\"tp-sr-only\")Tweet(/span)(span id=\"share_twitter\" class=\"twitterTweet\") (/span)(/a)  (a class=\"share_button\" href=\"#socialMediaShareContainer\" )(img src=\"//www.cdc.gov/TemplatePackage/3.0/images/social/addthis-32.png\" alt=\"Share\" /)(span class=\"shareButtonEn tp-sr-only\" aria-label=\"Share\")Share(/span)(span class=\"shareButtonEs tp-sr-only\" aria-label=\"Compartir\")Compartir(/span)(/a) \t(/div) (/div)  (! target anchor for return to top feature in VP1 ) (a id=\"content-start\" tabindex=\"-1\")(/a)        (/div)     (/div)   (/div) (/div)   (div id=\"body\" class=\"span19 \")   (div id=\"contentArea\")          (div class=\"nav-related hidden-three hidden-four\")(/div)       (div class=\"row\")   (div class=\"span19 ntl\")        (div class=\"disabled nt\")Warning - Level 3, Avoid Nonessential Travel(/div)       (div class=\"disabled nt\")Alert - Level 2, Practice Enhanced Precautions(/div)       (div class=\"nt-watch nt\")Watch - Level 1, Practice Usual Precautions(/div)   (/div) (/div)  (div class=\"notice\")(h3)What is the current situation?(/h3) (p)Recently, there has been a large increase in the number of dengue cases in Vietnam, according to a World Health Organization (WHO) report. As of August 2017, more than 80,000 cases have been reported. Although most cases have been reported in the south, there has been a sharp increase in cases in the north, especially in Hanoi.(/p) (p)Dengue is spread through mosquito bites and can cause symptoms such as fever, headache, nausea, vomiting, rash, and pain in the eyes, joints, and muscles.(/p) (h3)What can travelers do to prevent dengue?(/h3) (p)Because mosquitoes transmit dengue to people, travelers to Vietnam should (a href=\"https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/page/avoid-bug-bites\")protect themselves against mosquito bites(/a) to avoid getting the illness. There is no vaccine or medicine currently available in the United States to prevent or treat dengue.(/p) (p)Learn more about dengue, how to prevent it, and what to do if you think you are infected at&nbsp;(a href=\"https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/diseases/dengue\")CDC&rsquo;s dengue page for travelers(/a).(/p) (h3)Traveler Information(/h3) (ul)   (li)(a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/dengue/resources/factsheets/factsheet_dengue-what-you-need-to-know.pdf\" target=\"_blank\")Dengue Virus: What You Need to Know(/a)(/li)   (li)(a href=\"https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/page/avoid-bug-bites\")Avoid Bug Bites(/a)(/li) (/ul) (h3)Clinician Information(/h3) (ul)   (li)(a href=\"https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2018/infectious-diseases-related-to-travel/dengue\")Dengue(/a)&nbsp;in&nbsp;(em)CDC Health Information for International Travel,&nbsp;(/em)the &ldquo;Yellow Book&rdquo;(/li)   (li)(a href=\"https://www.cdc.gov/dengue/clinicallab/index.html\")Clinical &amp; Laboratory Guidance(/a)(/li) (/ul) (/div)(div class=\"clear\")(/div)      (/div) (/div)           (/div)         (div class=\"row\")           (div class=\"span24 visible-one\")            (/div)         (/div)         (div class=\"row\")           (div class=\"span24\")     if (navigator.appVersion.indexOf('MSIE') )= 0) document.write(unescape('%3C') + '\\!-' + '-');     //)(/script)     (noscript)(a href=\"https://www.omniture.com\" title=\"Web Analytics\")(img src=\"https://mtrics.cdc.gov/b/ss/cdcgov/1/H.21NS/0\" height=\"1\" width=\"1\" alt=\"\" /)(/a)(/noscript)     (!/DO NOT REMOVE/)                             (/div)                 (script type=\"text/javascript\" src=\"/travel/scripts/public-bundled.min.js?v=2\")(/script) (/body)  (/html) ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Western Sahara":{},"Yemen":{"63":{"title":"Cholera,\r\n\tdiarrhea & dysentery update (87): Asia (Yemen) ","date":["20","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera,\r\n\tdiarrhea & dysentery update (87): Asia (Yemen) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Sun 20 Aug 2017. Source: Al Arabiya (edited) (http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/gulf/2017/08/20/Cholera-death-toll-in-Yemen-rises-to-1997.html)   WHO has announced another 22 deaths within the last 5 days caused by cholera in Yemen. The reported numbers affirm a total of 1997 deaths starting from the end of April 2017. As of Saturday evening 19 Aug 2017, the number of cholera cases stands at 527 000.  The WHO report also noted that Yemen's Sanaa and Al Hudaydah governorate, located in the west of the country, have the highest rates of cholera spread compared with other governorates. The combined number of infected individuals in the two areas stands at 62 000. The Hajjah governorate has maintained the highest number of cholera related deaths reported at 381.  Meanwhile, the United Nations has raised the Humanitarian Response Plan budget to address the Yemeni crisis. The new budget is placed at USD 370 million. Despite the critical situation in Yemen and the spread of cholera, the international organization said that only 33 per cent of the required funds have been provided by donors, most notably Saudi Arabia.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Although a number of sources had reported decreasing numbers of daily cases, the new numbers seem to support the continuing robust number of daily cases. If the epidemic were to continue at the current rate of cases per day, by the end of 2017, there could be 700 000 more cases for a total of 1.12 million cases since the end of April 2017, with 3300 more deaths for a total of about 5500 deaths over that period.  The statistics related to this record-breaking epidemic of _V. cholerae_ in Yemen are shown below:  Date (2017) / Cases / Deaths 8 May / 1360 / 25 11 May / 2752 / 51 13 May / 8595 / 115 14 May / 11 000 / 180 17 May / 17 200 / 209 19 May / 23 500 / 242 21 May / 29 300 / 315 22 May / 35 217 / 361 24 May / 42 207 / 420 27 May / 51 832 / 471 30 May / 65 300 / 532 2 Jun / 73 700 / 605 4 Jun / 86 400 / 676 5 Jun / 91 400 / 728 6 Jun / 96 000 / 746 7 Jun / 101 820 / 789 10 Jun / 116 700 / 869 12 Jun / 124 002 / 923 14 Jun / 140 116 / 989 16 Jun / 151 000 / 1054 19 Jun / 166 976 / 1146 21 Jun / 179 548 / 1205 23 Jun / 200 000 / 1310 26 Jun / 219 000 / 1400 28 Jun / 231 364 / 1439 30 Jun / 240 000 / 1500 4 Jul / 275 987 / 1634 7 Jul / 297 438 / 1706 10 Jul / 313 538 / 1732 13 Jul / 332 600 / 1759 17 Jul / 356 591 / 1802 20 Jul / 368 207 / 1828 25 Jul / 402 484 / 1880 26 Jul / 408 583 / 1885 29 Jul / 419 804 / 1912 7 Aug / 463 000 / 1940 13 Aug / 494 000 / 1966 19 Aug / 527 000 / 1997  In the last complete year of data (2015; (http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/250142/1/WER9138.pdf)), WHO reported a total of 172 454 cases worldwide in 42 countries. This continuing cholera disaster in Yemen is only almost 16 weeks old and now has more than 3 times the total number of cases of 2015 and 50 per cent more than the peak year of the Haiti outbreak (2011) of 340 311 cases. - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/126).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"90":{"title":"Cholera,\r\n\tdiarrhea & dysentery update (89): Asia (Yemen) ","date":["22","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera,\r\n\tdiarrhea & dysentery update (89): Asia (Yemen) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Tue 22 Aug 2017. Source: WHO (edited) (http://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/yemen-cholera-response-weekly-epidemiological-bulletin-w33-2017-aug-14-aug-20-enar)   Yemen: cholera response. Weekly Epidemiological Bulletin: W33 2017 (Aug 14-Aug 20)  Country level:  - The cumulative total from 27 Apr 2017 to 20 Aug 2017 is 542 278 cases and 2003 deaths (case fatality rate CFR 0.37 per cent). A total of 27 766 cases and 17 deaths were reported in week 33.  - A peak is observed week 26 and the weekly number of cases have been decreasing since that week (6 consecutive weeks).  - However, the trend of the last 3 weeks is considered as stable (-7 percent). The average of weekly cases for the last 3 weeks is 36 603.  - Children under 5 represent 23 per cent of cases. Children under 18 represent 53 per cent of cases.  - In total 10 108 rapid diagnostic tests (RDT) have been performed, which represents 18.6 per cent coverage.  \nGovernorate and district level:  - In total, 22 of 23 governorates (96 per cent) and 300 of 333 districts (90 per cent) are affected by the outbreak. Up to 3 new districts were affected this week week of Sun 20 Aug 2017.  - No interruption in transmission is observed yet in any governorates.  - The 5 governorates with the highest cumulative attack rates per 10 000 are Al Mahwit (432), Al Dhaele'e (421), Amran (366), Abyan (312) and Sana'a (240).  - The trend of the last 3 weeks has increased in 3 governorates (Al Jawf, Saada, Shabwah) and decreased in 9 governorates. The trend is decreasing or stable in the 4 governorates with the highest attack rates.  - Raymah governorate remains with a cumulative CFR above the threshold (1.1 per cent).  District prioritization:  - A total of 86 districts have been identified for prioritization based on attack rate, trend and population size. - In 35 districts, the CFR is )1 per cent, and these have been targeted for urgent review of case management practices.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Although a number of sources have reported decreasing numbers of daily cases, the numbers seem to support the continuing robust number of daily cases. If the epidemic were to continue at the current rate of cases per day, by the end of 2017, there could be 700 000 more cases for a total of 1.12 million cases since the end of April 2017, with 3300 more deaths for a total of about 5500 deaths over that period.  The statistics related to this record-breaking epidemic of _Vibrio cholerae_ infection in Yemen are shown below:  Date (2017) / Cases / Deaths 8 May / 1360 / 25 11 May / 2752 / 51 13 May / 8595 / 115 14 May / 11 000 / 180 17 May / 17 200 / 209 19 May / 23 500 / 242 21 May / 29 300 / 315 22 May / 35 217 / 361 24 May / 42 207 / 420 27 May / 51 832 / 471 30 May / 65 300 / 532 2 Jun / 73 700 / 605 4 Jun / 86 400 / 676 5 Jun / 91 400 / 728 6 Jun / 96 000 / 746 7 Jun / 101 820 / 789 10 Jun / 116 700 / 869 12 Jun / 124 002 / 923 14 Jun / 140 116 / 989 16 Jun / 151 000 / 1054 19 Jun / 166 976 / 1146 21 Jun / 179 548 / 1205 23 Jun / 200 000 / 1310 26 Jun / 219 000 / 1400 28 Jun / 231 364 / 1439 30 Jun / 240 000 / 1500 4 Jul / 275 987 / 1634 7 Jul / 297 438 / 1706 10 Jul / 313 538 / 1732 13 Jul / 332 600 / 1759 17 Jul / 356 591 / 1802 20 Jul / 368 207 / 1828 25 Jul / 402 484 / 1880 26 Jul / 408 583 / 1885 29 Jul / 419 804 / 1912 7 Aug / 463 000 / 1940 13 Aug / 494 000 / 1966 17 Aug / 527 000 / 1997 20 Aug / 542 278 / 2003  In the last complete year of data (2015; (http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/250142/1/WER9138.pdf)), WHO reported a total of 172 454 cases worldwide in 42 countries. This continuing cholera disaster in Yemen is only almost 16 weeks old and now has more than 3 times the total number of cases of 2015 and 50 per cent more than the peak year of the Haiti outbreak (2011) of 340 311 cases. - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/126).  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"120":{"title":"Cholera,\r\n\tdiarrhea & dysentery update (91): Asia (Yemen) ","date":["26","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera,\r\n\tdiarrhea & dysentery update (91): Asia (Yemen) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Sat 26 Aug 2017. Source: Anadolu Agency (edited) (http://aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/cholera-has-killed-2-018-people-in-yemen-who/894568)   A total of 2018 people have been killed by a cholera epidemic in war-torn Yemen since late April 2017, the WHO said Sat 26 Aug 2017.  In a statement, the WHO said 565 041 suspected cases of cholera have been recorded in the country since 27 Apr 2017. According to the WHO statement, the recorded suspected cases were in 22 out of 23 provinces. The UN agency said the highest number of fatalities, 382 cases, was recorded in the northwestern Hajjah province, while in western Yemen's Hudaida province only around 70 000 suspected cases were recorded.  Impoverished Yemen has remained in a state of civil war since 2014, when Houthi rebels overran much of the country, including the capital Sanaa. The conflict escalated when Saudi Arabia and its Arab allies launched a massive air campaign in 2015 aimed at reversing Houthi military gains and shoring up Yemen's embattled government.  According to the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC), over 3 million people have fled their homes since the onset of the Yemen conflict, and more than 20 million throughout the country are in need of humanitarian assistance.  Byline: Mohamed al-Samei   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Although a number of sources have reported decreasing numbers of daily cases, the numbers seem to support the continuing robust number of daily cases. If the epidemic were to continue at the current rate of cases per day, by the end of 2017, there could be 700 000 more cases for a total of 1.12 million cases since the end of April 2017, with 3300 more deaths for a total of about 5500 deaths over that period. Date: Thu 31 Aug 2017.\nSource: Athr News in Arabic, trans. Mod.MM, edited\n(http://www.athrnews.org/athr257473pp) \nToday, Thu 31 Aug 2017 the General Directorate of Health-Jizan\nregion tweeted regarding the detection of 4 cases of cholera among the\nexpatriates with positive laboratory results. The tweet added that the\nnecessary control measures for the above mentioned cases and their\ncontacts have been undertaken. \n<br><br>Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n(promed@promedmail.org) As noted by my MENA colleague MM, in the above mentioned news wire it\nis not clear the country of origin of the affected expatriate cases\n(called wafideen in Arabic versus citizens). However, taking into\naccount the close proximity of Jizan city to Yemen, one might assume\nthese cases may have crossed the borders from Yemen as Jizan is one of\nthe gates to pilgrims going for Hajj these days. Jizan Region ((https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jizan_Region)) is the 2nd\nsmallest (after Al Bahah) region of Saudi Arabia. It stretches 300 km\n186.41 mi along the southern Red Sea coast, just north of Yemen. It\ncovers an area of 11 671 km² 4506.19 mi² and has a population of 1\n365 110 at the 2010 census (preliminary result). The region has the\nhighest population density in the Kingdom. - Mod.LL ","keywordsMatched":[]},"177":{"title":"Cholera,\r\n\tdiarrhea & dysentery update (93): Asia (Yemen) ","date":["30","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/EDR> Cholera,\r\n\tdiarrhea & dysentery update (93): Asia (Yemen) [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Fri 1 Sep 2017. Source: Save the Children (edited) (http://reliefweb.int/report/yemen/alarming-cholera-spike-yemen-coastal-region)   An outbreak of cholera has spiked dramatically in several areas of Yemen, including its largest governorate of Hodeidah, Save the Children is warning.  \nRecent health figures from the WHO reveal a far more mixed picture than reports of a nationwide slow-down have previously suggested.  In the coastal Hodeidah Governorate, where the charity runs malnutrition and cholera treatment centres, suspected cholera cases have jumped by 40 percent over the past 3 weeks amid heavy rains and a heat wave. Some districts are now reporting weekly caseload figures more than double their previous peaks. Hodeidah also has some of the worst malnutrition rates in the country, with an estimated one in 4 children under the age of 5 suffering from acute malnutrition. Save the Children has previously warned of the deadly link between hunger and cholera, with malnourished children at least 3 times more likely to die from diarrhoeal diseases.  Neighboring Raymah Governorate has seen an 18 percent increase in suspected cases over the past 3 weeks, while the southern port of Aden has seen a 12 percent jump.  James Denselow, Head of Conflict and Humanitarian Policy at Save the Children, said: \"This epidemic has spread at a frightening rate, and it's clear we're far from seeing the end of it. Given the ongoing bombing, and restrictions on bringing life-saving aid into the country, aid agencies are struggling to get cholera under control. Just when we think we've got it under control in one area, it suddenly spikes elsewhere.\"  \"We need to get more medical supplies, fuel and food into Yemen and to the children who need it without delay. The warring parties that are obstructing the country's ports, roads and airspace are directly responsible for this cholera outbreak and must immediately facilitate humanitarian relief.\"  Suspected cholera cases nationwide have declined from a peak of about 50 000 weekly cases at the end of June 2017 - but that drop stalled 3 weeks ago. Levels now remain at about 35 000 new cases every week.  In the last 4 months, there have been more than 591 100 suspected cases of cholera and 2035 deaths, according to WHO figures from Wed 30 Aug 2017.  \nChildren make up an increasing proportion of both suspected cases and deaths - representing 54 percent of cholera infections and nearly a 3rd of all deaths.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  Although a number of sources have reported decreasing numbers of daily cases, the numbers seem to support the continuing robust number of daily cases. If the epidemic were to continue at the current rate of cases per day, by the end of 2017, there could be 700 000 more cases for a total of 1.12 million cases since the end of April 2017, with 3300 more deaths for a total of about 5500 deaths over that period. With the continue hostilities in Yemen and the onset of the rainy season, whatever is being reported as a decrease in cases will likely and perhaps dramatically reversed. In the last month August 2017, there has been reported to have been 171 296 cases, 5710 new cases of cholera PER DAY.  The statistics related to this record-breaking epidemic of _Vibrio cholerae_ infection in Yemen are shown below:  Date (2017) / Cases / Deaths 8 May / 1360 / 25 11 May / 2752 / 51 13 May / 8595 / 115 14 May / 11 000 / 180 17 May / 17 200 / 209 19 May / 23 500 / 242 21 May / 29 300 / 315 22 May / 35 217 / 361 24 May / 42 207 / 420 27 May / 51 832 / 471 30 May / 65 300 / 532 2 Jun / 73 700 / 605 4 Jun / 86 400 / 676 5 Jun / 91 400 / 728 6 Jun / 96 000 / 746 7 Jun / 101 820 / 789 10 Jun / 116 700 / 869 12 Jun / 124 002 / 923 14 Jun / 140 116 / 989 16 Jun / 151 000 / 1054 19 Jun / 166 976 / 1146 21 Jun / 179 548 / 1205 23 Jun / 200 000 / 1310 26 Jun / 219 000 / 1400 28 Jun / 231 364 / 1439 30 Jun / 240 000 / 1500 4 Jul / 275 987 / 1634 7 Jul / 297 438 / 1706 10 Jul / 313 538 / 1732 13 Jul / 332 600 / 1759 17 Jul / 356 591 / 1802 20 Jul / 368 207 / 1828 25 Jul / 402 484 / 1880 26 Jul / 408 583 / 1885 29 Jul / 419 804 / 1912 7 Aug / 463 000 / 1940 13 Aug / 494 000 / 1966 17 Aug / 527 000 / 1997 20 Aug / 542 278 / 2003 25 Aug / 565 041 / 2018 30 Aug / 591 100 / 2035  In the last complete year of data (2015); (http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/250142/1/WER9138.pdf), WHO reported a total of 172 454 cases worldwide in 42 countries. This continuing, record-breaking cholera disaster in Yemen is only a little over 12-weeks-old and is almost 3.5 times the total number of cases of 2015 and 74 percent more than the peak year of the Haiti outbreak (2011) of 340 311 cases. - Mod.LL  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/126).  ","keywordsMatched":[]}},"Zambia":{"4":{"title":"Trypanosomiasis - Germany: ex Zambia ","date":["16","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Trypanosomiasis - Germany: ex Zambia [EXTERNAL]","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 16 Aug 2017. From: Timo Wolf (timo.wolf@kgu.de) (edited)   A German resident developed a febrile illness on Sun 13 Aug 2017. She also noticed an eschar on the left thigh on the same day.  She had returned from Zambia on Wed 9 Aug 2017. The last 7 days before the return flight were spent in the South Luangwa National Park (northern aspect), together with her husband. They went on game tours and described the area as being very wet due to a comparatively heavy rain season. She recalled several bites by tsetse flies during the time spent there.  She presented to the Frankfurt University hospital emergency department on 16 Aug 2017 and blood was immediately taken and examined for parasites. Trypanosomes could be seen in a QBC microscopy and a thin film. Treatment with suramin was initiated and the case was brought to the attention of the WHO.  The patient is suffering from human African trypanosomiasis (HAT), East African form. Her symptoms consisted of fever, headache, muscle aches and a very notable eschar. The patient had a remarkable pancytopenia initially.  According the WHO, 8 cases of HAT were reported in Zambia in 2015 ((http://apps.who.int/gho/data/node.main.A1637)). In 2015, a case of HAT was reported in a Canadian tourist who had also visited South Luangwa National Park ((http://www.promedmail.org/post/http://promedmail.org/post/20150904.3625005)).  Another 3 cases were described on ProMED-mail in 2010, all of which had visited South Luangwa NP http://promedmail.org/post/20101111.4093, http://promedmail.org/post/20101022.3833, and http://promedmail.org/post/20100915.3338  HAT is repeatedly affecting travelers to the African subcontinent, when they are exposed to tsetse flies. Clinically, an eschar can be an important clue to the diagnosis.   Professor Dr Timo Wolf \nProfessor Gudrun Just-Nuebling Frankfurt University Hospital Infectious Diseases Group Frankfurt Germany (timo.wolf@kgu.de)  ProMED-mail thanks professors Wolf and Just-Nuebling for this communication.  Zambia is endemic for African trypanosomiasis caused by _Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense_. A map of areas in Zambia where there is trypanosomiasis can be found at (http://www.who.int/trypanosomiasis_african/country/Zambia_whole_1014.jpg).  An update of the distribution up to 2014 was recently published: \"Franco JR et al. Monitoring the elimination of human African trypanosomiasis: Update to 2014. PLoS Negl Trop Dis 2017; 11(5): e0005585; (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5456402/).  Overall, the incidence in humans has been declining over the past decade, and a list of all countries affected with either _T. rhodesiense_ or _T. gambiense_ is found at (http://www.who.int/trypanosomiasis_african/country/foci_AFRO/en/).  The case illustrates that not all patients returning with fever from Africa have malaria and the availability of qualified microscopy service is important. - Mod.EP  A HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/170). Date: Wed 16 Aug 2017. Source: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly disease information 2017; 30(33) (edited) (http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24570)   Foot-and-mouth disease, Zimbabwe  Information received on and dated 16 Aug 2017 from Dr Unesu Hildah Ushewokunze-Obatolu, principal director, Department of Livestock and Veterinary Services, Harare, Zimbabwe  Summary Report type: immediate notification Date of start of the event: 21 Jul 2017 Date of confirmation of the event: 25 Jul 2017 Reason for notification: recurrence of a listed disease Date of previous occurrence: 14 Oct 2016 Manifestation of disease: clinical disease Causal agent: Foot and mouth disease virus Serotype: not typed Nature of diagnosis: clinical, laboratory (basic) This event pertains to a defined zone within the country.  New outbreaks (11) Outbreak 1: Davata, Chiredzi, Masvingo Date of start of the outbreak: 21 Jul 2017 Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: village Affected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / 1341 / 176 / 0 / 0 / 0 Affected population: cattle of varying age groups sharing the same watering and grazing points. Outbreak 10: Chipfugwana, Chiredzi, Masvingo Date of start of the outbreak: 10 Aug 2017 Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: village Affected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / 1047 / 127 / 0 / 0 / 0 Affected population: cattle of varying age groups sharing the same watering and grazing points.  Outbreak 11: Mwambe, Mwenezi, Masvingo Date of start of the outbreak: 16 Aug 2017 Outbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided) Epidemiological unit: village Affected animals: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / 1047 / 127 / 0 / 0 / 0 Affected population: cattle of varying age groups sharing the same watering and grazing points  Summary of outbreaks Total outbreaks: 11 Total animals affected: Species / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered Cattle / 14967 / 1094 / 49 / 0 / 0 Outbreak statistics rates apparent, expressed as percentages: Species / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost* Cattle / 7.31 / 0.33 / 4.48 / 0.33 *Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction, and / or slaughter  Epidemiology Source of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: contact with infected animals(s) at grazing/watering, contact with wild species Epidemiological comments: the outbreaks are occurring in FMD vaccination zones of the south-eastern lowveld which lies close to a national park (Gonarezhou) and wildlife conservancies. Routine vaccinations in these areas are now long overdue. Mixing of cattle and buffaloes is being exacerbated by the shortage of grazing pastures. All the infected districts have been placed under quarantine with veterinary check-points also manned by police personnel placed at strategic areas to prevent cattle movement. Inspections and community education campaigns are currently on-going.  Control measures Measures applied: movement control inside the country, vaccination in response to the outbreak(s), surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone, surveillance within containment and/or protection zone, traceability, quarantine, control of wildlife reservoirs, zoning, no treatment of affected animals Measures to be applied: no other measures  Diagnostic test results Laboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result Central Veterinary Laboratory (national laboratory) / Cattle / antibody detection ELISA / 25 Jul 2017 / Positive Botswana Vaccine Institute (OIE reference laboratory) / Cattle / virus isolation / Pending Future reporting The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.  The location of the outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in the OIE report at the source URL above.   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  According to the Zimbabwe page on the WRLFMD World Reference Laboratory for Foot-and-Mouth Disease website at (http://www.wrlfmd.org/fmd_genotyping/africa/zim.htm), the following serotypes have been recorded there throughout the years: FMDV-SAT 1 (livestock): 1937, 1953, 1957-1962, 1966, 1972, 1976, 1978-1981, 1989, 1999, 2003-2004, 2015 FMDV-SAT 1 (buffalo): 1988, 1990-1998 FMDV-SAT 2 (livestock): 1931, 1950, 1951-1955, 1957-1962, 1964-1967, 1970-1973, 1975-1981, 1983, 1987, 1989, 1990 (carrier cattle only), 1991, 1997, 2000-2004, 2009-2011, 2013-2015 FMDV-SAT 2 (buffalo): 1988-1991, 1994-1995, 1997-1998 FMDV-SAT 3 (livestock): 1934, 1953-1954, 1974-1978, 1981, 1983-1984, 1991, 1999, 2013 FMDV-SAT 3 (buffalo): 1990-1991, 1994  All 3 SAT types are endemic in the African buffalo population.  See maps of Zimbabwe at (http://www.nationsonline.org/oneworld/map/zimbabwe_map.htm) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/171). - Mod.CRD  ","keywordsMatched":[]},"301":{"title":"Anthrax - Zimbabwe (07): (MN) human, wildlife, contained","date":["20","Aug","2017"],"url":"promedPRO/AH/EDR> Anthrax - Zimbabwe (07): (MN) human, wildlife, contained","summary":" A ProMED-mail post (http://www.promedmail.org) ProMED-mail is a program of the International Society for Infectious Diseases (http://www.isid.org) . Date: Wed 6 Sep 2017. Source: AllAfrica, The Herald report (edited) (http://allafrica.com/stories/201709060179.html)   The country has contained an anthrax outbreak that killed one person and infected 56 in April this year 2017, when villagers in Binga Matabeleland North ate meat from infected dead hippos. According to the Ministry of Health and Child Care, no new cases of anthrax have been reported since June 2017. \"The Ministry of Health and Child Care weekly disease surveillance report revealed that no new suspected cases of anthrax were reported during the week ending 20 Aug 2017,\" reads the report.  \"The cumulative figures for anthrax are 57 cases and one death.\" Anthrax is a life-threatening infectious disease caused by bacteria that normally affects animals.  Anthrax-infected hippos started dying from 27 Mar 2017 and some people ate meat from their carcasses after they were found dead in Binga's Mlibizi area.  Chief Saba of Binga had urged the Government to help urgently contain the anthrax outbreak which killed one person and 16 hippos in his area. He said many people including his family ate meat from the dead hippos.  Byline: Thandeka Moyo   <br><br>Communicated by: ProMED-mail. (promed@promedmail.org)  There is no mention of further wildlife deaths so I think we can presume that Mr Moyo's claim of containment refers only to the human cases. Interestingly, the previous report (11 May 2017 Anthrax - Zimbabwe (06): (MN) human, wildlife http://promedmail.org/post/20170511.5028820) referred to 2 human deaths, 21 hippos dying (not 16), plus 2 young crocodiles. The absence of any comments on the specifics of wildlife losses probably comes about from reliance being placed on the update report from the Ministry of Health and Child Care.  Maps of Zimbabwe can be seen at (http://www.un.org/Depts/Cartographic/map/profile/zimbabwe.pdf) and (http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2956). For a description of Matabeleland North on the western border of Zimbabwe with Zambia, go to (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matabeleland_North_Province). Binga district lies along the border with Zimbabwe and the Zambezi River valley; see (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binga_District). It can be seen on the map at (http://tinyurl.com/kkn6l9s). - Mod.MHJ  ","keywordsMatched":[]}}}
